Soft shirt, fits a little large, but it looks decent and isn't too thick/heavy. If you're looking for a nice, simple, comfy Hawaiian shirt, this is a good option!

Instead of knocking over the entire pile of Melissa & Doug puzzles every time our child wanted to play with one in particular, we though we'd purchase this rack for the puzzles and store them in it for easier access to any puzzle at any time.It's really a mixed bagâ€”it's hard to get puzzles in and out of some of the slots, though once they're all in, they look neatly organized. A toddler will likely get frustrated, though, trying to get puzzles in and out of the rack... and in the end, they'll all end up spilled out on the floor anyways!One other note: 'sound' puzzles (which are slightly thicker than the normal M&D wood puzzles) will NOT fit in most slots in the rack. So we had to set our sound puzzles elsewhere, which is also annoying.All in all, I wouldn't buy again unless I just wanted a semi-permanent rack to organize the puzzles. Too much hassle for the very slight convenience of being able to pull out a puzzle from the bottom more easily.

I've carried a small external USB battery pack with me for the past few years, ever since I started relying on my iPhone as my only camera, phone, reading device, and emergency-backup-Internet device. And there have been many times where I would've been up a creek (or more literally, lost in the middle of an unfamiliar city!) without it.But the little battery pack I tote around is only really for emergenciesâ€”it can barely top off my iPhone when the phone is already at 50% capacity, and if the iPhone gets below 10%, it'll struggle to even maintain the current charge if I have to use the iPhone while charging!Enter the modern 10000+ mAh external battery pack. For review purposes, I was given a Intocircuit® Power Castle 15000mAh 4.8A Dual USB External Battery Portable Charger with Built-in Flashlight (say that three times, fast!). This battery pack provides two USB ports, both of which are capable of charging any modern device at a decent clip with up to 2.4A of power draw per port. My iPhone and iPad both got two full charges before the unit itself needed a recharge, and when using it only with one iPhone 6, I could get between three to five full charges, depending on how much I used the iPhone on a given day.If used conservatively, you could keep a phone going full-tilt for an entire week without any external power access at all!Intocircuit Power Castle - PortsSome of the nice features of this charger:- The LCD on the front gives all the information you need at a glanceâ€”mainly the big "X%" charge indicator, that goes up while you charge the unit, and down while you pull charge from the unit. It's easy to see how much charge remains, and the screen is responsive when you plug in a device to charge it or press the 'ON/OFF' button to quickly check remaining capacity.- It's gimmicky, but the LED flashlight did come in handy once or twice. Just double-click the 'ON/OFF' button to activate. It's not too bright, but it's good enough for finding your way in the dark if need be.- The hardware fits together pretty well, and all cables, plugs, ports, etc. feel solid enough to last a few years. It's not Apple-quality, but the thing doesn't cost as much as something similar from Apple would cost, either!Some things I didn't like (but for the price, I'm willing to accept without too much judgement):- It takes a very long time to charge the unit itself; even if you have a 2A+ wall wart to charge the unit, it will take many, many hours to go from 0% to 100%. Typically not a huge deal, but when I'm on longer trips, I don't always have a full day I can let the unit sit and charge somewhere.- The front of the device looks pretty nice, almost elegant, in fact, but is marred by the cheesy 'Intocircuit' logo. Not a major flaw, but sometimes it's the little things...As another fun test, I even plugged in two Raspberry Pi model 2 computers to the Intocircuit, and under light load (they were both running webservers for utilitarian purposes), they ran for over a day with some charge left in the Power Castle!Overall, this is one of the best and most capable battery packs I've used. The LED is mostly a gimmick, but the main purpose of the deviceâ€”charging and recharging your mobile devices over and over without needing a wall plugâ€”is achieved in spades. I would definitely recommend this to anyone who needs to go on long trips, especially when power is a precious commodity!

I use these giant air filters in place of an old electronic filter that is no longer in use in my home HVAC system. They fit the system perfectly, and on Amazon, in this multi-pack, they're a great deal cheaper than the $30-per filters at the local hardware store.I can generally leave in a filter for 3 months without any particular issues. When I take them out, there is only a small amount of dust deposited on the intake side, and the airflow is still great.

I have wanted to replace 6 halogen 75W R20L bulbs with LEDs for the past few years; every time I turned on the track light with all those ~500W energy-wasting bulbs, I cringed.After trying a few different dimmable LED R20 and R30 replacements, I settled on these Philips bulbs. They are a pretty decent replacement, and they definitely use less power/generate less heat (my main concern), but there are a few caveats to those going from incandescent/halogen to this generation of LED:1. There is no color temperature shift when dimming the bulbs; with halogens, you could get a nice, warm, fire-like glow if you dimmed them down a bitâ€”the color temperature would shift when the bulbs were dimmer. With these, they stick to about 2700K all the way up and down their brightness range. I'm used to it now, but it was strangely disconcerting at first.2. If you use a standard old incandescent dimmer, be prepared for flickers and other weird behavior. My solution was to buy a modern LED-specific dimmer, which uses a digital circuit to make the dimming and on/off a lot smoother, and prevents weird flickering issues.3. These bulbs, while better than most other LED bulbs I've tried, still have a slightly more defined 'spot' feel to them than my old halogen bulbs. The halogen bulbs would wash the entire wall with some light, with a smooth blend of light to dark on the border of the spot. These bulbs are close, but if you're looking for it, you can see the 'LED spot' for each bulb. Not a big deal, and these are way better than most, but just something to be aware of.These bulbs aren't the perfect incandescent/halogen replacement, but they're close enough to make it worth it to me, for the power and heat savings.

I was given the iClever 6-port USB charging station pictured below so I could review the device on this site and on Amazon.com. I'm no stranger to beefy multi-port USB chargers; I now own three of the things, and use them for charging many devices at night, powering a cluster of six Raspberry Pi computers, and charging USB battery packs for long trips (it's great to not have to worry about finding an outlet for two or three days at a time while on vacation!).I like two things about this particular charging station that are improvements over many of the other solutions (besides the fact that it's priced at about $25, which makes it one of the most inexpensive chargers!):1. All the ports are 2.4A, meaning I don't have to care what port I plug what device intoâ€”all six ports can charge up even my most power-hungry device (e.g. an iPad with retina display) just as fast as the others. Many inexpensive multi-port chargers have some low-power ports, meaning I have to look at the device to figure out into which port I can plug in certain devicesâ€”not so with iClever!2. The hardware itself is unassuming and small. This is a charger. It shouldn't try to look sleek, stylish, or at home on my desktop. I want utilitarian, I want it to stay put, and I want it to look simple and functional. It excels in all these aspects, and I have now stuck it on the underside of my desk so I can just plug and unplug devices all day long.This iClever charging station is now my favorite, and for most people who need to charge and/or power more than two or three devices at a time, I highly recommend it. Charging two batteries, two iPhones, an iPad, and a Raspberry Pi didn't produce any noticeable heat on the device, and everything charged as quickly as possible, with no weird power blips that would affect the running of the Raspberry Pi.

I bought one of these bulbs to compare against some 75w Halogen PAR30 bulbs, an LED R20, and another LED PAR30 bulb. For less than ten bucks, it's a no-brainer for certain applications!This light was by far the 'coldest' 3000K bulb I tested. It's CRI is rated 82, and it does seem to put out some good quality lightâ€”not quite 'blue' like a daylight bulb, but not very warm at all. While dimming, the color didn't change at allâ€”just the brightness (both a good and bad thing, depending on your desired use!). Halogens obviously run much more yellow (especially as they're dimmed), and the other 2700K and 3000K LED bulbs I tested were somewhere in-between.This light made no noise whatsoever when dimmed or at full brightness, and worked great with a newish Lutron dimmer in a nice track lighting system. It's a bit more 'spotlighty' than some of the other LEDs, but it actually had the same spread/brightness as the halogens I was replacing (a narrower bright spot in the middle, maybe 30 degrees or so, with a slightly dimmer spot out to 40 degrees or so).Definitely worth trying out if you are okay with a little colder color temperature. For one room, I need a warmer, dimmer light, so I went with some 2700K Philips R20 LED bulbs instead. For an office or public/daytime space, I'd go with these bulbs in a heartbeat. Great price, runs cool, and dims pretty well (not as good as halogen/incandescent, but as good as most modern LED bulbs).

I bought a set of these to wire up to a set of six Raspberry Pis (a 'Bramble'/cluster), and I'm using them to indicate server status using different colors. You can use PWM to set any color you'd like, or even to fade LEDs if you'd like.I also have one wired up to an Arduino for a temperature indication project as well. They all worked great, didn't include any resistors (like the picture shows), even though the printed card with the LEDs said resistors were included. No big deal; I have a box of spare resistors :)Wiring these up, make sure you have a resistor on each color legâ€”so 3 resistors per LED!

You can really never have enough blanks; I have about 12 4-gang Panduit Mini-Com wall plates throughout my house, and most of them just have one network jack and three empty slots (for future expansion). These snap-in blanks fit the blank slots perfectly, and the ivory matches the ivory wall plates perfectly.Buy an extra bag or twoâ€”you'll need them!

The case was a little tricky to put onto the Pi, and required a few minutes' work peeling off the protective coverings on each layer. However, once that was done, the A+ was a lot nicer to work with (especially with the included rubber feet), and all my accessories could easily plug in as before. I like this case since it's very minimal, has decent markings for everything (including a handy reference for the GPIOs!), and makes me less nervous about touching the Pi while it's in operation.Highly recommended, and have bought a couple more since trying the first one!

I originally had a bunch of Cat5 drops terminated straight into plugs, and plugged them into the back of my gigabit ethernet switch. This worked fine, but made the setup look a little ugly, and also made changing the network setup a little annoying. I bought this patch panel so I could terminate the existing five rooms, and have some room for future expansion (in the basement and some other rooms).The patch panel looks great, and has a large mounting bracket that allows all the cables to enter from behind neatly. The punch-down terminals are well-labeled for each jack, and if you have a typical krone-style punchdown tool (Amazon sells one for $5 or so), terminating all the connections is a quick affair.The panel's metal edges are a little sharp, so make sure you don't snag a corner on your clothing (or your skin!), but other than that, there's really nothing not to like here. The price is great, and it looks and works flawlessly.

I mount a 23" monitor on the wall for my standing desk workstation, and I have had trouble in the past with other cables that stick straight out of the back of the monitor; because of the tight clearance with my mount, I've had to bend the cables pretty severely, meaning they get kinked, and over time, the signal goes away.I was looking for a 90° cable, and finally settled on this one; all the connections are solid, the elbow connector (which I have plugged into the back of my monitor) fits snugly, and gives me an extra inch of clearance (so I can tilt my monitor without smashing the cable), and the signal has been perfect so far.The only real complaint I have is that the monitor is very thick; twice as thick as almost all the other DVI cables I have. I'm hoping the thickness results in longevity, but I'd rather buy a new cable every three years and not have to deal with the cable's inflexibility when I try routing it behind my desk! It's only a minor complaint, so I'm still giving the cable four starsâ€”it's a good value for the price.

I needed to expand a door handle opening in a metal door, and was dreading trying to do it with a dremel tool and/or a hand file. My Dad suggested I purchase one of these and give it a try. I bought this attachment and the RCT-10 Saw Adapter, and went to down on the opening. After about 5 minutes of careful filing, the hole was just the right size for a new, larger handle.If you don't have a *very* firm grip on your reciprocating saw, you'll probably find it wandering off. Also, make sure you file at angles and with pressure so the file doesn't hit the thing you're working on and put a nice dent or scratch in it if it gets out of control (I learned this the hard way, and had to do a little touch-up painting!It's not the best file I've used (a good hand file will do wonders, and allows great precision), but it works well enough, and makes a difficult job much easier.

I replaced the water panel every year since moving into a home with a Aprilaire model 600 installed. The first couple of years, relative humidity levels would stay constant around 30-35%, even on the coldest, dryest days of the year. This winter, however, relative humidity levels in my home have been as low as 23%, causing myriad problems: cracking and bleeding skin, bloody noses, and enough static to break one of our TV remotes when I picked it up from a microfiber couch!I bought this repair kit as a last resort; I was considering purchasing a new steam humidification system for a much higher price, but figured if this repair kit could get the humidifier back to a working state, I'd be happy with the $40 I spent.The kit came in a rather large, roomy box, and included every internal part of the humidifier; the frame, the water spreading tray, the hose, the drain hose adapter, and even an extra humidifer manual! Installation of all the new parts took maybe five minutes, and within a day, the relative humidity level was back up to 31%.So far, it's been a week since replacing the guts of my Aprilaire 600, and I'm very happy with the results (plus, I now have an extra frame I can clean out and swap in next winter if the need arises! I'll report back after winter's over with any more relevant details.

One major complaint I've had with almost all silicone/semi-rigid iPhone cases is that, once you get your phone into them, you feel like you have to break your phone to get it back out.This case has just enough flex in it to get your phone out with just a little bit of fidgeting, but enough rigidity to make me feel safe dropping my phone (which I've done many times... thus the case!).I wish it were maybe $5-10 cheaper, but it's priced well compared to other cases of similar quality.

I've used a variety of saucepans, and usually go through one every two years or so. Most of the non-stick or cheaper pans I had used in the past seemed to slowly warp after a year or so (causing less even heating), and the interior surface would get scratches and not inspire confidence that my food was remaining uncontaminated.I now own two of these stainless saucepans, and they're both holding up great after almost two years. One time, my wife accidentally steamed some apples for much too long (all the water had evaporated), and then the apples were burnt to a crisp on the bottom of the pan. It looked dire, but after two scrubbings, some baking soda, and one more scrubbing, the bottom of the pan was spotless again.The pouring spout and strainer lid are just added bonuses. I don't usually use them (since I do pastas in a larger pan), but the few times I have used them (for single servings, usually), they worked great and helped me avoid using (and having to wash) a strainer.They work great, and I would buy another!

I have a standing desk at home, and another at work. At home, the standing desk is in a nice, plushly-carpeted area, so I have no problem standing in that area all day. At work, though, the desk is in an area with industrial, short-pile carpet, which feels almost like standing on concrete.This mat helps my feet feel slightly nicer at the end of the day, and as long as you use it on a hard surface or short, tough carpet, it won't move easily (at work, it slides maybe a half inch a day, but I just kick it back into place once it gets off center).The only thing that could make it better is maybe an extra few mm of padding, just to give a tiny bit more comfort. All in all, it's a good price for a good mat, and it arrived in perfect condition (even though it was in a pretty large box)!

I've done a lot of networking work in my home and in small businesses, and I'm used to creating my own patch cables. However, I only have bulk grey cable, and in one part of my home, I wanted to have a nice-looking network panel on the wall with all-black networking equipment, and cabling to match. These strain-relief connectors and black cables (I bought the 1' 5-pack) look and work perfectly.I would buy them again if I need to add more than 5 wired connections in my house! Saved me about 30 minutes making all the short cables, and they look better to boot!

For a wireless button that pairs with a wireless doorbell chime, a ten-dollar price tag isn't asking too much. I have a Honeywell wireless doorbell, which came with one chime, and that chime has not needed a battery change yet (after 1 year), and still looks and functions great.I wanted another chime for the back door, and this one worked perfectly; I just held down the pairing button on the chime until the second doorbell light was flashing, then pressed the button on this new chime, and it was paired. Couldn't be easier.I used a cordless drill and a drill bit to mount the button on the door frame permanently, but the sticky tape would hold for a few years at least, too, if I had wanted to save two minutes installing the button.

Elsewhere on Amazon, you have to pay two dollars *more* than this package to get six rolls of Scotch tapeâ€”without the tape dispenser! This price is about as good as you can get for six rolls of tape, and it comes with a nice Scotch weighted tape dispenser (the kind you can leave on a surface and use without two hands.Note that this dispenser is slightly narrower, and the spindle is a tiny bit smaller, than older tape dispensers. It's not a big deal at all, but it does feel ever-so-slightly less luxurious. Still vastly better than a cheap plastic dispenser.Scotch tape is my favorite; it is relatively strong, has good adhesion, works on almost any surface (especially hard surfaces), and is nearly invisible. Just don't leave it in place for a really long time (it gets gummed to the surface), use it with anything damp or wet, or use it with cardboard, and you'll be find.

This steamer works well when steaming many different friends and vegetables, and fits a few cups' worth of veggies at a time. The expanding/collapsing 'leaves' allow for many different pot sizes, and they open and close pretty easily.Two caveats, though:1. A few of the metal leaves have become finicky, requiring some extra work to get them to fold up with the rest of the leaves again. The way they're connected just uses tension and a little bent metal clip, and it's not extremely durable.2. The center post, with a keychain-ring sized ring on the top, is used to pick up the steamer; it gets really hot, and is also a little short, so to pull the steamer out, I usually end up using the handle of a wood spoon or something similar to slip it in the loop and carefully pull the steamer out of the pot.It's a good steamer overall, and worth the price I paid; the stainless steel shows no signs of rust after a year of use, and it hasn't broken (besides me having to put a leaf back on after it fell off a couple times).

I was looking for a similar cable at local stores like Best Buy and Micro Center, but couldn't find any; the only 3.0 cables they had were either extension cables or A to B; none were A to micro+power, like this one.This cable allowed me to use my new USB 3.0 hard drive with my computer at work, since my hub is a few feet away from where I needed to put my hard drive, and the drive only came with a 1' cable.The cable looks a little chunky and ugly, but since it's out of sight, it's not a big deal. The dimensions are correct, and plugging and unplugging is as easy as any other cable I've used.

I inherited a Febco 765-1 backflow preventer along with a decent in-ground irrigation system at my house. Unfortunately, the backflow preventer acted as a geyser whenever I turned on water to it from inside the house. After removing the cover, I noticed the plastic body had snapped right in half, requiring replacement.This replacement part is an exact match for the OEM part from Febco (as far as I can tell), but is a bit cheaper. And 1/4 the price of an entire replacement backflow preventer!To remove the old part, I just grabbed a screwdriver and wedged it into the remaining plastic bits, and carefully unscrewed all the old parts. Then I cleaned off the inside with a little alcohol and water, and hand-tightened the new kit in place.Pop on the metal 'bell' cover on top, and you're done! Turning the backflow preventer back on requires a bit of wet fun, since you have to open some valves, build pressure, then close valves, with water squirting out all over the place!I've had the new part installed for three months with pretty high house-side pressure (measured at 85 psi), and I haven't had any leaks or problems!

I read the first two Making of Star Wars books by J.W. Rinzler within months of their being published. Both were engrossing works of art containing many rarely-seen photos and anecdotes from cast and crew from Star Wars.Just like the first two books, this book gave so much detail and life to what used to be my favorite movie of the original trilogy, and made me want to watch the entire original trilogy again. Everything from set design to sound design and the soundtrack is explored and related in incredible detail, from pre-production to post-release.Unlike most other 'coffee table' books of similar girth, these books will have any serious Star Wars fan devouring every word, cover-to-cover--you can't repel a book of this magnitude!There are only two complaints I have about this book:1. The text is very small, and the pages are glossy--meaning it can be slightly difficult to read in some light.2. It's the last Making of Star Wars book for the original trilogy. Somehow I don't think reading about Jar-Jar's floppy ears will ever be as enthralling as reading about the countless hours Anthony Daniels and Peter Mayhew spent in their iconic costumes.If you love Star Wars, this book is worth every penny.

I bought two of these; one for my desk and one for my bag. I've never had a connection issue with either one, and they're about as small as I've seen USB NICs.The only limitation with this USB adapter is that it's USB 2.0, and maxes out at 100 mbps. I wish it were USB 3.0 so it could make better use of my gigabit network's bandwidth. For 99% of my usage, though, I don't saturate the bandwidth, so it's not a big issue.There's a more expensive Thunderbolt adapter that supports gigabit networking, but I don't want to waste my MacBook Air's only TB port with that adapter.

I bought these edge guards to stick to our sharp fireplace brick facade after seeing them installed at a friend's house. The pads are nice, thick foam, and they feel soft and don't look too bad (imo).The included 3M double-sided tape works great if you're sticking these pads to a hard, non-porous surface like glass, wood, or tile. But if, like me, you try sticking the tape to brick, the tape doesn't hold up too well.I've been able to mount the edge guards using the following method:  1. Screw masonry screws through a piece of velcro into some grout, every 6" or so.  2. Stick a piece of velcro along the edge guard's inside.  3. Stick the edge guards to the screwed-in velcro strips.I'm using a small masonry screw, and the holes that remain are pretty small, so I can patch them up when my children are old enough to not bang their heads on the fireplace corners. But to do this, you need some extra screws, some industrial-strength velcro, and a hammer drill.Ease of installation gets 2/5 stars, but in every other regard, these edge guards are pretty good.

Along with the stacking ring toy, and maybe Sophie the Giraffe, there are few toys I see in as many houses with babies as these squishy teething rings.Some babies seem to enjoy gnawing on them endlessly, while others (like my own baby boy) likes to hold it, bite it, then throw it off to the side. I give this product a definite five stars for how durable it is, and how easy it is to clean, but four stars for its general utility. If your baby doesn't like it (like mine doesn't), it's almost pointless to have.I still like that I can chill it in the fridge and help my baby get a little cooling action on his gums during times when I can tell a new tooth is cutting in and giving him pain, but this toy is usually sitting in the back of the fridge.

For $9.99, this is a rock-solid adapter that allows you to use any old-style MagSafe power adapter (from the original MagSafe MacBook Pro adapter to the 2011 MacBook Air/Pro adapters) with newer MacBooks (which have a thinner connector).It's a bit of a necessary evil, since the power adapter had to slim down to fit more easily with Apple's ever-thinner laptops. But it works well and doesn't feel like it will ever break.The one gripe I have is that, if you need to use it only sometimes (say, you have an older MacBook and a newer one, and you switch between the two), it's a little clumsy to pop the adapter on and off (it almost always requires two hands). Plus, it's so small it could easily get lost if you don't keep it attached to the power cable.

Removing lug nuts or other bolts on a car can be very stressful when you only have a little 8" ratchet wrench. Not wanting to sacrifice mine, I bought this breaker bar, and am not worried about putting my full body weight down on the bar to pop a bolt loose.Even if your local auto shop decides to tighten every bolt to 100+ ft-lbs pressure with an impact wrench, you'll be able to budge them loose with this breaker bar. If you need even more pressure, slip a piece of metal pipe over the end, and you'll get way more leverage.I just wish there were a good 16" or 18" breaker bar available on Amazon; 12" is almost too small for some bolts!

This is a very nice and sturdy storage system for the price. You can find some better name-brand systems for double the price (or more), but this rack system will hold up to many years of use as long as it's installed properly.Make sure you have a standard-thickness door, and it's wide enough to hold this system, and you'll be set to go.Installation is pretty easy, though it took a little pressure to pop some of the shelves into the vertical hangers. Make sure you use the included plastic clips and long screws to securely attach the vertical hangers to the door--and do this *after* you've installed everything and have it in the position you want it.Once installed, pantry door swings a little more slowly (since we have about 20 more pounds of stuff on the door!), but it closes fine, and the storage rack doesn't swing around or bang on the door, since it's screwed down with the six included plastic straps.

This is the exact same sensor as was included in the Honeywell L5100PK - LYNX Touch security system I purchased from Amazon. I use a few of these around the house in rooms that are unoccupied at night, for extra peace of mind (in addition to door/window/glassbreak sensors on all perimeter doors and windows).The sensor seems to work very well, and covers a broad area, so I can have one sensor cover practically an entire large family room without worrying about dead zones. I don't have any pets, so I can't test the ability to not detect small pets, but I do know I was not able to fool the sensor during a walk test.Note that the sensor seems to not come with mounting screws; you'll need two #6 screws to mount this to a wall. You can mount it flush or in a corner.

Since bringing our baby boy home from the hospital, we've tried a variety of pacifiers, to see which ones (if any) he would like; the Philips AVENT Soothie Pacifiers were great for the first 2-3 weeks, but after that, they ended up being spat out almost constantly. So we bought these, a generic brand, and a pack of Dr. Brown's PreVent Design Pacifiers, and noticed that these were the only pacifiers our son seemed to keep in his mouth.The other brands, he just gnawed on them a bit, then spat them out and started crying. These pacifiers are large enough to not be a choking hazard, but discreet enough that his nose never touches the pacifier. Additionally, cleaning is easy; just run the thing under hot water, or boil them if you need to sanitize.Each pacifier comes with a durable and securely-fitting clear plastic cover. For someone who's not a germaphobe, but would rather not toss a pacifier just anywhere, these covers provide peace of mind. Most other manufacturers only provide one cover per two pacifiers, or no cover at all!

This iPhone dock (which looks much different than the current pictures on the product page; see my customer pictures to see how it actually looks) is so-so. I wasn't expecting too much for $15, but I wish it were a little better in a few ways: - The plug in the base is slightly thick for the iPhone, so you have to push the iPhone down pretty hard. - Because of this, removing the iPhone is a definite two-hand operation. - The dock is pretty substantial (about 1/2" wider than the iPhone). - The rubbery bottom is not very grippy, so the dock slides around my wood table easily.However, it does hold the iPhone upright, and has a built-in lightning plug, so you don't have to sacrifice a cable and install it in the base of the dock or anything.I think if the tolerances for the plug were just a little better, this would be a great deal. As it is, I'm only giving three stars. YMMV.

This mic screen fits perfectly on a Shure SM58, PG48, and most other standard varieties of mics with a 'ball' on the end. It is simple to slide over the end of the mic, and only adds a little more bulk.It definitely muffles sound a little (not so much as to make it unusable), so don't use this if you just need simple pop filtering and are recording in a controlled, indoor environment (like a stage or studio)--in those situations, just get a real pop filter/screen or a better windscreen.This windscreen is great for situations like field reporting or recording while outdoors or in places where you don't have control over the environment, and there may be moving air (ever been stuck right next to an air vent at an event?).Overall, well worth the price to have a couple of these laying around, but not the highest quality windscreen I've used.

These magnets and spacers are the exact same as the ones you get with a Honeywell 5816 Wireless Transmitter.Screws are included, as are spacers for each magnet.These things come in handy when you mount one of your magnets to a door or mechanism that moves in such a way as to completely destroy the magnet you just mounted. Always make sure you put the magnet in a place that has enough clearance throughout your door or window's full range of motion to prevent the magnet from being smashed!My only complaint is the price. I know these are a bit of a specialty item, but anything more than $10 seems excessive. Oh well.

I now have one of these on every external door of my house, as well as a few other internal doors (like the basement door) and a few windows.** In the Box **They're really easy to install, and they come in a box with a plastic mounting plate, a magnet and magnet spacer, the proper screws for mounting everything, some double-sided tape (which is okay for indoor use, but I'd rather use the screws!), and an A123 battery (see my picture above for an overview of all the included bits).** Quality and Installation **The design is pretty minimal, and fits in okay with the white door and window trim in my house. Honeywell also makes a 'slimline' version of this sensor that's much narrower--but also much more expensive!The sensor is easy to maintain--every couple of years (when a battery dies), just push in the tab on the bottom with your fingernail and pop off the front cover (your alarm system will start beeping at this point, since you're 'tampering' with the transmitter... ignore it and reset it when you're done). Pop out the old battery, put in a new one, then replace the cover. Nothing to it.** Function and Battery Life **These sensors use two Loops for sensing door/window open and close states: Loop 2 (most common) is used with a magnetic reed switch (magnet must be within an inch or so of the reed switch sensor), and Loop 4 lets you use a wired contact (installation is more difficult, and probably uncommon).As long as you have a flat surface on the door and on your door casing or wall within an inch or so of each other, you can just mount the magnet to the door, and the transmitter to the wall/door trim, and you're done!I installed my Honeywell L5100PK - LYNX Touch security system a few months ago, and haven't yet had a battery die. A few other people I know have a similar Lynx system, and nobody seems to have any complaints about battery life.** Recommendation **Buy enough of these to cover every entry/exit in your house, and you're set! Get the slimline version if you can afford it--otherwise, these things work great and are very reliable.

This cable is built very well; I now have three (one for the car, one for night stand, and one for carrying with me in my bag), and all three have worked perfectly, and still look like new, after more than a month.I just bought the third one from Amazon after I noticed the price (on Amazon only, it seems) is down to $15--that's about the same as the AmazonBasics USB A to Lightning Compatible Cable! If you need an extra lightning cable or two, buy them while the price is low. These Apple cables are nice and thin, and plug and unplug easily (unlike some third party cables).My only complaint is Apple's packaging for these cables--I wish Amazon could offer 'frustration-free' packaging, because it takes some effort to get the sticky cardboard insert off, and that's *after* using some force to open the box the cable comes in! Apple's usually very good about packaging, but it's obvious this box was designed for theft-deterrence and not a happy opening experience.

I have a variety of iPhone microphones and audio adapters that have fairly short cords, but require a TRRS connection. Normal TRS extension cables (like you'll find at RadioShack) don't work in this situation, so I was glad to find this cable on Amazon.It's cheap, it doesn't degrade the sound quality of a microphone or headphones, and it looks a lot nicer than many other cables and adapters that cost much more! Highly recommended if you need to extend your smartphone/iPhone's headset, or if you need to extend an smartphone/iPhone microphone's cable length.

This case fits any model of Raspberry Pi very well (with very close tolerances); for the model B, with it's RJ-45 plug and extra USB port, you need to use a screwdriver or pliers to pop off a couple little pieces of protective plastic.Putting it together is easy enough (just put the Pi in the bottom case, and cover it with the top case)--that is, until you screw in the four included metal screws! The screws don't go in very well--and I think it's because the plastic screw standoffs they go into are not pre-tapped. You can feel a ton of resistance the whole time you tighten the screw.I used a phillips #1 driver to carefully, slowly screw in the screws, and was able to screw them in without stripping the heads. Go slow, and hold onto the case tightly!Once the case is on, you don't have access to the GPIO pins, or the camera plug, but you can get to all the 'external' ports, and the LEDs shine through the indicators very clearly. I like the black case, because it's relatively discreet compared to the mostly clear/translucent cases found elsewhere.

I give these batteries five stars for the price and how they work (so far), but four for the packaging (not necessarily Energizer's fault). All the batteries were simply tossed into a plastic bag, and that bag was thrown into a box with the other Amazon products in my order.This isn't the end of the world, but it can definitely affect the battery life--especially if the batteries bounce around enough inside the box to hit something else and get damaged!The batteries fit my wireless security system sensors, and seem to last a while. None of them have gone dead yet, but I'd bet that not all of these batteries came with the same charge as a plastic-cased battery like I'd get at a retailer.

I donâ€™t have many USB Type-C devices yet, but when Apple released the new MacBook that charges and syncs data through a single USB Type-C port, that lead me to start looking into products that used USB Type-C. While USB Type-C is not a new cable format, it is becoming more mainstream with the inclusion of the cable type on computers like the MacBook. As a tech reviewer, you never want to be behind the times and since this is a technology that is emerging more and more, I really started to take notice and tried to figure out a way to start incorporating it into my current devices.This USB Type-C to USB 3.0 Adapter is a great solution to this problem. It makes it possible to continue using your current USB cables â€“ like standard Lightning cables, Apple Watch charging cables, and even Micro USB cables â€“ without having to replace them to work with USB Type-C. The adapter has a really nice look to it. It has a aluminum shell with silver edge and is about the size of a small USB flash drive.Even though products like the MacBook are starting to use USB Type-C as its main method of data and power transfer, there are still very few products that have begun to adopt the technology. That being said, I actually do have a couple of battery packs and chargers that use the technology.On a trip I took a few weeks ago, I had to charge my iPhoneâ€™s battery while I was in the car. The problem was that I had a battery that I was testing out that only had a USB Type-C charging port. Since a Lightning-to-USB Type-C cable does not exist yet, I ended up using this adapter to connect the battery and the phone. It works beautifully. I was able to plug the USB end into the adapter and the USB Type-C end into my battery allowing me to be a happy camper with a full iPhone charge.If you are interested in keeping up with technology and making sure your devices can be compatible with the newest emerging devices with USB Type-C, consider giving this adapter a try. Itâ€™s affordable and works like magic."This product was received at a free or discounted price in exchange for my review. I am a technology journalist and pride myself on providing fair and honest reviews. Please feel free to ask any questions you might have."

Home automation has become like a small obsession with me. From turning on/off my lights and opening my garage door to just saying, â€œHey Siri,â€ and asking it to turn the heat up in my home, I am really hooked on the technology. One item lacking in the HomeKit area are wifi enabled cameras. Having the option to have Siri pan or tilt my cameras would be really nice, but since I donâ€™t have that option yet Iâ€™ll stick to the next best thing â€“ an app controlled, WiFi camera like this one from Inspira Technologies, LLC.The Astro View HD 360 Wi-Fi Camera is a product that was introduced to me off of Amazon and I love it. With this little camera I can pan and tilt to grab the right viewing angle with ease. It has really been a great camera to use. The camera provides 720P HD resolution and has six infrared lights and a cut-off filter for nighttime video. This allows you to view black & white images in complete darkness up to 25 feet away from the camera. This camera also features a 2-way audio feature so that you can essentially incorporate the Astro View as an intercom in your home.Astro View HD 360 comes with a one month free trial subscription to iSecurity+ cloud recording service. This is regularly priced at $10 per month or $100 per year per camera. Recordings are accessible for 14 days after they are initially stored. This isnâ€™t something that you necessarily need as you can still view real-time video once you receive a notification, but itâ€™s a nice option should you ever need to refer back to a historical event â€“ like a break-in.I think one of the most impressive things about the Astro View HD 360 is the fact that it can be told to remotely pan and tilt so that you have the best viewing angle possible. This is a wonderful feature that none of my other cameras have.First Impressions & SetupI was instantly impressed with this little camera from the moment I took it out of the box. Sometimes, you donâ€™t know what to expect from products you find on Amazon, but this was a very pleasant surprise. When you first open the box, the camera is laying inside of a plastic mold that separates the camera from the accessories. The camera itself looks like a little robot (we actually nicknamed it â€œBB-8â€ on our network). Included in the package with the camera is its power supply, a user manual, and some mounting supplies for installation.Connecting to my WiFi was simple. I opened the app (available for iOS or Android) and followed the basic instructions to connect to my home WiFi. Within a few minutes, I was connected. Iâ€™ve not experienced any issues with it disconnecting randomly or not being available when I call it up on the app.One thing Iâ€™m always nervous about is being able to connect to my cameras when Iâ€™m away from home. What sort of quality will I get? Will I be able to connect at all? These are very good questions as the most important part of having network security cameras is being able to pull the video feed up at anytime from anywhere. I can happily say the Astro View 360 does not disappoint. In fact, my experience with this camera has been even better than my Dropcam Pro.You can mount this camera on a wall or even ceiling if you wish, but it also have a flat bottom, which makes it conducive to acting as a table top camera, too. I really like that Inspira Technologies designed this camera to have an easy wall installation. It has a bottom plate that you can remove and mount it to the wall. Then, you can affix the camera to that plate with a simple twist. I definitely prefer this method to the guess and measure option that some manufacturers force you to do. For testing purposes, I decided to use the Astro View HD 360 as a desktop camera, but very much appreciated that those supplies were included.TestingBecause I was so excited about the condition of the Astro View, I immediately set it up on my home network and starting looking at video. My office is actually a major thoroughfare in our home. From my desk you have a view of our front door and so this area was the ideal testing ground for the Astro View. Once the camera was on, I just let it go. My fiancÃ© and I went out to dinner and while we were out, I received real-time notifications of movement and was able to pull up the video feed very quickly. I do have some pre-existing experience with network cameras and accessing them remotely. Every time Iâ€™ve done this process with other cameras, Iâ€™ve had issues with connection or video quality. This time, the video was crystal clear and even though we were looking at the cameraâ€™s night vision, it was very easy to tell what the images were.The video does operate off of a delay. It seems to be less than 5 seconds, which wasnâ€™t a problem for me. We also tested out the pan and tilt function via remote and found that it worked flawlessly.ConclusionsThe Astro View 360 HD is a wonderful choice for home security camera. I canâ€™t say enough good things about this little camera. Itâ€™s easy to set-up and use. It is actually my personal camera of choice at this given time. I love that you can change its viewing angle so easily and the quality of the video overshadows all of my other home WiFi cameras. This is a very affordable camera and even though it may be a bit larger than other WiFi cameras, itâ€™s well worth the extra space it takes up."This product was received at a free or discounted price in exchange for my review. I am a technology journalist and pride myself on providing fair and honest reviews. Please feel free to ask any questions you might have."

When Apple announced the release of the new Apple TV in September, I knew I would be among the first in line to pick one (or two) up. It had a faster processor, better hardware, and just offered a better experience than the previous generations of the device. One of the features I was most looking forward to was the promise that the Apple TV would be a premier gaming system as well as a media player. Even though the Siri Remote is a great accessory for the Apple TV, itâ€™s not a gaming controller. The SteelSeries Nimbus, however, is a gaming controller and itâ€™s designed specifically for the Apple TV (and other Apple devices).FIRST IMPRESSIONSThe very first thing I noticed about this controller was how much it reminded me of an Xbox controller. Side-by-side, you almost wouldnâ€™t be able to tell the two apart except that the analog sticks have placement similar to the PlayStation controller. The designers of the Nimbus really looked at what worked with both of those systemsâ€™ controllers and pulled them into this device.In addition to the two analog sticks that Iâ€™ve already mentioned, Nimbus also features a standard D-Pad on the left-hand side of the controller, a menu button (more like a multi-function button) in the center, A/B/X/Y buttons on the right-hand side, Right & Left triggers, Right & Left bumpers, and a Bluetooth pairing button. All buttons and control functions operate as you would expect them to and if you have any experience with a gaming controller, you wonâ€™t have any â€˜translationâ€™ issues carrying over to the Nimbus.While the main body of the controller is made primarily of plastic, it doesnâ€™t feel that way. Itâ€™s got some great weight to it and it feels solid. The packaging for the controller is pretty nice, too. The only thing in the box with the controller is a manual so you will have to supply your own charging cable.TESTINGEven though I enjoy product testing, the trial run of the Nimbus was definitely a highlight of my testing year. After all, testing meant that I got to play games. Even though this is a Bluetooth controller and compatible with many different devices, it was designed for the Apple TV. And, as such, I did the majority of my testing with the new Apple TV. Pairing was very easy with the Apple TV and you donâ€™t have to keep re-pairing it. The controller and Apple TV remember each other.Once the controller was paired, I was off to the races. First, I played a few rounds of Rayman Adventures. Not having any previous experience with the game, I felt like this was a good test of how well I would understand the controller and how well it would communicate with the Apple TV. I can say that it was a flawless test. I was able to learn the commands quickly and found that holding and using the Nimbus wasnâ€™t much different than holding my Xbox controller. I also did not have any communication or connection problems between the Apple TV and the Nimbus. Playing Rayman Adventures felt very much like a standard gaming console experience. Movements were fluid and the controller had a great response with the Apple TV.One of the other games I tried out was Beach Buggy Racing. This game has a Mario Kart feel to it and is really a lot of fun. The Nimbus performed beautifully and had great options for controlling the beach buggy. Again, this was a very fluid action/reaction between the Nimbus and the Apple TV.After taking some time with the Nimbus, I found that really the only place it fell short was with the activity-based games that call for a more Wii-like control. Thatâ€™s where the Siri Remote really shines.CONCLUSIONSI used to consider the Xbox the best gaming controller, but now I find myself wishing I could use the Nimbus for all gaming. This controller is allowing me to enjoy playing games on the Apple TV and because it works with other Apple products, I might find myself liking the iPad Pro as a gaming machine, too.Playing games using the Nimbus really feels great and takes you back into childhood. While I was playing, I found myself feeling more like a kid playing those colorful games I grew up with â€“ except that those games never looked as clean and crisp as they do on the new Apple TV.One additional feature that is very cool is the iOS app from SteelSeries that allows you to update your controller when itâ€™s paired to your iPhone or iPad. This is a review of the Sentey Artix Gaming Headset. It is a over-the-ear, USB headset with microphone suitable for use on Windows or Mac.Initial ImpressionsThis thing is big. It reminds me of a big set of cans you might find in a recording studio. It has a nice plastic coated braided USB cord with a simple USB connection to your computer. It is self adjusting with a spring loaded headband, which I found perfectly comfortable. I had no trouble connecting it to my Windows 10 PC, and there were no drivers to install. It was effortless to select it for use in Steam for voice use.FeaturesOn the headset you will find a volume control, LED switch to make the headphones light up bright blue, and a mysterious â€œVâ€ switch which I could find no mention of in the documentation. The â€œVâ€ switch seemed to do nothing as far as I could tell. Testing with Audacity, there was no effect on the microphone. The manual mentions a special microphone control, but there wasnâ€™t one anywhere to be found. The microphone has a sturdy retractable boom that swings out of the left ear piece.The USB connection provides all that is needed for interfacing this to your computer. Having an on-board audio adapter means that you donâ€™t have to fiddle with plugging in separate cables for sound and mic in. To me, the audio quality is good, if just a little heavy on the bass side which many will find a positive.You will find it very comfortable to wear, and very effective at isolating outside sounds thanks to its comfortable ear pieces with rubberized foam pads.QualityThe fit is pretty impressive. I found the spring loaded headband to be perfect for my head, and I had no problem wearing it for a couple of hours at a time while playing games or listening to music.The major disappointment for me was its very weak microphone gain. Even with all my levels at full, it was difficult for anyone to hear me unless I was almost yelling. Evaluating in Audacity, I was unable to get it to register at more than half level without speaking very loudly. I tried setting gains in the application, Windows, and even fiddling with the volume control and â€œVâ€ switch on the unit, but to no improvement.Final ThoughtsThis is a decent set of headphones that are very comfortable to use, easy to install, and sound great. Poor microphone performance and its rather large size might make you think twice about this particular set."This product was received at a free or discounted price in exchange for my review. I am a technology journalist and pride myself on providing fair and honest reviews. Please feel free to ask any questions you might have."

One of the struggles that I deal with daily is desktop clutter that is caused by charging multiple electronic devices. Sometimes this issue can be dealt with by the addition of a charging dock that neatly tucks away cables and provides you with one option for storing  your devices on your desktop. One such product that offers this kind of freedom from clutter is the Basecamp Charging Dock from INZeyo Labs.First ImpressionsThe very first thing I noticed about this dock was the assembly required to get it up and running. Assembly doesnâ€™t typically scare me off of a product, but this was a bit more than I expected. Itâ€™s got a nice weight to it â€“ heavy enough not to tip over, but light enough to carry from place to place if need be.One of the unique features of this dock is that you can use any cables you prefer along with it. There are two standard USB docks built into the power station of the dock (on the inside), and you can use your preferred cables with the dock. The productâ€™s website claims the following devices are compatible with the Basecamp charging dock:iPhone 5, 5c, 5s, 6, 6+, 6s, 6s+Apple Watch 38mm/42mm, all bandsiPad, iPad Pro, iPad Air and iPad MiniIn addition to these products, the website also indicates that you can use non-Apple tablets, e-readers, and smartphones with it as well. I found while assembling the dock and installing the cables that only the Apple Lightning cable will slide through the smartphone/tablet charging port. There is a USB port on the back that can be used to charge other non-Apple devices, but just know that you may not be able to set your device on the dock. There might be some small form Micro USB cables that can fit, but the form of the standard Apple Lightning cable is a bit small. I tried using a third party Lightning cable and it would not fit. This is just something to take into consideration when thinking about whether or not this dock will suite your needs. I would also hesitate to charge the larger iPads on it if they are not in a case. The dock provides minimal protection for devices that are charging, but they will still rest their backs on the aluminum finish of the dock. I am using my iPhone 6 in the charging dock and itâ€™s got the Apple Silicone case protecting it. The phone fits very well.InstallationWhen I first took the Basecamp charging dock out of the box, I was surprised to find that there were not instructions included. Itâ€™s pretty self-explanatory, but I thought there might at least be a Quick Start Guide. The first hurdle I had to clear was routing the cables. While that in itself isnâ€™t a monumental task, wrapping up the longer Apple Watch charging cable is. If you have the shorter Lightning and Apple Watch charging cables available, then I would highly suggest you dedicate them to this cause.Once the cables were plugged in and wrapped, I screwed the bottom plate onto the dock base. Helpful hint: If you are having trouble with the correct size of Phillips head screwdriver, try a flat head screwdriver. I found that two of the screws were a little tougher to attach than the others, but when I tried using the flat head screwdriver, it worked very easily and the best part was that I didnâ€™t end up with a stripped screw.The other part of the assembly is determining which dock guide to use with your smartphone or tablet. You can go through trial and error, but this is one of those pieces that would be great to include in a Quick Start Guide. Both the Apple Watch puck dock and the backing to the dock guide for the smartphone are adhesive to secure those pieces in place.Once all the basic pieces were completed, all I had to do was plug in the power supply and I was off to the races. The nightlight doesnâ€™t require anything specific for operation or installation. It operates by touch and you can dim it by tapping and holding your finger in place until the desired light level is reached.Testing & ConclusionsEven though I found some room for improvement in certain areas, the Basecamp dock is a wonderful piece of technology and is a great option for any desktop or nightstand. Currently, I have the dock resting on my desk at work so that my watch and phone both have a place to live during the day. I quickly found that I didnâ€™t have any problems with my phone charging â€“ sometimes a connection isnâ€™t made due to the case thatâ€™s on the phone â€“ and the watch rests comfortably on its charging puck. The nightlight is a really nice touch and offers a soft, abundant light. Something thatâ€™s really nice about the way this dock is designed is that the smartphone docking station has enough space for your phone to rest in either portrait or landscape mode without having to be plugged in.Basecamp offers a really nice option for charging multiple devices at once. Itâ€™s a stylish, functional charging dock that reduces desktop clutter. Itâ€™s priced competitively with other docks in its market space."This product was received at a free or discounted price in exchange for my review. I am a technology journalist and pride myself on providing fair and honest reviews. Please feel free to ask any questions you might have."

Iâ€™ve recently become enamored with wireless charging. Itâ€™s not something that I really felt I needed until I actually had it available to me. Now that I do, I canâ€™t get enough of the accessories that are available for Qi wireless charging devices. I recently acquired a charging case for my iPhone that operates through Qi wireless charging. If I didnâ€™t have it, I wouldnâ€™t be able to use these really cool wireless charging devices â€“ like the Mo.Mat Wireless Charger.The Mo.Mat Wireless Charger a bit smaller than my iPhone 6, but about twice as thick. Also, itâ€™s a bit on the heavy side. Iâ€™m not saying that the charger isnâ€™t portable, but there are definitely other Qi chargers in the market that are a little less portly. The Mo.Mat charger gets itâ€™s power via Micro USB. The manufacturer was nice enough to provide two Micro USB cables â€“ one long and one short â€“ in the box with the charger.So, how does it work? Through my testing, I have found it to be a successful charger. I do have a couple of issue with it though. First, the energy exchange between the charger and the device itâ€™s charging seems to create a large amount of heat. Iâ€™ve noticed this with other Qi chargers Iâ€™ve used, but it wasnâ€™t to this great of an extent. The heat does dissipate once the device is removed from the charger, but itâ€™s still concerning as I donâ€™t want any damage to be cause to my device because of it. Because there is an exchange of energy, I would expect some heat, but not as much as I experienced with the Mo.Mat Wireless Charger.The other issue I had with it was the resting platform for the mobile phone. When the Mo.Mat is unfolded and being used as a vertical stand, there is a small trap door that I refer to as the resting platform. The platform has a groove in it to help with stability for your device, but because I have my device in a special case that is rounded, I did have a few issues with it rocking off the platform and falling onto my desk.Overall, I like the concept of this charger, but have some personal concerns with it. This Notebook Computer Lock is a nice theft deterrent system. While it doesnâ€™t completely protect your computer from being stolen, it does make a thief think twice. The lock is actually quite heavy for what it is. Some locks are key locks, but this one is a simple combination lock. The cable measures at 6.2 feet in length, just as advertised. On one end is a silver lock, fitting into a Kensington or â€œK slotâ€ security port. The other end has a fixed wire loop, which allows you to feed the lock end through and tether the device to a fixed structure. It is important to note that this lock will not work if your device does not have a Kensington security slot. This rules out most tablets and newer iMac computers and MacBooks. As Apple has made ever smaller devices, the traditional T lock mechanism for Kensington security locks has been left behind. However, they do make adhesive Kensington ports which would work with many of these devices. At first glance someone may feel uneasy about trusting this as anti-theft, as it seems a hard tug would just pull it out. That is where I was surprised. This is not simply a plastic hole in the laptop, but is in fact metal reinforced. The lock has sufficient swivel and will rotate 360 degrees (the power cable on my laptop blocks some of this range of motion). The cable attaches to the lock perpendicularly and can swivel 180 degrees. This provides a good number of options to sit with this Device comfortably and not find an awkward position. Another concern that I felt was that the cable may be too thin. The cable is twisted giving it more strength and it is approximately 1/4 inch wide with charcoal semi translucent coating. It would take bolt cutters or a saw of some type and time to get through this wire. Time is the deterrent as nobody can snatch the device and run, no grab-and-go. If you have the slot, you will not find a more cost effective, intuitive, theft deterrent system."This product was received at a free or discounted price in exchange for my review. I am a technology journalist and pride myself on providing fair and honest reviews. Please feel free to ask any questions you might have."

Since a recent physical exam, I have been taking Vitamin D3 daily in a dose of 1000 IU. It seems that I and just about everyone else has a Vitamin D deficiency. This dose of 2000 IU is a little higher than my 1000 IU. I checked out Vitamin D3 on the Mayo Clinic web site. They say "Vitamin D is likely safe when taken by mouth in doses of 100 micrograms of vitamin D3 daily (4,000 IU)."These Chewable Tablet, in Raspberry/Lemon flavor, are a very nice way to get my daily Vitamin D3. The taste is good. The ingredients are organic. The tablets dissolve instantly in my mouth. I assume then that taking these 2000 IU pills should work for me.

This is by far the smallest frying pad that I own.  However, it is the perfect size for the small burner on my gas range.  It takes only a minute to melt butter to put on popcorn.  I also see using it to reheat small quantities of sauces.  The rubberized coating on the handle keeps it quite cool. This is indeed a very nice addition to my kitchen.

The Braun shaver with screen foil and cutter give me a very close shave, closer than that of rotary razors.  .  The screen foil lasts more than a year.  However, given the cost, you could buy a new razor every year or so and throw away the old one,

Over the past several years I have had knee miniscus problems problems.  One had to be operated, but the other one cured itself slowly with the help of 750 mg of Glucosamine a day.  I get this in one pill from Vitacost.  I have found that if I take a smaller amount or stop taking it, I begin to have knee pain.  In order to get my 750 mg, I can take two of the Viva pills.  They are smaller, so it is an even trade-off.  I have no idea whether the other ingredients contribute, but the Glucosamine definitely helps.

How could you not love the Bangles.  They may be an 80s band, but their music resonates with the 60s/70s. Their "Hazy Shade of Winter" is so much better than Simon and that other guy. It alone is worth the price of the album.

One week, I happened to notice that my skin looked particularly good. I had been eating more than the usual amount of fish that week.  When discussing this with a friend, she suggested that I read Dr. Perricone's book. Indeed, his book does recommend a fish diet, as well as other aspects of a diet that will be good for your skin.  I do not do everything that the book suggests, but I find that following the diet suggestions has resulted in smooth better-looking skin.

The editor of "Hitler is Alive" Steven Westlake has collected over 400 pages of stories about Hitler published in the National Police Gazette during the 1950s and the 1960s.  We learn that Hitler fled Germany before the fall of the Third Reich and then found refuge in Argentina, where he and his fellow Nazi's plotted to regain power.It is easy to dismiss the claims made in the Gazette, but how plausible could the stories be.  We know that in today's Internet-connected world, where US security agencies can read and store every tweet, every e-mail, and record every phone call, today's most-wanted evil doer was able to hide out for over a decade.  Could Hitler have done the same in a pre-Internet world?  Don't even get me started on the pyramids as grain silos.Actually, I am not sure that Hitler's escape justifies the 400 pages of this book. The Gazette covered a wide variety of subject matter.  The introductory pages mention other headlines including "Battle with Corpse-Eating Cats."  I would like to hear more about those creatures.

These DII cloths come in a nice blue color. I measured their size at around 15 x 22 inches.  They are not very thick, but they do their job for dish drying, countertop cleaning, and even hand wiping.  I am happy with these cloths.
The New Riders of Purple Sage incorporates country, western, and rock, all at once.  Their music is wonderful, characteristic of the early seventies.  This is my era and this is my music.

Turbo Tax is certainly one of the easiest ways of doing your taxes. Using Turbo Tax, I have never received a letter from the IRS telling me that I had made an error.  Before Turbo Tax, I was around fifty percent.

In jeans, I wear Levi's 550, 33 waist, and 30 length.  The Oxfords at 34w, 30 inch length are a good fit, although a 33 waist would also work.  The 30 length is comparable to my Levi's 30s, although it is at the long end of the Levi's range.  The material is smooth, light, and stretchy.  The Oxfords are good for going to the office or for occasions that may be more formal than for wearing jeans.

I was surprised by how good this was. Most Korean-style products are overly spiced.  This was mildly spiced and salty, but not too much to overcome the natural taste of the meat.  It was a lot like bacon but without the grease. There are 11 grams of protein in one bag.  That is good.  The bag also comes with a zip-lock closer, but I did not get to use it because I ate the contents all at once. I definitely recommend the product.  However, the price is somewhat high.

These 18 ounce plastic cups are sturdy and just the right size for beer or soft drinks. I love the alligator logo on my Florida Gators cup. The colors are solid: blue, orange, and green.  Now that I have their cups, I suppose that I have to become a Gators fan. Go Gators!!!

I have been taking Omega-3s for many years.  They help to keep my skin smooth and clear.  This DHA/EPA combination has the same total of Omega-3s as the pills that I have been taking, but it does have a higher ration of DHA. The pills are also slightly smaller, making them easier to take. So far, I do not notice any difference from my old pills, which is a good indication that this Viva labs product is doing its job.
This CD is a wonderful collection of classic country songs sung by a great singer.  I can play this CD over and over and not get tired of it.

The Oxford NY Men's Crew Neck T Shirt is a quality product.  The material is heavy, not thin like many polyester blend t-shirts.  It also has a nice textured surface finish. I tried it on while engaging in my usual winter outdoor activity, splitting wood.  The shirt breathes well, taking perspiration away.  I am totally pleased with this shirt.

This Solid Gold Fit as a Fiddle Holistic Dry Cat Food, Pollock flavor, gets five stars because Willy really likes it just as well as his regular dry cat food. Willy loves to do taste tests. I put samples of his old chicken/turkey dry grain free food and the new Pollock grain free food in bowls next to each other. He went for the new food first. I moved him back to the old food. He ate that. I move him back and forth several times. He ate from the bowl that was in front of him. Willy seems to like everything that I give him, but he was certainly pleased by the new food.Willy is a large gray tabby, who now weighs around 13 pounds. When I adopted him, he was a skinny 11 pounds. He had been living on the streets of New York City. After several months of eating only dry food, he became a round 16 pounds. I switched to mostly canned food and some dry food for treats. After a while, he slimmed down to his present 13 pounds. I intend to keep giving him mostly canned food, but also this new dry grain free food.

As a longtime reader of National Geographic, I am happy to be able to review "The Old West."  The over four hundred page work, about 10 x 11 x 1 inch, covers the time period from the Louisiana Purchase in 1803 to the end of the frontier, characterized by the Buffalo Bill Wild West Show, in 1912.  Today, Buffalo Bill's grave is nearby the Denver-owned Buffalo Herd.  I am happy to say that the buffaloes (really bison) get top billing on the I-70 exit sign.The themes of  exploration, discovery, and settlement are offset by continual conflict: between pro and anti slavery factions, cattle people and homesteaders, and throughout, between Native Americans and those who were taking their land and their ability to survive. National Geographic does not omit key episodes like the massacre at Wounded Knee or the deliberate slaughter of the buffalo, but it is all presented in a glossy once-removed manner. Native Americans are referred to as Indians.  The word genocide is not used. This all appears to rest in the long-gone past, certainly not related to the present..The illustrations are excellent, starting with drawings and paintings for the first half of the nineteenth century, giving way to photographs as that technology came into use in the latter half of that century.  I liked the classic photo of Judge Roy Bean's saloon and courthouse in Langtry, Texas.  The two-page wide prints of Bierstadt's paintings were beautiful.As is obvious, The Old West is a great coffee table book.  However, I think that it is also an educational book that a young person might enjoy.

I received two sticks: one beef and one turkey. This review is for the beef.  I found the beef to be mild tasting and slightly salty, but without any hint of artificial ingredients. I gave a few small pieces to Willy, my feline Amazon focus group.  He liked it too. The label indicates that the beef is a good source of protein.I also tried the turkey. It was oddly sweet. Willy ate his share, but I did not like it very much.  i do recommend the beef.

The 2016 Fourteeners calendar has some impressive photographs. This year, the 14ers pictured are: Handies Peak, Longs Peak, La Plata Peak, Mount Bross, Mount Lincoln, Mount Sherman, Crestone Peaks, Snowmass Mountain, Capitol Peak, Humboldt Peak, Mount of the Holy Cross, Wetterhorn Peak, Mount Antero, Mount Shavano, Tabeguache Peak, and Mount Lindsey .I have climbed all of these, except for the Crestones and Capitol. I think that the most interesting was the north ridge on Mount Lindsey.  The Wetterhorn is ok if you do not look down.This calendar provides a standard presentation of each month divided into a grid of five weeks. There is also a page for November/December 2015. Each page is placed below a mountain photograph page. The pages are fourteen by eleven inches. Each day in the calendar grid has its own 1-7/8 by 1-7/8 inch box, leaving sufficient space for notes. Astronomical events and holidays are indicated.I recommend this calendar for anyone who is a fourteener fanatic or who likes mountain photographs. If Amazon is sold out and you cannot get to the Tattered Cover, there are other web sites which may still have one: "Calendars" or "Skylinepress."(Photo: On the slopes of Snowmass Mountain, first week of July)

Willy, a grey feline, is my primary focus group for testing Amazon products.  He took an immediate interest in the rug as soon as I rolled it out in front of couch.  He soon decided that it was good for stretching, playing, and then sleeping.  It also matches his color fairly well,The rug provides protection for the floor in a heavy-traffic area. I also find that the rug looks good with my wood floor as a background. It is a nice addition.

Until I got these bags, I used paper bags from the market for my kitchen garbage. They were less than perfect, especially when they became wet.The Hefty Odor Block Tall Kitchen Bags fit perfectly into my plastic kitchen trash container. They are strong enough and flexible enough to hold the kitchen garbage as well as the used cat litter. The draw string is also convenient. These bags get my vote.
I buy the Colorado Fourteeners calendar every year.  So far, I have climbed 41 of the 54 official peaks.  The calendar is functional as a calendar with great photos.

In order to appreciate the beauty that is France, all that you have to do is to watch the Tour de France on TV when it is on in July. You can spend a week or two in any of a dozen regions. I was fortunate to have lived in the Alps for two years doing atomic physics at the University of Grenoble, and, of course, skiing.In my two years in France, I did get to tour the Rhone Valley, Provence, and the Mediterranean coast, first by train, then by bicycle, and then by car.  This is a region well worth visiting.If anything, this Road Trip tries to cover too much territory. In doing so, it leaves out some places of interest that I would have included.  For instance, there is the town of Grasse, north of Nice, which is famous for perfume.Although the road tour passes a few miles from Avignon, it is not mentioned.  In Avignon, there is the Palais des Papes, the old walled city, and Le Pont dâ€™Avignon made famous by the song: â€Sur le Pont d'Avignon, L'on y danse, l'on y danse.â€I recommend starting with this Road Trip book as an introduction. It contains the basics: sights, hotels, and restaurants. Decide what is the most appealing and then get a more detailed guide book for that particular region. It is all good.

The hardest part of this was unplugging all of my power cables, figuring out which was which, and then plugging them into the Woods device.I plugged my Toshiba laptop PC into the master outlet.  Next, I plugged my peripheral work devices: monitor, electric stapler, and desk lamp into the controlled outlets.  When I am ready to leave work, I shut down the PC. Like magic, the monitor, the stapler, and the lamp go off.  The non-controlled outlets are not effected.This is a wonderful energy-saving idea. It really works!
I bought this calendar for my nephew who is into Rock & Roll as I am.  It was a big hit.

What can you say about Dark Side of the Moon.  It may be one of the greatest albums ever; way ahead of its time. As a spectroscopist, I love the cover art. They got the order of the colors correct.  I even have a bike jersey with the cover design.

I like bamboo so much that I have planted small clumps in my backyard.  The Bissett Bamboo has grown to about thirty feet in height.  I have cooked some of the shoots in the spring. The woody stalks have been put to many uses.These "Now Designs Bamboo Utensils" are my first bamboo cooking utensils.  They are comparable to wood versions that I have been using.  I use the wood utensils with my non-stick pots and pans. Now, I am using the bamboo ones. I like the white coated handles.  I expect the bamboo to wear better and last longer than the wood counterparts.

This is a great Blondie album, possibly their best. The songs are great 1970-80s music. Note that there are tow versions of Hanging on the Telephone.  A real treat. It is also nice to see that they gotten together recently for live performances.

The seaweed and brown rice combination cracker is a good start.  However, the spices drown out the more subtle flavors of the seaweed and brown rice.  I tried these crackers first with a dip.  The crackers were not quite strong enough for dipping.  I used them next to go with a mild cheese.  This combination did work.  However, I think that the Seaweed Crisps would be much better with less spice.
This is a great Blondie album. The songs are great 1970-80s music. A real treat. It is also nice to see that they gotten together recently for live performances.
