The Nitty Gritty Dirt Band has been performing for almost fifty years.  So much for the myth of rock stars all dying young.  They are still performing.  This weekend, they played in Colorado,This album contains live performances that illustrate the band's energy.  Mr. Bojangles makes it worthwhile.

These suction lids are a reusable replacement for using plastic wrap to seal bowls with leftovers.  Rubbong a thin layer of cooking oil on the rim of the bowl helps to make the suction work.  Very nice.

The Nitty Gritty Dirt Band has been performing for almost fifty years.  So much for the myth of rock stars all dying young.  They are still performing.  This weekend, they are playing in Colorado,This album contains some of their greatest hits, including Mr. Bojangles in the lead off spot.  This is all great music.
This is the first Blondie album. The songs are great 1970s music.  A real treat.  It is also nice to see that they gotten together recently for live performances.
This is a very consistent high-quality album by Carly Simon. It is not the only one that I own, but I do think that it is one o her best.
This is the third CD album of Nellie McKay that I have.  Her attitudee and wonderful voice makes for great music.  I really like her stuff.

These labels have a beautiful pearlized surface and rounded scalloped edges.  They make great add-ons for gift packages or greeting cards.  They can be written on or printed.  However, because the sheets are not the standard 8.5 x 11 inches, printing requires more effort than other Avery labels that I have tried.  I do not see the point of the smaller carrier paper.

This toy appears to be well designed with a nice surface for scratching.  It even looks good as furniture. First, I tried this new toy out with my Cat Amazon Focus Group A, Willy.  He is a large grey tabby, around three years old.  Willy is very aggressive when it comes to play. He has liked all of the cat toys that I have given him to test.  At first, this toy got a less than enthusiastic reaction.I put the sphere on the floor for Willy. He circled it once cautiously.  He then smacked it with his paw and ran away.  Next,  I wiggled the tassel for him.  He was willing to chew on it for a few seconds. (First Photo) He then walked away. Last chance: I draped Willy's favorite shoelace over the sphere.  Willy attacked it, even sinking his claws into the sphere for a few seconds.  He then walked away and ignored the sphere after that.Thinking that Focus Group A may have been a too small sample size, I turned to Focus Group B.  This group consists of three cats, Lucca, Honey, and Tilda, who are a few years older then Willy.  They live just down the street. The results with Group B were the same as for Group A.  They were not interested.  Catnip was added to the sphere.  Group B was still not interested. I took the sphere home.Several hours after I got home, Willy rediscovered the catnip-covered sphere.  He actually played with it for a while. (Second Photo)  He seems to come back to the sphere to play.  So, with the catnip, the sphere is a viable toy for Willy.

This tape dispenser has a nice two-tone design.  The blue color brightens my desk.  However, it was not put together properly. As soon as I removed it from its package, it fell apart.  The blue top plastic piece separated from the bottom black plastic piece. I was able to glue them back together, but this defeats the idea of having a simple easy-to-use product.

Can anyone deny that the Beatles are one of the greatest, if not the greatest rock group ever?  Rubber Soul is an early rock album that you can listen to end-to-end and never get tired of it. This version of the album, the UK version, has Drive My Car and Nowhere Man, which were left off the American version.  Altogether, it is an experience.

The DII Oceanique Shower Curtain is the standard size, 72 x 72 inches.  Because it is polyester, it does shed water, although I do have a plastic liner to go with it. I like the chevron design, which has alternating yellow, grey and deep purple colors on a white background..  The yellow is especially bright, making this a happy color curtain.  There is enough of the white background to let light in. Altogether, this is a nice product.

Taken purely as science fiction, The "War of the Worlds" strikes a resonance as a story of an alien invasion that comes to a bad end.  The theme is one that has been copied repeatedly in other media.  The radio broadcast by Orson Welles, no relation, is said to have caused listeners to panic. In motion pictures, in addition to remakes of "War of the Worlds," there is "Interdependence Day," where the aliens are defeated by a computer virus.  Good thing that the bad aliens used an Earth-compatible operating system. Altogether, "War of the Worlds" holds up well.

This collection of essays is an astute analysis of the game of baseball.  Gould tells us why there are no longer any 400 hitters and why it is extremely unlikely that anyone will ever exceed Joe DiMaggio's 56 game hitting streak.  Of course, I love Gpuld's deconstruction of what I believe to be the greatest event in sports history, the improbable victory of the Mets over the Red Sox in game six of the 1986 World Series.

My renewed interest in this work was inspired by a conversation that I had with my friend Peter, who is the great nephew of the Capeks.  R.U.R is a classic work, whose theme runs through modern literature.  People use science to create artificial beings, in this case robot workers. The Capeks were the first to use the term "robot." The robots get out of hand.  End of story.We can see the same line in such works as Frankenstein, The Terminator, and endless Star Trek episodes.  So far our robots are still behaving, but maybe some day ...

The Lonely Planet Route 66 Road Trips Travel Guide is a concise 120-page pocket guide to Route 66.  It has the basics that can be expected from a Lonely Planet book: places to stay, restaurants, local sites, and a map.  There is not a lot of detail past the basics, but it is sufficient for the reader to decide whether to make the trip.  The guide book does intersperse the text with many photographs.Route 66 stretched for over 2000 miles from Chicago to Los Angeles. There is no way that a compact 120 pages is going to have everything  along those 2000 miles, but it is a good way to decide if you want to do the Route, and which regions are the more appealing.I have done only small sections of Route 66.  For instance, we rolled into Winslow, Arizona to look for the park where my friend camped out over forty years ago when he was hitchhiking from Colorado to the Grand Canyon.  We drove around town for a while until we discovered the Monument.  The people of Winslow had erected a  wall of false store fronts with false reflections in the windows dedicated to the Eagles hit â€œTake it Easy,â€ which contains the line  â€œStanding on a corner in Winslow, Arizona.â€  The Monument sits along the old Route 66.At the advice of a local, we walked over to the Posada for lunch. It is one of the Harvey Hotels, like the Bright Angel Hotel in the Grand Canyon.  We also stopped to see Meteor Crater nearby, and then on to Flagstaff.  All of this is in the Lonely Planet Route 66 guide.  Sometimes the best discoveries are the ones that you happen on accidentally, but this guide will point you in the right direction.

This new Hill's Science Diet Cat Food cat food gets five stars because Willy loves it. Willy really likes to do taste tests. My plan was to put samples of his old cat food and the new Hill's Science Diet Cat Food in bowls next to each other for the taste test. As I filled the bowls on the kitchen counter, I accidentally dropped one piece of the Hills on the floor.  Willy scooped it up and then got really excited. He meowed for more.When I placed the bowls on the floor, he went for the Hill's first. I moved him back to the old food.  He ate that. I moved him back and forth several times.  He ate from the bowl that was in front of him. Willy seems to like everything that I give him, but he was certainly pleased by the Hill's. Besides, he looks like the photo on the bag.Willy is a large gray tabby, who now weighs around 13 pounds. When I adopted him, he was a skinny 11 pounds. He had been living on the streets of New York City. After several months of eating only dry food, he became a round 16 pounds. I switched to mostly canned food and some dry food for treats. After a while, he slimmed down to his present 13 pounds.  I intend to keep giving him mostly canned food, but also the new Hill's Science Diet for treats.

Neil Young is a great performer both with and without CSN.  This CD does indeed collect Young's greatest hits.  Almost all of them are from the 1970s.  Among my favorites are Helpless and Heart of Gold.  You will not be disappointed by this collection.

This is the first Dove hair product that I have tried.  I have been happy with Dove Soap. This  conditioner comes in an 8.45 ounce tube. The tube has a flat top so that you can stand it on its end and get everything out of the tube as it get empty. When I first used the conditioner, I was surprised by its tan color.  I got used to that. There is some aroma, but not too much.  What I found is that the conditioner leaves my hair soft and smooth.  It really fells nice and looks great.

This new Hill's Science Diet Cat Food  gets five stars because Willy likes it just as well as his regular canned cat food. Willy loves to do taste tests. I put samples of his old cat food and the new Hill's Science Diet Cat Food in bowls next to each other. He went for the Hill's first. I moved him back to the old food.  He ate that. I move him back and forth several times.  He ate from the bowl that was in front of him. Willy seems to like everything that I give him, but he was certainly pleased by the Hill's. Besides, he looks like the photo on the can.Willy is a large gray tabby, who now weighs around 13 pounds. When I adopted him, he was a skinny 11 pounds. He had been living on the streets of New York City. After several months of eating only dry food, he became a round 16 pounds. I switched to mostly canned food and some dry food for treats. After a while, he slimmed down to his present 13 pounds.  I intend to keep giving him mostly canned food, including the new Hill's canned food.

My primary use for this cup has been to keep my coffee warm.  If I microwave my coffee at the office and leave it in my ceramic cup, it stays warm for about an hour.  Pouring the coffee into the AVEX after microwaving keeps it warm for two hours. Unlike the ceramic, it does not feel hot on the outside even when boiling hot coffee is poured into it. This is also a good indication that it is keeping the coffee warm.Of course, I did try the AVEX with a cold drink with ice added.  It does fulfill its advertised purpose of keeping drinks cold.  So, if it keeps hot drinks hot and cold drinks cold, how does it know which is which?As to the blurb "enjoy every ounce of your favorite beer when you top your favorite '14er," I regard this as so much hype. You would not want to lug the AVEX and a beer to the top of a 14,000 foot peak. I did see someone once pop the top of a beer on the summit of Mt. Oxford.  The stuff gushed 20 feet into the air. There was little left to drink, but maybe that was a good thing since alcohol adds to the dehydrating effect of the thin air.Altogether, I like the AVEX for keeping my coffee warm at the office, but I will leave it behind when I go to Colorado in a few weeks to work on my 14er total.

Tresemme shampoos and conditioners have a long history in my house. I have found that they are all good products. This Youth Boost Tresemme Conditioner is no exception. It comes in a nine ounce tube, which has a flat top so that it is possible to get the conditioner out when their is only a little left. The conditioner itself is a white liquid that emerges easily from the tube. There is not a really noticeable aroma.I have been using the conditioner with Youth Boost Tresemme Shampoo. My hair came out clean, smooth, and shiny.

The new Remington R8 Lithium Rotary razor gives me a fast, close, and clean shave, which is the equal of the best that I have had. Over the years, I have used electric razors manufactured by Remington, Braun, and Norelco. I have owned a Remington R5 Lithium Rotary Shaver for over a year. The new R8 is very similar in design to the R5 and works just as well.

If you are a Doors fan as I am, you will love this album.  It may not be the greatesr Doors, but the live performance brings some extra energy that you do not get from the studio performances.The tracks include some of the Doors hits like Light my Fire and Break on Through.  I like the Alabama Song. also know as Whiskey Bar. This is an old Bertolt Brecht and Kurt Weill song from almost a century ago. The Doors bring it to life.

This album will help you to remember* the sixties whether you were there or not. This is great CCR, well worth the price of admission. Unfortunately, this was their last album together.CCR has to be the prototypical rock band. They are my favorite. The play list for this album includes some of my favorites: Hey Tonight and Have You Ever Seen The Rain?  These are almost more folksy than rock.*The saying goes, "If you can remember the sixties, then you weren't there." This is a self-referential quote. No one remembers who said it first. According to Wikiquote, it is "Attributed to Grace Slick in Bangkok Babylon (2006) by Jerry Hopkins, p. 217, and elsewhere, this was also attributed to Paul Kantner in The New Yorker, Vol. 67 (1991), Dennis Hopper in Roger Ebert's Movie Home Companion (1992), and in various books to numerous others, including Judy Collins, George Harrison, and comedian Robin Williams."

I have been using Imation USB flash drives for several years.  They are compact, rugged, and easy to use.  A swivel cover protects the contacts when the drive is in your pocket.  Altogether, this is a well designed reliable product.

Over a lifetime, I have used many electric shavers, both foil and rotary types.  I find that the foil razors give closer shaves, but tend to leave some whiskers behind.  The Remington PF7400 F4 does give a decent shave. It has a head that pivots and a curved handle for comfortable easy holding.  The trimmer attachment works well. The razor is light, so will be a good choice for travel.The razor is designed for cordless use. That means that it cannot be used while it is plugged in. It has to be charged.  A green light indicates that it is plugged in, but does not show when the charge is complete.Altogether, this is a reasonable low-cost razor.

"Forever Christmas" is the first full-length collaboration by pianist/composer David Lanz and singer/songwriter Kristin Amarie. Conceived during one of the coldest and snowiest East Coast winters on record (2013/2014), the fourteen tracks feature twelve original Christmas songs plus new arrangements of â€œSilent Nightâ€ and â€œO Holy Nightâ€ that the artists dedicated to their mothers. Only three tracks are all solo piano, but two others are mostly piano with some wordless vocals and a little bit of additional instrumentation. Most of the solos are quite short, much like the â€œangel interludesâ€ on Lanzâ€™s 1994 Christmas Eve. Six are vocals with lyrics and three are instrumental ensemble pieces. David Lanz has been one of my favorite artists since the early 1980â€™s (I still have several of his early albums on vinyl!!!), so Iâ€™m disappointed that there isnâ€™t more of his solo work on this album, but itâ€™s certainly a very pleasant addition to the Christmas music repertoire. The piano and vocals are supported by Grammy winning duo Eric Tingstad and Nancy Rumbel (colleagues from the Narada days) on guitar and woodwinds, cellist Walter Gray, bassist Keith Lowe, and co-producer Gary Lanz."Forever Christmas" begins with â€œWinterâ€™s Prelude,â€ a lovely instrumental piece with the full ensemble plus Amarieâ€™s haunting vocals. The title track is a sweet love song that also reflects on the meaning of Christmas. â€œSnow Danceâ€ is one of the piano solos. Spare and very free, itâ€™s a lovely meditation for a cold winterâ€™s day. Amarieâ€™s passionate, crystalline voice really soars on â€œO Holy Nightâ€ - a gorgeous arrangement of one of my favorites. â€œJubilateâ€ is the longest of the piano solos at just over 2 1/2 minutes and is pure Lanz in one of his more celebratory moods. â€œSweet Winter Loveâ€ appears as both a vocal and a shorter instrumental version. The lyrics refer to many holiday festivities as well as to the gift of each otherâ€™s hearts on Christmas Day. â€œWhat Is Christmasâ€ also has vocal and instrumental versions, and this time itâ€™s the instrumental thatâ€™s a bit longer. The melody is wistful and reflective and the lyrics are poignant and kind of sad. â€œWinter Starâ€ is mostly piano, but has wordless vocals here and there for â€œangelicâ€ embellishment. This is my favorite track and shows Lanz at his gentle, introspective best. â€œA Thousand Lightsâ€ features lyrics in both English and Norwegian and some lovely English horn by Nancy Rumbel. This peaceful, flowing arrangement of â€œSilent Nightâ€ is a sung in English and the original German - also a favorite. Tranquil and ambient, â€œHeavenly Peaceâ€ is arranged for piano and wordless vocals and brings the album to a quiet close. If you are looking for some brand new music for the holidays, "Forever Christmas" is a good place to start!

This is a really nice area heater. My office is in an added-on room in our house, and keeping it warm back there is very difficult. The floor is not insulated and there are big windows, so while it's a beautiful room, it gets very cold during the winter months. I have tried a variety of different portable heaters, but this is by far my favorite. It warms up quickly and is very quiet. (It makes a sound, but it's easy to ignore.) I really like that it has a built-in thermostat as well as a digital thermometer so you know what the temperature is in the room you are trying to heat. It has a full-speed fan setting and a half-speed which is really convenient once you approach the target temperature and don't need it to be operating full-blast. I like to keep the heater either to the side of my desk or under it (it is not a confined area) to keep my feet and legs warm (I hate shoes when I'm home!), and this seems to be working well. The casing remains cool to the touch and doesn't heat up the floor or any rugs that it's sitting on. The carrying handle doesn't get hot, either, so if you need to move it during operation, no problem. I had a little trouble getting the included batteries to work in the remote, but once I got them into exactly the right position, the remote works great. It allows you to turn the unit on and off, adjust the temperature, and to select the fan speed. The compartment in the back of the heater for the cord and remote will be great once the weather warms up again and the heater can be stored. The unit is small enough that storage won't be a problem. This is a great little heater and I've very pleased with it!

I know that these kinds of gifts are expensive, but for $33 I thought we'd get something REALLY special. Don't get me wrong - this is a very tasty treat, but it's just popcorn, pretzels, yummy caramel, and some Hershey's milk chocolate. Nice combination, but is it worth $33? Hmmmmm. The tin was packaged incredibly well for being non-breakable, but I guess the extra care was so the popcorn brittle didn't get bounced around too much during shipment . I could see this if all of the pieces were of a fairly uniform size, but they vary from BIG hunks to crumbs with a variety of sizes in between. It doesn't appear that there was any attempt at uniform sizes at all. With that in mind, I don't have a clue about how a "serving size" is determined to know how many calories you are getting with each piece. There are about 13 200-calorie servings per container, but that doesn't help much. The brittle comes in a tightly-sealed plastic bag inside the tin, but pieces are not individually wrapped, so if the tin is open for any length of time, the rest of the product will get stale. So, to summarize: Is it tasty? Yes. Does it appear to be a gift that would cost $33. I don't think so.

"All Is Calm, All Is Bright" is a collection of thirteen familiar and not-so-familiar Christmas carols arranged for solo piano and performed by Jeremy Yowell. â€œFor this project, I have purposefully chosen to arrange with a meditative, reflective quality. Amidst the busyness of the season, it seems like we need a reprieve.... this collection will hopefully offer some much-needed solitude and inner renewal.â€ (quoted from the CD liner notes) This is Yowellâ€™s third album, and as the pastor of a small church in Illinois, it is not surprising that this collection focuses on the traditional sacred songs of the holidays. A masterful and very expressive pianist, Yowell imbues each of these songs with warmth and a clear message of love. Yowell recorded the album at Joe Bongiornoâ€™s Piano Haven Studio on Joeâ€™s wonderful Shigeru Kawai grand, so the piano sound is smooth, clear and beautiful."All Is Calm, All Is Bright" begins with a wonderful arrangement of â€œSilent Night, Holy Nightâ€ that is played somewhat slower and more thoughtfully than we usually hear it, focusing on the message of peace and hope within the melody. â€œThe Coventry Carolâ€ refers to the Massacre of the Innocents, in which King Herod ordered all male infants under the age of two in Bethlehem to be killed, and takes the form of a lullaby sung by the mothers of the doomed children. One of the darker Christmas carols, Yowellâ€™s arrangement is both hauntingly beautiful and mournfully sad. â€œThe Holly and the Ivyâ€ is almost unrecognizable, so Iâ€™m not sure if itâ€™s a very different arrangement or an alternate melody. Either way, it overflows with emotion - a favorite. â€œIn the Bleak Mid-Winterâ€ is an  exceptional duet with Melissa Yowell, Jeremyâ€™s wife. I wasnâ€™t familiar with â€œRise Up, Shepherd, And Follow,â€ but it is an African-American spiritual first published in Slave Songs of the United States in 1867. Yowellâ€™s arrangement is sweet and gentle. On the more unusual side, Yowell created a medley of â€œO Little Town of Bethlehemâ€ and Debussyâ€™s â€œReverie.â€ Iâ€™ve heard some interesting combinations of pieces, but this stands out as a favorite - the two pieces fit together seamlessly. The album closes with a heartfelt and very effective arrangement of â€œO Holy Night.â€ Yowell takes the less commanding approach that has become popular the past decade or so, relying on the beauty of the melody to convey the message rather than drama - a peaceful and poignant end to an excellent album.There are some exceptionally good new solo piano Christmas albums this year, and this one is definitely in that category! Recommended!

"Myths and Fairy Tales" is a solo piano album freely improvised in a cabin in the woods near Ash Fork, AZ by pianist/composer/double-bassist Glenn Stallcop. The music was recorded over a three-day period in October 2009, but was only recently released (9/1/15). The five pieces are about the â€œlovely and fanciful Little White Lies we tell our children and ourselves. They fuel our dreams and aspirations, our passions and fantasies. Some become an inspiration; some become an impediment. Many are beautiful; none are real.â€ The titles are fanciful, reflecting their inspiration, and the music is very free and unstructured, sounding and feeling more classical than jazz.Glenn Stallcop is an active and versatile composer who has published more than seventy-five compositions. Originally from Seattle, WA, he earned his Bachelorâ€™s degree in Music from the University of Washington in 1976 and a Masterâ€™s degree in Music from Arizona State University in 1993. The Phoenix Symphony Orchestra has performed nine of his orchestral works and his music is performed by symphonies, festivals, chamber musicians, and youth orchestras around the country. At the keyboard, Stallcop has been active in classical music, jazz, free improvisation and the performance of his own music. After playing classical piano and rock music in his teens, he turned to improv in the 1970â€™s and has performed almost exclusively in free improvisation, both as a soloist and in groups, ever since. Dreamcatcher, his 1998 CD of solo piano improvisation, was nominated for a Grammy in two categories.Appropriately enough, "Myths and Fairy Tales" begins with â€œOnce Upon a Time.â€ Sometimes dreamy, sometimes darker and full of longing, the harmonies are complex and often dense, but Stallcopâ€™s expressive playing communicates well. â€œLong, Long Agoâ€ is nostalgic and bittersweet, and quite a bit of it is played in the lower half of the piano. â€œHappily Ever After,â€ perhaps the biggest fairy tale of all, is very open, free, and exploratory. It is also the longest of the five pieces at over 11 minutes, giving it plenty of time to evolve and tell its story. â€œMyth of Self, Myth of Sameâ€ is also quite lengthy at 10 1/2 minutes, taking the initial musical idea in several different directions that are sometimes quietly introspective and sometimes more turbulent. The last track is called â€œRapunzel Turns Ninety,â€ a title that initially seems humorous. However, the piece is not lighthearted, but more serious and reflective, perhaps depicting Rapunzel sitting in her tower thinking about her life and how long it has been since someone has come to visit her. Not so funny at all!If you are looking for some moderately challenging solo piano music, this is a good choice. If it is melodic and soothing that you seek, I suggest listening to some samples first.

"Butterfly Rapture" is SF Bay Area jazz pianist/composer Brian Kellyâ€™s first album since his 2008 "Afterplay" and his first solo piano album ever - something Iâ€™ve been looking forward to for a very long time. When I lived in the Bay Area, I had the opportunity to see Kelly play live several times and he became one of my favorite live performers. Iâ€™ve also worked with him by proofing some of his sheet music, so Iâ€™ve gotten to know his music quite intimately and love it. Overall, the music on "Butterfly Rapture" has an intoxicating energy but also has many quieter, more reflective moments. Kelly started playing the piano at eight years old, so his composing reflects a lifetime in music and feels as natural as speaking. The twelve pieces on "Butterfly Rapture" are a fascinating combination of classical, jazz and new age influences intertwined to give Brian Kelly a unique and original voice."Butterfly Rapture" begins with â€œPiano Escapade,â€ a bright and lively piece that (for me) expresses the joy and freedom of getting â€œlostâ€ in the music. It also clearly indicates that this is someone who really knows his way around a piano! â€œRoom For Skyâ€ has a beautiful flowing quality and combines elements of classical, jazz, and new age piano - a favorite. I also really like â€œLilac Horizon,â€ a lyrical beauty with just the right touch of mystery to make it compelling. â€œChasing a Breezeâ€ has a carefree energy that goes in different directions like its namesake breeze would do. Lovely images of an abundance of wildflowers and new grasses gently caressed by a soft wind are evoked by â€œHills in Bloomâ€ - warm and soothing. â€œNikoâ€™s Delightâ€ is a multi-movement piece with a more classical structure that begins with a sweet and simple melody accompanied mostly by blocked chords. The second theme is somewhat more agitated yet beautifully flowing - I really like this one, too! As its title implies, â€œPlaying My Heartâ€ is poignant and sincere, a deeply personal expression - and a very beautiful one. â€œWinter Auraâ€ goes darker to capture the feeling of winterâ€™s chill. Much of the first half of this piece is played in the bass of the piano, becoming livelier and more percussive and then returning to the original theme - cool! Kelly saved the elegant title track for the end of the album. The various runs throughout the piece are crystal clear and intricate while the smoother and more lyrical passages flow effortlessly. Itâ€™s a great ending to a great album!"Butterfly Rapture" was worth the long wait between albums and is sure to inspire and delight! Very highly recommended!

These lights are really pretty and usable all year. I really like the crackle effect inside the bulbs. They have two modes - steady and flashing. The lights are bright, so the flashing isn't for everyone (including me!), but the steady mode is gorgeous. The battery case isn't waterproof, so these lights would be best on a porch or indoors. I plan to put them on the Christmas tree in a few weeks, but they are on my fireplace for now - they're just too pretty to put away! The box they came in is a little confusing, as it says "length 175.19 Inches (4.6ft)" - um, no! - and the other side says "Saffe, power-saving and aco-friendly." I get the idea, but I don't think these are an American brand as stated on the Amazon page. Anyway, that's a small complaint and doesn't detract from the beauty and convenience of the lights. I really like them a lot and will most likely use them around the house all  year.  I received a complimentary set of lights in exchange for an unbiased review, which this is.

I just recently discovered solar powered lights, and LOVE THEM! I live on the coast, so the star fish lights will be appropriate around the house and yard all year. I do plan to put them on the Christmas tree in a few weeks, but they won't be put away with the other decorations after the holidays. Right now, I have them on my mantel and they look so nice! I have the solar battery in a window, and if I want the lights to turn on before dark or when the lights are on in the room, I just turn the sensor face-down, and they light right up. There are eight different modes from flashing quickly to dimming and coming back up to steady (no flashing), and they are all beautiful. I've had them on all evening the past several nights, and they haven't dimmed at all. I will definitely be buying some more strings of these lights!ONE WEEK LATER: I hate to say it, but these lights are not working very well after a couple of weeks. I have the lights indoors and have been putting the solar battery on the window sill to recharge, but when the lights do come on, they are very dim and don't last long. I either turn the sensor face-down so it "thinks" it's dark or put something over it, so it isn't that the room isn't dark enough. I had hoped to buy several more strings of these starfish lights, but must instead lower the star rating. Very disappointed!

I really like these hoses despite the fact that they don't always last very long. They are lightweight and don't kink, and as long as I handle them carefully, they seem to last fine. I bought three this spring for the three faucets around my yards and only one popped. For that particular location, the hole waters an area I would water anyway, so I just get a little wet getting to the faucet to turn it off. The other two hoses have been fine, and I used them daily throughout the summer and early fall. I really like the convenience of not having to unkink them all the time, and they don't take up as much space.

I'm very happy with my new iMac, but the one I bought was brand new, not "like new." I've been using Mac's since the little 7" SE back in the late '80's and have never considered buying anything else. I am currently using three iMacs and a MacBook Pro in my business and am very happy with them. The new one doesn't have an internal disk drive, but I bought external drive for playing CDs and DVDs and am very happy with that. Without that internal hardware, the new iMac is much lighter and easier to move around when necessary. The internal speakers seem to be improved a bit and the screen resolution is gorgeous. I'm very happy with my purchase!

I have to admit that a garden hose nozzle isn't something I'm going to get all excited about, but this one is REALLY good! It has a heavier construction than the last several nozzles that I've bought and seems MUCH sturdier. The eight settings are not that different from other nozzles, but with this one, the various sprays are much more powerful and distinctive. What I'm the most excited about is the "jet" setting which is powerful enough to do a light power-washing that is very effective. I've used it on my windows that are hard to reach by hand, and they come out much cleaner than with my old nozzle. I've used it on the wood siding on the house to remove cobwebs, pine needles, and just plain old dirt. I'm also using it to power wash my wood deck, and it is looking MUCH better. I really like the feel of the nozzle, too. It is coated with a baked-enamel finish that doesn't get slippery when wet. It will also prevent rust. You just can't go wrong with this nozzle! Oh, and it's also great for watering plants and the yard. I received a free sample of the nozzle in exchange for an honest review.

I have been drinking Matcha green tea every morning for the past year or so as a supplement and cancer preventative (as recommended in a book I read). I'm not crazy about the flavor of hot Matcha tea, so I've been mixing it with some iced tea mix and drinking it cold. Before I received this Matcha Whisk to review (I received a free sample in exchange for an honest review), I was stirring like crazy as I mixed the ingredients, but had to have a spoon handy when I drank it because so much of the Matcha filtered down to the bottom of the glass. I tried starting with warm water and the Matcha and that worked a little better, but this whisk fixes the problem and with a lot less effort. I still mix the Matcha in a small amount of warm to hot water with the whisk and then add the tea mix, cold water and some ice. The tea gets nice and frothy with the whisk, and I'm sure it would work great with other beverages, both hot and cold. The whisk itself seems like a fairly simple spring-loaded device that should last a long time even with regular usage. The bamboo handle is attractive and feels good in the hand. This is a great gift either for yourself or someone else, and the cardboard tube that it comes in would be sturdy in the mail and easy to wrap. I'm very happy with mine!

"Eight Winds" is the third release from Canadian finger-style guitarist Bob Ardern. Although I have thoroughly enjoyed the all three of his albums, "Eight Winds" is my favorite (so far!). All twelve tracks are original compositions, and three are guitar duets played and co-written with Ardernâ€™s longtime friend Duncan Woodcock. Additional instrumentation is spare, but brings out the very best in the music and lets the guitars (and guitarists) shine in the spotlight. The overall feel of the album is very warm, genuine, and relaxed, although several of the pieces have a wonderful energy. The music is simple enough to provide easy-going background music, but it is also complex and interesting enough to listen to with full attention (and enjoyment) many, many times. A variety of influences are heard in Ardernâ€™s music, blended together to create a unique musical voice that is rich and very satisfying."Eight Winds" begins with â€œZephyr,â€ a piece that immediately grabbed my attention. It features Ardern on 12-string guitar and producer David Findlay on bass and piano. Upbeat and light-hearted, it gives the album a buoyant start. â€œMatildaâ€™s Danceâ€ features Ardern on six-string guitar and Findlay on bass and accordion. This one feels a bit more like a folk song with a ballad-style melody that tells an interesting tale of your own choosing. â€œCrusaders and Jestersâ€ is the first of the duets. Originally written in 1973, it was the first piece the two guitarists wrote together. Both play six-string guitars and create the kind of musical magic that can happen when kindred spirits play together. â€œCascadingâ€ is a gently rhythmic and spirited piece that has Findlay adding colorful touches with piano, bass, percussion, cello, and synthesizer - wow! howâ€™d he do dat??? There are two versions of â€œ50 Not Outâ€ - a duet for two six-string guitars and the closing track that features the â€œfull band.â€ Although it is a cricketing term, the title relates to how long the two friends have known each other. The quiet energy of this piece expresses the joy of making music. â€œAnother Time Maybeâ€ is upbeat with a slightly bittersweet flavor. â€œThree Years Onâ€ is the third duet, but is actually a trio with Findlay adding bass, percussion, and glockenspiel to the guitars. Gently rhythmic and a little bit melancholy, itâ€™s a favorite. I also really like the much darker â€œMatushka,â€ which has Ardern on guitar and bouzouki and Findlay on bass, cello, and percussion. Mysterious and poignant, itâ€™s a beauty! The ending version of â€œ50 Not Outâ€ adds bass, piano, and percussion to the two guitars, upping the energy level and leaving us with a great big grin."Eight Winds" is a delight from the first note to the last and I highly recommend it!

"Om Land" is award-winning producer/guitarist/multi-instrumentalist David Vito Gregoliâ€™s musical meditation on the divine sound. In collaboration with Grammy-winning artist and producer Ricky Kej, percussionist and sound healer Christo Pellani, and singer/songwriter Kimberly Haynes, the project was started with the Om sound as its core, then adding the ambient bed and percussion. From there, Gregoli said, â€œSoloing over it was effortless because the resonance of Om is a calming inspiration. It all flowed very easily.â€The recording is in three parts: â€œSaguna,â€ â€œNirguna,â€ and â€œPranava,â€ with each segment running about twenty-two minutes. The music is intended for yoga, meditation, massage, healing and relaxation and really wasnâ€™t created as musical entertainment. Gregoli, a Buddhist who has practiced yoga and meditation for many years, appears on a variety of guitars, dobro, esraj, keyboards, voice, bass, piano, and percussion (impressive!). Ricky Kej adds strings, keyboard, and the Om chants; Kimberly Haynes provides vocals on â€œNirgunaâ€; and Christo Pellani plays percussion."Om Land" was inspired by both the Om mantra and the yantra symbol and has its roots in the artistsâ€™ own spiritual philosophy. Gregoli explains: â€œWithout beginning or end, Om embraces all that exists.... We started with that very personal and yet universal sound and then layered on our musical interpretations.â€"Om Land" begins with â€œSaguna,â€ which means â€œwith attributes.â€ â€œSaguna Brahmanâ€ implies that God has a name, form and other attributes. For this track, Gregoli chose a nylon-string guitar for its soft and gentle tone. Combined with the light percussion, strings, and Om chanting, this track is quietly hypnotic and very peaceful.â€œNirgunaâ€ translates as â€œwithout attributesâ€ and â€œNirguna Brahmanâ€ implies that God as the Absolute Spirit and Pure Consciousness has no name, form or attributes. For this track, Gregoli chose a dobro, an instrument often used in country music and similar to the Indian lap-steel guitar. The piece is a bit darker in tone and somewhat mysterious, and Haynesâ€™ voice adds an exotic contrast to Kejâ€™s earthy chants.â€œPranavaâ€ means â€œcosmic soundâ€ or â€œOmâ€ - the sound that everything in all of existence makes if one hears it all at once. It is said that Om comes the closest of all sounds to what this hum of the universe is. For this piece, Gregoli uses a finger-style acoustic guitar that gives the music a special voice that is both grounding and ethereal."Om Land" is both beautiful and extremely well done!

Bill Leslie returns with the follow-up to his 2013 ZMR Album of the Year - "Scotland: Grace of the Wild" - with the equally-enchanting "Across the Water." Inspired by a trip to Ireland, Leslie and his talented crew of instrumentalists take us on a magical tour of the Irish countryside and the land of his familyâ€™s ancestry. As an award-winning television news journalist, Bill Leslie has spent much of his professional life arranging and communicating with words, but as a composer/musician, he again demonstrates that he is just as adept at telling vivid and colorful stories without any words at all. The twelve pieces celebrate the places that deeply touched Leslieâ€™s heart as well as his two sisters. Ten of the pieces are original compositions, three of which are new interpretations of songs Leslie wrote and recorded fifteen years ago with the Celtic fusion band Bragh Adair. The band of â€œmerry minstrelsâ€ who accompany Leslie includes pianist/composer Joseph Akins - one of my favorite artists - who plays on nine of the tracks; Leslie very competently fills in on piano on the other three. Other instrumentation includes guitar, Celtic whistles and keyboard (Bill Leslie), bass, accordion, violin, cello, oboe, flute, harp and pipes - all performed by living, breathing musicians who do an exceptionally soulful and heartfelt performance on every track."Across the Water" begins with the title track, a wonderful piece that evokes picturesque images of a peaceful yet rugged countryside. Music is often very visual, but I havenâ€™t run across many pieces that are as vivid as this one. â€œThe Boatmanâ€ is a traditional Irish song with a very sad story to tell, and Nancy Greenâ€™s cello just about breaks your heart.  â€œConnemaraâ€ lifts the mood to dreamy and misty. â€œLoricaâ€ is one of the older pieces given a refreshing new makeover. This one is also very visual and seems like it would be perfect in a film soundtrack. â€œGaelic Ghostâ€ tells a â€œhauntingâ€ story without words that becomes more lively and upbeat as the story progresses. â€œCloud of Witnessesâ€ is another older piece given a new treatment. Strings, piano, accordion, guitar and whistles give this a light touch that almost dances - pure musical sunshine and contentment! â€œGougane Barraâ€ goes a bit darker, but expresses a gentle sense of tranquility. Bill Leslie and company close this excellent album with a heartfelt â€œIrish Blessing.â€"Across the Water" is very likely to win another round of awards for Bill Leslie and I guarantee that it will be on my list of Favorites for the year as well. I give it my highest recommendation.

"Elders & Ancestors" is the first full-length album by Agreliaâ€™s Castle and chronicles their love story and cancer journey. Husband and wife duo, Paul and April Brown, started composing and recording together to create a meditation and relaxation CD for Wind River Cancer Wellness Retreats and discovered that their music spoke to others in a very soothing and calming way. This excerpt from the liner notes explains it best, written by April Brown: â€œThe songs on this CD are very meaningful to me. They have grown from our journey through the cancer landscape. They come from a desire to create peace, joy, and hope in our lives. When I listen to our music, I feel soothed and uplifted. It is my hope that other people, people living with chronic illness or those in caregiver positions, will experience the same soothing, uplifting feelings when they listen to our music. ... This is our humble offering to the world; and for me, itâ€™s a way to give back for all of the help and guidance I have received along the way.â€ The album consists of seven tracks - six originals and a wonderful arrangement of the traditional folk song, â€œWayfaring Stranger,â€ that features the vocals of Grammy-winning Mike Farris. Paul Brown is a Grammy-nominated producer and keyboardist who appears on the album as composer, percussionist and drummer. April Brown co-composed the original tracks and appears on Native American-style flutes, drums, percussion, and vocals. Tom Shinness appears on guitars and cello and Richard Cushing plays sitar on one track."Elders & Ancestors" begins with the title track, a 14 1/2 minute instrumental piece with a strong Native American influence. Native flutes, hand percussion instruments, wordless vocals, and keyboards create a peaceful and calming atmosphere with a rhythmic pulse that is both infectious and hypnotic. â€œAdriftâ€ is more ambient and a bit darker. Very sparse and understated, the simple keyboard lines and occasional wordless vocals are mysterious yet soothing. â€œBreatheâ€ begins with the sounds of birds, wind chimes, and the ocean - all very relaxing. When the music starts, it is lightly rhythmic and sometimes playful. Aprilâ€™s lyrics and vocals send the piece soaring, as do Paulâ€™s keyboards and Cushingâ€™s sitar. At almost 12 1/2 minutes, the piece has plenty of time to unfold at a leisurely pace. â€œSpirit Dreamingâ€ features Aprilâ€™s haunting Native flutes and vocals surrounded by beautiful keyboard washes and enhancements. â€œSonnetâ€ begins as a beautiful piece for Native flute and keyboards, gradually evolving into a love song to both life and a beloved person. Tom Shinnessâ€™ poignant cello adds to the deep emotions expressed in the piece. â€œWayfaring Strangerâ€ has always been one of my favorite folk songs, and this 10+ minute version is one of my favorites. â€œAgreliaâ€™s Lullabyâ€ brings the album to a close with a beautiful instrumental piece enhanced by the sound of thunder and rain in the background.Very best wishes to April Brown and many thanks to Agreliaâ€™s Castle for sharing their journey with the world. Iâ€™m sure many will be very positively affected by this music. Recommended!

"Fall Into Winter" is Bryan Carriganâ€™s sixth solo album of original electronic music and is quite possibly his most compelling recording to date. Two years in the making, the album could be described as seasonal (winter), but is NOT a holiday album per se. Carrigan says: â€œNo jingle bells or Christmas covers were harmed in the making of this CD.â€ Capturing the feeling of winter rather than the events that take place during that time period, Carriganâ€™s music provides what could be considered the ultimate â€œchillâ€ album! He expresses the cold and darker tones of that time of year, but also the stillness, beauty, and quiet reflection that seem to come with the slower pace of the season. Well, except for the holiday part, but this music can provide an antidote to the frantic pace that the holidays can bring. The album consists of eleven tracks that range from 3 - 6 1/4 minutes plus a 22 1/2 closing track. Carrigan has worked on the music for a very large number of films, television programs, and recordings in a variety of roles, so this isnâ€™t the kid down the street who bought a new keyboard and proclaimed himself a musician. Carrigan is a master of electronic music and of creating moods and atmospheric qualities. The sound quality is crystal clear but never harsh, and the individual instrumental â€œvoicesâ€ are rich and distinctive.I really donâ€™t have a favorite track on "Fall Into Winter." I love the whole album and think it needs to be listened to in its entirety. It begins with â€œThe Calm Before,â€ a haunting yet very beautiful piece that chills to the bone. I can almost feel an icy wind on my face as I imagine standing in the midst of the profound quiet of snow all around. This is NOT a winter scene out of Southern CA! â€œTellings From the Ravenâ€ is a bit more melodic, but just a bit. The rhythm is lively and gently propels the piece as layers of instrumentation flow over the top of it. â€œDeepest of Nightâ€ goes very dark and still with occasional sparks of light that I would assume represent stars. There is a mysterious cast to the piece that isnâ€™t at all threatening or frightening - just dark and intense. â€œA Hundred Winters Oldâ€ expresses majesty and awe while creating feelings of bitter cold and pristine beauty. â€œSnow Dayâ€ is much lighter and more magical, and includes the infectious sound of childrenâ€™s laughter. â€œAfter the Rainâ€ is very still and peaceful - guitar with atmospheric sounds. The playful rhythm that runs through all of â€œBehind the Wallâ€ lightens the mood and counters the darker instrumentation - a magical mix! The epic â€œComparing Snowflakesâ€ is a study in subtlety and stillness, sustaining a mood of quiet chilliness for well over twenty-two minutes.Bryan Carrigan has created a classic masterpiece in the ambient/ new age genres, one that Iâ€™m sure will garner him many â€œBest Ofâ€ awards for the year!  Very highly recommended!

I had never had mulberries before, so I wasn't sure what to expect. I have to say that they were and are a very happy surprise! I'm not a big snacker, but quite often around 10 PM I just want something sweet before bed, so these are great. They are kind of like a raisin, but a little bigger, crunchier, and not as sweet - and look more like a berry. In addition to eating them right out of the resealable bag, I have sprinkled them on top of fruit and vanilla yogurt, and that's REALLY good for breakfast. I love that there are no additives and that these are sun-dried without chemicals. The list of ingredients is quite simple: "certified organic mulberries (morus alba)." That's it. There is a multitude of health benefits from these berries, so there are so many reasons to try them. I received a free sample bag in exchange for an unbiased review.

I LOVE CINNAMON! It's probably my favorite spice, but I had no idea what I was missing until I tried this Kazu Organic Ceylon Cinnamon Powder. I didn't know there were various kinds of cinnamon, but this one is amazing. It is much richer and deeper in flavor than the spices in a can at the supermarket and is also a much finer powder. It is lighter in color than the usual cinnamon, but it is the flavor that makes such a difference. I have used it on toast with some sugar, sprinkled on fruit and yogurt for breakfast, and baked it into bread pudding, and I am truly "wowed" by the flavor. Yum! Buh-bye Schilling and Spice Islands! I also love Kazu's approach to business and marketing - using the highest quality ingredients, reducing their carbon footprint, and using socially and environmentally ethical methods to grow and process their products. Once the free sample I received for reviewing is gone, I'll be ordering some more of their Cinnamon!

What I liked most about Hyacinth Girls is that it's a more complicated novel than it appears to be at first blush. Yes, it is a story about bullying, but it's a story that treats the issue in a subtler manner, which I think is to its advantage. Bullying is a far more complex issue than it's sometimes given credit for being, and I think this book poses some deeper questions that have a great deal or relevance even to those of us whose teenage years are in the rearview mirror. Some spoilers to follow.One big thing to this novel's credit is that it doesn't strive to make any of its characters entirely likable. This doesn't mean that they're sympathetic, but I admire when authors make their characters flawed and even downright unlikable, because there seems to be a trend today in publishing that demands that we love all characters all the time--unless they're the bad guys of course. How does this have any resonance with the real world, and how does this make literature interesting? Human beings are complicated and often contradictory, so I tend to be far more invested in books that reflect this side of human nature.Both Callie and Rebecca fall under this umbrella. There were times when I felt sorry for them and wanted to them to overcome their obstacles, and there were times when I was disgusted with them. Rebecca suffers from a serious case of willful blindness throughout much of the novel, but isn't this a danger with most parents? It's hard to see your own children objectively, especially when you've known them since the moment they were born and, therefore, tend to think you know everything that's on their minds. I liked that Rebecca sometimes hadn't the faintest clue what was really going on with Callie, especially because I find this very realistic. It's not just that parents will see what they want to see, it's also that, as in Rebecca's case, parents are sometimes so stressed about doing the right thing and being the best parent they can be that to face up to any shortcomings in their children would mean they would have to face their own failures. That's painful, to say the least.As for Callie, though she isn't a perfect person, I did feel sorry for her. It was easy to understand why she felt as trapped as she did, and even why she reacted as she did--not that it made her behavior excusable. Adults tend to acknowledge that children feel intense pressure to conform, but they often fail to understand that they face a lot of the same pressures. After all, how many of us tend to tailor our behaviors because we know that if we act otherwise we'll upset someone we don't want to upset. In some ways, we're all pretending, and I think the strength of the book is that it explores this theme. It's not just children who bully, but adults as well, and I think that's a very important point. There are many times when adults tell children one thing and then act in a manner that's contrary, and I think it would behoove us all as a society if we thought deeply about that.Unfortunately, for me, the book slipped on a downward slope toward the end. It's not so much that I wanted a worst-case scenario ending, but the ending that I did get felt a little too sitcom for me, wrapping everything up in a neat box. Yes, the characters suffer and there are consequences, but the ending seemed to me to be stretching a bit.

Wow. Absolutely, scorchingly phenomenal. Easily one of the best young adult books I have ever read."...men have the necessary experience and intelligence to choose better for you than you could choose for yourself."And that, dear reader, will be the jumping-off point for my entire review, which will contain spoilers because there is so much about this book that begs for discussion. I highly recommend it to anyone looking for a searing, brilliant depiction of what it means to grow up female, but don't read any further if you don't want the details of this brilliant book revealed to you.If you're still with me, buckle up. This is going to be a very long, bumpy ride.First off, I think it's important to note that I read a ton on the subject of feminism. I am a proud feminist, and I'm open about that--I don't shy away from "feminist" as a label. The reason I mention this is not so much because this is a feminist novel (which it most certainly is), it's because, given that I've read many books on feminism, coupled with endless articles on feminist issues, this book was, for me, like a distillation of everything I've read about feminism. Trying to shove this book into a genre box might result in it being called dystopian or some other variation of sci-fi, but in my opinion this book isn't that at all. It's something of a satire, holding a mirror up to society and relaying what the mirror depicts with some embellishment. Yet while this book does exaggerate things, it also doesn't. Maybe all the women in the world aren't designer babies, and maybe they aren't being raised in schools where they're explicitly taught that their only worth lies in what they can provide to a man, yet, in many ways, that is exactly what's happening in our society today.There are so many themes that run throughout this book, but the strongest one centers on the girls' physical experience. Their school isn't a school so much as it is a factory churning out designer sex objects. The girls at this school can't read, and why should they? Their only real purpose is to be ornamental. They're weighed on a daily basis, subject themselves to painful and uncomfortable "beauty" procedures, agonize over their clothing and makeup choices, and constantly compare themselves to other women, wondering how they measure up. That doesn't sound all that far-fetched, does it? The women of the present day routinely wax themselves, use copious amounts of beauty products, get plastic surgery, and bleach unspeakable areas in order to meet an undefined standard of beauty. As the Father (who I think is basically patriarchy personified) reminds the girls in a video they are shown in class, "...you may be perfectly designed, but there is always room for Improvement."This relentless pursuit of an unattainable ideal of perfection seeps into every facet of the girls' lives, including how they interact with one another. Every time the girls would gather to do one of their tear-down sessions, in which they insulted themselves and then waited for the others to protest, I couldn't help but think of the searingly hilarious Inside Amy Schumer skit "Compliments", in which a group of female friends literally cannot cope when one of their fellow friends accepts a compliment on her jacket with a simple, "Thank you!" That skit got so much attention because it, like this book, is tapping into something that's a regular, everyday occurrence for many women.And yet, even though the women in this book are supposedly perfect, genetically engineered and produced to be beautiful, thin, and free of any "undesirable" traits, they are never quite good enough. Girls and women deemed defective are sent Underground, where they serve as lab rats for male scientists who are always working to continue to refine their techniques, always attempting to create better models. Again, I see so many parallels here between the book's world and our world. Cosmetic companies are multi-billion dollar industries, and if women didn't feel they had "flaws" they needed to "correct", would those industries make anywhere near as much money as they now do? At younger and younger ages, girls are being coached in "self-care" in the form of using a variety of beauty products. Fashion magazines and TV shows are awash in advice about how women can improve their looks, what exercises they can do to fix their "problem" areas, what clothing they can wear that will highlight or camouflage their thighs, hips, bust. There's nothing wrong with wanting to care for yourself, with enjoying cosmetics or other enhancements, and with dressing in a way that makes you feel attractive. What is wrong is the way the conversation is framed, the underlying messages that "there is always room for Improvement."Is it any wonder that the girls in the book have such unhealthy attitudes about their own bodies? Eating disorders have been normalized to the extent that the girls are given medication to help them throw up if they've ingested foods from the "Fatgirl buffet". They take other drugs to help them regulate their caloric intake, and if they gain weight they are sentenced to exercise on machines that scream abuse at them to "encourage" them to work harder. Sound like any TV shows you can think of? How about "fitspo"? The message that fat is bad is relentlessly drummed into the girls, in the form of movies (The Eternal Fat girl), songs ("Big girls...don't get the guy-yi-yi"--by a group called "the slutz", no less), and social media. The girls constantly take pictures of themselves and upload them to their "MyFace" pages. In class, they step into glass boxes while the other girls examine their bodies and deliver advice and criticism, their voices scrambled to ensure anonymity. They're encouraged to use sites in which they pit themselves against one another to figure out who's hotter, who wears an outfit better. Again, sound like something you could easily find on the internet nowadays?The book's tackling of sex is brilliant as well, because it makes so little sense. Divided into three tiers, every girl will ultimately become a companion (read: wife and mother), a concubine (essentially a sex slave), or a chastity. Girls aspiring to companion status are supposed to be beautiful and have flawless figures, but they're also supposed to be "good girls". They're never supposed to refuse the whims of the men they serve, but they aren't supposed to make themselves available to anyone but the man who chooses them, and they are certainly not supposed to express any of their own desires or wishes. Concubines are expected to fulfill the every whim of the men who hire them, but they have no agency over their own bodies or their own desires. And the chastities are just that, chaste, responsible for schooling the younger girls and taking care of other background tasks. When you think about the mixed messages we send both young girls and boys about sex, is it any wonder it's so confusing to them?TV doesn't get a pass here either. One of the girls' favorite shows is Chilling with the Carmichaels, a show that chronicles the adventures of cassie and carrie (an aside: the lack of capitalization when it comes to female names is another brilliant device, yet another reminder of how little these individual girls matter). When Charles, carrie's Inheritant, feels she's being too chummy with a friend of his, he breaks her nose and two ribs on a live broadcast, an event about which the girls are incredibly blasÃ©. "He's yummy. I'd let him beat me any day," one of them remarks. If that doesn't disturb you, I don't know what will. On another show, two companions rip into women who choose to bottle feed rather than breastfeed. They're quick to add that, while breastfeeding is best, women should be sure to do it in private. kate, who received a number one ranking seven years prior, is rewarded with her own show, What kate Did Next. And, of course, the girls are exposed to pornography, because they're expected to know how to please their men, after all. Everything they watch centers around women tearing one another down, or submitting to brutality at men's hands, or ostentatious displays of wealth, all the better to encourage them to work hard to become number one, so that they'll be chosen by a man with high social standing.Lest it seem that this book is one-sided, life isn't a picnic for all of the men either. (And LGBTQ people don't exist, because they're labelled "Aberrant", and the geneticists ruthlessly work to engineer them right out of existence.) We don't see as much of what non-conforming men go through because the book takes place in a closed environment in which men are prohibited, but it is there. Darwin, the choicest Inheritant, chafes against his father's strictures, yet laps up his father's praise like a kitten would a bowl of cream. He suffers several injuries throughout the course of the book, all of which are implicitly attributed to his father, and yet Darwin would stop at nothing to please the man. Even so, he never quite measures up, even when he does exactly as his father wants him to do, destroying freida, about whom he seems to care. As he and his father leave, his father feigns fondness for his son by tousling his hair, pulling away in disgust and saying, "Hair gel? You can be such a girl at times, Darwin." Boys are constantly fed the message that to be feminine is the worst of all insults, that they should strive to attain a hyper-masculine standard. Even boys, the book shows, suffer at the hands of patriarchy.I'm astounded by all this book manages to pack into its pages. It is not an easy or pleasant read, but it is wholly compelling, and I think it's a necessary. I read a lot of YA lit, and so much of it contains messages that I find so damaging, messages about girls rescuing "broken" boys, tacitly accepting their abuse. Messages that the sexiest men are hyper-masculine bad boys, not the soulful, thoughtful guy living next door. Books like Only Ever Yours are so necessary precisely because myths about girlhood and boyhood continue to be perpetuated, even though every day there is mounting evidence of the damage it does to boys and girls alike.

I have mixed feelings about this book. On the one hand, it kept me turning pages, needing to uncover the layers of mystery buried within it. It was suspenseful at times, but it also had some lovely descriptive passages about the setting, and I enjoyed its contemplative moments. However, in the end, it just didn't come together for me the way I would have liked it to. Spoilers to follow as some major plot points are relevant to why the book didn't work as well as I felt it should have.This book is really a combination of two things: a suspense novel and a novel about the difficult intricacy of a romantic relationship. This sort of makes it sound like romantic suspense, which it definitely isn't. Both the suspense element and the psychology of the romance worked for me, but they didn't mesh together. In a lot of ways, the suspense part of the book is more there to propel the necessary revelations that will test the strength of Liz's and Dante's bond, and I felt the book was the lesser for it.I liked Liz's character. She's made some serious missteps in her past, and it's left her with a good case of neurosis, something I thought was understandable. I liked the way the book wove together all the complex threads of her life, from her difficult upbringing to her strained marriage to her ambivalence about her relationship with Dante. The weight of Liz's emotions was very real to me, and she felt like a human being, one who was flawed, who had missteps, who did stupid, self-sabotaging things, all while kind of knowing she was sabotaging herself. I thought her portrayal was very complete and felt very authentic, which was definitely the novel's strong point.The weak point was the Root brothers. As I read, I kept waiting for some big revelation, for something to happen that would tie them to Liz's life. A lot of times I felt like maybe the author intended them to be symbolic, like their presence was meant to represent the savagery of the wilderness, a savagery that's meant to force Liz to strip aside all of her justifications and petty self-deceptions, face up to the truth, and let everything out rather than continue to spin webs of lies and omissions. I think that could have worked, but because they were real and not a figment of Liz's imagination, they needed some reason for being where they were and doing what they were doing. I could have bought the randomness of their presence, could have accepted that coincidence was what had led Liz to cross their paths, but their presence feels far too necessary to the narrative for that. Were they not there, would Liz have done the self-examination she did? Would she have been honest with Dante? I'm not convinced she would have, and so in that way the Roots felt more to me like the heavy hand of the author than like characters who made sense in the story. They're like a bridge, stringing together the scenes where Liz stop lying and evading and forces herself to face the music. This robbed something from the book because it made the sense or urgency feel like a plot device rather than something organic to the book.It's a shame because I thought the writing was otherwise strong. I really like novels like this, where I get deep into the psychology of the characters. Liz's story would have been compelling to me without the Roots' presence, and this made the novel feel like it was awkwardly straddling two genres. I think I would have liked it better had the author chosen to let Liz's story shine, had Liz's journey not been so fraught with physical danger, since the mental danger seemed more than enough to carry the story.I didn't dislike this book, but it wasn't everything I wanted it to be either. Still, I do like seeing authors take risks, and I'm also a fan of genre blending and bending. I'd be interested in reading more from this author.

I'm sure most parents can identify with this dilemma: the endless quest to get your kids to eat better. It takes time, patience, and some more patience. One of my biggest tools is involving the kids in menu planning and meal prep, so I am always on the lookout for good children's cookbooks. It's not that they can't use adult cookbooks. They do, but the children's cookbooks we own are laid out in a way that appeals to kids, and they provide additional details and information that can be very helpful to budding chefs.This book is divided into the following sections: Before you Begin, Breakfast, Soups and Salads, Light Bites, Main Meals, Desserts, Cakes and Muffins, Cookies and Bars, Bread, and Party Time. Naturally, my kids always race right to the dessert sections, and I let them indulge in that. Then we start planning dinners, which diverts their attention to sections like Main Meals or Light Bites, and I let them choose a recipe that they want to try. So far, we've tried three recipes from the book:- Lamb Kebabs - We subbed chicken here because we didn't have lamb, and we omitted the apricots from the couscous because we didn't have those either, but otherwise we followed the recipe. The chicken and vegetables were delicious. The marinade gave them a nice, light citrusy flavor with a subtle hint of spice. The kids initially balked at the idea of raisins, nuts, and onion in their couscous, but after explaining to them that it was like a couscous salad, my five-year-old announced that it was a really good. And it was. The sweetness of the raisins and crunch of the nuts added a nice contrast to the chicken and vegetables.- Bruschetta - My eleven-year-old likes tomatoes and mozzarella drizzled with olive oil and balsamic vinegar, so this recipe caught her eye. She flipped the page and found the "Four ways with bruchetta" section, realized we had everything we needed for the crisscross ham version and asked if she could make them. She handled all of the prep herself, and then I popped them under the broiler. They were delicious, and she asked if she could make them again the next day. We've since eaten them one other time. The quality of ham and cheese that you use will make a big difference in the outcome, but what I really liked about this recipe was that it got my daughter interested in and motivated to make her own meal.- Sausage hotpot - My husband and I loved this. My five-year-old chose it, and he did give it a fair go, though he mostly stuck to the sausage. My daughter wasn't happy about the beans, but my husband and I pretty much vacuumed it up. I used Granny Smith apples, which gave the dish nice flavor, and by the time they came out, they were soft, tender, and not too sweet, an excellent substitute for something like potatoes. The combination of ingredients sounded a bit strange, but the end result spoke for itself. As we ate the leftovers the next day, I told my husband that the next time I make this dish I'll double the recipe, that way we'll have more leftovers next time around.There are still many other recipes I want to try, and the kids enjoy looking through these. There are lots of bright, appealing pictures of the dishes. This isn't necessary for me, but it does work nicely for the kids because it gets them looking at the end product, observing how all the ingredients work together. In addition to the pictures of the finished dish, each recipe includes pictures of each step, illustrating for children how to chop strawberries for a smoothie, and how to pour marinade over shrimp kebabs. All of the photos are bright, appealing, and pleasing to look at, which makes this book a real pleasure to browse through--just don't do it on an empty stomach, unless you enjoy torturing yourself.The opening section of the book is very nice. Rather than just listing common kitchen tools and gadgets, it has pictures of each, so that kids can see what a whisk or a plastic spatula looks like. The book also includes an explanation of different ways to cook, everything from frying to broiling to grilling, and there's a picture of each method to give kids an idea of what that method looks like in action. There are also illustrations of how to prepare ingredients (chopping, peeling, etc.) and of baking techniques (whisking egg whites, making a piping bake, etc.)This book makes a very welcome addition to our library of kids' cookbook titles, and I think it would make an excellent gift for young chefs-to-be or kids that need a little coaxing to get them more interested in food prep and nutrition.

When you read a book like this, you need to plan on being angry by the time you finish. I thought I was prepared for that. Reading the book description alone was enough to tell me that I was going to be very outraged over the atrocity committed, but it didn't prepare me for the weird legal labyrinth later chapters would describe. Given the current climate as far as police abuse goes in modern-day America, it's becoming increasingly difficult to be convinced that the justice system works. Were it not for events in Cleveland, Ferguson, and New York, I might have thought a crime like that described in this book was an isolated incident. I would say "would that it were", but what happened in New Orleans should never have happened, just as what's happened elsewhere in the U.S. should never have happened. By journalists bringing these events into the light of day, I can only hope that vast changes and improvements are on the horizon.This book is very difficult to read at times, as it should be. Some serious discomfort is what people need to feel in order to be compelled to demand change. There's nothing lurid in this book, but reading the matter-of-fact account of what happened to the victims of the Danziger Bridge assault is stomach-turning. It's the sort of thing you could imagine happening in a warzone, not in a supposedly civilized country with a rule of law. Yes, there were extenuating circumstances, but I don't find them to be an excuse in any way. While I admire those law enforcement officers who stayed behind to help the citizens even as their chain of command collapsed, there is simply no excuse for what happened on the Danziger Bridge. I understand why the officers' defense attorneys took the tack they did, emphasizing how their clients had risked their lives in staying to help out, and describing the trauma and chaos they experienced in the wake of the hurricane, but what they suffered was no different from what the victims suffered, yet none of these innocent people seized assault weapons and opened fire on innocent civilians.And what does it say about our police forces that they are wielding assault weapons, regardless of circumstance? Isn't that a job for the National Guard? Had the officers not had such weapons, maybe at the very least they would have caused a whole lot less pain, suffering, and trauma to the Bartholmew family, to the Madison family, to JJ Brissette. Had they not felt they had such overwhelming firepower at their disposal, maybe they would have taken the time to assess the situation, to shout out a warning to the innocent victims, to do anything but what they did do. Police officers may receive weapons training, but they are nowhere near equipped to be patrolling with assault weapons. That is a job for those with military training, and even they have been known to forget their training and commit horrible acts in the heat of the moment. The NOPD officers had no business whatsoever being armed as they were. It doesn't matter that the department didn't provide them with those weapons. They may as well have, given that they provided the officers with the tactic approval to carry them.Race cannot be taken out of the equation either. The fact is, there is no way of knowing what the officers might have done had a group of white people been crossing the bridge after they received the shots fired call. But the U.S. does need to do some serious soul-searching and does need to vigorously question why members of minorities are so very disproportionately represented in prisons and in prosecution. Greene offers some statistics as to the number of people arrested in the hurricane's aftermath, and the numbers speak for themselves. What does it say about our country when the people who are responsible for large-scale murder on American soil (what happens overseas is a whole other matter that needs a great deal of consideration) fall into one of two categories: mass murderers or police officers? What does it say about our country when whites and minorities use drugs at about the same rates, but prisoners imprisoned on drug-related charges are far and away more likely to be members of a minority?Egregious as what these law enforcement officers did was, what happened in the courts was a massive failure of epic proportions. The fact that one judge could have such enormous power is frankly scary. We love to tout our legal system, to blather on about how great it is that we're judged by a jury of our peers, yet what's the point when a judge can just go right ahead and set aside a jury's verdict? I know those checks are supposed to be there to protect against abuse, but who protects victims against judicial abuse? What Judge Englehardt did comes across as his personal vendetta against the Justice Department, which led to a one-man crusade to right what he saw as DOJ's wrongs. Yet what about the victims of the crime? It's as if their suffering mattered a whole lot less to the judge than did the sweet plea deals some of the offenders received, as if the judge would rather free convicted murderers than stomach the idea that some of those murderers got off with lesser sentences. While I agree that this is a serious flaw in our legal system, it's unconscionable that the victims should have been so repeatedly denied the justice they fought so hard to try to win.This book left me feeling nothing but disgust and fury toward the legal system as a whole. On behalf of the victims, I feel a hopeless sense of desolation. How many times can people be victimized by the very system that purports to protect them? I find it exceedingly hard not to lose faith in our democracy when such undemocratic acts occur. They're an offense against our very country and against the basic ideals of human justice and dignity. If there is any good at all that can come out of these situations it's that maybe, just maybe, Americans will care enough to demand better, that maybe they will decide that ALL human life is worthy of dignity, and that they will fight to ensure that atrocities like this never again happen to another person.

I'm a fan of microfiber clothes in general and like using them for household cleaning and dishwashing. I'd never tried using microfiber dishtowels before, though, so I was eager to see how these would stack up.Laundering them was easy. I did them in hot water along with my other dishtowels and cloths, and dried them on high using the towels setting. They came out looking perfect, and didn't bleed onto my old towels at all. The stripes are nice, and the colors are a little more vivid than the pictures suggests, especially the one with the turquoise/teal stripe running down it. I especially like the look of the charcoal and gray towel.The one thing to know about microfiber if you've never used it before is that it has a tendency to stick to dry skin, which can make it feel strange to handle. These towels are no exception. It's not a major complaint, but they do cling a bit to any rough areas on your hands.I don't plan on using these to scrub as I have smaller, designated microfiber cloths for that, but the thing to know is that the microfibers give cloth very good scrubbing power. I've had my dishcloths for quite some time, and when my mom used them while at my house once, she asked where I got them so she could go out and buy some of her own.Most impressive for me was how nicely these dried my dishes.
