There's something visceral about grinding coffee by hand. I likewise use a mortar and pestle when I grind black pepper.Directions aren't really important here. Pour in beans. Grind. Take out ground coffee. The only thing you really need to know is how to adjust the grind (how coarse).It is easy to use, as I've said. That's technically. Like my dear mortar and pestle, you will get tired. It took two minutes to get enough grounds for one espresso. There are good reasons people have electric grinders.Meanwhile, it doesn't hold many beans. That just the nature of beans; they take up space. This means if you are looking to grind a full pot of eight cups, you'll need to portion off some time. If you are camping, this is your only choice.The trick is to hold the grinder with your left hand (I'm a righty), crank with your right, while wedging the grinder in your gut. I tried positioning it on my counter, but that was more difficult.Consider adding this to your morning routine, or bring it along when traveling. It's less expensive than a fancy electric burr grinder, but only the most discerning taste buds will notice a difference in quality. Incidentally, if you've never made freshly ground coffee at home, you are in for a treat.Anthony Trendlanthonytrendl.com

I love Hot Wheels and I love the characters of DC Comics, so I expected to be excited about receiving DC Comics Hot Wheels.Here's the trouble: None of these cars are plausible. Batman's Batmobile is more like the DRAG-U-LA from the Munsters. And Superman's car? He flies. He can run fast. Why would he need a car? Same thing with the Flash, except without the flying thing.Design-wise, they have a McDonald's Happy Meal look about them, not the usual smartly designed vehicles Hot Wheels usually turns out.The good news is they are actually well-made, largely die-cast metal. Your kids will be free to knock them around and they'll survive (the cars as well as your kids).Unfortunately, this comes across as an attempt to milk fandom for money. We love our superheroes and related products. They should go back to the drawing board and take the job more seriously. However, they look cool in and of themselves, especially the Flash version, so get this and head to the sandbox.Anthony Trendlanthonytrendl.com

Where do I begin? This is not an ordinary book. One of America's greatest novelists chose to only publish one book, "To Kill a Mockingbird." No one knew why and we all wanted more. Wasn't gonna happen. But it did. Here is that book we wanted. Or not.Then there was the yet unsatisfying suspicion that the brilliant Harper Lee may not have approved publication of, "Go Set a Watchman." Or she approved it, but not fully aware. Legally, it has been cleared, and so whatever the motivations and manipulations existed or didn't exist, all of which is acceptible by law. Either way, the book is here.I have one of the two million first copies. Many more will no doubt will be printed. After the initial buzz dies down, we will find out if this will be the classic "To Kill a Mockingbird" is.Lee's writing is similarly toned as her other book. It has the same feel but misses the urgency. Occasionally, Lee draws us in casually, but poetically, as when describing Maycomb:"New people rarely went there to live. The same families married the same families until relationships were hopeless entangled and the members of the community looked monotonously alike."There's so much said in those few words. She describes then small-town Alabama in the 1950s, but it could be small-town Iowa or Massachusetts in the 2010s.Other times, as during a major trial, a tighter edit would serve well."Go Set a Watchman" precedes "To Kill a Mockingbird" in its writing, but its plotline takes us years later. It has been 20 years, and Scout, now an adult, is off to visit Atticus, her dad. She discovers her dad isn't the hero she thought."To Kill a Mockingbird," as I've reviewed, is a love story between Scout and her father as she admired his heroics and love for all."Go Set a Watchman" is like that, but Atticus is more complex than the Atticus she, and we, thought we knew.How so? Take a look at this from chapter 12:  Atticus turned to her. "Scout, you probably don't know it, but the NAACP-paid lawyers are standing around like buzzards down here waiting for things like this to happen.----"  "You mean colored lawyers?"  Atticus nodded...It goes on to examine the state of "Negroes" in the legal world.Atticus tries to educate Scout who is less naive than he thinks. Mind you, he's no Archie Bunker. He's fairer-minded that that, but he's no Meathead either.We also learn about Jem, Calpurnia, and others from "Mockingbird," but this is all about Scout and Atticus, who they were, who they thought each other was, and who they are discovering the other really is. It is extremely honest.Like "To Kill a Mockingbird," "Go Set a Watchman" is forcing discussions of racial conflict, racism, and the context of real life "Go Set a Watchman." While "To Kill a Mockingbird" came out in the midst of the Civil Rights Movement. In fact, it can be argued it was part of move forward.This isn't "Mockingbird." Don't be fooled. Lee created a legendary book there. This is just very, very good. I give it five stars because of how it matters in continuing the national racial dialogue."Go Set a Watchman" was written then but remains relevant now. Racism is racism and people aren't simple good and bad cartoons. Not one of us is pure minded. Not Atticus, not Scout, not Harper Lee and not this reviewer.I fully recommend "Go Set a Watchman" by Harper Lee. Once again, she has changed the landscape of modern American literature. May she change the hearts of we humans as well.Anthony TrendlAmericanSpeechwriter.com

There are a few books writers need. Writer's Digest publishes a few. There's a good dictionary and thesaurus, of course. And if they intend to publish in a Christian market, they need this one, "The Christian Writer's Market Guide 2015-2016: Everything You Need to Get Published."I've long been a customer, going back to when Sally Stuart was publishing it. Now, under the direction of Jerry B. Jenkins, it is better than ever.Jenkins' authority in the matter far extends his massively popular "Left Behind" series. In fact, it precludes it. By then, he had established a bit of a name for himself, and publishing was a little easier. (Note, not "easy," as good writing never is, nor is getting it published, ever.) He had written numerous articles, as-told-tos, and even penned a sports themed comic strip. His bio says 186 books, 21 of which have been NYT bestsellers. He's seen the good, the bad, and the ugly of it all, and that experience informs this book. In other words, be glad that Jenkins is on the job. He's poured his career into writing for and about Christians, and now, he's giving back to the next generation.So, the book? What's it all about?The reason I bought it is the huge directory of places to publish. I love short literary fiction and am looking to sell my stuff. Where? I don't know yet, but in this book are 930 listings. This includes book publishers, agents, and periodicals. There's more, but you get the idea.With each periodical entry, for example, you'll learn where to send what, how much they pay, and other helpful details. You'll see similar entries for book publishers, subsidy publishers, and so on. It is all neatly organized and cross-referenced. Topical listings will help you sort through the 488 pages of gold.There's a large collection of articles like, "Do You Need a Literary Agent," by Dennis E. Hensley. Some appeal to newer writers, and some to more seasoned folks. There's even a glossary to catch you up on the myriad of industry terms. And when you've decided to learn more, there's a thorough bibliography. Whew!The short of it is you need this book. It has no peer. It is all here in one place.My copy is still hot off the press, and I'm already thumbing through it, hoping to find a publisher interested in some Flannery O'Connor meets Twilight Zone fiction.Anthony Trendlanthonytrendl.com

Reviewing this was a strange experience. What? It is only a windshield wiper blade. That's true, but things got complicated.First, when I ordered it, the Chicago area (where I live) was experiencing a two-week onslaught of rain. The blade in question was ragged on my car (a 2003 Corolla) and I was due to replace it.Then the rain stopped. And the pictorial directions made no sense to me.A friend who is no mechanic himself came by and showed me how easy it actually is. To say I was embarrassed understates the matter, but my goal to replace the blade was met. All is good.Unfortunately, I needed to wait another few days before it rained.And, the good news! It works just fine.I'll be watching to see how durable it is and will append my review if necessary.I'm giving it five stars despite the useless directions. My concern is keeping my windows clear.Anthony Trendlanthonytrendl.com

You can buy cheaply made balls or you can get this, the real thing. These have the official MLB approval. That means this is what they use.Everything about it has to match MLB standards: fabric, stitching, texture, color, everything inside the leather. Then there's the weight, and so on.That's what you are buying. The real deal.There's nothing wrong with buying cheaper balls to knock around all summer on any kind of playing surface, but if you want the same ball as Major League Baseball pros use, you need this.Anthony TrendlAnthonyTrendl.com

While these don't taste like real mashed potatoes, they approximate as well as instant mashed potatoes can.What I like about it is that it tastes good enough, is easy to make (and quick) with no real cooking knowledge.I just nuke some water in a bowl, pour in a random amount of potato powder, stir with a fork, and add more powder until it looks like the consistency I like. A little salt and I'm good.If you want real mashed potatoes, go buy some potatoes and prep accordingly. Otherwise, this might be good enough.Anthony Trendlanthonytrendl.com

I carried an early edition of "Butterflies and Moths" around with my as I traipsed about fields near my home, butterfly hunting. I'd find a butterfly (or moth, as the case may be) and approximate which one it was through this guide.The pictures are accurate. Not only will you see the butterfly, but a close up of various parts. There are maps showing where it can be found, a very useful tool when the picture doesn't seem to match. It can help you determine if you have a certain variation, or a very lost butterfly.Though a picture is worth a thousand words, the text found here is equally helpful. There are Latin names, pupae descriptions, eating habits and more. They've been careful not to overwhelm the reader, but there's plenty to whet the reading appetite of any young butterfly hunter.It isn't just for children. Anyone with a garden would be happy to have this as a reference or as curious reading to learn just who has been munching the lettuce.I fully recommend "Butterflies and Moths."Anthony Trendltreefortbooks.com

As a speechwriter, I'm asked to include quotes from noteworthy people. Invariably, my clients see something on Facebook and are convinced it is accurate. It might be, but we all know Albert Einstein didn't say everything attributed to him.That's where Bartlett's Familiar Quotations kicks in. I've been using this since childhood, and now, as it is continually updated, it searches for the balances of classical and new quotes.Among the things Bartlett's does better than some former Star Trek star posting quotable memes on social media is that these are vetted. They are sourced. You know who really said them. Don't speak at a fundraiser and say, "J. K. Rowling said..." when, in fact, it was actually in the Bible, Shakespeare or Bob Dylan. Bartlett's will help you there.Can it be better? Yes. It can be thicker. Make it comprehensive, not merely portable.While for me, this is a tool of the trade, it is also wildly entertaining, inspiring and challenging. There are reasons speakers love using quotes: they say important things well.Whether you want this at your office or on your coffee table, buy Bartlett's.Anthony TrendlAmericanSpeechwriter.com

This is an easy kettle to love. Why? It is exactly what you see. It is a rich blue with silver highlights. As you expect, it whistles when ready.Its modern yet classic look means you'll love it on the stove. The construction is not good looks: it is sturdy. It'll retain heat long enough for a second or third cup.The downside is as with most kettles. You'll need a cloth to pour it. The heat transfers into the handle. Too hot. I still love the kettle, but I hope some engineer resolves this issue someday.Anthony Trendlanthonytrendl.com

This is Easy Cheese in a spray can. Basically, it is cheez whiz in a can. There's no one on any planet who will tell you this is a health food, or that it is in any way good for you. It is what it is.You've got a few options regarding consumption. There's crackers and veggies, or even a sort of ham and cheese sandwich (better than it sounds). There's directly spraying into your mouth (be careful kids). And there's spraying onto a large spoon and having at it.It is a sharp cheddar flavor. It's a little (OK, a lot) greasy, so keep that in mind. You might find that factors into the "too much of a good thing" reality an hour later.Anthony Trendlanthonytrendl.com

Barq's remains one of the few (only?) national root beers with caffeine. For me, that's a plus. It is on the sweeter side, with a vanilla emphasis. It goes back to the 1890s, and it is one of the true original root beer drinks.As hot day drinks go, this can hit the spot. Goes well with hot dogs.Because of the vanilla, it goes well with classic root beer floats. Called a "black cow" here in Chicago, it is made with vanilla ice cream and root beer, traditionally served in a tall frosted glass.Barq's is hardly the only worthy root beer available, but it has a frequent place in my fridge. Watch the price for deals.Anthony Trendlanthonytrendl.com

Hopkins is one of those poets hidden from so many because of his subject matter, yet is considered one of the most influential Victorian poets for his use of word combinations, meter and image.Added to the delicious and poignant poetry is the contemplative nature of it. You'll read about his humility and submission to God, his genuine faith, his desire that his poetry exalt God and not Hopkins himself.Most his work was published posthumously, as late as 1920 or so, and immediately influenced the likes of T.S. Elliot (AKA, the guy who wrote the poem "Cats" is based on and "Wasteland") and his contemporaries.While Walt Whitman and Oscar Wilde were exalting in themselves, and just after Ralph Waldo Emerson and Henry David Thoreau were helping us see creation, Hopkins demonstrated prowess in pointing readers to see the Creator in the creation.Atheists won't agree with him, of course, but he says it so well, they will at least go, "Hmm... if I believed, I could see that... yeah, wow, well put." The Catholics will cheer him on, "Atta boy... yep, that guy's a Jesuit!" Not undone are the Protestants who will be so impressed in agreement they'll be happy he was a Christian.Check out this snippet from "Pied Beauty":Glory be to God for dappled things--For skies of couple-colour as a brinded cow;For rose-moles all in stipple upon trout that swim;Fresh-firecoal chestnut-falls; finches wings;Landscape plotted and pieced--fold, fallow, and plough;And 'all tra'des, their gear and tackle and trim."Those accents are in the original.Delicious to say aloud? You should hear the second verse. His others are as tasty.I fully recommend this book.Anthony Trendlamericanspeechwriter.com

Chips Ahoy! aren't going to be in the annals of great chocolate chip cookies, and yet I love them. No one will confuse them with a homemade Tollhouse Chocolate Chip, for example.Instead Chips Ahoy! is more like a guilty pleasure. Me? I'm snacking on a bag I snuck into the library while working.These are crunchy. If you are into the soft cookie texture and taste (I'm not), look elsewhere.To best appreciate them, have a glass of milk ready. They make them better. No, I don't know why.Anthony Trendlanthonytrendl.com

The Oxford Dictionary of Quotations gets it right.My day job requires I know the best sources for quotations. A good number of the ones on the web are poorly or inaccurate sourced. Too often, the quote is wrong, or the speaker is not who they claim.There are two ways to use this. One is to read and remember. That's slow-going but very entertaining.  The other is to become comfortable with the Index. That's hardly a quick thing, but it will help you refine the quote you want. If you've ever used something like Strong's Concordance, this will be familiar territory.When you aren't researching, you will enjoy just opening the book wherever and reading. You'll be exposed to new writers (new to you, that is) whose ideas match or capably challenge your own. Anytime I look in here, I learn something.Anthony TrendlAmericanSpeechwriter.com

In "Feral Cities: Adventures with Animals in the Urban Jungle" Tristan Donovan looks at the range of animals that have come to reside in cities where they aren't native.  He looks at the animal's behavior -- why it does what it does and how it can survive in places we might at first think unlikely.An immediate thought I had when I saw the title, "Feral Cities" was of cities with an abundance of cats. Largo di Torre Argentina in Rome came to mind, as did perhaps some random ghost town which might have had cats overtake whatever was left. But, cats are one animal. And there are a lot of cities which are abandoned or which simply cannot handle the multitude of creatures. He broadens the usual definition of feral, and includes any animal making a new home in an area where we might not expect.Meanwhile, there are famously infested cities, like New York City, with arguably more rats than people.In my own community, in a suburb 35 miles west of Chicago, coyotes and red foxes have started showing up with greater frequency. The city is trying to sort out humane ways of managing this, of course, but small pets, like dogs, have been lost.Coyotes, for example, Donovan points out, are not just showing up in suburbs relatively close to the woods. They are in Chicago itself, as well as Miami (and elsewhere).Donovan's writing style is part documentary and part feature journalist, with a storytelling bent. This makes it an easy read, grabbing your curiosity while you learn something interesting.I fully recommend "Feral Cities: Adventures with Animals in the Urban Jungle" by Tristan Donovan.Anthony Trendl

I have mixed feelings about Dad's Old Fashioned Root Beer. It is a loose, easy drinking root beer, but reminds me of root beer flavored hard candy.The flavor is light, with vanilla in the foreground. It can be a little syrupy, with a root beer candy taste.It's not the root beer you want for a root beer float (called a black cow where I live). Too sweet for that.It is a good for a quick cold glass, but a second might be too much.Anthony Trendlanthonytrendl.com

I use Figaro Hickory Liquid Smoke at home when I'm in a pinch, like when I'm unexpectedly out of wood, or cooking in the kitchen. It works well enough, although it has a salty-vinegary over-taste if you use a lot.When I need just a dash, this works well, but any recipe needs less salt accordingly. Because it is liquid, compensate by reducing other liquids when possible. The liquid is mostly water and can leave your burgers sloppy.Your best choice is real hickory wood. Figure out the timing and quantity for whatever dish, and go that route. If you are cooking inside, this is a good, but imperfect choice.Having a few bottles handy will ensure you are never mid-recipe without the sauce.Anthony Trendlanthonytrendl.com

Many of you know the Corduroy story because you, like I, grew up with it. The rest of you are wondering if you should buy this classic. Don Freeman wrote and drew a masterpiece: it is worthy to join the other books on your shelf.The plot is simple: A little girl wants her mom to buy a stuffed bear. Her mom is trying to watch her expenses and says no. Besides, she says, he's missing a button. Corduroy, that night, sets off through the store to find the button.Another day, the girl comes back and buys him with her own money (with her mom's permission).The girl is obedient and the mother is firm and kind. No whining, no trouble making. This is just good ol' family warmth.I fully recommend "Corduroy" by Don Freeman.Anthony Trendlanthonytrendl.com

I'm killing a 5.5 oz box as I write. I love Cap'n Crunch.I grew up with it. You know the scene: Saturday morning, 1970s, Scooby Doo is on. I've got a box of Cap'n Crunch and a glass of milk. That's right, I eat 'em dry. Crunchier that way.Apparently, there's a load of vitamins in them. 25% of a lot of stuff. Plenty of sugar too. I'm not a dietitian and won't pretend to know how good these are nutritionally. I'm just telling you they are tasty.Oh, and the Cap'n? His real name is Horatio Magellan Crunch. I looked it up. The internet knows everything.Anthony Trendltreefortbooks.com

Salt plus nuts. Add beer. Happy.Make those nuts cashews. Ecstatic.That's where the Planters Cashew Halves and Pieces come into play. These are roasted, not raw, with just enough salt.You get the idea. I like cashews a lot. When I was a kid, they were too expensive for us to have regularly, so we lived on peanuts. While I love peanuts, cashews are better.About these in particular, they are halves and pieces. Come on, if you are just munching them, do you care if they are whole? I don't. The only time I do is if I'm serving them at a party. If it's just me, I'm good.I buy the smaller container for the freshness factor. Once opened, they start losing their magic. I like having some ready mid-day when I need a boost but don't want to ruin dinner, or when I've fired up the grill.Anthony Trendlanthonytrendl.com

Get the mix of sea salt and iodized salt. This is coarser, which, for my preference, is better on burgers and steaks.Morton is an old brand you probably know. The real question is if you like all three features: that this is sea salt, iodized, and coarse.I grill often, and use a lot of salt especially when making a salt encrusted roast (slow cooked, juicy and delicious). While I keep a larger one ready, I like this smaller one for when I'm making burgers or certain steaks (when a quick sprinkle is enough). The good thing is salt doesn't go bad so long as you keep it dry.Anthony Trendlanthonytrendl.com

Get the mix of sea salt and iodized salt. This is coarser, which, for my preference, is better on a roast.Morton is an old brand you probably know. The real question is if you like all three features: that this is sea salt, iodized, and coarse.This is a two-pack (I keep wanting to say, 'Tupac' but hip-hop music has zip to do with this review). If you use salt sparingly, this is more than enough. I grill often, and use a lot of salt especially when making a salt encrusted roast (slow cooked, juicy and delicious). The good thing is salt doesn't go bad so long as you keep it dry.Anthony Trendlanthonytrendl.com

I sought out this book as research as I write eulogies for clients. I expected merely a collection of eulogies spoken at the event of someone's death. There's that, but so much more.Part of what's here are the eulogies given at the deceased's memorial service. Others are announcements, like Bobby Kennedy announcing the death of MLK. There's Sandburg discussing Lincoln, who he never met. There's Twain remembering his daughter who died at age 24.There's also poetry by Gerard Manley Hopkins, John Donne, John Dryden, and so many other classics. There's a few even the most well-read reader might not know but will love.Yes, I read this with my clients in mind, but I also read it selfishly. My heart feels broader and deeper for having read this.Anthony TrendlAmericanSpeechwriter.com

Anyone remotely serious about BBQ has invariably watched one of those PBS series on grilling and BBQing and has learned a little of the history. This is particularly true of Steven Raichlen's shows. But when it comes to feeding that curiosity through books, mostly we consume tomes on technique and recipes. That's great -- gotta know the best way to smoke a large roast without drying it out or how to keep fish from falling apart.Until now. Until Tim Miller's "Barbecue: A History (The Meals Series)." Miller's a historian, not a chef. While he obviously loves 'Q, he knows what a proper history is as well.Miller gets through the types of barbecue, the American culture of it, and what BBQ is like globally. But he also has a strong focus on barbecue from the 1800s onward, when the American culture and industry really took off, from random stands to complete restaurants emphasizing some nuance of this great cuisine.Particularly interesting are the stories behind known brands, like KC Masterpiece. A sauce was developed by a physician who sold it in Kansas City. The success led to a small, but growing chain of restaurants. Bad business decisions were made, fostered by a mix of ignorance of how to run a restaurant and family in-fighting, and now, today, there are no restaurants left. The sauce exists, of course, in several varieties. Miller tells the tale of Smokey Bones, Famous Dave's and others.A fascinating read for the BBQ fan from start to finish. I fully recommend "Barbecue: A History (The Meals Series)" by Tim Miller.Anthony Trendlanthonytrendl.com

I'm killing a 5.5 oz box as I write. I love Cap'n Crunch.I grew up with it. You know the scene: Saturday morning, 1970s, Scooby Doo is on. I've got a box of Cap'n Crunch and a glass of milk. That's right, I eat 'em dry. Crunchier that way.Apparently, there's a load of vitamins in them. 25% of a lot of stuff. Plenty of sugar too. I'm not a dietitian and won't pretend to know how good these are nutritionally. I'm just telling you they are tasty.Oh, and the Cap'n? His real name is Horatio Magellan Crunch. I looked it up. The internet knows everything.Anthony Trendltreefortbooks.com

I have a relatively low salt diet and thought the Low Sodium V8 would be worth a try. The short review? Awful.Some things need more salt than others. I love V8. I have a 11.5 oz can next to me as I type. While I don't have a direct medical need (no orders from my doctor) to reduce my salt, I try to keep it low. It made sense to give the Low Sodium version a try.There's nothing complicated to understand. Without the same amount of salt, V8 is nasty.Anthony Trendlanthonytrendl.com

Nick Vandome has been writing simple how-tos for software for years. "Photoshop Elements 13 in easy steps: For Windows and Mac" accomplishes that as well.This is for beginners. Photoshop Elements is, of course, a simpler version of the complete Photoshop.Inside Photoshop Elements is an array of tools. These range from creating layers to adjusting color to fixing less than perfect photos. Despite this being the lesser version, there's still more in Photoshop Elements than most people realize or know how to employ.Vandome shows you systematically how to use them. He says the steps are easy. They are. He mixes screen shots and text to explain step-by-step what's required to do what you like.One thing you might find as I have -- learning more about the tools has given me ideas for my own photos.Anthony Trendlanthonytrendl.com

I'm upgrading from the Johnston & Murphy Melton Oxford (see my review there) which I enjoyed thoroughly. These Greenwich Oxfords are fantastic, albeit slightly large at the same size as the Meltons.As a slightly flamboyant wingtip, these are stylish yet conservative. As I see clients, I'm pleased knowing that I've taken care to look professional. The stitching and cuts are consistent -- I'm confident they'll hold despite me knocking them around.As these are better quality shoes, there's a break-in period. For me, this matters as these are slightly larger than my Meltons (maybe a quarter size), and I'll need them to fit well over long periods of time.They are comfortable and, as the description says, there's an insert to absorb moisture.Overall, I'm pleased. I expect to use them for years to come.(reviewing size 6, black)Anthony TrendlAmericanSpeechwriter.com

To coincide with the release of Superman's 75th anniversary in 2013, DC wanted to make a grand spectacle story of the Man of Steel in comics by using an epic team to coincide with that idea.  Look no further than DC's biggest names in comics currently than Batman writer Scott Snyder and mega-hyper-superstar artist/co-publisher Jim Lee to do the trick.  With a team this massive and a massive story to tell in 9 issues does it live up to the hype?  No, but it's still a fun read.  This review will be a little bit spoiler-ish to explain the general plot, but nothing too major.Collecting all 9 issues, SUPERMAN UNCHAINED begins in a flashback to 1945 where we see the bombing on Nagasaki and notice the nuclear bomb in the history books isn't really a bomb but something else entirely.  Fast forward to modern day where Superman is trying in all his power to stop eight falling satellites from plummeting to Earth's atmosphere and killing people from the debris.  It appears a cyber terrorists group called Ascension might be responsible for the satellites falling, but Superman thinks Lex Luthor might be the real culprit.  Looking into who or what really brought down the satellites, Superman finds out another party might be in on the incident called the Machine, a secret black ops division of the government lead by general Lane that has been defending and controlling events throughout America since the 1930s.  And one of the Machines greatest weapons is Wraith, an alien similar and more powerful than Superman who's been working for the American government for 70+ years including the one reasonable for the Nagasaki bomb.  Who really brought down the satellites?  Ascension?  The Machine?  Lex Luthor?  Maybe all three?  Either way, Superman will give it his all to fight figure who did this and even get some help from the Justice League to do it.With an epic creative team, you need to create an epic story that Snyder and Lee handle reasonably well.  UNCHAINED is equal parts action heavy, character building, and metaphorical as ever could be; with additional handles on all aspects of the Superman mythos under story while dealing with the current New 52 continuity and being a stand-alone tale.  So all of Superman's list of characters like Lois Lane, Jimmy Olsen, Perry White, Lex Luthor, and a few others make appearances, while still holding firm so some the New 52 Superman's personality traits reasonably well.  Snyder's work on darker material like Batman, American Vampire, and current Image series, Wytches, are his suitable options, but his work on lighter material like Superman is handled pretty well for Superman's character, as well as the numerous other characters like Lois Lane being the tough reporter she is, Luthor being the cool, calm, and collected evil genius, and yes: Batman gets some of the best times to shine (what did you expect from the current Bat-writer?).  And the new addition of Wraith is a decent and likeable character as we see him being a semi-mentor figure (you have to read to find out what I mean).  So overall, Snyder makes a story that is gripping, massive in action and scale, and just what Superman means to the beacon of hope with his own touches to what a Superman story could be.Since Jim Lee is the artist, it should come as no surprise that he is still one of the best artists in the industry for a good reason.  Sure the comic was delayed for months because of his slow drawing style (9 issues were done from June 2013 till November 2014).  Every detail, done to the littlest scratch is done in full by Lee, with massive splash pages of kinetic energy ripping off the page.  The epic 6-page foldout from issue #1 (which is not part of the deluxe edition sadly), saving the worlds tallest building in Dubai,to the vastness of the Batcave and Fortress of Solitude, to the fight with Wraith taking place all over Earth and the Moon, and Batman fighting Wraith that Bat-fans go hog wild; Lee's art will not disappoint, which is also in thanks to long time inker Scott Williams.  I do think there are parts of Lee's art that look a little rushed by comparison to many of his other works, but that's only something diehard fans will notice.  Additional art is handled nicely by Dustin Nguyen on the backup stories and flashback sequences.So although I liked this series, I'm only giving it a 4-star rating.  A few of the flaws go toward some of the changes in the story.  One of which is the massive change for Wraith, who readers will get to know for a while throughout the first half of the story, then he does a complete 180-character change and he becomes one-dimensional and reasoning is narrow minded; his character feels like it was forcefully changed and it didn't make sense.  Another aspect one that is amongst the many themes in the story, the first being time.  This theme has been covered in past Superman tales, but it doesn't add because: 1)it's comics; these characters have been around 75 years and they do not age.  I get Snyder's concept, but I doubt the theme he introduces will ever come up again because comics will never get to the point he references and 2)we already have the Legion of Super-Heroes to show that Superman's influence goes a long way for time (like say the year 3000 or so).  And the other theme that Snyder introduces goes against many of the ideas he uses throughout the story at the ending.  It felt a little anticlimactic.As for this hardcover deluxe edition, under the dust jacket is a blank black board (why can't DC make a decent board cover?).  The book is sewn/glued binding and has a lot of pages for the buck.  Unfortunately for the binding, there are times the book suffers from gutter loss, not in the wording balloons, but Lee's jaw-dropping art.  Some of those splash pages cannot be presented properly because of the loss in some of the art.  It's only a few pieces I felt were lost, but still.  As for extras, if I counted right, there are 55 alternative covers! With most of issue #1's script with some of Jim Lee's rough sketches.  So there are some nice extras here.  And as I mentioned before, the regular comic issue #1 had a 6-page foldout of Superman busting through a satellite whereas that is NOT included in this deluxe edition.  So any of you fans who own the regular comic, you do have bragging rights.Even with one of the hottest writers and artist on one of the biggest characters in comics, SUPERMAN UNCHAINED is an enjoyable romp that fans of the Man of Steel will enjoy, as well as feast on Jim Lee's rich art.  The problems with the ending and some of the themes do hamper this story though.  I do not think it was one of the strongest Superman tales that would go in a top 10 or 20 Superman stories ever told, but this is still an enjoyable and lush book for new and old fans.

Batman the Animated Series is widely considered one of the best comic animated television shows of all time, even among some of the best regular animated shows.  That is quite a feat.  I am a part of those who give it such praise because I am a part of those 90's kids who faithfully watched the show all the time.  During the time of the shows air time, a comic book series was published to coincide with the show like many marketing ventures would do.  Now most projects that tie-in to advertise usually fail to match the same material, but this comic series did carry on a good continuity with the show.  So after being out of print for some time now, the original comic series has returned and guess what?  It's still pretty good.BATMAN ADVENTURES VOL.1 collects issues #1-10 that consist of stories that are stand alone tales of Batman taking on numerous classic rogues like Penguin, Catwoman, Scarecrow, Clayface, Killer Croc, Riddler, and Joker; with some familiar faces like Alfred, Robin, detective Bullock, and Gotham report Summer Gleason.  There are some stories that loosely connect to an over-arching plot (say issues 1 and 2 lead-into issue 3), but these are done-in-one stories.There isn't much I can say about that.  Kelley Puckett wrote a good majority of these issues with Martin Pasko doing scripts with issues #4 and #5.  The following stories include Penguin stealing money for a charity scheme, Catwoman stealing jewelry (as usual), T.V. reporter Summer Gleason being used by Clayface, and Bruce Wayne being framed for murder is some examples.  Puckett follows the animated series greatly by being for all ages, yet keeping some of the darker elements of the show like blood, violence, and poetic justice/cryptic endings just right for comic readers.  One story with Scarecrow creating fear gas that makes people illiterate has a fascinating ending that really stood out for me.  Even the voice of the characters match the show enough where you can hear the voice actors lines when reading.As for art, Ty Templeton and Rick Burchett do majority of the shows Bruce Timm-style mockup drawings reasonably well.  All the bold details, noir black backgrounds, and touches of cartoony expressions are handled with care.The collection has zero additional material, even to the point of no advertisements in the back.  One slight error happened in issue #6, pages 133 where an interrogation piece between Bullock and Bruce's lawyer that their word bubbles are blank.  No big deal, but still an error.If you are a fan of the original Batman: The Animated Series or Batman fan in general, THE BATMAN ADVENTURES is a nice slice of nostalgia for you.  And it's also a good book for younger audiences who may want to stay away from the darker Batman stories out there.

With this summer's past release of Guardians of the Galaxy, it was only natural for Kotobukiya/ArtFX to release a statue as one of the many and current popular characters to people. That going for two of the most prominent characters in the film by most people: Rocket Raccoon and Groot. What is here is an awesome small statue, but some surprises in terms of scale compared to the other 1:10 ratio figures.For starters, both Groot and Rocket are separate piece. As with the rest of the ArtFX line, parts have to be assembled together. Groot is already done and requires no assembly; whereas Rocket has to be place on top of Groot and his arm holding his gun is a separate piece. Not too many parts and not difficult. As for the detail art, it's a usual Kotobukiya-level of detail and design that one would expect form the company. Every part of the two's coloring and subtle details show. Every scratch of tree bark, roots, and fungus is superb on Groot with those black eyes in an emotionless expression, while Rocket has tons of tiny holes to show his fur and mechanical display from his gun as he snarls onward grasping to Groot. Both are well-rendered from their movie counterparts.Now here is where some of the troubles are.As for the height, the Amazon product description is wrong. It says Rocket is 5.6 inches tall and that is incorrect. That is the height of Rocket WITH his gun ON Groot's shoulder. Rocket himself without the gun is 3.5 inches tall and about 4.7 inches tall with the gun. This isn't necessarily a negative considering the amount of detail the figure has, but once you piece it all together it looks small and underwhelming, especially when you compare it side-by-side to the Avengers statues. Rocket himself matches the right size of his character when you place him with any other Avenger at their waist level, as does Groot's head and shoulders. But since it's only 1:10 of Groot's scale, it just feels odd.Another aspect is the lack of a base for the figure. Amazon has it stated it comes with a base like the many other statues from Kotobukiya, but my figure had none. It could have been a packaging error on my copy, but none the less it does seem a little odd not to have one even though Groot/Rocket stands extreme well without it.And the last setback is the little flaw in placing Rocket just right on Groot. Yes Rocket does have pegs in his feet to place at, but his hand has to be just right when you connect to Groot which might be a problem. Nothing severe, but it's a small detail.As for the ROCKET ROCCOON AND GROOT ARTFX+ STATUE is usual Kotobukiya high level detail at a modest price when compared to more statues, I am a bit let down by this figure by the small sized compared to the other Marvel figures and at the same price. I think it would have been better for Kotobukiya to make a full-scale 1:10 ration body of Groot and upped the price tag like they did with Hulk. It's a good little statue, but I would have liked it to be a little bit bigger. If you are a hard-core Guardians/Rocket/Groot fan, this might really make you happy regardless of the lack of a base and size. But for the price, I was a little let down from the size compared to the other Marvel figure. A 3 ½ star-score, nut I'm rounding to 3 stars.

With the Kotobukiya/ArtFX Marvel NOW! Statue collection in full-swing, only two figures of the Avengers line need completion to round out the line-up: Iron Man and Thor.  While Iron Man will not come out until end of this year, my favorite Marvel super hero, Thor, has finally been released just in time for Halloween.  Although Thor may not be quite as detailed-oriented as some of the other figures, heâ€™s still a solid piece to the collection.Thor is one cool statue that stands at 7.14 inches from head-to-toe (8.3 inches if you count the wings on the helmet.)  Compared to the other Marvel statues that have some likeness to the actors, I find Thor to be solely based on the comic version and none of Chris Hemsworth facial expressions (but Hemsworth never wears the helmet in the films).  Thor stands strong-fully with his right hand in a tight fist, while his left arm is extended forward to ready a bolt of lightning or stand in a strong defensive position.  Standing next to Captain America, Thor looks a bit bulkier looking (heâ€™s a god after all!).Although Thor isnâ€™t quite as detailed as most of the other figures in tiny ways due to Thor being made up dark navy throughout, Thor still is a solid piece and detailed where it counts.  His belt, the outlined armor from his legs and arms, the head and helmet, and the cape.  There is a certain aura about his battle stance with the cape that makes Thor look wicked.As with the rest of the Marvel/ArtFX line thus far, the model has to be assembled. The lower torso connects to the upper body with the cape, the two arms connects on there own, head connects to upper body, and Thorâ€™s hammer, Mjolnir is made up of two-parts (the hammer connects to the handle as to slip on Thorâ€™s hand).  So for the most part, it felt pretty easy to piece Thor together compared to Hawkeye who had quite a few small parts.And like the other statues, Thor comes with a 4x4 black display stand that is magnetic. Thor is reasonably sturdy thanks to the magnets where even some wobbling wonâ€™t knock him down, though he can still fall over if an earthquake.  But heâ€™s pretty sturdy.My favorite Marvel superhero Thor is great for the price.  If youâ€™re collecting this whole collection, Thor is not one to be missed out on.  Tisâ€™ a good statue.

Ms. Marvel, a female-version character who was created in 1968 for Captain Marvel as Carol Danvers (not the original and confusing history of DC's Captain Marvel now called Shazam!).  Carol held the title for numerous years in comics and as sexual icon with her black spandex, long stocking boots, and red stash.  Carol has been a prominent component for Marvel women the past decade and has risen to now status in 2012 as Captain Marvel under writer Kelly Sue DeConnick with a whole new suit and outlook on life.  So with the title of Ms.Marvel being vacant, who else will take up the title?  How about fan-fiction writing 16-year old Pakistani American teenage girl  from New Jersey who is Muslim and who adores her idol, Carol Danvers?  Well that is one way to get peoples attention.MS.MARVEL VOL.1 NO NORMAL collects issues #1-5 and All New Marvel NOW! Point One.  Our protagonist, Kamala Khan is your typical 16-year old geeky girl who lives in a working class Muslim family.  She wants to hang out with the cool kids, go to parties to fit in, but her family's lifestyle holds her back.  But one night, while sneaking out to a party against her families wishes, Kamala gains shape shifting abilities in a dark mist.  Now scared and amazed by having super powers, Kamala takes up her icon's old alas and costume, Ms. Marvel, to help out the community, yet Kamala is trying to work out her new powers and the pressures of school and family life.The re-launched Ms. Marvel caught a lot of media attention because it is the first time a Muslim character stars in a comic book.  I personally do not care about such subject material, especially thanks in part to the wide acclaim the series was getting.  And it shows.  This is thanks greatly to writer G. Willow Wilson, who I have heard before but never read any of her material.  She is an American who went to college and changed to a Muslim during that time, so she has a working understanding of the religion and is a woman writing for a female lead.  I must say I am impressed.  What makes this series special is the simple, tired-and-true regular person gets super powers formula and makes for an engaging piece that is more human and down to Earth from many other comics.  The formula is very similar to Spider-Man for this opening volume with Kamala getting over her life's problems and dealing with superpowers.  This isn't a book where numerous characters throughout the Marvel universe pop in and out, or ties in to other titles, or be earth-shattering consequences; this is a grounded coming-of-age superhero story that our main heroine just happens to be Muslim.This is thanks to Wilson who portrays the character of Kamala as highly likable from the start.  The Muslim background is downplayed the moment we see her family and find out, even if their religion can a bit different from most people, they are just like every family out there and we connect with Kamala.  She's a bit of an outcast (with and without her Muslim background), she has anxieties about fitting in with the crowd, she likes all kinds of stuff, and she has a good heart.  Wilson gives Kamala a massive amount of charm, humanity, and even some funny pieces, which is backed up by an every strong supportive cast of character as well.  Kamala's best friend and her older brother are just examples. These characters are offbeat yet very real to the point where I like just about every character on panel (even the popular snobbish student, Zoe, has a selective charm as well).  And this is also shown throughout this volume where the antagonist is only a secondary story that will resolve in volume 2, where Wilson spends these 5 issues getting us used to Kamala' ordeals that I think most 16-year olds would go through.What greatly brings Wilson's story to have such visual wit and charm is Adrian Alphona's art work.  The man is responsible for drawing Runaways: The Complete Collection Volume 1, so Alphona knows exactly how to draw and express teenage characters, not like super models where many comics do.  It's good art and maintains a fine line for somewhat cartoony look and manga style for all ages.  And Ms. Marvel's new costume is practical in the same vein as Carol Danvers current costume.I didn't find any flaws in this opening volume from Wilson and Alphona, which those flaws are minor and do not affect the story.  It's not an action-packed story like many others.  It's rated Teen+, but aside from a few PG curse word this could pass for an all age's story.  One fault is the lack of explanation of the Terrigen Mist which gives Kamala her power in the comic is not explained or referenced.  The events of Infinity lead to the aftermath of the terrigen from the Inhumanity storyline, which explains the mist in this series.  Although it is annoying for new readers who might not know that, even lack of knowledge really didn't effect the charm of the series.So MS.MARVEL VOL.1: NO NORMAL is one of the most human and charming books on the comic stands.  It's a very grounded story with a lot of heart and humor that may not be anything new in comics, but it does it right.  This is one series I highly recommend and will continue to read from.

If there is anything DC needs more to break the doom-and-gloom of the New 52, is more light-hearted comics and more female leads.  Marvel is doing pretty well in those departments with Marvel NOW!, so it makes sense to give one of the most popular females in DC her own comic for awhile.  Sheâ€™s done it in the past before, so why not?  DC has a very slim selection of offbeat comics like the brilliant BATMAN 66â€™ come to mind, it is always nice to have some more entertaining comics we can smile with.  And this new series of Harley Quinn fits the bill.Collecting issues #0-8, HARLEY QUINN VOL.1: HOT IN THE CITY seeâ€™s Harley Quinn inherent a building complex in Coney Island, Brooklyn from a friend who was in Arkham asylum and passed away.  Harley is alone without the Suicide Squad, without her on/off again lover Joker not around, so some change is needed for Harley.  She decides to move to Coney Island and becomes land lord of a 4-story building and its tenants that inhabit it.  But Harley cannot just sit around a building all day since the previous landlord owed back-taxes, building cost, and numerous other deductibles.  So Harley finds two different jobs working for as a therapist for a nursing home during the day and roller derby at night to keep the building afloat.  And in the background, there appears to be numerous bounty hunters gunning for Harley because someone put a hit on her head.  Itâ€™s going to one crazy adventure for Ms. Quinn.Outside of that summary of the story and issues #5 and #6 being a 2-part arc, a great deal of these stories are made up crazy shenanigans in the life of Harley Quinn.  .  Itâ€™s an absurd series where Harley takes on the classic tradition of the DC universe where one character is the social-satire/self-relevant/fourth-wall breaking character to point out the oddities in comics.  For the past two decades is was Lobo (Pre-52 Lobo, not slimed-down New-52 Lobo), so DC has made Harley the new advocate for insane hijinx.  Harley is nowhere near as fanatical as Marvelâ€™s Deadpool, but this new series is still fun, whimsical, violent, and loaded with irreverent humor and frenetic action.  Yes, issue #0 is all about breaking the fourth-wall with its cast loaded with all-star artist that draw one page apiece because Harley is having a dream about finding the perfect artist for her new comic series with additional commentary from writers Palmiotti and Conner.  Outside of that, most the issues are less meta and more crazy situations.Writers and husband/wife duo Jimmy Palmiotti and Amanda Conner make Harley a little of her Pre-52 self and some of her current New-52 version really embodies Harley Quinn as the "lovable psychopath" character she is and what situations she gets herself into.  Sheâ€™s a little ditzy, adores animals to the point of killing people who mishandle them (wait till you see what she does to a guy dragging his dog while talking on his cellphone), fights love-induced people on Valentines Day akin to Night of the Living Dead, helps out an old-retired super spy, gets advice from a stuffed beaver, and her closest friend which I will not spoil who she is drops by that makes some of the best scenes in the book and calls back to Paul Diniâ€™s work on Harley Pre-52.  Additionally, the writers have also wisely created a supporting cast that complements Harley reasonably well.Besides the massive cast of high-profile artist in issue #0, a good majority is handled quite well by Chad Hardin.  Itâ€™s lush, a bit cartoony, and surprisingly detailed considering this series could have done with more simplified art considering the humor.  Hardin also conveys a great deal of the running jokes and pop culture references on every page.  Additional art is provided by Stephane Roux who blends well with Hardinâ€™s art appropriately.I didnâ€™t feel this book had any flaws.  I say that loosely because itâ€™s a comic for a certain crowd of people.  I thought it was fun and humorous at times, but it wasnâ€™t gut-busting humor.  I thought the 2-part story arc was a bit of a drab.  The true flaw might be the books intentions.  It doesnâ€™t really know what it wants to be.  Itâ€™s just Harley getting into crazy scenarios.  It doesnâ€™t have anything to do with the larger DC Universe and its plot is paper thin especially considering the ending that we find out who put the bounty on Harleyâ€™s head.  And maybe thatâ€™s just the point of this series is to have fun without any real story here?Either way, HARLEY QUINN VOL.1: HOT IN THE CITY sets out to be a entertaining and buggy series for Harley Quinn, which I think it accomplishes quite well.  The action and zaniness are entertaining, the art is pretty great, and a lovable Harley is back in the New-52.  The lack of direction for this series might or might not prove if the sight gags and characters can hold up for future issues though.  I still enjoyed this comic for being light-hearted material and being different from the darker corners of the New 52.
