These are both areas where neuroscientists are increasingly hubristic, and I think many of the authors' criticisms apply well to these areas.All in all, this is a good book, particularly for those with a sneaking suspicion that while neuroscience is a very valuable field, it breeds a tendency toward over-eagerness among acolytes. Like the authors, I admire the field of neuroscience and believe that it is and will help us better understand the human brain and human condition. But I don't think - at least where it is now - that it tells us all that some think it does. Very well done book. (Also, if you like this, read Michael Gazzaniga's Who's in Charge?: Free Will and the Science of the Brain.)

I read Paul Bloom's Descartes' Baby: How The Science Of Child Development Explains What Makes Us Human some years ago and found it an intriguing and persuasive read. This book in some ways picks up where that one left off. Descartes' Baby had the thesis that babies are born in some sense 'hardwired' for things like a very basic understanding of physics, like that objects have some sort of physical permanence and that objects that go up will come down. This book, cataloguing a host of intriguing studies, argues that babies are 'hardwired' for certain basic moral sentiments (a basic sense of justice, fairness, etc).For instance, in some studies, infants and toddlers will 'help' a stranger by pushing a ball back to the stranger or helping a stranger by reaching for an object the stranger seems to want. In other studies, babies are shown a puppet show with two sets of puppets; in one, the puppets help each other, and in the other, one puppet does not help the other. When given a choice, Bloom reports that a statistically significant number of infants and toddlers choose to play with the helping puppet rather than the non-helping puppet.Bloom's chapters range from exploring infants' and toddlers' sense of justice (little egalitarians, they tend to be), their sense of empathy (they generally prefer to help others, but this desire increases with age), whether their 'moral sentiments' change when dealing with members of their family or those who look like them, their sense of disgust (both moral and physical), etc. But here is where my mild complaint about Bloom's book starts. While I found the entire book well written and attention-holding, a good half of the book really is not about the moral sense of babies at all, but about what evolutionary accounts there are to humans' moral sense in general. For instance, the chapter on humans' sense of disgust was about 7/8ths a rumination on why humans have a sense of disgust and how much is cultural versus biological, and really only briefly mentioning a few studies about babies' sense of disgust interspersed throughout. Same with the chapter on humans' seemingly innate preference for members of the in-group (those who look like they do or share something in common with them): a few studies having to do with children - of many ages, not just babies - and the rest, theorizing about why we have these biases.Not that this detracts from the book's interest... if exploring the world of moral psychology in general is your thing. But I do worry that Bloom strays a bit far from what the book is supposed to be about: babies and what kind of innate moral sense they have. Otherwise, the book is a very interesting survey of existing literature (with citations at the end for further reading!) on the world of moral psychology (with SOME emphasis on the moral psychology of babies).

John Owens was a bad teacher... at least according to his supervisor at a NYC charter-esque school. This is both his adventure of his brief tenure (less than one year) at "Latinate Academy," and an argument about how hard teaching is and how wrong it is for politicians, pundits, and the general population to blame teachers - rather than elements of the system they work in - for poorly performing schools.I must say - as a former high school special educator - that my eyes were very much glued to this book. I was a teacher for two years and an instructional assistant (teacher's aid) before that for two years. And Owens's experience overlaps pretty well with mine - going into work day after day trying to do one's job given some very lofty goals, very little time to get them done, and virtually no support from administrations who care mostly about the schools numbers appearing good enough to justify their own jobs. Students are often passed on grade to grade in order to make schools' numbers look good, leaving teachers to teach students who are often ill-equipped for the subjects they are teaching and must get students to pass on frequent standardized tests. Given this, when behavior problems understandably arise, administrators will often make it known not only that teachers are to deal with these in-house (while still trying to teach the other students in class), but (often indirectly) that behavioral problems are just the result of bad teaching. So, despite teaching several classes per day and having to grade homeworks, plan lessons, and enter data on evenings and weekends, teachers often go into school with a sense that no matter how well they do, every day is a steep uphill climb.Owens makes this come alive. It is CLEAR that he really enjoyed his students, and doesn't blame them for the situations they are put into. In other words, this is not a book about how horrible kids are today, how this generation is the 'dumbest generation,' or anything like that. It is a book meant to show how even the purest-hearted and most diligent of teachers can hardly avoid seeming to fail in a system where they are given little discretion, a hell of a lot to do, expectations that get higher all the time, and very little support from administrators.Two negatives: first, perhaps Owens is NOT the right person to make this case, especially to those not already convinced. As he lasted less than a year (rightly or wrongly) I suspect that there are some who will too easily dismiss him as a novice, and it is widely reported that the learning curve for teachers is about two years: the first two years are often nightmarish and after that, teachers start to really get the hang of it. Second, while Owens does not want(us) to blame teachers for schools' failing, his story does SLIGHTLY contradict that message, given that some key figures in his book were subsequently caught padding data to make it look better tahn it was, and generally cheating kids in order to make themselves look better and advance their careers. Granted, these teachers (and administrators, who often started as teachers) are in the minority, but it will cause readers to rightly suspect that there really are SOME bad teachers out there.Otherwise, I liked this book a lot. Those who have not been teachers really should read this, the next best thing to trying the actual profession out for a while. And while I disagree a bit on the author's anti-school-choice bias (no, no one believes it would be a cure-all, so that is a red herring), I think his case that the problem is less the teachers in the system than the current state of the system itself is well-taken and needs to be heard.

There are two schools of thought about human rationality: the economics profession models humans as rational calculators, and the behavioral psychologists (in books like Predictably Irrational, Revised and Expanded Edition: The Hidden Forces That Shape Our Decisions) model humans as decidedly irrational. Both, say the authors of "The Rational Animal," are partly right and mostly wrong. To a large degree, humans do make decisions based on weighing costs and benefits, and humans do have many "blindspot" areas where their decisions are often less than rational.But instead of asking whether we are or are not rational, these authors use evolutionary psychology to show that, given our evolved brains, many of the areas where humans look irrational exhibit a hidden rationality. So, several behavioral economic studies show that humans have a loss aversion: we value things higher when we are faced with losing what we possess than when gaining them for the first time. (In concrete terms, we will pay a lower cost to attain a thing than we would to give it up once we have it.)The authors would respond to this above tendency as follows; we have several 'evolutionary selves' - mate attractor, survival expert, social networker, parent, etc - and each of these serves an evolutionary function and has slightly different preferences. So - and this is verified in studies the authors rehearse - when our 'mate attractor' self is primed (by having people look at pictures of attractive members of the opposite sex - we exhibit less risk aversion and are more aggressive in the amount of risk we often take. But when our 'parenting' selves are primed - by having people read stories about happy families - we become more 'conservative' in our riskiness behavior. (This, because in evolutionary terms, attracting mates often requires taking risks while raising successful offspring often requires more stability and less risk.)So in this and other areas, some of our seemingly irrational tendencies have a deep rationality to them (those who raised successful offspring were less risky, and their loss aversion helped them survive. So, when we are loss averse, we are doing what made sense for our ancestors.)Here is my big problem with this admittedly very interesting book. I am not sure the authors are saying anything that most economists (on the one side) and behavioral psychologists (on the other) would really object to. When economists model humans as wholly rational actors, it is WIDELY known among economists that this is a model valued for its simplicity, not its descriptive accuracy. (There are only a few more extreme economists who take this model as an accurate description.) And conversely, behavioral psychologists who say that many human behaviors are irrational, they mean irrational according to the standard of making the decision that makes the most rational sense given the context in which the decision is made. In fact, Dan Ariely's big selling book on why humans are often irrational is called "PREDICTABLY Irratioanl" and has a subtitle about what the 'hidden forces' (often, the evolutionary forces) that create those blind-spots in human rationality.So, what this book does is gives us a good, plain-English survey of evolutionary psychology and how it helped shape current thought processes that often appear irrational (ironically, something similar to what Ariely does in the book these authors treat as a foil). What this book is not is an argument for anything new. The only reason it might seem novel is because the authors do not represent the present state of economics or behavioral psychology very accurately.Still worth three stars for being really interesting, though.

I was recently offered a promotional copy of Office 365 to review for Amazon and I eagerly accepted. I am a Linux user and I have heard that, where Linux cannot install Microsoft Office, Office 365 comes with Office On Demand, a web-based application of the full MS Office Suite. (For the record, I am quite happy using LibreOffice instead of MS Office, but have many occasions where I need to create on MS Office in order to collaborate with others. So, I was excited: the ability to work on MS Office on the web on my Linux machine?Linux users beware, Office On Demand does not work on Linux machines - even though it is web-based - because it requires the download of a client that only works on Windows and Mac. (To my knowledge, WINE cannot bypass this.)So, what does the Linux user get for the Office 365 University subscription? Basically, 20GB worth of storage on a cloud word processing app (Skydrive) that anyone whose used Google Drive for five seconds would recognize as vastly inferior.I will go further and suggest that WINDOWS USERS WHO HAVE OFFICE DO NOT NEED OFFICE 365. What do you get besides the Office package you already have (and LibreOffice really is as good as Office 2013)? 20GB on Skydrive, some Skype minutes (who calls a landline from Skype, anyway?) and Office On Demand (the web-based version of Office). Not worth the price tag, honestly.I'll just keep using my Linux machine with LibreOffice for most word processing tasks, and Google Drive for the rest.Once again, Microsoft Office has created something not worth the money.

Alison Wolf's book about women in the late 20th and 21st century, The XX Factor, bears both good news and (what some would consider) bad. The good news? Many, and the most important, gaps in achievement and opportunity between women and men have disappeared. Somewhat controversially, I'm sure, Wolf presents a bevy of statistics to show that things like the wage gap between women and men has virtually disappeared (when we adjust for things like hours spent working and type of career). Women in careers where there used to be noticeable "glass ceilings" (finance, business) do not appear to have them any more. And when it comes to college attendance and degrees earned, women have been outstripping men for years.But the bad news: all of this equality is leaving noticeable gaps between upper and middle class women, and poorer women. Upper income women have largely been the beneficiaries of the women's movement(s) and the emphasis on choice, because these women are the ones who have resources to take advantage of things like increased educational opportunity. Poorer women, on the other hand, are having more children earlier, taking either lower wage jobs or traditionally-female-heavy jobs like daycare, teaching, and social work (that are lower paying on the whole, or have fewer chances of advancement. In fact, as a criticism, I'd have liked to see some discussion about whether some of these inequalities - like, choice of man women to enter lower-paying 'caring professions' are likely make in a fully deliberate way, or may be due to perceived or real lack of choices, and whether inequality that is arrived at by differences in deliberate choice are problematic.)So, the upside is that the goal of equal opportunity for women seem to have largely been achieved, at least as borne out by Wolf's lengthy statistical analysis. But the downside is that the inequality has manifested in the different choices women in different income groups make, either with full deliberation or because some women don't have the options others have.Stylistically, readers should be 'warned' that while this book is fascinating (chapters exploring everything from whether women really do more labor around the house compared to men to differences in how 'rich' and 'poor' women approach romance), it is very statistic-heavy. Wolf not only asserts and argues from anecdotes, but summarizes A TON of statistical literature on each subject, which bolsters her case, but also makes for (what some would call) dry reading. Another thing I think could or should have been made clearer is the author's actual thesis - which comes out much clearer in my review than in her book; she doesn't very explicitly pull all of her separate threads together into an outright argument. That may have been a deliberate choice to keep the book more of an objective survey of literature, but her conclusions are sure to be controversial enough to warrant arguing a more explicit 'thesis.'I really enjoyed this book, mostly because it bears a lot of good news for those of us who care about equality of opportunity regardless of sex. Whether many of the inequalities between women are problematic, and subtract from this good news, may well be a matter of whether the inequalities are arrived at by differences in choice or by some lacking options that others have. But it is always healthy to take the good news with the bad, and anyone wishing to take stock of what women's rights movements - both in developed and under-developed countries - have yielded (so far).

Situated in working-class Levittown, Pennsylvania is a high school drama program so successful that it routinely wins national accolades and attracts Broadway directors to see its productions. At the heart of this program is drama director (and former English teacher) Lou Volpe. When journalist Michael Sokolove was invited to give a graduation speech at his alma mater of Truman High (where he took Volpe's English classes), he decided to write about Volpe and Truman's drama program - what makes him and it so special, how it maintains excellence every year, how it changes the lives of its participants.This is a year in the life of the Truman drama program. Volpe and company are putting together a production of an edgy and controversial work, Good Boys and True (exploring themes of homosexuality, teen sex, etc). We not only get to know Lou Volpe and members of the Truman drama program, but the dedicated students (who really aren't the 'typical' drama students) who make the program go. Sokolove not only tells the story of how this production comes together, but, through in-depth interviews, paints a picture of each player and what the drama program means to them. What emerges is a program that challenges students to know and push themselves through acting.I will tell you that I had a hard time putting this book down. And it is not because of an intense plot - the book reads more like a character study that meanders from narrative accounts of rehearsals to biographies of participants to musings on arts programs in an age of standardized testing. Through all this meandering, what sustained my interest is Sokoloe's ability to get at the 'soul' of this drama program and how it affects students, and the pleasure of getting to know that such a program exists for students... somewhere. In an age of emphasis on standardized testing and all things human capital in American schools, Sokolove gives us a really inspiring story of how educational well-run drama (and probably other arts) programs can be. This is a truly inspiring story.

Markets can't cater to the poor. Markets in education are motivated only by profits, not by concern for education. Private companies will work in education only by selecting the best students and ousting the others.These are some of the common objections heard to markets in education. Just like he did in The Beautiful Tree: A Personal Journey Into How the World's Poorest People Are Educating Themselves, James Tooley gives us more evidence that calls some of these into question. Here, his focus is entirely on one global education company: SABIS International Schools Network. The SABIS company grew from a school founded in the late 19th century in Lebanon as a private girls school (when girls didn't generally go to school), SABIS gradually expanded into a brand of schools represented everywhere from Kurdistan and the United Arab Emirates to England and the US. And they tend to open in areas - like post-Katrina New Orleans - that caters to what most would call "at risk" (or at very least, poor) students.Using a mix of interviews with central figures in the SABIS history, trips to various SABIS schools, and access to archives, Tooley tells us about the history, the pedagogical methods (which eschew many ideas at work in current public schools, like individualized instruction), and their results. SABIS students undergo, for instance, testing schedule that may well be more rigorous than in US public schools with one very key difference: the SABIS tests are formative, rather than summative: designed to really figure out what students are and aren't soaking up in order to figure out what instruction should come next. And with this and other methods, SABIS students have experienced marked success as measured by standardized tests...results that become more impressive when we factor in the student populations they tend to serve.While Tooley documents SABIS successes, he also documents some of their failures, particularly some attempts to start charter schools in the US. Despite having a proven record of success in a range of locations, starting charter schools (schools that run privately, but receive public money as part of the public school system) often meet with fierce local and national opposition, often motivated by concern that private schools run by for-profit companies are not likely to offer a good quality education. SABIS however, remains steadfastly for-profit, and Tooley devotes a chapter to explaining why they made and make this choice, which largely has to do with the idea that not seeking profit limits their ability to grow as a company (similar to the arguments made in Uncharitable: How Restraints on Nonprofits Undermine Their Potential (Civil Society: Historical and Contemporary Perspectives).For me, the SABIS story fits in well with contemporary work on the idea of conscious capitalism (Be the Solution: How Entrepreneurs and Conscious Capitalists Can Solve All the Worlds Problems and markets that serve the poor and disenfranchised (The Fortune at the Bottom of the Pyramid: Eradicating Poverty Through Profits, Revised and Updated 5th Anniversary Edition. By seeking profit, SABIS turns what could be charity (or a clunky government enterprise) into a positive sum situation where they, do well by doing good for others. It is sustainable, it is proven effective, and it is innovative. Critics might wonder whether the SABIS model (in all its painstaking detail) is scalable and whether its very standardized approach to schooling avoids the problems of standardization within current public ed models. But anyone who wants to see what markets and for-profit companies are capable of in the are of education needs to read this.

In Caring Democracy, Joan Tronto is concerned with how we allocate care services (and care for others generally) in society. Despite professed gender and sex equality, women bear the brunt of care work (teaching students, care for the elderly, care for the vulnerable), men are often not recognized as capable of giving and receiving care, and we tend only to care for those very close to us (or if for others, we do it in the context of markets where service is paid for). This, Tronto suggests is a problem. Correspondingly, and she suspects, relatedly, there is a marked apathy toward civic participation in American society. Maybe we are just becoming disconnected from each other and, by effect, care services get relegated to low paid labor and people find more excuses not to form caring relations with others.Tronto's book is an exposition of how we might use some sort of deliberative democracy to alleviate this problem - to regain our concern for and connection with others and to democratically allocate caring services in a just way where we all recognize our potential to be care givers and -receivers.My big problem with the book is that I cannot quite figure out how Tronto's solution is actually better than the problem she points out. Partly, this is because if the problem is that caring services are, to some degree, forced onto people who have little choice but to take them - either women who've traditionally had no other option to but be 'home maker' or low wage workers - I don't see how allocating caring services in a democratic way would not result in the same kind of dilemma: if a majority - even after a reasoned discussion - wants to allocate care on a minority, how is this better?The reason I think Tronto believes it will be better is because I think she overestimates democracy and badly caricatures markets. Tronto talks about the importance of democratic deliberation most often with the assumption that the democrats share her values (equality of the sexes, inclusion of all in deliberation, etc) and are all quite engaged. In reality, democracies don't generally work this way. Quite a bit of literature documents that democracy is more often marked by low participation, dialogue that is often more polarizing than unifying, and special interest politics. (See The Myth of the Rational Voter: Why Democracies Choose Bad Policies (New Edition) and Selling Out America's Democracy: How Lobbyists, Special Interests, and Campaign Financing Undermine the Will of the People for just two sources. Most of the "public choice" economic literature tells the same story.) Tronto recognizes these possibilities occasionally, but assumes that in the absence of markets, people will just behave better, becoming more civic minded, informed, and reasonable.Tronto also mischaracterizes markets and what they entail very badly. Markets, she tells us, can only be defended if one believes that humans are exlusively or primarily self-interested calculators operating under conditions of perfect knowledge. Of course, Tronto points out that neither of these describe the actual world, but she'd be surprised perhaps to know that even some of the most ardent champions of markets (and most market-oriented economists) argue the same. In fact, most defenses of markets use almost opposite reasoning: since perfect knowledge doesn't exist, this is all the more reason to distrust governmental solutions that also suffer from that knowledge problem.. even if they are 'democratic.'  (see Individualism and Economic Order and  Robust Political Economy: Classical Liberalism and the Future of Public Policy (New Thinking in Political Economy Series)). Markets, Tronto also writes, are unequal in that they tend to favor the well-off over the less-well-off. Well, research shows that deliberative democracy suffers from basically the same problem, favoring the better-organized, more persuasive and articulate, and most assertive....who tend to be the better off. (See The Other Invisible Hand: Delivering Public Services through Choice and Competition on this point). Nor are markets any less voluntary than forcing the results of majority decisions onto minorities. (At least in markets, leaving a particular role as consumer or producer is a POSSIBILITY.)In the end, I believe Tronto fails to make her case that deliberative democratic allocations of care would fare any better than market (or private) allocations. Some people don't have a choice in the private sector? Others won't have a choice under a democratic decision making process. Markets corrupt caring by turning it into something done for money? The only option that wouldn't is allowing care work to be done ONLY voluntarily: yes, governments pay public school teachers just like schools pay private school teachers. Markets lead to potentially exploitative relations? So do social situations where individuals must abide by whatever allocations the deliberating majority chooses and have no exit options. To be convinced of Tronto's case would involve painting democracy in its most ideal form and markets in their worst possible form.Maybe neither of those assumptions is justified. If not, Tronto doesn't make her case.

Drug dealers, sex workers, gypsy cab drivers, under-the-table nanny services. These are areas of the American market that we don't consider when we tabulate GDP. But they are vibrant markets, and markets just like any other, so according to sociologist Sudhir Venkatesh. And just like he did in the critically acclaimed Gang Leader for a Day: A Rogue Sociologist Takes to the Streets, he has sought to understand the people who buy and sell (mostly the latter) in these markets: what are their motivations, what are their business practices, how do they think about what they do?The Floating City is written in an engaging ethnographic (narrative) form, where Venkatesh hangs out among those working in the sex industry (prostitutes, brokers, a few clients), the drug trade (primarily one popular drug dealer), and a few other industries to find out about their lives. Shine, an established drug dealer in New York, is looking to expand his market with a new drug for a new and more "upscale" audience. Margot is a middle-aged broker for sex workers (the less kind word, of course, is "pimp," but Margot does much more than most pimps, including counseling about money management) who is preparing for her future; Analise is the young woman trying to get into Margot's business. Vanketesh tells the story of these and other characters in New York City's vibrant black markets.Interestingly, we also get a significant amount of Venkatesh's own story. We find out, for instance, about his struggles to meet new people (er...research subjects) in New York, a city very different from his previous Chicago. Also, we get a glimpse of how a "rogue sociologist" manages - or mismanages? - to keep his professional life separate from his personal life when dealing with prostitutes and drug dealers during the day, but a wife at home. As I am an aspiring academic, I found a lot of interest in Venkatesh's writing about how he struggles with generating and growing his research questions: what do I want to know about these people, and now that i know some of that, what are the remaining or new questions.While this book doesn't make too many arguments, there are some key takeaways. First, these black markets may take place under the radar, but they are markets very much like legal ones, but with their own peculiarities (often stemming from their illegality). Transactions take place on trust, entrepreneurs try to find their niche and grow their markets, and the most savvy do their market research before making any big moves. The second takeaway: as Venkatesh is fascinated in this book by finding out the similarities and differences between the black markets amongst the disenfranchised and black markets amongst the wealthy (crack versus powdered coke, cheap motel prostitutes versus posh escorts), Venkatesh found a slight difference in how each talk about what they do. the former group talks about doing what they have to do to climb the ladder, and the latter talk of the kick they get from flouting social conventions. In other words, the former do it because they have to, the latter do it because they want to, and both find a way to one might say) ratioanllize why they do what they do.But a formal sociology book, this is not. Venkatesh is a great writer and the book reads more like a a work of journalism than a stuffy "ethnography." To me, the best part is that Venkatesh writes in a way that seeks to understand and even relate to, rather than in a way that treats his subjects as victims who know not what they do. One can see quite easily why his "subjects," who probably don't talk to many people, talk to him so freely.Anyone wanting to understand those secret markets that keep some of our other markets afloat should really read The Floating City. You will just never see New York City, or crime, again in the same way.

I have put many a screen protector on different devices, and am generally quite decent at it. This protector is not only extremely difficult to get on my Nook HD+, but you only get one shot at it. Why? Well, of course, they only send you one sheet. But, you ask, can't you pull a bit of the sheet off if it touches your screen the wrong way to readjust it?Well, no; once the sheet hits the screen, you basically have to rip it off to get it off. This is a big problem because the protector is actually quite difficult to affix; first, you have to make sure to line up the "n" button with the corresponding cut out on the screen protector, but once you do that, odds are that another part of the screen protector has already touched the screen; at least that's what happened to me. And... you only get one shot at this because, like I said, once any area of the protector touches the screen, you are not getting it off without a fight.I would not dream of ordering this product again. Unless you want to take a chance on throwing money away for an overpriced piece of thick plastic, I'd advise you to steer clear. There are better less expensive and less frustrating options.

I got these headphones because I like clip ons and heard good things. And the sound quality is good. Too bad I can't enjoy it.I use my headphones primarily while running or at the gym. And there are two BIG problems. First, they do not clip to the ear very well; since I move around when using them, they actually gradually fall off of my ear (as the clip is not very secure). And that leads to the second BIG problem: the clips snap on... and off. So, when I adjust the phones, odds are about 3 to 1 that one of the clips will snap off, meaning that I either stop my exercise to fiddle with the phones, or I do without for the rest of my workout (an option I am increasingly going with).So, these are great phones... as long as you don't dare move while using them.... and as long as you don't touch them while using them. (Would you buy headphones from a company with that motto?)

When I first got a Kindle (generation 1, in early 2008), Amazon advertised the heck out of their $9.99 price for most books. It was a huge selling point, because other ebook sellers (Sony, Barnes and Noble) were selling at higher prices. I fell out of love with the Kindle (for other reasons than book pricing) and got a Nook, accepting the slight rise in book costs. So, I didn't pay attention to the legal rumblings I occasionally heard about. Then, one day, Barnes and Noble sent me a notification that, per the result of an anti-trust suit launched against publishers, I was being credited for ebook prices that were the result of collusion by the major publishers.That was really all I knew.This very short but informative book fills in the remaining details. The long and the short is that, by the time Apple decided to launch an ebook platform for their first release of the ipad, the main six publishers were not happy with the wholesale model where they sold to Amazon and Amazon charged whatever price they wanted, largely because they feared that in the long run, it would bring down prices of books and limit their own future profitability, and that Amazon would grow to dominate the market such that they might start publishing directly. Apple proposed that the they and the publishers deal instead on an agency model, where publishers set the ebook price (within certain Apple-defined limits) and give Apple a 30% profit on each book sold at that price. But here's where it got dicey; Apple informally told each publisher that they must agree to only operate with Amazon if they accept the agency model.This short book is a blow-by-blow account of the lead up to the legal war and (surprisingly quick) legal war itself. While it is interesting in and of itself, there is really no editorializing on the story, which does leave the reader wondering why, other than hearing an interesting story, they read this book. Is there a "moral" to this story? Was there an aftermath to the story? And what might this story mean for the future of ebook sales?This leads to my next complaint: the book really reads as written in haste. Most of the book focuses on the run up to the legal battle, exploring the tense relations between publishers and Amazon, exploring the genesis of Apple's strategy, and the negotiations between the publishers and Apple and Amazon respectively. The legal battle, by comparison, is given very short shrift and I would bet that the book was basically written right after (or during and after) the legal battle; that's how short that latter section is. And there is NOTHING exploring the aftermath of the antitrust case or what all of this may mean for the future of publishing. The book literally stops at the very end of the antitrust case.Interesting read that fills in a backstory I was always fuzzy on. But that's about it.

Dan Palotta has devoted his life to helping others through several non-profit charities, particularly geared toward funding AIDS related causes. Over this long career, Palotta became frustrated at every turn at the different rules people expect for-profit and non-profit companies to play by. For-profit companies are allowed to invest money in advertising and expansion for the future, are allowed to spend money paying employees in order to attract and keep talent, and are not expected to put all of their money directly toward commodity production. Non-profits, on the other hand, are expected to pay workers poorly and not invest in infrastructure for the future or advertising, all because the money is supposed to go directly to those in need.Uncharitable is Palotta's attempted explanation of why it makes complete sense to think about non-profits the way we think of profit-making companies; no one expects profit-making companies to squeeze every dollar into commodity production, because it is understood that advertising, investment in infrastructure, and offering competitive salaries aid the company's mission every bit as well as producing the widgets. Yet, no one seems to be fine with allowing non-profits to do anything but put all of their money into direct aid, which means sacrificing the kind of expansion that for-profit companies can achieve.I found the first chapters of this book to be the best by far, where Palotta addresses the obvious concerns that markets play on self-interest, where non-profits are supposed to operate from altruism. Rightly, Palotta suggests that this is a dangerously false dichotomy we hold. Doing for others isn't positively correlated with the degree of self-sacrifice we make. (It is not as if the impact of my doing for others hinges on the degree to which I deny myself.) And as long as we allow that people can be interested in helping others (and feel good doing it), behavior oriented toward helping others can be behavior that nourishes, rather than sacrifices, the self. (Palotta gives a too-abbreviated, but interesting, discussion on how the idea that doing for others requires self-sacrifice was something we likely influenced from the Puritans. I suspect it is older than that.)Palotta also aims to convince us why we should allow non-profits to advertise, pay competitively, and invest in infrastructure in the same way for-profits do. As to the second of these, the theory is that offering high pay attracts people primarily motivated by money, not "the cause." Restricting the amount non-profits pay might help them hire some altruists, it is true; but more than not, it leads to hiring people with few other job prospects (and even altruists get tired of working long hours for low pay!). As to the third point above, it seems pretty obvious that for-profits invest in infrastructure because they value long-term growth and know that infrastructure is a way to help secure it. Yet, people scoff when non-profits hold events that have relatively high overhead, purchase good equipment rather than cheap equipment, etc. But, Palotta argues, disallowing this sort of thinking-toward-the-future for non-profits only limits their future growth potential, not something people should want if they care about doing good in the future as well as the present.Now for my two criticisms. First, this book probably could have been 75 pages less and still contained the same argumentative force. It reads like a 75 page essay that employs a lot of repetition in order to get more pages. And for all of that, my second criticism is that Palotta doesn't really address how one could convince donors to give money to a charity that is planning on spending a good percentage of that money on advertising, infrastructure, and paying employees handsomely. I don't think Palotta's idea is wrong at all, but I just worry that people do not want to donate if they know the CEO is getting paid in the upper six figures. And Palotta didn't really convince me that there is a way around this. Instead, he repeated his main points again. Hopefully the next edition will include a bit more by way of persuasion toward the skeptic who wonders whether people will donate to a cause not much of their actual money will go to.All in all, though, Palotta's message is super-important. For those who care about helping others through charity and non-profits, it is time for us to consider using the power of market capitalism to do as much good as we possibly can. And it is time for those not on board to face Palotta's arguments and explain why restricting non-profits to relative subsistence rather than allowing them to use market forces to expand their scope does more good than harm. Palotta goes a long way toward explaining that these well meaning "anti-capitalists" are just wrong.

This is the story of Jacob Asprey, Jr., mid-twenty-something son of a con-artist, and his attempt to pick up the pieces that his father shattered. At one point, Jake was in college, but all of that changed when his father went to prison (for fraud and other things) and some of Jake Sr.'s debts became his son's. Now, he is working a somewhat crappy lifeguard job and living with his uncle. He works with a former sweetheart who left him when she found out his father was a con-artist.Jake is down on his luck...until a proposition comes to him from some former friends of his father's; help them steak something (what, we don't know until late in the book) from his employer and he will be made well. It sounds good, but Jake (a) wants to move on from his father and everyone associated with him, and (b) this theft requires that he steal from his ex-girlfriend, who he still loves.This is How You Fall is not quite a thriller, and is not quite a work of "literary fiction." It tries to be a bit of both, though I think it succeeds more in the latter. What I did like about it was the story line, which is slow moving but quick enough moving to hold an eager reader's interest.What I didn't like - hence the deduction of two stars - is that the main character of Jake Asprey is entirely one dimensional and repetitive. I didn't count, but I have to think that three quarters of his inner thoughts that we are privy to deal with him feeling very sorry for himself about his father. It got to the point where, in the latter half of the book, I skimmed past all the predictable internal monologue (because I knew what it was about from the book's first half) and read only the action.Oh, and while the book is sort of interesting as a character study, those who expect a big ending (like the kind from a thriller) will be a bit underwhelmed.Overall, I'd give it a lukewarm recommendation and mostly to those who want literary fiction.

Eamonn Butler's Best Book on the Market is a good explanation of markets and why they work - especially when "no one is in charge." It is precisely because no one central body coordinates economic behavior in markets that lead to so much anxiety about how they work and calls for central planning by governments. Butler does a good job explaining to lay readers how and why markets often do their jobs when left alone and when they are most decentralized.Butler's account of markets is very "Hayekian" (after the economist Friedrich Hayek). Rather than using the standard - and utterly false - idea that markets only work when actors have perfect information about the market landscape, and when a perfect equilibrium between consumer demand and producers' supply is reached, Butler sees markets as dynamic forces that NEVER reach equilibrium, whose value is precisely because actors don't have perfect information. In other words, markets work because they allow producers to make educated guesses about what consumers will want, and consumers to figure out what they do want using a standard price system to weigh options against each other. If private actors have imperfect information - and they do - so do government actors. Government intervention in markets (price and wage controls, regulations that make production more costly or restrict consumption, etc) tend to have unforeseen and under-appreciated negative effects (so, regulation restricts market competition, which often makes goods more costly, etc).While Butler gives a good "Hayekian" account of why markets work so well, and government interventions don't, there are two things readers should note. First, the explanation is definitely geared toward the lay reader and is somewhat surface-level. (I was looking for some sort of bibliography so that readers interested in a particular area of Butler's argument could read further, but there is none.) Second, Butler does not deal much at all with the common objections to markets: that they can't deal well with "public goods" or private goods that produce significant "external" costs or benefits to non-purchasers, that markets are unjust because they produce inequality, that certain things just can't be "commodified," and that markets threaten community or tradition. Not that I think these can't be or haven't been answered, but if we are making the case for markets to lay readers, it might be best to show how such commonly heard tropes can be answered.Otherwise, this is a really good book and those who want a good but simple overview of how markets (and free markets) work. Other books of possible interest might be The Morality of Capitalism: What Your Professors Won't Tell You and that oldie but goodie, Free to Choose: A Personal Statement.

I am giving this book two of five stars, not because I disagree with most of the conclusions, but because I find almost all the reasoning to the conclusions to be faulty and oversimplified. I agree, for instance, that the popular conception that humans are selfish creatures who only cooperate when they can benefit from it to be correct; I just hold that most people (yes, even Adam Smith and most 'neoclassical economists') have known that. I am an avid user of Linux and advocate of its open-source way of operating; I am just at a loss as to why anyone thinks that Linux is a golden model of cooperation. And I am an advocate of doing what we can to harness human cooperation;; I am just at a loss as to why 'cooperation' is conceived of NECESSARILY as 'other-oriented behavior engaged in at expense to self.'On this first, Adam Smith's use of self-interest as an idea was very broad. For Smith, engaging in self-interested behavior essentially meant pursuing what one was interested in. If I am interested in helping a friend or giving to a charity whose cause I believe in, this was me pursuing my self-interest. The author may well have a case that 'Chicago School' economists like Gary Becker often did fall into modeling humans as selfish utility-maximizers, but even most 'neoclassical' economists modeled human behavior AS IF if was selfish (often because some people would be selfish, and since that is true, social institutions needed in a way that, if the knaves fell into power, they could do the least harm.)As to holding Linux as the bastion of what cooperation can do, it is certainly a BIT true. Linux operates on an open-source ethos of sharing with others. Developers promise to keep the source code open and often contribute voluntarily (though developers often get paid, too). Yet, Linux is also quite competitive, largely because innovations ARE open-source and cannot be protected by competition-inhibiting trademarks and patents. Here are the words of Linus Torvalds as quoted in the book Top Dog: The Science of Winning and Losing: "Does this mean that there will be tension and rivalry [between linux developers]? Hell yes, but that's kind of the point. Life is a game, and if you aren't in it to win, what the heck are you still doing here?"Lastly, the author talks as if the ideas of cooperation is simply antithetical to self-interest - the subtitle alone illustrates this dichotomy. But it doesn't take much thought to see that this is dead wrong. I can cooperate both because I want to help others (when I give fifty dollars to you)  and because I am aware that helping others can enhance my own position (when I give fifty dollars to you in exchange for something you are selling, or because I want to stay in your good graces). The fact that people contribute to wikipedia doesn't mean they are not doing so out of self-interest, unless you conceive - as the author does - of the term 'self-interest' in such a narrow way that nothing which produces positive externalities to others could possibly qualify as self-interested.I fully agree that humans exhibit a marked tendency to cooperate, much more than we are often given credit for. But I think that the author seeing this as a point that needs to be made shows his ignorance more than his interestingness. And the fact that he makes this point against economists who really always knew this shows that he might want to either read them again.

Julian Le Grand has written a really good book in The Other Invisible Hand, but one that will likely appease any ideologues. Libertarians and (maybe) conservatives will like his cases for competition over command-and-control government services, but may want to go "all the way" toward full markets, rather than Le Grand's so-called "quasi-markets." Social Democrats, on the other hand, may be put off more fully by Le Grand's championing of markets and, particularly, his theoretical and empirical arguments that markets DO NOT produce knavish behavior any more than "public service" does.However, Le Grand's case is not simply a celebration of competition and choice in public service; it is much more complex. Le Grand explores four different ways public services can be delivered: trust (we can just trust the administrators to deliver good service), command-and-control (we can vest power in a central agency to give instructions on how to administer the service), voice (we can allow customers input into the service that administrators can use to adapt the service to customer demand) and competition (we can allow consumers to choose between competing providers). Springboarding off of his previous work (Motivation, Agency, and Public Policy: Of Knights and Knaves, Pawns and Queens), where he discussed the presence of altruists and self-interested actors in about equal measure in the public and private sector, Le Grand suggests that, on balance, competition leads to the best results. Trust and command-and-control demand that we trust people (the providers or the organization that tells them what to do) to do the right thing, when they may have incentive not to. Command-and-control and voice models may risk insulting service providers, who may feel like they are instruments rather than authority figures with expertise. And all three of these lack an exit option for customers, meaning that there is a lack of incentive for providers to take outside advice (from customers) into account, and that consumers may be stuck with service that they find to be suboptimal or would prefer to exit.Competition, on the other hand, generally means that customers can shop for the service they like (and diverse customers can each choose different service), allows service providers to feel like they have some authority over their service (they run things the way they think customers will respond to and the 'feedback' is whether customers DO respond to it). Also, the competition process puts pressure on 'firms' to be efficient, responsive to customers, and innovative. The work is not simply theoretical, either. Le Grand reviews a lot of literature showing (a) that (contra critics) the poor prefer choice more than the middle class or rich, (b) that (again, contra critics) when choice is offered, people use it and report feeling empowered by it, and (c) that markets may well not "crowd out" altruistic behavior (data is mixed on that point, but Le Grand finds that altruism is as likely to be expressed in the private, as the public, sector).As mentioned earlier, Le Grand is not simply a "privatize everything" advocate. He is not talking about private markets exactly, but "quasi-markets" where government redistributes wealth (in areas like healthcare and education) to ensure that everyone has access, regulates the market (both to increase flow of information to consumers and to regulate quality), and may do things like provide transportation to schools and hospitals (as Le Grand finds transportation issues to be an obstacle to effective competition and choice.)Here, admittedly, is where I start to have a few concerns. My concerns are that Le Grand does not adequately deal with some of the tensions between some of his goals. For instance, Le Grand wants to ensure robust competition for services by keeping entry and exit costs of 'firms' low, but at the same time, he advocates the kind of regulation that may keep entry costs high (firms wanting to enter educational markets must prove to an independent board that they meet certain fairly high standards, which can make for costly entry). And while Le Grand is aware of the potential for 'regulatory capture' that comes  from introducing regulations (and advocates that an independent body regulate and monitor school quality), I wonder how independent this independent body can be (would they be paid by the government? If so, that may lead this regulatory agency to make 'politically correct' decisions). I think these issues deserved a bit more exploration.I really liked Le Grand's book, though. In clear and precise language, Le Grand explained the benefits (and the limits) of markets and competition in public services. He follows it up quite well with empirical evidence about the ineffectiveness of trust, command-and-control, and voice options as well as the benefits of choice models.

For quite a while now, care ethicists like Noddings (Starting at Home: Caring and Social Policy) and Held (The Ethics of Care: Personal, Political, and Global) have argued that an ethic of care offers a viable supplement - if not alternative - to political theories of justice. These writers have sought to use care ethics to articulate a caring vision of social policy. This has proven to be an uphill battle for a few reasons. First, if care ethicists often acknowledge that care is most powerful and effective the 'closest to home' it is (we care best for those who are close to us, then how can an ethic of care say anything about what we owe to far-off others? Second, as Engster points out, because care ethics celebrates contextuallity and moral pluralism, many of the suggestions for a caring social policy have been vague guidelines rather than concrete policy proposals.In Heart of Justice, Engster attempts to flesh out a bit more what caring social policy might look like. What is the role and scope of government in a caring world? Is caring most compatible with socialism, market socialism, free markets, or some sort of mixed economy? And even beyond that, can we ground care ethics in something other than the natural emotion that most of us have to care for others (in other words, we have all sorts of natural emotions - from anger to revenge to care - so are there grounds to argue that care, rather than one of these other emotions, is what we should seek to nurture?)As best I can tell, Engster is a sort of market socialist who believes that markets in care services COULD do a better job in some cases than direct government provisions (allowing, for instance, that a regulated voucher system may lead to better outcomes of people's needs being satisfied than government provision of education). In my view - and my biases are revealed here - there is actually plenty of reason to take the idea that markets can provide caring outcomes better than government services; a simply perusal of decades of public choice economic literature should be sufficient to cast doubt on how responsive government bureaucracies often are to 'consumer' needs, and if decentralized governments are what we want, whether there is reason to think that decentralized governments stay that way for long. I like Engster's treatment; he is very balanced and unlike many care ethicists (see particularly Tronto's recent Caring Democracy: Markets, Equality, and Justice), gives at least some attention to whether markets can produce better outcomes than government provision of services. With proper regulation and state oversight, he suggests, they SOMETIMES can.Before that is an interesting discussion where Engster tries to offer a rational foundation for an ethic of care, not because we want to turn care ethics into a rationalistic philosophy, but without giving some rational account of why care, we risk not being able to convince those skeptical of adopting a care-based approach. At the risk of simplifying, the argument is this. (a) all of us are where we are today partly because of the care of others, sometimes those close to us, and sometimes from those distant from us; (b) we all probably agree that when we are in need, it is good for others to step in and help us; (c) because of that, if we want to be consistent, we should also hold that when others are in need, it is good for us and others to step in and help when they can. I think this is pretty solid, but my one reservation is that it may only set up a reciprocal obligation to care for those who've cared for us. In other words, why 'pay it forward' when it is clearer that my obligation to help only extends to those who have cared for me (or who I think are likely to return the favor)?To close the review, my real concern with this book is not whether it's arguments are interesting and good - they are both - but whether Engster's approach departs too radically from most existing accounts of care ethics. So, for one, Engster is more or less a consequentialist - what matters most is whether people get their needs met, not as much whether those meeting the needs do so from caring motive or within caring relationships. Second, while care ethics is often best seen as a communitarian theory, Engster's consequentialism and focus on a theory that satisfies people's needs seems to put him closer to a prioritarian or positive-rights position. Third, Engster does seem to value the idea of autonomy and individualism a bit more than many care ethicists (if one can take care of themselves, they should, often because that means that finite resources can be devoted to those truly in need of care - again, prioritarian.) And lastly, his starting off by offering a rational foundation for care, while I agree with this approach, seems to depart from the care ethics of someone like Nel Noddings.I guess in a philosophy so comparatively new, this kind of differentiation and modification should be welcomed, but I still wonder whether Engster's philosophy bears too many differences to existing accounts of care ethics that he risks being read as a positive-rights or prioritarian theorist in disguise. (As Engster actually admits, his approach bears a lot of similarity to a capabilities approach, and I suspect he may be closer to that here than to an ethic of care.) But either way, the book fills a needed hole in care ethics research and social policy, and Engster's arguments should evoke a lot of exciting thought and discussion. Recommended for anyone concerned with care ethics and social policy (or finding out why a caring approach can supplement or replace accounts of political justice.)

The Barnes and Noble Nook HD+ is either a really good tablet or a slightly below average tablet depending on what you are looking for (and maybe the price you paid). If you are looking for a decent semi-android-like tablet and don't need front or rear cameras - mostly for media consumption and sometimes productivity, it is pretty good. If you are looking for something more like an Ipad or Nexus 10, you may be best spending the extra money. In what follows, I want to give the pros, cons, and how the tablet compares to its chief rival, the Kindle Fire HD 8.9PROS OF THE HD+: First - and this is PURELY my aesthetic taste - I love the look of this tablet. Yes, it is made of plastics rather than metals, and I can kind of see how some, who want a firmer construction, might see and feel it as cheap. But in a world where 9 and 10 inch tablets have boring black bezels that screens that are flush with the bezel, this tablet actually looks quite stunning (well, everything except that strange little ring on the lower left side). Second, this tablet is the lightest you will find on the 9 inch market - WAY lighter than the Kindle Fire 8.9 and Ipad. Third, the operating system strikes a good combination of easy to use but customizable (one part Kindle Fire, one part Android). Fourth, the HD screen is just the best and brightest I've EVER seen on a tablet....nonetheless of this price point. And last... the price is very good for a tablet of this price, though there are some competitors that have prices just as low for those willing to make a few concessions (like the ASUS MeMO Pad Smart ME301T-A1-BL 10.1-Inch 16 GB Tablet ( Blue ) and the Sony Xperia 16 GB 9.4-Inch Tablet S SGPT121US/S.CONS OF THE HD+: First, no back- OR FRONT-facing cameras, which may be a drawback if you want to take pictures or video chat. Next, while this comes with Google Play, it is not exactly a full android experience. So, things like the 'swipable' update menu, the ability to create folders of apps, Google Now, and the ability to resize app shortcuts do not exist on this tablet; usably decent, but not as free-feeling as android. Second, the performance is decent for a dual core processor (same as the Kindle Fire HD), but is a bit laggy compared to some tablets. Websites load and scroll a bit choppy, the carousel on the homescreen (which is honestly quite useless seeing as you can put app and media shortcuts on your homescreen!) is laggy, etc. (Oddly, I have not had a choppiness problem streaming music or movies, though.) Next, there is a proprietary charger, so while all of your other devices use a micro-USB port, you will have to carry a Nook charger (that is mildly pricey) for this device. Lastly, this tablet does tend to heat up on the back when used for periods of time longer than, say, 40 minute. (I should probably mention here a quirk that may be a minor negative but is really more of an annoyance: this seems the only tablet in the history of tablets that can only charge when the device is ON.)Now, for those considering buying a Fire HD 8.9 or a Nook HD+, here is a quick rundown of the (good and bad) features each has that the other doesn't.KINDLE FIRE HD 8.9: Prime members have access to text-to-speech on books, the kindle lending library, and free streaming of SOME videos from Amazon Instant Video. The hardware is way clunkier and heavier than the Nook HD+ (but many will find it sturdier). Front-facing cameras for video chat. Easy to use Kindle Fire Operating System that is absolutely not customizable. (You can sideload third party apps, but Amazon goes out of its way to make this difficult, so most users will be locked into Amazon's app store.) Very good stereo speakers. This is a great tablet for those locked into amazon's ecosystem, consuming media primarily from amazon.NOOK HD+: Text-to-speech access (experimental) for Nook books and access to the (limited) Nook video library. Access to the Google Play store and the Nook App store (so you are not locked into one app store, and can get books and other things from many sources.) Nook operating system that way more customizable than Amazon's. Expandable storage via micro-SD card slot, which the Kindle Fire HD does not have. This is the better tablet for those who want a more tablet-y experience, beyond consuming Amazon media content.

Why does a marriage's health correlate with the percentage of time each person spends online? Why do divorce rates go down with recessions (unless you are poor)? Why is the percentage of black men who date women of other ethnicities higher than the percentage of black women who date men of other ethnicities?Economics is often called the dismal science, and one based on a presumption of 'rational actors.' For these reasons, it may seem off-putting to apply microeconomic methods to explain sexual and romantic behavior. But Professor Marina Adshade does a good job of showing us how economic thinking can help explain how and why humans choose as they do when it comes to sex and love. It is not that we ARE all rational calculators who seek to maximize utility (and isn't 'utility' a tough concept to define when it comes to romance?), but that the intuitions on which we make choices are often calibrated AS IF we are rational actors. (For more detail and argument, see Passions Within Reason: The Strategic Role of the Emotions.)This book is based on a course that Dr. Adshade created in 2008 at the University of British Columia, out of concern that many first-year economic students are not 'turned on' by talk of interest rates and consumption functions enough to remain Econ majors for year 2. The classes's success led to a successful blog and now, to a same-titled book. Adshade organizes the book 'chronologically': from discussing how opportunity costs (the available choices we forego in making a choice) help determine how we date and 'hook up.' Next, we get into courtship and marriage (and how the latter produces a 'mutual gain from trade' and a sort of insurance policy). Last, we get into how economic thinking can explain decisions to have children and who with (or who we risk having children with out of wedlock). Last, we discuss love in the 'golden years' and the economic reasons why it is easier for men AND WOMEN to find love at older ages.I confess to being a bit squeamish at applying certain economic assumptions to the realm of love and sex. For instance, in discussing why couples seem less likely to divorce during a recession, she essentially describes a situation where it is harder for people to walk away when the costs of doing so are higher (when they are in debt, when they owe on the house, etc). This may well be, but there may be psychic factors involved that are difficult for economists to measure, like the loyalty one feels for the person one has pledged their love to or the joy one feels in being with the other. Dr. Adshade certainly acknowledges these difficulties, but  gives them short shrift. (She sort of has to when using a methodology employing ideas 'utility maximization' on a subject where what 'utility' is may vary wildly from individual to individual.)Be that as it may, I really enjoyed this book and would readily recommend it to two groups: first, those who want a really interesting introduction to economics without the feel of a 'traditional' economics text. Here, we are introduced to such ideas as thick and thin markets, opportunity cost, equilibrium, and supply/demand shock, in a way that makes these concepts quite understandable and relatable. Next, I recommend this to folks already familiar with microeconomics, who want to see it applied in an exciting way to an unusual subject area.Some have found the book dry. I didn't find it that way, but then again, I'm used to reading academic texts. I found Dr. Adshade to be concise, clear and, at times, witty. She interjects personal and hypothetical stories quite often to illustrate what she says and keeps econ jargon to a minimum (though a certain amount of it really is unavoidable). So, I'll say it this way: if you expect Freakonomics (co-written by an economist and a popular journalist),  you'll be a bit disappointed in the prose. If you've read the popular columns of someone like Gary Becker, Milton Friedman, or Paul Krugman, you'll be able to make it easily through this book.

I REALLY wanted to like Lanier's new book, as I liked - and positively reviewed - his previous work, You Are Not a Gadget: A Manifesto (Vintage). I like and admire several points Lanier made there, but alas, there are simply too many fallacies in this book for Lanier's conclusion to hold. Also, stylistically, the book is poorly laid out, very repetitive, and prone to meandering.First, the positive: as with Lanier's last book, I think he is on the right track in criticizing the insane mantra that "informatoin wants to be free." (First, information isn't sentient enough to want anything, and second, those who produce information often want to be paid because the production isn't costless.) Second, several of Lanier's points about siren servers' ability to lock customers into their particular ecosystem to access content (think Apple's ios, or amazon's cloud for ebooks and mp3 music) are very well taken and need to be taken seriously. Third, as big an "open source" enthusiast, I can see at least some danger in allowing (or encouraging) individuals to create and make available information "for free" (though I don't think the results will be nearly as dire as Lanier predicts).Now, for the negative. First, his argument is premised on the idea that for economies to be healthy, the existence of a middle class is required. I am not an economist, but I know enough economists to know that this is a contentious point and very probably a tautology (the truth seems to be that an economy where products can be geared toward a middle class needs a healthy middle class.) Not that there aren't good reasons to want to see a healthy middle class, but "economies need them" is either not a good reason, or a good reason that requires more argument than Lanier gives.Second, Lanier is certainly no luddite, but his argument is identical to the luddite arguments of the past...the ones which have all proven wrong - that the new technology will simply destroy more jobs than it creates. Why have these arguments proved wrong? Because they are based on the assumption that the current marketplace (and the demand consumers express in it) is what the future economy will just look like, and that our lack of ability to guess at what people may demand in the future (once technology renders some current occupations and products obsolete) means that those possibilities probably don't exist. Take his brief discussion of how technology will destroy, or seriously dent, higher education. He talks about how new technologies that can scale instruction in a way that will render the existing model of higher education largely irrelevant spells doom for the higher education industry.That may be, but if this new education costs less than current education, we must imagine that the money that people WOULD HAVE spent on higher education will go somewhere - either saved (and invested) or spent. Where? We can only imagine. Lanier really does write as if he believes that people will just stop demanding things when present demands become easier to satisfy.Second, he writes that people should be paid when they contribute information to, say, Google, Facebook, etc, because they are providing these companies with valuable information (remember, facebook's users ARE NOT the customers; the businesses that use user's information are.) But, is the fact that they don't receive money payments mean they are not paid? What about Google providing me a free word processor, helpful calendar program, a free website creation service, and other things? Yes, Lanier may have a point that users may not realize exactly what information they are giving up, but I do have to imagine that a great many of them would still see the services "gives" them as a payment, even if they were made aware of exactly how much Google benefits from their information sharing. (Even in cases like Youtube, there must be a reason people are willing to create videos and share them freely; maybe the payment is just the knowledge that others are benefiting.) Simply put: just because money doesn't change hands doesn't mean payment doesn't exist.There are some other flaws in the book, such as Lanier's bizarre talk of how siren servers undermine the idea of free will by creating better and better behavior-prediction software, as if the fact that I can predict what choice you will make means you actually didn't make a choice. (Even if a company can predict what advertisement or price point it would take to 'nudge' you to buy x, that doesn't mean that you had no choice in buying x.)Stylistically, the book is very rambling and somewhat disorganized. It may well be that Lanier's case is much stronger than I am giving credit for and he just wasn't able to properly express it in this book. He is a very smart man indeed, but reading this book was much like reading someone who had so many intricate thoughts (and saw synthesis between just about every field on the planet) that he had difficulty limiting himself to one cogent argument. I skipped or skimmed a good many pages in the book largely because there were tangents and repetitions throughout.As I said, I wanted very much to like this book, and pre-ordered it months ago in anticipation. Unfortunately, there are many bad assumptions and arguments here, and the lack of structure just pushed it over the edge into the "disappointing" category.

"[T]his is not a memoir exactly; it is an account of a syndrome whose nature was a war with and for a self" (loc. 634)."Denial: My 25 Years Without a Soul" is a story of writer Jonathan Rausch's childhood, adolescent, and young adult years and what it was like to be gay without realizing one was gay. Rausch just believed that he was either asexual (or a heterosexual whose sexual feelings were just around the corner), and - smart as Rausch was - his brain ratioanlized his obsession with men's muscles as a strange case of envy. But meanwhile, where everyone else could feel romantic love, Rausch simply believed that that he was incapable of those feelings.The book starts during Rausch's early teens, when he realizes - just like that - that he'll probably never get married. He just doesn't have feelings toward girls. We follow Rausch through his burgeoning obsession with the male (athletic) figure and, in particular, a bodybuilding friend named Paul. It literally doesn't dawn on Rausch that he is gay, because (he says) he doesn't have sexual thoughts about boys. He rationalizes his admiration for their bodies as a sort of envy of a scrawny awkward boy of his "betters." In college, the same, and when periodic friends suggested he may be gay, he very honestly denied it (again, because homosexuality was about wanting sex with men, different from what he felt). It was only in his twenties (for reasons I'll leave you to discover) that he realized he may be - and then was - gay.I must reiterate - per Rausch's above quote - that this is not a memoir or even a story per se; Rausch is writing a psychological account of who he - this unsuspecting gay man, obsessed with his muscular friend Paul and convinced he was just abnormal and broken - was from childhood through adulthood. It is very well written, unflinchingly honest, Not a book you read if you just want a good story, but one you read if you really want to feel things you may never have felt before about a boy who exists but you've never known. This is what happens when a writer (given to self-analysis and -reflection) sruggles mightily with his sexuality and can put it into words for us.This book, that may have seemed too egocentric had it been a full novel's length, was quite perfect at less than 100 pages. Rausch's writing is appropriately self-reflective (even if his prose CAN be grandiose at times, using phrases like "dear reader" a bit too much for my tastes.) In this short book, though, Jonathan Rausch gives us a very compelling portrait of a boy trying desperately and unsuccessfully to figure himself out and finally - finally! - doing so.

In the 1960's, the hijacking of airplanes became something of an epidemic. Those who wanted money, amnesty in other countries, and both, decided that they could achieve these by taking over airplanes once in midair, and making demands. In order to save lives, airlines created policies that pilots and stewardesses should accede to hijackers' demands which, of course, made hijacking more lucrative and thus more common. This is the story of one such incident, of an interracial couple whose intent was to hijack a plane, rescue professor and political activist Angela Davis from a criminal trial, extort money from the US government, and give the money to Vietcong forces in Vietnam. The hijacking worked, but not as expected.This book is a journalist's attempt to tell the story of the hijackers, the hijacking, and the aftermath. This is interspersed with chapters about the American government and airlines attempts to deal with the new "epidemic" in hijackings from the late 1960's to middle 1970's. The writing is fast paced, well staged, and engaging.But honestly, I think the story falls a bit flat largely because there just wasn't anything particularly extraordinary about it. Particularly, about a third of the book is devoted to what happens to Holder and Kerkow after the hijacking, and much of this is quite anti-climactic. Of course, as the story isn't fictional, the author can't be blamed for the lackluster latter portion of the book, it does it did make me wonder several times why this hijacking story was picked rather than others.Also, those who like historical readings will be a bit disappointed. To some degree, this story does intersect with America's attempts to grapple with the Vietnam war, civil rights, the rise of the Black Panthers, and debates over airport security in the age of hijacking, but these excursions are minimal, only engaged in to the degree necessary to explain the book's characters and "plot.'This is an averagely enjoyable book, and those who want some mix of an engrossing journalistic story interspersed with some history will find some enjoyable things here. But I came away questioning why this story was told, as I didn't find it terribly compelling.

In one way, I am not the best person to write this review, but in another way, I may be exactly who should be writing the review. I am NOT the target audience for Office Professional; I'm a PhD student who uses a word processor, slide presentation software, database creator, and (if we go back about five years) a native e-mail client. But, on the other hand, I can approach Office with fresh eyes, because I haven't used Office for about two years. I tend to use the free LibreOffice for the my word processing and other needs, and webmail rather than Outlook. I use Office 2007 at work, but that is about it. (If you are wondering, I was given a promotional copy of the software to review for amazon.)And, to be honest, I don't love or hate the new Office. What do I like? Web integration is great - the way we have the option to sync files seamlessly with Microsoft SkyDrive (Microsoft's cloud storage). Of course, you can also do that with Google Drive, but there are still some lingering compatibility issues between Office and Drive. (Contrary to another reviewer's comments, one does not HAVE to save documents on the cloud; rather, setting up Office automatically sets up a SkyDrive folder that links to the cloud. So, when you save a document, you can either save it in that folder and, by extension, on the cloud, or in another folder not linked to the cloud.)I kind of like how easy it is to insert pictures and videos into documents and presentations (for videos). Unlike some past versions of Windows, one needed to have a picture or video saved natively in order to insert it, and inserting web video was a multi-step process. Not anymore. There is an easy option in PowerPoint (and Word) to insert pictures or videos from the web that, when clicked opens up a Bing search for pictures or videos by keyword. Once you click on your desired image or video, it inserts into the document.
