(The feature for inserting video into PowerPoint has proven A BIT buggy for me, where it will insert a picture of the video, but not the video itself, but that's only happened a few times.)Other than these, there is absolutely nothing that would compel me to spend a large amount of money on this product. Simply put, Microsoft now has competition in every area of Office, and everything Office can do, something else can do either just as well or better. LibreOffice has every bit of the functionality (with the possible exception of PowerPoint being better than Impress) for a price of zero. Google Docs and Google Drive can do quite a bit of what the average user would require from Windows, as well as replicate the experience of SkyDrive....also for a price of zero. I made myself try Outlook for purposes of this review - because I haven't used a native e-mail client in many years - and I don't see much that it can do that is worth the hard drive space, price, or giving up the convenience of cloud-based webmail.I think I will stick with LibreOffice, Google Drive, and webmail. Office has offered me no compelling reason not to.

I think we jazz lovers are all guilty, at times, of using jazz as background music - letting one's brain wander onto other things while songs play in the background. This, folks, is an album that should never be reduced to background music. Jimmy Smith and Stanley Turrentine are both exquisite soloists, and both are at their most melodic on this record (Smith plays a bit more sparingly on this album than he often does). While Donald Bailey (dr) and Quentin Warren are relegated to supporting roles (the only soloists are Turrentine and Smith), they do a great job, especially following Turrentine and Smith's dynamics changes and cues).The songs here are pure soul. Prayer Meetin' is a roadhouse style 12-bar blues with a wickedly soulful guitar riff. When the Saints Go Marching In is pure energetic gospel, and Smith's syncopated solo is probably worth the price of the album. I Almost Lost My Mind is a beautiful slow, sensitive blues. The album is pure soul from start to finish (even the strange latin feel of Stone Cold Dead in the Market has soul to it!).I've had this album for precisely three days and I've listened to it precisely three times, and I have to imagine that this will work itself into my "favorite albums" list. Please, no background music here. This here is foreground music.

This is the best space/portable heater I have ever used! I work in a very cold office and this provides plenty of warmth for myself and coworkers who sit near me!What I love:1. Amazing quality and craftsmanship! It is very good looking, unlike other space heaters.2. The cord can be wound up on the bottom for easy transport and storage.3. Simple simple simple operation.4. Very well built high quality switches and knobs.5. A 5 year warranty.6. We tested the "tip over" protection and it works perfectly.7. Built in carry handle.What I do not love:1. It is quite expensive, but you get what you pay for. This does not change my 5 star rating, just wish it was a little cheaper in price.2. No thermostat feature. Its either on or off. No temperature setting like some other models. BUT the strange thing is it "sort of" does have a thermostat built in, because the unit will shut off if it gets too hot.. unfortunately this is a safety feature only.If you need a space heater, and want "quality", "simplicity", and "durability", AND you don't mind the hefty price tag, THIS is simply the best option out there in my opinion. It's like the "Dyson" of space heaters.

I got this toy to give to my friend with a one year old baby daughter! I got some "hands on" time unboxing it and watching her play with her new toy. The toy is very well built and durable. It does require AA batteries which are not included.The handle can be attached to "push" around sort of like a lawn mower, or removed to be played with like a toy car. The buttons all light up and different songs/phrases are played electronically.I see this as a gift that can grow with the child as they get a little older, assuming they don't get bored easily. Right now, because the girl is only one, she is playing with it without the handle attached. I have nothing to complain about and this would make a wonderful gift for any toddler or young child. It doesn't just make sounds, it is somewhat educational too!

I don't have a fancy set-up, nor do I play that many games. I acquired this remote to use while watching Blu-Rays and videos on my PS4. My set-up is simple, my large TV connected to my PS4. No soundbars, cable boxes, receivers, surround sound, or any other gadgets.So my review is only based on using it as a remote solely to watch movies/videos on the PS4. I was sick and tired of using the dual shock controller, always bumping a button by accident or forgetting what button does which... This is why I got this remote.It paired very easily, the quality is decent, I can play, pause, skip, rewind, etc without problems. For this, it deserves 4 stars.I easily programmed my TV (Vizio 70" 1080p) and that's it. It powers on my TV, it works the volume, and controls my PS4. I can't really complain.Now, for those who have multiple devices (receivers, etc), I can totally understand the lower ratings and frustration. I am just a simple person, with a simple set-up and this basic remote works fine for me. I don't have to constantly guess which buttons do what on the DS4 controller anymore when watching a movie. The best thing is now I can just use batteries and they should last a loooong time, instead of charging my DS4 every few days.

This Serta Comfort Blanket is the best heated blanket I've ever used. Even though I live in Houston, TX.. when the cold fronts come in, I love using a heated blanket instead of turning on the heater throughout the entire house. The reason is by the next morning/day, it'll be warm again and then the entire house gets too warm. (Houston weather problems).So with this heater blanket, my wife and I can sleep comfortably and save quite a bit on our electric bill.My favorite features are:1. Very very plush and soft (Queen size)2. Very long cord, 19 ft. VERY LONG and reaches our oddly placed wall outlet.3. Digital controller (easy to use, temp +/-, Time +/-, and On/off) Simple!4. Lighted display on the controller so you can see in the dark.5. A 3 year warrantyMy wife and I sleep very little ~5-6 hours each night due to our schedules so the 12 hour timer doesn't really make a difference, but its great to have. We usually set it for 7 hours and simply go to sleep. The unit gets very warm (this is subjective) so we just set it on the lower temp settings. Usually a 2 is plenty warm for us in Houston.The blanket is wonderful and we highly recommend it. I really wish if they could improve ONE SINGLE thing, it would to put a rubber texture around the control unit so it doesn't slide off the night stand, and will be quieter when setting down onto a hard surface.One last thing, Can you feel the wires/heating elements? The short answer is "no". You literally have to try and squeeze your fingers into the blanket and you "may" feel something, but with normal use, we do "not" feel any wires like the cheaper heating blankets.Hope this helps, this is a "top of the line" heated blanket and it works very well.

This Sentinel 12 sheet crosscut shredder is a beast. A very very quiet beast. It will literally devour and shred EASILY 12 sheets of paper at a time. Now, I just stick the entire envelope without bothering to open it straight into the shredder. Before with junk mail, I'd have to open the letter, take the paper out, unfold the paper, etc.. Now, the entire envelope goes right in. Boom, Done! I've also shredded many old cards and the shredder didn't show any sign of hesitation. Stick it in, and its shredded into confetti like little pieces.I love crosscut shredders because you don't have to empty the bin as often, plus it is much much more secure than the strip style of shredders. The unit is very quiet compared to my previous cheaper model. The unit is very robust and well built, almost unnecessarily heavy in weight, but it just means I don't need to worry about it tipping over.I love the carry handle and lock to bin feature. Now I can just carry the entire shredder/basket easily into my garage to empty and not have to worry about picking up tiny pieces of shredded paper like before. The compaction feature works well, but I find with cross cutting, it isnt really necessary because the tiny pieces of paper take up much less volume. But regardless, it will compress the paper (manually) and you can keep shredding before needing to empty the basket. But remember, if you keep compacting and compacting, the moment you do empty the shredder, the paper will expand and you risk having tiny pieces fall all over the floor. This is why I do not compact it too much, I just simply unload it and prevent a mess.This is a very solid unit, it works very well and I expect it to last a long time.

I love Ultimate Direction gear. I have the AK vest so I am used to the bottles they use. This Access 20 Plus waistpack is comfortable for what it is.. Of course with the 20 oz. size of the bottle filled with water, it's heavy. If you pack in gels, keys, a phone, it gets even heavier. BUT this is nothing new, just don't think the belt will be 100% motionless and feel perfectly weightless. That's impossible.The reason I chose this pack is mainly for the storage! Finally, I can fit my iphone 6 with case and keys and not worry. Every other pack i tried can barely fit an iphone 6 or simply can't. I do not use the gel tube and leave it off the belt since I do not really run long distances. When I do, I wear my vest.The water bottle itself is sturdy and holds lots of water, yes it is stiff, but that makes it easier to unholster and reholster the bottle. I do wish it were insulated since Texas heat can be brutal in the summers. What I do is fill it 40-50% with water and freeze it overnight.. right before my run, I top the rest off with water. On short notice, I just use ice cubes but it "rattles" and can be a bit annoying. The wide mouth makes it very easy to put ice cubes, powders, etc into the bottle. It also makes it super easy to clean with a regular bottle brush. I just toss the lid into the dishwasher and have no problems.It's a great pack and very secure.. but just don't have a false impression that is simply "disappears" and you won't realize it's there. You will (minimally), and you will make minor adjustments throughout the course of your run. But it's no different than a vest or any other type of bottle belt. I wear this with the bottle positioned in the small of my back.If holding a large phone or multiple items is not a primary concern of yours, there are more "minimalist" options to pick from. This is the waist pack made for pack-rats like myself.

Until this iron, my experience with irons has been minimal at best. I must admit, I am not very good at ironing dress shirts, slacks, etc.. Im just a 35 year old guy who does his best.However, this iron really makes things easier because of the incredible amount of steam it generates. My prior iron (Rowenta) did the job fine, but the output of steam absolutely cannot compare to this B&D unit.Pros:Heavy and well built.TONS of steam.Easy to use digital controls.Long cord.Doesn't leak if filled properly.The plate is smooth as a polished mirror & robust.Heats up very quickly.Beautiful design. Modern and almost futuristic.Cons: None I can think of. (Remember, I am a amateur at ironing and don't know the nuances about irons). This thing just works and works great to me. I can basically "steam" out any wrinkles in any article of clothing or fabric.I highly recommend this great Allure Digital Iron. I cannot find fault.

What can I say about "commercial grade" toilet paper? Let's see...Each roll is individually wrapped for sanitary purposes and presentation.Each roll has 400 double ply sheets.There are a total of 20 rolls in the box, "equivalent" to 59 "standard" rolls.The box is perforated and easy to open, AND acts as "storage" for easy access and organization.I find it to be a step above "Scotts" brand of toilet paper in comfort and quality. It gets the job done, may not be THE most comfortable and blankety like in softness, but hey it's "commercial grade".I have no complaints and recommend this.

Great watch! I use it every time I run both indoors on a treadmill and outdoors. It is very accurate, and I love that it can sync via Bluetooth onto my android phone. The battery lasts a long time even when using the GPS. It is very accurate on a treadmill and there is no need for a foot pod. Just keep it calibrated by doing an outdoor gps run once in a while, and when on the treadmill, it will be almost spot on. The new usb battery charger device is tough and well built and very east to use.I love this watch and would buy it again. It tells you your hear rate, cadence, speed, pace, distance, time.

I've never played any of the GOW games on PS3, so this is my first experience as a PS4 owner. This game is amazing. Easy to play, beautiful graphics, and I love the setting/characters. The Greek mythology story line is awesome! For $20 bucks, you simply can't beat it.I have no complaints. If you've never played GOW on the PS3, get this! You won't regret it. The visuals are stunning!!!

I ordered this vest from Amazon and wanted to leave a review to give other potential buyers a heads up.Fit: Good, I am 6'2" ~178 lbs and the vest fits me just fine, it is very adjustable.Movement: Good, it remains motion free and still, if the vest were empty, I would say it is very comfortable.Pockets: The front zipper pocket will hold ID's gels, keys, etc... BUT no modern smartphone larger than an iphone 5 with no case. But that does not affect the rating. (just a warning to those who are wondering)Hydration bladder: Holds plenty of water, doesn't slosh, long easy to reach tube. water gets warm quick, especially in sun. No really insulated. If you take little sips, the water remaining in the tube is really un-insulated so it will warm up.Look: I think it looks greatWeight: this is my first pack so I don't have anything to compare it to.NEGATIVES:1. The clips that secure the tube to the front of the chest are super tight. It really takes some work to clip and unclip the tube. Otherwise, it flops and flys around like a snake when running. Like pain in the nail type of difficult. - 1 star2. The Angle of the front water bottle holders... grrr this was the major problem. I tried running without the bladder and use the 2 front pockets with regular water bottles instead (a 20 ounce, and 12 ounce)... but what a bad design!!! The bottles are canted/angled so the bottom of the water bottles hit your elbow each time your arms swing back and forth. At least the way my running form is (nothing unusual I promise). Make sure you look at a front facing picture and you will understand. -2 starThe angle of the front bottle holders really ruins this vest. It may work just fine if you are walking, or you dont swing your arms..Just a fair warning! Make sure you look at pictures from the Camelbak website prior to purchasing to see if this will bother you. I had to return it.

Awesome. Holds my LG G3 with a slim case in the main top pouch.My keys in the smaller lower pouch. Does not move while running. I love the top loading feature. Keeps you from accidentally dropping your phone when inserting and removing. I'd buy this again.

When fully expanded, it holds 13-15 pairs of my mens size 12 Running shoes. Like Nike Frees, etc..I put the slightly taller shoes on the top rack.Each row (3 total) will hold 4-5 pairs of mens size 12 easily.It feels sturdy even when fully loaded. Assembly is easy, took 5 minutes, no tools needed. For the price, its awesome.

Yes it expands, Yes it does not move while running. Yes it feels secure. BUT OMG, why is the zipper in the middle of the pouch?!!I have almost dropped my cell phone every single time I try to insert it and zip it up. You literally have to take the belt off, insert your phone very carefully, zip it up, then put the belt on. grrrr.If you only need to carry a key and a ID/card. this will work great. BUT if you carry a phone (especially a larger phone like my LG G3, I would look for a belt with a top loading zipper (which there are plenty of)I wont be using this much for running, because I must carry my phone with me.

Boots in secondsMy battery is averaging 12-13 hours of web browsing. I rarely watch videos.The wifi connects to my home and everywhere else perfectly.Light weightGood build quality for the priceDecent screen, but the viewing angle is pretty unforgiving.Resolution is good for the priceThe built in speakers actually sound very very decent. I listen to spotify all the time and the audio is on par with Macbooks, or other laptops costing much more.I rarely carry the charger anywhere because of the battery life.Sleek and fast. Its just a Google Chrome browser basically.This is my first Chromebook. It really blew me away once I started using it... I realized 95% of what I do is through a browser anyways. This is the perfect travel companion. It is very quick and snappy, faster than my desktop or other laptops running a full OS.Gripes:the charger prongs do not retract or fold. (think apple chargers, the metal prongs fold) The Asus charger does not.The blue outer shell is okay, but an absolutely fingerprint magnet.The proprietary charger connector should be redesigned. It "seems" weak and delicate. Even though I have had no problems yet.Remember, this thing is below $200 for the 4gb version (the one I bought). I really works awesome! I recommend this 100%

I am just an average guy who surfs the net, reads the news, and rarely demands much from my mouse/keyboard. So this review is coming from a non-power user.Please be aware, this keyboard is designed mainly for Windows 8, not Mac OS, or previous older versions of Windows.I paired the keyboard and mouse to my HP desktop w/ Win 8.1 (with built in Bluetooth) effortlessly. I really like the quality feel of the keyboard. The mouse on the other hand is not very comfortable and honestly, it is too flat for long term use (-1 star). My wrist hurt after a while because I have large hands.Battery life: I am on the original set of batteries, so I cannot comment on battery life yet. The battery doors are very nice.Please be aware, your PC must have Bluetooth built in, OR you must purchase a Bluetooth Dongle separately! (-1 star) for the price of nearly $100, a Bluetooth receiver should have been included.The keyboard keys are similar in feel with a modern Mac type keyboard. I personally do not like typing on Keyboards like this. But it works, and that is subjective.The Keyboard and Mouse combo is very pleasing to the eye. It looks sleek and high quality. But as we know, looks only go so far.I really wish the keys were backlit, but being battery powered and wireless, I can see how this would drain the batteries quickly.So honestly, for the price, I would look elsewhere.

I am familiar with JA Henckels products, I own a pair of kitchen utility scissors and several of their chef knives. All have served me well.I received this nail clipper hoping the extra cost is justified, and that it would be a superior nail clipper that will last me years and years....This JAH Nail Clipper has a few minor annoyances I would like to share. The plastic nail catcher (black part) is extremely difficult to get on and off. Its very wide, and simply a poor design. Also the Nail clipper is quite small, so it is mainly meant for cutting finger nails. Yes, the quality of the metal and the cutting blade is very good, but honestly my $3 clipper works the same.The nail file is a thin strip (like a toothpick) built onto the edge of the nail catcher (black part). It does not work very well because of the long/thin shape. It does work to get rid of minor unevenness, but not much more than that. For the price, I would probably pass this clipper up and stick with lower cost options. This Henckels clipper isn't really worth the high price.

Simply magical. Soap and this scrubber will leave your skin squeaky clean. My skin has literally never been this clean. Just know, the texture is very rough, like sand paper. People will delicate skin need to avoid this. My wife could not stand using it, it was way too abrasive for her.If you want your skin clean, this works!

This Thule Sapling Elite is an amazing child carrier. The carrier has MANY pockets and storage compartments for everything you could possibly need for an outing. My wife and I find the carrier to be super comfortable when worn. I am 6 foot tall and she is 5 foot 2 inches. The carrier looked "intimidating" to me when we first got it. Tons of straps, buckles, zippers, etc. Once you look at the carrier, everything makes sense. The adjustments are easily made and well thought out. My favorite features are the light weight, adjust-ability, and storage ability. The only downside I can think of is the price, but you certainly get what you pay for. I highly recommend this Thule Sapling Elite carrier.

Works great for me to chop onions, garlic, tomatoes, etc. The clean up is very simple. I take it apart and put the plastic parts into my dishwasher.I find the 3 cup size to be perfect for quick chopping and less waste. The unit is loud (subjective) but works well and is cheap. The unit features a high and low speed button. The cord is long enough, but thankfully, not tooooo long.I would certainly buy this again, especially for the price.

The charge HR is my first activity band. It honestly has replaced the traditional watch I wore daily because it also displays the time and date. I really like all the features of the charge HR. Once you understand that it is not a professional/medical grade "data" tool, but more of a "motivational & personal activity" tool, then the Fitbit's purpose will make sense to you. My wife uses the Fitbit Zip and she loves it too. We challenge each other daily on who can do more steps in a day. I average 12K/day and my wife blows me away at 18K+/day!I am 6'1" and 210 lbs, the Large fits me perfectly. I average 4-5 days of battery life on a full charge, and I am constantly syncing my watch, especially at the gym. Since the charge HR needs to be removed when showering, this is the perfect time for me to charge it. Setup is simple via a PC or just using the smartphone app. Fitbit has nice social features to join groups and add friends for challenges.My wife and I love our fitbits! I think the Charge HR model is the best one to get for the price and options. If you are on a budget, the "Charge" model is a great value. It has everything this one has, except for the heart monitor, AND buckle to keep the strap on. I like the strap on my charge HR, because it is more secure and I don't need to worry about it accidentally falling off my wrist.The heart rate monitor is just as accurate as anything found on a gym treadmill/elliptical. Usually only off by 1-2 beats. Please note, the reading can take a while to "catch up", as this technology has it's weaknesses. Again this is not a professional/medical grade heart rate monitor. It is for a fitness enthusiast or someone looking to be more active.The software works well both on PC and Android.Another awesome feature that I LOVE is the "vibrating" alarm. It is surprisingly powerful and wakes me up easily. I really thought this feature was gimmicky and would never really be able to wake people up, but every morning at 7:45am, mine goes off and I instantly wake up. The vibration "gently" startles you awake, but not in a heart pounding panic like regular audio alarms. You can set multiple alarms and have them repeat on specified days of the week.My few small complaints:-Fitbit, please add a feature to vibrate the watch and remind you to drink water at certain intervals/period of time.-Increase the vibration time of the incoming call notification. One quick vibration is easily overlooked, especially when working out.-Please also include a longer usb charging cable-Feel free to go bolder with the colors/designs. Black silicone rubber is boring, even as a guy. Have some more vivid, eye catching design options/colors available.-Please use a more scratch resistant display, such as Gorilla glass. (even though my plastic display has not scratched, it is still a concern), especially working with weights.-MAKE THE DARN WATCH SHOWER-PROOF! it's 2015 and the watch is $150! It should be water resistant enough to safely shower without removing.Even with these complaints, I would still recommend the charge HR. There is no need to spend any more on the Fitbit surge model IMO, as your cellphone can track outdoor running with it's gps and many apps.I think in a few more generations, these fitness bands will be amazing, but the latest Fitbits prove the technology is maturing very well.

I use a Fitbit Charge HR and my wife uses this Fitbit Zip. She loves it, and we compete all the time with our daily steps using the social media friendly app. Its a fun way to get motivated for the gym and pushing the limits on cardio. Yes the zip works very well on an elliptical machine and treadmill. Easy to set up and can be done completely from the phone app. You don't necessarily need to connect this to a PC, but it does make the experience more enjoyable.If you have the ability to, I highly recommend the Charge or Charge HR for all the cool features they offer. I've been wearing my Charge HR for almost a week now and it's been great.

The Febreze air freshener comes extremely well packaged in a recycled cardboard packaging with a plastic film you peel off. Just like other oil air fresheners, you unscrew the tops (2) and insert the oil vial into the warmer. Nothing new.The oil warmer plugs into the wall, on the back is the sliding adjustment for a weak or strong scent.The (Shimmer) scent is hard to describe, but is a mixture of Rose/Melon/Watermelon. It is very sweet and almost overwhelming. I do like the product, just not this particular (Shimmer) scent. But smells are very subjective. I have one unit plugged into the center of my one story house and the smell fills the entire house.I will try a refill with a different scent next time. Hope this helps.

#### UPDATE #### UPDATE ######## UPDATE #### UPDATE ####It has been a little over a week now and I wanted to take a moment to update you about my Arlo system.I did absolutely forget to mention one more important aspect of the Dropcam, which is AUDIO. The dropcam offers very accurate and sensitive sound detection. You can customize the sensitivity and even hear the faintest sound.  This means the dropcam can also be set to record audio constantly, or begin to record once sound is detected. The dropcam also features a basic low quality output speaker, which you can talk through using the Dropcam app on your mobile phone. I actually tested the feature and spoke with my wife who was at home, while I was overseas on a business trip using wifi and my mobile app. It works very similar to a walkie talkie. It does not work like a normal phone conversation, instead, only one person can speak at a time, like a 2 way radio with a delay. This feature may only be useful for monitoring a pet "OFF the Counter!!", lol or maybe reminding your child "Do your homework!". The Arlo does not have audio, but I knew this going in, so it is of no consequence to the Arlo system's score. I simply did not use the audio feature enough on my dropcams and forgot to mention audio in my original review. It's a great feature, but for my purposes, audio is not a priority.Regarding the battery life, I have good and bad news. The bad news is the outdoor camera battery, only lasted around 6 days after installing a fresh set of batteries. The low battery warning appeared around the end of the 5th day, and the camera was dead by the 6th. I think this may be an issue due to the infrared sensors or maybe temperature? (its pretty chilly in the evenings ~38-40F). Again, I'm not an engineer so I have no clue what is causing this issue. For those like me who are price conscious, I am now on my third set of CR123A batteries. Again, the cost of the batteries could be justified somewhat due to the fact that the Arlo works well being FREE, you do not need to pay a monthly fee for cloud recording like dropcam.Remember, battery life varies greatly for everyone on something like security cams. Just because I am getting 6 days of use does "Not" mean "you" will get the same. You have to take into consideration, settings, environment, ambient light, temperature, and many other various options. So please don't say "well I only got 2 days" or I got 2 months of use". Everyone's mileage will differ. This is why I cannot change the rating of my review.Regarding reliability, I had to restart the app on my phone a few times. The app would freeze and become non-responsive. Rebooting my phone or restarting the app solved the problem every time. A very minor annoyance, and has only happened about 3-4 times. I have had no issues with the cameras operating as of yet. I am sure as the software is upgraded and improved, the issue with the app will be sorted out.Besides the short battery life, I have nothing else to report. I have another week to decide if I will keep the Arlo system or return to my old dropcams and deal with the annoyances of wires. As of right now, I am leaning towards keeping the Arlo system as I really enjoy having the camera outside on my porch. It makes me feel safe to know that potential thieves/criminals would be recorded and stored in the Arlo servers "cloud". With dropcam, they can only be mounted inside the house, near a power outlet.If anything else changes, I'll certainly report back with an update. Best Wishes!"#### END UPDATE #### END UPDATE ######## END UPDATE #### END UPDATE ####[[[[[ORIGINAL REVIEW]]]]]]I have used Dropcams (2 were in constant use) in my home for over 6 months prior to purchasing the Arlo system. The dropcams have served me very well, but they also have limitations which I will explain throughout this review.Let's start with the setup. The Arlo system did honestly take me longer to decide where to put them, compared to the time it took me to set up. 5 minutes using an iPhone app, checking a few options, and done! The dropcams, were also similar in ease to set up. I consider this a tie between Arlo and dropcam.The video quality on the "balanced (middle)" Arlo setting, is about the same as the Non-HD setting on a Dropcam. (my dropcam only has the option of HD or non-HD) This resolution is fine for my use of home monitoring, without killing your internet bandwidth.. (don't forget to take this into consideration). (wifi video monitoring and streaming uses a lot of data, so make sure your home internet provider doesn't have a cap on your data usage).The greatest advantage to the Arlo system compared to the Dropcam system is:1. Wire free, no cables whatsoever attaches to the camera. This is the very reason I eagerly purchased this system! I hated having to compromise with the placement of Dropcams because of the power outlet requirement. With Arlo, you can easily get creative in the ways to mount the wireless cameras, which is a huge plus. Dropcams can be easily "unplugged" by anyone. If the Arlo is mounted on a ceiling or high up, this would make it much harder to disable.2. Arlo provides SEVEN days of FREE cloud storage of your video stream! Dropcam charges $10/month! or $99/year for 7 days of storage for the 1st camera!! (more for additional cameras!!) For 30 days of recording, it costs even more! If you don't know, this is where they will store the video in their servers for 7 days, so you can access the videos online or on your phone app, and save them onto your computer. In case you need to share the video with police, friends, etc.3. The Arlo system is also weatherproof. But only time will reveal how it stands up to humidity, moisture, condensation, dust, sand, HEAT (im in Texas)! Until this is an issue, it is a clear advantage compared to dropcam. Dropcams are only for indoors! You cannot mount them outside as they are not weatherproof and require a power outlet.The Arlo system truly shines because of those three reasons, especially when compared to DropCam!I love the magnetic mounting, I have one pointed straight down the largest portion of my living area/kitchen to monitor my beloved dog when I am out. The other is pointed outside in my patio so I can record deliveries, solicitors, potential burglars, etc.The DropCam system is greatly disadvantaged because it must have a power source nearby to plug in. That forces you to live with long or short, exposed cable, or breaking sheetrock and repairing the walls to hide the cables. This really limits the placement of dropcams.Now here are 2 Advantages of the DropCam system (again, I am being fair and non-biased).1. Rock solid stability. In the 6 months I've used both dropcams on my wifi system. I have NEVER had a single problem. I can view livestream, recordings, get notifications, change settings, etc all on my phone in an instant. I understand the Arlo system can do the same, but only time will tell if the Arlo system is as solid and reliable as DC. (this does not influence my rating, because the Arlo system has worked fine (surprisingly)...so far)2. The field of view on the Dropcam is superior to Arlo's very very wide view. I find the dropcam view a much better compromise of size and wideness. (People are larger in size, everything seems more normal, and not "fisheye'y on my dropcams)(I take away half a star on the Arlo system because of this) The Field of view on the Dropcam really is better. The Arlo view makes everything look small and the slightly rounded fisheye effect is not desirable for my needs. Is this an absolute deal-breaker? no. But the next topic may be...For my final topic of discussion, it will be about battery life.I have used my Arlo system for 2 days now, I purchased at a local electronics store in Houston called, Fry's)My indoor camera in the living room/kitchen is still running on the first original fresh set of batteries. whew.The outdoor camera however is now on the 2nd set. Like the other reviewer, within 10-12 hours, low battery warning was showing. This is not good. Either there is something wrong with the IR sensor for night vision, or maybe the temperature is affecting the battery life? Im not sure, I'm not a electronics guru or anything. But I replaced the battery and things are looking good "so far", but it hasn't been long. This really concerns me as the batteries are expensive. CR123A, check it out yourself and see if you are willing to risk needing to constantly replace these batteries...even if it's every 2 weeks. These batteries are expensive!That is where the Arlo system lost another half star.I would rate the Arlo 4 stars for its excellent design, ease of use/setup, quality, price, weatherproof feature, and most importantly No Wires and FREE!!! cloud recording.My biggest complaints are the field of view, and the potentially unacceptable battery life... (I will try to update in a week or so)Yes, you can argue that the battery costs, are offset by the free cloud recording.. but do you want to risk being on vacation and the battery dies and renders the camera useless?I hope this review helps. Please know that I am not affiliated with either company. I used my dropcams for 6 months and I am merely offering a non-biased comparison explaining each systems own pro's and con's. The deciding factors between the two, DEPENDS on if You must have wireless, want free cloud recording, and if you're willing to spend $$$ on CR123A batteries. Or a combination of those factors.The Arlo is a great product, I really hope the battery issues are sorted out. I will try the Arlo system for 3 more weeks and decide if I will keep it or return it before the 30 day return period ends. I will update in a week or so.Best wishes to you all.

Very nice 5 subject notebook, but >$10 for each notebook? That is very very high! I recommend that you purchase these at a local store, as they are MUCH cheaper.The quality is excellent, pages tear cleanly, the front and back covers are very durable. I like having pockets to put in additional papers, etc. Please note that it is Wide ruled (fewer lines) and not college ruled (more lines) which is fine by me, as I write big.These are fantastic, but save the $ and purchase locally. These notebooks certainly deserve 5 stars, even at the premium price.
Bought these for my wife in case she ever wants to cook. Her knife skills are very poor and I am always afraid she will cut herself.This is good protection for anyone Not good with sharp knives.

One of the most entertaining movies I've seen in a while. Very strong language, so definitely not suitable for kids/children.Very bloody, violent, and witty. I love the dialogue & humor. Another classic by QT.

Super comfy, looks great, and cheap!I ordered a 11.5 4E, and they fit pretty much true to size. BUT they are slightly long in length as some people have mentioned.  It doesn't bother me though. I would recommend you order your normal size for a relaxed fit or half a size down if you want a snug fit.I would buy them again.
I love these socks, they are cheap and durable.The black color keeps them looking new. I purchased a second pack recently and they all fit great. cheap and lasts a long time. I cant complain.

Ultra comfortable. Feels amazing, lasts a very long time. All my underwear is now ExOfficio. I like the boxers and boxer briefs.My favorite feature is the sturdy and firm waist band. They dont flip over or become bothersome, even while exercising at the gym.Every pair I own still looks pretty much new. No pilling, fraying, tearing, etc.

Used during a return flight from Orlando FL, to Houston, TX. to carry dirty clothes, non-important clothing items back from a 1 week vacation. This allowed me to put gifts, souvenirs, expensive goods, etc in my hard suitcases after a vacation.No issues whatsoever, no tears or damage. The bag is VERY large. so look at the dimensions before ordering. You can also lock or ziptie the zipper tabs together.Id buy it again for sure.

I love these headphones. They are bass heavy (which i prefer), and honestly sound better than beats solo2's which I also own.I find these cans very durable and comfortable. I have a very large head and they fit just fine. These cans sound incredible listening to hiphop, electronic, techno, dubstep, etc..I would not recommend these for acoustic, vocal, classical type music as the mids and highs aren't as accurate.These cans are made for hiphop/electronic bass heavy music. I use these for the gym and playing video games they work well.

Lightweight hoodie, comfortable, soft, and the sleeves are long enough for me. I am 6'2" 210lbs with somewhat longer arms than normal.The only complaint I have is the cuffs on the sleeves are very loose, and wont stay up if you like to wear the sleeves around your elbows.The cuffs don't have much elasticity to it and constantly slide back down towards your wrist. It can be quite annoying if you're in a slightly warmer environment.I love the design and look. The XXL fits me loose and comfortable, BUT not baggy or sloppy.

I wanted to write a review after putting in several hours into the game. I installed the game and the update file before playing for the first time.The graphics are jaw dropping gorgeous. I can honestly say, it is one of the most beautiful games I have ever played. The level of details and the environment (old Paris) is stunning. The movement of the character is fluid and easy to grasp. I do not play FPS type games and have no problems scaling walls, running, jumping etc. The game begins with a built in tutorial which flows very nicely and introduces the story and main character. Once you complete the "tutorial" the world opens up and you are free to roam and play individual missions, if you choose to. The combat system is simple, but not boring. which is a good thing.On the downside, the graphics do show some bugginess such as flickering textures, missing textures, etc.. BUT it honestly does not take away from the game. Now, it HAS frozen on me a few times and required me to go to the main PS menu, and close the ACU application. Also, the game has to load constantly, especially before, during, after cutscenes. Sadly, this is why the game has lost 1 star.I must admit, I had high hopes that the issues/bugs were 99.9% resolved, but unfortunately my game has frozen a few times randomly. If you can live with these minor annoyances and get the game cheap/used, I would still recommend it. Just don't pay full price or have super high expectations that the bugs have all been resolved.I do enjoy the game, and I would still recommend it to anyone who is not into FPS games such as myself. I am a very casual gamer, and not very critical of small bugs. Could it have been more polished and refined? YES absolutely! But is the game unplayable now? No, it is very fun, beautiful, and full of exciting things to do. I really do enjoy it as much as Infamous, Tomb Raider, and even GTAV(which I love).I never pay money for in game purchases, so I don't care either way about that.

I love everything about these headphones except for the sound.They are the only ear buds that do not fall out of my ears! Very comfortable.But, the sound is very lacking. Low volume, not much bass/lows, decent mids/highs.I love the ear tips, but the sound doesn't do it for me, especially in a loud environment such as a gym or plane. (yes I've used them on long-haul flights.) Even with the volume at max, these headphones are not very loud.

This BT headphone sounds amazing.... especially for the price.They are bass heavy, which I prefer and are very comparable to Beats in the way they sound. The downfall is a much cheaper build quality and construction.Charges via USB, charge lasts quite a while. I would certainly purchase this again. I use it for the gym and it is perfect. Pairing takes a few seconds.I wanted to also say I have a gigantic head (MLB fitted size 7 3/4) and these fit quite comfortably. After extended use of 2+ hours, the top of my head gets a little sore. Thicker, plusher headband padding would be appreciated.

Excellent spiral notebook. Very high quality.This pack includes 2 separate notebooks. One pink, one blue. Each contains 3 subjects separated by a divider with a pocket.I really like how durable the plastic covers are, The pockets are also very convenient for returned assignments or loose paper. Perfect for school. The bright colors are somewhat of a more feminine shade of blue/purplepink, but I don't care. It makes the notebook easy to grab/find in a backpack.Why I took off 1 star.1. Price is VERY high, may be cheaper to buy locally at a store. (these come out to around $8 per notebook!2. You cannot write on the cover because it is plastic (school subject, etc). But a label sticker can solve that problem.Although the quality is excellent, I would not purchase these again simply due to cost. MUCH MUCH cheaper spiral notebooks can be purchased. I don't see the point of spending this much on a "disposable" spiral notebook with only 150 sheets of paper per notebook.

I purchased this for my wife. I love the scent, Mine was sold and shipped by Amazon, so I was not concerned over authenticity. Its my favorite perfume for a woman. Would buy again for sure. Much cheaper than purchasing at a DY boutique.

Used on a recent trip overseas (Thailand) and charged my Android phone, iPad, etc perfectly. Now it use it in my home instead of the OEM chargers. I really like it and the build quality is excellent. Great product. Charges very quickly.

A great concept and idea, but poor construction and build quality. The velcro tabs are weak. The fabric on mine was not cut correctly and simply doesn't fold nicely together like the picture. I would not recommend this. Unless you wear XXL or XL mens clothing, this is too large.
Bought this for my backpack. Great quality, bright colors, perfect size. I would buy this again. The size is also perfect for a baseball cap, or lapel.

I wear a mens size 11.5-12. After a day, they stretched and fit fine. I wear these around the house since I have all tile and wood floors.Complaints: Very thin bottom, Very noisy bottom.Pros: Lightweight, flat, easily packable for vacations, dries your feet after a shower. Decent price.

First one lasted over 2 years, looks fine but needed to be replaced. I replaced it with the exact same model by the same manufacturer (repeat purchase). My dog loves it and it fits his kennel perfectly. He does not chew on it.

My wife loves the light weight build of this dryer. She notices it dries her hair much quicker and her hair looks professionally done. She really likes the dryer and would buy it again. Came very well packaged and brand new.

Almost excessively thick and bulky. BUT the protection is there. I really like how the corners and edges of the screen are well protected by thick soft rubber. But this case will easily double the thickness of your phone. Actually a little more than double the thickness. It is a very affordable alternative to an Otterbox. I would still buy again.Cons: Almost excessively thick, VERY small headphone jack opening (-1 star).

This is my second Anvil Belt. Excellent quality. Thick and stiff leather. For those who wear holsters, this belt is thick and stiff enough to use for that purpose. The brown color is very deep and dark. I would buy again.
Fit perfectly out of the package. After one wash (following the printed directions), All shirts shrunk about 1 size, from XL to L. Now they are very short and tight. I won't buy again.

Pros: Larger than expected, heavy, high quality, durable, easy to wash, stainless steel. Works very good on my gas range.Cons: quite heavy (some may find the weight problematic).(but it does NOT bother me, so not an issue)Packaged very well in a nice box. No damage. Perfect for making stir fry dishes.

The Deep Dive glycolic facial cleanser by Jack Black is a very good facewash if you are not turned off by the price. I have been using this facewash for a few days now and it is a very good facewash. The cleanser foams quite decently and a little certainly goes a long way. My face is naturally very sensitive and most foaming cleansers will leave my skin very dry. I find that this facewash is a little drying and somewhat strong for me to use multiple times daily. Because of this, I only use it at night now.For people with very oily skin, this is a very good, deep cleaning, facewash. Because of the sensitive and dry nature of my skin, I will not be using it as a mask, only a facial cleanser.
Fits my 2015 Lexus ES 350 perfectly. Self explanatory, took less than 1 minute. Seems very high quality. I'd buy it again.

It's not clear from other reviews here whether or not we're all talking about the same edition of the book. I got the version with Gus Grimly's illustrations, and my five stars are tied specifically to those illustrations, which I loved. They bring humor into a story that is otherwise a little grim, and given that some of these original Sherlock Holmes stories seem a little cartoonish by modern standards, they do extremely well when illustrated like a graphic novel.

This is a paint-by-numbers noir tale, set in Egypt a few years after the end of WWII. The beginning is fun, with some repartee as our protagonist, Peter Wells, deals with bureaucrats at the American embassy after his travelersâ€™ checks have been stolen. And the end, amidst a (fictional, or fictionalized) revolution, is intense and showcases some entertainingly cynical politics. The middle of the book is weaker. The plot rambles, thereâ€™s no tension, no surprises, the characters are uninteresting and paper-thin. For about 50 pages, the protagonist is referred to only as â€œhim,â€ or â€œhe,â€ making me wonder if perhaps Gore Vidal had forgotten his own characterâ€™s name.Thereâ€™s nothing very interesting in the book, it reflects no special erudition. Nothing that evokes Gore Vidal. I donâ€™t recommend it.

In this mystery, the three investigators find themselves in possession of a seemingly magical talking skull and clues to $50,000 from an unsolved bank robbery. They are chased by various bad guys, helped by a mysterious gypsy woman, and in 165 pages all is solved.The mysteries in this book fall into two categories, many are so simple that almost any reader will guess their answer, and others are impossible to solve with the information provided. Other Three Investigators books have surprises, but this one always feels expected.

Bill Browder set out to write a Michael Lewis-style tale of wacky life in the financial trenches, plus a Tom Clancy-style geopolitical thriller, plus a tribute to a man named Sergey Magnitsky, who was murdered by corrupt Russian government officials for his refusal to play along with their schemes.I expected to like the "thriller" material the best, but I was favorably impressed with the entire book. Browder's backstory is amusing and briskly told, and the tribute to Magnitsky was deeply moving even though I had heard the story before.Browder skillfully uses small incidents to foreshadow later developments. For example, he stopped to help a sick man who had collapsed in the road in Moscow and in so doing may have gotten himself almost arrested by the police. This foreshadows his experience in challenging Russian oligarchs. He thought he was helping, by identifying and pointing out their crimes, but he was soon terribly punished, expelled from Russia, tried in absentia, and Magnitsky was murdered.The book is highly credible, and I raised a skeptical eyebrow only twice. First, in his early days in Russia, Browder describes everything as going perfectly. Were there really no bad investments? No ugly run-ins with gangsters? And secondly, Browder describes finding the data to investigate his first big asset-stripping investment on a CD-ROM being sold by a Moscow street urchin. Really? It seems more likely that Browder or one of his minions paid a government official to part with the data.Regardless, the book is excellent and well worth reading.

Phone mounts for bicycles come in two categories -- some are based on adjustable clamps and can accommodate many different kinds of phones and cases. Others are custom fit to a particular model and take the place of your case. This mount falls into the second group, so if you like the case you're using right now, this mount may not be a good solution. That said, the iPhone 6 version at least seems to hold the phone well; it's clearly fine for road riding and I think it would suffice for mountain biking as well.

The story of The Fifth Element is weird enough not to have been done before and never to have been tried since. The style is unique, and the special effects are more than adequate. It is ultimately a story about sacrifice. The priests who devote themselves for generations to carry word of the elements, the Diva who must die to deliver the stones, Korbin Dallas who must be willing to give up the woman he loves, and Leelu, of course, who seems to sacrifice herself. The unusual aspects of the narration, including especially the use of Ruby Rhod's radio transmissions, work surprisingly well.
They fit my PX100-IIs well. They're a bit thicker than the original foam covers and the sound through the headset is a bit muffled accordingly, but still fine for my purposes.

Dave Barry has a very distinctive authorial voice and you might think that after reading his pieces for 25 years I would no longer find him funny. Nonetheless, I laughed over and over again when reading this collection. I actually made a mark in the margin at every line that made me chuckle out loud, and by the end had marks in every chapter except one making fun of cable news, and the final chapter in which Barry gives humorous advice to his newborn grandson (a chapter that was clearly aiming to be more sweet than funny anyway).Ignore the putative organizing scheme here -- Barry's introduction claims this book to be about "happiness," but few of the essays have even a tenuous link to the topic. Barry's publisher ought to just label his books with the year, like computer software. This would be "Barry 2015," and I preferred it to "Barry 2014", not least because there was a hint of misogyny in that collection that is not apparent in this one. To the contrary, Barry's wife figures well in several essays in Barry 2015 about sports (she is a Miami sportswriter).Little here is likely to become dated, with the exception of a brief essay making fun of Google Glass, but even that one spends as much time making fun of Barry himself, an inexhaustible source of humor for this very funny, very gifted writer.

Satin Island is certainly not a book of events (almost nothing happens in its pages), nor is it a book of personalities (we barely even get to know our narrator, and certainly nobody else). It presents itself as a book of ideas, but I honestly can't tell you what lesson McCarthy is trying to teach here. Certain themes recur, but to no obvious conclusion. Near the end he hints that the ideas of Friedrich Nietzsche may be central, but I can detect none of the man's philosophy elsewhere in the work. If Satin Island were 800 pages long this would be intolerable, but at 170 pages it's a quick enough read to be buoyed by the strength of McCarthy's writing, which I enjoyed for the most part.Much of the text has a sort of rapid, highly detailed patter to it, reminiscent of David Foster Wallace or William Gibson (if one is feeling generous), Chuck Palahniuk or Mark Leyner if one is not. I found it fun to read even if the book's larger point was lost to me (if indeed there even was one).

We have a door with a very large gap underneath and it lets cold air in during winter. This buffer has proved a nice solution. Out of the box, it was too long, but it was easy to cut off part of the styrofoam berm and fold over the cloth so that we have a perfect fit.

Charming soundtrack. I'd have bought it electronically if it were available that way, but it was not. The only wrong note was the cliched inclusion of George Thorogood's "Bad to the Bone" but the rest of the collection, and Alan Silvestri's score, are so good as to redeem it.

Works perfectly with the iPhone 5 and iPhone 6 and iPad Air 2 we have in the house. It's short enough to avoid clutter while being long enough to let us place the devices comfortably on the counter as they charge. Four stars rather than five only because I don't think I can "love" a cable. However, if you are the sort of person to develop intense emotions for cell phone accessories, this cable should please you.

These work perfectly in a Blue Cows laminator in "heat" mode. I haven't tried them with cold lamination. Four stars rather than five only because I don't think I would "love" any laminating pouches. However if you are the sort of person who develops intense emotions for office supplies, these will certainly please you.

This is basically a thick plastic tarp. It provides little cushioning or absorption of sound and  it doesn't fold as neatly as the photos here suggest. The first time I used it, for a workout of only 45 minutes, the cord of my rollers burned a hole through the mat in a small patch where it wrinkled upwards and made contact. As others have noted, it smells.The "Deluxe" trainer mat protects the floor from sweat so I will continue to use it, but it's clearly not going to last and I won't buy another of these.
I got my order from "Mr Medical" promptly. The batteries appear to be genuine, in original packaging, and fresh ("use before" date 3/2019). My calculator is now running again.

This book is certainly not for everybody, the subject matter (elderly parents as their health fails and they die) will not appeal to all. However, the book handles this difficult material as well as can possibly be done. It's funny and sweet, as Chast discusses her memories of her parents and their foibles, and it's heart-wrenching as she copes with their deaths. I've not generally been a fan of Chast's cartoons in the New Yorker, but it seems as though her decades of work have been a sort of apprenticeship for the writing of this book, which was for me entirely a success.

The publishers would very much like you to think of this as being like "Harry Potter." Chris Columbus (Harry Potter director) co-wrote it, they have a blurb from J.K. Rowling on the cover, and I think they even use the same typeface as the original Harry Potter hardcovers. That said, the book is nowhere near as good as any of the Harry Potter series.Our heroes are faced with terrible magic and get thrown in a whirlwind of excitement. Each chapter lasts about three pages and ends in some deus ex machina or another. Though the framing device is fun (that our heroes are in a world synthesized from three works of genre fiction), the rules of that world are never made clear to the readers or the characters in the book. It's a little like watching a bewildering foreign sporting event in which nobody speaks your language, but where one team (the good guys) is bound eventually to win.

Perfectly charming little film with an astonishing cast. Everybody is smart and ultimately decent. The plot is about 80% Bildungsroman, 20% romantic comedy. Kudos to the casting director, so many of these actors have gone on to great heights.

I can't imagine how they sell these profitably for $11 shipped. Maybe it will fall apart in a week, but if not, this mouse is the bargain of the year. Feels great, works well, Mac compatible. I even like the glowing blue lights.

We installed our KX-TG6513B system about a month ago and it has worked very well. Installation and configuration takes no time, and the range extender (KX-TGA405B, sold separately) enables the system to reach every floor of our house, something that was never true with any other cordless phone. The phones use stock NiMH rechargeable batteries, which if history is any guide will save a lot of money. You can attach a headset to each phone if you want, and there's an easy handset-locator function, which comes in handy from time to time. The price was fair, no complaints.

A striking collection of information and photographs about this nearly-forgotten blizzard. 75 people died, but most interesting I think was the thousands of cars stuck on highways around New England, many with people still inside. The winds were so strong it blew trucks around like sailboats, jackknifing them across highways in all directions. Photos of the resulting traffic jams, cars buried in snow almost to the roof, are the best things in this book.

This clock is easy to use and easy to read without being so bright as to keep anybody awake. In fact, it has something like five brightness settings, the dimmest of which is about the least bright I've ever seen in a clock radio. I like being able to beam music to it via bluetooth, and had no trouble getting this to work. The sound quality is perfectly adequate for podcasts and children's music. In practice, ours gets used as a USB charging station and as an alarm clock more often than it gets used as speakers.

This is a breezy, amusing tale of a middle aged man who is a failed actor and an indifferent teacher, and who makes the ill-considered decision to sell a sex-tape of himself with a old girlfriend. His life turns almost immediately into a reality TV and tabloid affair, and most of the book is a satire of that world. In this, it compares with Ben Elton's "Dead Famous," though it's a bit less funny and it casts its net wider than that book.The chief weakness of Arts & Entertainments is its main character, "Handsome Eddie," who is for most of the book's length a purely reactive figure. He's not very sympathetic and it's not much fun spending hundreds of pages with him.That said, it's fast-paced and funny, perhaps particularly so for readers who watch reality TV from time to time.

My nine year old daughter, who is an avid reader, insisted I read this book, saying it is "the best" Nancy Drew. That's high praise. I give only four stars rather than five because, as an adult, I found the story to be tedious. For kids though, it's a fine tale of adventurous youth and reason overcoming crooks and spiritualism.
If I work this stuff for any length of time, my palms turn blue. Did I get a bad batch? It's weird and not desirable.

Much of this writing is easily five stars, perhaps most of it, but as a collection I'm not going to go all the way to the top. A number of contributors were allowed to pick the work they liked and perhaps to write a brief (one page) explanation for why they chose the work they did. Too many of these people selected stories that involve depression or suicide, in the assumption presumably that these become more interesting after DFW's death by hanging in 2008. And some do, a bit. The story "The Planet Trillaphon", published while DFW was still an undergraduate at Amherst, is particularly striking but as much for revealing how thoroughly developed his writing style was so young as for his insights into clinical depression. And while this depression was obviously important to DFW and his writing, the repeated reference to it in this collection comes by definition at the expense of his writing about other things that were also important to his development and self-identity.The book contains excerpts from DFW's novels "Broom of the System," "Infinite Jest," and "The Pale King," and while I understand the importance of these novels, especially Infinite Jest, to the man's legacy, there is simply no way that any 240 pages of it can do justice to the work. The way to introduce DFW's novels, I think, is to introduce his short stories. And if the reader appreciates them, he or she will move on to the novels naturally.Fiction dominates the collection, accounting for perhaps 600 pages of its length. It is followed by some 60 pages of teaching material, some of which necessarily comes across as filler "Student info sheet -- name, hometown, campus phone number," etc., but on the whole makes me regret never having had the chance to hear the man teach. I suspect I would have failed any course of his miserably -- after exposure to DFW for any length of time I find my speech patterns and writing unconsciously mimic his for days, which he would probably have interpreted as my weakness as much as his own strength, but I would have loved to see how others learned from him. Have any of his students yet made their marks as independent writers?DFW's wonderful nonfiction is shoehorned into the final 300 pages. We get two tennis essays (which are used to bookend the section, a decision I am not sure I agree with as it suggests less evolution in concerns than I think DFW actually experienced), one essay about pop culture, two travel pieces (they've included both the title essay from A Supposedly Fun Thing I Will Never Do Again and the Illinois State Fair essay that did as much as anything to make DFW famous, and these two are, for me, sources of inexhaustible pleasure). We also get several pieces about fiction and writing. No politics or math. The nonfiction section of the book is for me more obviously incomplete than the fiction section, though there too some really striking and memorable stories have been omitted.On the whole, this book is a fine purchase for known fans of DFW, for the few items that have not been published elsewhere, and perhaps if they're wearing through the covers of the collections in which these pieces otherwise appear. The commentaries, though brief, provided mostly interesting discussion of why certain of the selected pieces seemed important to include, or their relationship to other work by DFW. Anne Fadiman breaks this pattern in describing her use of DFW's work in teaching creating writing. For new readers? If they're the sort to read just one thing, better to pick a single short story or a single essay (I suggest Supposedly Fun Thing or the Illinois State Fair essay, though sometimes his piece on the McCain presidential campaign in 2000 or the Kenyon college graduation address from 2005). If they are willing to try a whole book, I generally suggest Consider the Lobster, because of its consistent strength.

I have an iPad Air 2, which I have been using without a case. This case is relatively slim and holds the iPad by the corners, which are a sort of semi-stiff plastic that have to be bent back to give the iPad space. It has a cutout for the back-facing camera and doesn't seem to impede photos at all. though the power button a little harder to reach.A case like this is most useful to me to hold the iPad upright when my kids want to watch a video. It does that well. Normally I would want to remove the case except when being used in that specific way, but I'm not sure the plastic corners will take repeated bendings like that without breaking off.

In this incompetently told tale, a hunky special ops soldier / doctor named "Clay Harbor" and his once-and-future girlfriend "Dawn Knight" fight off her boss, an evil, sadistic hedge fund manager. The names of the characters, their physical descriptions, and the book's dialog are soap-opera bad. The dialog is so unnatural that it sounds like the over-enunciated speech of semi-educated gangsters in shows like The Sopranos, laden with bizarre exposition that no actual human beings would ever shoe-horn into a conversation, but which the author here must rely on for lack of any more skillfull narrative techniques. Imagine a woman speaking to an old friend, "are you all booked up with Brandon Dunn, that stud trader from distressed debt?" Any actual human would say "aren't you still with Brandon?" The rest is to tell us, the readers, that the inhabitants of this book's reality are hunky, and that this particular hunk is a distressed debt dealer (a point that is not even relevant to the story).The brutality, sadism, and violence in this story is astonishing. The lovingly described drownings, and arms being torn off, and people being paralyzed and watching their intestines being eaten by bears (I am not making that up), not to mention the shootings, stabbings, and eyeballs being torn out (I am making up none of this). Ben Lieberman may want to consider therapy, after even the first incident of this sort in the book I found myself concerned for his mental stability.Everything in the book is painstaking spelled out for the reader, with no artfulness at all. While some of the financial material or murder techniques would be new to a typical reader, a more gifted author would introduce an investigator who would piece together what had happened and why, and the reader would learn along with him (or her). In this book, we just get long, awkward explanations by the characters or the omniscient narrator.And the finance doesn't even make sense. In the first murder, evil guy Rory Chase kills an old man whose life insurance policy he had purchased. We are told that it was a $5 million policy and that Chase had paid $3 million for it, and that without his intervention it would not have been expected to pay out for another 30 years. If a life insurance policy isn't going to pay out for 30 years, why would it cost $3 million? That's saying that Rory paid so much for the policy that it would be an almost certain bad deal without his murderous intervention. Like he paid $1 million for a piece of canvas so he could forge a Picasso on it and sell it for $2 million. Absent the crime, the parchment is worth only a $10, and the planned crime shouldn't make it worth more. In fact, anybody willing to pay $1 million for a piece of parchment is clearly up to no good, and similarly, Rory's willingness to pay so much for that man's policy should have been a red flag to the seller that murder was intended.There's a little bit of sex in the book as well. X-rated, of course.Anyway, the book is terrible. Don't read it.

I found El Deafo to be charming and sincere and affecting where appropriate. It tells the story of a young girl who loses her hearing and who learns to navigate elementary school as a bit of an outsider. Some classmates regard her as a freak, some over-compensate, but her worst enemy is her own insecurity. Gradually she overcomes.What's best about this book is that the deafness, while integral to Cece (the author and main character)'s experience, it is not the subject of the book. Worrying about fickle friends, and cute boys, and how much to comply with the rules, is universal. You will relate to her experience even if you have never had to deal with a physical impairment.The book is never didactic but it will teach those of us who have never had a deaf friend how to communicate with them more effectively, and perhaps will inspire additional compassion in some. The book is perfectly appropriate for children (age 7+?) and adults.

I've been using a 1999-era Brother P-touch, and this unit is surprisingly similar. I guess there haven't been any radical improvements in label technology. Perfectly nice fonts, perfectly nice output. Labels up to 1" in height, which I appreciate. I can connect it to my Mac when I want to print non-western character sets, but for all other uses, I use the built-in software and keyboard.One warning -- this printer, like all label printers, is sold inexpensively with the expectation that Epson will make up the different on the tape. They sell tape with many different heights, print colors, and background colors, and a cartridge costs anywhere from $14 to $30 depending on what combination you pick.

This book promises to be a survey of the industries that thrive on and perpetuate poverty in America -- payday lenders, subprime mortgage lenders, tax rebate advancers, pawn shops, loan-to-own, etc. But while all these are mentioned in the book, only the first three types are discussed for more than a sentence. Typically, Rivlin identifies a couple of entrepreneurs in each industry and a couple of the activists who have sought to restrain their excesses, and then described how each industry (or sub-industry, depending on your point of view) evolved, especially since the mid-1990s. It's a decent idea for a book and there is some worthwhile information here.Unfortunately, I found the text repetitive and boring. Too many of the anecdotes were basically identical, and the story, while it has a relatively clear beginning, has no end, so it almost can't help but meander. By page 200, I found myself almost yelling at the page "we get it, they were making a lot of money and they were good at lobbying the government so that they could continue to do so, what else have you got to tell me?"The material about "instant tax rebates" was new to me. The book may be of greatest value to those who believe that the 2008 financial crisis was caused by laws promoting lending to black people (a canard popular with libertarians). Otherwise, the book is mostly old news.

Perfect for my nine-year-old daughter. Fits well, works with her ponytail, not too "girly". It's also easy to adjust so that it fits properly on her head, and it's a quality helmet that I feel I can rely on to protect her.
This set of helping hands has no easy way to affix it to a desktop, but it costs so little that one must forgive this omission. Very handy when doing light soldering.

I had a Sonnet USB2 card that stopped working. First it stopped charging devices that were attached to it, then it stopped passing data. I'm not using this card for its speed; I have Firewire 800 ports for that. However in a 2008 Mac Pro, it worked perfectly as extra USB ports for charging and syncing an iPad and iPhone, and for interfacing with a scanner. Plug-and-play, no driver needed in OSX.
Cheap. Works. Allows me to keep a charger at home and other at the office.

It's the nature of a collection like this that some pieces will appeal to any given reader more than others. That said, given the weltgeist and the preferences of the editor, each year's edition tends to have a common feel and certain themes that recur. The 2014 collection features many imperiled children in financially strapped post-crisis families and these stories, even if excellent, are hurt by their proximity to others that are thematically similar. The collection contains nothing that I would describe as a "genre" story, which is to say, no mystery or science or adventure. There isn't even any humor, with the exception of Benjamin Nugent's gem "God." I will look for future writing by Nugent, and by Nell Freudenberger, whose perhaps-magical-realism "Hover" was excellent. Nicole Cullen's "Long Tom Lookout" was worthwhile, though hurt by proximity to other similar stories. Peter Cameron, who is presumably not an older, rural white woman, writes beautifully in the voice of one in "After the Flood." T. Coraghessan Boyle, who so often impresses, does so again with "The Night of the Satellite."A handful of the stories were, to me, uninteresting. But in a collection like this, those are easily skipped.

I've used a lot of different sorts of external speakers with my desktop computer and iPad. The X-mini KAI2 is unquestionably the cutest. It's tiny when closed down and has a sort of R2-D2 charm when opened up.You can connect it to your computer via an audio jack or via Bluetooth. It has a rechargeable battery and comes with an odd hybrid cable that connects it to USB for power (but not for audio!), and/or to the audio-out port for sound. It's too short to connect to both at the same time in most cases.The audio is lousy but louder than the built-in speaker in both cases I tested. To their credit, the designers did not even try to put stereo speakers in this thing. Given the size, it would be a mono speaker anyway, so they just left it as mono. It's fine for use as a speakerphone.The instructions are wordless, Ikea-style.

The Peripheral is at its heart a time travel story, a genre I generally dislike because there's no way to resolve the plot contradictions they invariably raise. Some authors go to great lengths to explain why paradoxes don't occur. Others skip over the issue entirely. But for me neither solution ever really works. Gibson tries to split the difference, waving away the technology behind his sort-of-time-travel entirely, but explaining the absence of paradox in some detail.He unfortunately doesn't do so well explaining the shocking amount of coincidence in the book, the familiarity of different characters with each other in different timelines, even the reason the main characters get involved in the first place. Gibson seems to trust that he can plot quickly enough that we won't notice these issues, and he is in part correct. The story is a lot of fun to read, and much more rapidly paced than some of his early work.The story contains many characters in two different time periods. Their personalities tend to be perfunctory, however, and with maybe a couple of exceptions they're memorable only for their job titles and the bits of plot they're assigned to execute.Those who expect Gibson to predict the future, as he did in Neuromancer, will be disappointed. Much of the technology in the near-future portion of the book is torn from the headlines -- dark nets, 3d fabrication, online gaming, drones, etc. And in the far-future portion, technology is so advanced as to be basically magic.Lest this sound only like complaints, I found the book fun to read and Gibson used some great turns of phrase. I particularly liked one character's comment that she disliked a group of people so much it made her do "hate Kegels."

It is no surprise, I suppose, that Carl Hiassen likes the writing of Elmore Leonard or that Hilary Mantel reads a lot of Shakespeare. But that Bryan Cranston was moved by Moby Dick, or that Sting favors Bulgakov and Mark Twain? Not as expected.This book is a collection of interviews, a sort of "greatest hits" collection from the New York Times Book Review column of the same name, including brief excepts from some of the dozens (hundreds?) of interviews that didn't make the cut to be included in full. And to the extent one would have any beef with this collection, it's only in the selection of which interviews made the list. The book is somewhat heavier in writers than the column, I believe, and omits the Arnold Schwarzenegger interview that I found particularly memorable.Some of the questions are specific to one person (Editor Pamela Paul asks Sting about the "book by Nabokov" he sang about in "Don't Stand So Close to Me," for example, and his response is self-deprecating and amusing), but other questions get asked over and over again, and this allows us to compare the responses from people of different backgrounds, at different stages of their careers. Most of the subjects take the questions seriously but sometimes they let loose (John Grisham can't really think that Barack Obama should read "Fifty Shades of Gray," can he?)It's a fun collection, easy to read in parts or straight through.

This is a review of Acceptance and, to a degree of the entire Southern Reach "trilogy" (which I put in quotation marks because it's not really three books, I think. It's one book they elected to publish in three parts). Southern Reach was never about plot, of which it has little. It's somewhat about character, but mostly about the imagination of our interactions with powers and intelligences far beyond our own. The bounds of that interaction are described in the first two books, leaving not much for this, the final chapter. Herein we learn somewhat more about the actual nature of Area X and how it came (or was brought) to the lighthouse. The book ends with the characters of Southern Reach effecting a change on the Area, though precisely what is not made clear to them or the reader (and couldn't be, thematically).

This is an interesting design - a magnetic holder - so I decided to try it out. I find it to do a good job of holding the phone, with great viewing angles, but to work best on horizontal air vents.The device is simple to use, and can be mounted two ways. First, they supply a metal piece with self adhesive, for those who want to place it directly on their phone (I would never do that).  This is for folks who don't use a case. The second way (and my choice) is to place the second metal plate they provide (which has no sticky back) between your phone and the case. It is thin enough that it works great. Then you can use the universal direction joint to find just the right angle and tighten it down -  it has around 60 degree motion in all directions.  To remove, all you have to do is pull the phone off. I found that I needed to reach around and hold the rotating base to easily pull it off, but it is quite sturdy and doesn't come off unless you want it to. Of the two methods, I think putting it under your TPU case (I use an Otterbox Defender) works best - the bare metal really holds the phone a bit TOO well, and is harder to remove.Mounting is another story. The device fits between the louvers on your air vents, and my Ford has vertical louvers. This works OK, but you have to slide it all the way down, and it isn't really as effective as horizontal louvers. I have those in my Civic, and that works much better.The only disadvantage (and it may not be obvious, but perhaps should be), is that you are blocking the air vent!
