Really, this output and size is similar to what some of the modern tablets put out - and as a result, it is really too heavy for pants or purse, but works well for backpack use.Summary: A great price considering the amount of charge provided - just make sure you can carry it! Highly recommended.-------Design Notes:The device has a single input from a MicroUSB (a common power cord for phones chargers, which is nice), and two standard sized USB output ports. Other than that it has four LEDs that indicate power and a single button to either check the charge levels or turn on the power when charging. It comes with a 1 foot microUSB charge cable. The instructions recommend charging the device every four months if it is being stored.Please note that I received a coupon that covered the cost of this device, so I could test and review it. I did order through Amazon.

A direct connection capability is great for those times when I plug in to a hotel or at work, but my ultra portable doesn't have a 10 Base T port, so I ordered this USB 3 model. I find it to work simply with Windows 10, and to do a great job of transferring TCP/IP data.The device is very compact, and I really like that it will fold over the cord into the main housing. To use, just plug it in, then plug in your wired Internet connector. I found that Windows 10 recognized the device immediately; the instructions say that with Windows 7 you might get a notice that it installed wrong, but to just hit "Cancel" if that happens. The device transfers data at the maximum that my provider allows, which is all I need.Why do you need this? There are a couple of reasons:1. Speed. A wired connection is much faster than even the best WiFi.2. Security. For use on the road, a hotel connection is simply not trustworthy - it is very easy for others to sneak (and snoop) on the network, since they generally use a common WiFi key (or even have no key). This won't replace a good antivirus, but at least no one will sneak into your system via WiFi hacking.Summary: A compact device that does the job. Highly recommended.

I use this pan in the mornings to fry eggs, and it is great; the aluminum construction means that it heats quickly and you can control the temperature easily.  This is a great size for a personal omelette or a single hamburger patty (7 inches is smaller than you think). Obviously you have to use plastic or wood utensils to protect the surface when cooking.I've been using it for a couple of months, and there is no sign of the non stick coming off. I do hand wash. Food comes off cleanly with the spatula, and it washes up with water.Summary: Super price for a great product. Highly recommended.

I love a good beef stick snack, so I ordered these to try them out. I find them to be decent tasting, with a slight aftertaste.My "gold standard" for these sort of snacks is the Slim Jim. In comparison, this stick has less texture for the actual internal product, but the taste is similar. I like the sort of "snap" that the casing provides. I normally provide nutrition information with food reviews, but if you are eating this, that probably doesn't matter! These have a lot of fat, but only 1g of carbohydrates - so it is suitable for low carb eating.Taste wise, it is really a matter of personal preference. I'd suggest that you buy a single one at a convenience store before ordering the whole box. The only thing I didn't care for (and the reason for four instead of five stars) is that the taste lingers a bit. I like the taste better than the aftertaste.Summary: A good low carb snack. Recommended.

These looked like a good replacement for the expensive name brand towels I use, so I ordered them to see how well they work. I find them to have a smaller size roll, but with good absorbency.The rolls are about the size of standard size budget towels, which is at least 20% smaller than the premium large rolls. They are quilted, and absorb spills well. These are not the new "pick your size" towels - they are full size sheets (which I actually prefer).  The individual towels are thick enough to have a good feel, and they look good as well. More importantly, they work fine.Summary: I would suggest pricing these out against your regular towels before buying, but these do the job well. Recommended.

I lke Jack Links brand, so I ordered these to try the combination. I find them to be unappealing in size, texture, and flavor.I was hoping for a nice balance of chicken and hot with these, but I'm a bit disappointed. They have the "buffalo" flavor exactly right, but the balance is way off. Unless you get one of the very biggest bites, the spice is overwhelming.  It doesn't help that the bits of chicken are irregular in size - this makes the flavor inconsistent as well. Also, the texture of the bites turns me off entirely. Nobody in my family likes these, and they are too spicy for the dogs, so I'm going to toss the rest of the bag.Summary: Flavor without meat. Not recommended.

CoQ10 is an important part of my supplement plans (I'm on a higher protein eating plan), so I ordered this one. I find it to have no appreciable taste, and to have the right amount of the supplement at a decent price.I an a bit skeptical about the black pepper extract, but there have been some unofficial studies that support this products claims that it helps CoQ10 processing, so I'm willing to have an open mind. So far I've noticed no ill effects, but then I use a lot of black pepper anyway.The thing I like about this product is the price. Under 13 bucks is a good bargain for CoQ10. The dose of 100mg is a bit lower than my past capsules, but at this price I could take twice the dose and still be cheaper than the stuff I used to buy.Summary: A good price for an essential ingredient. Highly recommended.

As we get older, it seems we lose hair where we want it (head) and gain it elsewhere (ears and nose), so I ordered this device to help deal with the occasional problem. I find it to be well designed, to work very well, and to be nearly silent.I have a couple of nose / ear hair trimmers, but they are not suitable for use at the bathroom at work - because they are battery powered. Nobody wants to be caught admitting they need this sort of device! These work by rapidly closing the spring loaded bottom, which causes the cutting blades to twist inside the protective shroud. I found that with a bit of practice, I was able to move the bottom levers and still keep the blades in the targeted location. This design is simple and really works.This device uses exactly the same cutting design that is used by the electric models, but has two big advantages.1. It is very silent. You can visit the bathroom before your important meeting and not create the wrong kind of "buzz".2. It doesn't require batteries. This is ecologically sound as well as convenient for occasional use - not to mention cheaper.Summary: Not quite as convenient as a battery model, but it works really well is far more quiet. Highly recommended.

These 3 mil-thick laminating pouches are FANTASTIC.  Though they will only accommodate items up to the size of a piece of legal paper, they are still absolutely WONDERFUL.~~ They are nice and THICK!  The laminate available on many commercial laminating machines (such as those at schools or office supply stores) is thin, so even a laminated piece of paper is floppy.  These pouches, however, are 3 mil thick, which makes for a much more substantial item once it is laminated.  Therefore, they can stand up to abuse!  I laminated papers I needed to stay legible when thrown in a camping backpack and when exposed to sweat and water.  These pouches are thick enough that my back-to-back papers laminated in the pouches were able to withstand such abuse.~~ They can be used with dry-erase markers.  I laminated bingo boards for kids to use with dry-erase markers, and they are able to be used, erase, used, erase, used, erased, and so on.  They still look new!~~ They can be used with poster-board-thick paper.  I have laminated business cards, thick fliers, brochures, and other papers that are thicker than standard printer paper.  I ran into no issues whatsoever!~~ They are easy to use!  One end is sealed, but the other three sides are open.  That allows you to arrange items as you need them to be arranged before sending them through the machine.~~ The price is VERY reasonable here on Amazon.  I've paid as much as 0.48/each for a box of 50 of these pouches, which is outrageous.  The prices here are much more reasonable!  Of course it usually works out best to purchase in "bulk." :)

I have hair that is half wavy/curly and half slightly wavy/straight, which makes for quite the challenge in both styling and care.  I have found products that seem to control my hair adequately, but they are unfortunately quite expensive, so I am always on the quest for different, cheaper, more readily-available products.  Unfortunately, my trial of "L'Oreal EverCurl Sulfate-Free Conditioner" was a huge disappointment.Despite applying a massive amount of conditioner and letting it soak in for several minutes (up to 20 on certain trials!), my hair didn't feel conditioned AT ALL.  It wasn't soft, wasn't de-tangled, and was just as frizzy as it was prior to using the conditioner.  My curls weren't defined in the least.Once this conditioner was rinsed out, my hair felt squeaky-clean, which might sound like a good thing, but it felt TOO clean, as if I had only stripped it with a cleanser, and hadn't conditioned it at all.What this conditioner does have going for it is that it is lightweight (so it doesn't weigh down the hair) and has a very "gentle" fresh scent.  I am sensitive to smell, and this conditioner's gentle scent is far from offensive.I figured out that I could use this conditioner and then use coconut oil for my hair to feel conditioned and de-tangled with defined curls, but the conditioner alone couldn't do that.

These boots are absolutely adorable, with their French phrases and cute sketches!The boots are comfortable to wear, but are traditional rain boots, so they are wide and "flop around" a bit.  They also, like most rain boots, do not offer arch support.  Still, I have been able to wear these boots all day without any discomfort.  I wouldn't walk a marathon in them, but for regular daily walking, they are quite comfortable.I added a fleece boot liner to the boots to help them absorb moisture from my feet and to make them more comfortable in the winter.  I would definitely suggest doing that if you plan to wear these boots in any season other than summer.

I have been using this Vitamin C serum for about four months now and am amazed at how effective it is!My skin is extraordinarily fair, heavily freckled, and (unfortunately!) fairly "lined" for my age (despite wearing sunscreen daily, wearing a hat when in the sun, and avoiding the sun as much as possible).  I have, since the age of 25-30, had deep lines between my eyes, across my brow, and around my lips (due to using straws, I believe).  Around age 35, I began getting lines near my eyes and very deep laugh lines, as well.Trying to make myself accept my lines, I called them my "lines of wisdom," but still (vainly, I suppose) wanted them to go away.  Hence the reason for buying this vitamin C serum!~~EFFECTS ON WRINKLES AND LINES~~Within about two weeks of daily use, I noticed the lines between my eyes were beginning to fade.Within about four weeks of daily use, I noticed the lines between my eyes were less than half as deep as they had been, the lines near my eyes were completely gone, and my laugh lines were beginning to fade.Within about eight weeks of daily use, I had a SIGNIFICANT reduction in the lines between my eyes, the lines near my eyes, and my laugh lines.  The lines around my mouth and my forehead lines haven't been significantly affected, but I can deal with those if the others are so significantly reduced.~~USE ON SENSITIVE SKIN~~I have very sensitive skin that turns fire-engine-red when most skin products come in contact with it, but my skin handles this serum quite well.  I have ZERO redness, don't break out, and have no other ill effects.If you are expecting PERFECTION and to have the skin of a young child, you'll be disappointed.  This serum is excellent, but it isn't able to erase the signs of aging completely.If you are expecting to look just a few years younger, though, you'll love this serum!

I have been a fan of Priscilla Cummings for about ten years now, and her Red Kayak stories are among my favorite young adult books.  I have read the first book in the series-- Red Kayak-- so many times I've lost count.  All three books in the series, Red Kayak, The Journey Back, and Cheating for the Chicken Man, tell the stories of three teenage boys who live on the Eastern Shore of Maryland and who are all, in their own ways, involved in a tragic incident that took the life of a young child and forever affected the lives of everyone involved.After we heard Brady's story in Red Kayak and Digger's story in The Journey Back, there was a piece of the story missing-- the story of J.T., the tortured young man who allowed others to control him and thus committed a crime for which he had to pay a big price. When I learned that Priscilla Cummings had written J.T.'s story, told from the viewpoint of J.T's sister Kate, I was very excited.  I ordered the book and waited patiently for July 14, the date it would be delivered.The book was delivered today and I read the entire book in one sitting.  It is one I just couldn't put down.Cheating for the Chicken Man takes place about a year after Red Kayak ends.  After J.T. serves his year-long sentence in a juvenile forestry camp, the sentence he received after being convicted of second-degree murder, he returns to his family's chicken farm on the Eastern Shore of Maryland.  Several things have changed in a big way-- J.T.'s father has died, his mother is struggling with grief and agoraphobia, and friendships have changed. Unfortunately, other things haven't changed at all-- J.T. is still being bullied and tortured by Curtis and other students, the family's chicken farm is still a major commitment, and life is still hard for J.T.Kate, J.T.'s intelligent, honest, and dedicated little sister, can't stand seeing her brother be tortured by the bullies at school, so she takes action-- painfully acting in a way she never thought she would.Cheating for the Chicken Man is a heart-breaking story that captures how there often is no "happily every after."  The repercussions of poor choices often resonate for a very long time, and sometimes poor choices might FEEL "right" even when they are very "wrong."I cried throughout this book as I was pulled deeper and deeper into the world of J.T. and Kate, and I was forced to question of myself, "What would I do?" and "What is the right thing to do?"This book is a realistic fiction book that will appeal to both young adult and adult readers.  While it isn't required, it would probably be extremely helpful to have read Red Kayak prior to reading Cheating for the Chicken Man.  Knowing the "back story" will help the reader better connect to, understand, and feel for J.T., Kate, and their mother.

I bought and set up my Worm Factory composter about three months ago, and my worm factory is now in full "factory" mode!  I am now feeding in tray #2, and will likely be ready to harvest my first tray of compost within a month or so.  The first tray of compost **looks** ready, but I am making sure it is FULLY ready before I harvest it. :)To set up this composter, you put together the bottom section, which includes a spigot for letting out excess moisture and a "worm ladder" to help worms that escape through the bottom tray to get back to the feeding tray.  You then mix together some bedding (coconut coir, pumice, and shredded paper) with some food (a mix of "brown" high-carbon items and "green" high-nitrogen items).  You then put your worms in the bin and leave them alone for SEVERAL days to let them get used to their new home.  The entire tray should be covered with a layer of moist newspaper or thin cardboard, and then topped with the lid that is supplied.Depending on how many worms you have and how hungry they are, you will have to feed the worms 1-4 times per week, though you **can** go longer between feedings if you give them a good feeding at one time, mixed with paper and other browns.I started with approximately 400 worms and it took them approximately two months to compost everything in the first bin.  I then added a second bin on top of the first, and began feeding only in the second bin.  It took only about 48-72 hours for the worms to figure it out-- they'd have to move up to the new tray if they planned to eat. :)It is important to keep the bedding moist, but not too moist.  It should be like a rung-out sponge.  If it gets too moist, just add some more paper.  If it gets too dry, just add some more moistened paper or greens.  It is also VERY important to keep the Worm Factory out of the rain and direct sun.  My bin is in an insulated cabinet (NOT air-tight), so it stays relatively dry and cool.  Even though it is 100 degrees outside right now, my worm factory's soil is currently measuring at 76 degrees.Good foods/bedding to put in your Worm Factory include:~ Coffee grounds and tea bags~ Junk mail (plain paper; no glossy paper or plastic)~ Kitchen scraps (vegetables and fruits only.  NO dairy or meat should be included, and only MINIMAL amounts of garlic, onions, peppers, and citrus should be included)~ Some pasta or bread is okay~ Egg shells~ Dead plant material (not diseased)~ Dead leaves from autumn~ Deadheaded flower heads~ Newspapers~ Paper egg cartonsI keep a freezer bag in which I put "worm food."  I then freeze the food to kill any fruit fly larva/eggs, and then just thaw the food before I feed it to my worms.  This also helps me ration out their food because I seem to go through "spurts" of producing lots of scraps, and then "spurts" of not having as many scraps.I keep my bin outdoors, and I DO have other critters-- mainly spiders-- that like my Worm Factory.  This is not a problem, of course.  As long as no black widows or brown recluses move in, the spiders are welcomed.  I have NOT had problems with mice, rats, roaches, flys, or other "undesirables."  I think this is because I do not include any dairy or meat, so there is less to attract pests.If you need to go on vacation for a few weeks (up to 2-3 weeks), it isn't a problem.  Just feed your worms very well prior to leaving.  They'll be fine!This is a great system for novice "vermiculturers,"  and would probably be a great system for introducing children to the concept of vermiculture.

The Amazon Echo is far more than a toy, though it *is* fun to "play" with it.  It is a tool without which I am already not sure how I'd function.I have CHOSEN to not have a TV on the main floor of my home.  I've always had a stereo, and thus can listen to music while on the main floor, but  it has been a pain to change the music.  I've tossed around the idea of a Bluetooth speaker for a few years, but have never gotten around to ordering one.  When I heard about the Amazon Echo, I got excited-- the Echo could act as a Bluetooth speaker (playing my THOUSANDS of songs in my Amazon Prime library) AND a "Siri for my house."  All in one device!A few of the Echo's features include:~~Playing Music from Amazon Cloud Library~~ Having "Alexa" (the default "wake-up" word is "Alexa") play music is super-easy.  All I have to say is something such as, "Alexa, play U2 music."  It will then play whatever I tell it to play.  The Echo also works with Pandora.~~News Briefing~~ I have set up my Echo to give me an NPR news briefing (customized to my desires) whenever I tell Alexa to give me the brief.~~ Weather~~ All I have to do is ask, "Alexa, what is the forecast for today?"  or "Alexa, will it rain today?"  I have noticed that the Echo *cannot* give me the heat index, though.~~ Audiobooks~~ You can play audiobooks available through the Kindle library.~~ Volume Control~~  You can manually adjust the volume by turning the ring on top of the Echo, or just tell the Echo, "Alexa, reduce to volume 4."  It works fantastically!~~ Set a Timer or an Alarm~~  No more need for kitchen timers when you have Alexa!~~Shopping Lists and To-Do Lists~~ Telling the Echo, "Alexa, add flour to my shopping list" adds the item to the list, which you can access through the Echo app (free for phones and tablets)~~Facts~~  I asked the Echo to do some math for me while I was building a bookshelf, and it had no issue adding fractions quickly.  I have also asked it to tell me historical facts, scientific facts, and general facts, and it has done well.  *Every once in a while,* Alexa says, "I cannot answer that question" or "I do not understand the question."~~Home-Connected Devices~~ **I** haven't yet used my Echo to connect to the Hue lightbulbs or WeMo outlets/switches, but it is possible to do it!Setting up the Echo is very easy.  Just put batteries in the remote, plug in the Echo, download the app (again, free for phones and tablets), and follow the steps given in the app.  It took me less than five minutes to full set-up my Echo.The Echo is about nine inches tall and about the diameter of a Pringles can.  It fits on a bookshelf and blends in fairly well. :)I haven't any complaints about the Echo.  It has excellent sound quality, is fast to access the Cloud, and is easy to use.  What else could one want?

This works so well that I am disgusted. :)  The amount of skin that comes off after using this product is unbelievable.To use this product, you first soak your feet, then put your feet into the two gel-filled booties, tape them closed (with the enclosed tape strips), and relax for about an hour.  They wash your feet with soap and water and go about your business for a few days.About four or five days after you use the product, your feet will start peeling, and peeling, and peeling.  It works best if you soak your feet each day to loosen up the skin that is peeling off.  Your feet will be fully "baby-fied" within about a week.Warning:  if you have toenail polish on, be prepared for it to be BLEACHED WHITE and softened to the point that it is disgusting looking.  It would be best to take it off before you use Baby Foot.

It is very difficult for me to find hats that "fit" me, not just physically on my head, but also in need.Need #1:  I have a HUGE head and "one size fits all" hats DO NOT usually fit me.Need #2:  I am also extraordinarily fair, with light eyes, fairly light hair, and freckles.  I am, as my dermatologist stated, "skin cancer waiting to happen."  Therefore, I like to wear sun hats (in addition to sun screen) when I am out in the sun for long.Need #3:  I overheat VERY easily, so I don't like to wear dark colors in the heat of the summer.Need #4:  I need a hat that can stand up to salt water and chlorinated water.Need #5:  I need a hat that can be packed easily.Need #6:  I need a hat that can be washed.That's a tall order to fill, but this Coolibar UPF 50 hat fills the order without issue!The hat itself is made of a lightweight, almost swimsuit-like material that easily stretches around my GIANT head.  The brim is then a little thicker fabric, so it stands out to protect the face and neck.  The underside of the brim and the band around the hat itself are a fun black-and-white pattern.  The brim is wide enough to provide good sun protection without being so wide it is obnoxious.The hat folds flat for packing and works just fine in water!I would ABSOLUTELY recommend this hat to anyone who is like me-- with a big head and need to have good sun protection.

The "L" is very cute, but the crystals are on the wrong side, so the "L" is backwards.  That is problematic!The "L" arrived quickly, which is a plus, but unfortunately cannot be used as it is backwards!

I have a food-motivated yellow lab who LOVES her treat-dispensing toys.  I am always trying to get her to chew on bones to clean her teeth, but she is resistant.  When I saw this toy, I thought it might be the best of both worlds-- dispenses treats, but will make her "work" for her treats by chewing.She doesn't like the toy at all.  It is VERY difficult to move the pods to get treats into them (or out of them for her!).  She is interested in the toy for about 10 seconds before she loses interest altogether.  Even with her favorite treats inside, she couldn't care less about this toy. It is just too difficult for her to use.Maybe this toy is good for young puppies, but my old girl has zero interest.After seeing that my dog disliked this toy, I offered the toy to my friend's dog, a two-year-old Retriever mix, and he too had zero interest in it.  He'll play with ANYTHING, including twist-ties, but this toy didn't entice him at all.

I have a rather "bad" addiction to Bondi Bands, now owning over 35 bands.  Of my 35+ bands, almost all are the "heavy sweat wicking" variety, which are my favorite.  They fit my giant head extremely well, stay put whether I wear the band across my forehead (as shown in the photo) or across the top of my head, absolutely wick sweat away so it doesn't drip in my face, are cute (especially the ones with sayings), and are comfortable to wear all day.When the bands are sweaty, they can be thrown in the laundry to be washed with other athletic clothes, and they come out nice and clean and ready to wear again.Bondi Bands come in solid colors (such as the one pictured here), in prints, and in sayings.  My current collection includes:~ solid black~ solid navy~ solid hot pink~ blue with white stars~ camouflage~ black with green shamrocks~ black with silver guitars~ white with red hearts~ black with pink butterflies~ black with silver horns~ black with silver "party" lines and dots~ black with reflective stars~ black with reflective squares~ purple with yellow Peep~ Chinese symbols~ USMC Eagle, Globe, and Anchor~ "Pain is Just Weakness Leaving the Body"~ "Slow...It's the New Fast"~ "I Don't Sweat; I Sparkle"~ "Just One More Mile"~ "May the Course Be With You"~ "Pain is Temporary; Pride is Forever"~ "Gotta Run"~ "Keep Running"~ "Born to Run"~ "Run Now, Wine Later"~ "Santa's Little Helper"~ "Fight"~ "Never Go Through Life Without Goals"~ "I Run for Those Who Can't"~ "Warning, Frequent Walk Breaks"~ "Looks Like Walking; Feels Like Running"~ "Run, Walk, Crawl, Just Finish!"~ "I Love Running; I Hate Running; I Love Running; I Hate Running"~ "Run with Heart"~ "What I Lack in Speed, I Make Up for in Cute"I've also given away Bondi Bands to others, including bands that say/picture:~ "Chicks with Sticks" (lacrosse)~ Soccer ball~ "Life is Short; Play Hard"~ PeaceAs you can see, Bondi Bands come in a wide variety of styles!

I am glad I followed the advice given in other reviews and ordered a larger size of this dress because it does fit somewhat small.  I am a size 4 (or so) and ordered this dress in a size large.  Even in a size large, the dress is quite fitted on top, but loose through the waist and hips.The dress is lightweight and is made of a slightly textured polyester/spandex blend (96% polyester; 4% spandex).  Even though it is lightweight, it has a nice weight, so it hangs well and has a nice "swing" to it.  It is a good spring/fall weight if you wear it with a sweater.The dress is "handwash only," though it could probably be washed on a gentle cycle if it is then hanged to dry.When I first unwrapped the dress, I was upset because I thought it was doing to be too short.  Even holding it up against myself, I thought the skirt was going to hit me about 10 inches above my knee (mid-thigh), which would be an issue if I planned to wear this to work (with a sweater on top).  I am so glad I tried it on before repacking it to return it, because it isn't nearly as short as I thought it was.  The skirt actually hits me about 4-5 inches above my knee, which I can deal with for work. I have relatively long legs (32" inseam), so anyone with legs longer than mine might find this skirt too short.I noticed some other reviews mentioned a belt, but my black and white dress did not come with a belt.

I am an extraordinarily picky eater who also has food allergies.  Therefore, I need to be careful about what I eat, and also need to be prepared to not have any food choices when I'm out and about, and away from my "safe" foods.  I carry protein bars with me "just in case" I need them.  These Balance Bars (Cookie Dough flavor) are one of my favorites!These bars taste good, are not super chewy (as some nutrition bars are), and don't have a waxy/chemical-flavored "chocolate" coating.  They are delicious!Nutritional Content:~ Calories-- 210~ Total Fat-- 7g~ Sat. Fat-- 4g~ Trans Fat-- 0g~ Cholesterol-- <5mg~ Sodium-- 200mg~ Potassium-- 115mg~ Total Carbohydrates-- 22g~ Dietary Fiber-- <1g~ Sugars-- 17g~ Protein-- 15gThe bar is 40% carbs, 30% protein, and 30% fat (hence the "balance" part of the name!).This bar does contain soy, milk, and wheat.  It is processed on the same equipment that also processes peanuts, tree nuts, eggs, and sesame.The bar has a chocolate coating that actually does taste like chocolate, and a filling that tastes a lot like cookie dough.  It is DELICIOUS!

I have several bands for my Fitbit Flex and was THRILLED when two of them came with silicone fastener rings to help keep the band on.  Once I saw how much those helped secure my band, I searched for more.  That's how I found the MDW silicone fastener rings.My pack of fastener rings/clasps came with:~ two bright orange clasps~ two cobalt blue clasps~ one lime green clasp~ one hot pink clasp~ one black clasp~ two margarita green fastener rings~ two cobalt blue fastener rings~ one bright orange fastener ring~ one sunshine yellow fastener ring~ one black fastener ring~ one hot pink fastener ring~ one kelly green fastener ringI am quite pleased with the color selection and feel the rings and fasteners do a nice job adding a "pop" to all my bands, including my zebra band, polka dot bands, dalmatian band, black band, etc.My only criticism is:~ The fastener rings are narrow and thin.  The rings that came with two of my bands are twice as wide and made of a thicker silicone, so they are easier to move into place.  These rings are difficult to move into place, and I feel I must use at least two rings to make the band feel secure.I would definitely recommend these fastener rings/clasps to anyone who wants to better match their band and clasp (i.e., my zebra band came with a gray clasp, and I like the idea of using a black clasp, or my blue band came with a pink clasp and I like the idea of using a  blue clasp), those who want to "jazz up" a boring band (such as the original band), or those who want to add some security to their bands so they won't lose their $100 Fitbit.

I have now ordered several packs of these Active Basics tee-shirts, and have found that they all seem to be different.My latest pack was supposed to be a 2-pack of white "short-sleeved, scoop-necked" shirts.  Interestingly, the shirts that arrived ARE white, and ARE short-sleeved, but NEITHER is a scoop-necked shirt.  One is a *deep* V-neck, and the other is a high-necked regular tee-shirt. :(One of my latest shirts has a neck lined with a light green trim and the other is plain.  While they are both a size medium, one is at least 1.5 inches shorter than the other.The shirts I received in my latest are very thin/lightweight (which is what I wanted), but are not as thin as my previous shipment.  The last shipment had shirts that were practically transparent, but worked fabulously for the use I had.I also have several of these Active Basics shirts in colors (black, red, gray, teal, navy, and electric blue), and they are thicker, though the necks on those shirts have also varied a little (but not as much as my latest shipment of white tee-shirts).I'd recommend these shirts if you want very lightweight shirts that are VERY affordable, but would caution you against these shirts if you have a certain neck style in mind.  You never know what neck style you'll get!

I absolutely love 50's-style dresses, but was very disappointed in this particular dress.  I won't be returning it, but will also not recommend it.~~~Fabric~~~The fabric is a thin, unlined cotton that looks rather cheap.  With a crinoline/petticoat, it looks better, but because it is SO lightweight, it hangs funny on some crinolines/petticoats.~~~Quality~~~~ Issue #1-- The Zipper-- The zipper broke the first time I wore the dress.  It wouldn't unzip all the way when I put the dress on, but unzipped enough that I could get it on.  When I went to take the dress off, however, the zipper would only go down about halfway.  I was STUCK in the dress.  Pulling very hard on the zipper made it separate from the dress itself.~ Issue #2-- The Finishing-- There were random stray threads EVERYWHERE on the dress-- along the seams, along the zipper, and along the hem.  There was certainly not much finishing work done on this dress.~ Issue #3-- The Care Label-- There is NO care label.  It isn't in the back of the dress, isn't in the waist, isn't in the side seam, and isn't in the hem.  I don't understand how a garment can be sold without a care label.~~~The Fit~~~The dress is definitely small.  I am a size 4-6 (usually a 4 in A-line or Fit-and-Flare dresses) and am NOT busty, yet needed a size large in this dress. The large fits me in the torso, but the waist is big, so I need a belt.Overall, I am disappointed in the quality of the garment for the price I paid.  While the dress wasn't expensive, it was certainly more expensive than a dress of this quality should be.

I have *extremely* damaged hair, so I am careful about the products and tools I use.  When I broke my previous flat iron, I cautiously ordered a new one-- this Xtava infared flat iron.  I was impressed by the reviews, but was only cautiously optimistic because I was so concerned about how the heat could damage my hair.  Thankfully, I had nothing to worry about.~~ Infared vs. Ceramic and Hair's Response---  All my previous flat irons were ceramic irons, which did a good job ironing my hair, but I didn't like how I could hear my hair frying (even at a low temperature of 285*).  I don't hear my hair fry with this iron.~~ Flattening Quality--- This iron does a great job ironing my naturally wavy hair into a smooth style.  My hair looks NATURALLY straight, not flattened straight.  I like that!~~ Heating Time--- This iron does seem to take a little longer to heat than my previous irons, but it is still ready within a more than reasonable time.  It takes approximately two minutes to heat to 285*.~~ Cord Length--- This iron has a nice, long cord, so I can plug it in and easily maneuver around without difficulty.  I am no longer tied to one spot only inches away from the outlet.~~ Storage--- The iron comes with a zippered bag that is lined in a heat-resistant fabric.  It is very nice!~~ Overall impression--- I am very impressed.  My hair looks good, the iron is easy to use, and the manufacturer seems responsive.  This is a great purchase!

I ordered this shirt to which to apply a rhinestone iron-on for an upcoming 5K race.  I didn't want to spend a lot of money because I was not planning to wear the shirt all that often, but I also wanted a shirt that was well-made, wouldn't chafe, and wouldn't hold heat against my body (especially because I needed a black shirt).The shirt IS well-made, but is super-thin.  It is actually partially translucent if you hold it up to the light.The shirt is NOT form-fitting.  It is loose, but comfortable.  I like the shirt the way it is, but those who like form-fitting shirts might find this too loose.The sleeves are quite short, seeming almost like a hybrid between cap sleeves and true short sleeves.  I like that length, but some might find the sleeves too short.Overall, I am happy with this shirt, but do wish it weren't translucent.

These bands fit just like the original Fitbit band, but are much cuter!  From Amababa, I now have the dalmatian band, the black and white polka dot band, and an orange band, and I am quite happy with all of them!While some have complained that these bands fall off easily, I haven't found that they are any less secure than the original band.  In fact, they are more secure because they have a silicone piece that goes around the clasp/band to hold it closed.  I have found that the original band can be quite difficult to clasp closed, but once it is closed, it stays closed.  The same goes with these bands; they can be a little difficult to close, but once they are closed, they stay closed.The lights show easily through the band (just as they do in the original), and the sizing is correct.Fitbits are not exactly fashion statements, but these bands make them a little cuter!

I have LONG been a fan of seatbelt bags (Harveys and Maggie Bags) and own well over 20 different ones.  Yes, it is embarrassing how many I have.I had wanted a Maggie Bags Butterfly Bag, but couldn't justify it when I had so many other great bags.  When I heard Maggie Bags was closing its doors, and thus was clearing out all their bags, I ordered a Butterfly Bag for myself as well as another as a gift. :)I carry A LOT with me, so I need big bags.  The Butterfly Bag not only is more than large enough for all the things I carry (a wallet, a small file of coupons, three pairs of sunglasses, two sets of keys, makeup, Epi-pens, inhalers, my phone, and more), it has plenty of room left for me to throw in a small jacket or pashmina, a small umbrella, or small purchases.  It is huge.Inside, there is an elasticized pocket on one "short" side (perfect for a small water bottle, I suppose, though I use it for my work ID's and keys), a set of organizing pockets along a long side (including space for pens and a phone), and a zippered pocket along the other long side.  On the outside of the bag, there are two zippered pockets inside the "wings."  These pockets are tiny, but work well for a bus or train pass, a key, a lipstick, or something else small that you wouldn't want to lose inside the big portion of the purse.The bag has two handles that fit well over an arm or the shoulder.This bag is so large that some may find it even works as a small carry-on on a plane.  Again, it is quite large!  As you can see in the photo (attached), the bag is quite wide and tall.

I normally don't "fall" for most Made-for-TV gimmicks, but have found a *few* Made-for-TV products I LOVE, so I hoped this Amish Wood Milk would find a place on my list of items I love.  Unfortunately, instead of loving this product, I hate it.I have tried this product on painted wood cabinets, stained wood tables, varnished wood shelves, and hardwood floors.  On each of those items, I have found that this product does NOTHING to clean or polish, and instead only does one thing-- leaves a haze.  I believe **plain water**would do a better job cleaning and polishing wood than this "Wood Milk" does.This Amish Wood Milk comes in a small bottle with a pump spray attachment.  The idea is that the end user spray the wood milk onto the furniture or other wood and then use a microfiber cloth to clean and polish. It took me about 50 pumps of the spray top before anything came out, and once it did, I noticed how thin and ineffective the product is.  It does NOTHING to clean or polish!

This collar cover works quite well for a few hours IF the weather is 100% dry and you don't allow your dog to swim, but it then starts to die.Because I walk my dog in the dark, I have had quite the collection of light-up paraphernalia for her and me-- a light-up leash, a light-up collar, a Nite Ize "spot", a reflective leash, a reflective collar, an LED vest I made, flashlights, reflective clothing for me, and so on.  When my dog's LED collar quit working and I couldn't fix it, I purchased this Nite Ize collar wrap so I could get the benefit of the LED collar, without the cost.This collar cover is great in theory.  It has two modes (constant on or blinking) and wraps around the dog's current collar.  Unfortunately, it doesn't stay on very well (my dog's went flying when she shook off after a raindrop hit her ear) and doesn't last long.  After about ten, fifteen-minute walks, the collar started "dying."  The battery needed to be replaced.The biggest issue is the battery; it is FULLY exposed, so rain, snow, or swimming could ruin it.This is a poor design feature!I would suggest this collar cover for **light** (pun intended) use in DRY weather, but don't get your hopes up that this is the perfect product.

My dog LOVES her treats, but is insanely picky about her chews.  She won't touch most chews, including ones that most dogs usually like-- antlers, bully sticks, etc.  She *will* chew on a rawhide or cow leg bone from time-to-time, but quickly loses interest in those, as well.  I would just buy her treats, but she needs the chews to help clean her teeth.  When I heard about the Himalayan Dog Chews (on Shark Tank!), I decided to give them a try, with the hope that I wouldn't be throwing away $10+ on something she wouldn't show an interest in for more than a few minutes.She didn't lose interest AT ALL.  In fact, she goes searching for her Himalayan Dog Chews (HDC's), seeking them out over any other treat or chew.The large size HDC is perfect for my 50-pound yellow lab.  It is small enough she can carry it around, but large enough that she cannot bite it in half or quarters.The HDC makes ME happy because it doesn't stain my carpet or rugs, doesn't smell bad (as a vegetarian, many meat-based dog treats make me gag because of their smell), and doesn't upset my girl's tummy.  She can chew on the treat/chew to her heart's delight and I don't see any negative effects (stains, smells, or vomit).The HDC makes my dog happy because it is easy for her to hold in between her paws, it apparently tastes good, and it doesn't upset her belly.The HDC **is** expensive, but is SO worth it (in my not-so-humble opinion).  My dog is a "moderate" chewer, so owners might have a different experience with "heavy" chewers.  For my dog, the HDC lasts about 2-4 hours of constant chewing, or about two weeks of every-once-in-a-while chewing (when I hide it in between chewing sessions).  When my dog gets the HDC down to a nub, I just microwave it for about 40 seconds, which "puffs" it up so she can hold it again.I think the HDC might be my (and my dog's) favorite chew/treat/toy.  We love the HDC!

I ordered two of these cases for two very different purposes.~~~Case #1~~~I ordered this case to keep all my chargers for all my different electronics well-organized and protected at the bottom of a suitcase.  With a tablet, an e-reader, a phone, two GPS devices, three cameras, a Fitbit, and a few other random chargers, the chargers can get a little out-of-control.I used to keep all my chargers, when traveling, in a Ziploc bag.  After I broke two chargers this way, I realized I needed a way to transport them that would better protect them.This case is perfect.  It has semi-hard sides to protect the chargers (no more broken pieces, I hope!).  It also has multiple pockets and a fold-out organizer in which I can store all my different chargers and other electronics paraphernalia. The only chargers that won't fit in the case are my laptop chargers.  Otherwise, everything is there-- organized, and protected.~~~ Case #2~~~I ordered this case to use for organizing the medication and medical "supplies" I must carry with me.  As an asthmatic who also has severe allergies, I must carry Epi-pens, Zantac, Zyrtec, Benadryl (liquid and caplet), a mask, two inhalers, and a few other meds.  Finding a case that can hold all these necessities without being cumbersome is quite difficult.  This case is PERFECT, though!On one side, I can fit my Epi-pens, nasal allergy medication, two inhalers, and a peak flow meter.  In the fold-out piece, I can fit Benadryl, Zantac, and Zyrtec. On the back side, I can fit two masks.Everything is EXTREMELY well-organized (so not only I can find things, but others can in an emergency, as well) and the entire case can be moved from one bag to another without any issue at all.The semi-hard sides also protect the contents so the meds inside don't get crushed, which is a risk with any soft-sided case/bag.

I now have two Sinland microfiber towels in different sizes and can say I am THRILLED with both.I originally ordered a Sinland microfiber towel to use as a "travel towel" because I thought it would take up far less space in my luggage, and dry far more quickly, than a traditional towel.  The first size I ordered-- the 31" x 60" size-- was fine, but a little small for use as a bath towel.  As a hair towel, though, it was great!The larger size is PERFECT as a bath towel.  I have long hair that holds a ton of water, but the Sinland towel can easily dry me and my hair and still feel only damp.  It is amazing how much water this towel can hold!  Even more amazing is how damp the towel can be and that it can then be entirely dry in a matter of an hour or less.  Incredible!Both of my Sinland microfiber towels are white, so I haven't had issues with them bleeding color the way others have noted with their brightly-colored towels.  I also haven't had any issues with them "pilling" and shedding on my clothes.  They stay quite absorbent (don't use fabric softener!) and soft, even after multiple washings.I anticipate that I will be replacing all my towels with Sinland microfiber towels as my other towels wear out.  I am so impressed with how well they dry and how little space they take up!

I am extraordinarily picky about my pillows, but this pillow makes me very happy because I sleep well!My asthma and dust mite allergy make it difficult for me to sleep well on traditional pillows.  Even with dust mite covers over down-stuffed or polyester-stuffed pillows, I wake up coughing and stuffed up.  I do *much* better with memory foam pillows, but memory foam pillows cause me to have issues with overheating in the summer.When I found this pillow, I was extremely excited-- it was memory foam but had a gel insert that was supposed to help with cooling the pillow.The first week I used it, I thought I had made a mistake; it seemed so stiff and uncomfortable.  Then it started to "give" a bit, and I fell in love.  This is an extremely comfortable pillow!The gel in the memory foam does seem to cool the pillow *a little bit,* but I don't see that it makes a significant difference.  The gel does seem to add a bit of special support, though, which makes this pillow a fantastic choice.

I have issues keeping all my different chargers under control, especially when I travel, but these cord wraps have been PERFECT!Each cord wrap easily controls the wires for standard chargers.  I use one for my phone charger, one for my tablet charger, one for my GPS charger, one for my GPS car charger, and one for my aux cable, and they all work fantastically for all those different types of chargers. They help me stay organized and sane!The wrap clips are hard plastic, but have *just enough* "give" to allow you to wrap cords without damaging them.And the colors are cute!

I was so excited to order these and put them into use at work, where I have cables that can look like a mess of Medusa snakes if I don't keep them under reign.  As a teacher who uses lots of technology, I have a lot of cables and wires to control on just one cart-- projector, DVD player, VHS player (yes...), document camera, docking station, speakers with sub-woofer, two lamps, and SmartBoard.I thought these clips would be perfect.  I could attach them (they use a double-sided tape) along the side of the cart, and guide all the different wires and cords through them.The first clip worked well for three cords.  Then I put two more on the cart, and both broke as soon as I clipped them shut.  The fourth one broke as soon as a student unclipped it and reclipped it (gently!).I am disappointed by the quality of the clips.  They just don't seem durable enough to live up to any actual use.

I now have four sets of Xtenex laces, with another set on its way. These are truly the best laces I've ever used, and I've used A LOT!I like to run short races (5K's and 8K's), but struggle with my shoes and laces for several reasons. 1) I have to wear gloves to run if the temperature is below about 45, and gloves and shoe laces don't mix well. 2) I have broken my feet so many times that they now swell randomly, and swelling makes shoes get too tight too quickly. 3) I am lazy and like to slip my shoes on and off rather than having to untie them.I have used Lock Laces for the past few years, and have loved them, but they aren't the perfect solution all the time. I LOVE my Lock Laces, but they keep constant pressure on my feet, which can either be a good thing, or it can be very painful.At a race last year, a friend of a new friend introduced me to Xtenex laces and told me they are revolutionary. I ordered a pair and tried them, and he was right! They are PERFECT!1) While they aren't easy to get set in your shoes, once they are set, they are set. That's it. You don't have to adjust them for different thicknesses of socks, and they stretch enough to accommodate some swelling.2) You can set them to be tighter on some parts of your foot than on others, which is helpful for those of us with "unique" feet (a common issue among runners).3) They are tight enough to keep the shoes correctly on your feet, but aren't so tight that they cause pain.4) They allow triathletes to slip their shoes on and off without much difficulty at all. This also comes in handy at airports, when shoes might have to come on and off to go through security.5) They are fun! They come in lots of fun colors (I have royal blue in one pair of running shoes, neon yellow in another pair of running shoes, black in a pair of boots, and vanilla/brown/black in a pair of hiking shoes. Bright pink is on its way for yet another pair of running shoes!), and can really "pep up" a boring pair of shoes.Xtenex laces are expensive for a pair of shoe laces. Very expensive. However, they are worth every penny. The ease of use and comfort they provide makes them worth every bit of their high price.

This petticoat is a "one-size-fits-most" size, so it is big on me (a size 2-6 depending on manufacturer), but it works just fine.  I just pinned it a bit at the waist so it fits better.The petticoat is VERY sheer at the top, so it really couldn't be worn as an undergarment that will be seen in costume changes (if you want modesty, that is).  This is probably more of an issue for actors/costumers who want this petticoat as part of a costume, but I just wanted to note that.Like most petticoats, this petticoat will make you itch if you don't put a slip between it and your skin.  That's typical of petticoats, though.At 26" long, this petticoat will fit fantastically under most 50's-style dresses and skirts, and it does a great job making the skirts "pop" in a 50's-style way.  You'll get a full skirt without a hoop-skirt style.

I ordered this dress in the blue with white dots thinking it was a dark cobalt blue, but the dress is actually more of a dark navy blue.  It is pretty, but darker than I thought it was based on the photo.  It's pretty, though.The belt that comes with this dress is huge and not very attractive with its brass buckle, so I will not use this belt.  I'll find another that looks better with the blue dress.I am 5'8," 125 pounds, and a size 2-6, depending on who makes the clothing.  I ordered this dress in a size large, thinking I *might* have to alter it a bit to fit me.  I'm so glad I did order it in a large because the way it fits, I cannot imagine a medium fitting.  The top, near my neck, gaps a bit, but the bust fits just fine.  The waist is a little large, but can be cinched in with a belt once I find one that fits and looks good with the dress.I ordered a 22" petticoat to go with this dress, but it hasn't yet arrived, so I tried the dress with a 26" petticoat I already had, and it fits well.  It gives the dress that extra "pop" and makes it a really fun dress.I would definitely recommend this dress and this seller (the dress came very quickly and with a note about guaranteed satisfaction).  Just be careful with size and don't be disappointed by the belt.

This guide is a basic, but remarkably thorough guide to the shells frequently found on the shores of North Carolina, South Carolina, and Georgia.Presented in laminated, pamphlet style, this guide works well for actually bringing TO the beach.  It fits well in a beach bag, large pocket, or backpack without adding a lot of weight.  The guide is also presented in full color, which is nice.While beachcombing looking for shells, you'll find this guide incredibly helpful!

What a deal!The cheapest I could find a single six-and-a-half-long HDMI cable at a local store was almost $10 more expensive than this two-pack was here on Amazon.  So, these are actually, in effect, $20 cheaper than what is available in local stores.Effectively, HDMI cables are HDMI cables.  There isn't much difference between one basic HDMI cable and another.  Some do support 3D or ethernet capabilities, and advanced audio or video, but unless you need those capabilities, a basic HDMI cable is a basic HDMI cable.While most components are now connected to televisions via HDMI, many components do not come with an HDMI cable.  Therefore, you must purchase your own.  Unless you need a super-long cable or a highly specialized cable, these "AmazonBasics" HDMI cables are a fantastic choice!

If you have dry skin and/or hair, this can be a miracle product!~~~~ USE ON HAIR ~~~~I have horrifically dry, damaged hair and thus spend an absolutely embarrassing amount of money on haircare products.  I do believe I've tried almost every product that exists, and while some work decently, or even quite, well, nothing has been perfect (yet...) either because it doesn't work that well OR because it's cost-prohibitive to continue using the product.After having read about coconut oil and its fantastic health benefits inside and out, I decided to try it as a moisturizer and conditioner.WOW!Coconut oil becomes liquid at 76 degrees, so it stays in a liquid state in my bathroom in the summer (when it is HOT upstairs).  Therefore, I do not have to liquefy it when I use it in the summer.  In the winter, I have to put a spoonful of coconut oil in a glass container and place that in hot water so the solid oil is liquefied.  No big deal.All I do is rub the oil through my **dry** hair, concentrating on the ends.  I then brush the oil through, wrap my hair up into a loose bun, wrap a towel or showercap around the bun, and relax or work for about two hours.  Then, after two hours, I rinse my hair, then wash it well (especially near my scalp), and let it hair dry.WOWZA!My natural waves are soft, not frizzy, and my fly-away hairs are better controlled.  My auburn color POPS because it is shiny instead of dry as dust.  It is great!You do have to be very careful to wash the oil out well so your scalp doesn't look greasy.~~~~ USE ON SKIN ~~~~My skin is so dry that it flakes.  However, I am allergic to many ingredients in traditional lotions, so I can't use them.  All-natural coconut oil works BEAUTIFULLY on my dry skin, and it doesn't cause any allergic issues!  Hurray!I also love how the coconut oil moisturizes (beautifully) without making my skin greasy.  The oil just sinks into my very thirsty skin.  It's great!This oil works FANTASTICALLY as a pre-paraffin treatment on my rough feet.  I just coat my feet in coconut oil, then dip them in a paraffin bath, and let the heat of the paraffin push the coconut oil into my rough-as-sandpaper feet.~~~~ USE ON FACE ~~~~I tried using this coconut oil as a facial moisturizer, but it is a bit too heavy for my very, very sensitive facial skin.  While it certainly does moisturize well, it seems to clog my pores, as well.I also tried using this coconut oil as a makeup remover (as I read in a magazine).  It worked well to remove makeup, but it didn't work well with my contact lenses.  It is too oily and makes my vision blurry for HOURS after I use it on my eyes.I would HIGHLY recommend coconut oil as a hair and skin moisturizer.  It will soften and moisturize even the toughest skin and driest hair.

I bought a pair of the 45-inch, multi-color (rainbow) laces to fit in a pair of tie-dyed shoes.Pros:The laces fit well in standard shoesThe laces were easy to lace in the eyeletsThe laces are very pretty with their bright colorsCons:The laces are very slippery, so even when tied in double-knots, they come untied very, very easily.The plastic tips fell off one end within a week.I LOVE the look of these laces, but would only recommend them if you don't mind them coming untied extremely easily.  They are more like ribbons than laces, so they slip easily.  Because of their slippery composition, these are probably not great laces for children's shoes.

I first discovered these "Five Star Flex Hybrid Binders" about three years ago and excitedly bought a 1-inch-capacity binder to use as my teacher plan book/ grade book.  It SEEMED to be perfect for my needs-- small enough to easily fit in my school-to-home-to-school bag, light enough to carry to and from meetings, flexible enough to be effective for my needs, and "stocked" enough (with dividers and pockets) to not require me to have to buy new dividers.  In addition, it was Five-Star brand, and I have always been impressed by their products.  I *thought* I had found the perfect plan book/grade book.  I was wrong.The binder worked out beautifully for me for about two or three months, but by Thanksgiving, it was struggling.  One of the rings would **barely** stay in the hole, and another was bent at a very funny angle.  By the New Year, it had to be replaced because all three rings were no longer staying locked.Thinking that my issue was that I tried to open and close the binder too often, I bought a **new** Five Star Flex Hybrid NoteBinder for the following school year, but that time bought a 1.5-inch.  I got ALL my necessary papers for the ENTIRE year together, put them in the order I wanted them, and opened the rings one time to "load" the binder, and then closed the rings (I used sheet protectors for some papers that have to be switched often so I wouldn't have to open the rings).  That binder lasted longer than the one the previous year, but was still "done" by spring break.  Again, the rings bent in a funny way and that caused one of the rings to no longer "lock."I didn't use one of these binders last school year, but after hearing that the technology was improved, and that now Mead/Five Star stands behind their guarantee that this binder *will* last an entire school year, I bought another one (another 1.5-inch) for this school year.  It's been in use for only two weeks, but is already showing issues with one of the rings.I am a *teacher,* not a student, so my binder probably takes far less abuse than a student's binder.~~ I only open and close my binder a few times per school year, while a student would likely open and close it a few times per HOUR.~~ I don't shove my binder into a locker, a backpack, or other small space.  Mine is brought to and from school in my "school bag," but it is a big bag that offers *protection* to the binder.~~ I don't sit on, stand on, toss, drop, or throw my binder as some students do (yes, they do this).  It sits quietly on my desk or shelf until I need it.I certainly don't dislike this binder (it certainly has some fantastic features!), but am also far from thrilled with it.  I would recommend it with caution.  If you or your child is rough on supplies, this is probably not the binder for you/your child.  But if you or your child is easy on supplies, it might be worth a try.

I am a teacher who has to haul things around the school, or in and out of school, on a regular basis, and finding a truck on which to haul things is very difficult.  I bought this cart to use for my hauling needs so I would have to search the entire school for the elusive trucks we are allowed to use.  I haven't regretted my decision to purchase my own cart!This cart is relatively small-- you can haul a small file cabinet, but won't be hauling a desk, but is plenty big enough for general office/school/home hauling needs.The best part of this cart is that it folds flat!  To fold it, you squeeze the two red tabs on the handle, then squeeze the handle that's in the base.  It then folds completely, including the wheels folding in.  It is fantastic!The ONLY reason I rated this cart a "4" instead of a "5" is because I wish its handle could be angled if the user chose to angle it (to make it easier to pull).  Other than that minor "issue," this cart is perfect!

I now own two of these bottles-- one in red and one in bright blue-- and would love to order more.  They are FABULOUS bottles!The main part of the bottle is made of a very flexible silicone, but there is a stabilizing "bar" across the bottom, and a hard plastic ring inside the mouth to help keep the bottle from collapsing.While the top is hard plastic and has a flip straw much like you'd expect to find on a traditional water bottle, these silicone water bottles *do not have a straw* attached to the flip straw, so you MUST tip the bottle and squeeze in order to get liquid.Pros:~~ Flexible, so it fits anywhere~~ SUPER easy to clean~~ Can be frozen~~ Non-slip~~ Collapsible to store in a carry-onCons:~~ Sweats when cold~~ Must be tipped to drink from itI would definitely highly recommend these bottles, but be aware of the two "cons" I listed above.

This is a big pack for everyday, in-town tasks, so it is probably overkill, but it is a FANTASTIC pack for moderate hiking.This backpack has one main zippered compartment, which is plenty big enough for a weekend's camping gear and clothes (other than a tent,and sleeping bag/mat, of course), with another smaller zippered compartment on the front (in which is an organizing panel and a key fob).  Then, on the very front of the pack, there is a very small zippered compartment that is big enough for a phone, GPS unit, or small camera.  There is also a daisy-chain and carrying handle on the very front of the pack.On each side of the pack, there is a mesh waterbottle holder and a vertical zippered compartment big enough to hold a rain cover (that's what I keep in one of my side pockets), more water bottles, or other small gear.This backpack has an internal frame, so it is somewhat of a hybrid between a traditional daypack and a camping backpack.  The internal frame can be bent to fit the wearer's body, and directions are included to help the wearer figure out where to adjust the backpack to make it comfortable.  There are pads on the back of the pack to protect the wearer's spine from being irritated by the center stabilizing bar.The straps on this pack are well-padded and quite comfortable to wear, but the backpack offers two additional ways to make the pack more stable and comfortable-- a great waist band and a sternum clip.  The waist band on the backpack is very comfortable and very stable.  To further stabilize this pack, there is also a sternum clip.The entire back of the pack has "Dynamic Air Flow" to make it more comfortable to wear, especially in hot or humid climates.There are several straps and compression straps to further personalize the backpack.  On the bottom, there are two straps that *could* be used to secure a sleeping mat or *possibly* a one-person tent, but I don't know that I would trust the straps to hold much in the way I use the pack.I have several different backpacks that I use for different purposes, but this has definitely become my "go-to" for hiking, canoeing, and traveling.  It is a great backpack that is very comfortable to carry.

When I run, I need to be able to carry my phone, Epi-pens, keys, tissues, and an inhaler, so I need a belt that can handle my "carry everything but the kitchen sink" needs.  While I adore some of my other running belts, I wanted to try something that would allow me to spread my things out so they would not bounce around.  The FlipBelt is PERFECT for this need.I waffled on which size to order, but finally went with the size smaller than I thought I'd need because I didn't want the belt to ride up while I was running.  That was a good choice.The belt has multiple openings for shoving your things through, and once you put them in, you just flip it over to use your body to "seal" the belt's openings.  It looks like a waistband, so it blends in well with your workout clothes.  It works well; it is secure AND comfortable!There IS a reflective logo on this belt, but by the time you flip the belt over to "lock" it, the logo is hidden.  I think it should be printed on the other side!*****Update 9/20/14 (reduced to 4 stars)-- I ran with this belt again today, just as I have MANY times, and unfortunately had happen what has happened to others-- the car key fell out of the belt (it didn't have a place to hook it) even though the belt was flipped and secure against my body.  :(  :(  What a headache and pain in the wallet this is to lose a chipped key!  There are MANY people out looking for the key, but no one has found it yet.  What a pain! :(I would DEFINITELY recommend putting keys inside a ziploc bag before putting them in the flip belt.  That should make it harder for them to fall out.

I have *always* been a "bug magnet."  In fact, my family used to tease that they could be sure they wouldn't get bitten by bugs if they brought me with them because all the bugs would bite me instead of them.  Even with use of bug spray (DEET) when I am going to be outside for more than a few minutes, I usually have no fewer than 15 mosquito bites at a time.  I also seem to have a talent for picking up ticks when just strolling along a sidewalk in my suburban neighborhood.  Like I said, I am a bug magnet.With the higher incidence of mosquito-borne and tick-borne illnesses lately, I am getting more worried about the fact that I am so often targeted.  So I decided to take action.I began treating a few sets of workout clothes, several pairs of socks and shoes, my outdoor chair, and a set of hiking clothes with permethrin so I would have more protection from mosquitoes and ticks.  A 24-ounce bottle of Sawyer Premium Permethrin treats a few sets of clothes, and each treatment lasts approximately 4-6 weeks OR 6 washings.  I am currently on my second bottle of Sawyer Premium Permethrin, having just emptied my first bottle.Permethrin works differently than DEET.  Permethrin is odorless once it is dry (though it STINKS when wet!), and is not really a repellent.  Instead, it is an inhibitor-- it actually kills any bugs that stay in contact with the treated clothing/gear.So does it work?  YES!I do still have to treat exposed skin with DEET, but no longer do I wind up with mosquito bites through my running pants.  No longer do I have mosquito bites through my socks.  No longer do I find ticks crawling on me after simply walking my dog down the sidewalk.A few basics about use of this product:~~ It lasts well over a month OR for about 6 washings (though Sawyer recommends hand-washing garments).~~ It will last on items put in storage, but exposure to light does break it down a bit, so Sawyer recommends storage in dark plastic if you must store the treated items and expect any chemical to remain.~~ It works best when you treat ALL your clothing and gear, not just one item.  You also do have to completely permeate the fabric, so it takes quite a bit of permethrin to treat gear and clothes.  Again, a 24-ounce bottle should treat a few sets of clothes-- approximately 8 items total.~~ It **cannot** be used on skin, but works quite well on gear and clothing when it is used correctly.

I have very problematic hair-- it is damaged from washing too often, poor nutrition, genetics (dry!), and several other "assaults" against it.  Because it is so damaged, but I want it to look like it is NOT damaged, I have spent a small fortune on products to help it look better.When I saw this Fructis Marvelous Oil Color Illuminate at the store, and realized that it looked like a clone for one of my very pricey salon products, I decided to give it a try.My hair is relatively long-- reaching my shoulder blades when it is brushed straight (it is naturally wavy, so it seems shorter when it is left natural).  Because of its length and its extreme dryness, I decided to use a little more of this oil than is generally recommended.  Below is my experience with the oil in several different "settings."1) *Applied to damp hair prior to blow-drying*  I applied six pumps of this oil to my hair and then used a blow dryer with diffuser to dry my hair into its natural waves.  The oil was a little heavy (perhaps three or four pumps, or brushing it in to better distribute it, would have been better!), but it did make my waves look smooth instead of their typical frizzy look.  I'd give this application three-and-a-half stars.2) *Applied to soaking-wet hair prior to allowing hair to dry naturally*  I again applied six pumps of this oil to my hair, brushed it through to distribute it evenly, and then allowed it to dry naturally.  This actually worked much better!  While it was a little heavy near my scalp (although I didn't apply the oil near my scalp, brushing it into the hair distributed it near my scalp a bit), it made the rest of my hair look fantastic!  It was slightly weighted down (again, six pumps is probably too much), but I had little-to-no frizz.  I'd give this application four-and-a-half stars.3) *Applied to dry hair prior to flat-ironing*  I applied three pumps of this oil to my dry hair, brushed it into the hair, and then used a low-temp flat-iron.  This worked well, and my hair looked VERY shiny.  I STRONGLY caution others, though, about using oil and high heat.  This is the same as FRYING your hair.  I used a LOW-heat flat-iron, and even that is risky.  I am not assigning stars to this application because it is not one I would advocate others using unless they are very careful.4) *Applied to dry hair-- ends only-- to smooth split-ends and frizz*  I again used three pumps of the oil, but applied it only to the ends, and brushed it into the ends only.  I didn't like the look of this application.  My hair was frizzy up to the last three-or-so inches, where it was greasy.  I would give this application two stars.5) *Applied to wet hair, left in overnight, and rinsed out in the morning*  I used six pumps of the oil, applied it to my wet hair, tied my hair up into a loose bun, and left it to "soak" overnight.  In the morning, I then rinsed it out.  Or tried to rinse it out, rather.  This  oil doesn't *rinse* out; shampoo is required, which strips the hair of the oil, leaving it the way you started.  My hair was slightly softer, but not enough to make me happy.  I'd give this application three stars.6) *Added to hair conditioner*  I added two pumps of this oil to a handful of my regular conditioner (in the shower) and rinsed it out.  WOW.  This was FANTASTIC!  My hair was soft, close to frizz-free, and shiny!  I'd give this application five stars.7) *Applied to ends of hair in shower prior to shampooing scalp*  I applied three pumps of this oil to the ends of my hair prior to washing the rest of it with shampoo.  The oil protected the ends of getting dried out by my shampoo, and the little bit of shampoo that did rinse over the ends of my hair removed enough of the oil that it didn't "goop" the way application #5 did.  I'd give this application four stars.Overall, I am happy with this product.  It does offer some fierce competition for my expensive salon products, but for about 1/4 the cost.  It is a LITTLE bit too heavy, but once you learn how much is needed for *your* hair, it is easily managed.

This set is cute, but is VERY simple.  It is composed of a few small pieces that make up a sand with small pier, and then a handful of pieces that make up the water scooter on which the "Friend" rides.The entire set took an eight-year-old less than seven minutes to put together because the scooter itself is only a handful of pieces.  The "beach scene," with the "pier" is 100% pointless.  The "pier" is only a 2x4 "bump" piece, which is so tiny that there is truly no point to it.The set is cute, but there is so little to it that I don't think it is worth the price tag.  The good news is that this set is compatible with other standard Legos, so it could just be added to other Lego sets to "jazz up" other sets.

This set, like most "Creator" sets, is a 3-in-1 set.  One can choose which style seaside house he/she wants to build.  Very clear directions are included for all the options.Option 1, the seaside hut, is considered the easiest buildOption 2, the seaside apartment, is considered the average buildOption 3, the seaside house, is considered the most-advanced buildThis set does not come with a large building base, but instead comes with several small plates that get connected together to form the building base.  This works adequately well, and does seem to be the "norm" now.  I choose to build the house on a large Lego building plate to strengthen the build and to be able to attach the "random" pieces (palm tree) that are not designed to be attached to the other building plates.I have now built all three of the options as instructed and found that, for an adult, they were all relatively easy builds.  When I provided the set to an 11-year-old and 8-year-old, they had no problems building the two easier builds, but struggled with the house build because the top floor is fragile, and they couldn't get everything attached without help.After trying out the three builds Lego recommends, we built the most-advanced build, but modified it by adding a TON more bricks to make the house a seaside "mansion." :)This set is very cool, and some of the details are quite interesting.  For example, the house has an outdoor shower with towel rack, and it also includes directions and blocks to make "rolling waves."  These are details I wouldn't expect in a set that it priced to be one of the more "introductory" sets.There are also some other neat details in this set, including an osprey or eagle that sits in the palm tree, a small sandcastle, and a mounting "hook" for the surfboard.This set comes with several more-rare pieces, including:* pale blue bricks* a silver fish* an orange crab* a white surfboardThe ONLY "cons" I found with this set are:* The building plates can be tough for kids to all fit together without assistance* The set only comes with one mini-figure* There are few details inside the seaside house(None of these "cons" are significant enough to make me downgrade the set's rating)

This is a very fun set that is quite easy to build.  What could be better? :)This set includes three main parts-- a firetruck, an ambulance, and a police motorcycle, as well as a crook (who the police officer chases), a skate boarder (who the paramedic/EMT assists), and a fire in a box (trashcan?  crate?) that the firefighter fights.This set was completely assembled by an eight-year-old and a six-year-old in a matter of about ten minutes, and they didn't struggle with any of the tiny little pieces- not even the teeny-tiny face mask the firefighter can wear when using the oxygen mask.Each of the main pieces-- the ambulance, fire truck, and motorcycle-- comes with its own set of directions, and is bagged in its own labeled bag, so there is little room for error or confusion.After assembling the pieces, this set offered over four hours of imaginative, cooperative playtime during which time a "public safety center" (hospital-police station-fire station cross) was assembled from random bricks, some old Lego pirate ship pieces (including a shark, a dinghy, and a parrot) were thrown into the mix as catalysts for public safety emergencies, and a cafe was assembled for the public servants to enjoy a snack and cup of coffee.  After four hours of straight play, the kids were tired, but they refused to disassemble the pieces because they were to be used the next day.I love that this set celebrates public servants and is relatively easy for kids to assemble on their own.  It has enough pieces to make elementary-aged children feel they are assembling an age-appropriate set, but not so many that they get frustrated.  The **only** suggestion I have for improvement of this set is to make the top of the firetruck and ambulance *hinged* to make it easier to get the figures in and out of the trucks.  Otherwise, this set is perfect!

These goggles fit quite tightly around the inner eye/nose, which is great for keeping water out, but NOT great for comfort.  I typically can wear these goggles for about 15 minutes before they have pushed so hard against my inner eyes and nose that I have bruises.  I then can't wear them for about three to four days while the bruises heal.(And, YES, I have tried loosening the strap.  That doesn't help because the issue is the hard plastic and lack of padding.  The only way it doesn't hurt is to loosen the strap so much that it renders the goggles ineffective by no longer helping the goggles form a water-tight seal.)For the 15 minutes or so that I CAN wear these goggles, they work well.  I can actually see while swimming outside, they are watertight, and they don't fog.  They work well.  They just hurt like crazy to wear!

This running skirt is longer than some other running skirts, but for anyone who wants a more modest running skirt, this is a good one!The skirt has shorts attached, and the shorts are quite comfortable (not binding on the leg in any way).  The shorts also have a small pocket on the outer thigh for a phone or music player.The skirt itself has a headphone "port" built in, so it works just fine to use the pocket for a phone or music player, and to snake the headphones up through the skirt's headphone port.The running skirt washes easily and always looks nice, both while standing still, as well as while running.

This mix includes a little of everything-- from Britney Spears to Red Hot Chili Peppers, from EMF to Monica.  The playlist completely captures what the 90's were-- a mix of pop, grunge, techno, and just about every other genre of music.All the songs bring me back to high school and college and make me think of where I was, and what I was doing, when each song was popular.

I have a body that is difficult to fit into clothes because my size 0-2 waist doesn't quite "match" my size 6-8 (depending on brand) hips.  Therefore, I LOVE fit-and-flare dresses; they allow me to accentuate my waist while hiding my hips.  I buy fit-and-flare dresses like most people buy socks-- in bulk and often.When I found this dress on Amazon, I was ecstatic.  While I have MANY black-and-white-striped dresses, I did not have any with an accent color such as the one this dress has.  When I ordered the dress, there weren't any reviews on it yet, so I knew I was taking a risk.The dress shipped quickly and when I opened it, I was quite happy.  The fabric is a brushed cotton with a slight sheen, and the dress looks like it cost more than it actually did.Once I actually got the dress ON, I was happy, too.  It is comfortable, moves well, and fits beautifully.So, I'm sure you're wondering why I only gave this dress four stars?1) The side zipper doesn't go all the way up, instead ending about an inch from the arm hole, which makes it difficult to get this dress on.
