Solid four stars.  Wish the display was nicer and the system came with Windows 10, not Windows 8.1.  Recommended!

QUICK SUMMARY:  Great storage enclosure for permanently (or semi-permanently) enclosing a 2.5-inch hard drive.  USB 3.0 connection makes a huge bump up in performance, as expected.  Recommended!INSTALLATION NOTES:  Opening the case requires unscrewing two Phillips-head screws on the front panel (that is, the side that has all the connection ports), then removing the entire circuit board.  To install the hard drive (HDD), place the HDD flat onto the circuit board and slide it into the Sata connection.  Then, flip over the circuit board, take four of the five screws that came with the enclosure and screw the hard drive to the circuit board.  Next, slide the circuit board back into the outer casing (it only fits properly into the groove where the screws go, attempts to slide it into any other grooves will be met with failure) and, finally, re-affix the faceplate back onto the enclosure.WHAT I LIKED:- USB 3.0 connection allows for a massive increase in data transfer rates. The hard drive I installed, which once capped out at 30MB/s read/write via USB 2.0, achieved 100MB/s read/write after being installed in this enclosure- The enclosure is a smooth, black, brushed aluminum, and is comfortable to hold- The back end of the enclosure has a red LED showing disk activity- In addition to its USB 3.0 port, the enclosure has a Sata port (NOT eSata), which, when paired with another Sata-connected device, will allow easy, speedy backups and file transfers (I didn't test the Sata connection)WHAT COULD BE BETTER:- The accompanying instruction manual wasn't as clear as what I've just written on how to install the HDD in the enclosure.  :-)WHAT YOU SHOULD KNOW:- It's a little too troublesome to quickly swap HDDs using this enclosure.  This is good for permanently or semi-permanently installing an HDD into this StarTech enclosure, but if you plan on frequently swapping HDDs, look for a different product than this model.CONCLUSION:  If you have a spare 2.5-inch (the kind of HDD that commonly is used with laptops) and want to start using it, and you have USB 3.0 port on the computer (or other device) that you're going to connect with, this is a great choice!  I loved the bump in speed USB 3.0 made.  Recommended!  (Vendor supplied free product in exchange for unbiased review).

QUICK SUMMARY:  Surprisingly effective knife sharpener is easy to use.BACKGROUND:  I've never had much luck with the rod-style knife sharpeners that come with a set of kitchen knives.  Try as I may, I've never been able to get my kitchen knives consistently sharp using those rods.  But with this Wiitek knife sharpener, I actually could sharpen knives easily and effectively.  For as little as this sharpener costs, I'm actually very surprised it works as well as it does.  And it's easy to use, too!  The sharpener itself isn't much to look at, and it feels very light, which gives it a cheap feeling.  But I can't argue with what it does.Note:  The "coarse" sharpener actually left tiny little metal shavings on my kitchen counter, so I would generally avoid using the "coarse" sharpener unless your knives are really, really dull.  Be careful as you clean-up those metal shavings so as to not accidentally get them into any food dishes.  After using the "coarse" sharpener, be sure to use the "fine" sharpener slot to remove any burrs on the knife blade and create a very sharp edge.WHAT I LIKED:- This was the easiest sharpener I've used.  Hold it with my left hand, run the knife blade through the sharpener with my right hand.  Repeat 5 or 6 times, done.  Your blade is noticeably sharper.- The sharpener actually works!  Pruning knifes and carving knives were noticeably sharper after using this thing- One-piece design makes it easy to stow, then pull out when you need itWHAT COULD BE BETTER:- I would prefer that this sharpener were a little heavier, so it weren't so cheap-feelingCONCLUSION:  This item in very inexpensive, and yet it does what it says it will do, and it does it easily.  Recommended!  (Vendor supplied free product in exchange for an unbiased review).

QUICK SUMMARY:  Everyone in the family wanted to keep this lamp in their own bedroom.  But they're all disappointed; it stays in MY bedroom.WHAT WE LIKED:- Novel use of multi-colored lamp (256 colors) makes for a nice nightlight- The LED white lights work as well as white LED lights are supposed to work (I personally prefer a warmer color than white LEDs)- Three different white light settings allow for some control of the brightness of the lamp- The flexible neck was stiff enough to retain the desired position of the headlampWHAT COULD BE BETTER:- The user manual was written by a non-English writer who has very poor skill at writing English user manuals.  It's actually very difficult to understand how to use the lamp by reading the user manual.  Instead, just experiment touching the on/off control and color ring on the base of the lamp, and you'll pretty easily figure things out.  One hint:  press and hold the color ring on/off control to cause the base of the lamp to slowly and continuously change colors.- The lamp seems a little expensive for what it is, so the value exchange isn't as favorable as I think it ought to be.CONCLUSION:  Everyone liked this lamp because of the way the base could change colors (my daughters especially liked this feature).  It's good as a desk light or even a focused room light, and you can use the base as a night-light, too.  Recommended!  (Vendor supplied free product in exchange for an unbiased review).

QUICK SUMMARY:  Great way to wash a car without hand strain!We used this hand mitt to wash our minivan, and the results were very satisfying!WHAT WE LIKED:- Wearing a hand mitt meant no hand strain that comes with long grasping of a sponge or wash rag- Easier to wash the crevices of the wheel rims- The little tentacles do a nice job of reaching into other cracks and crevices, too- Microfiber material meant no worry about scratching the surface of the car- The mitt had a snug fit, but not too tight that it cut-off circulation to one's hand or fingers- It dried quickly (but it needs to be hung up somewhere to dry-out, don't just leave it lying about)CONCLUSION:  There was nothing we disliked.  Hopefully it will hold up under long-term use.  Recommended!  (Vendor supplied free product in exchange for an unbiased review).

QUICK SUMMARY:  We used this mostly in our backyard swimming pool.  What a disappointment!  It takes on water inside the two pontoons, began listing to the right-side, and one of the functions associated with the remote just stopped working after literally one minute in the water.  Might be fun for non-water use, but forget about using this in water.BACKGROUND:  I gave this to my older, pre-teen son to try out.  After charging the battery for the required five hours, we dropped in the battery into vehicle and went outside.  On the ground, it moves side-to-side very quickly, but going forward and backward was ridiculously slow.  Some blades of grass got caught in the rotating pontoons, adversely affecting its forward motion.  But we mostly wanted to try it out in our pool.In the pool, it was an utter disappointment.  On the remote, the right-side button I think angles the pontoons so it moves forward or backward, but after a minute in the water, the vehicle stopped responding to the right-side forward/backward button on the remote.  It was stuck in the forward position, so we were still able to maneuver it in the water okay (tricky, though, as the left-side button is imprecise).  But then the pontoons started filling with water, and the vehicle listed badly to the left, then it nose-dived forward, too.  At this point, it's still useable, but in looking over the battery cover seal, I feared that it would foul the battery compartment, so we took it out of the water.  Even after drying, the right-side button on the remote that controls the forward/backward motion doesn't work correctly on the vehicle.In short, this was a huge disappointment, and for the money that Mattel is asking for to buy this thing, I'd be furious if this weren't a review sample.  My son has since tossed it to the side, unable to use it in the pool.  Maybe we'll bring it indoors, but the outdoor experience was so bad, it immediately lost its appeal with my son (and with me).WHAT WE ALSO DID NOT LIKE:- The remote control is super-chintzy, light, and not at all like a nice gaming console control- The two buttons on the remote have terrible tactile feel, imprecise and cheap-feeling- Although this is supposed to be used in water, the vehicle's pontoons take in water and cause the vehicle to list if they don't take in water at the same rate- The battery compartment doesn't have a gasket to keep water out of it; it's just a plastic cover screwed onto a plastic body- The fine-printed instructions give important information that should be much more prominently communicated, like, don't recharge a hot battery, wait about 10 minutes, or else you'll damage the battery's future charging capacity, and charge the battery for 5 hours for the first two charging cyclesCONCLUSION:  Save your money and buy your kid some Legos or a cheap quad-copter instead.  Not recommended

QUICK SUMMARY:  Nice little portable desk fan works well, it's versatile, but I wish it offered different speeds and it's awfully costly for what it is.BACKGROUND:  We got this an immediately put it onto a gaming desk we have, in a room that tends to be warmer than the rest of the house because of the gaming computer and hot, overhead lights.  It was a cinch to plug this fan into a USB hub on the desk, and it helpfully kept the gamer cooler.  If you don't want to plug it into a USB port or another, powered device with a USB port, you'll need to use your own electric wall adapter that converts AC power to DC via a USB port, as this box doesn't have such an adapter.WHAT WE LIKED:- It's small enough to take up little desk space, but works well to keep someone cool that's within a few feet of it- It's a great idea to make this USB-powered- It has a battery compartment so, for short intervals, this could be used without a power cord- You can easily tilt the fan up or down to achieve optimal coolingWHAT COULD BE BETTER:- There is only one speed; I wish it offered at least a high and low setting, especially if I didn't want extra room noise- It's reasonably quiet, but it does add some noticeable room noise (again, I wish it offered a high/low setting)- The USB cord end that plugs into the fan isn't micro USB, so if you lose/misplace this particular cord, you can't easily swap to use another one- The cost of this fan doesn't strike me as a good value; I think it's worth maybe half the current selling priceCONCLUSION:  I like the USB-powered feature and small design of this fan, but for the selling price, I think it doesn't represent a good value.  If you have an electric socket nearby, you can get a similar desk fan for the half the cost.  If you need the USB-powered capability of this fan, and the ability to use battery power, too, then it's an okay (if costly) choice.

QUICK SUMMARY:  A mildly interesting read with some mildly interesting advice, but it's not something that really inspires (me, anyway).I was intrigued by this book because it's written by a Christian author about creativity.  I applaud what the author has set out to do -- and what he finished.  But the author is a creative arts type of person, and I live in a world of convergent, analytical thinkers (and I am one of them).  So, I don't know what I needed to be inspired, but the author's book just didn't really grip my analytical mind.  Maybe I was looking for a checklist of creative exercises or something like that.  If you consider yourself to be a very analytical thinker -- either according to some personality test or just by your own judgment -- rather than a "feeler" or "intuitive" type person, this book may not be what you need, either.

QUICK SUMMARY:  Long-lasting battery provides plenty of power for that Saturday morning hedging you've got to do.  Powerful enough to snip off all but the fattest branches that fit through the guiding teeth of the blade.  And it has a battery power indicator, too!BACKGROUND:  I used this to trim my 30' long ficus hedge in my front yard this morning.  With my old Black and Decker cordless, this job would expend a single battery and then some, depending on how overgrown the hedge was.  Using this Scotts Li-Ion cordless, though, the battery level still read "Full" even after I finished the job!  Wow!  This new hedge trimmer weighs about the same as my old one, so no noticeable improvement there.  The blades move more slowly than the Black & Decker cordless, but they do the job its designed to do.  A few quirks about this device make it 4.5 stars overall.WHAT I LIKE:- The Li-Ion battery charged quickly, and provided PLENTY of power for my hedge-trimming chore- The hedge clipper only got stuck on a few fat branches that didn't quite fit the teeth of the hedge's blade, everything else got snipped off just fine- The hedge clipper has a battery indicator light which shows how much charge is left- It was reasonably easy to use, not anything better than what I'm used to with other cordless trimmers- It comes with an easy-to-use blade guard for when the hedge clipper isn't in use- The Li-Ion battery can be left on the charger; it can't be overchargedWHAT COULD BE BETTER:- When you squeeze the on/off trigger, the battery level light may not read correctly.  Be sure to squeeze the trigger fully and for a few seconds to get a reading.  When I first was testing this, I briefly squeezed the trigger and the battery charge showed only one bar, which I knew wasn't right.  But if I squeezed the trigger fully, the correct battery charge displayed.- When I replaced the battery onto its charger, the battery charger slowly glowed red - defective battery!?!  I removed and reset the battery onto the charger using a swift, sure movement, and that time, the battery began charging as I expected.  I don't think the battery is defective, rather, I think the battery can't be slowly inserted onto the charger and get a charged properly.  This shouldn't be a finicky procedure.CONCLUSION:  Nice cordless hedge trimmer will replace my Black and Decker hedge trimmer mostly because I know I won't run out of battery power doing my Saturday morning yard work.  Nice unit overall.

QUICK SUMMARY:  Nice wicker basket (made from plastic, probably recycled) has a humorous shape and with the lid, it's quick to hide the dog toy clutter.  Not well-constructed to tote heavier loads around the house, it's fine for what it is.BACKGROUND:  We've got a mutt with a bunch of half-chewed plush toys, balls, old socks and more that we keep around for him to play with.  Until getting this basket, all that unsightly, cluttered mess was in a wicker basket on the floor.  Using this basket, it's a cinch to close the lid if I don't want to look at the clutter (downside:  the dog doesn't know how to lift the lid himself).  But use this indoors, not outdoors!  My experience with recycled wicker products for outdoor use is dismal; the plastic quickly disintegrates.  In a pinch, you could almost get away with using this as a picnic basket, but the lid locking mechanism isn't well-constructed, unfortunately, and probably would break if too much weight were being carried for too long.WHAT I LIKED:- Fun shape- Neutral color works well just about anywhere- Good size to stow a lot of dog toys, bones, clutter- The lid hides all the clutter nicely- The lid strap locks into place, allowing you to securely carry this storage basket by its handleWHAT COULD BE BETTER:- The strap that attaches the lid to the basket compartment is attached rather flimsily; I wish it were more sturdily attached- When closing the lid, the lid is a slightly misaligned so it doesn't lay flush on top of the basket; I wish it lay flush instead (not a big deal, though)CONCLUSION:  A nice product overall, but if you're planning on regularly toting this basket around by the handle, I wouldn't advise getting this product.  It's fine when it sits on the floor, looks nice, and does what it's supposed to do -- hide the dog toy clutter.

QUICK SUMMARY:  Great value for what you get, but if you're a runner, these probably aren't what you want, even if they stay securely attached to your ears (too much microphonic noise).  For gym use and walking, though, these are fine.BACKGROUND:  I use Bluetooth headsets while running 30-40 minutes outside during lunchtime.  During the summer, I sweat so much that I couldn't get wetter if you poured a bucket of water over me.  These Soundpeats lightweight headphones have a lot going for them, but what keeps them from getting 5-stars is I hear a LOT of microphonic noise as my feet hit the pavement, and the resulting vibrations seem to get picked up by these headphones and delivered right into my eardrums.  But these headphones are great in many other ways, not the least of which is they're price-competitive.  If you're not a runner, you may like these headphones even more than me.WHAT I LIKE:- The headphones were easily paired, and once paired, they connect very quickly to my iPhone- The set comes with a nice selection of ear pieces and attachments; I use the ear hooks to keep them securely attached while running- While running, I did not have to adjust these earphones even once; with a proper fit, they stayed very securely attached- They are comfortable to wear, too- I can turn my head from side-to-side without the cord (that's behind my head) tugging at the ear pieces- The audio sound, while not breathtaking, is good for the money- The set comes with a nice, zippered case to stow the headphones and all the ear piece attachments- It was easy to add/remove the ear hooks without accidentally detaching the already-attached ear rubbers- The headphone battery level is displayed on my iPhone when the two devices are connected- Despite my profuse sweating, these headphones worked wellWHAT I DID NOT LIKE:- The microphonic sound is really bad (that is, unwanted sound from vibrations) while running- The ear rubbers are constructed with very thin rubber; I wonder if that contributes to the microphonic sound I hear while running- The bass sound is underwhelming, even if I hold these headphones at an optimal position in my earsCONCLUSION:  Since I use these while running, the microphonic sound really impedes my enjoyment in using these headphones.  I don't expect to have vibration-free sound from a pair of headphones while running, but these are worse than other Bluetooth headphones I've used.  That said, these are a very good value for the money, and if you're not planning on running with these on, they may well be a 5-star item for you.  (Vendor supplied free item in exchange for an unbiased product review).

QUICK SUMMARY: These lights work as designed, but the color change effect was too abrupt for my liking.UPDATED 6/15/2015: ** DO NOT BUY **. After six months, most of these light fixtures stopped working. All of them showed a LOT of rust spots (the "stainless steel" is of such poor quality that they began showing small rust spots after just 30 days), marring the appearance of the one light that is still working. Terrible quality, a great disappointment. Try another a product - avoid these completely!BACKGROUND: I installed these lights around the footpath around my backyard pool, where they get a lot of sunlight during the day.WHAT I LIKE:- Easy to assemble. Just insert the plastic stake into one end of the stainless steel tube, and insert the light fixture into the opposite end of the tube. To turn on the automatic light mechanism, twist off the top of the light fixture, flip the switch to the ON position, then re-twist the fixture on again.- Each fixture came with a rechargeable battery pre-installed- The batteries are Ni-MH, not Ni-Cad, so they shouldn't be subject to a battery "memory effect" that degrades performance- The batteries are user-replaceable- I only cared that these lights would work from dusk until midnight, and they do that- They are maintenance freeWHAT COULD BE BETTER:- The light color-shifting is too abrupt, occurring in 1-2 seconds. I wish the color shifting was more nuanced, even imperceptible. Instead, the too-quick color shifting draws attention to the light fixture. I want these landscape lights to be more subtle than what they are.- The stainless steel tube is paper thin and easily bent. I wish the product used marine-quality stainless steel that was thicker, sturdier, since these are going to be subject to the elements. As-is, I have my doubts that the "Made in China" stainless steel will stand-up to Florida's heat, humidity, and rain. (I also wonder how the batteries are going to hold up in Florida's summertime heat, too).- The red color is so dark, that it fails to illuminate my footpath. Only the greenish-blue color does a reasonable job of illuminating my footpath.- I wish there was a way to not allow the colors to change; instead, I wish I could just choose a color to always have lit up.NOTE: The package boasts "Color Changing LED Lights" which is true. But it also says, in smaller letters, "The lights...have super bright white LED lights" which is not true. They don't cast off white light, much less "super bright" white light.CONCLUSION: If the light changing colors were much more subtle, and if you could choose to display just one color (turning off the color changing feature), this would be a 4-star item. I do worry that a landscape light set that is "Made in China" won't hold up to Florida's climate very well. (Vendor supplied free item for unbiased product review).

QUICK SUMMARY:  An outstanding 10KmAh battery charger that looks great and comes with a plush storage pouch and highly useful 4-in-1 charging cable.  This is an instant favorite charging power pack in my home.  Highly recommended!I have reviewed quite a few charging battery packs in recent years, and I really like them.  This Foxnovo battery pack may well be my favorite of them all.  I love the premium feel of its aluminum alloy shell, the high-quality feel of the included 4-in-1 charging cable that connects to all sorts of devices (micro USB, lightning, 30-pin Apple, and micro USB 3.0).WHAT I LIKE:- The 10KmAh battery capacity is enough to charge an iPhone several times before the battery pack itself needs charging- The aluminum alloy shell looks great, feels great, and the overall size is a little smaller than other 10KmaAh packs I have- The 4-in-1 charging cable is of nicer quality and feel than other, similar charging cables I have- The plush storage pouch is surprisingly nice, with a cushioned feel and attached, external pouch for the 4-in-1 cable, too- The battery pack performed as expected- The blue LED lights are muted, a pleasant change from the blinding blue LED lights of other, similar products- It's designed with one 1.0A port and one 2.1A port, so it can be used with both iPhones/iPods and iPads (and other devices, too)- This would make an excellent, elegant gift, not for the packaging, but because of the product itselfCONCLUSION:  I don't usually get that excited about battery packs, but both my college-aged son and I feel like this is the best external battery charging pack we've ever come across.  I'm delighted with what I'm seeing so far from the Foxnovo brand.  Highly recommended!  (Vendor supplied free item in exchange for an unbiased product review).

QUICK SUMMARY:  Finally!  A cable that serves the needs of everyone's electronic gadgetry! This cable is not only a great idea, Foxnovo did a great job with the construction, too.  Highly recommended!I have reviewed a lot of cables in recent years, but this one is an instant favorite.  Why?  It's got a nice length (2.6 feet) so you can charge your device while using it, but the best part is the well-thought way you can convert the micro USB plug to an Apple lightning cable.  The plug is narrow enough to fit easily into my iPhone with its protective case on.  The bright yellow-green color makes it a snap to identify as the one cable I want to take with me.WHAT I LIKE:- The 2-in-1 feature is one I've wanted for a long time.  Thank you, Foxnovo, for creating it!- The lightning connector fits very securely onto the micro USB connector- The yellow-green cable color makes it easy to pick-out of the dozens of cables I have in my home- Having this one cable means I don't have to carry two cables anymore to charge devices I carry with me- The overall construction feels good, it feels high-quality- I like the flattened, no-tangle design of the cable itself- The plastic coil that keeps the Apple connector secured to the cable stretches when needed, coils up when not in use- It's Apple MFi CertifiedCONCLUSION:  This is one of the very few times I review an item that I really love, and that I can't think of any way to make it better.  An excellent product!  Highly recommended!!  (Vendor supplied free item in exchange for an unbiased product review).

QUICK SUMMARY:  The "feel" of using a hard-tipped stylus on an iPad isn't pleasing to me, the palm-rejection works (but not perfectly), the lag time between writing and seeing what you've written is noticeable, sometimes it just doesn't register what I've written, and heaven help you if you lose the charger.BACKGROUND:  Both my teen daughter and I used this stylus.  She liked it well enough, but I didn't really like using it.  She'll use it for drawing, not note-taking.  I was interested in note-taking, but I'm not going to replace my disposable fountain pen and paper just yet (or just typing out a Word document on my laptop).  We used this with an iPad Mini.WHAT WE LIKED:- The Bluetooth-enabled capability helps with palm rejection- My daughter liked the feel and balance of the pen (but I didn't)- My daughter liked using it to draw with because it's a fine-tipped penWHAT COULD BE BETTER:- As I summarized above, there is a noticeable lag between what you write and what you see written on the iPad if you write quickly- Palm rejection works okay, but not 100%- When I tried writing quickly, sometimes what I'd written didn't appear on the iPadWHAT I DID NOT LIKE:- I just didn't like the feel of the pen's fine tip moving across the iPad.  I guess it's just too smooth or slippery for my liking.- I didn't like the weight, balance, and feel of this pen, despite the premium materials.- I didn't like that it has a special USB charger.  I hate devices that have special chargers when micro USB is ubiquitous.  There is no reason why this pen couldn't have accepted a micro USB input at the end where it fits onto its magnetized USB charging base.  Maybe it's not cool to have a dangling USB cord attached to a pen, but I've got 100 micro USB cables in the house, but I better not lose the charging base that comes with this pen or else I can't use this special, expensive pen.CONCLUSION:  I'm not to be counted among those who love using stylus with any kind of computing device.  This device isn't going to set me out on that road just yet.  My daughter gave this item 4-stars, but I gave it 2-stars; hence, it gets a 3-star review from my family.

QUICK SUMMARY:  I could not get the 5Ghz AC band to work well at all, but the 2.4Ghz BGN band worked well.  The mini CD containing the Wifi driver was inconvenient since my laptops either have slot DVD drives or don't have DVD/CD drive.  And the branding makes it impossible to know where to go for help.  Not recommended.BACKGROUND:  I run a sophisticated home network with dozens of connected devices.  At the core, I use an excellent TP-LINK AC dual band router with a D-Link and Linksys access point repeaters.  To test this unit, I sat five feet from my router and connected to both the 2.4Ghz BGN band and the 5Ghz AC band.  While the BGN band worked well, permitting data transfers from my Windows 2008 server at the 8-10MB/sec range, I nearly came to a crashing halt when connected to the 5Ghz AC band, where data transfers slowed to a crawl (< 1MB/sec).  My test laptop was an old Windows 7 Dell laptop using just USB 2.0.  I didn't expect great speed from the AC band on a USB 2.0 connection, but what I didn't expect was dismal performance.  Before I tested this adapter, I did install their included driver firstly (having my son transfer the mini CD to an ISO file that he put onto a USB thumb drive).WHAT I LIKED:- The performance on the 2.4Ghz BGN band was very good, at 8-10MB/sec- The size of this adapter is great, very small, very unobtrusive- The included installation manual was surprisingly clear with color screenshots of the installation process (albeit with a very small, 6-point font)- The optional Ralink utility that shows wireless connection options and information was useful and helpful- The Ralink utility lets you change your computer to an access point to extend your Wifi networkWHAT I DID NOT LIKE:- The performance on the 5Ghz AC band was dismal, it never worked well for me.  This is the key reason for my 2-star review.- The green LED light on the adapter is nearly impossible to perceive because it's so tiny- The branding of this unit creates a lot of confusion.  The item is sold by Etekcity, but the manufacturer of both the adapter, driver and utility is Ralink, but Ralink isn't mentioned on any of the included packaging.  When I tried visiting Etekcity's website for a driver, I couldn't find this adapter.  When I tried Googling for it, I still couldn't find one.  The user manual unhelpfully says, "Wireless USB Adapter" on the cover, never disclosing that Ralink is the manufacturer.- The instructions should be very clear about where on the Internet to go to download the required driver (instead of using the mini CD)CONCLUSION:  I use the 5Ghz AC band in my home network on other devices, so I know that the issue I had using the AC band with this adapter is localized to either the adapter itself, the adapter's driver, or my Dell Windows 7 laptop.  Since I can use my laptop's original Intel Wifi card to connect to the 5Ghz band reliably (using the BGN protocol, not the AC protocol), I am concluding that the issue is with the Ralink hardware and/or software.  Not recommended.  (Vendor supplied free item in exchange for an unbiased product review).

QUICK SUMMARY:  Nobody in my family liked its taste, so irrespective of its health benefits, no one in my family will use this product.BACKGROUND:  I made a plain smoothie (milk, this protein powder) using a shaker bottle.  The powder didn't dissolve easily from the bottom of the bottle; I had to use a knife to dislodge some of the powder, in fact.  When I tasted the finished result, I didn't care much for the taste at all, and I disliked the foamy texture of the smoothie.Then I tried making another smoothie for my daughters, without giving them any heads-up on my experience and opinion.  This time, I added ice and a strawberry Greek yogurt, too, and blended it together using our Vita-Mix blender.  I was hoping the ice would make it icier, but it still came out with a foamy texture.  When my girls tried their smoothies, they didn't even want to finish them.  One daughter just refused to sip any further, in fact.Then my college-aged son came home, so I gave him some smoothie without telling him anything about it.  He disliked it just like the same.Now, as a family, we love strawberries and we like bananas and eat a lot of both fruits regularly.  But one of my daughters summed up the problem this way:  "It tastes like strawberry-flavored toothpaste."  I had to agree.Although this product might be well-suited to families looking to steer away from dairy and wheat products, there is a downside to this soy-based product:  it doesn't taste that good, and it creates a foamy smoothie texture that you may not like, either.CONCLUSION:  Unless you like ingesting strawberry-flavored toothpaste, stick with a good chocolate protein powder.

QUICK SUMMARY:  I used these *NOT* for moving or protecting furniture, but to create an acoustic barrier for a small, home recording studio.  Works very nicely for this purpose!  And these look nice, too.BACKGROUND:  I created a very small home recording studio this weekend in a small nook of my master bedroom.  To improve the acoustic features of this nook, I wanted to hang an acoustic curtain.  After doing a little research, it seems like buying moving blankets is a cheap way to do this.  I chose this set because at least one other reviewer said they bought this 4-blanket set for the same reason with good results, and other reviewers gave generally positive feedback, too.BUILDING THE ACOUSTIC CURTAIN:  Each blanket weighs 5 pounds.  To build the curtain, you're going to use brass grommets to attach 2, 3 or all 4 curtains together.  Others said they made curtains using three blankets, so I did that, too.  I started with the first blanket, used a grommet kit to punch five holes across one of the shorter edges of the blanket, starting about 6" from one corner, then punching another hole every 12 inches until I punched five holes.  The stitching design of these blankets made it a very easy to do this, because the zig-zag design is stiched in one-foot intervals, so I didn't need to use a measuring tape to know where I needed to punch holes into the blanket.  Then I laid the 2nd blanket atop the first blanket and lined-up everything so when I punched five holes into the 2nd blanket, they'd line-up to the holes I'd punched in the 1st blanket.  Repeat again for the 3rd blanket.  Note that I didn't fold back the edge of the blanket when I was punching my holes (in effect, creating 2 holes for each grommet, ten holes total for five grommets total) which would have strengthened the hanging feature of this acoustic blanket, but I didn't think it was necessary since I will only hang up this blanket for a few hours at the most before I take it down again.After all the holes are punched, I used a General-branded grommet kit (1/2" size grommets) to affix brass grommets to all three blankets so they're all joined together now.  This acoustic curtain now weighs 15 pounds!I used the 4th blanket as a smaller curtain by folding it lengthwise once, then affixing three grommets to the top of that 4th curtain.  I use this short curtain to cover the doorway into the master bathroom.To hang this acoustic curtain, I was going to use 3M Command hooks (Medium) until my wife got a clue as to what my intentions were.  She didn't want to see any hooks inside the bedroom walls.  So, instead, I tapped in picture hooks into my bedroom nook (which its walls cannot be seen from inside our master bedroom), then used a carabiner clip hook with keyrings to hook the curtain by its new grommets, and put the keyring onto the picture hook.  Worked like a charm!  It's a cinch now to hang up the curtain and remove it when I'm done using it.PERFORMANCE:  I used an iPhone app that measures decibels to see what difference my acoustic curtain made.  To test, one of my sons was watching a movie at full volume in our family room.  I shut my bedroom door and the reading was 40 decibels inside my bedroom.  Behind my curtain, though, it was 35 decibels.  A five decibel difference is very noticeable to the human ear.  Although I could hear the movie from behind my acoustic curtain, it was definitely more muffled now.OTHER:  There was a faint smell that these moving blankets have.  I suspect if I aired them out, put them outside and in the sun on a sunny Saturday, that smell would soon dissipate.  As it was, the faint smell didn't trouble me and didn't keep me from using them as a make-shift acoustic curtain.CONCLUSION:  For an acoustic curtain, these worked great!  If you've read this long review and only plan on using them to protect furniture and other stuff you're moving, well, these seem like a nicely made product that would do a good job protecting your stuff.  Highly recommended!

QUICK SUMMARY:  Worked to deaden the reflected sound in a small nook of my bedroom that I've turned into a recording studio.  Seems like a lot of money for foam, but I'm no sound engineer.BACKGROUND:  I've turned an unused make-up counter in my master bedroom into a home recording studio.  The built-in make-up counter is walled-in on three sides with a large mirror behind the countertop.  Without treatment, the sound was reflecting mightily off all the hard surfaces.  On a recommendation, I ordered these Auralex Studiofoam squares to dampen the sound in this area.  It worked!  The space I'm working with is approximately 2' x 3' x 2'.  Ideally, I need 21 squares to cover the walls 3' up from the countertop, and another 6 squares to create a hood over the countertop -- 27 squares total.  This set only has 24 squares, so I'm missing a few squares on both side walls right now.INSTALLATION:  To attach the Studiofoam squares to my walls and mirror, I used Velcro squares I cut-out from industrial-grade Velcro tape.  I only used two small, 1" squares of Velcro per foam square.  Seems to work so far to keep the feather-light foam panels in place.  I did also try using 3M Duct tape (black, which has moderate adhesion properties), and that didn't work at all, which surprised me.  For the hood over the countertop, I used small picture frame hooks and 28-gauge picture frame wire to string thin strands of wire over the countertop, then laid six Studiofoam squares on the overhead wire.  That worked very well, but it doesn't look too nice, because the wire does tend to sag a little.  The benefit of this whole arrangement is I could completely remove all the squares anytime I want, as none of them are permanently attached to anything.PERFORMANCE:  After installing just the squares on the three walls, I sampled my voice above the foamed walls and within the foamed walls.  It was very, very noticeable the difference!  My voice sounds "dead" when I'm talking into the foamed walls, meaning that it sounds weird, almost muffled (it's not really muffled, of course, it's just that it's harder to hear my voice because so much of my voice energy is absorbed by the foam squares).  For my purposes of voice recording, this will really be very beneficial.CONCLUSION:  I'm not a musician or recording artist, just somebody who has a need to professionally record my voice at home without a big investment.  To me, spending a hundred bucks on something like this is a fairly big investment since it looks just like foam padding you'd find when unpacking a new TV set from its shipping box.  Be that as it may, these are doing the job they're intended to do, so all I can quibble on is their price.  Recommended!

QUICK SUMMARY:  The built-in amp of this subwoofer delivers bass that easily fills a room.  Be sure you've got room for it in your room, though!BACKGROUND:  I have a small family room with a 46" TV and Bose Acousitmass speakers, including the Bose subwoofer which is powered strictly from the speaker wires rather than externally powered.  And the Bose subwoofer, for all these years, has been very nice, augmenting the terrific sound of the small little Bose speakers atop my entertainment armoire.  This Sony subwoofer is about twice the size of my Bose subwoofer, and it's externally powered, too, delivering over 100-watts of power.  The result?  Much bigger bass effect!  But as my kids pointed out, it's not the kind of bass that resonates inside your chest.  It's just full, deep, and room-filling.WHAT I LIKE:- The wiring was straightforward and simple, identical to the Bose subwoofer we had.  Left & Right inputs coming from the receiver, and Left & Right outputs going to the small little Bose speakers we already had.  That, plus you plug-in the electric cord into a wall outlet for power.- The sound is much more room-filling than it was before, and I never thought our subwoofer before was that bad at all.  Now, the bass is really deep, and depending on the audio source, it's easy to discern the bass guitar or other instruments that operate in the low frequencies of a subwoofer.- There is a knob on the backside to adjust the amount of sound you'll get relative to the input source- A non-blinding, green LED light indicates power-on condition, and shows red for stand-by mode- The power-save feature should be set to ON to turn-off this subwoofer when not in use (it's a slide-switch on the backside).  If you're watching a movie, turn this feature off to avoid the power-off feature switching on and off throughout the movie.- The black color is standard, but that's a good thing, as I wouldn't want this thing to stand out in any wayWHAT COULD BE BETTER:- The power-save slide switch and power button are inconveniently located on the back side of this subwoofer.  These could certainly have been put on the front or side locations on this big black box to make them easier to find and use when necessary.  As is, the power-save switch is located next to the phase selector switch (it lets you choose normal or reverse selections which can affect how the sound is reproduced), and since both switches are on the backside, it's hard to know which switch is which without bending, stooping to read the nearly illegible switch labels.- When power-save is enabled, if you turn on your audio input at a low volume level, this subwoofer won't automatically power up.  It will automatically power up at a higher volume, though.  So, you may have to crank up the volume more loudly than you want in order for this subwoofer to automatically power-up (or, kneel down and press the power button off, then on again, which is inconvenient)CONCLUSION:  For a small or average sized room, this subwoofer will easily fill the room with the deep, rich, bass sounds without overpowering the rest of the audio frequencies.  The subwoofer is double the size of non-externally powered subwoofers because it doubles the amount of sound it produces.  Recommended!

QUICK SUMMARY:  Tiny wireless adapter installed easily on two of our home laptops.  But getting the AC band to operate was a mystery in our networked home.BACKGROUND:  We have an unusual home environment.  We run two Windows servers, a TP-LINK n-router with the wireless feature turned off; instead, we use a D-Link AC router to broadcast the WiFi signal because it worked better than our TP-LINK (but we prefer TP-Link's router features over the D-Link).  We also have two repeaters in our home, only one which repeats the 5Ghz band.  My laptop is an old Dell XPS M1530 (2008).  My college son's laptop is a modern, mid-range Asus with built-in AC (2014).To use this TP-LINK USB adapter, the accompany instructions say to install the TP-LINK drivers firstly.  I downloaded the drivers easily from TP-LINK's website, which included a little utility which wasn't particularly useful.  To test with, I went into Device Manager and alternately disabled/enabled my Intel card and this TP-LINK USB adapter, with reboots between switching devices.  I tested sitting right next to our router and also outside on our patio, behind hurricane-resistant sliders.  I use a free utility, called INSSIDER, to examine the broadcast signal from our D-Link.  Weirdly, on my laptop, the utility only showed that our home network was broadcasting an n-signal, not ac, irrespective of whether I was using my laptop's built-in Intel Wifi card or this TP-LINK adapter.  But using the same utility on my son's laptop, the 5Ghz network band appeared as an ac signal.  I bring this up because I wanted to see how using the ac protocol would improve data transfer, but my son and I had difficulty ascertaining whether we were using the ac protocol at all.  On his laptop, he got dismal download speed using this TP-LINK connected to the 5Ghz band (3MB/sec, when his built-in Wifi card was getting 20 MB/sec on the 5Ghz band), but I think he just had some configuration issue with his laptop.  On my laptop, I got about 24 MB/sec using this TP-LINK adapter, which was about 4-6 MB/sec better than my Intel WiFi card.  When I was on our patio, I ran several comparison tests between my Intel card and this TP-LINK adapter, and overall the performance was about the same between the two, between 8-12MB/sec (which would seem to me to indicate I was only operating on the n-protocol, not the ac-protocol).NOTE:  The packaging for this TP-LINK Wifi adapter says that the max transfer speed is up to 433 mbps, which may be lower than what you're expecting for a WiFi adapter operating on the ac-protocol, but is perfectly fine for streaming HD video.WHAT I LIKE:- Extremely compact, and extremely easy to use, just install the drivers and plug-in- For laptops that don't operate on the 5Ghz band, this adapter gives them that opportunity in a small form-factor- The green LED light is useful to show the device is enabled and operating, but it's not blindingly bright- When I was near my router, the data transfer speed was better than my Intel 4965AGN cardWHAT COULD BE BETTER:- Instead of the mini-CD, I wish the packaging had included a small USB thumb drive with the drivers.  Mini-CDs don't fit into my slot CD drive.- The TP-LINK Wireless Configuration Utility only operates with the TP-LINK adapter, not with any Wifi adapter.  I wish it would let me select which Wifi card to use instead of having to use Device Manager.For whatever reason, though, neither my son nor I could seemingly get this to operate on the ac protocol.  I don't think that's the fault of this device, though.CONCLUSION:  I expected to write-up a comparison of data transfers between an n-network and an ac-network, but that didn't pan out.  All I can say is that the 5Ghz band worked fine with n-network speed, and that it performed better than my laptop's Intel wifi card.

QUICK SUMMARY:  An excellent value for the money!  These candles flicker realistically as if affected by a nearby fan or outdoor breeze.  And the company definitely stands behind their product and wants you to be a satisfied customer.  Recommended!WHAT I LIKE:- Small little candles fit nicely on bookshelves and other nooks in your home- By day, they're slightly off-white in appearance, by night, they glow warm yellow- Easy on/off switch on the bottom.  Note that Festival Delights offers this same product with a 5-hour timer, too.- The box came with a battery installed, plus each candles comes with a spare battery, too!WHAT COULD BE BETTER:- I wish the candles had two "ON" settings, one for a slight flicker, as if there was no wind/breeze in the area, and one for flickering like when there is wind/breeze in the area.  As is, these only flicker as if there is wind/breeze in the area.WHAT I DID NOT LIKE:- Three of the six installed batteries were dead-on-arrival.  I pulled the insulating plastic tab from the bottom of all six, but only three candles lit after that.  No big deal, though, as the package came with six spare batteries.  I installed three spare batteries to replace the three defective, dead-on-arrival batteries, and had all six candles glowing nicely afterwards.WHAT GREATLY IMPRESSED ME:- Given the very low cost of these candles, and knowing it would be a hassle to seek a remedy for the three bad batteries, I was contented to just let things be.  But Festival Delights sent me an email following the delivery, asking if everything was satisfactory.  I wrote back, telling about my experience with the three batteries.  A few more emails, and I'll just say that I was more than satisfied with the remedy that Festival Delights came up with on their own.  This is a company that really, really wants to do right by their customers.  The issue I had was a supplier problem with another company who supplies Festival Delights with their batteries, but Festival Delight made this their problem, and didn't pass the buck to their supplier.CONCLUSION:  I buy a ton of stuff online, but this experience was shocking to me for how well I was treated after the sale.  I intend to buy these exact candles as small gifts for next Christmas.  These little candles are a great value!  Highly recommended!

QUICK SUMMARY:  Nicely-featured, low-end laptop will suit many user needs in a very affordable price-point.  Several quibbles keep me from loving it, though.BACKGROUND:  I bought this laptop for my wife, who uses it for email, Netflix (DVD and streaming), creating documents, and surfing the web.  She plays no games and uses few other programs besides the Microsoft Office suite.  It replaces a 10-year-old Dell laptop running Windows 7 Professional on 1GB of RAM and a 128GB SSD.  Her old laptop was choking on lack of RAM.OUT OF BOX EXPERIENCE:  This Asus had relatively little bloatware, but there are a few Asus utilities and Asus-selected apps from the Microsoft Store preloaded.  I was surprised and irritated that Asus included Windows 8, not Windows 8.1, which meant I spent HOURS downloading security patches and doing the Windows 8.1 upgrade followed by more security patching.  But the *worst* decision Asus made was pre-loading McAfee anti-virus software tools.  The McAfee scanner gobbled up 500MB of RAM memory on a machine that only had 4GB to start with!  This, without me asking McAfee to do anything on my behalf.  My experience with McAfee and Symantec's Norton anti-virus products is dismal and it's impossible to fully remove their fingerprints from a system (running their uninstaller program notwithstanding).FOR TECHIE FOLKS ONLY:  I also encountered an error when I tried using my Windows Home Server 2011 to backup this Asus laptop.  The problem is that this Asus uses GUID Partition Table (GPT) for disk partitioning rather than Master Boot Record (MBR).  There is a hotfix for WHS 2011 for this, but that has it's own issues, so I've opted to use Windows 8's new backup/restore methods, like using File History.  I still created a system image backup in Windows 8, though, just to have an image copy of the hard drive.  To rid myself of McAfee and Asus's utilities, after I upgraded to Windows 8.1 and learned I couldn't use it with my WHS 2011 to do nightly backups, I decided to do a fresh install of Windows 8.1, deleting all of Asus' hidden restore partitions (which would have uselessly restored my laptop to Windows 8 and caused me hours of subsequent patching, rather than restoring this laptop to Windows 8.1) and letting the Windows 8.1 installer program create all the necessary partitions beyond the C: partition that I created myself.PERFORMANCE:-  About 45 seconds from power-on button to sign-on screen-  About 1 minute, 15 seconds from power-on button to your Desktop after signing on; this was actually 30 seconds faster than our old laptop that had an SSD but only 1GB of RAM!- Using the USB 3.0 port, I moved a 70GB file averaging just under 90MB/second- Using the USB 2.0 port, I moved a large file averaging around 25MB/second- The wifi card was moving about 4MB/second between our home server and this Asus laptopWHAT I LIKE:- Fairly lightweight, weighing just under 5 pounds (nearly 2 pounds lighter than our 10yo laptop)- The built-in CD/DVD drive is great for my wife, who still handles physical media to play movies from Netflix and the library- Has both VGA and HDMI outputs- Has a USB 3.0 port, which was helpful in quickly moving some large files to this laptop- The color display looks nice, as long as you're looking at it straight-on and not from a side angle- This is my first Windows 8 machine in the house (besides my college-aged son's laptop), but using freeware Classic Shell makes this laptop look and act like our familiar Windows 7 machine-  Fairly standard 4GB of RAM and 500GB HDD is a big step-up if you're using an old laptop or desktopWHAT I DID NOT LIKE:- The keyboard is terrible, but my son says that most keyboards today are terrible, so this one is no different than all the other terrible keyboards out there, especially for a low-cost laptop like this one.  It's a chiclet-style keyboard, and typing on it feels pretty awful, really.- Already mentioned above, but this laptop comes with Windows 8, not Windows 8.1, meaning you'll spend hours to patch/update your operating system, and you'll do it again if you do a factory reset sometime in the future- The WiFi doesn't operate on the 5Ghz band, just the heavily-used 2.4Ghz band- There is no disk activity light!  I really dislike not being able to tell if the disk is doing anything or not, especially when I want to perform some operation (like hard reset my laptop) and need to know if my laptop is actually doing something, and isn't stalled- The battery life isn't any better than laptops made new 10 years ago; expect ~2 hours- The touchpad isn't as sensitive as I'd like, and there appears no way to adjust the touchpad sensitivity, either.  I found myself having to tap the touchpad (for a left-mouse click) repeatedly because my first tap didn't register.  I downloaded the latest touchpad driver from Asus, but that didn't help any.CONCLUSION:  This isn't the cheapest low-end laptop on the market, but what you get for the extra hundred bucks you're spending on this laptop is probably a little faster CPU, the built-in CD/DVD drive, a single USB 3.0 port, and perhaps a slightly larger hard disk.  I primarily got this model for the built-in CD/DVD drive.  Windows 8.1 works well on it (using Classic Shell so it looks like Windows 7), but getting from Windows 8 to 8.1 is all up to you to do.  To me, this is a 3.5 star product (rounded up to 4-stars, as I like it in spite of my quibbles).

QUICK SUMMARY:  Great first impression, this is a squirrel-proof design that works.  Hopefully, it holds up over time, too.BACKGROUND:  In the winter months the last few years, I'll setup a bird feeder and watch the various birds in my Florida home come to enjoy the free (to them) seed.  But then come the squirrels and then the blackbirds, and by spring, I'm tired of feeding all the non-songbirds and give up replenishing the bird feeder for the summer months.  I was happy to try this feeder because of its claim to keep at least one pest away -- squirrels.  Today I watched one squirrel try to get seed out of the feeder.  Our feeder is on a hooked, 6' iron pole stuck in the ground.  The squirrel evidently had unsuccessfully tried jumping onto the perches, but the perches must've given away and the squirrel must've fallen onto the ground.  So, this squirrel would climb onto the iron pole and look longingly at the seed and the perches, but never tried jumping onto them.  He also climbed on top of the feeder, but the seed is too far down the plastic tube, so there was no way for him to get seed from the top of the feeder, either.  He wound up contenting himself with finding whatever seeds may have fallen onto the ground.WHAT I LIKE:- It works!  Our squirrels can't dive into the seed inside this bird feeder.- It holds a lot more seed than our old feeder (in fact, I've filled our feeder only halfway so the seeds stay fresher and to reduce the stress of our bent, iron pole from which this feeder hangs)- Five perches mean up to five birds can feed at the same time.  I watched four birds feeding simultaneously.- Easy to pop-off the top and refill the feeder- The clear, plastic tube makes it easy to see how much seed is left in the feeder, even when looking at it from a far distance- The materials look reasonably weather-resistant, although I have doubts about how long the clear tube will stay clear since it's made of plastic, not tempered glassWHAT COULD BE BETTER:- We have pigeons, too, that like to land on the bird feeder and eat.  The blackbirds haven't yet come, but they will.  It'd be great to have a user-controlled setting to determine how much resistance can each perch withstand, so I could set it so the pigeons and blackbirds can't land on the perches, but the songbirds still can.  Our pigeons can land on these perches, but the perches do bend downward about 45 degrees, but not enough so the pigeons lose their ability to eat.CONCLUSION:  This is a very pricey bird feeder, but if you spend a lot of money on bird seed, it may pay for itself by keeping you feeding birds - and not squirrels.

QUICK SUMMARY:  Stealthy USB recorder provides highly portable and discreet voice recording capabilities, but several design choices keep me from really liking this unit.BACKGROUND:  You probably already know this, but in many states and jurisdictions, it's illegal to record somebody's voice without their knowledge and consent.  To test this device, I used it to record my family's dinner conversation one evening without their knowledge or consent.WHAT I LIKE:- Serves dual purposes.  It's a 4GB USB thumb drive, and it's a voice recorder, too- Highly portable and as durable as any other USB thumb drive- Offers highly discreet recording capability- The voice recording WAV files offered very good sound in relatively small file sizes (roughly 1MB per minute)- Charging the rechargeable battery is as simply as plugging it into any USB-powered portWHAT COULD BE BETTER:- The LED indicator showing recording on (blue light), low battery (flashing red), battery recharging (red) was so hard to see that I thought my unit was defective.  Only when I was making a short video clip to send to the vendor did the video pick-up the faint light emitting from a tiny pinhole on one side of this USB.  I wish this light were brighter, although I suppose that would take more battery energy, and it would diminish the discreetness of this unit- The sound files are dated with January 1, 2000.  Although there is a small application to set the device's internal clock day/time, that did not seem to permanently set the date/time inside the unit.  I ran this application several times, and immediately afterwards, recordings would have the correct creation date/timestamp.  But if I used this device a day later, for whatever reason, it seemed to lose the date/timestamp, and the battery never discharged fully during this time period.  There seems to be glitch in how the internal clock is set.- The voice-activated capability, which functions to only record when there is something being picked-up by the microphone, caused a lot of voice clipping to occur, especially if a person's voice was soft to begin with.  I actually hated this particular feature because there was no way to turn it off.  I would much rather have a setting that let's me turn-off voice-activated recording if I wanted.- The recording files are WAV files.  I'd prefer MP3 recordings, but this is probably a design decision to avoid having to compress data in such a small device.  It's easy to convert WAV files to MP3s, but that's just an extra step you'll have to undertake if you prefer working only with MP3 files.- Sliding out the male connector that inserts into a USB port is difficult to do, and cannot be easily done using just one hand.  You have to hold this device with one hand, and use your other hand to slide out the connector because there is so much resistance involved.- Since it can be used for very discreet or even stealth recording purposes, it's probably a good idea to avoid inscribing the abbreviation, "REC" on the slide switch, which would tip-off someone that this more than just a USB thumb drive, but also a recording device, too.CONCLUSION:  If you have the need to make discreet voice recordings in a highly portable, easy-to-operate device, and if you aren't concerned about a nearly-invisible LED indicator light and WAV files that are all dated January 1, 2000, then this just might be the very thing you're looking for.  (Vendor supplied free item for an unbiased product review).

QUICK SUMMARY:  Serviceable clock/radio is fine for a guest bedroom or for a kids' bedroom, but you might want to look at other options firstly before getting this for your bedroom.BACKGROUND:  With so many clock/radios fetching half the cost of this item, you have to wonder what you're getting for the extra cost of this iHome Bluetooth Stereo Clock Radio?  Well, you get Bluetooth connectivity, a USB charging option, stereo speakers, and that's about it.  The fidelity from the speakers is what you'd expect from a transistor radio, except there are two speakers, not one.  But various quibbles I have about this product keep me from really liking it.WHAT I LIKE:- Intuitive to use.  I figured out how to set the time, connect to Bluetooth, use the audio cable input all without reading the instructions- Compact design doesn't take much space on a nightstand- Bluetooth capability is the highlight feature for this item, it's why you're paying more for a clock/radio/alarm- I liked the white digital display, not too brilliant at night, perfectly legible during the day- It's easy to adjust the display brightnessWHAT I DISLIKED:- The FM antenna comes out of the back of the unit and it's just a long wire, really.  But you can't detach it!  I don't care about the AM/FM radio, and would prefer to remove that dangling wire, but I can't, as it's not user-removable apart from using wire cutters.- The unit came with 2 AA batteries for the clock back-up feature.  After I inserted the two batteries, the "Low Battery" indicator kept flashing.  Why?  I checked, and I inserted the batteries correctly.  Then I tested them with a multi-meter.  One battery was 0.00 volts, but it looked fine on the outside.  The batteries are made from (www-dot-china-dishy-dot-com).  I tossed even the good battery fearing it would leak if I used it, and replaced them both with Duracell-branded batteries.- The battery compartment cover requires a screw to loosen, but why?  I suppose it if it's used in a small child's bedroom, it would add a measure of safety.  It would be better, then, to make using the screw optional if you need it, but allow the cover to be closed securely without using a screw.WHAT COULD BE BETTER:- The audio quality is transistor-radio quality; don't expect great sound.  It's serviceable.- The audio input is on the backside of the clock/radio, where it's more difficult to get to.  It would be better to have the input positioned on the front, side, or top of the unit so I don't have to fiddle with getting to the back of the clock radio.- The standard USB port (for recharging something) is also in the back, where it's not easy to get to.  You can recharge your iPhone using a cable plugged into the USB port, but I would much prefer a clock/radio with a built-in lightning connector so I could dispense with the cable when recharging my iPhone on the device.- There is no date function.  If there were, it could auto-adjust for Daylight Savings Time, saving the trouble of twice-a-year time adjustments.- I wish there were a light sensor that would automatically adjust the display so it's brighter during the day, dimmer at night.  The user should still initially set how dim the display should be at night.  Then, the light sensor would auto-adjust the brightness based upon whether the room is lit or not.  That would eliminate manually adjusting the brightness each morning and each evening.CONCLUSION:  My family collectively thought this is the kind of item you might see in a 3-star hotel room.  It's serviceable, but not elegant, and it doesn't have outstanding design or sound, either.  If you need a clock/radio with Bluetooth for any bedroom in the house except for yours, this might work, but for your bedroom, get something better.

QUICK SUMMARY:  This belt works as designed, but for my 6'+ size, it is much too tight around my waist.BACKGROUND:  I usually use an armband to carry my iPhone.  The idea of a waistband is good -- include a keycard, a set of keys, whatever.  But even when I fully extended this belt, it did not easily fit around my waist at all; it was just too tight.  And I'm not overweight, either; in fact, I'm rather slender.WHAT I LIKE:- Well-constructed and very, very light- Easy to buckle and easy to adjust the band- Easily fit my iPhone 5C (but note it was a *tight* fit)- Felt surprisingly comfortable to wear, even for the first time (except, it was just too tight around my waist)WHAT I DISLIKED:- I think this might only work well if your waist size is 30" or less, maybe 32".  Would be nicer to either make two versions of this item (one for smaller sizes, one for bigger), or at least make the band more adjustable for larger waist sizes.  This single complaint was serious enough that I can't really use more than 2-stars for this item.- The weather resistance doesn't mean that electronics in the carrying pouch won't get wet.  The fabric is very stretchy and lightweight, but not waterproof.  I wish it were somehow able to be waterproof, too, so my iPhone wouldn't get wet if I ran in a rain shower.CONCLUSION:  If you have a waist size 30 inches or less, this would probably be a 3-, 4- or 5-star product for you.  (Vendor supplied free item for unbiased review).

QUICK SUMMARY:  The corkscrew and foil remover are great, the stoppers work well so I don't have to reinsert the cork back into the opened bottle, and the pourer worked as designed (in spite of its distorted, egg-shape rather than round).  But I don't get the whole pump thing, and just tossed the pump into the trash because I don't know how to effectively use it.WHAT I LIKE:- The corkscrew was a little bigger than the one I'd been using, and it was easier to screw it into the cork- The foil remover was surprisingly effective to effortless remove the foil over the cork- As long as the stoppers don't leak (they haven't yet), I find using them to be much easier than re-inserting a cork back onto the neck of an opened bottle of wine.- The wine pourer made it easier to pour wine without splashing any in the process of pouringWHAT I DISLIKED:- This set lacks a case to hold everything, so it just adds more clutter into whichever kitchen drawer you're going to stow everything- There were no written instructions on how to use the pump to effectively remove air from a bottle (just a single picture of someone positioning the pump over the wine bottle).  I made a few lame attempts, guessing at the process, before giving up and tossing the pump into the garbage.- The pourer was distorted; it is a little egg-shaped.  I didn't try hard to re-form it, since it has a rubber collar on the steel funnel, and it works well to more easily pour wine into a wine glass.WHAT COULD BE BETTER:- They should have included an instruction to visit YouTube and watch a video on how to remove air from a wine bottle.CONCLUSION:  Overall, it's an okay set.  You may want something like this to get the wine stoppers, pourer, corkscrew and foil remover, and just toss out the pump.  If you really can tell that your wine is being despoiled by air, you ought to get a better wine accessory set than this one.

QUICK SUMMARY:  This is my college son's favorite battery pack for his electronic toys, so I'm having a hard time using it for mine.  Highly recommended!WHAT I LIKE:- Huge capacity (13000mAh) is the largest among the many battery packs I have in my home- Three charging ports let you charge multiple items simultaneously, or use the included tri-cord to do that with just one USB port (which will cause the devices charging from one USB port to charge more slowly, though)- Built-in flashlight has been surprisingly handy to have at night when the lights have been turned off in our home- The battery level indicators show how much power remains in the battery pack- The included tri-cord is a hit in my home!  We love its versatility and the just-right length of each cord- The Nationite reCharge A3 is astonishingly inexpensive!  I've reviewed items like this from other vendors and competing products usually cost 2x more than this one costs.WHAT COULD BE BETTER:- When plugging in a USB cord, you plug it in upside down, meaning the USB logo (stamped on the end of the USB cord) will face downward rather than upward, which is not intuitive at all.  It would be better to orient the USB ports so USB cords plug-in with the USB logo facing up, as it is for nearly all other devices.- The LED lights for the battery level are too close together, so if it's at 75% capacity, the lights from the three lit LEDs make it appear that all four LEDs are lit (so be careful to distinguish whether three or four LEDs are lit when checking remaining battery level).  That said, this wasn't an issue when the battery pack was at 50% or 25% levels and just two or one LEDs indicators were lit, and my college-aged son thought nothing of this, though it did slightly bug me.CONCLUSION:  This is an excellent battery pack, overall, and an extremely good value.  If you don't already have a high capacity battery pack, get this one -- you'll be surprised at how you got along so long without one!  (Vendor supplied free item for unbiased product review).-

QUICK SUMMARY:  These are the BEST earbuds I have ever used.  Period!  They actually make a drum cymbal sizzle and reproduce sound with amazing clarity and crispness.UPDATE:  6/12/2015:  Sadly, these terrific-sounding earbuds broke.  This was the 2nd pair of earbuds I received for a review, as the 1st pair of S5 earbuds broke just a few days after I received them.  By "break" I mean that the sound in the left earbud just stopped working.  These earbuds were well-cared for (and frequently used), and I'm really disappointed that they broke just a few months after receiving them, because they sounded so good.  Accordingly, I've knocked three stars of my 5-star rating because if you're spending about a hundred bucks on a set of earbuds, you expect them to last for years -- not months.<< Original review follows >>BACKGROUND:  I have always enjoyed listening to music with accentuated treble and midrange tones more than bass.  And I have used a lot of earbuds over the years, nearly all of which do a poor job with treble.  When I first put on these S5 headphones, I was a little disappointed because they didn't sound noticeably better than other, less costly earbuds I have.  It wasn't until my college-aged son used them and came back with glowing praise for them that I had a second listen.  Taking his advice, I *very carefully* fitted the earbuds into my ear (I usually do this hurriedly).  The result was astonishing.  With the right-sized earbud tip and position, these earbuds sound better than anything I've ever had before.  The treble of a drum cymbal just sizzles.  Vocals are clear and strong.  Altogether, my music sounded bright, lifelike, and undistorted.  Bass response was surprising because I could hear the bass chords very, very clearly, yet they're not emphasized -- there is no strong "boom-boom-boom" bass response like you get with a subwoofer.  So, the bass was just as clear as the treble, just less pronounced (which I actually liked).  I used these S5 headphones only with my iPhone and I didn't adjust use an equalizer app, but I'm thinking I'd like to get an equalizer app because with these earbuds, I could have full control over how I listen to music because these earbuds can fully reproduce the whole range of sound.  But to achieve this great sound, you MUST take care to position them correctly, and with the right-sized eargel for your ears.  If you get these and they don't sound great, try a different eargel and reposition them back into your ears until they sound great.WHAT I LIKE:- Amazingly clear sound with sizzling treble and crystal clear vocals- The flat cord resists tangling- They come with a great variety of eargels so you'll get a great fit- They are aesthetically pleasing- The bass response let me very clearly hear bass chords, yet these earbuds aren't "boomy"- They come with a protective, zippered case that also holds the extra eargels- The audio cord fits into my iPhone with me having to remove my iPhone's protective caseCONCLUSION:  If you are wondering whether spending $100 on a pair of earbuds is worth the high cost when you can get other earbuds that are much, much less expensive, all I can tell you is Amazon has a great returns policy -- try these out and see for yourself!  For me, these have set a new, high bar on how well earbuds can reproduce sound and how much I enjoy listening to my favorite tracks out of my music library.  (Update:  I had given these headphones 5-stars and a high recommendation, but after the 2nd pair broke, I cannot recommend these headphones any longer).  (Vendor supplied free product for unbiased review).

QUICK SUMMARY: Small scale works fine for a non-scientific scale that costs as much as two or three McDonald's dinners.WHAT I LIKED:- Accurate to within a gram or two (see below)- The backlit LCD display was easy to read- Battery powered, so, no cords- Small and compact, just 5" x 4"- The "Count" function makes it easy to, say, count a jar of coins having the same denomination- Has plastic covers to protect the scale when not in use (it has one cover for the weighing surface, and one for the entire scale)WHAT I DISLIKED:- This scale only weighs up to 500 grams, which is a little more than 1 pound.  Smart Weigh makes another model that weighs up to 2000 grams (4 pounds) but with 0.1g increments instead of 0.01g increments.  If you really need 0.01g accuracy, you need a real scientific scale.  This is a great little scale, but consider the other model that weighs up to 2000 grams.- The instruction manual uses a teensy-weeny font size of about 3 or 4 points- The plastic covers lack a thumb notch to make them easy to remove (and why have two covers?)- After self-calibrating, the scale tended to still bump around +/- 0.010 grams, even when nothing was on the scale. And really, can a scale like this really measure 1/1000th of a gram accurately?HOW TO CHECK SCALE ACCURACY:A cup of water is about 8.3 ounces, or, about 237 grams. Use a measuring cup and the Tare function on this scale to check its accuracy. After turning on the scale, put a plastic cup on the scale and press Tare so it reads 0.000 grams. Then, pour exactly one cup of water into the plastic cup. It should read 237 grams, more or less. My scale read just slightly under 237 grams.CONCLUSION: Great little scale for the money, but a good kitchen scale does everything this scale does. Unless you weigh very light items and/or need a very small scale, get a good kitchen scale instead.

QUICK SUMMARY:  Deeply flawed collection of "Made in China" tools are not even suitable for emergency use.  Avoid at any and all cost.WHAT I LIKE:There really isn't anything to like about this three piece tool set.  It is cheap, true, but it is very cheaply made and you're throwing your money away if you buy this set.WHAT I DISLIKED:- The pocket knife tools can't be extended out of the handle without breaking your fingernail- I easily, permanently bent the corkscrew tool (in the pocketknife) by over extending it when I retracted it out of the handle- The multi-tool's handle (when unfolded) is almost knife-like sharp, burred, and VERY painful to use- The multi-tool isn't spring-loaded, so you have to manually open the pliers each time you close them- The wood saw blade is uselessly, surprisingly dull- Like the pocketknife, the toolset in the multitool can't be extended out of the handle without breaking your fingernail- The flashlight uses an inefficient incandescent lightbulb instead of an efficient LED- The flashlight's on/off switch was faulty, causing the light to flicker on and off when switched on- The flashlight's light beam is so diffused and dim that it's nearly uselessCONCLUSION:  You're throwing your hard-earned money away with this set.  It's not wise buying such a cheap set of tools that involve life-threatening things like knives.  Unless you're shopping for a White Elephant Christmas gift for co-workers you dislike, spend the extra money it takes to get a good quality knife, flashlight and multi-tool.  (Vendor supplied free item for unbiased product review).

QUICK SUMMARY:  The knife blade is burred and dull, the multi-tool is uncomfortable to use and I'll break fingernails trying to pry open the tools.  Even the belt pouch has a design flaw.  Not recommended.WHAT I LIKESadly, there is nothing I liked about this product.  I don't hate it - each item does do what it's designed to do, and if I had access to absolutely nothing else, I would use this knife and multi-tool set.  But each item here has flaws that take all the joy out of using any of them.WHAT I DISLIKED:- The knife blade came burred and was dull.  When the blade is closed into the handle, there is a protruding, 90-degree corner of the blade base that sticks out from the handle which could actually be dangerous.- The multi-tool is uncomfortable to hold when it's unfolded and you grasp the handle- The multi-tool has no spring-load, so you have to manually open the pliers each time you close them- The various tools built-in to the multi-tool's handle are nearly impossible to extend without breaking a fingernail in the process- The wood saw tool is uselessly, surprisingly dull- Even the belt pouch is flawed, where the Velcro hooks sewn into the pouch are sewn about two inches too high up on the pouch, so the pouch's cover rises and sags over the tools rather than snuggly securing them.CONCLUSION:  This is a "Made in China" set that should stay in China.  Not recommended!  (Vendor supplied free item for unbiased product review).

QUICK SUMMARY:  Easy to use, and works surprisingly well to give long-lasting light where you're in pitch-black situations (like camping or during a power outage).WHAT I LIKE:- Cranking the hand-crank for 60 seconds will cast off useful light for 30 minutes, but the diminishing glow will continue for well beyond an hour making it a terrific camp tent light.- The hand crank fits snuggly into the body of the light fixture, rather than protruding from it- The adjustable lantern handle makes this very easy to carry as a spotlight or upright lantern- The two sets of LED lights provide a dim, diffused lantern glow or a tightly focused spot light - versatile!- The black ring around the spot light is notched so, if it's placed face down, the spotlight lens won't get (easily) scratched- It's light!  It only weighs 1 lbs, 2 oz.- The hook/handle above the lantern make it easy to hang inside a tent- You can charge this item using a supplied car charger, too!WHAT COULD BE BETTER:- I wish this lantern could be alternately charged using a USB cord, rather than using the hand-crank or 12-volt car charger- I wish you could alternately install some alkaline batteries for additional versatility- Space-saving features are important when camping.  I wish this overall item were designed to be smaller, more space-saving.- The lithium battery isn't (evidently) user-replaceable, which makes disposing this item more difficultA NOTE TO ALL CHINESE MANUFACTURERS:  Please, please, hire an American to proofread your instruction manuals and item packaging.  This item's packaging included the following product features:- "Dark Light-up"- "Farming Usage" - really?  I'm from Illinois, but I have no idea how farming is helped by this item.- "Adopt most capacity lithium battery, light weight.  More time with discharging, longer life time." Okay, good then!- You would also avoid the numerous misspelled words on your product packaging, tooCONCLUSION:  This is a versatile item that would be good where dim lighting is acceptable, such as in emergency situations or where you're working in pitch-black darkness.  The item is thoughtfully designed and it's priced right, too.  Recommended!  (Vendor supplied free item for unbiased product review).
