I fish in the Adirondacks and catch a fair amount of Northern Pike and Large Mouth Bass. These leaders do the trick in keeping pikes from biting through the line when going for a lure. I haven't had a broken line since securing my lures with these leaders and the lure action seems to be virtually the same as when attached directly to the line.

The Vega Sport protein bars are designed for athletes to build muscle tissue after a workout, but they're also a tasty snack while travelling or will keep you going if you miss a meal. The bar is completely plant-based (brown rice, pea, alfalfa, etc.) from non-GMO sources. They're also gluten-free in case you've got a wheat intolerance or allergy. In terms of flavor, the chocolate mint bar is a bit mintier than I expected, but still pleasant. Consistency-wise, it's more chalky than chewy, so I can't say I'm a big fan of the texture. Overall, though, these are tasty bars that do seem to provide an excellent source of lean protein (15 grams), BCAAs (2.5 grams), Glutamine (2 grams) and Omega-3 fatty acids (1 gram).

These make great Walter White/Breaking Bad glasses for Halloween. They're a perfect rectangular aviator shape. I modified mine to remove the two metal pieces on the bridge (with wirecutters and a metal tile to smooth the edges). See pic for details. The first pair I received had a broken lens but Amazon sent a replacement quickly so it all worked out. They can darken a bit in a bright room (I guess this is what they're designed for) but this doesn't hurt the overall look.

These are excellent cord covers. I used three of them end-to-end outside on a driveway to cover a power cord running to a projector and speakers for an outdoor movie night. They laid perfectly flat and stayed in place nicely without any tape. Riding bikes and scooters over them had no effect and they're even rated for light vehicular traffic so they should hold up well.

Not a great app. It's awkward to take pictures (scan) the tickets and even with good lighting it still consistently can't read some numbers. For example, it read the number "67" as "57" on multiple attempts. And attempting to manually fix the number lead to a screen where I could only select a number from 1 to 56 (MegaMillions numbers actually go up to 75). This meant that it was actually impossible to fix the scanned card number. This app is useful for storing numbers and checking winning numbers but for its primary value-add purpose - automatically scanning in numbers to check winners - it's not very good. I found it easier (and faster) to just manually check my tickets for winners.  By the way, in case it helps, I used the app on a Samsung Galaxy Note 3, which does have a pretty good camera.

From the write-up, it seems like this book would be fascinating and exciting, but the reality is the author gets too bogged down in detail for there to be much tension or hold my interest. It took me several weeks to get through the book because I kept falling asleep whenever I picked it up after just a few pages. Another pet peeve: please don't reveal major plot points -- like the death of a famous exhibition flyer -- in the image captions before they've been revealed in the actual text!I do admire the author's thoroughness -- it is certainly well-researched -- but I think some of the minor players in the early days of aviation could have been omitted for the sake of focus on the lead characters: the Wright Brothers and Glenn Curtiss. I will say I had no idea how litigious the Wright brothers were about their patents and it's frustrating to see how they squandered the country's lead in early aviation due to pride and greed.

I wanted to like this rack more but had some serious problems getting it successfully installed on my bike. I removed the two mounting bolts and lubricated them with oil as other reviewers have suggested, then put the mount on my (removed) bike seat post. I tried using all three shims but they did not fit so I went with two. When I was tightening the bolts, the rack just wouldn't get snug so I kept tightening until POP! The metal bolt heads actually both snapped off from the force (the bolts broke in half). I decided to try again with a replacement rack from Amazon. This time I used the two thickest shims of the 3. It felt relatively snug before tightening the bolts. But just when I almost had it secure - POP! - one of the bolt heads snapped off again and went flying across the room.Because I liked the look and overall design of the rack, I decided to pick up a couple of replacement bolts at Home Depot. For anyone who might care to try this, it's a metric 8mm 1.25 thread bolt. I bought the 30 mm length bolt because they had them in stock. A 25mm (maybe even 20 mm) length bolt would also probably have fit. The heads are a little too large to fit into the recessed holes on the mount, but otherwise work fine. They even use the same size Allen wrench as the original bolts.Anyway, with the replacement bolts, the rack seems to be mounted just fine, very secure and the bolt heads did not snap during assembly. I do like the mount once it's secured with better bolts, but really it shouldn't be necessary to pay an extra couple of bucks for hardware just to get it securely mounted.UPDATE (August, 2015). 1 year and a couple of hundred miles later, the rack is holding up well with the replacement bolts from Home Depot. It holds items well and stays firmly in place. It also provides a nice shield against water coming up from puddles or rainy streets. The cord that comes with it isn't great but regular bungee cords work well with this rack.

Excellent basket that is easy to install and also easily removable by simply lifting the basket handles (the mount for the basket stays attached).  I had first thought it would be tricky to install as there was a brake cable in the way of the mount, but the guy at my local bike repair shop showed me how easy the brake cable is to move by simply removing it from one of the brakes and clipping the cable back in once I installed the basket mount to the handlebars. Installation should take less than 5 minutes. Also, the padded Velcro mount and hooks stay secure and don't rattle very much except on big bumps.UPDATE: Having used the basket for a few months, I did want to add one warning. The basket stays secure during most casual bike riding, but if you want to ride fast and particularly if the road gets a bit bumpy (which is common in NYC), you should probably remove the basket. I've now had several occasions where the basket has detached and gone flying off the bike. Fortunately it hasn't led to any dangerous situations or damage to other bikes or vehicles (or people!), but I did want to put this warning in there in case people just think that they can leave the basket attached at all times. The basket is so easy to remove that this doesn't really affect my opinion of it (nor the score). Also, it has held up fine even being thrown onto the pavement multiple times. But be aware that it can come detached when riding over bumps and/or at higher speeds.

Nice bench: solid, nice-looking and comfortable for duets at our console piano with my nine-year-old daughter.  It was also super-easy to assemble. Seems like it will hold up pretty well over time. Recommended.

Great lure. Caught a 22-inch pike and a 16-inch large mouth bass within a few casts with the 4-inch pike lure. My 9-year-old daughter tried a couple of casts and a big pike jumped out of the water while pursuing it (got off the hook but still very exciting for both of us). The lure's got great action: looks like a real fish with the tail wagging back and forth. As others have mentioned though, the tail is a bit thin so the lure may not last long. We went through two in about a week of regular fishing in a lake in the Adirondacks. We tried gluing one of the broken tails back together (luckily had both pieces). The glue held but the action got a little stiffer and the lure got no love after that.I'm ordering more though: 4-inch, 5-inch and also going to try out the Storm perch lure. We sometimes use live perch as bait and the pikes do love to go for those!5 stars for action, 3 stars for durability so 4 stars overall.

We've had bath products cluttering up our shower for years. I hadn't looked into a shower caddy like this before now as we have a jacuzzi-style bath (Bain Ultra air jet tub) and the controls are in the corner where we wanted to put the caddy. But based on the pictures, it looked like this OXO caddy would be close enough to the corner to not interfere with the tub jet controls.  When I unpacked it, this turned out to be true. The support column goes almost all the way into the corner, leaving plenty of space for the jet controls on the tub.Installation took maybe 20 minutes. There are 4 bar sections that screw together. Depending on the height of your shower wall, you may only need two or three of these sections. In addition to these fixed length sections, there is a tension clip on the bottom section that unsnaps to allow you to add additional height and adjust the pole to the exact required height. When you have it adjusted properly, just snap this clip back down to lock it into place (it may take some force to do this).The shelves are very nicely designed with open drain holes to prevent water build up. Some shelves even have round holes the size of your average shampoo bottle top which allows you to store these upside down (which makes it easier to get the shampoo out). The shelves are also completely adjustable in height which allows you to leave room for tall bottles on certain shelves if required. And while they remove easily, the rubberized hook on the back of each shelf holds each shelf securely.So far, it's too early to tell how this holds up to rusting (reviews on this seem to be mixed so far), but I'll update this review over time to note any changes. But so far, so good.

We bought this to replace a utility sink faucet that had broken after only a few years of use. This Delta installed easily using existing hardware with no leaks and decent pressure in the tap. It took a little over an hour and a half for me to disconnect the old faucet, move the sink away from the wall, reattach everything and reinstall the sink. A pro plumber could probably do it faster.  Luckily the compression fittings on the supply hoses we had were still in good shape so I didn't need any new hardware.Installation/removal order is important (and may vary based on your existing hardware). In my case, I already had the flexible supply pipes with compression fittings on each end and our utility sink is light and pretty easy to move so I could easily flip it to remove the old faucet and install the new one. If this hadn't been the case, getting under the sink to remove the old faucet and install the new one would have been really tricky.Here's what I did:1.) turn off the water to the sink2.) disconnect flexible supply hoses from cold/hot water pipes3.) disconnect flexible supply hoses from faucet intake pipes (this may require physically moving the sink to gain access to the bottom)4.) if you need to move the sink, be sure to uninstall the sink drain and separate this from the drain pipe5.) remove old faucet which should be secured to bottom of sink with one or two metal or plastic nuts6.) secure new Delta faucet to sink using two plastic nuts (supplied). Make sure they are tight enough so the faucet does not wiggle7.) attach existing flexible supply hoses to intake pipes on faucet using compression fittings on existing hoses.8.) reinstall sink to drain and secure to wall (assuming your sink is mounted, not free-standing)9.) reattach flexible supply hoses to hot and cold water pipes10.) turn on water supply valves, open the faucet valves and check for leaks.I initially had a leak on one intake pipe (compression fitting wasn't tight enough) and a leak from the drain (had not secured the compression fitting on the drain all the way), but once I sorted that out, everything was peachy.  I attached a hose to the faucet (it comes with a threaded end for this purpose) and was able to wash the car without any problems (right before the rain, natch!).In terms of quality, the Delta seems pretty solid and the valves operate smoothly. The spout is a little wiggly, but I think this is normal. For the price, I'm very happy with the purchase.

After our neighbors came down with a mysterious "flu," we headed down to the bunker and started digging into our stash of Wise MRE meals. The first few weeks weren't too bad. But there's only so much "Savory Stroganoff" or "Creamy A La King" I could take without feeling the need for something to expand the palate. So I ventured outside to explore.I admit, it was pretty bad out there. The stench of rotting garbage, burning buildings and decaying flesh can really spoil your appetite. But I was able to make my way past the burnt-out hulks of smashed up cars and city buses, sidle past a few mutilated corpses and squeeze my way into what was once our local Costco. Inside, amid the bodies and debris, I found an untouched (extra large, of course) bag of Pepperidge Farm Goldfish crackers! Oh, sweet cheddary, crunchy goodness!Unfortunately, on the way out, distracted as I was by my delicious find, one of the "corpses" lurched up and grabbed me, biting out a nice-sized chunk of my bicep. Oh, I managed to escape and found my way back to my bunker, but after a few hours, I got a bit feverish, and lost my taste for food, even the delicious Wise MREs; even those heavenly goldfish crackers. My wife complained that I really shouldn't have left the bunker. So I ate her brains. The kids weren't too happy about that, so I ate their brains too. I feel a little bad about that, but once you've tasted the sweet slimy goodness of warm brains, nothing else matters.By the way, I still have a fair supply of these Wise meals available if you're interested. I've put up a Craig's List post, hoping to lure hungry survivors, but that hasn't worked out so well, what with the power out and no broadband services any more.  If you manage to see this review, then feel free to stop by for dinner.  You can leave your wallet at home. Just bring brains.

We bought these for shipping individual DVDs and Blu-ray Discs and they work great for that: lightweight (about 0.45 ounces each), with a good amount of bubble padding and a good strong sealing strip. Recommended if you need to ship small paperback books, DVDs, CDs or Blu-ray Discs.

From the item title, "100 (50+50) PCS #0~#1 7.25x10 "E-LITE" Kraft Bubble Mailer Padded Shipping Envelopes" I thought I was getting 50 size #0 and 50 size #1 padded envelopes. What I actually received was 100 padded envelopes that are sized between a #0 and a #1 envelope. Actual outer dimensions are about 8.1" x 10" with the flap open, 8.1" x 9" with the flap sealed. Inner dimensions are around 7.25" x 9" when sealed. So no matter how you slice it, the description is ambiguous if not just plain wrong. However, they are still a nice size for mailing larger DVD and Blu-ray sets (which is what I needed them for), so I'm OK with them.When I enquired about it, the seller offered to take them back and issue a refund or credit me 10% and keep them, so that's a decent way to handle this.  But really they need to fix their product listing to be more accurate.In terms of quality, the envelopes seem pretty well made with ample bubble padding and a pretty solid sealing strip. I add a strip of packing tape to the flap for safety, but this is probably not necessary. For those who care (trying to keep the weight of mailings low), the weight of each envelope is around 0.55 to 0.6 ounces.

We got this book when my son was a Tiger Scout and it has proven its worth year after year. My son has won or placed near the top of his pack races almost every year and even took home third in the WEBELOS division in the New York City all-city pinewood derby race in 2013.The book is well-written both for the novice and for the more advanced craftsman. There are basic tips like proper lubrication and sanding techniques, as well as more advanced recommendations such as using a machine lathe on the wheels to make them perfectly round or notching the axles to reduce friction (both of which were a bit outside our skill levels).But be sure to be involved with your scout every step of the way: I made the mistake of handing him the book and saying "pick a pattern" - my boy picked one of the most advanced designs which was extremely tricky to cut and shape using the rudimentary hand tools at our disposal.  I think that particular car ended up being about as much Bondo as it was wood. But it was fast!The author also stresses the importance of letting the scout do as much of the work on the car as possible.  Of course, it doesn't make sense to let a 7-year old boy operate a jig saw without supervision, but let him trace the pattern onto the car, show him how to cut and sand the wood, let him file and sand the axles to make them smooth and get him involved with the final painting and/or stickers that give the car its character. While a strictly parent-made car might win more races, the whole point of the derby is to allow parents and scouts to collaborate and spend quality time together while the scout learns useful skills about woodworking and friendly competition.I'm not sure if the book has been updated since we originally purchased it but the copy we bought a few years ago has definitely served us well in designing and building cool (and fast!) pinewood derby cars.

I'm using this with a couple of Philips slim LED bulbs in a bedroom light fixture and it works very well. There is a nice range of dimming and a great amount of customization for turn-on and turn-off delays. I programmed mine to turn on with a quick fade to bright but turn off with a longer (5 second) fade to dark so I can make it back from the switch to my bed without tripping over anything in the dark. In addition to programming the turn-on and turn-off delays, you can also optimize the dimming range for your specific bulbs.If you want to do any custom programming, you'll need to download the programming guide from the Lutron web site.  Just Google "program Lutron maestro c.l dimmer" to find that. It's pretty straightforward.

This replacement part matched the color, design and size of the original handle which cracked after 10 years of use. This is the "bisque" or beige colored handle, not the light grey or dark grey versions which are different part numbers. It did not have the little black sorbothane "grip strip" which was inside the original handle, and which makes grasping the handle a little more comfortable. But I was able to transfer that over from the broken part to the new one with some Gorilla Glue so now it's pretty much identical to the original. It would have been fine without it, but I'm a bit of a perfectionist.

These are the latest (2014) model of Samsung's entry-level active 3D glasses. They adhere to the Full HD 3D RF glasses standard, adopted in 2012, and are somewhat backward compatible so they work with Samsung 3D TVs back to 2011. They also work well with recent active 3D TVs from Panasonic and others as well as Epson's latest 3D-capable projectors. Since they adhere to the Full HD 3D standard, they will work with many other brands and models as well. I've personally tested them with a Panasonic 2013 model year 3D TV (TC-P60VT60) and an Epson Home Cinema 2000 projector and they worked great with both. They are *not* compatible with any passive 3D TVs, such as those from LG, Vizio and some Panasonic 3D LED/LCD TVs, nor will they work with earlier active 3D sets (or projectors) that used IR (Infrared) 3D glasses. Check your TV or projector to make sure it adheres to the universal RF 3D glasses standard before buying these.Per the packaging, they will work with any Samsung model that includes the following letter codes: D, E, ES, F, FH, H and HU series. So they'd worth with a UN55F8000 (F series, from 2013) but not a UN46C8000 (C series, from 2010). I've uploaded a picture of the box which lists compatible Samsung TV models.As with last year's 3D glasses from Samsung (SSG-5100GB, now discontinued), these are great glasses for the money. They're not perfect, but they work well and are inexpensive. These glasses are very light, provide an acceptable field of view, and create a solid, stable full HD 3D image. As with last year's model, these ones do not fold, which means they take up a bit more shelf space than folding models, but this is a fairly minor gripe. Also, they allow light in on the sides (which is actually nice if you need to walk around at all) but this does make it more important to keep your viewing room fairly dark so the ambient light will not be distracting or impact 3D viewing.Samsung went with a smaller battery this year (CR1620 vs. last year's CR2025). I guess this makes the glasses slightly smaller/lighter but it also reduces the 3D viewing time from a rated 150 hours to 70 hours.  Still, 70 hours of 3D viewing is a very long time (30+ movies), and the SSG-5150GB comes with two batteries (one plus a spare) so it's not worth worrying about. I'd recommend ordering a few extra CR1620 batteries on Amazon and just keep them in a drawer.In terms of getting these glasses up and running, it's pretty simple. Put your TV into 3D mode, hit the power button on the top of the glasses and you're done. On a Samsung TV, you'll see a notification that the pairing is successful. On some other displays (like Panasonic) you may not see any indication on screen even though the pairing is successful. But it should be clear when you look through the glasses if the pairing worked. If you're having trouble, here are the details on how to get up and running.*Detailed Assembly and Pairing Instructions*First make sure your TV is powered up and you've got 3D content on the screen. The best bet is to use a Blu-ray 3D Disc in a Blu-ray 3D player and get to the disc menu. If you like to watch 3D content at home and don't own a Blu-ray 3D player, then get one! But if you don't have one, then you can also put your 3D-capable TV into a 3D-simulation mode. On Samsung and Panasonic TVs, you should see a "3D" button on the remote. Hit this to go from 2D to 3D mode. On other compatible 3D displays, you should see a 3D button on the remote or a menu option to put the TV into 3D mode.If your TV is in 3D mode and you are not wearing glasses, you should see doubled lines on the screen (it will look "fuzzy"). It's easiest to see this with text. Once you're in 3D mode on the TV, then do the following:* Take the 3D glasses out of the box and attach the arms to the bridge. The underside of each arm is hollow so you can tell the top from the bottom easily and can figure out which side each one goes on.* Open the battery compartment by turning the round panel on the inside center of the glasses (on the bridge) counterclockwise. Use a coin or the spare CR1620 battery in the slot to open the battery panel.* Insert the battery into the recessed battery compartment with the "+" side visible and pointing toward you, reinsert and rotate the battery door clockwise to close it.* Remove the protective films from the lenses by pulling up the red and blue tabs on each side of the lenses (these are only to protect the lenses during shipment).* Push the little power/sync button on the top of the bridge of the glasses (it will turn green when it syncs).* Put the glasses on your face and look at the TV screen.If your glasses have paired properly with your TV, you should see depth to the image. The doubled lines will be gone replaced by three dimensional goodness. If you have a Samsung TV or Epson projector, you will see an on-screen indication that the pairing was successful. If you have a Panasonic 3D TV, you will probably not see any on-screen indication (no message or icon) that the pairing was successful, even though the glasses have paired. In any case, if your image now has 3D depth instead of doubled lines, then your pairing was successful and you are ready to watch.Do this once for each pair of glasses, hand them out to your family and/or friends and press play!With Samsung TVs, the glasses should turn themselves off once the TV is turned off or the 3D signal is lost. On other brand TVs, it's probably a good idea to hit the power/sync button one more time at the end of your session to turn the glasses off. The indicator light will turn red then go off.If this works (or doesn't work) for your TV, let me know in the comments. Be sure to specify what brand and model TV you are using.

I purchased a couple of these for use in a ceiling light in our bedroom and have been very impressed. They're as bright as a 60-65 Watt incandescent bulb, but use only one sixth as much electricity. They offer a very low profile due to their slim design. This makes it easy to fit them in most standard fixtures.  Also they dim extremely well and remain stable at low light levels using a Lutron MACL-153M-WH Maestro CFL/LED Digital Dimmer.I have read some reviews that say they buzz on some dimmers but I have noticed no noise at all using the Lutron dimmer which is specifically made for LED and CFL bulbs. Also, the Lutron dimmer itself is programmable so you can max out the dimming range of the bulb.Color temperature is just slightly cooler than an incandescent bulb but much warmer than the stark bluish "daylight" or "bright white" LED bulbs. The light these soft white bulbs provide is bright without being sterile. The price may seem steep - they were $10/bulb but were lowered to $9/bulb - this is much more expensive than incandescent or CFL bulbs.  But it's actually much less expensive than previous generations of Philips bulbs and even cheaper than some of the no-name (and inferior) competition.  And with the energy savings and longer life expectancy, it won't take too long to recover your investment. I'm definitely buying more.

I bought this to mount an Epson PowerLite Home Cinema 2000 Projector to my basement ceiling. For the most part, it worked fine, but it did not have enough height adjustment for me to be able to get a geometrically correct screen image without having to use keystone. And when you use keystone, you lose screen resolution (which is bad).  Ideally, you want to mount any projector so that it creates a rectangular, squared off image without any digital keystone. This assures that all of your pixels are being used to create an image, instead of shifting some of your available resolution outside the active picture area. But I digress...First of all, my mount came with all of the necessary hardware (screws, washers, etc.) and the instructions were pretty clear. The only extra tool I needed was a drill for the ceiling mount holes and a Philips head screwdriver.  The mount comes with two Allen wrenches to adjust the rest. The VideoSecu mount comes with an adjustable extension arm. If you want your projector right up against the ceiling, you can mount it without using the extension arm at all, and this will put the top of your projector 5.5" from the ceiling. For me this was just slightly too high to get a squared off image on my 92-inch screen which is permanently mounted to the wall.So I tried the extension arm, which drops the projector down significantly lower, with a range of around 16.9" to 25.6" and this was slightly too low (I feel like Goldilocks!).  At the least amount of extension (16.9" from ceiling), I was able to square off my projection image using about +7 on the vertical Keystone scale.  This isn't terrible, and did create a nice-looking image for most content, but putting up a 1080p test pattern showed that the view-able image was no longer getting the full 1920x1080 pixel resolution. In actual viewing, this becomes noticeable mostly with text as in movie credits, and a subtle loss of detail on some movie content.The only other issue I had with the mount was due to my projector having three instead of four mounting holes. The mounting interface has four adjustable feet that screw into holes on the bottom of the projector. Most projectors have four holes but the Epson Home Cinema 2000 and 2030 have three holes. The manual that came with the mount suggests that you remove two of the feet and place one of them in a fifth hole that is located between two of the others on the mounting plate. The problem is that the mount I received has no fifth hole - it's simply not there. It is pictured on the VideoSecu web site with a fifth hole, so I'm guessing they may have added this hole to a later version of the mount and I may have gotten old stock. I ended up leaving all four legs on the mount and just used three. Using two of the long feet and one short foot reversed (for the projector's center hole), I was able to get a nice tight mount, pretty close to the projector's center of gravity so it was not pulling in any one direction.It's important to note that this requirement to use Keystone may or may not affect you if you use this or any other projector with the VideoSecu mount.  My issue is due to a couple of things: the screen is already mounted in a fixed location (I can't move it up or down) and the Epson Home Cinema 2000 and 2030 projectors have a fairly unique throw angle. These projectors have 92% of the image above, and 8% of the image below the lens center line.  You reverse these numbers when mounting the projector upside down from a ceiling. On a 92-inch screen, this means the lens must be about 3.5 to 4 inches below the top of the screen in order to get a square image without keystone. If your projector has a different throw angle, or if it has lens shift, or if you have higher ceilings (mine are about 8 feet) or more flexible screen mounting options, then this VideoSecu mount may be a perfect fit.Other than the need to use Keystone in my specific case, the VideoSecu PF12W offers decent adjustability and performance for an excellent price. I was able to adjust the tilt in all directions to hit the screen properly and the projector locks in place pretty well so even the occasional light bump (from my head) does not misalign the image. If it weren't for the need to use keystone to square the image, I would be extremely satisfied with this mount.  As it is, I'm going to try out Epson's own Universal Projector Mount with its optional Adjustable Extension Column to see if that gets me the exact height I need. Based on the specs, I think it will.

First off, if you already own this tablet, and are having a problem getting your device to charge, turn on or power up, see below for a fix. For those considering buying one, here are my thoughts.Samsung makes great Android tablets (for the most part). I've owned a Galaxy Tab 2 and done some testing of other Samsung tablets as well.  They're responsive, offer a pretty straight-forward interface, full access to the Google Play Store (unlike Kindles), front and rear cameras, Bluetooth keyboard *and* Bluetooth mouse support and expandable storage via the microSD slot. This last bit is important if you want to keep local copies of music or movies (e.g., not rely on the Cloud) for mobile media entertainment.Also, the inclusion of an IR (InfraRed) port on the Galaxy Tab 3, and the remote app allows you to turn your tablet into a full-fledged touch screen home theater controller at no additional cost. For a gadget freak, this is pretty cool.  Overall, the fast processor, expandable storage, relatively low price, and wide selection of apps make the Tab 3 an excellent choice for a 7-inch tablet.But my experience with the Galaxy Tab 3 has been marred by a recurrent problem: sometimes the Tab 3 will become unresponsive: it won't charge, nothing lights up, and it won't turn on. This happened to the white Tab 3 I bought my daughter for Christmas after exactly one day of use. It happened again on the Tab 3 that Samsung sent as a replacement (the yellow kids' version) after about a week of use.  The first time, my daughter ran the tablet until the battery was exhausted and the unit shut itself down. After that, it never turned back on again despite multiple charging attempts from the factory charger plugged into the wall, or the factory USB/microUSB cable plugged into a computer.I looked online and found all kinds of suggested fixes: Hold the power button for 10 seconds, 30 seconds or 60 seconds (no joy).  Hold the power button and volume down button (again, nope). Hold the power button, home button and volume up button.  Still, NOPE! Try a trickle charge - plug the Tab 3 into a computer via the USB cable instead of the wall charger hoping that the lower amp charge from the computer would "trickle charge" the battery and fool it into charging. Again (at least for me) - FAIL!  But you are more than welcome to try these approaches as they are pretty simple and completely non-invasive.*HOW TO REALLY FIX THE POWER UP PROBLEM*What did work for me was to disconnect and reconnect the battery, then plug the unit back into its factory wall charger. After less than a minute, I saw the battery icon on the screen, and the unit began charging normally. Hooray! The only bad news about this is that it's not as simple as removing the back of a Galaxy phone. In fact, it's possible that attempting this will void your warranty, so proceed with caution!Getting the back off the Galaxy Tab 3 requires gently prying the edges away from the screen in the little crack between the screen and the case all around the perimeter of the screen. Doing this properly requires a thin plastic pry tool and some patience. I used a small jack knife, but would not recommend it due to the risk of scratches or even shorting out something inside the case. Once you've removed the back of the unit, gently lift the battery connector off its port by prying it toward you. Once it's disconnected, plug it back in by pushing it back down into place. Replace the cover by gently placing the tablet into its shell and pushing along the perimeter, snapping all the tabs back into place.There's an excellent video of this on YouTube by a user called, "JerryRigEverything" - search for "Galaxy Tab 3 Battery Replacement" and you should find it.  The only part you need to watch is the first one minute and 15 seconds to see how the cover comes off and how to separate the battery leads from the motherboard. You don't need to physically remove the battery or remove the screws that hold it in place to detach the battery leads from the motherboard. Once you've put it all back together, plug the tablet into the factory wall charger and USB cable. Within about a minute you should see the battery icon appear and normal charging should begin.Without this "little" issue, I'd rate the Galaxy Tab 3 as a 4-star or 5-star product. But with this major inconvenience, I have to downgrade it to 3 stars.  If it had only happened to one sample, I would have written it off, but seeing it happen to two different samples, and seeing how many other people are saying the exact same thing, I have to think it is endemic to all Tab 3s and it's only a matter of time before it happens to most owners. Let's hope Samsung figures out a software fix for this. Otherwise expect to see a bumper crop of factory-refurbished Tab 3s in the near future.If this helps you get your Tab 3 back up and running (or doesn't!), please let me know in the comments.By the way, in our case, the failures occurred when the app, "Dragon City" was running while the battery died. I know that can be a flaky app so am curious as to whether others who have this problem are also running that app.UPDATE: One more piece of flakiness on the Galaxy Tab 3. My daughter was unable to connect to the internet on her tablet the other day, even though it was successfully connected to WiFi and our router was fine. Upon investigation, we saw that the Tab 3 had reset its date to 1/1/2012. Once we went in and manually updated the date/time to the correct values, the tablet was able to connect to the internet again. No idea what caused this, but it's apparently another common problem with this tablet.

When one of our laptops died, I was reminded just how precarious our precious digital memories can be: digital photos and videos can be wiped out if you're not doing regular backups. Fortunately we were able to salvage the hard drive from the laptop without losing anything. But it was the incentive I needed to install an automated network-based backup system.Since this comes with no hard drive, I combined this unit with the WD Red 3 TB NAS Hard Drive from Western Digital. Assembling the unit was a simple as sliding open the case, connecting the ribbon cable from the DiskStation to the hard drive and securing that with a couple of screws (which were included). Getting the unit up and running took maybe 30 to 45 minutes using the included software CD. I then used the Synology back-up software to create a scheduled (daily) backup task.  I also mapped the drive from my wife's Windows 8 laptop and used it as her backup drive for Windows 8's file versioning/backup system. Seems to be working fine on both machines.The initial back-up of all of my documents and media took the better part of a day (16+ hours), but knowing that all of my photos and videos are safely backed up on the network is a very nice feeling.

We needed to replace a 12-year old Pegasus shower body (from Home Depot) that was leaking and wanted to go with something of higher quality. Looking at the trim options from Hansgrohe, as well as reviews, we decided to go with this German brand. This valve assembly is very solid and works well so far.Our plumber recommended Delta but we couldn't find trim and faucet options that we liked.  When he installed this one from Hansgrohe, he said he's pretty sure that actual cartridge *IS* made by Delta so win, win?What sealed the deal for us was Amazon's pricing which is much lower than the local plumbing supply stores. Time will tell as to whether this holds up better than the Pegasus but I am optimistic.
I used these as replacement bulbs in my kids' nightlights and they work great. They're brighter than the incandescent bulbs they replaced, but for a fraction of the energy usage. Recommended!

On our car (2006 Highlander Hybrid), this inverter isn't completely snug in the cup-holder, but it feels secure enough. At 34 inches, the included cord is long enough to make it to the 12V power port under the center console, but I put it on a 2-foot Y-adapter/extension cable just to keep a standard 12-V port available for my Garmin GPS. With 4 USB ports, and a shared capacity of 2.1 amps, we can connect my phone and my wife's plus the kids' iPod and tablet.  With that many devices connected the charge rate is a bit slow, but for our long drives, it works out OK.UPDATE: After using this a bit more extensively, I feel compelled to update this review and downgrade the score from 4 stars to 2 stars. Energizer says there is a shared capacity of 2.1 amps on the USB ports, but we're not seeing anything near that. When my kids have a tablet and an iPod connected, the charge rate is so slow that it will only actually recharge the battery if the device is turned off. If the kids are actively using their devices, playing movies or games, the best this charger can do is keep the battery capacity flat without going down.  And this is without using that splitter/adapter I mention above.If you want a high charge rate for a phone or tablet, look elsewhere.

This is great as a reading light for my son on his loft bed. The clamp has suction cups on it which made it a bit difficult to open but it makes it that much more secure when closed. Also, for only 3 watts of power consumption the light is plenty bright for reading. Now we don't have to worry about power usage if he leaves the light on at night.
This watch is very elegant but is much larger than we expected.  Too big for a petite wrist. Thanks to Amazon's return policy returning it was a snap.

I've been looking for a decent solar spotlight to illuminate our flag at night. Although this one isn't blindingly bright, it works pretty well, even from about 14 feet away from the flag. I actually spliced in a 100-foot long 14-gauge power cable so I could run the solar panel portion to the back of the house where we have unobstructed southern exposure and this worked fine. I also put a bead of silicon around the edges of the spotlight lens and the solar panel itself after reading some reviews that said some moisture leaked into the spotlight - "an ounce of prevention..."During the winter, with the reduced daylight hours and overcast weather we are only getting a few hours of illumination a night from this light but I'm expecting this to go up during the spring and summer.Update (1/25/14): though this is still winter and days are short, yesterday was a sunny day and when I checked the spotlight this morning, it was still going strong at 5:20 AM.  So this means it lasted over 12 hours. Considering how bright the light is (compared to other solar lights), this is really excellent performance.Update (04/07/15) - 16 months later, still going strong. As expected, the light performs best during the summer and doesn't do well on really dark cloudy days, but most days we still get bright light through the night from this little guy.

We needed a new shower body to replace a leaking old Pegasus shower body from Home Depot. After looking at several brands, we chose Hansgrohe for its elegance, simplicity and strong brand reputation. Along with the new valve/shower body, we picked up a new spout and trim to match.  This spout with diverter looks very nice but also feels solid in its operation.  Simply push in the button to divert the water from spout to shower and turn off the water (and back on) to disable the diverter and reroute the water to the spout. Simple!

As others have stated, this toy does not hold up well.  It made it through one Halloween party but the trigger mechanism inside broke the second time my son played with it.  This made it more difficult to get the rat-atat-tat sound effects out of it, and made it a lot less fun.  Also, it's really small. This makes it less suitable as a gangster costume prop for an adult.If you want a good sized gun for an adult gangster costume, look at the airsoft pellet guns like the Thompson M1A1 Military Multirail Spring Airsoft Rifle or this one: Soft Air Thompson M1A1 AEG Airsoft Rifle Drum Magazine Version, ABS. The "drum magazine" version has that cool round ammo drum like the classic Tommy gun. These are more expensive but have higher resale value too since they are functional pellet guns.  You may even be able to find one used for a lot less.As a Halloween prop for a child, this plastic Tommy gun is OK, but as a toy, it's too flimsy to recommend.

Paired with a nice Fedora and a Tommy gun, this little outfit was a big hit at our Halloween party on my 10-year old son. Size was exactly as described. The "tie" came detached a couple of times (it's held in place with a small bit of velcro), but otherwise this held up well to a party and trick-or-treating.

My kids (8 and 10) *LOVE* these things.  The 12-packs are their favorites as they have a couple of the Trashies visible on the outside but most are hidden inside (which gets the kids excited). They literally tear them open every time they get one to discover what treasures are hiding within.  It's nice to see Amazon actually selling the Trash Packs directly as previously they were only available through marketplace sellers at higher than retail prices. I hope this is a trend and Amazon starts carrying more Trash Packs items.In terms of this specific series (Series 4), my kids do like it, certainly more than the UFT trashies, which are their least favorite. New to Series 4 are the "Mini Trashies" which fit inside a Biter Trashie's mouth. Series 4 12-packs include 2 of these special edition Mini Trashies (usually in the lowest bins in the pack). On rare occasion, the Series 4 12-packs can also include Limited Edition Trashies.  These are numbered Trashies that are highly coveted by collectors (and kids), due to their rarity. Series 4 features one of the rarest Limited Editions ever made: Squish Bone (only 250 made), as well as 4 other Limited Edition Trashies (Festering Fowl, Rotting Rat, Foul Fish Bone and Cruddy Cow Skull).After getting *many* 12-packs, 5 packs and play sets from all five series (six if you include the UFTs), my kids are still hoping to find their first Limited Edition Trashie. Hey, maybe it will be in the series 4 12-pack I just ordered from Amazon? We'll find out on Christmas morning...

I bought this case for my Galaxy S3 when it first came out and absolutely loved it... for a few months. The case protects the phone well and feels nice and grippy in the hands.  The kickstand is excellent for placing the phone at an angle in horizontal or vertical position.  But the case does not hold up well if dropped (even a short distance, like 2 feet) when the kickstand is open.  Tiny little plastic tabs at the top and bottom of the kickstand snap off if the case is dropped with kickstand open.  I had this happen once (dropped 3 feet onto a rug) then again when I purchased a second one (dropped two feet onto oak floor).I know no case is completely idiot proof, but to have two of these fail within a year under fairly normal circumstances was disappointing.  I've reached out to Aduro customer service to see if they can help.  Their warranty link on their web site appears to be broken.  Will update this review if I get a response.UPDATE: Aduro customer service was very responsive and shipped me a new case after sending them proof of purchase (a screen shot of my receipt).  The replacement has been fine so far.  I just need to be careful about not knocking it over when the stand is extended. Upgraded review from 3 to 4 stars.

I purchased 10 of these to replace incandescent and CFL lights in my basement and other parts of the home.  Although I actually ordered the "Daylight White" bulbs, Amazon sent me the "Warm White" ones by mistake.  And I'm glad they did as the Warm White bulbs are definitely less blue-ish than the Daylight ones, and more like incandescent bulbs in color.  The color of the bulb is slightly whiter than incandescent but still pleasant-looking (not too stark), and the brightness seems about comparable with a 50-60 watt incandescent bulb with appreciably less electricity usage.  If the bulbs would last as long as their warranty period (or longer), I'd rate them a 4 or 5 star product.But less than 2 months after purchase, the first of the 10 bulbs has failed. It has only been used a few hours per week and now it simply won't turn on. "Lighting Ever" (the manufacturer) says they have a 3 year warranty on the bulb so I contacted them via their web site, and was told to fill out a form on Amazon for replacement.  I did that and the seller (Neon Mart) sent me a replacement, but it was a Daylight White bulb, not Warm White.  To be fair, Neon Mart sent me an exact replacement bulb for what was ordered, even though it was not what I received. They said they could only send me Daylight White bulbs because that's what appeared on the Amazon order.  So I contacted Amazon and they issued me a full refund for the purchase price of the bulb (gotta love Amazon!).Having one of the bulbs fail so early has me worried. I know it's a fairly small sample size (only 10 bulbs) but now I'm wondering how long the rest will last. The only way a bulb is worth $10 (to me) is if it saves money on electricity, looks good *and* lasts a long time. This bulb has the first two covered, but longevity is now a question mark. I will monitor the other bulbs and will update this review if/when any of the other bulbs fail.By the way, I expect to get some "not helpful" votes from the manufacturer, the seller, or their shills, so please counter these with "helpful" votes if you want this review to stay relevant and featured.UPDATES:(3/25/2014): It has been about a year and another of the original 10 bulbs is now flickering instead of staying lit solid. So that's a 20% failure rate after a year. I have contacted the seller about getting the bulb replaced under warranty and they said that they do not expect to have stock for quite a while so they refunded my purchase price. While this is very good service, I'd prefer to have bulbs that work properly. I have ordered a few of the newer Philips 11-watt A19 LED bulbs, for about $1 more as well as Philips 10.5-watt Slim Style Dimmable A19 LED Light Bulb, Soft White. These are both brighter and are dimmable. I've only had them about 2 weeks, but so far so good.(3/30/14): Poof. There goes another one. 3 out of 10 down (30%) after 13 months. I should note that the fixtures these are in are solid (one is brand new) and we have not seen any issues with our electricity service. And other LED, CFL and incandescent bulbs have not suffered premature failure in our home.

OK, I ordered this 2-pack of Energizer N size batteries on Amazon because it was less than half the price of a comparable item at Radio Shack (and the item ships free). The marketplace supplier I chose was "MyOfficeInnovations." A few days later, UPS showed up at my door with a 12-inch square, 6-inch high box. Inside was the single two-pack of batteries! A bit wasteful, I guess, but also impressive! I can't see how the company can possibly make any money on this, paying for UPS shipping and charging under $3 for two batteries, when other stores sell the battery for twice the cost, but I'm certainly satisfied with the service.As for the product itself, I have no complaints: genuine Energizer Max batteries (or at least they appear to be), with an expiration date of 3-2017. The battery fits and functions perfectly in the small clock I purchased it for.  If it suffers a premature demise I'll be sure to update this review, but for now: so far, so good.

When my iPad charger cable was lost in an office move, I went hunting for a new one on Amazon. The no-name branded cables were cheap but they seemed pretty hit or miss so I went with the iSmooth 30-pin USB cable.  A decent price, free shipping and lots of enthusiastic reviews.  The cable arrived quickly, and is quite well made, making a secure connection on both ends, with rounded edges on the 30-pin end just like the original cable.But inside the packaging were a couple of things that caught my eye: a plea for Amazon reviews on a little insert card and even an offer of a FREE CABLE for those who do choose to write a review.  So here I am, writing a cable review in exchange for another free cable.  "There are no catches or asterisks" the offer says, so even though I'm being completely honest about why I'm writing the review, they still have to send me one.  So now I know why there are so many enthusiastic reviews.But of course, *my* review is completely unbiased. :)UPDATE (June, 2013): free cable received so their "free cable for a review" offer seems legit.

My wife says I have a cable fetish. Fiberoptic digital cables, HDMI cables, component video cables, Lightning/USB cables, 30-pin cables, spools of phone and coax cable. You name it, I've got it. Bins full of the stuff. So I guess I'm a bit of a cable connoisseur. When the data/charging cable included with our Samsung Galaxy Tab 2 went bad from being abused (don't worry, the child responsible has been offered up for adoption), I came to Amazon to buy a replacement (cable, not child). This bulk packaged cable caught my eye, mostly due to the low price and other positive reviews.The cable arrived quickly, packaging was nothing special (you can't judge a book by its cover), but the cable itself is indistinguishable from the original that came with the tablet.  It's soft and pliable, yet at the same time supple and firm.  It forms a snug, secure connection on both the USB and 30-pin end, and works perfectly for charging and for data transfer.  In short, a great cable at a nice price.  Excuse me while I explain to the new children how to properly treat a cable.UPDATE (4/14): one year later, this cable is still going strong (and so are the new children). I should mention that my cable was fulfilled by Amazon from a seller called "HK Seller." If people are getting lower quality knock-offs, this may be due to some third party sellers selling inferior/imitation goods. Be careful who you buy it from!

My kids are getting into their "devices" (Kindle Fire, Samsung Tablet, Nintendo 3DS) in a big way.  But sometimes mommy and daddy aren't interested in hearing "Call Me Maybe" seventeen times in an hour. Thankfully the JVC HAS160V comes in purple, my daughter's second favorite color. It isn't quite as quiet (on the outside) as a pair of earbuds, but I don't particularly like the kids stuffing something in their ears when they're this young. The HAS160V headphones are fairly comfortable, offer nice sound and are inexpensive enough that I don't have to worry if they get lost or stepped on. Satisfying sound for my 7 year old daughter, peace and quiet for her parents. Thanks, JVC!Update: 9 months later, still going strong!

After some negative reviews of the larger AP-300PH I was a little worried that this unit might be loud but it isn't.  Even at its "Turbo" speed, the AP-230PH generates a not-very-annoying white noise background sound that is easy to ignore.  In its "High" mode, the unit is barely audible, but it definitely does its work as the room it's in smells noticeably better after just a couple of days of operation.I bought the AP-230PH as the basement started smelling a little musty (and not a little ripe) after my old high school buddy stopped by for a "short visit."  Two weeks later, with a few too few showers, the basement began to take on his particular musk.  But after a couple of days with the AP-230H, the basement now smells super fresh, even if "Stinky Pete" doesn't.  It's OK, we love him anyway. Thanks, Fellowes!

This a quick and dirty solution to USB port shortage on a Windows or Android tablet. It is essentially an OTG cable, but with two heads instead of one, and a third head that will let you power your accessories - but not the device itself - from an external USB power adapter.So what's an "OTG" cable - essentially it has tricky wiring inside that changes the micro USB power port on Windows and Android tablets into a regular USB port to which you can attach accessories.NOTE: so far as I have found, all Windows tablets will let you turn your micro USB charging port into a regular USB port to attach a keyboard or mouse or both (since this has two active heads) BUT not all Android phones and tablets have this OTG capability, check the details of your phone or tablet first!About the "charger port" for your phone or tablet charger: to repeat, that's to deliver power to your ACCESSORIES, not to your phone or tablet. The tablet or phone port probably doesn't deliver much power to accessories - the port was designed to charge the tablet or phone, not to power some accessory - so it's really important to have this third port to power your keyboard and mouse off your charger. Just don't have a heart attack if you plug your charger in, and the battery keeps running down on your phone or tablet. It's supposed to run down - plugged into this 3 in 1, you are only powering the accessories, NOT the tablet or phone.

This and the Oral B Pulsar are both excellent alternatives to manual brushing and expensive rechargeable, docking electric tooth brushes. They take different approaches - the 3d rotates the bristles, the Pulsar just vibrates them. The 3d is better is your manual brushing technique is a little weak - you just have to move the 3d head around gently. The Pulsar, when fresh, is actually better for dislodging plaque just below the gum line and between teeth - it's a more subtle motion at the tooth. You'll have to - should - try both to see which works best for you. Or, better yet, buy one of each and use one in the morning and one at night - you should allow at least 24 hours between toothbrush use to allow the head to dry out completely to interrupt bacteria growth cycles anyway.

Slows down minor pilfering, much easier to use than a lock. I use it for my overhead and seat side bag on flights, and for shoulder bags with zippers on crowded subways. All you do is link the two halves of a typical zipper, the closer to the base of the zipper tab the better.

Does what it promises, let's you use an Android phone charger on any Apple 30 pin Dock Connector device. NOT for data transfer (i.e., for hooking up to iTunes); just for charging. May or may not limit the power to 5 watts even if you hook up to a 10 watt charger, but 5 watts is generally plenty even for my iPad.

It actually works, for charging only of course, which is conceptually a mind blower for me since an actual Apple Lightning cable has a built-in chip to allow it to work regardless of plug-in orientation. This lets me carry just a micro USB charger on the road. Note that unless they worked some wizardry in their internal connections, this is probably limited to 5 watts even if your Android charger is 10 watts.

Doesn't offer a lot of protection if you drop it - this is a thin, hardshell polycarb snap-on rear cover - but it DOES recess the camera lens a bit to keep my fingers from sliding on it too often, and it DOES have a front raised ridge to keep the screen off night stands and countertops. I WAS SEARCHING FOR THE SLIMMEST, LIGHTEST REAR SHELL, AND THIS IS IT. I had a gummy Belkin on my 5th gen Touch, and wanted something much slimmer, and this is it.Wish they had one without the leash hole - the 6th gen doesn't have a leash attachment point anymore - but no one will ever notice.

This...or the Moto G 2015?Similarity:* Same Snapdragon 410 processor, using the ARM A53 architecture that is replacing the A7 architecture in the venerable Snapdragon 400, in both phones. NOTE: this only applies to the LTE version of the 2nd gen Moto E - the "USA" and "International" 3g versions of the Moto E are still using the Snapdragon 200 which gets slammed by online reviewers as being underpowered and not even as power-thrifty as the new, more efficient, 410 series. The Snapdragon 410 seems to be turning in 10% better performance than the old 400. This isn't due to the Snapdragon 410 being 64bit - which it is - because Motorola is running it in 32bit mode. It's due to better firmware, better chip design.Difference:*$179 for the Moto G direct from Motorola, unlocked and with both AT&T and T-Mobile 3g (actually 3.5g) and LTE bands.*$75 for the Moto E 2nd gen from AT&T, locked to AT&T for six months of active, paid up service. Then you can generally get AT&T to unlock it. Since GoPhone has the same great coverage and speeds as AT&T, my main reason for an unlock would to use it for travel.Similarity:* Generally the same design cues - shape, color - but the E is 4.5" vs. 5.0" for the G, a big difference you will notice right away.* Both can be expanded with 16gb, 32gb, 64gb (may require reformatting) micro SD cards.* Both have single front firing speaker - the E's is hidden in the ear speaker slot, the G's is in a separate grill at the bottom. One online review tested the G at higher speakerphone volumes than the E, but to my ears, the E is louder. Both will play right up to highest indicated volume levels with little to no distortion. Both beat the pants off any rear-firing speaker, if you want to watch YouTube without plugging in earphones.*Both have extraordinarily long active life - like playing a YouTube video in a loop. I tested my E at 8 hours at 85% brightness, the G at 8.5 hours. Online reviewers got in excess of 10 hours with 50% brightness. Standby battery life - in sleep mode - is not nearly as good, nowhere near the outstanding sleep mode endurance of iPhones and Windows Lumia phones.Difference:* 4.5" screen at 600p resolution (approximate) on the E; 5.0" screen with HD resolution, 720p on the G. The G is better as a micro-tablet simply for the HD resolution and ability to see a desktop version of a webpage all at once on the screen without scrolling. On the other hand the E is much cheaper, much more pocketable (and fits into more legacy small phone slots in backpacks and other bags), has the same splendid vibrancy and colors as the G, and works really really well with apps like 3rd party messenger apps like Line, Viber, WhatsApp. RECOMMENDATION: if you spend a LOT of time on FaceBook or Instagram and like larger pictures with dazzling sharpness, you really have to upgrade to the G. If you look for what friends are wearing or doing or whether they are smiling or grimacing - the E is perfectly fine. It's just that pictures you take and pictures you look at won't have that "technicolor impact" until you revisit them on a tablet or computer at home. YES THE TYPE IS PLENTY SHARP FOR READING, it's not like an old-fashioned computer monitor. You can read Kindle without any eyestrain, forever.Similarity:* Both are super fast if you have a good LTE connection (your area isn't swamped with other users). Unlike Cricket, which limits download speeds to 8mBps, GoPhone gives you unthrottled, full speed downloads. (Go figure - both are now AT&T companies.)Difference:* You can get the G in 16gb; the E is limited to 8gb. Fortunately, Android 5.1 lets you move a lot of apps to run on the SD card on either phone.* No prepaid carrier seems to be offering the G in their lineup, just the E. So pricing is much better on the E - you can get prepaid plan discount pricing, instead of paying full retail. For example, currently the unlocked LTE E is $99 from Amazon, while if you buy the GoPhone version it's just $75. During the holidays, I wouldn't be surprised to see AT&T offer additional discounts on the E. NOTE: the bands on the E from AT&T do NOT, according to AT&T's website, include all the bands used by T-Mobile - but the unlocked, $99-$120 version here does. So study up on the bands you need for YOUR carrier before you buy. I like the AT&T configuration better, since the 3.5g HSPA+ bands they DO include are more compatible with the foreign carriers I use when traveling.Finally - this is a solid, compact, modern "candy bar" phone. Motorola has been very good with updating the software, unlike most manufacturers who leave you frozen in time even if Google releases a new version of Android fairly quickly. I love Motorola for that, and for the clean, stock Android interface. You will have about 4gb of app space free when you boot up; I quickly used a gig of that on a minimal app install list. No Google apps will move to the SD card; I'm hoping more of the 3rd party apps will. But keep in mind this is budget phone, aimed at teenagers hanging out on FB, Snapchat, and Line (or similar 3rd party message app).

I bought this for my wife since she doesn't like to take the time to put in earphones. She watches foreign television, streaming, on her iPad Mini. I thought the foreign soundtrack was low quality, but actually the built-in speaker in the iPad Mini just isn't that good for quality extended listening. This is much better, plus it is so compact it is easy to find a place to put it.Don't underestimate the importance of the Bluetooth which means no speaker cord required. When I tried to get her remote speakers in the past, the speaker cords bothered her a lot, getting in the way. Bluetooth solves that problem neatly.Pairing is a cinch. You can't do it on the iPad Mini from the swipe up menu. You have to go into Settings, Bluetooth, then look for the Amazon device to pop up. Once it pops up, you just tap on it and you are done.One cool feature I didn't know about Bluetooth speakers: you adjust the volume on the iPad, you don't have to reach for the speaker.My wife is forgetful about turning stuff off. Since the battery is rechargeable, that's not a problem. It charges off an Android or Windows phone charging cable (standard micro USB).

Perfect fit, no "flashing" (untrimmed material from mold) along any edge, cut-outs perfect.This is TPU - cases for phones come in 3 basic material types:1. Hard brittle plastic. The thinnest, mostly useful for keeping fingers off the camera lens, and for providing a "lip" around the screen so the screen won't contact the surface of an end-table or other flat surface. Not much phone protection, except for eliminating scratches on the back. Great if you don't drop and want the slimmest, lightest case.2. "Gummy" or "soft silicone" cases - the thickest of the three, often wrap over the screen front more, because otherwise they can deform from normal hand pressures and slip off a corner. I put one of these on my 8 y.o.'s iPad - much too fat and heavy for me, but essential for some users. I have one on my 2009 iPod Touch, but I don't see these for phones any more - too fat.3. THIS ONE - thermoplastic polyurethane or TPU, which is the in-between style - thicker than hard plastic, much softer; not as thick or as soft as gummy. It's probably the most common type. The best material for cellphones, because there is a lot of protection, but very little added bulk and weight.The Cimo is half-frosted, half clear on the back. As a nice touch, there are some "dotted" surface areas along the edges to improve grip. The buttons all operate easily under the cover - the volume rocker and on-off are covered, which prevents dust from entering.If they had black when I got my Lumia 640 - it was a pre-public roll-out at Walmart for $79 locked to GoPhone (AT&T's prepaid division) - I would have gotten one of those instead, since my case is black anyway. You may prefer translucent/clear, if you have one of the brightly covered cases. I see they have black now! :-(BTW, the 640 is great!I ordered mine from CIMO Technologies, the importer and/or manufacturer. Amazon didn't stock and ship this directly when I ordered, but that worked out best for me since I dropped out of Prime ($99?) and CIMO shipped right away by Post Office. Unlike some Asian marketplace sellers, this was stocked in, and shipped from, a USA location - it got here in only a couple of days. Now that Amazon has taken over fulfilment, Prime members can get this in 2 days with no minimum purchase.

I purchased this simply because it was on sale for $79 - you can't beat that, based on the good specs, right? In this case, the build and operating quality exceed expectations, and match that of $300 phones (and $300 phones from Huawei, Alcatel, ZTE are pretty darn good these days).Some set-up notes to help you:1. Make sure you have your old phone backed up - Android and Apple phones back up automatically. If you have photos and videos set to auto-back up on your old Android phone, they will be there for you when you log into your new phone. I wouldn't factory reset your old Android phone right away, though, just in case. If you are coming from an older iPhone, things get a little trickier. Apple iCloud isn't available on an Android or Windows phone, so you need to make sure your pictures and videos are backed up to an alternate service - Dropbox, Box, Microsoft OneDrive, Flickr or the best yet, Google+. Telling you how to do that is beyond the scope of this article, so research it online or enlist a friend's help (it can be as simple as downloading the app, signing in, telling it to upload, and being patient). Once again, don't reset your iPhone until you feel comfortable.2. You need a Gmail account to sign in onto the phone. You probably already have one, otherwise you can sign up on the phone itself.3. You need to put a SIM in. Probably in SIM slot one - read the tiny manual in the box. I'm presently trying this out in tablet mode, so I don't have the answer on the tip of my tongue. But one thing for sure - on most dual SIM phones, only one SIM can use high speed data, so it DOES make a difference. (The other SIM will probably use slower 2G data.)4. I don't recommend backing up from your old Android phone's online Google backup. It may take a little extra time to remember and manually install your favorite apps, but it's a cleaner way to install, never hangs the phone (I've had some phones just stall out), and is like spring cleaning - you'll find some apps you never use, just hogging up space.5. This is a pretty stock Android user interface, thankfully, with practically no bloatware programs. That's welcome in terms of housekeeping, and essential in terms of making the most of your 8gb of storage. I had about 5gb before downloading my apps and 4gb after, no SD card installed yet (I have a card on order from Amazon now).6. If you are going to install a micro SD card, there are good deals on Amazon, with Samsung and Sandisk very popular. 32gb goes for about $16 and 64gb goes for about $32. Class 10 UH1 at a minimum is best, and no biggie in terms of premium. Amazon's own stock - not marketplace - is the most reliable. Install the micro SD FIRST before booting up, and before you download any programs, go into Settings- Storage-Install Apps to SD card and select that option; if you don't, you can't move programs to the SD card later, without re-formatting the SD card AND factor re-setting your phone OR uninstalling then reinstalling the app. You want to use the SD card for apps and storage as much as possible to reserve on-board storage for the many programs that won't install to the SD card.7. For some strange reason, the stock keyboard is AOSP (Android Open Source stock keyboard) but I downloaded the Google Keyboard, which has swipe text entry as an option, from the Play Store. Unfortunately it kept crashing on me, ymmv, but be forewarned. Fleksy worked fine.8. To get rid of vibrate on keypress, you need to toggle options in TWO places: the keyboard settings for your default keyboard, found under "Language & Input", and the sound settings, of all places, under "Audio profiles". Root around in those two categories and you can un-check the appropriate boxes.9. While you are in "Sound," un-check the box for enhancing the speaker sound; all this does on mine is make the speaker crackle at a middle volume level - with the box un-checked, it sounds like most other speakers in smartphones. It isn't a weak speaker, btw, at least not on my sample.10. In the "Display" setting category, turn off "screen adjust mode", because this has a nearly 3000 mAh battery and you shouldn't be sacrificing ANY screen quality to eke out a little more battery life. On the other hand, I left "ClearMotion" turned on, this is a "Video fluency enhancer" whatever that means, but if I end up finding the video a little weird, I'll turn it off. (This is non-standard function, btw.)11. Go into the "Battery" setting category and un-check the "CPU power saving mode" which throttles your octa core performance to "conserve battery life and lower device temperature." If you don't like your resulting battery life, you can turn it back on later. Please note that I turned this feature off, but when I came back to write this review, it had turned itself back on, so keep an eye on this setting.General comments:Phone box included good looking, white earbuds (no soft silicone tips) that remind me of the first Apple earbuds.Phone box also included a translucent, thin, medium soft (not gummy) silicone case with perfect fit, perfect cut-outs, easy to operate volume and on-off covered sections; a spare screen protector (there is also one pre-installed, perfectly, no bubbles); a 5 watt, super narrow (narrower than Apple or Samsung cube) charge; and a white, medium short, USB cable.I got about 27,000 on one Antutu test run and 28,000 on another.The translucency of the included case is just right so you can see the phone color but the BLU logo is subdued.The phone is super narrow for a 5.5" screen, the side bezels are super narrow. BUT, there is a lot of bezel on top and bottom. Net result, the phone probably couldn't be any narrower, and the slim case doesn't add much to that, but it is much taller than it needs to be.The attached screen protector is clear, smooth, and doesn't seem to affect screen color or viewing quality. Since I distrust these things, though, I removed it after giving the phone an initial workout. Turns out glass underneath is pretty grabby, the grabbiest ever with an Amazon screen stylus. You won't notice this if you use fingertips, like most people. BUT if you like to use a stylus, try for a while before removing the screen protector. Since the glass doesn't appear to be oleophobic (oil hence fingerprint resistant) expect to clean the screen more often than with some phones.Since I haven't dropped a SIM in yet, I can't speak to cellular call quality, but I tried Skype and Google Hangout calls in both regular and speakerphone modes and everything sounded great.Rear cover of phone snaps on perfectly with no mismatched cover-to-body spots.Screen seems of good quality, but give me a couple of weeks and I'll update.My initial reaction is that this is a carefully designed, well-thought out, well-built phone. BLU did a superb job here.

Caution: made to look like the more expensive Samsung 64gb EVO card in terms of colors and design. It only leaves off the Samsung name. Proceed with caution! Amazon's listing gives it prominence in the listings, and for a moment even I thought it was a Samsung.

Get this one, NOT the "newer model" in 24", the "newer" model isn't 100% sRGB capable PLUS factory calibrated (most factories skip individual calibration to match minor variations in electronice and screens). This is the model I am reviewing: VX2370SMH-LED 23-Inch.4 years ago I bought one of the early consumer-grade Viewsonic IPS monitors, the VP2365WB 23-Inch, and it couldn't hold a candle to this VX2370SMH. I got rid of it and replaced it with an LG.And the LG can't hold a candle to this VX2370SMH! I kept reverting to my iPad for quality video watching before getting this Viewsonic. Now, in a dark room, this Viewsonic is ALMOST but not quite as good my my iPad 4 - which is a huge step in the right direction, given the $149 cost of this 23" IPS, 100% sRGB, factory calibrated monitor. The only better option would be an iMac - Apple puts fantastic screens on those puppies. But trust me, this Viewsonic is the much more "pocket book friendly" alternative. I am running mine, ironically, off a Mac Mini, but of course you can turn this monitor off a Chromebox of Windows computer as well - or even off a tablet if you have an HDMI output.Now for some minor pluses and minuses:+ I like the tilting feature. If I am seated on my Swiss ball, I'm eye-level and the monitor is straight up and down. If I (somewhat precariously) kneel on the Swiss ball, that puts my eyes way above the monitor, but compared to the LG I can tilt the monitor back just like a laptop screen for a more uniform distance-to-eyes at both the top AND the bottom.- I HATE the on-off switch button location on the pedestal...at the pedestal TOP, almost buried - I take that back, ACTUALLY buried - under the bottom edge of the screen.- I wish this had a SECOND HDMI port. In terms of VGA and DVI, it's generous, it comes with those ports, but HDMI is so convenient these days, I wish I had a second port so I could switch to another device without unhooking a cable.+ I "downsized", very knowingly and deliberately, from a 27" monitor to this 23". The RIGHT SIZE is dependent on your sitting distance from the screen, if you are using the monitor for full-screen video watching, which I do a lot. I could have probably gotten by with a 21". The 27" was overkill, like sitting in one of the front rows at a movie theater.I don't know how long this monitor will be available. The so-called replacement has one nice new feature - flicker-free backlight adjustment by using an analog power source for the LED's instead of "digitial pulse modulation" which essentially means turning the LED's on and off at a rapid rate at the same power to raise or lower illumination. In any case, if you find your way over to the Viewsonic web page to look for different models and sizes, this is the "magic text" you should look for, QUOTE: "sRGB Color Correction Technology Delivers the Most Accurate Color Performance Available ViewSonic LED monitors embedded sRGB color correction technology reproduce 100% sRGB rich color for color performance matching original input sources without decreasing or leveraging color quality. sRGB ensures all displayed images/videos are as natural as the original sources, displaying real color for captured camera and camcorder content."

Not as good as your fingertip. On the other hand, never greasy, never smudges.So I make a simple compromise:1. If I am watching videos, I use this to keep the screen pristine. The stylus is more than accurate enough in that setting.2. If I am browsing content, I use my fingertip and just pay the piper and Windex the screen once in a while.So - what are the stylus-related problems I face? Believe it or not, accuracy ISN'T one of them! But "missed taps" are, and when scrolling content which is a mix of active (touch to activate) and passive content, I get too many unintended activations - windows popping up! - that I don't get with ordinary "finger tip" control.I regret getting this Amazon version with the "finger loop" on the end I'll have to remove the loop and find another use for it. Think twice about whether you want this zipper-pull version, I got it because it was the only black one, but if I could do it over, I'd get the one with the pocket clip.If the "rubber tip" on this gets oily over time, use some rubbing alcohol (maybe some fingernail polish remover, but it might dissolve the tip) or other degreaser to gently remove the oil or grease.One thing I learned for sure - once you start using a stylus, you'll keep using it, the screens stay a lot cleaner (this works on ANY modern finger tip sensitive touch screen, just not on the old plastic Palm Pilot "pressure type" screens).

Note: The scallops on the serrated side of this Mini Pal blade face up, if you are right handed and use this to whittle a pencil tip.This means the flat side is "down" for greater control in whittling - Emerson places his serrations on his chisel-ground combat knives on the opposite side, and if I try to whittle with an Emerson, it "bites" too deep and unpredictably.Curiously enough, the Mini Pal's "slightly bigger brother," the Urban Pal (1.5") are also on the "Emerson-side." You can see the difference in the pictures I will attach.I prefer the 1.5" blade length of the Urban Pal over the 1" length of this Mini Pal - the Urban Pal is closer to the minimum usable blade length of micro-pocket knifes like the classic Spydero Lady Bug or the Cold Steel Micro Recon.HOWEVER, the pictures will show that the Urban Pal is probably just too large for a key ring, while the Mini Pal is much more conveniently sized.Note that this new generation Mini Pal has a purely "friction" sheath, compared with the last generation which had a snap lock (released with a squeeze on the side lever). The sheath is nice and snug, however, so don't fear accidental slippage (caution: make sure the blade tip is actually IN the mouth of the sheath while putting it back in, or grip the top ridge of the sheath, so you don't poke yourself if you make a mistake - this actually applies to returning any blade to its sheath or scabbard).Also note that there is no way to tell by "feel" whether the blade will be "up" or "down" when you pull it out.
