But still I don't get the "fishy" flavor that a couple have mentioned.This product doesn't absorb a lot of moisture and clump like some other products do.  But that said, I recommend keeping the product contained in it's mylar package until you are ready to use it, and then dumping that into a quart canning jar to keep the oxygen out and the nutrition in.

I've used blood meal before, so I know what it can do for crops.  But the animal repellent aspect was new to me and quite a nice bonus.This is largely what I use as an organic fertilizer component for my green crops such as spinach, swiss chard, kale, and my herbs.  It's fantastic but you have to watch how much you put on.  I haven't ever had any burn issues, but you can over fertilize and have things grow faster than they should.  Just top dress the crop before a rain and let nature take it's path.The upside of course is that the deer and raccoons that have been pestering my garden are now warded off.  I could live trap the coons and try to fence out the deer, but not always with great success, and certainly with quite a bit of time and energy.  So far this year and to the best of my knowledge, I haven't lost any crops to the woodsy friends.  The coons stayed away from the root crops and the deer left the spinach alone.  These were the two crops that were the most seductive.  My neighbor still has problems and I still see them around, but they just aren't hitting my garden this year.

I used to be in the business and have installed hundreds of these on pumps where the motor has failed and the cost of repair was not justified by age.  When installed properly, they are a solid motor and will last on average 6-7 years of constant summer use before anything needs to be done.  And when it does need something it is usually to replace the capacitor on the back end, something that a teenager could do with a screwdriver and a pair of needle nose pliers.  The capacitor is basically the starter battery and they wear out.Also be sure to keep the area under the motor clear of leaves, debris, and dirt.  These are motor killers because they end up going up through the vents and onto the windings [copper wire coils] and the motor can't vent properly.  Even getting 10-15 degrees over normal operating temp will wear out a motor faster.When installing these, it's not tricky but you need to know two things about doing so if you want the motor to work properly and last:1)  Install a replacement shaft seal and do the whole thing, not just half of it.  They are cheap and there's no reason not to.  It will take you two minutes.  Old seals fail and when that happens, the motor will be subject to spray coming from the pump end of it.2)  When tightening the mount bolts, don't crank down one and then move onto the next and crank that one down.  Tighten all 4 fairly evenly, moving around the motor to tighten each one another couple of turns and keep going until they are all tight - - but only hand tight.  There's no reason to strip them out.  If you don't tighten the bolts evenly, the motor will sit in at a very slight angle, and this causes tremendous wear on the motor.  If you install them evenly, you will have years of service from the motor.

When receiving this pan, there are a couple of steps that aren't immediately made known, and these are very important to follow before making your first paella. Of course everyone will remove the sticker and most will wash the pan. BUT.... be sure to wash this pan with extremely hot water and lots of soap, making sure to flood the pan and wash it with a stiff cloth or a 3M cleaning pad, inside and out. There is a factory film on there that is easily removed and should be, but it takes more than a quick rinse out. I think it's part of the production process or something to help protect the pan till it gets to you. It's not going to make you sick, but just doesn't need to be in your food.Of course be sure to dry the pan immediately, preferably with a little heat to remove all traces of moisture before the next step. After the pan is dry, use a paper towel and rub a very light coat of shortening on the pan while it is still warm. I use Crisco. Then with a dry towel, wipe every bit of shortening residue off it. A slight film will remain. Do this inside and out to make sure it is well seasoned and protected from elements, and be sure to do this every time you use the pan for the next 5-10 times you use it. By then it will have started to build seasoning on it and you won't have to do it as often. However, I still put a little on my pan from time to time, and particularly if you know you aren't going to use it for awhile.This pan is pretty heavy duty and will hold up for my lifetime and more so long as you aren't throwing it around or bang it up too badly. Treat it with respect and it will serve you well for a long time. There are dimples in the bottom of this pan, and this is pretty typical of most top quality paella pans. I have never researched it in depth, but I have heard from several sources that it helps create the socarrat. â€œSocarratâ€ is that delectable, scrumptious crust that forms at the bottom of the paella pan when the fat is rendered, the liquid absorbed, and the rice has reached its peak.This pan is highly recommended for beginners and paella experts.

I purchased the #3 size for my 6 yr old grandson who has been playing with but overwhelmed by the size of his dad's soccer ball.  Size three is perfect for little feet to allow them to learn the fundamentals of ball control and moving downfield.  Unlike with the large ball, little feet can also find the thrill of a little air time with this size.The colors are great and the kids love it.  Despite having several other soccer balls on the field, day after day, the Adidas ball is the favorite.  There are several other complaints of wear, but a month after starting to use it daily, this ball still looks like it is fresh out of the package.  The stitching on it is fine, the material seems pretty heavy duty, and overall, I don't think they could have made a better ball.The one thing I would suggest to the manufacturer is that they don't fully inflate the ball prior to shipment.  We had to let a little air out to bring it down to ideal pressure, and that potentially could affect the bladder and longevity of the ball in higher altitudes or if it has been shipped by air.

I've had this product out for several trips now and am quite happy with my decision to purchase.  The bladder holds a full 70 oz and there are several other pockets to make this far more than just an insulated water bladder with a shoulder strap.  The design was well thought out with keeping the bladder off your hot skin but also protected from the elements, to help keep it as cool and refreshing as possible.Comfort padding, straps and buckles are well placed and designed to breathe, yet stay cinched and working in sync with your own movements without binding.  Any pack that doesn't do this moves on it's own and can shift weight at the wrong moment, stop you from moving as necessary, or just slip and slide around and add wear and tear to your day.Pockets and access points are well thought out and designed to allow you and others access to every portion of the pack quickly and without having to disassemble anything, as well as to allow you options in how you pack and what you carry.  Though this is not an expensive unit by any stretch, I've seen far more costly units that haven't been as well thought out.That said, be aware that you are buying a water bladder and it needs to be conditioned before you use it.  Don't plan to pull this out of the closet the in the morning and just heading out.  Putting it bluntly, water going in will taste absolutely horrible the first few times you use it, kind of like you are chewing on a tire.  And it isn't as simple as rinsing it out either.  This is vinyl and it will give off flavors for awhile.I pulled it out a week ahead of time and am glad I did.  Just take the bladder out to make it easier to condition, and don't forget about the hose either.  The whole thing needs some advance planning.  What I did was to first rinse it out a few times just to get anything out that might easily just rinse.  Then I filled it with about 100 degree water and let it sit for an hour, dumped it and did that again several times.  Already it was getting much better.  The next steps were to let it sit full of water overnight a couple of times, dump it and fill it again before going to work.  That way it would have a chance to leach out any flavors out of the vinyl into the water.  My final step was to add a couple of tablespoons of baking soda to water and fill it up.  Baking soda helps to remove odors and flavors elsewhere, so it makes sense that it might help here as well.The results were that the first trip out there was a slight flavor and odor, but nothing that would be noticed if you weren't looking for it.  By the time I hit the Appalachian Trail, I couldn't come up with any trace odors or flavors.  Problems solved, and nothing more than what I've experienced with other water bladders by other names.Also make sure that you are drying this thing completely out before putting it away.  Dampness can lend itself to formation of mildews and you just don't need these in your bag.  I solved this issue by pushing a few paper towels into it and massaging them around to absorb those  few remaining drops, then leaving a dry paper towel bunched inside to keep the bag separated while I laid it in the sun and let it vent any moisture out.  This isn't a big issue if you're going to be using it again in a couple of days, particularly if you fill it with chlorinated tap water.  But if you're only using it on weekends or longer, it's better to be safe than sorry.

This is now on my subscribe and save list.  It is so delicious!  However, I'm not particularly wild about the bags it comes it and so I immediately dump it into an air tight canning jar to keep it fresh longer.Keep in mind that wild rice takes a longer time to cook than most white rice and even longer than some brown rice.  However, it can also be a hard thing to eat straight.  If you are just trying wild rice, it is recommended that you use it in combination with other rices, cooked separately, and then added to your final rice dish.  But you will LOVE the nutty flavor and texture it imparts to other dishes.  It also makes an interesting addition to a mushroom risotto.I've also found that cooking this in chicken broth is a phenomenal treat that is worth trying.  It softens the rice slightly and brings in another flavor that complements the rice.

I believe this is essentially an extremely fine ground maple sugar.  But it really delivers and gives an intense maple flavor without the graininess of sugar crystals.  I tend to look at this as a "finish" rather than an ingredient, because it's best value is found in adding flavor and aroma to the outside when it would be lost by mixing into whatever you are cooking.So far I've used this on smoked porks such as shoulders, ham, ribs, and bacon.  But I've also used in several baked goods, the most interesting of which was a "bacon cake".The one caveat on this is to keep it dry, as like with most powders, it will absorb moisture, and then of course you've lost the purpose in having a syrup "powder".  All is not lost however, as several others have noted, it can be reconstituted into maple syrup, and actually serves as a great item to take on camping trips for just that purpose.

So our watch lasted a bit longer than most, but it was still a disappointment.  The people at Marvel Comics should probably look into the licenses they grant and the quality of the merchandise it is applied to.  Seriously, this does not reflect well on their brands and their royalty of maybe a buck or two at best isn't worth what it does to the impressions a kid has of the superhero when the excitement over the watch turns into disappointment when it fails.

The cherry flavor on this is pretty intense and it has become one of my favorite things in the spice cupboard for use on pork.  I've tried a bit on some veggies as well but haven't been able to make that same connection, but it certainly isn't going to take away anything from the really good experience.The other way I've found that this really works well is as an application to buttered Texas toast right before it goes into the broiler.  Oh, that is amazing!  Fats like pork and butter just seem to melt into this rub and take it from 5 stars to the moon.  Try it at your own risk, as you potentially can get hooked on it and then have an expensive obsession.

The first thing you need to realize is that there are two options on this mouse pad.  You must choose between the foam backing and the self adhesive strip.  If you don't, it will default to the self-adhesive version.These are thin and I'm not a fan of the texture.  It takes some getting used to.  The self adhesive does adequately stick to the surface, but my concern is how well it comes off when that time comes.  I'm hoping it doesn't turn into a gluey mess, but since I'm not ready to make that happen yet just for the sake of a review, we shall let that idea remain a mystery for the time being.  The one thing that is nice about this particular pad is that it is thin enough that if you put it on a slide out desk shelf like mine, it won't hinder the ability to slide it back in.  It is about as thin as a cheap paper plate, and hardly worth being called a "pad", and the texture is about like that of a shower curtain.I have had the thing applied to my desk now for about a year now and there is no visible wear to it.  However, in running my hand over it, the texture found at the edges is no longer to be found in the middle where the mouse is most used.  So despite appearances to the contrary, it does have a lifespan of maybe a couple of years tops.

I love this mold for making chocolate bombes.  I picked up one for my grandson's birthday party and the first go around was slow and tedious, but that was a matter of developing a technique.  From there on, it has gone fantastic. The key here is to learn to use a pastry brush and not really care that much about perfection.  The mold will take care of the outside, and that's the only part that anyone else will see.  If you're having a hard time getting full coverage or you have holes, just pop the mold into the fridge for a few minutes and let it harden up, and then paint over the hole.Leave enough of a lip so that when you extract the units and fuse them together, there's enough of an edge to do this with.  My first mistake was accepting a feather edge when in fact this is the part you need the most coverage.When you are ready to put the parts together, use the bottom of a slightly warmed pan to melt one edge and make it even.  Insert your ingredients in this half, then melt the edge of the second one and fuse them together.  Don't spend any time trying to clean up the edge.  It doesn't work and doesn't matter.  Just have fun and enjoy the results

I've now got two sous vide cookers including this one and a Polyscience Pro version, and have been using both for well over a year now.If you're reading this far, you already know the process and about the excellent end product.  What I'm here to tell you is that the product will last and has a good service record.  Having used the Anova now for well over a year and usually 2-3 times per week, often for 24-48 hours at a time, I don't have a single complaint.  It hasn't done so much as a hiccup or failed in any way.  And aside from some digital things and a slightly lower water volume limit, I haven't found much difference in service between this and the Polyscience at about 5 times the price.Now I do know that Anova has come out with a couple of new models between this version, but I don't see many advantages, and certainly nothing to spend an extra $100 to have.  Hopefully they will see a few comments like these and realize that there are many of us out here who love the older system, just want to cook with it, and bring the thing back as a cheaper alternative.  Puleeeeeaze!

I've been eating maca now for about 3 years and have tried a variety of packagers and products during that time.  Overall, I go through about one package per month, consumed almost entirely in Vitamix smoothies and as an additive to Greek yogurt.As with all the products from Maca Team, I've found this product to be top shelf stuff and worth continued buying.  It is always fresh, very well packaged, well ground, and it is well flavored.  I've well tolerated every produce I've received from them and that includes this one, their Yellow Maca.As for how it has affected my health, since adding it to the diet my overall energy level has improved dramatically.  There have been a few times that I've gone extended periods of time without and I noticed far more lethargy no matter what I did.  Getting back on maca provided a better sense of well-being and health and a stronger and more lively libido.I won't lie and say that I don't wish it was cheaper, but you're going to pay for what works, and it is more than a fair price for the product and compared to what else is out there.  I've come to trust this company to provide good products, and they haven't let me down yet.

I really love this seasoning, but at $40/ 2 pk, it isn't affordable.  Go directly to Trader Joes and get the stuff for about $4 a bottle.  I'm so glad they brought it back to the shelf at TJ.I simply can't describe the flavor other than smokey, but I know several people from South Africa who swears it reminds them of home.  Butter and just a tad of salt bring the flavor forward in a huge way, and it is phenomenal on a piece of sourdough or on those chewy torta rolls from Costco.

If politics,intrigue,and skullduggery is your fort,this novel will meet your expectations from the first page to the end. International politics,particularly when the CIA and Unions get involved is sure to provide lots of secrecy,people getting disposed of,anytime they foul up the government plans,because they are always less important than the mission.Don't look for characters that you would like to befriend,because this business does not attract that type.When any group sets out to overthrow a government,you need to enlist evil minded,egotistical,dishonest,people . This novel can be looked at as fiction or non-fiction but with the names changed;changed,that is to protect ,not the innocent ,but the guilty. As you read this novel,you may want to compare it to the Mafia and the Underworld;and wonder why anyone would get involved in it if they didn't expect to be killed,double-crossed or hung out to dry,when their usefulness becomes a liability. It is a well constructed story with several well developed,though not particularly likeable ,characters.There is some violent action,but that is somewhat minimal,as most of the novel deals wiht clandestine manoeuvering behind the scenes. There are a lot of organizations mentioned throughout and often referred to by their initials such as CIA,AFlL,ClU,CIT,CTAL,OWS,COO,UCV,UCAB ,CUT,NED,etc. so you might wish to keep a legend of them to keep them straight.Also,there are many individuals coming and going ;and since there is no list of characters included,you may also want to make your own. Overall,a great read and would be quite informative to anyone who wants to know what life is like in the international world of clandestine operations.

We all tend to think of the team of Simon and Garfunkel and what is probably their best known and loved song "Bridge Over Troubled Waters" I had moved my family to New Jersey in January of 1970 and that song never stopped playing on the radio that year.Yes,those born in the 80's and later can't remember that was where most got their music.It was just  the era when pop music and ballads were what music was all about..Paul Simon and Art Garfunkel broke up at the height of their success in 1970.Rock 'n Roll was also big and Rock was just starting to take over,especially for the young.Today the music of artists such as Simon and Garfunkel simply isn't being published any more,nor has it been for several decades. This is a wonderful collection of Paul Simon's music from his earlier days Although he became an accomplished Singer, he was also an accomplished Songwriter( "Bridge Over Troubled Waters");though all the songs on this album were written by others.Paul Simons was born in Newark N,J. on October 13,1941.He started his career in 1957 at the age of 16 and continues active to today at the age  of 74.He performed songs of Folk,Rock and Pop,and sang ,wrote songs and played Guitar;both alone and with his friend Art Garfinkle. The tracks are listed here,on the album and by other reviewers. This Stereo ,Vinyl,LP was released by Kapp Records (KS 3550) in 1977.Paul was 36 at the time.The sound quality is excellent and the tracks are also excellent and songs that you will only be able to hear from recordings. The album cover is more than excellent.It is a fold- out ablum with a pensive portrait of the youthful Paul on the front cover and a relaxed shot ,more like a snapshot,wearing jeans ,a vest and open shirt collar ,on the back. However; what is really special is that when you open the album cover;you are presented with the complete lyrics to all the tracks.As the tracks were not all recorded at the time of the album's release;the recorded dates and musicians involved are all there. Having all the lyrics ,is really nice,as most of the tracks are not familiar,particularly to me.

There are two kinds of "standards" in popular music.There are the great evergreen songs that began to pour out of Tin Pan Alley,Broadway and Hollywood beginning roughly in the  20's and continued through the 30',40's and the 50's.At that point,new exciting teen-age rythms seemed to take over,and the flow of enduring ballads slowed to a trickle.Then,in the 60's,with rock 'n' roll,the twist , assorted rhythm,blues and dance style continued to hit at the same pace,there began to appear on best-seller charts a number of sentimental ballads that had all the earmarks of standards...songs which would survive beyond the all-too- few months of bestsellerdom.Then along acme Rock ,Reggie ,etc,but if you still love the ballads of past decades;this is an excellent album.You may not recall any of the singers ,as this is one of those albums where the songs are sung by other that the artists who had big hits with them. Since the tracks are not listed here,I'll list them along with the singers.The album was released by RCA Camden (C-748)  as a Stereo,Vinyl LP  in 1963,and has excellent sound quality.  RAMBLIN' ROSE  (Noelton and Joe Sherman)....not Tony Bennett  I LEFT MY HEART IN SAN FRANCISCO  (Douglas Cross -George Carry)...Not Nat King Cole  GINA  (P.Vance-L. Carr)  TEN LONLEY GUYS  (Feldman-Goldstein-Gottehrer-Elgin-Rogers-Edwards-Weiss-Adams-Farrell-Lewis)  I REMEMBER YOU  (J.Mercer- V. Schertzinger)  AS LONG AS SHE NEEDS ME  (Lionel Bart)  WHAT KIND OF FOOL AM I?  (Leslie Bricusse-Anthony Newley)  LOVE ME TENDER  (Presley-Matson)  ROSES ARE RED  (My Love)  (Al Byron-Paul Evans)  ALL ALONE AM I  (Hadjidakis-Altman)

I am writing this Review after watching this classic Western on Video released by Warner Brothers in 1967.As far as I know it is a complete reissue of the original B & W movie released in1939 which won 2 Academy Awards,and lasts the same time of 97 minutes.I also can't say if other versions such as DVD or BlueRay are different in quality or otherwise.As I watched the Video,I was quite impressed with the quality and the fact that it had been released in 1939,that's now 76 years ago.Who would have believed that in future years,that one would buy copies of these movies and be able to watch them at will in one's own home.I was also highly impressed with the fantastic scenery shots that had to be done in B & W as color was only in the future at that time.I must admit though,that the sound left much to be desired,particularly when compared to what was to come in later years.However,I still found watching this version to be very enjoyable ,and I really felt like I was experiencing what viewing the movie would have been like in 1939The storyline and the acting is superb,especially considering when it was made.It is no surprise it won 2 Acadwmy Awards and set a whole new standard ,thus becoming a classic. Although John Wayne had made many movies B movies though he had not risen to the mega star that he would become in future years. .

Pearl Bailey was born on March 29,1918 in Southampton,Virginia.Sge passed away from heart problems on August 17,1990 at the all too young age of 72. She started her career in 1936  at 27  andcontinued to perform until a year before her death.She was primarily a Jazz singer ,but als an actress in Vaudville and on Broadway where she a Tony Award in 1968 for her role in the all-black Hello Dolly. This is an excellent album of her songs released in 1958 when she was 40.It is a Mono Vinyl LP and was released by Decca Records (VL-3621) and contains these songs;  SAY SI SI  I WOULDN'T WALK ACROSS THE STREET  8TYH ST6REET ASSOCIATION  AS LONG AS I LIVE  HUG ME A HUG (KISS ME A KISS)  I LOVE MY ARGENTINA  CIRIBIRIBIN  WORLD WEARY  I HEARD  NOTHIN' NOTHIN' BABY (WITHOUT YOU)  ALLA EN EL RANCHO GRANDE  (MY RANCH)  NOTHING

This is a great idea for packaging up a game that has entertained millions since ancient times.Who actually invented this game is lost in Antiguity;but continues to entertain even today. This game is usually sold with one set of 7 pieces that can be assembled into a square.It usually comes with a booklet or book of figures to make ranging from under 100 to several hundreds. Even here on Amazon,several sets of Tangrams are offered.However,in this case,the game consists of 2 sets of tangrams,one red and the otherblue..Also included are 27 cards,similar to playing cards with a figure to construct on both sides of each card,giving a total of 54 challenges or puzzles to complete.Solutions for each figure is given at the bottom of each card. The game can be played as a solitaire puzzle or with another person. Timing the time you or your opponent needs to complete a puzzle adds excitement to the game.Also there are literally thousands of figures that can be constructed;even more when using both sets of tangrams.iThe game has been packaged in an ingenious way that makes it very convenient to carry around with you ,even when travelling.It is also a game that can be played by all ages,and even if you solve all the puzzles;all you have to do is to put it away for a while and when you get it out again,the puzzles will be just as challenging as they were when you first tried them. I have many sets of tangrams and books of Tangram puzzles.If ,after playing with this set awhile,and you want to pursue this fascinating game further;I suggest you read the review I wrote on "The Tangram Book" by Jerry Slocum.Jerry Slocum is one of America's most popular puzzle collectors and writers about puzzles.My review was written on Amazon on January 6,2004.This is a beautiful book with hundreds of illustrations,and gives the whole history of the Tangram Puzzle as well as an unbelievable array of hundreds of puzzles to do as well as an amazing Bibliography and Reference section.

This is an excellent album of both the 12 String Guitar and Folk songs from the 60's. It was released by World-Pacific  as a Stereo Vinyl LP (ST-1814) and the sound quality is superb.Although the tracks are listed on the front of the album cover,the songwriters are not.The notes on the back of the album cover are exceptionally good and informative.I can do no better than quote what is said about each track:  DON'T THINK TWICE,IT'S ALL RIGHT..  One of the finest instrumental versions of this contemporary ballad by America's young folk poet,Bob Dylan.The guirarist utilizes the flat pick  technique.  EAST VIRGINIA  This traditional folk ballad provides a unique vehicle for the manner in which the TWELVE STRING GUITAR and FIVE STRING BANJO  complement each other  THIS LAND IS YOUR LAND  This Woody Guthrie composition is fast becoming the folk singer's anthem.A  melody with easy lilt and a memorable line,is given a modern and  heretofore unheard syncopation..  IN THE PINES  A sad,wistful melody in the Southern tradition.The TWELVE STRING GUITAR provides a voicing that is  reminiscent of the pathos that  mountain singers have given this song for many years.  HARD TRAVELIN'  This Woody Guthrie classic has been given every known treatment in recent years. This rendition provides a happy marriage between the  TWELVE STRING GUITAR and THE FIVE STRING BANJO.  GET TOGETHER (AMOR A TODOS)  Almost a Latin beat.A delightful new melody line that displays the amazing range of  the TWELVE STRING GUITAR.A little quiet "funk"  provides a quiet pleasure.  FREIGHT TRAIN  A "blues" instrumental,akin to "Railroad Bill".Another of the many songs that have crossed back and forth across the "color line" of the  south.the charm of its original "blues" tempo is retained.  GREENBACK DOLLAR  This is one of the many contemporary folk ballads that fall into the "hit" category. The TWELVE STRING INTERPRETATION has the same  power that composer-singer Hoyt Axton gave the original rendition.  WHERE HAVE ALL THE FLOWERS GONE  A truly lovely contemporary folk melody composed by Pete Seeger. The lyrics were inspired by "And Quiet Flows the Dawn" by the  Russian writer,Mikhail Sholokov. The song is fast becoming a world wide favorite in the plea for peace.  LEMON TREE  This Will Holt composition is, like others in this collection,among the best of the contemporary folk songs.Almost child-like in its simplicity but  the simplicity coupled with its lasting beauty has already placed the song in the realm of "Standard" folksongs.  GOTTA TRAVEL ON  TWELVE STRING  and FIVE STRING play a delightful musical "tag" with this familiar Paul Clayton folk standard.  SEE SEE RIDER  An old Negro blues that receives the original treatment here.Recent interpretations by such outstanding artists such as Judy Henske and  Ian and Sylvia have departed somewhat from the old blues  manner of presentation.This TWELVE STRING voicing of the traditional blues  retains much of the original charm.  MICHAEL,ROW THE BOAT ASHORE  This lovely melody has been sung for generations by  the inhabitants of the Georgia Sea Island .The TWELVE STRING  arrangement  retains the Sea  Islanders delightful simplicity.  TWELVE STRING SPECIAL  You will recognize a traditional hoe-down melody line.The skilled performers utilize this familiar piece as a superb showcase for their  instruments and their talents.  Also,there is lots  more informative information on the album cover.

In this episode,Longarm gets sent to Salt Springs,New Mexico, posing as a Land Speculator to investigate a fellow lawman who may just be crooked.Salt Springs is such a small town there is not even a jail,but that is only the half of it.There is no hotel for Long to stay at,so his only choice is the high class whorehouse called the KW ,owned and operated by Kay Wallace.The KW is well appointed with a total of 42 employees,.Half are beautiful sporting ladies, and the rest are support staff of cooks ,laundresses,and such.Custis is not usually one to pay for his female company,but since he has no choice ,and is on expenses;he makes the best of things. The story is well constructed and there are lots of interesting characters.There is some gun action,but all are short-lived and there is really no competition for someone with the skills of Longarm.In the end several are headed for jail  in Las Cruces .,and Longarm is on his way to Santa Fe by stagecoach...but hold on, a young woman joins in as a traveller with Longarm,,which appears to make the trip very pleasant indeed.

Glenn Yarborough was born in Milwaukee,Wisc on January 12,1930.He is a Folk Singer,Songwriter and Guitarist.He began his career in 1951 at the age of 21 and was one of the most popular of the Folk Singers.He was the lead singer of The Limelighters.This is a Stereo Vinyl  LP released in 1966  by RCA Records (LSP-3661) It was re-released as a CD in 1997.Glen has had an amazingly long career,and is one of the very few of the Folk Era still performing.This is a very unusual album as it was performed live at The Hungry i.This was an imagnitive idea by Glen and they issued song sheets to the audience for the recording. The sound quality is excellent and this vinyl album perfectly relives  the music as it was recorded during the Folk Era. Glenn was an accomplished sailor and at the height of his career he left the music business a took his family and sailed around the world;returned years later and continues to perform today..

This is one of my favorite albums by a female singer.For what it's worth,my favorite female singers are Judy Collins and Nana Mouskouri.They can both sing any song and make it their own.There is little I can add  to the many Reviews already posted here on Amazon ,starting on January 19,1999 and continuing up to July,19,2015.To think that an album can continue to be praised for 15 years attests to the brilliance of the album and how much it continues to be loved.Two songs ,"Bird On the Wire" by Leonard Cohen and "Sometime Soon" by Ian Tyson are classics,but you've never heard them better performed than by Judy Collins;and that is on this album released by Elektra Records (EKS-74033) as a Stereo Vinyl LP in 1968.Judy was only 29 when this album was released. By the way ,it is interesting to compare her singing of "Someday Soon" on her new album "Strangers Again" released in 2015,as well as others songs on the album,particularly "Send In Ihe Clowns".Judy is now 76 and still as enchanting as ever.

I have to say that this is one of the best books I've ever read on the Kennedy Assassination.That's saying a lot for me,because I'veread  a plethora of JFK books as they were published,and are still being published today.I don't consider myself a conspiracy addict;but I've never believed that the public has ever been told the full story on the Assassination.I have held that opinion from the day i saw the Assassination happen in real time on TV.The reason for my doubt is that I spent time  in the Army,did a lot of rifle shooting,and even won a couple of awards.First,the manner in which the back of Kennedy's head was blown out,could only have been by the exiting of a bullet by a frontal head shot.Secondly,even the idea that someone with mediocre marksmanship skills,particularly using such a mediocre rifle could even begin to accomplish the act,in the time taken,or even a much greater time.Also,any marksman would never have planned a shot of JFK moving away rather than approaching ,as was the case,and the shooter (s) had far better choices available.At the time it happened,I was convinced it had to be an expert sniper,who had the rare ability,and top line rifle to do the act..Also.the shooter would have had the ability to accomplish that act from  a Kilometer or more distance.,from any number of high points,and would have done just that.Also,if a conspiracy was involved,there would have been more than one shooter,placed in different locations as a triangulation to ensure absolute success;which ,by the  way,was what happened.I must admit,in the early days after the Assassination,I had no idea of what a widespread,complicated,personns involved,organazations and different factions from the CIA,Secret Service,Cuban interestsRussia and Communists,,Mafia,|Politicians,Military  Defence manyfacturers;and other Government enitities had good readon  to see JFK as well as RFK removed from power,even murdered ,if necessary..The other side of the coin was the insistant effort on the part of the Media,Government,Warren Commission,etc. to debunk any theory,witness,evidence,or logic other than that the idea adopted and perpetrated from day one that the Assassination was the exclusive act of a lone,unconnected,individual;namerly Lee Harvey Oswald.  After reading so many,other books,and watching so many movies , documents and information from various people and studies on the Net,as well as this late 2013,book by Ventura ,Russell and Wayne;I still hold with my original opinion;but only more inforced as the years and information unfold. What this book does that is so good is that it covers pretty much everything that has been covered over the years;but in short accurate detail.If one were to start from scratch today,and try to read all that has been published,the task would be humongous.What Ventura and all have done is to sum it up in an easy to follow book that pretty well tells all that is known today,and gives excellent references.Of course,there is still much more  that is to be known about the who and why of Kennedy's Assassination,;and we may learn more as secret files and information is released;the one thing that is for sure,is that the idea that LHO was a lone killer will be shown as a total fiction and that a comjplicated conspiracy of the highest level was involved.

Longarm is sent to Arizona to meet Major Anson  Belcher at Fort McHenry.The major.s wife has either been abducted or decided to run off with an Apache ,Black Twisted Pine and Longarm is assigned the tas of finding  her and returning  her to the fort and the Major.It takes almost the whole book to find the wife ,Lucy.However;there's plenty to interest the reader as we meet Lucy's twin sister,Leslie,the ravishing daughter Magpie,the daughter of Longarm's scout friend ,War Cloud,Blue Feather, the Major's housekeeper.,and a few others. The most interesting part of the whole novel is when Longarm really finds out what happens to Lucy.There's not a whole lot of action except that Custis takes an Apache arrow that pierces his arm.There is also little in the way of good Old West descriptions or expressions.Even so;it is still a good read.

This is one of the most unusual novels I have ever read.I have never been much of a fan of Sci-Fi,Fantasy, etc. but I love history.Also,Historical Novels are among my favorites as I find they are a great way to understand the culture,trials tribulations of the people during times in the past.I guess that is what made "Gone With The Wind" a classic,as it conveys what life was like and how it affected the upper class of society in and around Atlanta during the Civil War.I am not going to try to summarize the book because several other reviewers have done that very well.However;I srongly suggest that one read the reviews before even starting to read the novel.For those who read the book before reading any reviews;I think the reviews are still very interesting to read after.The very idea of a novel that has characters that "travel" through mankinds 's history starting 200,000 BC and carrying on until 2000+ ADis mind-boggling.Well,hold on for a trip that will capture your imagine in a way that dozens of history textbooks can never do,nor do they even try.  All through the ages and cultures of mankind,there have always been Gods,Spirits,Elves,Leprechauns,Trolls, Witches,Shamens,.Guardian Angels,.In other we have lost our wonder.You name the periods of history,and you will always find them.I'm ' not sure if the author has created Lumins,or that I have just never come across them;but they are central to the novel.. In other words,the people of modern society are the most spiritually starved people in history.In our age of science,we What this novel really drove home to me is that our modern society through advances in Logic and Science has tended to triumph ,or at least replaced Myth,Magic and Wonder.Not only that,this change has really taken place over the last 300 years.Modern society now tend to analyze,rationalize,define,and calculate;but we feel little wonder and awe.We no longer believe in magic,so we've lost the wonder that inspired our ancesters.Lumins give us guideposts.In every land and culture lumins are what represent things that mystify mankind.In ancient Egypt,they're sphinxes and talking basboons. In Greece ,they're satyrs, and nymphs.In Medieval Europe they're fairies and saints.All these creatures take their shape from myths and legends,and from the magic that inspired their people,. Will the awe , wonder and beliefs that guided mankind throughout history be lost when all this is replaced by science and materialistic logic.?

No doubt about it;this episode strays greatly from what we have been getting over the years.On rare occasions ,Longarm has had to put up with a "partner" who attaches himself ,or in this case ,herself,to him as he goes off on assignment.I might have expected somone like Ned Buntline;but a lady,dime novelist,and a real looker,.However;as the storyline progresses,Longarm is slowly finding out  having Delia Walker tagging along has some benefits and in the end she actuallyb becomes a real worthwhile partner. The story really reads more like a Mystery than a Western;something that usually turns me off;but this time the storyline and characters actually make it a good read.Also;the normal length of an episode in this series is about 180+ pages;but in this case There is a lot of blank full and part pages ,which makes it a very short read. Even at this point,longtime fans can sense something brewing and that all comes to pass with Episode 436,when the series abruptly ends.

Judy Collins was born Judith Marjorie Collins on May 1,1939 in Seattle,Wash.She began her career in 1959 at the age of 20 and continues to record and perform at the age of 79.She is a Singer,Songwriter,Musician and Actress.Her first album ,A MAID OF CONSTANT SORROW came out in 1961 when she was 22. She has had, and continues to have, a marvelous career and many of her songs have been favorites for decades.This is an excellent collection of songs that was released in 1975 when Judy was fairly early in her career at the age of 36 and 16 years along in her career..It was released by Elektra  (7E-1032), who released many of her albums early in her career.It is a Stereo Vinyl LP and has excellent sound quality, as well you get the real sound of her voice at the the best during her career.A couple of the songs were written by Judy,while the rest are by others.Her rendition  of SEND IN THE CLOWNS by Stephen Sondheim is one of her most popular and best loved songs..BROTHER CAN YOU SPARE A DIME has been done by many,but none have the heartfelt feeling as Judy's version..One of my favorite songs,CITY OF NEW ORLEANS,by  Steve Goodman is more often sung by a male singer;but when Judy sings it,you almost feel you had never heard it before.The album cover is unbelievable.Just to hold it and look into Judy's astonishing eyes is enchanting.,The album cover opens up to display the lyrics to all the songs asell as the names of the musicians and instruments involved with each song Songs on the album  THE MOON IS HARSH MISTRESS  ANGEL SPREAD YOUR WINGS  HOUSES  THE LOVIN' OF THE GAME  SONG FOR DUKE  SEND IN THE CLOWNS  SALT OF THE EARTH  BROTHER,CAN YOU SPARE A DIME  CITY OF NEW ORLEANS  I'LL BE SEEING YOU  PIRATE SHIPS  BORN TO THE BREED

5.0 out of 5 stars  Thinking of buying a Yo-Yo...Get the best!, September 7, 2013ByJerry Guild = Durability:5.0 out of 5 stars  = Fun:5.0 out of 5 stars  = Educational:5.0 out of 5 starsIf you set out to buy a Yo-Yo;you'll find a large variety to choose from.At one time Duncan led the pack .But no more,that honor belongs to Yomega.They have a large array to choose from and they are all excellent.You can buy cheaper ones,but you'll never be happy with them.Yomega Yo-Yo's are made of the best of materials,have excellent balance and will stand up to an amazing amount of hard use.Fireball is a basic Yo-Yo,as opposed to special ones such as Auto Return,Butterfly,etc.;and a great one to get started with or even for expert players.It comes in several colors,mine just happens to be blue.It has given great service,and has survived unscathed,in spite of accidental real hard knocks,that would easily have broken cheaper ones.Even if it hits a hard surface accidently,it will not break,as will cheap ones like you find in Dollar stores for a buck or two. When Yomega came out with this High Performance Transaxle ,they set a whole new standard.It gives three times the sleeping time of ordinary or fixed wood axles and makes tricks easy to accomplish, that previously none but experts could perform. When you own one of these High Performance Yo-Yo's you'll never be wishing you'd bought something else.This is a very good and popular YO-YO and you'll see it is offered in different colors and prices.However;they are all identical except for the color ,which doesn't matter,as long as it is a "Yomega Fireball",regardless of the price.

As we approach what appears to be the end of this great series (Episode # 436) I have noticed that several of the latest Episodes are much shorter,While the number of pages are still around 180;there is a lot of "white space" ,including full blank pages.Also,the writing style  and the character of Longarm is not what it used to be.All that being said,this episode had a good storyline and interesting characters,There is virtually nothing in the way of historical connections or any descriptions of the country,animals,or even much in the way of colorful Old West expressions or descriptions..Longarm has been sent to Missouri  to resolve issues over moonshining.There are several interesting things happening;but it is a stretch to think the Feds would send one man ,rather than a squad of Revenooers ,to take care of a situation like this...even if that one man is Custis Long.

This is a popular brainteaser.It has been around for so long that it deserves to becalled  a classic.It has been made by many companies,and in different sizes and qualities.It is often one of several included in sets or collections of wire puzzles.Some versions,are very small and made from much lighter wire.Those ones are very cheap and even found as "prizes" in candy boxes.However they won't last long as they can be bent out of shape easily.This version is heavy ,1/4" metal and will stand up to lots of heavy twisting;which by the way,is never required to solve wire puzzles,regardless of their complexity or difficulty. This puzzle is similar to several others  where one piece is to be removed from the other and based on getting the gaps in each piece lined up so they share the same space and hence can be separated.The difference with this version is that one piece,the larger,has a loop at each end where most others do not. It would make a great beginner puzzle and has a difficulty level of only 1 or 2 out of 10.

Connie Francis was born Concetta Rosa Maria Franconero on December 12, 1938 in Newark,New Jersey.She began her career at the age of 6 in 1943 and at the age of 78 is still at it. She sang just about everything,including Traditional Pop,Country,Rock & Roll,Jazz,and now even Irish. Connie probably had as rough a ride as any female performer in her musical and movie career.She had several marriages,She was even raped at a motel while on tour at the age of 36 on November 8,1974.This was a very low point in her life and career;but she persevered sand returned to recording and performing in 1978. Her brother was killed by the Mafia in 1981,and she was so affected that she nearly committed suicide.Her 1st Single Hit was a song that had been around for some time;but her recording shot her to prominence.She recorded "Who's Sorry Now" in 1958 and it remains one of the most popular songs from the Pop era,and nobody can sing it like Connie.When we think of or listen to Connie Francis,we think of her many popular and best loved songs;his is the original version of her "The  Very Best of Connie Francis".It is a stereo Vinyl LP released in 1963 by MGM Records (E-4167).the sound quality is excellent.It contains 15 of her biggest hits at the time when she was only 25 ande already one of music's biggest  female stars.Songs on this album are;  WHO'S SORRY NOW  EVERYBODY'S SOMEBODY'S FOOL  FOLLOW THE BOYS  LIPSTICK ON YOUR COLLAR  MY HAPPINESS  VACATION  AMONG MY SOUVENIERS  WHERE THE BOYS ARE  FRANKIE  I'M GONNA' BE WARM THIS WINTER  MY HEART HAS A MIND OF ITS OWN  SECOND HAND LOVE  DON'T BREAK THE HEART TYHAT LOVES YOU  STUPID CUPID  BREAKIN' IN A BRAND NEW BROKEN HEART.

Connie Francis  was born Concetta Rosa Maria Franconero on December 12, 1938 in Newark,New Jersey.She began her career at the age of 6 in 1943 and at the age of 78 is still at it. She sang just about everything,including Traditional Pop,Country,Rock & Roll,Jazz,and now even Irish. Connie probably had as rough a ride as any female performer in her musical and movie career.She had several marriages,She was even raped at a motel while on tour at the age of 36 on November 8,1974.This was a very low point in her life and career;but she persevered sand returned to recording and performing in 1978. Her brother was killed by the Mafia in 1981,and she was so affected that she nearly committed suicide.Her 1st Single Hit was a song that had been around for some time;but her recording shot her to prominence.She recorded "Who's Sorry Now" in 1958 and it remains one of the most popular songs from the Pop era,and nobody can sing it like Connie.When we think of or listen to Connie Francis,we think of her many popular and best loved songs;but here we hear her sing some of Ireland's best loved Irish favorites.If you love Irish ballads and cry easily,Connie will have you in tears within seconds as she sings "Did Your Mother Come From Ireland","Mother Machree","A Little Bit of Heaven","Too-Ra-Loo-Ra-Loo-Ra", asnd the all time favorite "Danny Boy". This album was released in 1962 by MGM .It  is a Vinyl Hi- Fidelity album E/SE-4013 .It is an original and the sound is an excellent representation of recordings of the era.Connie was only 24 when it was released

This is another great puzzle in Puzzle Masters collection of wire puzzles.It is a high quality puzzle made of fairly heavy,3mm Nickel plated wire and two wooden balls.There are 2 rings,each about 1 1/4 " in diameter,1 ring slightly larger and heavier,and 5 other pieces .The object is to remove the heavy ring from this tangle and later put it back.As with all such wire puzzles ,this can be accomplished without using brute force,which will only ruin the puzzle. The puzzle has a Difficulty Level of 9 out of 10;making it a more suitable challenge for a fairly experienced rather than a novice puzzle solver.

This is a real gem of an album by the Clancy Brothers & Tommy Makem for any longtime Clancy fan or anyone who is just getting to know this most popular Irish Group.This album was released in the earlier days of the group.Although there is no date on the album or cover,here,or at Diccogs.I surmise it was about 1962 or '63.This is early as the group was active between 1956 and 1998. The Clancy members of the group were Liam,Paddy,Tom,Bobby and Finbar.On this album we get to hear as well,Peg,Makem's Mother Sarah and Grandchildren..The album contains a wonderful collection of Traditional songs that were part of the Clancy family sing-songs passed down through generations.The album was released by Tradition (Everest) Records) (2083).It is a Stereo Vinyl LP and has good sound quality.The sound quality reflects how it was made and not like the reissued Audio CD in 2007 nor does it have the same songs.If you want the authentic sound of the family singing,this is the album you want. The notes on the back of the cover describes the album perfectly."Whenever and wherever the Clancy Clan collect there is sure to be music-and wherever there is music-they sing,as that is their way of life.Add to this the warmth of each individual of the clan-and you would sing too.  This collection of Irish Folk Airs,is the second of two sing-songs which started with Tradition #2060 "AT HOME WITH THE CLANCY BROTHERS AND TOMMY MAKEM AND THEIR FAMILIES" and features the singing of Peg,Bobby,Tom ,Patrick,Liam Clancy and Tommy Makem and his mother Sarah. (and Grandchildren) Though all of the songs were originally sung unaccompanied,the guitar,harmonica,tin whistle,and Irish harp are now widely used.Often in the evening around the fire,the grown-ups would lead in a song while the children would join in on the chorus.Out of this atmosphere of freshness and beauty,the happy mornings,the wintry evenings ,the loves and tragedies of the people,has come a great wealth of songs and music,as presented in this latest offering by the Clancy Brothers & Tommy Makem."Songs on the album are;  PAPER BAND PINS  I KNOW WHERE I'M GOING  AS I ROVED OUT  THE COBBLER  WHISKEY YOU'RE THE DEVIL  ALL AROUND THE LONEY O  THE MOONSHINER  ME GRANDFATHER DIED  (A) SHELLEY  (B) AROUND TO THE BUTCHER SHOP  (C) ONE TWO THREE  THE LITTLE BEGGARMAN  THE REAL OLD MOUNTAIN DEW  THE WOMAN FROM WEXFORD I'LL TELL MY MA

Patrick Baker takes a demented look at the performances of 44 U.S.Presidents.Although this little tome consists of only 52 pages,he leaves no stones unturned.Actually he completely exposes all the stones be they small,medium,large,or WoW.There are many ways to rate a President;,and everyone knows that the supreme prize has to go to "Tricky Dickie " Nixon.However;Baker doesn't let the rest of the Presidents simply hang around,but presents them all front and center.Since many people manage to go through life without knowing much at all about many of the Presidents,and certainly anything about what they did or didn't accomplish during their terms;Baker lays it all out for you,in a totally different way than your History teacher did.He has done a great amount of research to find,explain and inform the readers of the "Dickiest" things each President did to allow us to remember him.He is not satisfied to leave it there;he decided to put it in a book and supplied us with stickers so we could do the honor of presenting them ,or if you prefer,attaching them ,not on their chest where most honors get placed ...but right where they belong. Since this book will likely take its place among the important History books of the nation;I am sure Baker will update it with each new President.We'll all be waiting with baited breath when the first woman gets elected  as Commander-in Chief.

This is Neil Diamond's 5 th album.It was released in 1969 by UNI (Universal City Records (UNI-73047) It is a Stereo Vinyl LP with very good sound quality.Diamond's career got started in 1962 vwhen he was 21,and he was 28 when this album was released.He is still active in his career at 74. This album is quite interesting and has come out in 26 versions.The original album had a  gatefold cover depicting two men,one on the Travelling Show wagon and the other sitting nearby on the ground ( different than shown here).It has 12 tracks but subsequent  versions had the hit "Sweet Caroline"added and the album title was changed to "Sweet Caroline Brother Love's Travelling Salvation Show". It is a different but excellent album and unless you have been a longtime fan of Diamond;there are sure to be some songs that you have seldom or even heard.  Songs on the album;  BROTHER LOVE'S TRAVELLING SALVATION SHOW  DIG IN  RIVER RUNS,NEWGROWN PLUMS  JULIET  LONG GONE  AND THE GRASS WON'T PAY NO MIND  GLORY ROAD  DEEP IN THE MORNING  IF I NEVER KNEW YOUR NAME  MEMPHIS STREETS  YOU'RE SO SWEET HORSEFLIES KEEP HANGIN' 'ROUND YOUR FACE  HURTIN' YOU DON'T COME EASY

As a longtime fan of The Trailsman Series,I really enjoyed this episode.Though not written in the style we're used to,it has a great storyline,lots of well developed characters and all kinds of action;fast,wild,savage,surprising and even diabolical.Poor old Fargo,,as usual,didn't ask for any of this,but he decides to see it through to the end,whatever that may bring.The torture scenes and descriptions would put to shame anything the Apaches or even Dracula could stage.They make a pirate scene of  "walking the plank" look civilized,and all this from a 15 year old "kid". We have yet to find Fargo confronting a woman he couldn't or wouldn't dare to trifle with;but the banker's daughter,Amanda,is something to behold;even her beauty is overshadowed by such spunk and outright bombast ,that our hero Skye decides he can do without.Too bad the author didn't see fit to give us the scene and descriptions of the funerals that were sure to be taking place in the Boot Hill Cemetery of Horse Creek,Wyoming, in the next few days.But then again,maybe that was best left to the reader's imagination.

This is one of the most popular YO-YO's from one of the best YO-YO makers in the last couple of years.It is a very well made YO-YO and a great choice for a novice or expert player.From what I see here,Yomega have discontinued making it.I am sure their decision was based on the fact that they had produced so many excellent YO-YO's that they felt it was time to change. The "Firestorm" came in several sizes.This one has a silver center with black lettering and flames and flames.The inside pieces are black plastic.Mine is the same except the center is gold with black lettering anf flames,and the inside pieces are clear ruby-red plastic.It is a strikingly beautiful YO-YO. It has a fixed steel axel.The Firestorm is almost identical ,except the center of the Firestorm is raised.

This is one of the more difficult wire,or disentanglement puzzles from the large collection made by Puzzle Master.I suppose it gets its name from the shape of the large piece,which somewhat resembles a Yak along with the second largest piece which resembles a rider.It is an intriguing looking puzzle made of fairly heavy wire that won't bend out of shape,unless brutal force is applied.There are actually 5 pieces to the puzzle.The object is to remove the handle,or what looks like a cross or man.What complicates this puzzle is the two diamond  -shaped brass pieces,one which needs to be removed along with the handle and the other,which only serves to complicate things.,As to difficulty,it deserves a Difficulty Level of 10 out of 10,;in other words very difficult. This puzzle was designed by Dick Hess,a well known puzzle designer from California. If you get stumped,and there is a good chance you will,Puzzlemaster.ca  will give you a solution ,or if you prefer, there is a video on YouTube to assist you.All is not lost even after yo have solved it and put it back together;as all you have to do is put it away for a while and it can be just as challenging once again.Wiree puzzles are many and varied and have entertained and challenged puzzlers for generations.They come in all prices,quality and difficulty.This Yak Puzzle is more suited for someone with some experience in solving disentanglement puzzles rather than a novice just getting started.

This game called "Dolphin Solitaire" is basically the same game that has been popular for many years.comes in many versions and made by many companies.Normally it goes by names such as Peg or Marble Solitaire (see my review dated May 25,2015) This is a very different version in that it comes in a cardboard box,the board is a fold- out cardboard ,rather than wood or plastic,and the playing pieces are wooden Dolphins .The game can be played solitaire (1-player) as the classic version.  However; there is another great difference,it can be played by 2 opponents or 4 opponents or teams.this is called a Bonus Game of Migration Checkers,and It is played in much the way moves are made in the classic game of Checkers. The game is suitable for anyone who would like a bit of change from Solitaire or Checkers,especially if you'd like to play Checkers with 4 people.

This is a very interesting book in the collection of puzzle books published by Sterling.They have books that cover the gambit of puzzles.Some are quite simple and others are difficult.This one is more suited for kids who tend to relish this type of humor ;whereas adults would probably consider it(,I really can't think of an appropriate word ) trifling.Lateral Thinking puzzles can be very thought provoking,but these puzzles are so off the wall,that few if anyone will "guess" the answers,even when using the Clues.The answers are almost so unusual,that they are even ridiculous. Just to show you what you can expect; here are a couple of examples;  .Walter spent three days in the hjspital.He was neither sick nor injured,but when it vas time to leave he had to be carried out.. Why?  Clues  Walter was human and physically normal.  The hospital was a normal hospital.  He wasn't able to walk into the hospital or out of it.  Answer  Walter was a newborn baby.Not Eating  A hungry man has food on his plate but doesn't eat it. Why?  Clues  The hungry man wanted to eat and there was no medical,religious,or financial reason  for him not to eat.  He was physically fit,healthy,and normal.  He was in the same room as his plate and the plate had food on it.But he wasn't able to eat it. Answer  His plate is his dental plate.

I recently was given this video and it had never been opened.As a big fan of Westerns of the Clint Eastwood Sphagetti  types;I wasn't sure what this movie would be like.Of course,'Ive known about Doris Day and Howard Keel for decades.Doris day in retired now and 91;but she was only 31 when this movie was released.Actually the color and sound is very good;but I had to admit I thought this movie was a bit silly when compared with Westerns of the past 20 years;but I quickly remembered that in 1953 we were still watching westerns such as Roy Rogers and Dale Evans,Gene Autry,Durango Kid etc.However this movie goes back to the days of "Oklahoma" " and other such wonderful movies which were really Musicals., This movie is pure entertainment and any real resemblance to the real characters ,the surroundings,and life in general of what occurred in the Wild West in Texas,New Mexico,Arizona,Kansas or the Dakotas in the 1880's is completely outside reality.Much like" West Side Story" and the reality of the slums of New York.For reality of that time ,you have to go to more recent movies such as "Gangs of New York" Be all that as it may, this is a great movie,and like other musicals of the time,are highly entertaining an if that is what you like to enjoy;by all means put your feet up and enjoy a great movie with excellent actors,music,scenes and storyline.

Elena is an opera by Francesco Cavalli, the star composer of 17th-century Venice. He wrote 41 operas, and 27 of them survive. Elena was penned in 1659, and was never performed since. The Aix-en-Provence Festival dug it up and give it a full blooded performance at the small ThÃ©Ã¢tre du Jeu de Paume, a relic in the Italian horseshoe style that is perfect for Baroque opera.Cavalli's score calls for no fewer than 23 different characters, which might explain why it has languished in obscurity for so long. With its European Academy of Music, Aix-en-Provence has a  pool of excellent young singers on which to draw; 13 gifted principals take the 23 main roles.Elena aka The Abduction of Helen by Cavalli is of course not about the life of Helen of Troy but about racy attitudes towards sex and marriage in 17th century Venice. All of Venice had been excommunicated when Cavalli was four years old, not for its free and easy morality but rather because this rich city had the confidence to ignore playing by rules imposed by others. Elena, the thirty-second of his forty one or so operas, is also about playing harmlessly outside the rules, those of restraint or civilized conduct in particular.Elena of the title is none other than Helen of Troy but that was in the future. The show in Cavalli's version is very nearly stolen by Menelaus, King of Sparta, who slips into a frock early in the first act as `Elisa' and spends the next three hours stealing his own share of male hearts before disrobing to win Elena's. The opera deals with Helen's marriage to Menelaus. The plot is full of twists as various suitors vie for the hand of the most beautiful woman in the world. There are some wonderful melodies and set pieces and the whole thing eventually ends in happy marriages.The opera opens with a Prologue which presents a version of the Judgment of Paris and Director Jean-Yves Ruf treats the Prologue as a burlesque.The convoluted plot centres, more or less, around the wooing of Helen by Menelaus, Theseus and Menestheus. Menelaus cross-dresses as an Amazon called Elisa in order to get closer to Helen. A bunch of men fall in love with Elisa. Theseus's real Amazon wife Hippolyta appears and she wants to kill her husband. The libretto was started by Giovanni Faustini and finished by Nicolo Minato. The plot is convoluted and long, but grab what you can of the central plotline and listen to the music and the singing and you will discover that Cavalli is unfailingly melodic, inventive and simply beautiful in his musical settings.The 13 young singers are all outstanding. In the two biggest roles, Hungarian EmÃ¶ke BarÃ¡th who sings the roles of Helen and Venus is a pretty blonde with a beautiful voice. Cavalli gives her some lovely melodies and her ringing and luminous voice delivers them to perfection.Rumanian countertenor Valer Barna-Sabadus is tall and rangy and is artlessly wonderful as the cross-dressing Menelaus, with all the bloom and agility of a top-drawer countertenor. His singing is simply gorgeous. Both he and Barath are at home on the knife edge between sentiment and comedy, in turn meltingly beautiful and cuttingly funny.Swiss-Chilean tenor Emiliano Gonzalez Toro also shows impressive range as the buffoon Iro, while Christopher Lowrey is impressive in the smaller countertenor roles. Portuguese tenor Fernando GuimarÃ£es as Theseus with his deeper voice provided a nice contrast to the countertenor pursuers of Helen. Theseus is betrothed to the Amazon Hippolyta. The latter is sung by mezzo-soprano Solenn'Lavanant Linke, a woman of some stature well suited to the role.Argentinian conductor Leonardo GarcÃ­a AlarcÃ³n and his Cappella Mediterranea offer us every opportunity to love Cavalli's fluid, inventive, witty, moving, clever music, with an organic musicality that gives every word expression, keeps every dance beat airborne and makes every lament affecting.Director Jean-Yves Ruf had some tough choices to make with a problematic opera. The opera has a problematic plot, but the performance is well worth its revival.

Johann Adolph Hasse (1699-1783) is one of those composers whose importance in the history of opera has never been questioned, but whose own works have long since disappeared from the repertory. Born near Hamburg, Hasse studied with Nicola Porpora and Alessandro Scarlatti in the 1720s in Naples, and, when he returned to Germany, settled in Dresden as court composer to the Elector of Saxony.  As prolific composer famous for his opera seria that established his reputation across Europe, Hasse composed more than 50 of them.â€˜Didone Abbandonataâ€™ was first performed in Dresden in 1742 to celebrate the birthday of Hasseâ€™s patron the Elector of Saxony August III. Beginning with Aeneas's decision to leave Dido and Carthage, to fulfil his destiny of founding a city, the opera plunges straight into the action, and conductor Michael Hofstetter ensures that the dramatic tension never slackens. â€˜Didone Abbandonataâ€™ is perhaps the first opera seria to adopt a tragico fine, as opposed to lieto fine, with the suicide of Queen Dido in the final Act.  Hasseâ€™s arias are the predecessor of the rococo style galant.  As in Purcellâ€™s famous treatment of the same story, it is Didoâ€™s anticipation of the personal catastrophe which will befall her, expressed in her desperate efforts to prevent Aeneasâ€™s departure, that is of most interest, and this part is being left out in Metastasioâ€™s libretto.  It is therefore only during the operaâ€™s final scene â€˜Fuggi, O Reginaâ€¦Ombra Cara, ombra traditaâ€™, the great monologue of Dido, that the intensity of emotion surrounding Didoâ€™s character and her music reaches its height.  Here Hasse employed versi spezzati (broken verses) to reveal her deep insecurity.  At its heart lies the short cavatina, whose music derives from the surrounding declaimed accompanied recitative. Through this Hasse emphasizes her helplessness through the contrasting natures of accompanied recitative and the more lyrical aria, a contrast which serves to highlight her desolation, and the tragic style prevails. This scene is reminiscent in style to Handelâ€™s â€˜Alcinaâ€™ in which the sorceress laments in an Act 2 monologue "Ah! Ruggiero crudel - Ombre pallideâ€ her abandonment by Ruggiero.There's something robust and purposeful about both the playing and the singing of this live performance taken from a stage production in the Munich Prinzregententheater in 2011.  While not totally polished, the best parts of this live performance represent the finest available.  Dido is sung confidently by Theresa Holzhauser, mezzo-soprano, while both Aeneas and Iarbas, the African king who attempts to blackmail Dido into marriage, are sung by two counter-tenors, Flavio Ferri-Benedetti and Valer Barna-Sabadus.  Iarbas, a role created by Hasse for Farinelli, gets the best aria in the entire opera, â€˜Cadra fra poco in cenereâ€™, just before Dido's final scene, and Barna-Sabadus delivers it with great vocal control and technical finesse. The sung parts are dominated by high voices, and only the minor part of Osmida (baritone) is allocated to a broken voice.  Both Theresa Holzhauserâ€™s Dido and Flavio Ferri-Benedettoâ€™s Aeneas are well done enough. The latterâ€™s heroic departure aria in Act Three â€˜A trionfar mi chiama un bel desio d'onore â€˜ is a tour de force, so is Didoâ€™s final scene and her important solo at the centre of Act Two â€˜Ah! Non lasciarmi, noâ€™, which has music of beautiful and deeply felt sincerity. Other sopranos are more variable in vocal level, and Seleneâ€™s aria â€˜Ogni amator supponeâ€™ is passable without being outstanding, with pitch problems abounding in Hinterdoblerâ€™s singing and in similar vein the Act III aria of Araspe â€˜Gia si desta la tempestaâ€™ of Maria Celeng.The orchestral playing of the Hofkapelle MÃ¼nchen under Michael Hofstetter is highly effective, allowing the range of Hasseâ€™s orchestration to make its mark, with the opening sinfonia splendidly done. The sound is no more than acceptable, with stage noises and the applauses, but at Naxos's bargain price this is a rarity that's well worth investigating.

Jennifer Lane (Mezzo Soprano), Karina Gauvin (Soprano), Melissa Fogarty (Soprano),Nathaniel Watson (Baritone), Stephen Stubbs (Chitarrone), Stephen Stubbs (Guitar),Margriet Tindemans (Viola da gamba), Maxine Eilander (Harp), Byron Schenkman (Harpsichord)Conductor:  Ingrid MatthewsOrchestra/Ensemble:  Seattle Baroque OrchestraRecorded in 2001 at Bastyr University, Kenmore, WA, this baroque work was written when opera was banned in Rome (1683), so this work takes the ostensible format of an oratorio. This is convenient since the famous Abraham/Sarah/Hagar/Ishmael story is from the Book of Genesis, chapter 21, and the opera takes the point where Abrahamâ€™s wife Sarah insists that he must banish the slave Hagar and her son Ishmael to protect their own son Isaacâ€™s inheritance.  In Genesis, Ishmael was fathered by Abraham at the urging of the then barren Sarah, who later (at an advanced age) to everyoneâ€™s surprise bore a son, Isaac. The anguished father very reluctantly agrees to banish the two, who end up nearly dying in the desert but are eventually, at the oratorioâ€™s end, saved by an Angel.This work offers an excellent example of Alessandro Scarlattiâ€™s vocal and dramatic facility and his engaging manner of setting melody to appropriately varied, effectively complementary accompaniment.All of the drama in this two-part work centres on the interaction of the four main characters (the Angel delivers the final aria). There are no choruses or significant orchestral sections save for the opening Sinfonia.  It contains wonderful arias (both accompanied by continuo and by orchestra), flowing recitatives, and occasional duets. Itâ€™s a very compact, tightly constructed piece of theatre that moves right along, and itâ€™s filled with lovely music.Canadian soprano Karina Gauvin heads the cast as the mistress Sara.  Her clear and captivating of voice with abundant musically intelligence shine through in the various arias of Sara, like â€˜Caro, Isac amato figlioâ€™ and â€˜E folle chi paventaâ€™ as well as the aria of the Angel (final) â€œChi lo sguardo, e constanteâ€™.  As the banished son Ishmael, American soprano Melissa Fogarty not only delivers her arias with a marvelous range of color and nuance, conveying the victimized boyâ€™s array of emotions, but her timbre, well-cored with its crystalline quality of utmost childlike spunk, befits the boyâ€™s role to a â€˜Tâ€™. Her performance in Part Two, in the duet where Ishmael and Hagar desperately face death in the desert, is outstanding, and really steals the show from even as eminent a performance as Gauvinâ€™s.  As Agar, American mezzo-soprano Jennifer Lane is also excellent, especially in the sombre second half.The only one who pales by comparison is baritone Nathaniel Watson, who sings well enough but puts little emotion into it and doesnâ€™t give us a real sense of Abrahamâ€™s character or his conflicted state throughout the work. Luckily, most of the singing, however, is done by the women and the action moves swiftly.The instrumental playing is excellent, and the continuo players are particularly notable for their sympathetic accompaniments. The chitarrone flourish that introduces the Angel is a very effective touch.

The chitarrone flourish that introduces the Angel is a very effective touch.

This is a complete recording of Verdi's 'Il Trovatore', made in 1977. People complain against Sutherland and Pavarotti's portrayals as Leonora and Manrico.I find nothing wrong with their more bel canto style. Actually, Pavarotti is to be preferred to other big voices who inevitably gave Manrico an almost brutal vocal portrayal.Despite the heavy dramatic thrust of the script, the musical score is still basically bel canto. To treat the score as verismo is stylistically uninformed.That said, Bonynge here is only marginally alright, and could have fared better if he gives his singers more momentum by adopting a briskier tempo, such as in 'Ah si, ben mio'. His recitatives were also too bland at times.Pavarotti has sufficient squillo to bring off 'Di quella pira', no frills. The timbre is focused and the high notes well hit and well held and brought off in real bravura. If he could not, then there is really no place for the like of a Domingo (with lowered pitch).Pavarotti is musically more nuanced than Franco Bonisolli, who otherwise would be a perfect Manrico.The main draw for this album not being awarded 5 stars are first Horne and second Sutherland.Horne's timbre is hardly resplendant in this recording, and she pressed her voice at the mid range to an unpleasant squeal quite often. Her `Stride la vampa' suffers as well as ensemble work from this inadequacy.Sutherland after the mid-1970's began her slow but gradual vocal decline, and this is sadly evident in this recording at critically lyrical moments. Contrary to what other reviewers said, it is her soft singing that posed most problems here. 'D'amor sull'ali rosee' is a sad example of a great soprano showing signs of a past-prime vocal state. She is still very capable in the ensembles, though.Wixell is a vocally effective Count, more so than Milnes at any point of time.

Both Handel and Hasse did not come up with first rate music for this libretto, but by comparison, Hasse fared slightly, though very slightly, better. Even so, the opera is not representative of top rate baroque music and George Petrou and his highly capable cast managed to salvage the wreck without bringing it to illustrious height.The piece is very misleading, for in its premiere, two of the greatest castrati of the time sung the title role Siroe (Farinelli) and Medarse (Caffarelli).In this recording, Siroe is undertaken by Max Emanuel Cencic and Medarse by Franco Fagioli. Both singers gave solidly capable performances, but it is the music that forbids them from offering truly inspiring performances. The same thing happened with Handel's 'Siroe', for sure, for though the two lady leads in Handel's premiere were sung by Faustina Bordoni and Francesca Cuzzoni, the uninteresting music precluded the work to attain the status of a 'Giulius Cesare', ;'Alcina', 'Tamerlano', "Rinaldo" or a "Serse". The Spering recording about a decade ago was a good testimony of Handel's piece, but it also showed the limitations of the score, with much less colourful music as in Handel's greatest operatic outputs, the chief reason of which may be accounted for by the composer's attitude towards the libretto.So there is no use whining over the production, which in nearly all respects are perfect - the sound is pristine, the voices of the singers blend well with the orchestra...On the whole, the surprising upstaging performance comes from the minor role of Arasse, a role transposed for soprano voice and sung by American soprano Laureen Snouffle in a clear, silvery tone with spot on high notes sung free and clean.The other soprano Julia Lezhneva did not come off as well as Snouffle, and the same problem as in Pergolesi's "Stabat Mater" permeates here in 'Siroe'. Her Laodice sounds shrill in high notes and the registral integration is less than perfect. Otherwise, there is not much to fault her singing, given that Laodice is given the most complex music to sing as compared to Arasse or even Emira (the last solo aria is really a hell of a piece for any singer).The heroine Emira is outstandingly sung by Greek mezzo-soprano Mary Ellen Nesi, an underrated singer in the same calibre as Joyce Didonato and Magdalena Kozena, owning a more interesting timbre than either Elina Garanca or Vivca Genaux.Her Emira is beautifully sung and dramatically vivid, and Nesi handles the fiorature capably if not perfectly..The parallel libretto of both Handel and Hasse's works can afford an interesting comparison. I find Hasse's to be more interesting in almost every turn, though only very slightly. Assuming the title role of Siroe in Handel's case was Senesino. While Farinelli sung Siroe for Hasse, Cencic's timbre has grown darker than a couple of years back and arguably would have made a better Siroe in Handel's. Farinelli's competitor and collleague Caffarelli's role of Medarse is undertaken by star countertenor Fagioli. Fagioli gave a technical display of Medarse's rather terse and harsh music to almost perfection, but arguably the pieces are less than enticing in musical terms.Overall speaking, the most pleasing vocal performances belong to Nesi and Snouffle, but the result is brought to bear by the score more than other considerations.For those interested in a scholarly comparison, this is still warmly recommended, hence recommended with slight reservation.

This is a very fine production and wonderful performance of 'Don Giovanni' back in 1999.Riccardo Muti has conducted a number of Da Ponte's Mozart operas in Vienna, and this, together with the 1996 'Cosi fan tutte', are musical winners through and through.The reason is simple - the casts in both productions are GREAT.In this 'Don Giovanni', for once, we have a Spanish 'Don'. Carlos Alvarez - who is both a fine actor and good baritone, though most of the time, he got 'muffled' in costumes and wigs that are not really becoming the Don.
