Visually he could have fared much much better had a more sensible art director been around.He handled the vocal parts with aplomb, though the 'Serenade' could have been a bit more sweet and alluring. But generally speaking, he has the vocal prowess to depict a roguish Don, and the looks to convince that this Don is a real charmer and seducer.As the 'counterpart' to the Don, D'Arcangelo is a funny and lithe Leporello, so rarely found in terms of comic capacity. HIS costumes are surprising effective, and he makes good use of his capabilities in this important role. The Catalogue Aria is a real winner.The ladies are all very good, with the vocal crown to Adrianne Pieczonka, whose Donna Anna blows the listeners away through and through, though visually more stolid. Anna Caterina Antonacci is very convincing as Donna Elvira. While her earlier entrance isn't that 'fiery' as the role demands, in the latter two Acts she is able to conjure up all the sympathy for this role.While the soubrette role of Zerlina is being sung by Austrian mezzo Angelika Kirchschalger instead, hers is both a vocal and acting winner. The Massetto is Lorenzo Regazzo, who has since built up a major baritone career. And even the Commendatore is none other than Selig!This production offers wonderful chance to see ALL these big operatic names in their youthful state, and with Muti at the pit, nothing can go wrong!

Katia Ricciarelli and Luicano Pavarotti: Arias and Duets is a program of scenes from Giuseppe Verdi's operas `Aida', `Macbeth', La Forza', `I Lombardi', `Il Corsaro' , :Falstaff' and `Otello' recorded live at the Teatro Pegio, Parma, on July 30th, 1976.TRACKS:1. La traviata: Lunge da lei...De' miei bollenti spiriti (Pavarotti);2. Aida: O patria mia (Ricciarelli);3. Macbeth: Ah, la paterna mano (Pavarotti);4. La forza del destino: Pace, pace, mio Dio (Ricciarelli);5. I lombardi: La mia letizia infondere (Pavarotti);6. Il corsaro: Egli non riede ancora!...Non so le tetre immagini (Ricciarelli);7. Falstaff: Sul fil d'un soffio etesio (Ricciarelli);8. Otello: Gia nella notte densa (Ricciarelli/Pavarotti).The entire LP last for about 45 minutes, and as far as this reviewer is aware, has been re-mastered digitally by Decca in another double CD issue, but not individually.Recordings of these two singers' collaborations are relatively few. Apart from a video of an early Metropolitan 'Un Ballo' performance, this live recording is about the only collaboration of these two singers in formal issue.In 1976, both singers are in their absolute vocal prime.  The tenor and soprano are about the best operatic voices to have emerged from Italy in the latter part of the 20th century.  In this live recording we do not hear applauses as we often hear today in digital recordings.  The sound is very clear and clean. The Orchestra of the Parma Opera House was conducted ably by Giuseppe Patane.  One thing is evident - while both singers sung the Otello duet at the end of the programme, Pavarotti did not, throughout his illustrious career, made Otello one of his signature roles as he did Mantua, Alfredo, Radames, Manrico, or other earlier Verdian tenor heroes.  Katia Ricciarelli, a celebrated Verdian in her time, was most adept at the earlier Verdian soprano roles with a heavy bel canto flavor than the more dramatic or spinto roles like Aida, as is evident also in this programme. Her Nannetta and Desdemona are clearly more than memorable, with a juicy lyrical soprano timbre capable of manoeuvring the finest dynamic changes and with her crystal clear idiomatic enunciations. In similar vein, in Verdi, Luciano Pavarotti, with his absolutely glorious timbre, negotiated the various numbers with highest musical elan and verbal incisiveness that pales every other tenor of his generation.While Ricciarelli had, during those years of her rather short vocal career, partnered the Hispana tenros Placido Domingo as well as Jose Carreras, this album with Pavarotti represents one of the desert island recordings of these two great Italian singers.Patane's orchestral support is also superb, and the vinyl LP released some years after the live performance by Decca offers great sound.

Giovanni Gualberto Magli, the castrato who took part in the premiere of Monteverdi's L'Orfeo, was a pupil of Giulio Caccini and who spent most of his life in the service of the Medici family in Florence.Some very fine performances of 17th century baroque music directly or indirectly associated with Magli is being presented by the young Italian Counter-tenor Raffaele PÃ¨, with harpist Chiara Granata and theorbo player David Miller.The group take us on a journey from Monteverdi's Mantua and Caccini's Florence, to Naples and Brandenburg, with music by Monteverdi, Caccini, Sigismondo d'India, Francesco Lambardi, Giovanni Maria Trabaci, Girolamo Montesardo, Alessandro Ciccolini, and Johann Nauwach.When Claudio Monteverdiâ€™s La favola dâ€™Orfeo was first performed at the Mantua court of Francesco IV Gonzaga on 24 February 1607, Magli is known from contemporary correspondence to have sung the roles of Musica and Proserpina, but probably Speranza as well.For a â€˜historicalâ€™ project like this success will only come if it has an artist for whom the music is an experience rather than an experiment. On top of a beautiful voice, the singer must connect with his audience on a level that transcends ego, intellect, and even musicality.This album starts with Monteverdi's L'Orfeo. Here PÃ¨ sings Musica's prologue, Speranza's solo from Act III and Proserpina's from Act IV, linked by instrumental interludes based on other material in the opera.The young Italian countertenor PÃ¨ uses a direct style, recitar cantando , in which he combines plangent tone with a strong feeling for the text.  His account of the Monteverdi arias very much creates sung speech and the results are brilliant.Amarilli mia bella by Magli's teacher Giulio Caccini (1550 - 1618) is more elegantly lyrical, but here PÃ¨ sings both Caccini's version and the highly ornamented version by Johann Nauwach (1595 - 1630). It was the composer Nauwach who produced the earliest known collection of arias for solo voice published in 17th century Germany.  In 1612 Nauwach visited Italy, and his ornamented version of Caccini's aria probably pays tribute to this PÃ¨riod.What follows is an imaginative journey of Magli. This album is almost a travelogue that documents the geographical progress of Magliâ€™s career. The selectionsâ€™ scene changes are audible in the musiciansâ€™ playing: the pieces composed in Mantua differing from that of music written in Florence or Naples.While perfecting the recitar cantando style, Raffaele PÃ¨ is nonetheless capable of singing in the most elegantly lyrical terms. He is poised to make his name among those of the finest modern countertenors like Fagioli, Davies, et. al.

01. Amanti, io vi sÃ² dire (Ciaconna)02. Occhi miei che vedeste03. M'amÃ² tanto costei04. Chi non sÃ  come amor05. Avverti Ã² cor06. Queste pungenti spine (Cantata Spirituale)07. Lingua di donna08. Udite, Amanti09. Io dissi al cor10. Non fia piu ver11. Cielo sia con tua pace12. Degg'io amarvi13. Quando prendon riposo14. O momumentiBenedetto Ferrari was an Italian composer of opera, librettist and theorbo player. born in Reggio nell'Emilia. He lived through most of the seventeenth century,  particularly noted for his poetic texts.When Monteverdi died before completing his final opera, Lâ€™incoronazione di Poppea, a colleague â€“ now believed to be Benedetto Ferrari â€“ supplied the workâ€™s final number and most famous duet, â€œPur ti miroâ€.  Ferrariâ€™s own operatic scores are lost, so it si impossible to verify that the music Ferrariâ€™s, but the text most certainly is his. Savour Jaroussky singing the fifth number here, â€˜Avverti Ã² corâ€™, and youâ€™d probably be convinced that it was Ferrari who supplied the final duet to Monteverdiâ€™s swansong.The solo vocal works of Benedetto Ferrari formed the contents of a recital of Philippe Jaroussky in October 2002.This recording made in the same year with his own Ensemble Artaserse found a perfect medium for Jaroussky's art--and it's quite formidable in both purity of tone and subtlety of expression as well as the near-inhuman technical feats he brandishes as naturally as breathing.  Jaroussky was barely 24 years old at the time of this recording, and the voice is as fresh and pure as crystal.The melodies, accompanied by various instruments, including viola di gamba, theorbo, and harp, demand an amazing capacity for ornamentation, for super-florid runs and whiplash-inducing turns--and Jaroussky conquers all with unruffled ease.  Although the 14 selections sound somewhat similar, along the way Jaroussky and his partners certainly will hold your interest, often astonishing you with their virtuosity. The sound couldn't be more complementary, and the notes provide substantial background on both music and performers, along with texts and translations. Of the entire set, the main composition is the Cantata Spirituale called â€˜Queste pungenti spineâ€™, accompanied here serenely by an organ. Jarousskyâ€™s ethereal timbre provides the perfect medium for such piece.It is a pity that this astounding album has since gone out of print. Unreservedly recommended.

This is a recording back in the mid-1980's of Pergolesi's highly delectable piece.The late Claudio Abbado gives his reading of this masterpiece, conducting the London Symphony Orchestra in a non-period period, so HIP insistents need not apply.For the general music lovers, this recording does have its own high points and allure.First of all, the Scottish soprano Margaret Marshall is every bit as outstanding in the soprano parts as Emma Kirkby, though Marshall owns a much fuller and juicy soprano voice than Kirkby. In terms of agility, Marshall never yields a single decimal point to Kirkby. Marshall's trills rivals that of Joan Sutherland, and her ability in coping with the most demanding pyrotechnics are second to none. Her highly pure and silvery timbre tops that of other much more illustrious sopranos in this work, viz. Freni (Gracis and Berganza), Ricciarelli (also with Abbado and Valentini-Terrani), Anna Netrebko (Pappano), Barbara Bonney (Roussett and Scholl), and needless to say, Julia Lezhneva (Fasolis and Jaroussky).Her alto partner the late Italian contralto Lucia Valentini-Terrani owned the most perfect timbre for this work - the voice is dark and shimmering, with a subdued yet gleaming hue that brings forth the alto parts in the best imaginable light.  No other mezzo-sopranos or countertenors ever managed to come close to Valentini-Terrani in this work, including great ones like Teresa Berganza, Jochen Kowalski, Andreas Scholl, Philippe Jaroussky.The argument against the choice of two women for this work as being running counter to the original intention is forever present, especially in the present HIP era. However, the voices of Marshall and Valentini-Terrani both embodied the most pure and neuter gender timbres for this piece - Margaret sounding appropriately boyish in most, if not all, the time, and Lucia sounding plush and deep as any alto castrato imaginable.With such two full-bodied yet distinctive voices, the forces of LSO seem just right. If one wishes for a period ensemble, the combination of vocalists would rightly demand two male voices to do justice to the original score, as exemplified in the more recent recording by Hofstetter with Wey and Barna-Sabadus.Abbado gave a grave and broad view of this religious piece. The reading is both inspirational as well as musical.  Many people slashed out against his `romanticised' treatment, arguing against the excessive vibrato, the jarring harmonics et al. Having said that, in the light of the recent rave reviews of Fasolis and Jaroussky/Lezhneva's most dissonant and jarring new star rendition, such arguments against good old Abbado in the 1980's hardly hold any more water.The conclusion, hence, is simple - the best conventional recording is this Abbado/Marshall/Valentini-Terrani, and the best HIP the Hofstetter/Wey/Barna-Sabadus recording.

I have been listening to this album for over half a decade since it first came out.  Ms. Zhu is one of the foremost contemporary pianists that I have unreservedly recommended to friends in the PRC.China has lost Gu Sengying, a foremost lady interpretor of Chopin. For those who do not care for humanity, such loss is only a loss among a million.  For those who care, it was an irreparable loss.As such, Zhu Xiamei, a rough contemporary of the ill-fated Gu and also from Shanghai, bursted onto my scene of contemporary Chinese musicians like a real whirlwind - her lucidity in this piece, her multi-faceted expressivity, her deep insight into the entire set, the psychological coherence she imbues into the 32 parts of the theme and variations, all bespoke of a musical mastery of the highest order.I was overjoyed.  I rushed out to obtain all her Bach recordings. She does not disappoint at all.  And as I listen to her recordings of Bach each time, the conviction that great art is inevitably linked with human joys and sufferings becomes greater and greater to me.There aren't too many artists in our era that have lived through a life experience such as Zhu's.  I haven't read her auto-biography, and I do not think I need to, in order to appreciate her performances.

This new production is designed by La Fura dels Baus. The arena at Verona is transformed into a huge desert, creating mechanical animals and manufacturing a solar power plant. Their experience in leading large-scale shows and opera enables them to create the Aida of the XXIst century, one that is also splendidly conducted by young talented conductor Omer Meir Wellber.The cast is almost legendary, with Hui He in the title role and Fabio Satori as Radames. Their voices represent the most beautiful ones available for their respective roles today. In the mezzo-soprano role of Amneris, veteran dramatic soprano/mezzo-soprano Giovanna Casolla gives an unbelievably capable performance of the Egyptian princess. Well-nigh 70 years of age, this vocal wonder was already 68 years at the time of this performance (in 2013). She never looked one jot her age, both visually or vocally this would well have been a Verdian mezzo-soprano singing in the height of her powers. It is only when she and Hui He engage in duet that there is some difficulty in distinguishing the voices of the two ladies. This is an overlooked soprano assoluta, who miraculously preserves her voice well into late maturity.Satori has a beautiful Verdian tenor voice, if not outright the most charismatic stage presence. His duets with Amneris and Aida are both highly convincing, the best voice of this genre since the great Carlo Bergonzi, if not the most stylish yet.This is the third Aida DVD of Hui He that I own, and am in agreement with the lead reviewer that she is best here, both vocally and visually. The intonation has improved, and her stage presence greatly enhanced by a slight yet significant weight adjustment.This is also my third Aida DVD of the wonderful Verdian baritone Ambrogio Maestri.I got this new Aida for Satori, and am pleasantly surprised by the veteran Casolla, as well as the beautiful Hui He.

French contralto Nathalie Stutzmann has been well acquainted with the works of Handel at the very onset of her illustrious career as a contralto.  In 2009 she established her own ensemble Orfeo 55, performing often as both conductor and vocalist.In this Handel album, Ms. Stutzmann assembles a highly individual compilation that is rendered possible solely by her extensive exposure and unique acquaintance with the works of this great composer.Titled Heroes from the Shadows, the disc seeks out secondary characters from Handel's prolific opera outputs, selecting arias that rival the best compositions in the baroque operatic oeuvre.Stutzmann focuses equally on the symphonic as well as vocal aspects of the chosen material.Each solo aria is preceded by a short and terse, yet dramatically highly affecting sinfonia from Handel's various operas: Poro, Orlando, Partenope, Scipione, Serse et al.The arias following are either highly viruosic and florid, or dramatically profound. The characters involved range from castrato roles to contralto roles, like Ottone in Agrippina, Arsamene in Serse, to Cornelia in Giulius Cesare in Egitto.As solo vocalist, Stutzmann still holds a firm grip on the reigns of Handel's high demands, and she is even more dramatically alert than in her early recording years in this repertoire. As conductor, she is way up her alley in this oeuvre, conducting with great verve and alertness.Particularly worthy of mention is the ability of Stutzmann in alternating the instrumental pieces and the vocal solo arias.  The musical and dramatic as well emotional contrast are astounding, and this aspect alone makes this disc one of the best ever all-Handel operatic albums to have been recorded.Unreservedly recommended.

Mozartâ€™s concert arias were composed either as additions to opera scores or as substitutions or alternative arias. In her Mozart album, Gauvin chose two composed specifically for concert performance: â€˜Misera, dove sonâ€™, composed for Countess Baumgarten and â€˜Châ€™io mi scordi di te?â€¦Non temere, amato beneâ€™ which was originally intended for insertion for performance in Idomeneo but adapted for the farewell concert of Nancy Storace, a singer much adored by Mozart. It is the latter version that we hear Gauvin perform here. The orchestration calls for piano obbligato and it is deftly handled by Benedetto Lupo.  Here, Gauvin imbues every question and response with weight and passion. The same goes for â€˜Misera dove sonâ€™, aria for Baumgarten, in which Gauvin employs an entire rainbow of tone colors to express the sensation of being torn apart by misery.The opera arias featured are also marked by a superb sensitivity to the deeply emotive undertones in Mozart. Not many soprano who can make an experienced listener hear Susanna's "Giunse alfin il momento," from Act IV of Le Nozze di Figaro, with fresh ears, but that is precisely what Gauvin succeeds in doing. Her highly expressive declamation opens up a unique thought progression for this character, one the audience had been watching for more than two hundred years. Gauvin's subsequent "Deh vieni, non tardar" is no less irresistible.She continues this personal approach with all the arias. In Die Zauberfloteâ€™s famous aria of Pamina "Ach, ich fÃ¼hl's" Gauvin drives home Pamina's utter desolation with her pianissimo iterations of the phrase "So wird Ruh' im Tode sein", which become an intimate confession. Just when you think she can't get any softer, the final phrases of the aria diminish to a stunningly sad finish. The returning of orchestra in plush tones underlines the depth of her loss.Another wonderful exchange between instrumentalist and singer occurs in Vitelliaâ€™s aria â€˜Non piÃ¹ di fioriâ€™ from the opera La Clemenza di Tito with AndrÃ© Moisanâ€™s gorgeously expressive basset horn obbligato. It is only in â€˜Non piÃ¹ di fioriâ€™, Vitellia's rangy rondo showpiece from La Clemenza di Tito that spends a fair amount of time in the rich middle of Gauvin's voice, that her lowest chest tones are comparatively underpowered.She integrates the low register more successfully in "Come scoglio," which manages simultaneously to be ferocious and a thoughtfully considered argument.Bernard Labadie and Violons du Roy, an outstanding ensemble, achieve the perfect balance between supporting Gauvin and taking the spotlight.Indeed, this recording demonstrates that Karina Gauvin shares a trait with Mozart: the ease and grace with which it falls on the ear of the listener belies the true complexity and supreme artistry inherent in the crafting of a truly exquisite performance.

When the most recent years see an upsurge in recordings for baroque masters Agnostino Steffani and Leonardo Vinci, Antonio Caldara remains a perfect bet for splendid baroque vocal compositions.In the present album of over 72 minutes, we are treated with arias from six of Caldara's operas and three cantatas.The three cantatas, 'Begliocchi adorati', 'Rotte l'aspre catene' and 'Creda Niso' were composed in 1712 and 1715 respectively.  The operas range from a later period, between 1729 and 1736, and are to be considered Caldara's mature works.  The cantatas follow the 'standard' pattern of a Sinfonia, two arias preceded by recitatives.American lyrical soprano Robin Johanssen sings the pieces in a seamless silvery tone, agile, bright and with a juicy middle voice, fully capable of painting the varied vocal hues demanded in the diverse oeuvre presented in this album, all of which are world premiere recordings.  The voice is some what akin to a younger Karina Gauvin, with the same flexible vocal allure throughout the range.She is very capably accompanied by the Academia Montis Regalis, conducted by Alessadnro De Marchi. The liner notes include full texts for the lyrics of all the excerpts.This is an artistically outstanding as well as highly substantial recording.

This album of Antonio Vivaldi's secular cantatas was made about one and a half year earlier than the French countertenor Philippe Jaroussky's 'Virtuosic Cantatas of Vivaldi' album, and two cantatas overlap - 'Alla caccia dell'alima e de' and 'Care selve amici prati' in these two albums.I have owned both albums for some years (they were recorded in around 2003/2004), yet Cencic's album issued by Capriccio was difficult to follow for the tracking of the pieces was all messed up until the last cantata (track 14 onwards). This aspect deterred me from frequenting this otherwise very well performed album, especially when one compares Jaroussky's (recorded when he was of the same age as Cencic, i.e. a year and a half later).While one would say that Philippe's timbre is sweeter (this is very subjective, mind you) and his intonation is right on (this is indisputable), Cencic has clearly more depth of interpretation (compare the final aria in Alla caccia dell'alma e de), and loads of more vocal virtuosity (compare the final aria in Care selve amici prati).The other cantatas include the popular Cessate, omai cessate and Amorel hai vinto (Rv 683), widely recorded by contraltos and countertenors alike.Cencic sung a lot of Vivaldi works during those years on stage, yet the only recorded production is Farnace (under the direction of Fasolis). His appearance in 'Orlando Furioso' as Ruggiero was not videoed as he sung in the alternative cast to Jaroussky under the direction of Spinosi (the Jaroussky performance was commercially released). I would only say that for operatic singers, there is no going back in time. The 'lost' Vivaldi years of as great a singer as Max Emanuel Cencic is the lost of all operatic audiences.This early album affords but a glimpse of Cencic's great interpretations of this composer's works.

This new production is designed by La Fura dels Baus. The arena at Verona is transformed into a huge desert, creating mechanical animals and manufacturing a solar power plant. Their experience in leading large-scale shows and opera enables them to create the Aida of the XXIst century, one that is also splendidly conducted by young talented conductor Omer Meir Wellber.The cast is almost legendary, with Hui He in the title role and Fabio Satori as Radames.  Their voices represent the most beautiful ones available for their respective roles today. In the mezzo-soprano role of Amneris, veteran dramatic soprano/mezzo-soprano Giovanna Casolla gives an unbelievably capable performance of the Egyptian princess.  Well-nigh 70 years of age, this vocal wonder was already 68 years at the time of this performance (in 2013). She never looked one jot her age, both visually or vocally this would well have been a Verdian mezzo-soprano singing in the height of her powers.  It is only when she and Hui He engage in duet that there is some difficulty in distinguishing the voices of the two ladies. This is an overlooked soprano assoluta, who miraculously preserves her voice well into late maturity.Satori has a beautiful Verdian tenor voice, if not outright the most charismatic stage presence.  His duets with Amneris and Aida are both highly convincing, the best voice of this genre since the great Carlo Bergonzi, if not the most stylish yet.This is the third Aida DVD of Hui He that I own, and am in agreement with the lead reviewer that she is best here, both vocally and visually.  The intonation has improved, and her stage presence greatly enhanced by a slight yet significant weight adjustment.This is also my third Aida DVD of the wonderful Verdian baritone Ambrogio Maestri.I got this new Aida for Satori, and am pleasantly surprised by the veteran Casolla, as well as the beautiful Hui He.

Ranking among the best operatic outputs of the great G. F. Handel, alongside the likes of Tamerlano, Alessandro, Rhodelinda, Rinaldo, Alcina, Amadigi di Gaula, Orlando, this opera is among the earliest revived masterpiece of Handel.  As early as the mid-20th century it was being regularly staged, though not in the historically informed mode as in the latter part of the last century.  The work is therefore widely recorded, both live or in studio, and on video as well.  The early revivals of Giulio Cesare in Egitto saw a 're-casting' of roles in the romantic operatic style - Cesare is reserved for a bass-baritone, and great singers like Cesare Siepi and Dietrich Fischer-Dieskau both assumed the role to distinction.Before and since the HIP movement, this opera has posed no small casting problems over the past decades of its revival. The titular hero Cesare is composed for alto castrato (Senesino) and so is the villain Tolomeo. In this production we have two countertenors filling the bills for these two major male characters, and this is a dramatically convincing arrangement.Sesto, on the other hand, was a trouser role in the original version, being sung originally by a mezzo-soprano Margaretha Durastanti. In the early revival period, divers tenors have assumed this role, including Peter Schreier(under Karl Richter). In this production we have new American mezzo-soprano Isabel Leonard singing Sesto. The original Cleopatra was Francesca Cuzzoni. Conductor Haim chose here French compatriot Nathalie Dessay.  This is a wise choice, even if Dessay is no longer in her absolute vocal prime in 2012. She is in more healthy vocal state than a year later at the MET. The young contralto Varduhi Abrahamyan is a rich-voiced Cornelia, if not out right as refined as Patricia Bardon (in the MET version).In the title role Lawrence Zazzo competent, if not outright great. Certain enunciation problem with vowels impeded an otherwise powerful and dramatic performance. Christophe Dumaux is a dramatically outstanding Tolomeo.but both he and Zazzo did not toss the coloraturas and fioriture as they might otherwise would if the conducting is less hectic and angular.Suffering from a similar plight is Abrahamyan's Cornelia. The pathos of her role was not being given full elaboration. New comer Isabel Leonard owns a voice to die for, but has yet to polish it to bring forth real vocal focus in the big arias.  Her stage presence is great and her portrayal of a young boy is very convincing.Tremendous stage activities impede the dramatic flow rather than enhancing them, alas.Nathalie Dessay's attire as Cleopatra is also controversial, but her acting is always pristine and shiny despite all distractions on stage.Veteran character countertenor Dominique Visse is also dramatically oustanding as the eunuch Nireno, though the intonation has flagged some what.New singers like Leonard and Abrahamyan are the main reasons for getting this DVD.

The edition of this book I have was published in 1929. It is an old-fashioned collection of inspirational verse. Many poems are by poets no one knows today. But the volume contains many familiar great works and excerpts which are still of great value today. Longfellow's 'Psalm of Life' Henley's 'Invictus'  Kilmer's 'Trees' MacRae's 'Flanders Fields' Keats 'Ode on a Grecian Urn'. It has a few prose pieces at the end including the 'Gettysburg Address' 'The Ten Commandments' 'The Magna Charta' 'The Declaration of Independence'.How different this Anthology is from the great majority of anthologies  which have been published in the past half- century. For these anthologies do not by and large concern themselves with moral or inspirational matters, but  rather focus  on linguistic and aesthetic elements alone.Here the aim is to reach the soul of , and improve the life of the readers.

This is one of the best books about sports I have ever read. Lipsky was a rabid fan and player in childhood. He did not make it to the big leagues of his dream, but he remained passionately involved. He writes of the greatest moment of his life being when the Knicks led by an injured but heroically determined Willis Reed defeated the Lakers and took an N.B.A.championship. Lipsky knows about all the major sports but his writing goes in a sense beyond Sports. He understands the role it plays as refuge and escape in American life. How the battles on the sports field provide clear victory and decisive outcome in a way much of more murky everyday reality cannot. He understands the special space sports heroes are given, and the drama and intensity of their on-the-field conflicts. He shows how being a fan is for many the great meaning of their lives. He is excellent in quoting outstanding sources in Sports knowledge, including the remarkable novel of Frederick Exley 'A Fan's  Notes'. He shows how the discipline of sports teaches certain basic values including those of cooperation and teamwork. He too shows the secret underbelly of 'Sports' which pretends to be an innocent world apart and is in fact a big business.Lipsky knows the stuff from inside but also knows the way the Sports world tries to sell itself.He writes in a clear and fluent way. An outstanding book.

Ferris is concerned with the connection between the vast world of the cosmos and the vast world of the human mind. In the course of his exploration he presents an exposition of the current scientific knowledge (As of the early nineties of the twentieth century) and many interesting thoughts of his own. One such thought which he outlines in the final chapter of the book struck me as especially interesting. It is the idea that humanity might help other 'minds' or 'civilizations' in the cosmos enhance their understanding of it. i.e. That our messages and information might conceivably be of use to 'others' in developing their own understanding of the cosmos. This idea contradicts the general feeling that other 'intelligent civilizations' are likely to be far more advanced than we are, and not in any way need what we know.

This is one of Agnon's signature works. The tale of the journey across the sea to the land of Israel by a group of Hasidim expresses Agnon's own story and love of the land. Rich and poetic, with a complex language it is suggestive of mystery and enigma. As with other Agnon works there is in each  line much to contemplate and reflect upon. The adventure of the  story is an adventure also of  exploration by the reader. Understanding does not come easily and in a straightforward fashion.Agnon is a writer whose poetic and religious complexity are do sense and rich in Hebrew as to make complete and  accurate translation impossible.

After Kristallnacht on November 9 1939 the British Government allowed 10,000 unaccompanied Jewish children from Germany Austria Czechoslovakia into Great Britain. The Kindertransport saved the lives of these children who would almost certainly been murdered by the Nazis.The children were taken in by various groups some Jewish and some not. Fifty years after this  two of those taken in Bertha Leverton and Shmuel Lowensohn contacted a group of these children and asked them to relate their stories. This book consists in short individual accounts of what happened to these children.Each of the stories is in itself fascinating. Some confine themselves to what happened at the time of their separation from their families and through the war. But others contain reports of the subsequent life stories. Many of the stories are inspiring  tales of lives rebuilt, of  people who did  not allow the horrors of their youth to break them. Not a few of them tell of making new lives in Eretz Yisrael and building families there and contributing to a Jewish society where they hope to find a kind of security they could not find in their native countries.But there are all kinds of stories including that of a wanderer of the world whose security is in his own ability to move on, and of a young man who found his security in enlisting in the British Army and fighting in some of the major battles of the war.The stories are deeply moving as they express in clear and straightforward terms the deepest human feelings and relationships. Love of parents, loss at separation, loneliness and isolation in new worlds, homesickness, sadness and longing for friends and family, appreciation of generous and kind strangers , difficult with harassing and ungenerous 'step-parents'  determination at being able to make new lives.I had the sense that each of the stories, each of the people is worth thinking about and remembering.Through one of the most evil times and experiences humanity has known a remnant was rescued and went on to build new lives and contribute to the building of new worlds.

Turnbull organizes the letters according to Fitzgerald's correspondents. He thus has sections on Fitgerald's letters to his daughter Scottie, to his wife Zelda, to his editor Maxwell Perkins, to his contemporary and friend Hemingway, to assorted others. I found the most interesting section the one in which Fitzgerald works to encourage support and educate his daughter. In the course of this we learn of many other things, including Fitzgerald's devotion to his sick wife Zelda, his constant sense of struggling to make money, his giving great parts of his time to writing screenplays. He is  strict at times and it seems to me unusually honest in trying to educate his daughter. He values hard work and worries very much she will fall into a world of privilege and worthless hedonism. He at the same time reveals his own strong desire that she make it somehow to the world of the privileged.In his letters to Maxwell Perkins we see him struggling with the writing, the correcting of the work, the making of money. What is astonishing is that he seems to have no idea that 'The Great Gatsby' is the one work of his that really makes it into the canon. He spends a lot of time fussing over 'Tender is the Night'. He apparently hated writing stories, but these could be money-makers and so he forced himself at them. My own sense is that they are far from his best work.His letters to Hemingway are a bit deferential. He recognized Hemingway's value and wrote to Maxwell Perkins that Hemingway was the 'real thing'.There are in certain pages of the work the kind of graceful beautiful writing Fitzgerald could be wonderful at. In other passages there are hints of prejudice.narrow-mindedness and pettiness.Money and the struggle for it pervades these letters.

Arnaldo Momigliano was one of the most important students of Jewish life in the world of Greek and Roman antiquity. In the first part this work are collected some of his most important essays including a major one on Flavius Josephus. The part of the book I however enjoyed most was the second half, that contained a large number of biographical essays. In these he writes about Jewish scholars of the classial world (Bernays Bickermanand Finlay)and well- know representatives of modern Jewish thought( Leo Strauss, Gershon Scholem and Walter Benjamin.). He shows a great appreciation for his fellow scholars. One of the best essays in the book is the introduction written by Silvia Berti. She outlines the whole range of Momigliano's scholarly work and provides a concise and convincing evaluation of it.This work is for readers of scholarly works and especially for those interested in Classical Antiquity and Judaism.Again the biographical essays which are in essence career reviews are outstanding.

This is far from being the best and certainly not the most entertaining or humorous of Roth's novels but it is a work of very great and wise perception of human character and situation. Roth is a master at analyzing complex human situations, and characters. In this work his analysis of the character Eve Frame and her dependent relationship with  her daughter is one of the best parts of the work. This relationship many have suggested the relationship between Roth's former wife the actress Claire Bloom and her daughter. Here what is  quite surprising and interesting is the way Roth on the one hand shows the pathetic quality of this dependent relationship while showing in various other connections the great virtues of the characters.  Again it is the complexity and intelligence of the writing which often surprises and delights the reader.As for the major character of the work IronRinn the angry and idealistic IronRinn the Communist who marries Eve I found him a Paul Bunyan like exaggeration.While not being one of Roth's funniest works it still often brings surprising laughter through some unexpected original perception.

Ingrid Bergman is one of the great Hollywood stars, one of the legends. She was also as this very detailed biography makes clear a tremendously hard- working and devoted actress who put her own work and career before anything else in her life. The story of her leaving her first husband and daughter and going off with director Robert Rossellini was one of the great Hollywood scandals. But this tell-it-all biography indicates that 'scandal' was a small part of Bergman's romantic adventures. Leamer's main contention however is that none of these could compete with her own devotion to career and self.This book will tell its reader more about the details of Bergman's life than they will probably want to know. But it also tells a long and complicated tale of a  person's struggles and transformations in life.It is written with true  narrative and dramatic skill. It gives us a sense of the vulnerability and fragility of even the most 'famous' and celebrated.The great physical beauty was not very beautiful in much that she did. But toward her work she had integrity and dedication.

The Edge Question series are invariably interesting and original. They bring together usually about one- hundred eighty or so  individuals most of whom are experts in some scientific or technological area. They provide an opportunity for rich speculation. The question 'What should we be worried about?' is no exception to this.If any reader thought they had a full understanding of the problems humanity is facing this collection should disabuse them of  that notion. It is possible to take tens of examples and illustrate this but I will take two only - the answers of Martin Rees and John Touby.They both talk about possible catastrophic scenarios that could eliminate humanity. Rees speaks about the possibility of a few wicked individuals being able to create viruses there is no way of stopping. Touby makes a long list of cosmic events, from gamma ray bursts to supernovae events which could lead to disastrous consequences for humanity.This  question and its answers like the others in this series provide an intellectual feast, a whole menu of material to think about.The problem is of course that there are so many worries that one has difficulty knowing which are most important to worry about.Another problem is that worrying (At least the worrying that most of us do) will not help provide any answers to the problems.To illustrate the fact that no thought about humanity and human history can be complete I will point to the fact that one of the world's major worries these days, the disintegration of the Middle East, and the ongoing violence between Shiites and Sunnites which is accelerating that disintegration is not even mentioned in this volumeHowever great and varied the worries are given in this book there are no doubt new and surprising ones to come. This by the way is a thought a number of those included in this volume-mention.

As with many memoirs of the Shoah one cannot read this work without wondering what it is to be a human being, without wondering how human beings can be so cruel and evil, without wondering how other human beings can endure horrors and yet remain truly caring and good people. Zev Birger tells the story of his happy childhood in Kovno with his harmonious family two loving parents and an older brother friend. He tells how their world is shattered by the Nazi takeover and formation of the ghetto.He tells of the struggle for survival  in the most inhumane conditions, of his family's trying to stay together, of his losing one by one first his mother then his father then his brother. He tells the story of how he survives the cruelty of the work- camps and the death- camps. He tells of extraordinary incidents of courage, and of one anonymous 'boss' of his who helped him survive through illness. He tells of his liberation by the American Army, his recovery and working with them in the war's aftermath. He tells the story of his meeting with the woman who would become his wife, and the decision to come to Eretz Yisrael.He gives us a picture of how his Zionist and hume ideals helped him and his friends survive. And he relates the story of the new life he makes in Israel and his contributions to the society and world being built there. There he would become an important government official and at some point becoming the movie spirit of the Jerusalem International Book Fair.This is a chilling read a heartbreaking read and yet too evidence of greatness in bearing and overcoming affliction, in working for and loving the good. Birger suffered much from the inhumane treatment of others but never lost his essentially positive and constructive nature. He lost a world, and found and helped build a new one. He lost a loving family and made in Israel a new family of his own.

Eileen Simpson the first wife of the poet John Berryman tells the story here of their meeting and their marriage,  and of  their time spent with the  many poet  friends of their youth. Berryman's closest friend in the early days was the legendary Delmore Schwartz. But Berryman had other important literary friends Robert Lowell and his wife the writer Jean Stafford, Theodore Roethke, Randall Jarrell. Saul Bellow .An atmosphere of adventurous exploration is part of the story, but the greater part is desperation and loss. Simpson  details her difficulty with Berryman's drinking and suicidal impulses, and explains her decision to leave him despite their mutual love. She re-echoes a theme of Schwartz on the sufferings wives of poets seem to necessarily be overburdened with. She has a generous attitude to others and the story of her relationship with Berryman is written in a moving and credible way.

This book is about a war being conducted against Israel and the Jewish people. It is not a war of one single power or source, but rather of many different sources, the `million cuts of the book's title. It is a continuation of war of Nazi Germany which attempted to annihilate every single Jew on earth. This present war does not however focus on destroying individual Jews, but rather aims at destroying the representative and heart of Jewish collective identity, the state of Israel.Manfred Gerstenfeld who is the world's leading expert on European anti- Semitism has in this present volume provided a detailed map of those who are engaged in this campaign of hatred and destruction. While pointing out that the decisive stage of such a campaign would have to be military he indicates two prior stages the first of which is already well under way. The first stage is the total defamation of the state of Israel, the attempt to paint it as the greatest threat to and Evil now facing mankind. This campaign has been waged now for many years, and certainly one major element in this has been the United Nations. Of the over one- hundred eighty countries in the world the one which has been subject to over half of its resolution of condemnation is Israel. Engaging in the kind of inversion of reality which is characteristic of the world- wide anti- Semitic campaign democratic Israel is time and again accused of crimes its totalitarian enemies commit against it.Still the most powerful source of violence against Israel is from the Islamic and Arab world. Here one can point to more than fifty years of anti- Semitic propaganda and hate- messaging. The massive influx of Islamic immigrants to Western countries has given new strength to traditional European anti- Semitism.In the West however there is a development so absurd and hypocritical so frightening that it leads one to wonder what has happened to common sense and common human decency. It is not only the traditional Fascist right, and Islamic fascists who have focused on vilifying Israel it is also their worst enemies the Progressive forces of the Left who have joined this campaign. Those who should support Democracy, human rights, equality, religious freedom, freedom of speech and expression, equality for women, have united with and are supporting the most reactionary and murderous Jihadi forces on earth.Hypocrisy in the West in joining the campaign against Israel is also displayed by other groups .Gerstenfeld devotes separate chapters of his books to other sources of the hate- war. There are chapters on the Media, Social Democrat inciters, Christian inciters including NGO's those engaged in Lawfare against Israel, Academic promoters of boycott against Israeli scholars.The effort to boycott and exclude Israel and Israelis from cooperative and productive effort in all areas of political economic social and cultural life is another major aspect of campaign of destruction. Gerstenfeld makes a strong argument for a counter- campaign which would be promoted by a special Israeli government office aimed at countering such efforts. He believes that the Israeli government and people have not taken the threat of boycott seriously often as they have focused on what has been the greater and more immediate danger, the various military challenges Israel has faced through the years.An Israeli offensive strategy which makes skillful use of the new media is for Gerstenfeld a sine qua non for winning the battle.Thus Gerstenfeld also devotes much space to showing how the Internet and modern means of communication have facilitated the spreading of Hatred. Another reason why there are 'a million cuts'is that the haters can so easily distribute their lies. And Lying as Gerstenfeld repeatedly points out is an absolutely  essential element in the war against Israel.He also indicates albeit indirectly how this how Culture of Lying and Hate so pervasive today constitutes a threat first of all to Israel but also Democracy and human decency for humanity as a whole.The book is powerful and wide-ranging and truly displays the extent and danger of the war of defamation now taking place.It is a must read not only for those who care about the Jewish state but for all those who care about the future of humanity.

In his introduction to this book Francis O'Gorman describes a number of systematic theoretical approaches to the subject which he refrains from using. Instead he tells us that he is going to grope his way to an understand of a very commonplace and common reality which a great share of humanity lives and suffers with. As a great worrier myself I appreciate very much the attention he gives, and the insight he has on the subject. Take one thing which has always bothered me. Perhaps it is because I am a traditional religious person. But I am always worried that if I do not worry the thing I do not worry about will happen. O'Gorman explains that this kind of need to worry as a kind of sacrificial payment to prevent the thing worried about from happening is also most commonplace. Worriers worry that if they do not worry they will be punished for not worrying.Worriers as we all know also waste enormous amounts of time tormenting themselves and others with needless worries. They also often discover problems which others ignore. Worry can also help.This is a book which I believe will help most readers better understand ourselves.

Nabokov is one of the most brilliant stylists Literature has known. Every sentence of his contains a surprise. His  descriptions are metaphorically rich, and make everything he perceives more than it is. This is true of Nabokov as storywriter as well as novelist.His stories are less well-known and satisfy less. This particular collection is rich in stories of disaster, and disappointment.The opening story 'Spring in Fialta' is the story of a married man's affair with an elusive and unfaithful lover. The stories which most impressed me were 'Signs and Symbols' and 'The Aurelian'. The first is the story of two parents contending with a mentally- troubled son who they reluctantly bring home from an institution. It is perhaps the only story that I found myself having some real sympathy for the characters. Nabokov is often a cold precise and exacting narrator whose irony and brilliance make it somehow less possible to feel for his characters. Often he himself has ironic distance and seems to simply be playing with them. His surprises in this sense are not simply in his language but in the turns the stories so often unpredictably take. In another favorite 'The Aurelian' a small shop owner dreams of a global- circling butterfly hunting expedition. This story gives insight into the world- famous lepidopterist Nabokov. The story has a disastrous ending which nonetheless seems to point beyond the everyday to a kind of transcendence Nabokov seemed to preserve for the aesthetic imagination.These stories are set in the thirties and they contain tales of exile, and violent displacement. Nabokov showsin them his anti- Fascist and anti- Communist , his anti- totalitarian sympathies. A supreme individualist with an elite sense of all that is wondrous in sensual reality he time and again brings the reader to amazement at his  literary genius.

Pnin is in many ways my favorite Nabokov book. Its bumbling awkward humorous endearing hero is the Russian expatriate teaching at an American university. At his core he is a person of great integrity and intelligence who carries with him a weight in suffering from his European past. Pnin is a vulnerable suffering and generous hero. He is manipulated by his former wife Erica Wind but his love for her persists. In his frequent recollections the story of his love for Mira Belochkin a Jewish woman murdered in the Shoah is revealed.Pnin is kind to a stepson who he treats as a son. .The language here as always with Nabokov is brilliant but I found it clearer and more understandable than in some of the more famous American works.This is the work that introduced Nabokov to the United States and first firmly established his reputation in it.To my mind there is no more purely enjoyable Nabokov work than this.

For me the truly interesting part of this book was not the sociological analysis but rather the stories of individuals. Some of these stories detailed incredible hardships of a wide variety of Americans. Some chronicle lives of well-known  Americans, Sam Walton, Robert Rubin, Peter Thiel,Elizabeth Warren, Raymond Carver.Packer is above all a  a journalist and his stories are factually rich without being particularly overwhelming emotionally. His scope is broad and in writing about those from different levels of society he gives a kind of overall  portrait of the United States today.

This small dictionary is organized alphabetically and focuses on everyday words and concepts. It is the kind of work to be dipped into, and enjoyed bit by bit. Its definitions are of course not comprehensive and there is a lightness to the work as a whole.Among the many enjoyable and wise words here is a small sample.CERTAINTY The only certainty is that nothing is certain. Pliny the ElderCHARACTER Character is that which can do without success Ralph Waldo EmersonJAZZ  American Folk Music .  George GershwinABSENCE  Absence diminishes little passions and increases great ones, just as the wind blows out a candle and fans a fire. La RouchefoucauldLIFE  A tragedy for those who feel, and a comedy for those who think. La BruyereSEVENTY- FIVE  An age at which few grow stronger.

Rabbi Shlomo Riskin is one of the most important  figures in the Jewish world today. His contributions to the Jewish people and Israel are by this time legendary, from the work he did in Lincoln Square Synagogue to the work done in Israel, founding the city of Efrat and the whole network of Ohr Stone Torah religious institutions. He has done courageous work in many other areas including work for the liberation of Soviet Jewry, and for the enhancement of women's role in religious life.Rabbi Riskin is a popular speaker and columnist, writer and thinker. In this work he touches upon a whole list of subjects which are at the center of Jewish life today. For instance in the question of whether it is religiously permissible to cede parts of the land of Israel in order to make peace he distinguishes between an ideal situation and today's present reality. In a situation where there would be a true partner for Peace compromise he suggests is permissible. But given the reality at this present historical juncture he sees that ceding of land now would now save lives but rather endanger Israel itself.Rabbi Riskin in each of the essays uses his deep knowledge of Gemara and traditional Jewish learning to address questions such as " Authority versus Autonomy: On Parents and Children,Masters and Disciples,  Who's an Apikoros?  Aguna Problem in our Time, Women and the Torah Scroll, Judaism and Democracy, the Significance of Israel's Return to Zion: Tikkun Olam.This book is a treasure of Jewish thought for all those who care about the Jewish situation today. It could not be more highly recommended.

Pearce begins by taking on the gloom of Malthus ( and Paul Ehrlich) and points out that in many areas of the world population is in decline. He does extensive traveling to investigate what is going on in population development in many different parts of the world. His writing on the subject is informed and detailed. I checked this in regard to one area of the world I know best, Israel. His writing on the ultra-Orthodox community and its unusually high - rate of population growth is by and large fair and judicious. As Pearce believes the true villain in the ecological struggle for a  better planet is consumption rather than numbers alone, he is not particularly critical of the Hasidim. After all they are generally very poor, value spiritual attainment rather than material attainment and so are not great consumers. For Pearce the ecological problem comes from that seven percent of the world's population that consumes fifty percent of its product.As he sees it not only in Europe but also in China, India, the Americas population growth has either slowed down or gone negative. The one continent where it continues at a  rapid rate, Africa, is the continent of poor people and low consumption.This book is valuable in the detailed picture he gives of dozens of local fertility and demographic developments.His generally optimistic view is that a world which has a more middle- aged older population will be a wiser one. These elderly people will have to work for more years but they will be encouraged in this by their improved medical situation.

In writing this work Tuvia Tenenbom  displayed a remarkable amount of initiative, energy and courage. A Jew living in Germany who was born in Israel he presents himself as a German Christian so as to be able to speak openly with Palestinians of all different stripes. His disguise also helps him sometimes in speaking with Israelis. The fundamental finding of his work is the enormous prejudice, and even hatred held by the Palestinians for the Israelis. He also reveals the superficiality, the historical ignorance and the hypocrisy of many of the Palestinians. Foremost among them is Hanna Ashrawi who does everything to try and get out of explaining why the Christian population of Ramallah and Bethlehem has disappeared, and why the Muslim majority tolerates no one with a different religion.But Tenenbom is  also highly critical of Israelis both of the Left -Wing and the Right. Perhaps his  most fierce criticism is for Benedict Arnold-like creatures such as Gideon Levi and Uri Aloni who without speaking any Arabic and so knowing Palestinian culture in any significant way nevertheless have devoted their careers to stigmatizing Israel and worshipping the Palestinians.Tenenbom does meet people he respects, but overwhelmingly his interlocutors are shown to be fanatical and hate- filled.He too has special venom for the European would- be-do-gooders especially the Germans who constantly work to undermine Israel.Tenenbom has an unusual sense of humor which is at work throughout and which very occasionally got a laugh out of me. The book is long but is an easy read , a piece of colloquial journalism.My great reservation about the book regards the kinds of people he spoke with on the Israeli side. He does not really get to a broad- section of the people but focuses on extremists from both sides. He underestimates it seems to me the strength of Israel's people though he often expresses admiration for the accomplishments of the Jewish state.I have lived in Israel for close to forty years but I nonetheless learned quite a bit from this work.This is an amusing take on a very sad and difficult situation.

This book's title is misleading. It is not 1001 books from all areas of the world of books. It does not contain non- fiction. It does not contain the great religious classics of humanity. It focuses very much on imaginative literature from the year 1800 or so. It contains a disproportionate number of British works. It mixes up works of enormous value and significance with minor works very few have heard or will ever hear of. It does however try very hard to describe the works in a positive way, show their unique value. It too includes a vast variety of literary works from throughout the world.I used the book not only to refresh my memory of books I have read but also to learn about books that I had heard of, and was curious as to the character of. The book is enjoyable and interesting in this way. However I would again protest against the notion of 'must read before you die'. I have in many years of reading read a small percentage of these works, and there are very few I would call 'must reads'. Why is it always necessary to 'hype' things? This book involved a great effort by its editor who should be applauded for the work done. Most of the entries are very well written and provide information and enjoyment as things in themselves.PS I must add something in strong favor of the book. I have been reading it now off and on and in small doses for about two months. I make discoveries of books that are new for me all the time. I take great pleasure in reading once again about books that I have read and thought about in the past. There is a great amount to learn here. The entries are usually very well- written if nonetheless scant.A valuable resource and a source of enjoyment despite its flaws.

This is a survey work consisting on groups of columns on twenty different subjects related to brain science. There is much valuable information provided in each of the sections but there are also far-ranging conclusions and generalizations which are questionable. I found the section on Alzheimer's with its descriptions of various paths to dementia, its account of the seven stages of Alzheimer's, and its sense that at least in one sense it can be seen as a speeded up form of the process of aging- most interesting. Swaab who is a senior neuroscientist in Netherlands contributes to this work the knowledge and understanding gained from a lifetime of study and research on the subject. He does however have biases. His justifiable condemnation of hard contact sports especially boxing, American football and rugby for the brain- damage they cause is overshadowed by his wholesale condemnation of Sport and Exercise in general. His one-sided analysis of religious behavior totally ignores the findings  regarding the beneficial aspects of religious worship. His rightful emphasis on the importance of genetics in determining much about human character and identity becomes at a point a downplaying of the significance of external factors in shaping  human character. But again there is much to learn here about subjects such as human aggression, autism, schizophrenia , addictive substances, puberty love and sexual behavior,sexual differentiation of the brain in the womb, moral behavior, memory. et. al. The book is very clearly written and truly readable, designed for the general reader. Perhaps this is the reason it lacks scholarly apparatus, and is without references and footnotes.

This book is more than a cookbook. It also a work of social history and provides insight into the American Jewish community historically. I cannot judge the recipes but one especially good cook I know has found the recipes appealing and interesting. The book is also  designed in a good way and has many photographs of great interest.Highly recommended

Bret Stephens is one of the world's most astute analysts of American foreign policy. In this book he presents the present day position of America in the world and argues that radical transformation of present day policy is needed. He believes that President Obama has retreated on all fronts and adopted a view of America's role in the world which will lead to disaster in the decade ahead. As he understands it the Obama policy of retreat has enabled forces inimicable to Democracy, and Freedom to advance. Yet his argument is not for an ideological-based kind of foreign policy advocated by the Bush Administration. Rather he proposes that America once again take on the role it  often has been blamed for having, as world's policeman. Stephens shows that the U.S. alone is capable of adopting such a role. He also argues that a more forceful and interventionist when necessary foreign -policy will be to the benefit of others as well as to the U.S. Observing the Iranian takeover of areas of the Middle East, the Russian expansion into Ukraine and potentially other Eastern European areas, the aggressiveness of the Chinese in the South China Sea he argues that all of this has happened in part because of American weakness. He also speaks about the downsizing of American military power and how this presents a danger to future security. In making these arguments he is critical not only of Democratic liberals but also of Republican conservative isolationists. He argues that a strong involved America is good for the world, and be of ultimate benefit to all of Mankind. Only American can do it and if it does not do it he sees more chaos and disaster ahead for humanity.

This is a layman's review of pocket guide to Clinical Medicine which is directed toward health- care professionals. Its language is a mixture of the very technical and the commonplace so a layman can use it to enrich both their medical knowledge and vocabulary. I of course cannot comment on it in professional terms, but as a general leader I find it informative.On the other hand and in another way it is distressing to bit to read through the too rich chronicle of possible human ailments.Almost all of what is written here I believe most laymen would rather not know about.I suppose there are more up-to-date versions of this guide which professionals need not schlep around in book-form but rather have on their electronic reading devices.Sic passit gloria the hardcover.

This book reveals yet another set of evidence to confirm the general contention that  Abraham Lincoln is American President whose best embodied its democratic values. In detailing the story of Lincoln's connection with the Jewish community of his time,  they also show what a generous, warm, fair- minded and kindly human being Lincoln was. Lincoln never indulged in a common discriminatory attitude of his time toward the Jewish community. He had a number of important Jewish friends including one Abraham Jonas who played a role in moving him toward the Presidency. He cancelled Grant's infamous decree expelling the Jews from the war zone during the Civil War.Lincoln was inspired by the Hebrew Bible throughout his life and its language and concepts inform his writings and speeches.This book is a special treat both for those who take an interest in American Jewish history and for all those who cherish the legacy of Lincoln.

The editor of this work Stephan Gill traces in his introduction the development of Wordsworth as a poet. The Anthology contains the work of Wordsworth from the beginning and includes the major masterpieces. Wordsworth was the great uniter of the simple and sublime in poetry, who made of the language of everyday a great philosophical poem of beautyThis is of course one of many editions of his works, but it provides the bonus of a most capable introduction and survey of the work as a whole.

I can think of only two very great poets William Blake and Emily Dickinson who have the same kind of density, intensity, compression of meaning that Menashe has. His poems are even smaller than theirs, and always contain within them a suggestiveness, multiplicity of meaning, metaphorical richness.These poems call out also for  memorization  recollection and repetition.I think that anyone who reads and rereads them will enrich their own spiritual worlds.

Emily Dickinson is one of the supreme originals. There seems no one and nothing like her. Her poems are riddles and gifts, beautiful and mysterious, surprising and always interesting. Every poem raises questions whose answers will always be suggestions only. Helen Vendler is a master critic whose readings enrich our knowledge, whether we agree with them or not. Putting together one of the world's greatest poets with one of the world's supreme critics is a combination which can only enhance the reader's appreciation and understanding.

This work is a masterpiece of memoir writing.Life-wisdom great intelligence remarkable beauty in writing are pervasively present in the four separate memoirs combined together as one here. I will cite here only a few of the subjects I especially appreciated her writing about. Her account of her mother's passing from the world, her family history in relation to longevity, the story of her coming out of nowhere and winning the Observer story-competition and in a sense being recognized and encouraged as a writer, her writing about 'mortality' in general, her exuberance in describing the way she reads, the story of her love life and her disappointing great love affair, the joy she found in sexual experience, the pleasure of 'seeing' as she describes it in her travel experience, her vignettes of many different individuals she encounters in her life, her description of her own 'laziness' her description of hunting and how those who hunt somehow know animals best, even those she also deplores the practice. I could go on and on. I also could make a couple objections to life- choices and attitudes. But on the whole this is a wonderful memoir a joy to read.

Athill is a remarkable writer and a remarkable human being. She sees and appreciates Beauty in life, and enhances the readers sense of life's richness and possibility. She brings her own unique way of seeing and feeling things to all her experience. In  a sense the center of this book is the story of her broken engagement to Paul, the great first love of her life. How this led her to the world of book-publishing, and an independent life is one part of the story. But the story also includes the record of her growing up at her grandmother's estate Beckton in East Anglia, the record of her three gloriously free years at Oxford, the years of working in London with Andre Deutsch in creating a respectable list of books. When she writes about her love of reading, about her experiences in travel she does so with clarity and grace.As a struggling woman largely alone she made one decision she shows no regret for, which I believe she should have, the termination of her only pregnancy. Her way of writing about this I found objectionable.This marred for me what would otherwise seem to be a Masterpiece of Memoir writing

This book is rich in fascinating information on the history of cooking. Its focus is not on the 'what' of cooking but on the why and how . It gives special attention to the tools of cooking and shows how they have altred in history. It relates the way many tasks and tools once used  in drudgery have become sources of play and pleasure in cooking. It tells us how we went from cooking by fire along to frying and boiling.  Pots and pans have their own history as do forks and spoons. There  is a chapter on the kitchen and its special role in family life. Coffee making too is given in its own special chapter relating on how the once most in-technology of the big machines has been at least in some places superseded by hand technologyWith all this  the book is missing something, and the feeling is it could  be more humorous and pleasurable than it is. Perhaps this is because storytelling is not at  its heart.Still it is  a very interesting  read.Sti

This book presents an idea and ideal of human aging that is different from the one most people hold. As Anne Karpf most people believe aging begins at a certain specific age, forty, fifty, sixty- five, seventy. In fact we begin aging from conception and our ideas of this aging are transformed in time. The young eager to grow up and have the freedom from restrictions are one pole of this. The young dreading the responsibility of adulthood and wishing to remain in a childhood world are another aspect. Karpf details the dread of going old so pervasive in our culture, and the various means we try to halt or reverse this process. The negative view of aging and the old is she claims very strong in our society. The Aged are those doubly condemned , first for being useless, and second for taking up the resources that the young might use. This view is increasingly prevalent as the numbers of those and percentage of those in our society over the age of seventy increase.Against the negative views of aging so commonly held Karpf argues for a more positive and balanced view. Each age of life according to her as its gains and losses. The benefits of aging can be a new kind of freedom, a freedom to be more truly oneself, a freedom from fear of the opinion of others, a freedom to give one's time and energy to those activities one loves. Without in any way minimizing the difficulties and even horrors that can come with old age Karpf shows how for many it is a most satisfying time of life. Realizing there is an end to come may very well deepen one's sense of life's pleasures and meaning.This  is  a highly recommended, excellently written and important work.

I found the parts of the narrative done by Joseph Heller more interesting than those done by Speed Vogel. Heller writes with intelligence and insight about his illness, and about the support he receives from friends and family.There is a no-nonsense realistic quality to the writing. On the other hand the book was hyped as especially funny but I did not find it so.Being funny is different from talking about being funny.I found the book informative but not especially interesting or exciting. Perhaps this is not the fault of the book but relates to my having read so many medical stories lately.

Athill opens this memoir of her childhood by giving an account of her mother's last days. The Athills or many of them live into their nineties with their mental facilities intact. When Athill comes to see her fading mother, the mother awakes and gives her a tremendous happy smile. Her death is difficult for some hours but is largely a 'good one' surrounded by loving family. Athill then chronicles the story of her childhood in the estate of her grandparents in Suffolk. Wealthy and isolated, closely connected with nature, the love of reading and the love of horseback riding are prominent parts. Athill give a gripping account of her parents' unhappy marriage. She then tells us of her first gropings at romance, and how the world of her imagination develops.She  is a clear, forthright writer whose writing is pervaded by a kind of aesthetic grace.

Wolfe is always interesting.In the opening and title essay of this work 'Hooking Up' he amusingly and it seems to me dismayingly chronicles the new sexual morality that 'liberated' the United States from any sense of moral restraint. He shows how 'everyman and every woman too' has thanks in part to the Internet turned into a kind of hedonistic narcissist. He shows how the lover middle class working America has become more luxurious and corrupt than ancient Rome. He does not however clearly foresee the kinds of economic strain and disintegration that will come to this class, and make it far more unhappy in the years to come.In for me the most interesting essays he writes on  the new Neuroscience and the way Evolutionary Psychology has become the first intellectual fashion. He somewhat exaggeratedly (But what is Tom Wolfe without exaggeration?) refuses to the biologist Edward Wilson as the 'second Darwin'.He tells the story of how Wilson and Marshall Macluhan made use of the cosmic evolutionary vision of convergence made by Teillhard de Chardin. In the course of it he tells the story of the Church's  prohibiting the publication of deChardin's writing and this great man's death alone in a small New York hotel room. He too writes about MacLuhan and his ideas, as well as in one long essay detailing the story of Robert Noyce the  somewhat unheralded pioneering figure of the whole Internet revolution. In the course of this he writes about the small town mores of mid-America and Grinnell College. Wolfe often repeats himself and he more than once exalts Neitzche for having prophetically foreseen the post-modern and post-moral mentality of the twentieth and twenty- first century. Without the restraint of Divine morality and punishment Neitzsche saw humanity as grouping itself into fierce warring mercyless tribes. Instead of Teillhard's convergence in ascenscion there is the precipitous decline into barbaric amorality. Wolfe describes and opines on much of this, also showing great concern about the neuroscientific effort to map the self, and in doing so doing away with the autonomy of consciousness, human freedom and the soul.Wolfe does not go deep in exploring these subjects but is an excellent and enjoyable guide in briefly outlining what is at stake.On more familiar ground for him he in two other essays takes apart two journalistic sacred cows, the New Yorker and the New York times. It is well to remember Wolfe once wrote for the now defunct "NY Magazine' In another essay he gets his revenge upon three writers Mailer Updike and John Irving who have called him a 'no novelist'. His success in full he thinks is envied by these three to him literary dinosaurs.Again he amuses and entertains and informs and excites the reader. Even if some of it is the same stylistic tics we are long familiar with.

This recollection of her years in publishing reveals Athill to have been a loyal editor and friend to many outstanding writers. The book contains many stories of the hit-and-miss business of publishing. Athill who loved reading as a child and saw it as a way of expanding her world remained faithful to the love of reading throughout her life. She also cared greatly for certain writers who she not only worked with but became the friend of. For anyone who wishes to knows the ins and outs of 'British book publishing this is an outstanding memoir.

Diana Athill writes with clarity, directness, and modesty about the last chapter of life. She tells the story of the consolations she finds in 'making things' in gardening in driving her car. She speaks about her family's history of longevity and tells us about the ways people she has been close to have died. She relates her own first experience of encountering a corpse.She writes too about her own personal affairs, her romantic and sexual life, the story of her one great romantic disappointment and the more practical attitude she took afterwards. She writes about caring in old age for a long-time friend of hers who was once her lover. She speaks of how she was educated to modesty and how this has stayed with her. She also apparently was educated to competence for she seems to do all she does in a reasonable and clear way. She tells about her religious or loss of religious feelings, and her relation or absence of relation to any idea of an afterlife, or the consolation that might come with it. I feel differently from her on this but at least she does not 'preach' her non-belief but simply and honestly reports it. She writes about a stage of life which there once was little written about but which there is now more and will be much written about. As the world ages and as more and more people face the various crises of longevity the literature on this subject will certainly grow. But this is certainly a respectable contribution to the literature made by someone whose writing clearly deserves the great respect it is given.

There is a tremendously moving story in this book. It is that of Yitta Schwartz a survivor of the concentration oung children there. After the war and time in Belgium she came to America. As her small Hasidic group had been destroyed she joined the larger Satmar group. When she died she had over two- thousand descendants. In one of the chapters of the book Berger tells the story of her life, a life emblematic of the great Hasidic demographic recovery after near total destruction by the Nazis.Berger's broader purpose is to give a portrait of Hasidism in America. He focuses a lot on one group the Satmar who are in certain ways atypical. He briefly recounts the story of their leader without speaking about his dubious escape during the War, and the leaving of his Hasidim behind. He describes the insular life style of the Hasidism and explains their way of life in largely sympathetic terms. He notes that their rapid growth means that they will be in the future a much larger and important segment of the American Jewish community. He notes that they are already thirty percent of the Jewish population of New York City, and with their numbers doubling every twenty years as the secular community assimilates will constitute a much larger percentage of the total community in the future.He writes too about their conflicts with various governmental bodies related to their own special demands for public services of certain kinds, and this when they have their own independent educational system. He writes of their conflict in upstate New York with poorer populations when the Hasidism who do not use the public school system insist on lower taxes which means poorer education for others.
