He too writes of their insular and inappropriate dealing with sex offenders in their midst. He shows their insularity often means lack of consideration for the broader  American community. Another element of this is that the male population devoted to traditional Gemara learning has poor command of English and does not have full participation in the work force. At one point Berger contrasts the remarkable success of the broader Jewish community in the past century. They were able to enter and make contributions to almost every area of American life. The Hasidic groups will being so insular make no such contribution.Berger closes with a chapter on the way the Hasidic groups spend their summers in the Catskills. He talks much about Kiryat Yoel near Monticello New York. He again contrasts with this with the very different kinds of Jewish immigrants who populated these areas in the thirties, forties and fifties of the twentieth century. The Hasidim show no hunger for this kind of participation.One senses that Berger has mixed feelings about the Hasidic groups in this regard. I too have concern that the Jewish people not lose itself to living wholly isolated from the world. Self-exile is also Exile.Berger does not really go into this, but another problematic element at least of Satmar Hasidism is their negative relation to the Jewish state. Here too the question is of whether a group wholly focused on its own need , oblivious to the wider community can be truly seen as a positive and beneficial force.

This book is Robert McAfee Brown's attempt to describe and present in the most sympathetic way possible the work and message of Elie Wiesel. As a highly respected Protestant theologian Brown makes a genuine and to my mind successful effort to understand the world and experience of one of the most important Jewish witnesses of the Shoah or Holocaust. He speaks of Wiesel's being a messenger for the dead victims, as being the one who tells their story and in this sense keeps them alive. He speaks of Wiesel's being a messenger to the living in teaching the consequences of the Shoah and in warning against Man's inhumanity to Man in the human future. He shows how Wiesel has been an important witness to other human tragedies, a spokesman for those seeking to prevent future evils. He speaks of Wiesel's being a messenger to God in questioning contending and arguing with God. He shows how Wiesel is first and above all a storyteller and a seeker, one who believes more in the questions than in the answers.And in showing this kind of sympathy and understanding , Brown too reveals his own deep humanity.This is in a sense a work of literary criticism but in another way it  is a religious one, and one whose message is not for the Jewish people alone but for humanity as a whole.

This book was published in 2003. Much has happened in the world of Hillary Clinton since including her Senate term, her unsucccessful run for the Democratic nomination  for the Presidency, her serving as Secretary of State. What is interesting is that in all these roles she has been true to the picture given of herself in this memoir. She is responsible, competent, clear-thinking and principled. She is forthright and assertive, and she deals with problems rather than running from them.She is also methodical straightforward and without tremendous charisma or charm. She is a hard- working politician and this memoir is filled with stories of her actions and decisions.  If I compare it to the autobiographical memoir of the candidate who defeated her for the nomination and later became her boss, it is clear that he is the far better writer and storyteller. As she apparently hopes to be the candidate for the Democrats in 2016 and eventually the President it is to be hoped that if elected she would do a better job  than he has done.In this memoir we learn of her childhood, her relation with her parents, her acquiring of political and religious principles. We learn of her education at Wellesley and Yale, her meeting with and relationship with her husband, their years in Arkansas, when he becomes a popular governor, loses an election , makes a great comeback. We learn of the way she has dealt with the various scandals regarding herself and her husband. We learn of her being a real people person who expresses by and large positive evaluations of a very wide circle of people. She is very smart, and also savvy politically. We also learn about her handling crises, both family and political. She says her role as mother has been most important to her.The book is not an exciting read but an important one if one wishes to know about the person who may well become the most powerful person in the world, and the first woman President of the United States.

This is the last volume of Leonard Woolf's biography.It centers on the period after his wife's suicide but does include a description of the conditions leading to the suicide, and reflections on his wife and his work. However most of this work involves description of Woolf's own work, especially his managing and directing Hogarth Press. Here his relationship with his some time business partner John Lehmann is given extensive analysis.Woolf includes in the book  a copy of his wife's most moving suicide note. She thanks him for the great happiness they have had together and tells him that no one could have been a better husband than him. Clearly she considered him and wished to free him of any guilt for her decision.Woolf details the horrible period leading up to the Second War and the destruction of the bombing of Britain. The desolation of this time clearly had a major effect on Virginia Woolf.Woolf gives a quite amusing account of his work-life detailing the many hours he spent. He attributes his work ethic to the example of his father and his father's drawing his strength from the Jewish religious tradition. Woolf was I believe the most prominent Jewish figure of the Bloomsbury group. He relates to his own Jewishness with understanding and pride. He is not religious but values the Jewish religious tradition and what it has given humanity in terms of standards of morality and justice. And in fact it is his sensitivity to injustice which is clearly the strongest motivating factor of his work life.He shows understanding of his wifes work arguing that the straightforward, fact -anchored works , the biographies for instance limit her imagination. And that her freedom of imagination was much greater in the works focusing on inner worlds and consciousness.Woolf in quite modestly evaluating the good done by his work life sees it as very little. He does not mention that posterity values him not for his own business or political activity but for being the nurturer and supporter of one of the twentieth century's major writers.One more point. Woolf has a very cordial and modest tone. He writes about himself with competence and it seems to me objectivity.A good person who enabled a great one to be.

Herb Keinon has been a writer for the Jerusalem Post for over thirty years. In between his writing on political and diplomatic matters he has written lighter pieces usually related to his family story. It was the story of American immigrants in Israel and the kinds of adjustments and surprises they found here. Keinon collects in this book these domestic columns and groups them in  four sections, Spring, Summer, Fall, Winter. In these columns there is a lot of comparison between American and Israeli realities and social customs. There is also much written about the differing perceptions of Keinon and his wife's generation, and that of their Israeli native born children. Many of the experiences written about here will be familiar to Israelis , including the major one of worrying about one's children in the Army. Keinon 's voice is a quite calm and normal one.It is as if he is showing despite the wars and struggles there is nonetheless ordinary life going on in Israel, in which many of the same problems families face everywhere are faced here. A very pleasurable read.

This book is a very rich collection of essays that focus on the attempts to boycott and sanction one state out of the world's close to two -hundred the state of Israel. Its first section deals with the general  question of academic boycotts and why and how they oppose the first principle of academic life i.e. freedom of inquiry and investigation. Open dialogue in search of the truth. Martha Nussbaum makes a strong defense of academic freedom using a case in the India province of Gujurat as extreme example.. Paul Berman writes of the century long story of  economic boycotts against Israel. In her essay Emily Bucick shows the absence of proper academic values, the failure to do proper research and pay respect to the facts displayed by supporters of the Boycott. At their heart has always been an effort to delegitimize and ultimately destroy Israel.And in fact many of the essays show the false face of the BDS movement. It claims to be a human rights movement but in fact is not a supporter of two states for two peoples, but rather aims at destruction of Israel. Its ideology is one which denies any national or even human rights to the Jewish people. It is in fact an anti-Semitic movement as some of the essays in the last section of the book clearly establish.The book has over thirty essays in four sections. There is a tremendous amount of information on Israel , on the experience of academics in Israel, on the whole character of the Middle East conflict, on the aims of the boycotters and the forces in the world which support them.The book also provides a history of what has actually happened throughout America in terms of the various boycott resolutions. They have had some success in undergraduate resolutions but none at at all in leading to institutional boycotts of Israel.This book is a must read for all students not only of the Middle East, and Israel, but of all those who care about academic  freedom , and in fact human freedom in general.

This anthology focusing on the last days of Socrates contains the Platonic Dialogues 'Euthrypho' 'Apology' 'Crito' and 'Phaedo'. Plato tells the story of the last days of his teacher and hero, Socrates. Socrates in defending himself against charges of corruption shows a courage in the face of death, and a moral integrity in standing for the Good in spite of the price he will pay for it. In 'The Apology' he makes a statement of defense for himself which involves his admitting his uncertainty as to what  is to come after the grave. This  is in true keeping the model of wisdom that he has presented and been condemned for . For this most wisest of Athenians is deemed so for repeatedly breaking down the mistaken certainty and false assumptions. The great questioner who knows that he does not know for certain, whose wisdom is an understanding of the limitation of wisdom provides an example of intellectual and moral integrity that still resonates with us today.

In her preliminary remarks Daphne Merkin tells of her adolescent dream of having long luncheon conversations with famous yet broken inside figures who she would heal and be healed by.In this collection of her essays, and book -reviews she may not achieve the healing but conducts the meetings and makes of them especially interesting and probing encounters. She writes with great intelligence and perception about a whole list of diverse characters  Marilyn Monroe Virginia Woolf Alice Munro , Ted Hughes and Sylvia Plath John Updike Michael Jackson, Henry Roth Princess Diana .Forty-six pieces in all are in the collection with the literary world and the Hollywood world especially well represented. She writes too very candidly about herself , her lifelong struggle with depression, her own particular struggles within and without her family. The essays are by and large a great pleasure to read, intellectual entertainment at its best.

I have not read the award-winning historical fiction of Hilary Mantel. She has a huge reputation and so my expectations for this collection were very great. I was disappointed. The stories are competently done and not without interest, especially'The Heart without Warning' a story of a dysfunctional family trying to help an anorexic daughter. Also the opening story 'Sorry to Disturb' with its detailing the confines of life in Saudi Arabia also was of interest. The title story on the other hand which involves the relationship between a wealthy householder and an IRA gunman who comes to assassinate the British Prime Minister did not really grip me. There are surprising endings in the story and a smooth surface of narrative but I missed deep feeling , strong love of character, humor, and a deep connection with the struggles of life.

This look at the cultural and social meaning of a decade was actually written in the decade following it. Dickstein sees the sixties as a transformational decade in American  life and surveys its meaning in poetry and fiction, in politics and journalism, in the general social life of the United States. In doing this he mixes his analysis with autobiographical experiences and reflections, indicating his own inherent conservatism opened up to many of the new developments in the Age. The transition from the staid conformist fifties to the radical sixties is one which left in Dickstein's analysis a lasting effect on American culture. For the idea of the all importance of 'personal self- fulfillment' which was a leading idea of the Sixties has  persisted in American life. Dickstein is at his best in his analysis of Literature, and I found the chapter on Rock Music a bit shaky, though I am no means a maven myself in this area. He writes with clarity and perception, and for those interested in knowing about this tumultous decade in a deeper way this book is highly recommended.

This is Borges first collection of stories. It is clear that he is searching to define his distinctive voice. And yet that voice is in this collection and the unique way he combines his vast knowledge with his imaginative power of recreation his evidenced already in the opening tale 'The Dread Redeemer Lazarus Morell'. In the very first page he takes one event' a scheme for importing blacks , so that they might languish in the hellish workpits of Antillean gold mines and from what he ironically calls 'this odd philanthropic twist' imagines there has come endless things from W.C. Handy'sblues to the mythological dimensions of Abraham Linoln, the five hundred thousand dead of the Civil War and its three thousand three hundred millions spent on military pensions' etc. The fabulous conconting of strange realities from high life and low, from history and daily life give the sign of a remarkably unique writer. The  collection might seem uneven with certain tales 'Monk Eastman Purveryor of Iniquities' and 'Streetcorner Man' being more interesting than others. But for me any Borges work is a source of interest and real entertainment.  As Kierkegaard once indicated there is a kind of writer who even the errors of become part of the composition and bring to it revelatory delight.

Heidi has the perfect husband. Tucker is kind, loving, honest and he loves her unconditionally. In fact, he loves her so much he invites her fantasy, rocker Ransom Reed into their bed for a scorching hot night she never dreamed would happen. Only that one night makes Heidi realize just how much she wants more. It also makes it even more obvious there are problems in their marriage. Not to mention Ransom wants more of Heidi as well.I enjoyed this book, yet I had mixed feelings about it. I hated that Tucker was being hurt by Heidi's obvious feelings for another man. He loved her so much he'd give her anything, even another man. While Heidi fought with her conscious over what she should or shouldn't do - I didn't feel like she fought hard enough. I also felt sorry for Ransom. He was a lonely man who had everything but the one thing he truly wanted. I felt Heidi used him as much as she did Tucker.The last chapter hints at the next book in the series. I hope he'll get the HEA he deserves. As an added bonus, it was good catching a peek of Justice again from Taint. We can never get too much Drake.

3.25 - 3.50 StarsThis is the 2nd volume of Jack and Celia's story and picks up right where Watching ended.  Their relationship is moving forward and Celia is becoming more comfortable in her own skin.  She and Jack are seriously considering Elle and Drew's proposal to be watched versus being the watchers.  It's obvious Jack will do anything to make Celia happy -- but how far will he go and at what expense to himself?Jack adores Celia and genuinely cares about her feelings.  Unfortunately, I'm not sure that Celia is willing to be as unselfish.  In this volume she appeared to lack maturity and I'm concerned her actions may cause problems.  I didn't understand the importance of the drama concerning her parents, but it seems to have worked out.In any event, I am curious to see what happens next in their relationship and plan to continue on with this series.

Shannon's life hasn't gone very smooth. After her parents' death, she's taken care of by her wild older sister who overdoses and leaves Shannon alone to live with her sister's six month old daughter and the baby's jerk father. On the day she turns eighteen, Shannon learns she doesn't have enough credits to graduate and will have to take night classes. It's here she meets Mateo, her new hot teacher who is ten years older than her. Shannon thinks he's just a teacher that is crazy about her, but Mateo has secrets that could hurt their potential relationship.Shannon is a great leading lady with a backbone. She may be young but she's strong and determined. She keeps going and keeps trying no matter how many obstacles get in her way. Mateo falls for Shannon immediately and you learn that he's been watching her and wanting her for a while. Their romance is hot and heavy and fairly fast paced. The age difference doesn't really make an impact at all the way the story is written.The story is told from Shannon's POV and is tied up nicely in the end.

This is one of those great stories that you need to read to truly appreciate all the twists and turns and secrets. I'm not really sure how to write this review without giving away too much, and I don't want to do that because it'll take away from the suspense and enjoyment of the story.Erika has been in love with Michael for as long as she can remember, only he acts as if she doesn't exist. She finally gives in to the pressures of their families and agrees to date Trevor, his younger brother. But she doesn't feel anything for Trevor but friendship and eventually breaks up with him.Micheal and his best friends Kai, Will and Damon are known as the four horseman. They're all from rich families and get away with doing things most people wouldn't. Michael has always been aware of Rika but stayed away because of her age and the desire to keep her safe. One night Michael ignores his rule and brings Rika along with his friends for their night of pranks. One night changes everything and sets the events of this book into motion.Corrupt takes you on a slightly dark and suspenseful ride switching back from the present to that night three years ago. Revenge is a strong emotion that can turn your heart black. It's also an emotion that each person handles differently and you see this first hand in Corrupt.I loved Michael! Hot, broody, mysterious. No matter how bad he tried to act, I still loved him and saw behind his mask. Rika was both stupid and brave with her trust, but under the circumstances I understood each of her decisions. She just couldn't fight that pull.I really enjoyed this book. I loved all the secrets and trying to figure out what would happen next. The secondary characters will keep you on your toes wondering who you should or shouldn't like and trust. It's a game of sorts where the winner continues to play and the loser taps out.

Wow! What an amazing story. I loved Raze, book one in this series, and was honestly a little skeptical as to whether or not I would like this book as much.  I was so wrong!! I loved it equally as much as Raze and cannot wait to get more in this series.You'll remember that Luka/Raze made a promise to his friend 362/Anri when he was forced to kill him in the cage. Luka swore to get revenge on his friend's behalf by killing the man who killed 362's family. When Luka discovers that his friend had a twin who is being drugged and forced to kill, Luka rescues him and takes him to the family beach house in hopes he can be saved. Although Luka's sister Talia is there, he knows she will be safe with her guards protecting her.  Luke never expected his sister to fall for him.212/Zaal is a broken man. He's been drugged, beaten and treated horribly for over twenty years. All of his memories have been tortured out of him, and he knows now is how to kill when Master speaks the order. When he awakens in a dungeon, he doesn't realize that he's been set free. As the drugs start to wear off, Zaal is captivated by the beautiful woman who comes to his cell.Talia is a strong character and being Luka's sister and the crime boss' daughter, she's a true mafia princess. Taking a trip to the beach house, Talia is planning on relaxing and enjoying a vacation - until Zaal is brought there. Day after day she watches him until she finally makes the decision to go in his cell and tend to him. His eyes capture her and she notices that her touch calms him.  Both of their life's will now be changed - but for good or bad?My heart broke for Zaal. I simply cannot imagine how someone survives what both he and Luka were forced to endure. It just saddens me. Yet both Zaal and Luka were similar in that they still had a tiny part of themselves still alive inside just begging to be shown a slimmer of kindness. Kisa did it for Luka in Raze.  Talia does this for Zaal in Reap. She's exhibits bravery and forces her guards to back down so she can gain Zaal's trust. Watching them fall in love pulled at my heart strings and was beautiful. You cannot help but hope that they can find some way to be together.I loved that Luka played a major part in this story, and another added bonus was getting to see Kisa again and seeing first hand that she and Luka are doing great. I'm loving how these characters are coming together and how the story is progressing, and I cannot wait for the next book in this series. The hint we are provided at the end proves the next book will be just as exciting.This was truly a wonderfully emotional story about finding your one true love and never giving up no matter what.

This is the fifth book released in the Stripped series. Unfortunately I didn't like it as much as the others and I've been waiting on Ivan's and Candy's story knowing there was something going on. It starts with Candy having just been rescued by Ivan when she was a sixteen year old runaway from the religious community/cult where she was raised. Since then, she has lived with Ivan where he has protected and provided for her. Everyone assumes there is more to their relationship, however that doesn't happen until Candy starts trying to leave - only to be brought back. At the same time it appears Candy's past has found her and Ivan does what he has to in order to keep her safe.I liked Ivan's character. He's cold and quiet, but he's been that way from the start. Yet when he's with Candy, he's softer in a dark and brooding way. He opens up about his childhood which in turn allows us to see why he has such a strong wall built around him. The only person he allows inside is Candy.Candy is another story. I got sick of being in her head and listening to her whine. She's nineteen I believe at the point of this story and has been working as a stripper at Ivan's place. There is no way she is as naive as some of the scenes depict. I did feel sorry for her, but she pushed away everyone who cared about her, so it was hard to feel anything for her but annoyance.On a good note, Clara's and Gio's story will be next.

This is a Sexy fast paced short story about finding your one and fighting for your happy ending.Penelope has come home from college in order to see her aging grandmother. Unfortunately, the only way her father will let her visit, is if she agrees to marry Scott, her father's slimy family attorney.The day Penelope brings her car into Paine's automotive shop, he's attracted to her in a way he has never been to another woman. He decides almost instantly he'll do anything to get her attention and get her into his bed. But he also wants more with Penelope and easily sees a future with her. Then he learns that Penelope is engaged and Paine is determine to stop her from marrying another man. Doesn't take him long to figure out the marriage isn't what Penelope wants either.Most of the books that I've read by AR have been sexy little fantasy based stories. Mechanic is no different and did not disappoint. Don't read this if you looking for a serious drawn out romance that takes forever for the characters to unite. No - this is a fun smutty read that quickly takes the characters where you want them to be. As an added bonus, there's a little surprise at the end with some of the characters from Mechanic.

When Elena married her high school sweetheart Dominic, she never realized he'd end up being such a hateful man. He is constantly saying hateful and degrading things to her and has caused Elena to think she doesn't deserve better. When Dominic ends up not having the cash he owes the loan shark he's bored money from, he trades Elena for three months. Ashton is astounded that any man would treat his wife that way and only allows the trade to happen in order to teach Elena she's worth more. During the time Elena spends with Ashton, they get closer and closer and both fall for the other. What will happen when the three months are over and Dominic makes it clear he wants his wife back?I loved Ashton. He may be a loan shark, but he also owns several restaurants and was a great man. He cares for Elena immediately and did everything he could to teach her how beautiful she was and show her the ways a woman should be treated. Poor Elena had been brainwashed by her husband and thought everything she did should be for him. What's sad is that you know there are really relationships that exist like that.This was a standalone story where Elena slowly learns about herself and what she's worth. It was a story about finding love where you least expect it and for Elena about second chances. It's told from dual POVs and has a happy ending.

Jack's mother is killed when he is only nine years old. Her dying wish was for him to agree to take care of his younger brother. He's thrust into the terrible world of sex slavery. Unspeakable things happen to Jack throughout the years, but he does it all to keep his brother safe. At the age twenty-seven he's saved by River and her friend Adam. Her father ran a slave business and since his death, River has made it her life's quest to save as many slaves as she can. Both Jack and River are broken souls with emotional scars. Together they are able to heal each other.This book contains a warning indicating that it contains dark material. With slavery being a theme, be prepared for a couple of scenes with non consensual sex.I felt sorry for Jack. I can't imagine what his life was like living where he did for nearly twenty years. It's terribly sad knowing places like this exist in real life. Although River did suffer a lot growing up, it was nothing compared to what Jack went through. Her choice to save slaves was both admirable and dangerous.The story ends at 70% with excerpts from other books. The next book in this series will be Saved By Him, the story of Sophia and Adam.

Belle meets Albie in Vegas right after she learns her fiancÃ© has been sleeping with her best friend/maid of honor for over a year. She and Albie end up spending the entire night riding around, drinking and talking and on a whim are married by Elvis. They never dreamed two weeks later they'd be standing in front of their parents being informed they were going to become step siblings.Albie is a cocky yet very loveable character. He's interested in Belle and gives her a hard time but it's obvious that's he's attracted to her. They're still married and up to that point they had not consummated the marriage. Albie takes every chance he can to let Belle know he's all for correcting that. Belle is an okay female character. She tries a little too hard to push Albie away and her sarcasm and constant denying of her feelings grated on my nerves. It caused her to come across as childish a few times and unfortunately wasn't funny to me. But my sense of humor must be off because a lot more readers enjoyed it. To each their own. There are more hot scenes in this one, but Albie is good at what he does and deserved the page space.Overall it was a cute fast read. As a bonus, another book in this series, Tool, comes with the purchase of this story. I've read it already and it's a good book worth reading.

SPOILER ALERT - DO NOT READ THIS REVIEW IF YOU DO NOT WANT TO SEE THE SPOILER - YOU HAVE BEEN WARNED!!I bought this with the expectation of reading about Jude's and Autumn's wedding. I was disappointed because this VERY short story is merely events leading up to the wedding.  There is no big event.  I'm guessing it'll be in the next book released in this series.There's a hint of the next story being about Summer, Autumn's sister and Travis, Jude's brother recently home from the service.

Autumn grew up in a troubled family and never knew the identity of her father.  It was common for her mother to date and bring home different men and her siblings were known for causing trouble around town.  In the end, her mother became a drunk who drank herself to death. The only good person Autumn had in her life was her Gran. Autumn went to college, made good grades and left town to make something of herself and to make her Gran proud. When she passes away, Autumn is forced to come back home to small town where she believes everyone thinks she's trash.Jude is the hot and single local doctor who took care of Gran while she was sick. The minute he sees Autumn, Jude feels a possessiveness and draw towards her that he can't shake. He's never been one to have a girlfriend so the feeling is unfamiliar but not unwanted.  The problem is, Autumn doesn't think she's worth Jude's attention. He came from a good solid family with lots of money and Autumn believes he can do better than her. Jude is determined to prove to Autumn she's the woman he wants and that he knows what's best for him.I really liked Jude. He's a great character. Nice and caring, possessive and alpha and so very sweet and tender. He treated Autumn as if she was the only woman in the world. Autumn drove me a little crazy with her I'm-not-good-enough mentality. I just wanted to reach into my Kindle and thump her on the head. Other than that, I liked Autumn well enough and enjoyed watching them get closer.The epilogue sets up the next book in the series which is about Jude's sister Bailey.

Jade was set up by her ex boyfriend and ended up serving time in jail. Once out, she has bills to pay and needs to find a way to make money. She starts a business where she provides her clients comfort as a professional cuddler. Ryland is a successful MMA fighter and becomes a regular client. Once he meets Jade, he decides he wants her even though she's determined not to get involved with a man again. When someone threatens an old friend of hers, she's needs more money. So when Ryland makes her an offer to pay her for traveling with him as he fights, she can't turn it down. When Jade's past come back, they could all be in danger.Ryland is a quiet, gentle giant. But he's a deadly bada$$ when he fights and makes Jade feel safe when she's with him. She doesn't tell him her secrets even though they get closer and Ryland makes his intentions towards her clear. She tries her best to fight her own feelings, but the attraction and chemistry between she and Ryland is too strong.There's some drama and suspense and the secondary characters were good. I'd love to see what happens between Jules and Jase if there's another book written. It's told from Jade's POV and I was happy with the ending.

4.5 starsLara has always adored her father. After graduating college, she went to work with him and is now the CFO of their company, a company which needs to be updated before it goes under. Her father however is old school and set in his ways and doesn't see the need to make the necessary changes. Determined to save the company she loves, Lara turns to the one man she knows can help.Conner is a successful businessman and is interested in Lara and her company. When she propositions him to marry her in order to become a board member for assistance in making good decisions to help save her business, Conner has his own proposition. He'll agree to marry her, but Lara has to agree to be his submissive. It will be a marriage for business yes, but it will also be a marriage of loyalty, honesty and sex. The only thing he doesn't want involved is love. Lara isn't sure how she can do that without her heart getting involved.I really liked Conner. He had a messed up opinion of love because of events that he watched happen to his parents. He's never been in a relationship and he's never loved another woman. The Dom/Sub lifestyle enables him to keep his heart uninvolved. But the more time he spends with Lara, the more he likes her. The closer they get, the easier it is to see them together. He's stubborn and sexy and sweet all rolled up together. The sex scenes are nothing too extreme for those who are uncomfortable reading about this lifestyle.Lara is a great character. She adores her dad and will obviously do anything to protect him and the company he started. She's scared of the feelings Conner brings out in her and terrified by how much she loves the things that Conner is teaching her. Her body responds to just his voice and the more time she's around him, the more she realizes how impossible it will be to keep her heart protected.This is the first of three books in his series. Each are standalones. The other two books will be about Conner's brothers Cade and Nathan. Brand is already released and Boss will be out early 2016. This is the first book I've read by this author and I'm looking forward to reading more.Told from dual POVs and has a good ending.

3.5 starsKade is a Navy Seal home on leave to take care of his grandfather who is dying from cancer. On the day he gets back, he ends up at the wrong place at the wrong time and is convicted of a murder he didn't commit.Harley works as an inmate dog trainer at the prison where Kade is sent to serve his sentence. She's had a crush on him for years and knows he's innocent of the crime he was convicted of. She gets him involved in her dog program and is surprised to learn that Kade has been interested in her since high school. Once his fellow Seals get home, they will do whatever is necessary to prove Kade's innocence and get his named cleared. But the ones guilty don't want the truth to come out and they threaten Harley's life in order to keep Kade quiet. Harley and the Seals have to find proof to get him released before it's too late.Kade is a really great guy. He's fought and served to protect our country and is loyal to all those he cares about. He cannot believe he finally has a chance with Harley and of course wants her safe and protected. He makes his feelings for her very clear and her safety is extremely important to him. He's been through so much and doesn't want to lose anyone else close to him.Harley tried my patience. I'm all for being an independent woman, but her stubbornness and childish actions were annoying. I mean Kade and his buddies are flippin Seals who are trained in taking care of themselves, know what they are doing and have the help of the district attorney to find those responsible. She made stupid decisions and let her pride put her in danger when she should have used her head. Granted it panned out one time when she went searching on her own. But the other times, especially the time with her bossy friend Bette, I was shaking my head thinking train wreck ahead. Personally, I have a hard time when this particular kind of storyline happens where the leading lady seems to lose her brain cells and struts herself around doing whatever she wants when her life in danger. Consequences be damned. Seriously, do these women actually exist? Obviously it was needed for the story to work the way it did - but still...Overall, it was a good book and I did enjoy it. It's told from dual POVs and has an ending that works great. Kade and Harley worked well as a couple and I liked the other two Seals, Kyle and Harley's dad.

This is book two in a series but can be read as a standalone.  I suggest reading book one first because not only is it a good book, but it lets you know in advance who these characters are.Macey is Cameron's sister and Reese is Cameron's best friend.  When Macey was a teenager, she and Reese had a relationship that they kept secret since she was the forbidden little sister.  When she got ready to leave for college, Reese broke it off.  Six years have passed and Macey is back.  She's ready to see Reese again and hopes to start back up where they left off.  Unfortunately, after losing Macey, Reese changed.  He's closed off and doesn't get to close to women anymore.  Seeing Macey again brings back all the old feelings he had and Reese tries desperately to push her away.  Will he finally give in and realize they are each what the other needs?This was a quick read. I liked both characters well enough and was pulling for them to get a happy ending.  Although Reese is a Dom and owns a sex club, the few scenes they share are pretty basic. I liked The Gentlemen Mentor better, but this was an okay story too.

Six years ago Charlie met Ava while helping to start a church in a remote area of Peru.  He was immediately attracted to her and found himself feeling things he hadn't felt in years for a woman.  Charlie is a priest who took a vow of celibacy and has devoted his life to the church.  He knows the way he feels for Ava is wrong, but the draw is too strong.  In the end, he knows that even though he has fallen in love with her, it can never work and he leaves.Six years later, Ava has come to finally confront Charlie.  She doesn't have any idea what his reaction will be, but she has never loved anyone else but him and has missed him terribly.  They are both surprised by their reactions when they meet again.This was a story of a forbidden love that was written in such a way that their falling in love felt nature and right.  They are both very likeable characters and I enjoyed getting both of their POVs.  It was a quick read with a happy ending.This purchase also included two other books by this author, Stepbrother Bad Boy and Tease.

3.5 starsElizabeth experienced a traumatic experience in high school that changed her outlook on life.  Now in college, she no longer believes in love and is content living only half a life studying, working and  making herself believe she's happy with the occasional one-night hookups.  Then she sees Declan.  He's a British hottie with a sexy accent and Elizabeth is instantly attracted to him.  To make matters worse, it's obvious he feels the same way about her.  But Elizabeth just can't risk her heart with someone else and does her best to fight the attraction.  Declan knows there is a strong connection between he and Elizabeth.  She's beautiful and makes him feel things he hasn't ever felt for another girl.  He's protective of her and wants her happy and next to him.  If only Elizabeth would give them a chance.I absolutely adored Declan.  He was such a sweet man and you could tell he genuinely cared for Elizabeth and was struggling with her constantly trying to push him away.  He was a strong character and worked hard at making his gym a success, even though his father wanted him to do something different.  He explained his feelings to Elizabeth more than once and had no problem making himself vulnerable.Elizabeth was a likeable enough character.  We learn in the prologue what happened to her and my heart broke for what she went through.  Unfortunately, my feelings for her never developed.  She drove me crazy with her back and forth and her constantly pushing Declan away.  Earlier in the book when Blake, a guy she'd been friends with since high school, tells her he's in love with her, she ignores him and never mentions it again.  This was pretty much her response to Declan when he expressed his feelings for her.  Her way of coping with everything was to ignore it and pretend it never happened.  Same thing she did with Colby.  I guess it just annoyed me and caused her character to seem immature.Another character I loved was Declan's twin brother Dax.  He's gorgeous, has a wonderful personality, is funny and I can't wait for his story to be released next year.  He needs to meet a feisty girl who'll bring him to his knees.Overall, I enjoyed the book and found it an easy read.

4.5 starsWhen Juliette's mother died, her father became a drunk, started gambling and basically gave up caring about anything including his two daughters.  When he dies owing the wrong person a whole lot of money, it unfortunately becomes Juliette's debt to pay.  She works three job trying to pay her bills, take care of her little sister and pay the debt she inherited.  Getting the money is becoming increasingly harder and when she doesn't have it, she's given a choice - either her or her younger sister Viola.  Knowing she'll do whatever she has to protect Viola, Juliette goes herself to Arlo.  Just when the unthinkable is about to happen, Killian McClary, the city's Scarlett Wolf walks in.Killian took over his father's business when he was a teenager after both his parents were murdered.  He's feared and has a reputation for punishing those who hurt anyone he cares about.  The problem is, Killian no longer cares about anyone and won't allow himself to get close for just that reason.  When Arlo give him Juliette as partial payment, he thinks it'll be just one night with a women he'll forget the next day.  Only Killian doesn't.  He finds himself thinking about her all the time and finally offers her a deal.  He'll pay off her debt to Arlo if she'll agree to spend the year as his anytime he wants her with the understanding feelings cannot get involved. Hesitantly, Juliette agrees because she knows that Killian is the lesser of two evils. But feelings do get involved - by both parties.  Past threats appear and both Juliette and Killian could lose everything.This was a really good book told from Juliette's and Killian's POVs.  It has romance and sex; danger and secrets; surprising twists and a hot alpha lead character who you'll love one minute and want to strangle the next.  I really liked Juliette and hated that she suffered so much loss in her life.  However the loss that Killian suffered was worse that hers, and I think part of the reason they both so perfect for the other.  Viola is a fun character and I also liked Frank, Killian's bodyguard.Be prepared to spend a little extra time reading because this is a lengthy book.  However, It's well worth it since it's complete and there is no flippin cliffhanger in sight!

3.5 StarsHot, short, erotic story similar to the others released in this series in that the characters are role playing.  But the actual story itself is different. Dante and Porter steal Sabrina away from a bar for a night of passion with them both.As an added bonus, this purchase also included book three in this series entitled Taking What's Hers.

4.5 StarsThis is the fourth book in the Cravotta Crime Family Series, and for a limited time on Amazon, all four books are included when you purchase this one.Luc works for the mafia and ends up spending a year in jail after Claire, the woman he loved, testified against him. Now he's out and the mafia want her dead. But what Luc discovers when he finds Claire is not what he was expecting. It turns out Claire had a huge secret and a good reason for what happened. If only Luc could forgive her, maybe they could work things out. Yeah, right after Luc takes care of the cop from the witness protection program who wants Claire for himself.Loved Luc and understood his feelings completely. I always have issues with women who do what Claire did, but in this case I understood her reasoning somewhat. Luc is a little more bad boy than the other men from this series, so be ready for a little more kink.Overall, I enjoyed it. The story is fairly short and told from both Luc's and Claire's POV.

Wow! What a thrilling conclusion to a great story. This is part 2 of King's and Doe's story. Before you read this, you first need to read King to get caught up.I didn't think it could get any better, but Ms. Frazier just blew me away. You just think you love King in the first book. Our boy steps up his game and I fell even more in love with him in Tyrant. He's determined to get Doe back and doesn't mind getting his hands dirty to do it.Doe has finally grown into herself and she's become stronger and more determined to fight for what she wants. I won't give away any spoilers because you have to read this and suffer through the tenseness and racing heart just like I did to get the full effect. I will tell you that at some point Doe starts to remember and there's this one strong memory that was nothing at all what I had guessed would happen. I imagine my mouth was hanging open and my eyes were crossed as I was reading and soaking up the words. Seriously great writing. Did not see that coming for sure!I also fell a little more in love with Bear and cannot wait until we get his story later this year. I know Lawless will be just as great as King's/Doe's and Jake's/Abby's stories.

I HATE cliffhangers and have actually stopped reading them until the series is complete and I can read the entire story without forgetting parts and having to wait.  That's right ... I'm one of those annoying inpatient readers.  If you're like me, it's safe to get started on this great story because the sequel Tyrant is out so there's no waiting for the ending.King just finished three years in prison and is not the same man he was when he went in.  He has one thought and that's to get Max no matter what he has to do or who he has to hurt.Doe has no idea who she is and remembers nothing about her life when she wakes up badly beaten in a hospital.  When the police are unable to figure out who she is, she ends up living in a foster home but leaves for the streets instead.Doe meets King at a welcome home party his best friend Preppy has thrown to celebrate his release from prison.  It's not a happy meeting and after what happens, Doe ends up in King's possession where for the most part she's offered food, shelter and safety.King is confused about the way he feels about Doe.  He's never done the girlfriend thing or had a relationship.  However he finds himself wanting to be near her as much as possible and spend time with her.  Doe knows she should be frightened of King or probably hate him, yet she's drawn to him and the way he makes her feel.  Unfortunately, there are secrets about both the past and the future that threaten what could be between King and Doe.Doe is a sweet character and I hurt for what she was going through.  I can't imagine waking up not knowing anything about who I am or where I belong.  Doe had to have been terrified living on the streets with no money and no memory.  King is definitely one of those bad boy alpha characters we love we hate.  He could make me mad one minute and then swoon the next. I was right there with Doe going crazy with King's back and forth when it came to his Pup.  Preppy, King's best friend, was a hilarious secondary character who added so much to the story.  He was able to lighten any situation and make everyone smile.  I like Bear's characters as well and am looking forward to seeing what happens next.Yes, there is one heck of a stressful cliffhanger - but as I mentioned above, Tyrant has been released so there is no reason not to start this great book and enjoy.By the way, it was told from both King's and Doe's POV.

Jack is a member of the Cravotta crime Family and his boss Johnny is trying to work out a peaceful alliance with the MC club they recently were at war with. The MC offer up one of their own for Jack to marry to serve as both an alibi and a peace offering. The chemistry between Beatrice and Jack is just too hot and no matter how hard they try to hate each other, they're unable to fight the feelings they have. When Beatrice gets pregnant, you'd think their happy ending would be smooth sailing, but of course that's not the case. During the war, someone from either the MC or Jack's own family killed his brother and he wont rest until he finds out who it was, especially now that it looks like they're after his wife and unborn child.I liked this book the best of the series so far. Jack was broken by the death of his brother who was the only family he had. Beatrice comes into his life and comforts him before he even realizes that's what's happening. They seem to balance each other and are perfect together. We get more Johnny in this story and there's a number of fairly stressful situations.This story is told in both Beatrice's and Jack's POV and we get one of those endings I love. This could technically be read as a standalone but I was glad I've read the others (at least KUBTBB) so I was familiar with Johnny and his story.

This book is now entitled "Heat" however when I purchased it, the story was entitled "Bang" and also contained 2 other books by this author, "Bro" and "Bad Boy."Trent is a porn star with a successful career, only lately it's boring and not as exciting as it used to be. After a night of drinking and drugs, Trent wrecks his motorcycle and ends up in the hospital. He falls instantly in love with the beautiful nurse Lexi. The more he tries to get her attention, the more she ignores him. He realizes he'll have to step up his game to be worthy of Lexi even if it means changing his lifestyle and career.I just loved Trent. He was such a sweet man underneath all his good looks and manwhore reputation. He genuinely adored Lexi and was sweet to her sister as well. Lexi was a little gun shy at first, but eventually she let her walls down enough to give Trent a chance.Sweet, easy to read HEA with a little heat.(I've added my reviews for the additional stories on their individual book pages.)

3.5 StarsI acquired this book as a bonus story attached to the end of Heat (f/k/a Bang) a purchase I made by this author.Nevada grew up living in a mansion where her mother was the head maid. She's never had much money and struggles to pay for her college. As long as she can remember, Nev has had a crush on Clayton, the boss' son who basically ignored her growing up. Returning home from college, she hopes that Clay will finally notice her now that her body has matured and she's grown up.Clay can't believe how beautiful Nev has become and doesn't understand the protective feelings he now has for her. He sets out to win her, only to discover that she's ignoring and avoiding him. Once he learns she still has her V-card, he's determined that she's going to be his and will stop anyone who gets in his way.I liked Clay although he was a little arrogant at times. But he did grow up with a family worth millions and had people waiting on him, so to me part of his attitude was expected. He changes though when he goes after Nev so I found I couldn't help but root for him to get the girl. I though Nev was seriously naive and I couldn't understand how she was so oblivious to the men who looked at her or wanted her (i.e. situation with Matt). What Nev ends up doing for college money came out of nowhere and I had a hard time believing she'd do that, especially since her mother had to have known.This was an easy read with a HEA and a few heated scenes.

I acquired this book as a bonus story attached to the end of Heat (f/k/a Bang) a purchase I made by this author. We first met Frannie in Bro, another book released by this author. You don't have to have read Bro to enjoy this story, although characters from that book, Clay and Nev, make an appearance in this story.Frannie comes from an extremely wealthy family but she has never cared about the money. What she wanted was attention from her parents who basically treated her as if she was invisible. Growing up, she was apparently a little overweight and was teased about her appearance. Frannie's therefore shy and has never dated, nor does she realize how beautiful she's become. When her car breaks down, the most gorgeous man she's even seen shows up.Jace is a bright mechanic who has seen his share of trouble over the years. He loves racing cars and as a result is doing community service for getting caught. When he goes on a call for work, he's dumbfounded by his immediate attraction to Frannie. Once he learns she doesn't have a boyfriend, he's determined to make Frannie his. Problem is she has no confidence or experience and can't believe that Jace would be interested in someone like her. He's determined to prove to her how beautiful she is and how much he wants in her life.Jace is a protective alpha from the beginning. He's really patient and kind with Frannie considering her lack of experience and confidence. I liked him instantly and was rooting for him to get the girl. Frannie is very naive for her age (she's graduating college). However, I found myself really liking her and wanting her to open up and trust Jace. The ending is nice with Clay and Nev and I enjoyed seeing them more happy than they were in Bro.Overall, this was an easy, stress free HEA with a little heat thrown in.

This is a hot little short story in the Forced Submission series.  It's similar to the others where a couple plays out a fantasy with steamy scenes.My only complaint is the cost versus the small amount of pages you get.  I like this author's short stories and I have bought a number of them, but unfortunately I wont be able to continue purchasing these when I can get full novels for the same price or sometimes less.If you've got deep pockets and want some kinky steam, these are the books for you.

This is a short novella that continues with Hannah's and Blue's story and sets up the next book in the series about Candy and Ivan. We are also introduced to West, Blue's best friend from the military. He's moving to town and taking a job at the club. I'm looking forward to reading more about him.Hannah is having a lot of trouble with confidence and feels lost since she's not stripping anymore. She isn't sure what to do with her life now and all her insecurities are causing her to doubt Blue's feelings for her and his commitment and promise to never leave her again. Gotta love Blue! He is clear about his love for Hannah and wanting a future with her.Bonus- there's an extended excerpt from Pretty When You Cry, the next book in this series.

3.5 StarsCameron is a tattooed MMA fighter with a horrible temper which has gotten him into trouble a number of times throughout the years. He's dad has always been hard on him and nothing he did made him proud. With his family owning a gym, fighting is all he's ever known.When Cameron was younger, his father surprised everyone by marrying his best friend's ex-wife.  Her daughter Victoria pretty much stole his heart at the age of six.  Over the years, Cameron has watched after and protected Victoria. No boy got near her without going through him and those left in bad shape.  Cameron eventually left town because it hurt too much to be around her and not own her.  After six months, he decides it's time and goes back to claim what's his.  It doesn't matter that she's his step-sister, she's just his.  When he gets home, he learns that his father and business partner (Victoria's dad) owe money to the wrong person and have involved Victoria.  He also discovers he might have some competition where Victoria is concerned and plans on proving to her that she's his life.I liked this story well enough.  It got a little long winded at times and is a fairly long book.  Cameron loved Victoria almost to the point of obsession.  He would never hurt her, but he made it clear it was his way or no way.  Victoria was a little naive and didn't have a clear understanding of what her father and Cameron's dad were getting her in to. Although Cameron could be pushy and a jerk, he expressed his concerns for her safety pretty clearly. It was obvious that she was the most important thing in his life.The story is told from both Cameron's and Victoria's POVs which would sometimes switch in the middle of a chapter.  It was confusing at times but I caught on eventually.  It is a standalone and does have a happy ending.

You can always count on this author to give you a great story that you'll enjoy and hate that it has to end.Blake is the owner of a tattoo parlor named Blurred Lines.  He has a number of addictions and has been working hard at getting past them.  When Riley walks in his shop wanting her first tattoo, Blake knows there's something different about her.  She calms him in a way no one ever has and being around her makes him want to be a better man.  Doesn't hurt that she's the most beautiful woman Blake's ever seen.Riley recently left an abusive relationship with a man she'd been with since high school and is determined to start living her life for herself.  She wasn't planning on starting anything with another man so soon, but Riley is drawn to Blake and wants to get to know him better. She thinks about him constantly finds excuses to stop by his shop.  Soon, Riley is as addicted to wanting to spend time with Blake as she is with her desire to get more tattoos.  Plus, Blake is gorgeous and makes her feel safe.Blake suffered a major loss when he was a child that resulted in a traumatizing childhood.  My heart broke for what he went through and I was extremely proud of the man he had become.  There is a connection between his and Riley's life which just proves further that they are absolutely perfect for each other.  Additionally, the fact that Riley was strong enough to leave behind her old life with no plans whatsoever, proved she was strong enough to be the person Blake needed in his life.I loved that in addition to meeting these new characters that we also got to see some of our favorite Selected Sinners MC men.  It's nice how the characters all weave together from the different series this author has given us.This was an amazing story of moving forward by accepting and shutting down the demons from your past and finding someone to love and have a wonderful future.  It was really a beautiful story with great characters that I fell in love with instantly.  I hope to see more of Stevie in the future and I'm thinking she'd be perfect for one of those sexy Selected Sinners.Loved it!

We met Cash in the first book Hard, and remember him as a playboy bartender and part owner of the club.  Cash has no desire to settle down with one woman, especially since there are so many that he can choose from each night.  Heâ€™s become good friends with Savannah (Ryderâ€™s girlfriend Cassieâ€™s best friend) and looks forward to the nights she comes in the bar.  It starts with a little innocent flirting, but soon becomes obvious that both Cash and Savannah are interested in one another.  They agree to keep it as a friends with benefits relationship.  Both have secrets and both begin to have feelings for the other they try to fight.I loved Cash and thought he was a hot sweetheart.  I liked Savannahâ€™s character as well and was glad she had a backbone when it came to her past.  I understood the reasoning behind Savannah keeping her secret, but I had trouble believing Cashâ€™s secret was that big of a deal.  Yeah, it was bad I guess, but I just didnâ€™t get it or why he kept it from his friends.  No big deal since it doesnâ€™t take away from the story.Overall, good book told from both Cashâ€™s and Savannahâ€™s POVs.  The epilogue is pretty quick and vague but it does end in a good place.

This is an emotional story about moving on from tragic pasts and finding love and going forward.Aspen lost her twin sister in a freak accident on their birthday when she was a teen. Her parents never forgave her, and she's never forgiven herself. Aspen has now moved from home and is attending college majoring in art miles away. She's sworn to herself to never get close to anyone again. When she sees her new hot professor Morgan Hampton, Aspen isn't sure how strong she'll be at fighting the attraction they obviously share.Morgan has come back home to take care of his niece. After he left five years ago, he swore never to return but under the circumstances he had no choice. Morgan is an art professor at the local college and thinks he's just met the woman who will change his life. Only problem - she's his student and therefore off limits. The chemistry between Aspen and Morgan is off the charts and the more they are around each other, the hotter the build up. You know the hook up is coming and you'll find yourself anxiously turning the pages anticipating what will happen. How can they make it work though when they aren't supposed to see each other. Plus, they each have something in their past that effects how they look at the future.I adored Morgan. Such a sweet, wonderful man and what a dirty talented mouth. He tried his hardest to resist Aspen, but some things are worth going after. Aspen was a sweetheart. She suffered a life altering tragedy and was treated horribly by her parents. From the moment Morgan and Aspen met, I was rooting for them to get their happy. They both have been hurt and both are scared but they are so perfect for each other. Morgan's niece is a cutie and a great addition to the story.Good book told from alternating POVs. Great ending and a standalone.

Gemma is a woman comfortable with her life. Although a little heavier than most, her parents taught her to be happy with her curves and most of all, to be happy with herself. She works as a chat line operator to men and talks them through their fantasies. She meets Jason on the chat line and they begin an online relationship of sorts. They've never met in person, never spoken by phone and have no idea what the other person is really like. But there's an attraction between them that as time moves on, becomes something more. Jason finally gets a phone number from Gemma and from there he gets her to agree to meet him with Gemma agreeing to be blindfolded to keep it anonymous. But feelings develop and things get complicated. Jason is married, but not happily. It's also public. He has a lot to lose if his and Gemma's secret comes out. Sometimes meeting the right person is worth breaking all the rules.I really liked Gemma. She took a lot of heat and received a number of snide remarks about her weight, but she stayed true to herself and met some great friends who were able to get her to embrace her curves and be proud of who she was. Jason was really a great guy and he never in any way made Gemma feel anything other that wanted. They really were perfect for her each other. As with the first two books in this series, there's some kink and intense scenes. I wished we'd seen what happened to April and Chelsea - I wanted them both run over! Saying they weren't nice is an understatement.Told from both Jason and Gemma's POVs.

Ayden's life changed on the day she turned six years old. In a terrible tragic accident she lost her father, the person she loved most in the world. Now nineteen, her mother reminds her often and harshly that it was her fault. It wasn't of course, but over the years the blame thrown her way from her mother has taken its toll and Ayden believes it. Her birthdays are a harsh reminder of what she lost. On her eighteenth birthday, Ayden approached a handsome man at a bar and lost her virginity to him. They never exchanged names and she never thought she'd see him again. Two weeks earlier she met a younger man who reminded her of him and she had an amazing night. Again no names and she left before he woke up the next morning. Although she's been thinking about the stranger a lot, she doesn't think she'll ever run into him. But life has a way of throwing you curve balls and Ayden had no way of knowing that the two men would be returning to her life. One as her future stepdad and the other as her soon to be stepbrother.Wow! This is an intense, antsy read. Mason is a really great man. He cares for Ayden but obviously also for her mother. It's awkward, but he and Ayden are able to keep their secret. Hunter is another story. He's not happy that Ayden left him the next morning and knows he's not finished with her. The chemistry between he and Ayden is off the charts and he has no problems pushing her boundaries to make it clear he wants her again. The tension between them is so strong you can feel it as you read each page and you know at some point it going to blow, and it's going to blow big.The step sibling thing - although it was there - it wasn't really weird because they met before Ayden's mom was involved and I never got the sibling feel from the characters at all. As much as I loved Hunter, he did make me mad a couple times with reactions to situations, but Ayden did too when she assumed the worst of Hunter without talking to him. Secrets kill and this story will show you that while some are worth keeping, others are not.Overall I really liked this story. You get dual POVs, although most are from Ayden. It also ends at a very nice place which will leave you with a smile. And yes, it's a standalone with no cliffhanger.

What a powerful and stressful story.  We only hoped Javier and Luisa were on their way to a happy ending.  Dirty Promises starts out with us discovering that Javier's sister Alana has been killed and as a result, he's treating Luisa horribly and pushing her away.  He believes that loving her and having her near him will be a sign of weakness so he treats her badly instead.  Javier disappoints us further by being unfaithful, although in his mind it's to protect Luisa from his vengeful anger.  But we can't be too quick to judge because Luisa is not innocent of fault either.  Este goes after her hard seeing his chance to be there when she's suffering.  You can't help but wonder if the King and Queen will be standing together at the end.This was an intense and highly emotion book.  KH didn't hold any punches and yet everything that happens in this story was needed in order to get the desired effect and to cause the events that happened.  There is love, there is deceit, there is hatred, there is revenge and there is forgiveness.  Even when I was annoyed at Javier, I still loved him - have from the very first book in this series.  Luisa loses her backbone for a short time, but she gets it back and comes back swinging.This was a great book told from alternating POVs from Javier and Luisa with the occasional chapter from Este.  BTW, I had Este pegged from the beginning and I'll just say there is no love lost there!I understand we may be getting another book in this series which will be about Evaristo.  He was a new character we met in this story and I immediately liked his sarcasm and confident attitude. So hopefully this wont be the end.

This is book 4 and the conclusion of the Bittersweet series. You need to read the previous books because not only are there spoilers, but the other books tie into this final one and you'll miss important details and not know the characters as you should at this point. This is Sofia's (Marcela's) story about how she came to be Hector's possession and about the years she lived in the Florez mansion.Sofia's real name is Marcela and her sister was Sofia. They take a trip on a super yacht with Sofia's boyfriend Alex and his friend Xavier. For several days the group lounges around, swims and enjoys their time together. On several occasions, Marcela feels as though the others are hiding secrets from her, but she decides to ignore it and concentrate on having fun. This all comes to a tragic end when the yacht is boarded by unwanted visitors. There are deaths, drugs, Marcela loses her name/identity and her nightmare of becoming a cartel leader's slave begins.I felt so sorry for Marcela. She was a wonderful character and even though anyone else would be broken by what she endured, Marcela never gave up on the hope that one day she would leave and have her freedom. Just like in Laughing Eyes, we are able to gain an entirely different perspective of books 1-2 by seeing the events from Marcela's eyes. She is not the cold uncaring slave you think she is and we now have a better understanding of her actions and attitude. Marcela lived through years of many unthinkable events and is treated horribly over and over again. Hector and Juan really are monsters. Once again I fell in love with Aiden and his protective and caring nature.I won't give away specific spoilers, but I will tell you that this story continues after the scene where Hector and Juan are killed. (That's not a spoiler since we witnessed their deaths in an earlier book.) There is a beautiful ending, one that I could not have dreamed up to be better. Great conclusion to a good series.

This is book 3 of the Bittersweet series and tells the story of Danny prior to the events that occur in books 1 and 2.  We already learned that he and Aiden served together in the Marines.  We now get his heartbreaking story and fall more in love with the wonderful man.  The first 65% of this book is Dannyâ€™s back story, but the remainder is an entirely different POV of what occurred in books 1-2 since we see it from Dannyâ€™s role behind the scenes.Danny and Aiden are Marines sent on a top secret mission to Costa Rica to locate and destroy El Leon, a man responsible for killing men, women and children in the surrounding villages.  When they arrive, they discover a group of doctors and nurses there who are trying to help with the devastation and injuries left behind by El Leon and his men.  Danny has an immediate attraction to one of the nurses Anna, and they quickly form a close friendship.  Through the weeks, their friendship becomes more and the two of them make plans for a possible future together.  Sadly, they learn that El Leon has also set his sights on Anna and heâ€™s not a man who likes losing.This is really a good story.  I knew going into this book that Danny had suffered loss and I was prepared to not get the happy ending I usually require.  However, Iâ€™m so very glad I read it because I would have missed seeing this side of Danny and discovering the wonderful man underneath.  He and Aiden were sent alone on what most would consider a suicide mission after El Leon, the monster with the beautiful eyes.  They are both great men and did what they could considering the circumstances.  This was an emotional story, but worth the read.Iâ€™m planning on reading Sofia next, the last book in this series.

After retiring from professional football, Chris becomes a high school football coach.  While his home is being built, he's been living with his best friend and wife, both of which have been his friends since college.  When their eighteen year old daughter Megan comes home after being gone all summer, the attraction between them is heated and charged.  Chris tries his best to resist Megan, but she makes it impossible and soon they're trying to hide their feelings from her family, other students and other teachers.This was a quick, short hot read with a happy ending.

This is book 2 of the series and you need to read Little Doll before starting.We pick up right where we ended with Ethan showing up at the hotel. Laila is angry for Aiden's secret but she soon realizes what he did was for her safety. Now, Aiden, Laila, Ethan and Jorge are on the run. Juan is determined to get Laila back and has people all over working for him. Hector is beyond angry and wants Aiden dead for taking Laila. It won't be easy, by Aiden is determined to keep Laila safe, get his revenge against his family and hopefully have Laila by his side at the end.There are a number of stressful scenes that will keep you on the edge trying to guess what will happen. Laila doesn't disappoint and still has her feisty attitude and smart mouth. You'll fall more in love with Aiden and his protectiveness.Danny's book, Laughing Eyes, is next and already released.

Laila hasn't always had a good life, but she had a brother Ethan she loved and she was happy. When Ethan appears to be missing, Laila goes in search of him. She had no idea that Ethan had gotten involved working with a Mexican Cartel and she was therefore placing herself in danger. Taken prisoner by Juan, one of the cartel leader's sons, she's held captive and promised a life she cannot imagine.Aiden is the other brother and although he tries to hide it, he's nothing like Juan. He had a plan and seeing the beautiful Laila now held captive changes things. He'll have to improvise but he'll do whatever he can to keep her safe and get her out.I knew from Aiden's first scene that he was notthing like the monsters that Juan and his father Hector were. There's a harsh intensity to him but also a softness that he only showed Laila. I began pulling for their escape immediately and wanted them together.Laila is tough. She never backed down and her mouth got her into trouble more times than not. Although I understood her reasoning completely, it still annoyed me when Aiden asked that she trust him and she didn't. She's a likable strong lead female character.There are tense moments and twists and turns. There are also some dark moments and uncomfortable scenes, but not near as bad as other books I've read regarding kidnappings. This book ends on a cliffy, but book 2 Crimson Desert is already out so there's nothing to stop you from reading this. Oh and the next book is the conclusion of Laila and Aiden's story, so even more reason to get started.

Tiffy is the daughter of a billionaire who owns a hotel where a male stripper show performs. She comes to town to check on things and meets Fletcher Novak, the sexy lead dancer of the show. Their attraction is immediate, no matter how much Tiffy tries to fight it. But she is determined to win Cole's heart, a guy she has worked with for several years. She's determined to think the worse of Fletcher and deny her feelings for him. There are secrets that both characters keep and things don't come together like either were expecting.I loved Fletcher from his very first scene. He's sexy, confident and there is no doubt that's he's a great guy. Tiffy goes after him with hurtful accusations and insults again and again. Fletcher shakes it off and distracts her by bringing her true feelings to the surface. Being the man he is, he's really hard to push away or forget. I'll be honest, I didn't care for Tiffy. At all! Not even by the end of the book. Fortunately, my feelings for her didn't take away too much from the story and I was able to enjoy this book.Claudio is Tiffy's best friend and assistant and he's a great character. He was good at balancing and acted the way we all want our best friends to act.Overall, I liked the book. Even though Fletcher is a stripper and Tiffy is technically his boss, there's so much more to the book than that. It's a reminder to look beyond the outside of a person and see what's inside and learn the facts before making a wrong judgment.3.5/4.0 stars

This is an extremely quick, short story - but it packs a heck of a punch.  Vince and Jill have a great marriage.  They love each other and are happy living with an open marriage.  Then they're kidnapped by another couple who cause them to rethink this and realize just how protective and possessive they are of each other.It's a twisted little mind screw book that will leave you with your mouth hanging open wondering WTF just happened.  It also ends at a place where there could possibly be more about this couple in the future.4.5/5.0 twisted stars

4.5/5.0 starsI genuinely love this series. The men of the HRT are all hot military men with special training who would not only die for each other, but also for the women and others in their lives that they love and care for.This is Ethan Cruz's story. The team is in his hometown of Miami tracking a man with connections to the most dangerous drug lord currently in the country. When he runs into his old neighbor Marisol, Ethan is shocked at the possessive feelings he has towards her. He always looked out for her growing up, especially since she was several years younger. Now, she's all grown up and is an Assistant U.S. Attorney working on the same case he is. Ethan struggles with his feelings knowing he'll be leaving soon and doesn't want to start something and hurt Marisol when he has to leave. However when she becomes a target and her life is put in danger, he'll do anything to protect her.Marisol has always had a huge crush on Ethan and has a hard time as fighting her affection for him. She knows he'll be going back home soon and knows she miss him. When it becomes obvious they each feel the same way, the sparks fly. But danger is closing in and the case she's working on is getting closer to trial and people want her stopped.Ethan such a great guy. All of these men are. I've loved every one of these stories and I especially enjoy getting to see them all again in each book. Marisol was a great fit for Ethan and like the other women in this series, she was stubborn and stood her ground. I hope Vance's book will be next. I'm curious as to how he's going to be able to successfully keep fighting that attraction he's developed for one of these guys' sister.I hope we'll see more of Georgia and there's a part of me that hopes Miguel will be back too. I'm hoping I interrupted that scene correctly and he'll be back - maybe....Overall, loved it and can't wait to see what happens next time.

Callum has nothing.  He's basically grown up living on the streets after his mother threw him out.  When he's released from a year jail sentence, all he wants is his dog back.  Sophia is a property manager in the area where Callum lives.  She's heard of him and aware he's trouble, but when she sees him, she realizes that Callum is the most gorgeous man she's ever seen.  Sophia helps him get his dog back and they develop a sort of friendship.  She hires him for security when she meets with men, however it's really Callum that she wants.  Callum wants Sophia just as badly, and during a heated moment, they act on the attraction.  Unfortunately Callum has never thought he was worth anything and never believes he's good enough for Sophia.  One incident may cause them their relationship.Sophia comes from a rich family, but isn't what everyone assumes.  She wants to be happy but is afraid to stand up to her family.  Callum is really a great guy who has been handed a bad hand in life.  He's a wonderful artist and just needs someone to care and give him a break.  I enjoyed watching these two fall for each other and thought they were perfect together.

3.5/4.0 starsMason is a Navy Seal who was injured in a mission. He now works for a service where he's hired to protect the beautiful Pansy Hightower who may be in danger.
