He thinks Pansy is a spoiled rich girl. Pansy doesn't like being followed and plans to loose Mason when she discovers he's been following her. After Mason saves her life, he realizes he was wrong in his opinion of Pansy. She trusts him and soon the sparks fly. Mason is determined to do whatever he has to in order to keep her safe.I liked both characters and enjoyed their back and forth when they first met. It's a quick read with a happy ending.

I made this purchase solely for the novella included entitled Alternate, since I previously purchased each of the books individually in the Gypsy Brothers series.  For those of you who haven't read it, this a great price to get the entire series because I paid a whole lot more.  Alternate is pretty short, but it does give you a few insights into things you didn't know about Jase, Elliot and Dornan.This was an intense, suspenseful series that kept you on your toes fighting for Julz (Sammi) to get her revenge and hoping that she gets a happy ending with Jase in the end.

4.5/5.0 starsThis is the story of Max and Mia.Max is a lumberjack in a small Alaskan town who is all hot sexy man. He knows the minute he sets eyes on Mia that's she's going to cause all sorts of problems in his life. He isn't wrong.Mia comes to town for her job researching the local grizzlies. She's beautiful and feisty and trips over her own feet every time she moves.  When she meets Max, their attraction is instant and fierce. Mia attempts to fight it, but Max is a man who gets what he wants and he wants Mia.There's a murder for which Mia is a prime suspect, an upset ex, a funny/crazy mom, a baby grizzly bear named BooBoo and a cast of other characters you'll love.I enjoyed this story and loved the banter that went on between Max and Mia. Maxine, Max's mom and her friend Martha were too funny. There's suspense and craziness and romance.  This story has it all.

This is a backwoods country short story of a lonely man who learns he can live life again.  Willow leaves her home to move in with Teddy and help take care of his three kids.  His wife died years earlier leaving him bitter and cranky.  From the moment Willow sees Teddy, she wants him and decides she'll do whatever she can to fix him.  Only Teddy keeps shutting her down.  Giving up, she decides it's time to move on, and is surprised when Teddy gets jealous and makes it clear no other man will touch her.I felt for Teddy and the feelings he struggled with in wanting Willow yet feeling tied to his deceased wife.  Willow is a free spirit who never gave up on Teddy and in the end, it paid off.  Clover makes an appearance and learn she is happy with Eustace and Jim.  Also, this book was a little more reserved than book one.

This is the story of Kristine and Garrettâ€™s daughter Amy, and her love/hate relationship with Noah, the adopted son of Justin and Riza.  Back when Amy was younger, she smarted off to Noah about him being adopted and since that day, the two of them have fought and not gotten along.  Now Amyâ€™s going to college and their parents want her to live with Noah to help keep her safe.  They still fight and then something serious happens that will change the paths of their lives forever.Iâ€™ll just say, the event that happened caught me off guard.  Itâ€™s a seriously WTF moment. I had a hard time connecting to Amy and thought she acted immaturely and childish.  I liked Noah well enough and was glad he was there to help Amy.  Then something else happens and I wasnâ€™t even sure where that came from.  The story ends in an okay place and sets up the next book in the series, Twisted Boundaries, which appears to be scheduled for released later this month.Overall, this was an okay book to me.  Itâ€™s ends at 78% on my Kindle with previews of a couple of other books by this author at the end.

3.0/3.5 StarsI really enjoyed Tag so I was looking forward to reading Youâ€™re It.  This Novella takes place four years later and life for Tango and Cali has been good.  They have a beautiful daughter Tyler and have adjusted and made their life as normal as possible.  Now the men responsible for the drug that cured Tango want to test Tyler to study the effects his injection may have caused in her. Tango and Cali are not happy and will do whatever is necessary to prevent it from happening.I loved Tango and was glad to see he was the same protective hot man I remember.  I wasnâ€™t as happy with Cali.  I remember her being tough and independent, but I thought she pushed it a little close to being obnoxious in this book. Donâ€™t get me wrong, thereâ€™s nothing wrong with protecting your child, I just didnâ€™t recall her being so rude and edgy.Bottom line, it was nice for the catch up and Iâ€™m glad Tango and Cali got their happy ending.

I've been looking forward to Jacob Decker's story. He's Chase's best friend from the book Breathe and I couldn't wait to see what woman would catch his heart.Years ago, Deck had his heart broken by the woman who he thought was the love of his life. Emme was his ex'es best friend and they've always shared something deep. Until Deck walks back into her life, he didn't realize what it was. Now he knows and he's going to do what he can to make her his.Deck is an absolute dream. He's so sweet and wears his heart on his sleeve. He'd do anything for Emme and is determined to keep her safe and have a future with her. Emma suffered a traumatic event in her childhood that she's really never dealt with and it keeps her distant. Deck knows this and is patient and does what he can to bring her around. But I'll warn you... around 60-75% Emme's gonna make you mad. I was not a happy reader and was not thinking nice things about this girl! Yeah she's got problems, and yeah she was having problems dealing with the problems, but I did not like at all how she was handling them. She's redeems herself completely, I'll say that, but during the bad time in the book- no! She did not do right. (Just my thoughts of course).Hoping there's more in this series and if so I'll definitely read it.

Zara had been in love with Ham Reece for a number of years. Problem was that he didn't stay in the same place too long and always left. He'd come back, but he never stayed. Although it broke Zara's heart, she knew it was time to move on. She'd met someone that she thought could maybe make her happy so she told Ham it was over.Three years later and Ham knows he should have never left Zara. When he finds out her marriage is over and she's lost everything, he's come back to town for her. Only now she's guarding her heart and won't let him in. Ham decides to give her time and prove to her, he's finally going to stay and he's going to stay with her.Dang! Kristen Ashley knows she can write a book. I will admit, this story started a little slower than some of the previous ones in this series, but once it got going, it was good. I adored Ham. Once you discover his reasons for always leaving, they make sense and your heart will break for him. But when you learn what Zara suffered through and how none of it broke her, you'll know she's the perfect woman for Ham and he's the perfect man for him. Ham supports Zara and has her back even when they're fighting or she jumps to the wrong conclusion. It doesn't drag out and Ham sets her straight in a way that gets her attention. He doesn't use words often, but when he does they're beautiful. Theirs is a touching story of finally getting the happiness that two people who should have it deserve.

There are a number of books that I've read which have touched me and Breathe is one I will definitely remember as being special.Faye had secretly crushed on Chace, a local police officer and town hero, for thirteen years since he moved to town. She never thought she'd ever attract his attention until she did. It was bumpy at first. Chace knew the minute he locked eyes on Faye that he wanted her to be his wife. Unfortunately life along with dirty cops and his father's mistakes didn't allow that to happen. Trying to discover who murdered the woman he was forced to marry, Chace struggles to fight the long term feelings he still harbors for Faye thinking he's not good enough. But there's only so much fight a man can have before he gives in, and Faye makes it too hard to fight.Chace is unquestionably a jerk at first. He's hurt and struggling with demons because of what's happened in his life over the last six years. However it's clear he wants Faye and it's also clear he wants her bad. Once he goes all in, he does just that and he becomes a wonderful, caring and protective man. He was so broken, yet he was also so sweet. Faye is amazing. She may be the towns quiet librarian but she has a fire and determination in her that helps Chace in a way no one else could. The side story to them falling in love is boy who changes their lives. I won't give away much but to say that this part of the story is heartbreaking and beautiful. He will touch your heart and make you feel deep inside. I badly wanted to hug this child and take away what he'd been through. Faye and Chace give him something that not many would. It will make you think about what you'd do in the same situation and wonder if given the chance, if you'd have the strength to go as far as they did.Although this is a standalone, it's helps to have read the previous books to know the characters and also to know about the murder that happened. It's not necessary, but the other books are good, so they're worth the read also.This was another great story by this author and I'm looking forward to the next book Jagged.

This was a long book, but it was so good and filled with twists and turns and good ole romance.  Hot romance with a hot man!  Ty was imprisoned for five years for a crime he did not commit.  He's thought of nothing by vengeance during his incarceration and now that he's out, it's time for payback. Lexie hasn't lived a great life, but she's determined to one day make that change.  When she's sent to pick Ty up the day he's released from prison, her luck begins to change.  Ty makes her an offer, marry him and he'll pay her enough to start a better life.  The only problem, once they're married, neither want the marriage not to be fake.  Soon, they're falling but Ty still needs his revenge and he may lose Lexie in the process.I absolutely loved this book!  Lexis is a wonderful person that no matter what happened in her past, she lived in the moment and had a great personality and was beautiful.  She brought Ty back to life and made a cold angry man smile.  Ty is damaged but he's soft around Lexie and begins to see the light and love around him.  They have some bumps in the road, but Ty proves himself and his love for Lexie.There's suspense in trying to help Ty clear his name and discover just who all is involved in his set up.  Both Ty and Lexie have great friends that added to the story.  Lexie is funny and sweet and I found myself laughing out loud throughout this book.  I loved that it's told from both POVs also.Loved it!  Moving on the the next one and can't wait.

This was an emotional, beautiful story of a strong but broken man who finds a reason to live again.  I knew from the small scenes of Deacon in previous books that his story would be intense.  The reason for his coldness is heartbreaking. But through it all, there is no doubt he is a wonderful man who deserves his chance at happiness.Since she was a child, Cassidy has dreamed of living in the Colorado mountains.  She finally gets her chance in her early twenties, when she purchases a number of mountain cabins to fix up and rent.  Throughout the next seven years, the mysterious stranger John Priest (Deacon) shows up and stays in cabin eleven.  She has no idea he's as drawn to her and she is him until one night Deacon helps Cassie with a bad situation and some renters.  They begin a perfect love affair and slowly grow closer.  Cassie knows Deacon has secrets and she's determine to break through and fix her man.  If only he'd erase all boundaries.Wow. Deacon is such a great guy. His past really did a number on him and he's suffered through the years a hundred times over.  Cassidy is the perfect woman for him.  Their story is beautiful and I thoroughly enjoyed.Looks like the hunt for Nair will reach it's conclusion in the final book of this series, Sebring, in which we finally get Nick's story.  I cannot wait to see what happens and whether or not Nick will be able to redeem himself to everyone.

What a beautiful and amazing story. Sylvie fell in love with Tucker Creed when she was six and Creed was eleven years old. When she finally turned eighteen, they were ready to leave and start their lives together. Only that didn't happen. Sixteen years later, Creed has found his Sylvie and this time, no one will stop him from claiming what has always been his.I loved it! Creed is a wonderful man. He's got that hot alpha thing going, while at the same time you know he's really just a great guy. Sylvie was a tough one and is perfect as the leading lady in this story. Both Creed and Sylvie were hurt tremendously in the past. When truths come to light, they'll break your heart. Watching them grow closer and plan for the future they've always wanted was beautiful to see. I loved Knight and I was glad we were able to see a little more of him in Creed. This was another great book by Kristen Ashley.

Kit comes to town looking for her brother and accidentally witnesses a man being beaten by the sheriff. She leaves the scene and literally runs into Father (Chase) who's suffering from amnesia from an attack months earlier. Both Kit and Chase are attracted to each other instantly. He's a Priest and they both know the attraction is wrong. But Chase wants Kit and is determined to keep her and see if she's the key to his memory. The town is full of secrets, but then again, so are Kit and Chase.I liked Chase's character and had a hard time trying to figure out the secrets with the twists throughout the story. I didn't feel as strong of a connection to Kit but she's like able enough as the female lead.  This story isn't dark like some of the others I've read by this author and I'm sure I'll read more in the series.3.5 stars

I can always count on Scott Hildreth delivering a story that I love from the minute I start reading until the very end and the very last word.  Ex-Con was no different and I was immediately swept into the Selected Sinnerâ€™s MC world and able to escape and watch Big Jack and Emily fall in love.We read in the previous book Hung about Jack being sentenced to life in prison for a beefed up charge by a dirty ATF guy.  In Ex-Con, we experience Jackâ€™s life prior to his time in jail and are shown what a fun, loving, protective and honest man he is.  Watching he and Em fall in love was so sweet and their love for each other was powerful.  The scenes we see during Jackâ€™s time in jail reiterate the fact that he is a great guy, although he isnâ€™t a man to sit back and be pushed around.This was a story about love that is soul deep and never dies.  Itâ€™s about making a family out of the people around you whether they are blood related or not.  Itâ€™s full of fun characters that will have you laughing yet you know they will die for each and every person they love.I cannot wait to see whatâ€™s up next in this series.  As always, great job and wonderful story!  Thanks for the bonus of a little Ripp, Shane and A-Train thrown in too. Love the Un-series boys as well.

Maddie had two great kids, was the president of the PTA and generally speaking, she had a great life. What she didn't have was a happy marriage. Her husband Richard ignored her and made her feel invisible. When Ben Hunter the new principal at school starts paying attention to her, she's flattered. She also realizes how badly she has yearned for the touch of a man. What happens when she gives in?Poor Maddie. She's taken for granted by her husband and has to deal with the town gossip of those snide women on the PTA. No one sees the real Maddie until Ben. He sees her and so much more and pushes her boundaries. He's a sweet man and it was obvious from the beginning how intense their attraction was that it was more than a fling to him.Don't think for a minute that Richard is being done wrong. He has his own secrets and turns out not to be a nice man at all.This was a pretty short book. I wish we would have seen more future in the epilogue, but it was good.

The Chaos series is a spinoff of sorts from Motorcycle Man and contains a number of the characters from the Dream Man series. Tabby is the daughter of Tack the president of the Chaos MC. She's feisty and beautiful and has had a crush on Shy, one of the members for a couple of years. Shy is hot but he's also a player. He cares about Tabby a lot but doesn't realize how strong those feelings are until Tabby suffers a loss. He's there to help Tabby get through a tough time and they become close friends. Soon both Shy and Tabby realize its more than just friendship they have. But they have friends and the club to get around for anything to happen.Shy reminded me so much of Tack, and because he tells us he respected Tack and learned from him, it's makes sense they'd be similar. Both bikers, both hot, both protective of their woman and both adamant about getting their way. Tabby is a handful but she's got such a big heart. I think they were prefect for each other and it was so sweet and heart warming watching them fall.There is some drama but not too much and you expect it with a MC book. Looks like we have more in store in future stories as well. Loved we got more Elvira - and she's got herself a bada$$ man of her own.The next story up is about Hop (club member) and Lanie (Tyra's best friend from Motorcycle Man). We see a little action involving them in this book, but we're not sure yet what's going on. Already downloaded it.

Tyra knew the minute she laid eyes on Tack, the President of the Chaos MC, that he was her dream man. They shared an unbelievably fantastic night and Tyra thinks Tack feels the same way - until he rolls over, tells her it's time to go and then asks her to leave her number. She's embarrassed, upset and angry. Mostly because she's not a one/night stand kinda girl, but also because Tack doesn't know Tyra will be his new secretary starting the following week.I loved Tack and thought he was both funny and bossy at the same time. He tells it like it is and makes his feelings on everything pretty flippin clear. Tyra is perfect for him and isn't afraid to talk back. His MC isn't perfect, but they're not into a bunch of illegal stuff and are all pretty great guys. I adored Tabby and Rush, Tack's teenage kids. They were great and loved their dad. The ex-wife was horrible and needed to be slapped. The main drama that occurs doesn't come from somewhere you'd expect so I won't give that away. I will say we get to see all the dream men from the first three books in this series who all come together.  Plus, their wives/girlfriends are now friends with Tyra.There is also a spinoff series called Chaos that will be stories regarding characters from the Chaos MC. Looking forward to reading them and I know they'll be good.Great series.

Brock is a DEA agent who has been working undercover for the past few months.  His assignment was to get close to Tess; but what started out as strictly doing his job turned into more.  Brock fell hard for the beautiful Tess and wants her in his life.  His problem.... when Tess is brought into the police station and interrogated about Damien, her criminal ex-husband, she discovers that Brock is a cop and believes he was only with her to find dirt on her ex.  Tessâ€™ heart is broken and she leaves the station refusing to talk to him.Three months later and Brock is done giving Tess space.  He goes to her house with plans to claim his woman.  He explains why he did what he did and promises to prove to Tess how much more than the job she was.  Fairly quickly Brock and Tess are back together.  She learns about his great sons and has to deal with his horrible, witchy ex-wife.  Additionally, Damien wants her back and is determined to make her give him a chance.I loved this story.  Brock is wild, bossy, stubborn and rough.  But heâ€™s also sweet, soft, protective and caring.  He loves his â€œsweetness.â€  There is also a sense of humor with him that has you grinning at he and Tess.  His family is a wonderful bonus to this story, along with the girls who make up Tessâ€™ posse.  Tess is a great leading lady and a very likeable character.  She loves her man and she doesnâ€™t allow her friends or other outside forces to sidetrack her from her feelings for him.There is drama and some major shake-your-head moments with the ex-wife.  That lady is a piece of work!  There is also some other drama that I wont spoil.Overall, I loved it.  It was mostly told from Tessâ€™ POV with a few chapters from Brock.  Great epilogue too. There are currently four books in this series.  Iâ€™ve read three and have already downloaded the fourth to read next.

Okay.... This book was good but the epilogue is absolutely wonderful! Best part of the entire book!Mara was raised in a trailer park by a horrible mother who taught her she was nothing. For the last thirteen years, she's been gone and hasn't missed it. Mara has a good job, great friends, but she still believes she's trash. For the last four years, she's watched the hot police detective who lives next door in her apartment complex. Mitch is everything she wants, but nothing she feels like she deserves.Mitch has wanted a shot at Mara for the past four years. When the opportunity arises to help Mara get her two young cousins from their drug dealing and using father, he sees his chance. He wants Mara in his life and in his bed and will do whatever he has to in order to convince her they belong together.Mitch is wow! He's hot, sexy, protective, sweet and is great with Billie and Billy, the kids who are the sweetest things. Those poor kids had been through so much and I adored Billy and his insight and protectiveness towards those he loved. Mara is a little tough at first to take. Her ability to throw up a wall and think badly of herself drove me crazy, but with Mitch's help and persistence she becomes a great character I really liked. There are some great secondary characters in this story too.I mentioned above that the epilogue was wonderful and I'll mention it again... So flippin good. Billy :-) that's all I'll say.Great book and great story. I read Mystery Man too, but somehow missed Wild Man so that's my next to read.

4.5 starsNina needs a break. She's engaged to Niles and isn't sure she's making the right decision with her life. Niles never listens, he works all the time and makes Nina feel as though she's invisible. They've been living in England and she plans a solo trip to Colorado for a much needed time out from Niles. Upon her arrival she discovers there's been a mistake with her reservation, and the beautiful vacation home she rented in the mountains is actually currently occupied by the handsome owner. Nina is tired, annoyed and has the beginnings of the flu.Max is amused by the gorgeous woman who shows up at his door with the sexy accent. After explaining his home isn't available for the week and sending Nina on her way to a hotel, he discovers her at the end of his drive in a ditch. He brings her inside and takes care of her for several days when she comes down with the flu. Max feels something for the feisty spitfire and decides he wants Nina staying in his home.This is a lengthy book with a lot that goes on. There is a blooming romance between Nina and Max and we meet some great secondary characters that add to the story. There is also a murder mystery as well as a character struggling with a recent assault.Max is a protective and very dominant mountain man. He has a heart of gold and is a great man. He's attracted to Nina and recognizes that the attraction is mutual. Nina hasn't felt this alive in years. Max not only argues with her and makes her mad, he causes her to feel things Niles never has. Max makes it very clear he wants to pursue a relationship with her and obviously he isn't the kind of man who gives up. I loved Max. He may have grunted and bossed her around, but the man had skills and I'd let him boss me around anytime. Nina drove me a little crazy occasionally with her jumping to conclusions without talking to Max. She'd run and take the cowards way out before she took the time to actually have a conversion with him and learn the truth.I've had this book on my TBR list for a while and I'm glad I finally took the time to read it.

This is book 2 in the series and is Brandon and Penny's story. It's a standalone, but to me personally, I think you'd have a better feel of the characters if you read Filthy Desire first which is Matthew and Ella's story.After being together for a while, Penny leaves Brandon. He's her Dominant but she doesn't believe he'll be able to provide her the pain her body needs and craves. Brandon is crushed and has a difficult time moving forward while Penny finds a new master to give her pain. A couple of weeks later there's a terrible accident which brings Brandon and Penny back together. Finally they realize that they're willing to work as a couple to reach a compromise so each of them will be fulfilled and they can be happy together.I was so mad at Penny. She suffers remorse and guilt for her decision, but honestly I had a hard time forgiving her. Brandon is perfect. He adores her and loves her dearly. I realize why Penny felt she had to leave, but that doesn't mean I liked it. Nate and Bianca are more involved in this book, so I'm wondering if their story will be the next release, Carnal Desire. Or will it be our bartender Dylan and Daisy the new single mom.Overall I enjoyed this story and I liked it being told from Brandon's POV exclusively. It was great to see Ella and Matthew again and see how their relationship was progressing. I intend to read the next book when it's released.

Ella interviews for a job with Matthew at Onyx, a club he and his best friend Brandon own.  Matthew never becomes attached to the women he sees, but is immediately protective of Ella and wants her near him.  When he discovers she's living in her broken down car, he moves Ella into his apartment.  Ella is poor but proud and won't stay without paying somehow, so Matthew offers to allow her to cook and clean his apartment while also working at the club.  He knows she's running from someone and has a horrible past, and is determined to learn the truth and keep her safe.  As weeks pass, they grow closer and Ella begins opening up to him.  But the past is never far behind.This is the first story I've read by this author and I enjoyed it. I liked both Ella and Matthew, although I had to get used to Matthew's abrupt and honest personality.  Ella is really good for him and softens his hard edges.  The story is told from dual POVs.  The next book is Dangerous Desires which is Brandon's and Bianca's book.

Joss is kidnapped in the middle of the night by someone close to her who wants something from her father.  In the blink of an eye, she's saved and her entire past is erased.  Joss no longer exists - now there is only Jill.  Slade is her very attractive savior and owns the bar where she will be working.  The chemistry between them is not only immediate, but intense.  The problem, Slade doesn't think he's good enough for Joss and attempts to deny his feelings for her and push her away.  He's determine to keep her safe no matter what it costs him.This is a romance/suspense book.  I enjoyed the characters and liked the plot of the story.  You'll fall for Slade.  He tries so hard to push his feelings for Joss aside and in doing so, he comes across as a jerk.  But because we are provided both his and Joss' POV, we know it's costing him to act that way.  He's so protective over her and genuinely only wants what he feels is best.  When Slade finally gives in to his feelings, you can tell just how perfect these two are for each other.  Joss is also a very likeable character.  Becoming Jill makes her stronger.Overall, I enjoyed this story and will read more from this author.  It's got a nice epilogue too.This wasn't a very long story that kept me interested from the very beginning.

Liam is such a hot, sweet man. He's known from the moment he laid eyes on Megan that she was the one. Problem is, her husband was a Marine who died overseas several years ago and Megan's been unable to let go of the past.The night of Cohen's and Dani's wedding, Liam is finally able to get past Megan's defenses and they share a hot night neither can forget. Liam decides to prove to Megan that she needs to feel again and he's the man to do just that. Throw in her adorable daughter Molly and you have Bleeding Love.This was a great book about finding new love and allowing your heart to heal. It was about learning it's okay to still love someone, even though they're no longer around. Liam is a wonderful man. He never gives up on Megan even though she tries to push him away. Liam knew she was it for him and he couldn't give up. Megan is a little slow to see what's before her, but when she opens her eyes it's perfect. You'll learn her whole story and feel for her and what she suffered. Then you'll fall further and further in love with Liam. And yes.... We get to see Sway too.Touching sweet romance.

3.5 starsRebecca is a young spitfire who believes Bray somehow got her fired. She doesn't care that he's a billionaire, nor does she care that he owns the building where she worked at a coffee shop. She wants him to own up to what she thinks he did and find her another job.Bray is a very organized and structured man who lives his life according to a detailed schedule. When Rebecca barges in his office, his world is turned upside down. He's had an attraction to her for a while but wouldn't allow himself to get close to her. Without thought he offers her a job working as his live-in maid and cook at his home. They soon grow closer and enter into a relationship. Unfortunately they both have secrets from their pasts that cause problems.I'm sure you've guessed by the book's title that both of our main characters are in fact virgins. Or were as the case is. They share a strong connection that grows the more time they spend together. Rebecca is normally feisty but with Bray her youth shows and she lacks her usual self confidence. She assumes the wrong thing a couple of times and causes major drama. Bray is extremely possessive of Rebecca. Because of his past and his lack of previous relationship knowledge, he doesn't always say or do the right thing. These two really needed to communicate with one another. In addition to their growing romance, there's a side story involving Rebecca's brother and trouble he ends up involving her with.Overall this was an okay read for me. I liked the concept and storyline, just felt Rebecca was a bit naive and the side story had me rolling my eyes a couple of times. It's told by dual POVs and has a happy ending.

At 5'4" and 105 lbs, I vary between a small and a medium t-shirt, medium because the small's tend to be too tight in the shoulders, but small because the mediums have sleeve diameters that are too large. In any case, this particular shirt is broad enough in the shoulders while still having appropriately sized sleeves. The poly/cotton blend makes the collar sit correctly while still providing adequate absorption. I like the crew type collar, which makes the shirt work as a stand-alone rather than simply useful as an undershirt. Nice color as well. Overall, great T.

This is a classic knickknack: a porcelain snowman with snow-globe mid-section to be used as decoration during the holidays, but with no other purpose. When not shaken, a large snowflake resides within the globe in a fixed position. Once shaken, snow and glitter gradually swirl and settle. The overall paint scheme is festive. There are a few rub spots on the shiny gold paint on mine. Otherwise, the overall unit is well made and is pleasantly colored for the holiday season.

I have a hood over my stove in which I have had three Sylvania Halogen Flood PAR 20 50w bulbs. The hood does not have a dimming or LO/HI feature, so dimming capability for the LED bulbs is unimportant to me. These LED bulbs provide roughly equivalent brightness, color balance, and spread of light when compared to the halogen, with a power draw of just over 25w total instead of 150w. All three work perfectly, come on quickly, and fit in the hood without difficulty. The fit isn't perfect, however, as the bulbs are just slightly too long, so instead of being flush with the surface, they stick down by about one quarter of an inch. They also have a slightly smaller diameter at their surface so there is a small circular space around them that's not present with the standard halogen bulbs. Overall, I'm very happy with the operation and the power draw differential.

Wonderful for drying teflon-coated pans, expensive glassware, and other materials that are subject to being easily scratched or marred. These fairly small washcloths are powerful at absorbency and one of them lasts through an entire sink load of pots and pans without getting so wet that you need to move on to the next cloth. There are a few different neutral color designs present here to relieve boredom on the part of the dish washer. Overall, great washcloths!

Glass bottles, real sugar, and a not-too-sweet cola taste. Somehow in my imagination, this is how cola tasted when I was a kid, though the bottle was green instead of brown, before recipes changed and sugar became high-fructose corn syrup. I don't drink soda much anymore, though I still prefer Coca-Cola to Pepsi, but it's nice to find a current cola that brings back the basics using the best ingredients. And the 10 oz size is a good middle ground between the 8 oz bottle and the 12 oz can. The cap says it can be twisted off, but I used a wall-mounted bottle opener, because that's just the right way to open these bottles.

The Canon MG6820 is a slightly modified upgrade to last yearâ€™s MG6620. The overall device has the same overall size and shape but is now a shiny black instead of flat black (and word has it that the model is available in at least a few other colors). Unpacking is easy and straightforward, easily handled by a single individual. At the top we have a single page scanner, near the base we have card slots for MSDuo and SD cards, and then weâ€™ve got a paper tray that can be used for plain or photo paper. Pull up the front panel to insert the five ink wells (M/Y/C/BK/PGBK - model 270 instead of the 250 provided for the 6620), then follow the instructions on the touchscreen to print out a head alignment sheet which is then scanned to auto-align the print head. On my first attempt to connect the Canon to my wifi router, the instructions froze and I needed to cycle power to the printer. The second attempt went well, at which point I noted that the MG6820 lacks the blue wifi LED that the 6620 has to alert the user that the device is connected to wifi. I was quickly able to access the printer from my iPhone using Canon Print, and could then scan to my iPhone, print from my iPhone, and so forth, all as easily as I could from my computer.Using my Mac running OS 10.11.1, I tried printing from the Mail application, at which point the MG6800 series printer was quickly located and set up without my needing to install any software myself. Since the instructions suggest that one should obtain the IJSetup software online from Canon, then install it, I figured Iâ€™d try it out to see if it gave any improved usability. The process froze at the â€œProcessing. Please waitâ€ stage. Since it ultimately wasnâ€™t necessary to operate the printer or scanner, I discarded the Setup file.Printing speed is the same for the 6620 and 6820. The printers take some time getting ready to print the first page if theyâ€™ve been off or asleep for a while, but once they get going, theyâ€™re pretty speedy. Two sided printing works very well, though slows things down as there is a required pause while ink dries on side one of any given page. I donâ€™t see any difference between the 250 and 270 ink sets and was unable to find information online to explain whether there is a consumer-notable difference.Overall this is a perfectly nice printer. The firmware and Canon supplied software are still a tad rough around the edges, as in addition to the difficulties described above, scanning from Apple's Preview application fails on launch, freezing the printer and returning a statement that the overview scan failed to complete. Photos look very reasonable given the limited number of ink wells, and standard business and home output is on par with that from similarly priced Epson printers. This Canon series is very well designed around an individual who will be using the Cloud, iPhones, iPads, and other mobile technology frequently, but I found it equally easy to quickly connect to computers and laptops on my network without having to deal with any significant software installation burden.Note that at the moment, the 6620 is available at half the price of the new 6820, giving you a very real option to consider given that the bulk of the connectivity capabilities have not changed significantly.

Very well constructed with bright LED's that come on with 9V and come to full brightness just below 12V. With a well charged car battery, full brightness is available even with the engine off. All wiring, an LED-indicator toggle switch, instructions, and heavy duty mounting brackets are included. Wiring allows for mounting of just a single pod, or both pods, as desired. You can purchase either the flood or the spot assemblies. I found the flood lighting to be well distributed for clear lighting of a fairly large field of vision. The logos on the front and sides of the lights suggests that the lights are meant to be mounted on top of a cab or bumper, rather than hanging down from the bottom of a bumper, but there are sufficient cooling fins on the lamps to allow for either approach. Given the overall field of light spread, however, you wouldn't want to mount these lamps too close to the ground. Sturdy and well-built, allowing for use in a heavy-duty truck environment, I found the lamps easy to install and posing no problems in operation.

Available directly from the manufacturer for just under $150, this is the holy grail for Lost in Space soundtrack fans. Including the full original John Williams cues from the first episode, numerous previously unreleased episode scores, and a detailed explanatory booklet, this set of 12 CD's makes the perfect accompaniment to the new Blu-Ray release of the 3 seasons of the series and the boxed collection of Star Trek soundtracks. Sound quality is excellent, with the occasional bleed through of louder passages due to the original magnetic tape source in a few areas, and notably in mono rather than stereo, again, as one would expect. There are some musical passages not present on the discs, and very likely sourced from library material during original production of the series - for instance, some of the music from Invaders From the Fifth Dimension episode does not appear on the CD and therefore was not produced specifically for LIS. There's room for a little more detail and explanation, but nothing that can't be released in online addenda to the published booklet. The key here, the CD's, are really everything musical that I've wanted since I was 10 and sitting next to the TV with a tape recorder so that I could play back audio versions of episodes at my whim.

This is a large watch. I tend to alternate between a Seiko digital watch that weighs just under 2 oz, and a Breitling analog aerospace chronograph, which is somewhat larger than the Seiko but also weighs about 2 oz. The Seiko easily fits under a dress shirt. The Breitling fits under some dress shirts, particularly bespoke shirts where the sleeve can be designed around it. This Lucien Piccard watch weighs about 3.5 oz, is nearly twice as thick as the Breitling, and has a notably larger circumference. It doesn't come close to fitting under a dress shirt sleeve, meaning that it dangles between my hand and my shirt sleeve. While the face of the watch is quite large, the legibility is poor due to the silver hands over a silver background. This is broken up somewhat by the white fluorescent material painted on the hands, but white on silver doesn't make for great contrast. If you want to quickly know what time it is, and you happen to be in dim surroundings, this watch may not be for you.Another reviewer spoke of the red second hand. There is, however, no red second hand. In fact, there is no second hand at all. The watch has a chronograph function: the red hand is the read-out for the chronograph once started using the top button. The left-most smaller hand then provides a minute function for the chronograph, with measurements up to one hour. The right-most smaller hand simply provides a 24 hour read-out, essentially telling you if it's AM or PM, something you hopefully don't really need to look at your watch for. At the bottom of the dial is a date readout.Date and time are both easily set. The chronograph works well. The watch itself keeps very good time. Figuring out the latch on the wrist band took me a few minutes since the instructions lack an explanation that the clasp is hinged to allow insertion of the leather strap. I discovered this by accident as I attempted to insert the strap somewhat more forcefully than necessary. The overall fit and polish of the watch is very nice, with highly reflective chrome, reasonably supple mid-grade leather, and a fine crystal that has no negative optical characteristics.If you like a thick watch that calls attention to itself with some silvery bling, this is for you. If you're more of a Piaget ultra-thin fan, you'll definitely want to look elsewhere.
Nicely made porcelain ornament with gold colored hanging loop and attractive chrome applications to arms and antlers. Fans of Frozen will appreciate having Olaf on their tree this coming season.

I have white skin that easily burns. I experienced no difficulties after a day in the sun with this applied, however. I did notice that the lotion caused some redness on my face when I tried it out on a day that I was to spend inside. The manufacturer, though, clearly states that this particular product is not meant for facial use (they have other products for that), so that's fine - just for the rest of my body. The product has no strong scent and does not feel greasy or sticky. It is water-resistant, but I followed the recommendation to reapply it after going in the water. I'd like to see a 3.4oz version so that I can pack it in a carry-on bag without TSA taking it from me at the security checkpoint.

The Greensboro sit-in took place in 1960, and well into the '60s it remained common for blacks to be openly treated differently than everyone else. Haley, to a great extent, was responsible for the generation coming of age in the 1970s, the last of the baby boomers, having a very different perspective. Though it was the TV miniseries rendition of Roots that was watched, on its first showing, by more than half of all Americans, it was Haley's efforts that brought the story to light in the first place. His own personal story as to how he reached that point is an enjoyable and straightforward way to pass the time.

These are patternless, large (32"x38") dishtowels. At first glance when completely unfolded, each looks like a small tablecloth. The fabric is fairly thin. However, when used as a dishtowel, the cloth is absorbent and leaves your dishes and pans spotless. I definitely prefer these to the usual smaller and more plush items typically sold as dishtowels. The size of this is sufficient to get you through an entire sink of dishes without needing to pull out a second towel, and the fabric thickness makes these very convenient to use on delicate items. These are 100% cotton and white. I assume that they might stain easily, but if you don't mind that, these work very well.

This Samsung flash drive comes formatted as MS-DOS (FAT32) with 64.14GB of capacity. It quickly mounted on the USB 3.0 bus of my MacBook Pro running OS 10.11.1. I compared it to a 1GB flash drive that I'd been using which is formatted as MS-DOS (FAT16) that works well with my MacBook. I moved a 125MB folder of several hundred files in the finder to both flash drives with no other applications running. Moving the folder to the 1GB flash drive, which does not use the USB 3.0 bus, took just over 40 seconds. Moving it to the Samsung drive took just over 8 seconds. The device itself is a solid piece of what seems to be aluminum. It inserts and extracts easily. It does not have any sort of cover for the port itself. It has a hole at one end so that it can be attached to a keychain or similar device. At 64GB, you can carry around all but the largest music or photo libraries, but the real advantage here is never having to worry that you won't be able to easily move a large database file or PPT presentation. Great little failsafe.

Fairly small, but sized perfectly for stepping out of a shower stall. Plush and soft, without any tendency to slipping on a granite floor. Sits nicely without the edges curving up. The rug is nicely absorbent but not so much that the bottom gets damp, so should withstand regular use without getting mildew between the rug and the flooring.

This is a product currently under development and now ready for programmers and developers to take their turn. This is not, at this point, a product that end users should buy, nor is the product being promoted for that particular use yet. What you receive if you purchase this now is a pair of the smart glasses and four pages of instructions directed at developers (instructions regarding debugging tools, driver installation, and so forth).The glasses themselves look like they're out of the mid-1950s and are designed with a large face in mind. I'm used to wearing glasses all day and found these perfectly comfortable. The right eyepiece has an extra screen in back of it which produces an image of a computer screen in landscape mode in front of or slightly below where you'd normally look. As you focus on the screen, you adjust your eyes as if you were looking at something fairly close. That means that if you're driving and you focus on the screen, the road is out of focus. The screen will appear blurry unless you have 20/20 distant vision, either with contacts, or with a corrective lens in place (in the provided adaptor). (And yes, you focus on something close yet you need good distant vision to see it...that may not make intuitive sense but that's how it works). If you wear glasses to begin with, you can place these on your head as well over your usual glasses, but it's clumsy and you will probably lose a visual of the entire screen.Mounted on the glasses is a camera for still or video photos. The entire interface can be controlled through a touchpad on the right side. I found my arm getting sore as I tried to manipulate things constantly over the course of a session of use. The touchpad is sensitive and it takes a little while to figure out what its size limitations are as well as the touch necessary to differentiate moving the cursor from clicking or double-clicking. I was, however, quickly able to connect the glasses to my wifi, then access the web and view various sites without difficulty. There are no built-in speakers, but there is a headphone jack on the right earpiece. Frankly, I'd prefer sound coming from ports close to my ears, since the earpieces are already there.Charging of the device is handy using a microUSB port. A red LED lights up to indicate the unit is being charged, and a green LED comes on to indicate that the product is turned on.The screen brightens and dims based upon ambient light and you can adjust the placement of the screen to suit your needs. I had no trouble reading the lettering on the screen once I got used to the overall product. The provided lenses are simply clear non-correcting lenses which darken upon exposure to sunlight. I noticed no darkening with any home light, including UV lights for plants or IR heat lamps.The overall fit and finish of the product, such as where certain plastic portions of the product come together with the rubberized surface of other portions, is fair. Again, this is clearly a product in development, and I would expect a significant improvement in the overall polish of the product once it is in full release. I'd also like to see both a smaller iteration for those with smaller faces as well as one that can be mounted on existing glasses rather than requiring an entirely separate product. As to what I'd use these for, I'm not entirely sure. I can think of several camera uses, such as video recording a skiing run or other activities in which you can engage while having a hands-free camera while simultaneously watching the video feed. There's also the more obvious GPS operation while driving, though I worry about the need to refocus one's eyes away from the road even given the screen's presence directly in your usual field of vision. There's a mic built in, so clearly one could use it for teleconferences, but while the smart glass wearer would see the usual interface screen, the camera, of course, is pointed away - at what you're seeing - rather than at your face.The star rating is based upon the product's readiness for developers, not on the degree to which this product would have value currently for an end user. At the moment, it would be like having an iPhone with no apps except for Safari and Camera. Three stars rather than four due to the Windows-only interfaces available without any clear interface for those who develop with Macs.

From my 33 year old professional makeup artist family member: "I absolutely love this product. Super easy to use. Heats up quickly. Lightweight in comparison to my other curling iron and I love the stylish streamlined look with the white and gold color of this curling iron, the controls are easy to use. Gorgeous curls that last all day! This product does an excellent job producing flawless curls with lots of bounce."

These are cute little square dishtowels, just a little bigger than a standard square paper napkin. The set of six has three white with purple stripes and three purple with white stripes. They are soft and won't scratch anything. They aren't quite as large as typical dishtowels, nor are they quite as absorbent as I'd like. In drying freshly washed dishes, I found that I wasn't able to completely dry anything and still needed to place items in the drying rack. The dishtowel gets wet, but doesn't seem to hold a sufficient amount to dry more than an item or two. I find these great for applying wax on the car or for buffing a countertop clean with a cleanser - they are very good for those applications.The dishtowels are marked to be washed in cold water, on the gentle cycle, and then dried at low temperature. I tried washing one once in warm water, with the normal cycle, and dried it at standard temperature. As a result, the product shrank from 12x12" to 10.25" x 10.25".

The iPad Air 2 weighs about 15 ounces versus the 3.5 lbs of my 13" MacBook Pro. So it's nice to have the lighter alternative for trips where I don't need the added abilities of the laptop. But the iPad really requires a case to avoid damage to the screen in my backpack. I've been using a Belkin keyboard case. With the iPad, the combination weighs in at 2 lbs, 4 ounces. This Otter Box case, plus the iPad, weighs 2 1/2 pounds. I still save a pound over the laptop, and the extra 1/4 pound buys me some added agility. There is, however, a cost.With the Belkin, you're restricted from using the iPad in landscape mode (horizontal longer than vertical), but as the unit folds over on itself, there's a magnetic grip that keeps the iPad in place. This results in a firm connection so that when you move things on the screen, everything stays put. With the OtterBox, you can rotate the iPad so that it can be in either landscape or portrait mode. There's a small flap that lifts up, which holds the iPad in place, but it does a much better job doing so when the iPad is in landscape mode. In portrait mode, you really need to lean the entire assembly against something firm so that it can be used easily. That said, the option to turn the iPad is welcome. You can also remove the iPad from the keyboard easily in which case the iPad is still well protected in its own little case, though the screen no longer has a cover. At that point, you can use the magnetic mounting bracket to attach the iPad to a specific spot on the wall where you've mounted the backing, again in either landscape or portrait mode no matter how you've attached the bracket.All ports and controls are easily accessed. The iPad can be removed from the protective case and replaced into the case as desired without too much difficulty. The keyboard is very much like the Belkin's, which is very much like that of the MacBook Pro though the keys are more tightly spaced together. Touch typing is easy with the OtterBox keyboard. The keyboard is separately charged from the iPad and has a different charger port (the cable is included). It would be great, of course, if the two could be charged together with one cable (I haven't seen any that do this yet).Overall pros are the wide variability of the system. In the keyboard case, out of the case, portrait/landscape, on the wall on a mounting bracket or fully portable. Cons are the extra weight (though there's probably more protection there as well) and the difficulty keeping the iPad where it's supposed to be when in portrait mode.

I recently reviewed a PUR pitcher (11 cup). I was annoyed because the pitcher couldn't pour unless you held up the tab at the end of the cover without slopping water everywhere. And that was difficult because the pitcher was so heavy when full. The Brita has no such design flaw. It pours well, whether you wish to pour quickly or slowly, so filling a small glass is not the chore that it is with the PUR pitcher.The PUR advertises that they remove twice the contaminants as the Brita. Of course I can't actually test this, but the PUR says they reduce microbial cysts, metals, industrial chemicals, and herbicides/pesticides. The Brita is certified to remove copper, mercury, and cadmium.Taste is excellent for water from both pitchers. And both have an LED system on the top (with batteries that can't be replaced) that tell you when to replace the filter. The Brita filter lasts 40 gallons or two months. Same with the PUR. The PUR brand filters are about $9 apiece. The Brita brand filters are about $5 apiece.Overall I definitely prefer the Brita unit. There will be some who will be convinced that the PUR is better given whatever they suspect is in their water supply, and that may be true for some locations with well water. For those with already purified city water, I'd pick the Brita.

These wireless bluetooth headphones easily and quickly paired with my iPhone 6, then worked unobtrusively as I went from stored music to Spotify to voicemail to phone calls. The controls on the right earpiece have a clean clicking action and allow for change of volume or moving quickly from song to song as desired. Audio quality is excellent in the vocal range with excellent stereo separation. Bass response is fair, without the deep bass that you might expect from high end music headphones; high end treble is very good, but you don't get quite the sheen that you might get from other components. Voices are clear and crisp, without the muffled quality that some headsets have.The headset itself folds up for easy storage, is clearly labeled as to right and left sides, and weighs about 5 ounces. Clamping force is slightly high, necessary for on-ear rather than over-ear wearing, and for an on-ear unit that will stay in place while you run or exercise. As a result, comfort is a little less than I'd like, but on the other hand I didn't need to keep readjusting the position of the headset, so on balance these are pretty good.Instructions are clear, somewhat witty, and unlike so many components these days, were clearly written by someone with a strong command of English. The internal battery charges quickly (about 90 minutes) and provides a full day of use. The microphone is built in, very much like the iPhone's own internal mic, so there's no boom mic. Pickup is very good and colleagues at the other end couldn't tell that I had switched from the built-in mic to the headset.If the battery dies, you can still use the headset to listen, but you can no longer use the mic, which requires a Bluetooth connection.Those interested in using these in their car should know that some states don't allow the use of headsets that cover both ears.Overall a very nice bluetooth headset.

I was disappointed by this pitcher for a number of reasons:1) The setup takes quite a bit of time. A new filter must be soaked in cold water for 15 minutes, then installed into the transparent blue portion of the pitcher (the installation takes a second), and then you have to fill the pitcher by pouring water into the blue top and letting it filter into the pitcher. This process takes about 5 minutes...fill it up and wait for the water to filter through, then repeat a couple of times. Finally take the pitcher and place it into the refrigerator.2) The pitcher, full of water, is heavy and doesn't fit particularly well on the side doors of my Samsung refrigerator. It fits only on the top shelf. Smaller family members therefore find this to be difficult without spilling the water.3) Pouring, the key design feature of a pitcher, should be perfect. Here, it's not. The first time we tried to pour water into a glass, most of the water went on the table, partially from the inability to pour water slowly from the spout, and partially because much of the water went down the outside of the pitcher. This usually is due to a lip design error. Either way, I found it difficult, particularly when the pitcher is mostly full, to accurately pour into a glass and to not lose any water along the side of the pitcher.4) Taste: I asked several members of the family to differentiate between the Samsung filtered water coming out of the refrigerator door, tap water (which in my area is supposedly pretty good), and water from the PUR pitcher, all at the same temperature. None was able to distinguish among the three glasses of water. Of course, much of what this filter filters out probably can't be tasted, and hopefully I don't have much of that anyway in my tap water. Needless to say, no bad taste is imparted by the PUR pitcher. I'm pleased, of course, that fluoride is not filtered out of the water.5) LED unit at the top is sealed and a button is pushed for five seconds to show filter status. Not sure how long the batteries will last, but they can't be replaced.I can't fault the pitcher for its size - big families need a lot of water, so it's nice to have this 11 cup option. However, given the weight and the fact that in big families, there might be kids around, I'd like to see a top that can be quickly snapped closed so that no water spills in the process of taking it out of the refrigerator, or putting it back. I'd also like to see a spout that provides some greater ability to pour water into a glass without overpouring or dribbling down the side of the pitcher as you slow down your pouring rate. Fit and finish is otherwise good. Stars lost due to poor pouring ability as well as high setup time compared to competing products.

This small wifi enabled camera is surprisingly complex. Starting out, you install the necessary app on your iPhone (or Android). I installed it on my iOS9 iPhone6 and had no difficulties connecting to the camera. Note that if you already have a TRENDnet AC adaptor, you need a different app for the camera. Once you connect to the camera, you instruct the camera how to connect to your home wifi, then you switch over to the regular wifi for your connection. The camera provides a clear picture, in full color in the daytime, and monochrome at night using an installed IR light source. The camera cannot be moved remotely, but it has a wide adjustment range whether the base is mounted on a table or on a wall (hardware is provided for wall mounting). Once I hooked it up, I found that the date/time was wrong and that the app had no functionality for adjusting that. That led me back to the printed users guide, which didn't help, and then to the more thorough pdf file available online from TRENDnet. I then connected to the camera from my Mac using a local URL. That allowed me to set the time, date, as well as more advanced video capabilities (better resolution and frame rate than the default setting). On several occasions, my iPhone app attempted to upgrade the firmware from the installed 1.0.0 version, but this failed after three efforts. Then I found that from the TRENDnet site, I could download a more current version of the firmware, and I was able to successfully install that from my Mac using the local connection. In the box is a small sticker that contains a cloud-based URL so that you can see the camera's visual output from any internet connection. Note that the camera also contains a mic so that you can hear everything going on as well. And there's a small speaker so if you wish, you can speak from a remote location. Speaking and listening both have a short delay over the internet. Obviously, the entire setup is meant to view, listen to, and speak remotely to a baby, but the unit can be used for any purpose, and with the LiveView capabilities on a computer, you could use this as an always-on security camera to watch over a remote location. Although complicated, and with firmware that isn't quite perfected, there's obviously significant potential here as well as significant functionality that is more adjustable than those of competing products. If ability to remotely move the camera is important, you'll want to look elsewhere, but otherwise, this presents an inexpensive and very workable approach.

My 11 year old son has extensive Nerf gun experience. His first impressions of this unit were based on failed efforts to get the gun to work. It took a few minutes to discover that the energizing button works only if the dart canisters are turned to the correct position. Once we got past that, he couldn't get the darts to actually fire. The BOOMco unit needs the firing trigger to be pulled back much farther than a comparable Nerf unit. The firing trigger also needs to be pulled back more slowly to prevent jams, at least at first. And there were many jams at first. The blaster was disappointing in terms of jam frequency. There were simply too many times when one would pull the trigger with a full dart canister and not be able to fire a dart.When the darts do fire, they do so with fairly good range - about 20-30'. There is a small target provided to which the darts stick and can be removed. Darts do not stick to anything else. Definitely should not be used without eye protection on anyone in the shooting zone. My son's conclusion: It's essentially a copy of the Nerf. I prefer the Nerf gun.

This trimmer includes three attachments, one that essentially gives you a haircut to a desired length, one that trims your beard and mustache to a desired length, and one that can be used on other body hair. Generally, body hair attachments for men leave something to be desired, rarely working without leaving you bleeding in several places. This attachment actually works; there's no pulling nor any slicing of skin. If you're looking for baby smooth skin, you will still have to follow up with a shaver, but if you're happy to bring things down to a light stubble, this is perfect. The beard/mustache trimmer, similarly, requires follow-up with a shave for those areas where you want things smooth. Frankly, the products out there that try to combine shaving and trimming don't work this well for trimming, and this Panasonic even has an extendable trimmer that can be used on sideburns or for precise shaping. The trimmer works well and is placed intuitively, again differently from most products and most similar to some of the older Braun shaver's trimmer extensions. This product charges fully in about an hour and will run for an extended period without getting too hot. The entire unit is washable under the tap, and oil is included so that you can treat the blades after they dry from washing, along with a small cleaning brush. Note that once the rechargeable battery has died, the entire unit is discarded (once the battery has been removed, which based on the illustrated directions is a rather lengthy process). Overall, the Panasonic is better than the competition and works exactly as promoted.

I've been a North Face fan for many years but I've been having problems with their zippers on more recent coats and their newer model ski jackets simply aren't as warm as their earlier models. I figured I'd try a Helly Hansen Epic. The coat is clearly more fashionable, but is the Primaloft insulation warm enough? It's not cold enough out to tell yet, but in the meantime:The coat is a waterproof shell filled with Primaloft insulation. There are two soft zippered pockets toward the bottom of the jacket, two vertical zippered pockets at the chest, one of which has a cleaning cloth for your goggles/glasses, and two diagonal zippered segments at the outer chest which provide air flow should you become too warm. There's a small zipped pocket at the left wrist, and another inside the main zipper on the left. There is also a large mesh storage area inside the right side. There is a handliner through which you place your thumbs so that there is no open space between gloves and the coat. There's also a snapped elastic inner band at the waist (which is removable) to keep snow out as you go through deep powder. The hood is large -- too large for regular use, but perfect for coming over the top of a ski helmet. The main zipper is a bit hard to get going at first, but I don't see any problem areas like with the North Face design where the zipper can easily grab fabric and get caught. Overall fit and finish is consistent with the cost of the jacket. The material is soft where it might touch your skin, particularly around the neck.So far, so good. Will bump up to five stars if it keeps me warm and dry when skiing.

Beautiful polarizing filter. Fit and finish are perfect and the polarizing lens turns easily and smoothly. I noticed right away that light transmission is markedly improved (by about one stop) when compared to my Canon PL-C II polarizing filter. That alone is worth the price of admission. I tried out the filter on a Canon 70-200 2.8L IS II lens and had no trouble autofocusing in low light despite the addition of the polarizer, something which isn't always the case with other polarizers. The grip is wide so there's no difficulty adjusting the polarizer as you frame your shot.One thing to keep in mind: if you tighten the filter too much, it will be difficult to remove since the front of the filter will simply turn in place. On the other hand, if you don't tighten the filter enough, there's a chance that as you adjust the filter, you will simply screw/unscrew the entire assembly rather than adjust the light flow. There's a middle ground, but the light transmission on this filter is good enough that you may just decide to leave this in place all the time and not worry about ever removing it.

Construction: If you've ever built anything from Ikea, you'll find this straight-forward. The instructions are clear, the parts are clearly labeled, and everything fits together easily and smoothly. You need only a hammer and two screwdrivers - one slotted and one Phillips. The delivery box is too heavy for one person to easily carry, so unpacking it and carrying the individual parts to the site where you want the dresser is a good approach. All the parts were present, including interesting metal knobs and all the hardware necessary to build the unit.Finish: The dresser is whitewashed particleboard. It is sturdy but, like similar products from Ikea, may not survive multiple moves. If you build it where you want it, the entire unit holds up quite well without requiring glue or bonding material other than what is provided. If you look closely at the design, you see that the top two drawers have an apparent height that is shorter than the lower four drawers. However, all six drawers are exactly the same dimensions within. There is some wasted space as the sides and backs of the bottom four drawers are the same height as for the top two drawers. There's room to pile clothing above that, of course, but things might fall out when you open the individual drawers. I'd prefer to see taller sides/backs for these drawers. Also be aware that the bottom of each drawer is fairly thin material. It's fine for clothing, but I wouldn't trust filling the drawers with heavy items, such as books. Due to the overall construction approach, you will have somewhat less storage space than you would within a similarly-sized all-wood dresser. This is typical for the price-point, however.Also note, as the company points out in the product description, that this dresser has six drawers, not eight as first glance would suggest.Appearance: The overall unit, once complete, has a light and breezy appearance, perfect for a child's room or beach house guest room. The company has a line of similar appearing units such as nightstands that coordinate well.

Kinetic sculptures are eye-catching, and some of the finest out there are thousands of dollars. Take a look at Mark White's sculptures, for example, to see what the best of the breed are like. So I was curious to see what just over one hundred dollars would fetch. This particular model is composed of two designed wheels on which you bend the spokes to a 30 degree angle so that both wheels catch the wind and spin in opposite directions. The process is easy and takes only a minute. The wheels are mounted already on an assembly that screws into a powder-coated metal rod which then is bolted in place in a ground mount which can be pushed into the ground with your foot. The entire process of installation takes only a few minutes.The assembly is a little taller than your average holly bush, so it doesn't look out of place on a small lot right next to your home. It would be lost if you have more than half an acre or so. The colors stand out, and while it's a bit gaudy up close, it has an attractive and eye-catching appearance from a bit of a distance.In addition to the two wheels spinning, the unit pivots about a vertical axis so that it aligns with the wind. It takes a fairly significant wind to start the wheels spinning, though, so even in a steady 10mph breeze, I noted that the wheels would often just sit there. A good 15mph gust would start the wheels spinning. This is therefore perfect for a beach or mountain location where you're likely to regularly get good quality and constant winds. A well shielded yard, however, will likely protect the device from wind sufficiently that it won't move very much.Each of the two spinning wheels is held in place by a nut which is placed at the factory. I didn't take a good look at that, unfortunately, and in the first day, I found one of the wheels on the ground, with the nut missing somewhere in the mulch. A nut from my workshop solved the problem, but you might want to hand tighten this before you put the unit outside.

By no means do I claim to be a short story aficionado; I certainly enjoy short stories, but the last place where I read one was in the science fiction magazine Omni back in the 1980s. I travel quite a bit and often grab a book to pass the time while doing so. I am from time to time let down, not finding a text to be worth reading beyond page 9 or 10, and then finding myself having to turn to other pursuits. Here, we have just over 700 pages and a multitude of stories, so already I am pleased. If one story should fail to encourage my reading beyond the first paragraph, there's another story just beyond. This is also the first time I've read a collection that doesn't follow a specific genre, nor even from the same generation. So part of the fun here is learning something about the era, reading something about the author, and then setting out into the story that follows. Obviously I can't say whether these are the best short stories ever written, nor whether they are accurately representative of each decade. What I can do is state that the overall text permitted me to enjoy the passing of several hours which would otherwise have been doomed by the surroundings in a coach seat of a modern overcrowded transport. Bravo.

Appearance: Attractive black glass top through which bright green LEDs display your weight.Accuracy: I have a mechanical medical scale against which I compared the nuyu scale. The nuyu scale appears to be quite accurate, providing weight validated against the mechanical scale, and reliably providing the same weight on repetitive measurements.Functionality: The scale itself works nicely, automatically turning itself on and off as necessary. It provides a stable base so long as it is used on hard flooring rather than carpeting. My one foot square tile surface in the bath worked well.Bluetooth Connectivity: Here is where the nuyu loses a point. The initial connection to the app is made by starting the app and standing on the scale when instructed. Your weight is transferred to the app and compared to a target weight that you've set. You may have a target weight above or below your current weight as desired. All is well at this point, until you go to use the scale again the next day. Even with my iPhone 6 nearby and turned on, with bluetooth on, standing on the scale will not cause connectivity to engage. You have to actually run the nuyu app again, and then find the unlabeled control which will prompt you to stand on the scale, which turns on the bluetooth connection. The app then displays your change of weight over time but does not transfer over all weights for which you did not connect the scale. That is, if you used the scale between connections, the scale does not store these weights for transfer when you finally do make the bluetooth connection again, such as, say, most bluetooth blood pressure devices do. The app itself does not clearly depict the method by which you should reconnect to the scale each time you use it, and the process will initially take some trial and error (hint: the little circle at the top right does the trick).

Wet your face and hands, pour some of this powder into hands, rub, and then use for facial cleansing. Straightforward enough and works well. This is a very mild exfoliant as well, but I noticed no scratchiness and no dryness after use. The product can easily be used daily before toning and moisturizer. In doing so, I had no irritation or redness. The powder exits the container rather like baby powder and quickly dissolves in damp hands. Once that takes place, you simply have what appear to be soapy hands but without the negative characteristics of soap or the ingredients of liquid cleanser products. There is very mild flowery scent in powder form that is nearly eliminated once the product dissolves. I noticed no significant scent on application. I note that some have complained about the product packaging; mine arrived intact without leakage, pours out easily, with a sliding cap that can be easily operated with one hand.

This is a redesign of a part that was previously all brass. The difficulty with the brass part is that it would become caked with lime and then stop turning. The new design is part brass, part plastic, with the valve assembly internally entirely redesigned. It fits perfectly, works smoothly, and cleanly moves to the on and off positions (unlike the prior design). We'll have to see about longevity and lime-related issues, but so far, I'm impressed with the redesign.

This mud mask is easy to apply after cleansing and causes no irritation, even while drying. It is light colored so will not destroy washcloths as you remove the product. You leave it in place for only two minutes, and it removes easily with a damp washcloth, so this is an easy addition to a morning shower without requiring you to awaken any earlier. I didn't notice any strong scent. I don't know if it actually purifies, but it certainly has a nice feel to it, and skin afterward is soft and ready for whatever lotion product you usually finish up with.

This is a cute little half-stapler that works well. Note first that it comes without any staples. Filling it is easy but you must first break the typical strip of staples in half to do so, hopefully not losing any in the process. Then you can choose to move the anvil at the base for either stapling or pinning (stapling is the usual, where the pins fold inward; pinning is the other choice, where the pins fold outward). Both work well; I found that I could staple by holding the stapler in my hand whereas pinning requires me to push down on a firm surface - that's not unusual at all. Either way, the alignment is appropriate and staples went in according to plan over the course of a day without any disagreeable outcomes. The feel in hand is nice, and the bright blue is great for a bright and colorful office where you might not want the standard black Swingline messing up your creative side.

This power strip can be wall-mounted or kept on the floor. It allows six AC cords to be plugged in, with a total draw of 1800 watts permitted before the built-in circuit breaker is tripped. There is a neon-lit on-off switch at one end of the unit. There are two indicators on the front panel, one green LED to indicate that the unit is properly grounded, and the other a red LED to show that the unit is protecting against surge. The power strip cord is thick and flexible. It has a right angle plug at the end. If your outlets are vertically oriented and have their ground receptacle at the bottom, this plug will probably need to go in the top outlet as the cord won't bend enough to clear the floor otherwise. And the cord will then cover the bottom outlet.  The 90 degree plug is definitely great for allowing furniture to be pushed back against the wall, so there are two sides to this story.The six AC outlets on the strip itself are vertically oriented, meaning that each ground receptacle falls between the top two prongs of the next plug. The outlets are rather tightly placed, so while standard three prong plugs all fit together nicely, it is more difficult to fit power adaptors next to one another. That said, some power adaptors these days are set up so that on vertically oriented strips, the bulk of the adaptor runs off to the side rather than covering up the other outlets. So before buying this, check to see what it is you're plugging in, and then figure out if you want horizontally oriented or vertically oriented outlets. There is an RF (cable TV) input and output so that you have surge protection on that line. There is no telephone or Ethernet protection here, however.Each of the outlets on the strip have child protection - a plastic tab can be moved over for each outlet.I did not test the surge protection itself so can't speak to that ability.
