I generally like LED indicators to demonstrate a condition warranting my attention, and to use a color code that makes sense. So here, since the on/off switch is already lit if the unit is on, I'd like a red LED telling me that the grounding has failed, rather than a green one telling me the ground is OK, and I'd like the red LED to tell me that the surge protection has failed, rather than telling me that the surge protection is OK. Ultimately, here, the LEDs go out in a bad situation, and since the LEDs go out, there's nothing calling your attention to a problem. And the red LED, which should indicate a negative condition, is used here to say something good is happening.Overall, it's a nicely designed power strip. Just make sure that the design is compatible with your plans.

I'm sure other reviewers will discuss the speaker's qualities for HDMI connectivity and use within a home theater environment, so here I'm focusing on the other potential uses that the Soundbar and Subwoofer present. I've had the HEOS 3 in my kitchen but the kitchen is large and I wanted a wider stereo platform as well as a device that would sit on top of the cabinets without being blatantly obvious. The Soundbar provides an excellent sound stage as well as providing the ability to hide the subwoofer in a corner, thereby filling the kitchen with a superb range of high and low frequencies without requiring any wires other than a couple of AC cords. So, no, I'm not using the HDMI in/out abilities, nor many of the other capabilities of the Soundbar. But I can easily and quickly use Spotify, Pandora, or music off my iPhone or my laptop (using the Spotify application on my Mac quickly provides access to the Soundbar and my other HEOS speakers and links). The design of the speakers within the soundbar provides a wider sound stage than one might expect with instrumentation clearly seeming to come from areas to both sides of the speaker. The subwoofer equalization can be boosted or reduced using the iPhone app with ease. I found the neutral setting to be just a tad low and boosted it slightly. Classical, contemporary pop, movie soundtracks, and even sounds of nature (rain/thunder) all sound excellent; the only downside is that poorly produced material is notably worse in playback quality than better musical sources.Overall setup went smoothly, with a firmware upgrade that took a few minutes, but I was quickly connected to my network and easily able to tie the Soundbar in with other HEOS speakers, listening either individually or as a group. The provided documentation is sparse so I used the online manual as a better reference, especially since the manual gives a complete description of the many possible LED status combination indicators, a few of which I encountered during the setup process. The subwoofer is paired with the soundbar at the factory; I had no need to make any changes there. Note that there is no wire between the soundbar and the subwoofer. You simply plug the sub in directly to an AC outlet, and the soundbar gets plugged in via a converter brick.So finally: high end stereo reproduction in the kitchen without wires, without resorting to in-wall speakers, and without needing an Ethernet connection

32" 720p televisions probably won't be around much longer as all the manufacturers move to 1080p as their low end. For now, though, we benefit by having this commodity level television available at a low price point. And frankly, with a TV this size, you will notice VERY little difference between 720p and 1080p. So if 32" is the size that you're looking for, 720p is fine. Note that this particular 32" screen is a half inch or so smaller than 32"; I'm not sure if that is universal among sets this size, but it's true here.Setup was easy. The TV comes with a base that attaches with 7 screws, or you can hook it all up to a wall hanging system (not included). The software is a little odd; I told it that I was connecting to cable, using an HDMI cable, rather than over the air and an RF cable, but it started to scan for channels anyway. After finishing and finding nothing it told me that I needed to scan for channels again. I finally simply switched inputs over to the HDMI input and all was well. There are three HDMI inputs, so connecting a DVR, a Blu-Ray player, and an additional source is easy; you also have component inputs for your old VCR. The internal speakers are perfectly adequate for small room listening, but there are audio output jacks should you wish to pipe the sound through your stereo or sound bar.The picture is very good, and if you're transitioning from an older non-HD television, you'll be thrilled. This is about the smallest size TV you should consider using today's 16:9 form factor, particularly if you actually intend to use the TV to watch old videotapes or other non-HD source material. There are several picture settings as well as sound settings, so you don't need to use the overly vivid approach often used in stores but can tone things down to where they ought to be. I saw no missing LCD colors (elements always off) nor were there any elements always on. The remote, running on two AAA's, worked well and the TV never missed a button push.My only complaint is about Polaroid itself. They simply don't have sufficient information about this model available. For example, does the TV have internal stereo speakers? Or does it mix the output down and simply provide mono output? A trip to the Polaroid website did not answer this simple question. What if I want to compare their 40" model to this one? What advantages does the 40" have besides the additional size? Sony, LG, and Samsung provide head to head comparisons for their own models. Polaroid should as well.Overall, a great value for the price point.

Two years ago, I reviewed Epson's excellent XP-850 printer, a unit that represented one of Epson's top-of-the-line models in this particular size with respect to photo output. The XP-850 uses six individual ink cartridges, each of Claria Photo HD ink, including five colors plus black. The unit can provide 5 ink droplet sizes, as small as 1.5 picoliters for a maximum resolution of 5760 x 1440 dpi. The print engine can run at a maximum speed of 9.5 ppm. A 3.5" touchscreen is present for a direct interface. And that unit retails for $100 more than the XP-830, which I'm about to discuss.So now Epson has come out with a brand new XP-830. This uses the exact same external form, so the unit is identical in size, though it weighs a couple of pounds more. The XP-850 remains available, though as of this writing Amazon has both the XP-830 and XP-850 available for the exact same price, leading me to believe that the 850 will be discontinued shortly. So now the question is: which one do you want?The XP-830 uses five individual ink cartridges. In this case, they are of Claria Premium ink, a step down from the ink set used in the 850. Further, there is standard black (for printing letters and business output) as well as photo black, leaving you with only three color carts instead of the five in the 830. The output has the same resolution and the same drop size capability. Photos look great, and are roughly equivalent to what you might have gotten in years past from your neighborhood photo shop, but there's no question that the photo output from the 850, particularly in larger sizes, has notably superior color and overall appearance. If your primary goal with this printer is to get wonderful photo output, I'd go with the 850 while it's still available.On the other hand, the 830's print engine runs at up to 14ppm, a better than 40% increase in output speed compared to the 850. And a typical printed page looks identical on the 830 and the 850. Presumably, with text output, the 830 will simply use the standard black rather than the photo black so you won't be wasting your photo ink while printing business output. So from this context, if your primary printer activity involves printing out pages and pages of text output, with only the occasional photo, the 830 would be the way to go (due primarily to the higher speed).Note that a full set of Epson brand ink for the 850 runs about $100 (standard capacity). That's significantly more than a full set of ink will cost you for the 830. So there again is a nod to the newer 830, again if premium photo output is not worth the premium cost. Note also that the 830 has a touchscreen interface that is 4.3" rather than the 3.5" on the 850, so another nod to the newer 830.As usual with this line from Epson, the unit has fax, scanner, and copy capabilities as well as printer capabilities. There are multiple interface techniques, with wifi connectivity as well as Apple AirPrint and direct camera card ports as well. A built-in automatic document feeder works brilliantly for scanning, and even manages two sided scanning of up to 30 sheets of paper. Two sided scanning can be somewhat tedious, so I wouldn't depend on this printer for that if it is a frequent requirement, preferring one of the larger units with a more dedicated scanning capability.Finally, you may wish to take a look at Epson's slightly older XP-820, which is similar to the 830 in terms of output speed and overall capabilities. There is no difference in photo or text output between the two units, and while they use slightly different ink cartridges, the actual ink is identical. The 820 has the older smaller interface screen but the newer speedier output engine. The XP-820 is available now at a price cut of $50 and given that the only real difference is the interface screen, that would probably be my pick between the two while still available.I had no trouble setting up the printer, updating firmware, and printing quickly from my Mac running OS 10.10.5 or from my iPhone 6 running the current OS. Overall Epson has done an excellent job in getting rid of the few little difficulties with this printer line over the past several years. Just like a new car where it's better to wait for the second or third year of a model, once all the growing pains have been worked through, we're now well into the Epson Expression line's middle age and as a result we have a printer that will very likely be problem free from both hardware and software perspectives.

A fine wooden box, crayons, felt markers, colored pencils, watercolors, along with pastels. Everything in the box has a spot within a plastic receptacle, and the box contains a fine tipped paintbrush alongside a pencil sharpener. All the artistic instruments work nicely and were in excellent condition within the box. The packaging is colorful and attractive. While the box indicates it is for children age 6 and up, our 3 year old loved it and began playing at once with a big smile. Of course, we needed to watch to ensure that the walls didn't get colored along with the appropriate paper and other canvases. All the contents are of normal size - that is, the crayons are like crayolas in size, the pastels are typical in size. Pencils are half-length, not unusual for colored pencils. The water colors will probably go quickly. Overall, a really fun set for a child, or frankly, for anyone who might wish to be creative without having the expense of buying fine arts supplies at typically elevated prices.

I frequently have to place shipping labels on packages, which generally involves printing the label on paper and then trying to figure out how to attach it without covering barcodes or using excessive amounts of tape. So here we have a full adhesive page, with paper stock that's thick enough to cover any prior labels or printing that you want covered. It ran through both laserwriter and ink-jet printer without difficulties, smearing, or peeling off in the printer. Most UPS or USPS labels take half the sheet and you can then just use scissors to separate the label from the receipt, which usually takes up the other half. (Avery makes adhesive half sheets as well, if that's your preference). Removing the backing paper is easy and the label adheres well to cardboard boxes, manila envelopes, and plasticized envelopes. The cost of these labels seems a little high, but I don't see a good alternative for comparison, so it is what it is.

Construction takes about 1 hour, 15 minutes. Parts provided allow for a single layout as depicted. Assembly is not difficult but requires considerable floor space. Needs to be built where it will be used, and deconstruction, while possible, will easily result in loss of parts and difficulty reassembling unless you've kept the directions. The track itself contains several features: a house with a door that opens as the train passes, a barrel that rolls down a ramp into the train, and an unloading platform and mechanism. There are also several ramps up and down. The train runs on two AAA batteries (not included) and pulls three cars. If the track is not aligned well, the cars will derail from time to time. We found it best if you want the train to run for a longer period of time, to simply remove the cars. Once each of the features has been used (door opens on house; barrel rolls down ramp), that's it until the next time you reset the feature (close the door and reload the barrel), so most of the time, the train will simply go around in circles, doing nothing....The instructions could be a little more clear if color-coded, but overall we made no mistakes as we went through the process. The build of the parts is reasonable and there is minimal warpage or other similar difficulties. Everything fit together well. Note that while Thomas is usually of interest to 3-6 year olds, they will not be able to put this together themselves, and they might find it difficult to control at the younger end of that spectrum.Thomas, as he goes around the circle, plays a tune, railroad noises, holiday cheer, and so forth, in a loop that can't be shut off. Run the train, and you're going to hear the little musical accompaniment.This track does not interface with standard Thomas track. Note that there is a single point on the track where a switch is incorporated. One pathway is along the circle, while the other goes immediately to a halt. One could conceive of adding additional track and a larger layout utilizing the switch. I don't know if components are available to accomplish this activity.

Well constructed, with double stitching in all the right places. Collar and sleeves sit nicely after washing. Cleans easily due to the cotton/poly mix and doesn't appear to shrink. This is promoted as being for boys, but looks great on girls as well.

One of the limitations of the HEOS system is its inability to utilize music sources other than those which are part of the HEOS app. So you can use Pandora, Spotify, Rhapsody, and others that are part of the system, and you can use music which is stored on your phone, but you can't stream from Apple Music. On the other hand, when you add this GO Pack, you can stream from anything which will stream on your phone, so Apple Music can now be utilized, this time through BlueTooth rather than through wifi.The battery pack installs easily after quickly taking off the bottom plate of the speaker. Don't forget to color coordinate your Go Pack with your speaker. Add the BlueTooth dongle on the back of the speaker and you can then either continue using the speaker in the usual manner through wifi, or transition over to BlueTooth and stream in that manner. The speaker actually did a great job keeping up with my transitions back and forth, and Spotify's app also did a very nice job going back and forth. The HEOS app, at one point, lost communication ability with all my HEOS speakers, but after leaving everything alone for ten minutes or so, it all returned. Just a little more improvement on the HEOS app would be nice with respect to returning a HEOS 1 to the wifi network after utilizing the BlueTooth connectivity. There are many helpful points, by the way, in the online manual available at Denon's website that are not present in the printed material - among which are the LED Status light explanations.The battery pack charges from the AC line to which the speaker is ordinarily plugged in, so there's no extra line necessary. It holds a charge as advertised and lasted for several hours (and had plenty more to go) on my test with no apparent change in speaker capabilities (as compared to AC power source).

I can't stand grilled food. I don't like the charcoal taste. I don't appreciate the fact that most people seem to burn the surface of the chicken or hamburgers that they're making while they leave the interior raw. And I don't like the mess that has to be cleaned up afterward. But I do like to be outside on a nice day. So when Vine offered the Indoor/Outdoor grill, I thought I'd take the gamble.Setup of the grill took just a few minutes and all the parts went together smoothly and easily. The entire unit is easy to handle, pick up, and move; and stable enough for cooking. I'd like there to be someplace to hang the top, however, so that when I take it off the food, I don't have to put it on the ground. Black handles on the sides and the top remained cool throughout. The heat control works smoothly, and a small LED tells you if you've reached the desired temperature.This is essentially an electric griddle with ridges so that cooked foods have the appearance of grilled food. The griddle is teflon-coated so you can't use metal grill utensils. The size is perfect for 6 or 7 hamburgers at once.  The grease is drawn away so hamburgers have a great taste, and you cover the food as it cooks so there's a steaming effect that takes place as well. Setting the hot plate to 3 1/2 gave us perfect medium rare hamburgers in just a few minutes per side. Taste is similar to what one would expect from stovetop frying minus some of the grease. If you love charcoal taste, this isn't a grill for you. Nope...this is the grill for all of us who dislike charcoal taste!Clean up afterward was easy since I just hosed off the hot plate after it cooled and I'd disconnected the electric cord, then dried everything with a paper towel.Don't leave it outside as it's not meant to be in the elements. You can easily break it back down or store it constructed in the garage as it takes up very little room.

Steil's fictional writing is as strong and compelling as her factual writing, with which she has significant experience. The author has much in common with the text's protagonist: they are both wives of a British ambassador, both free-spirited and lustful of life and travel, and both raising a young daughter. Miranda, the narrator of the book, and her family are based in the Middle East, where Steil spent significant time. As a result, the book runs thick with realism and depth. Interestingly, there are depths through which Steil seems somewhat reluctant to explore in her usual detail, specifically those around guilt and the extent to which such an emotion can impact a relationship. By the end of the text, both the Ambassador and the Ambassador's Wife have reason to feel guilty, whether over the heartache, physical hardship, and economic disaster that they have caused one another either directly or indirectly, or through the impact that they have had on the lives of others. But there are only so many pages in a book, and here I found myself often enjoying the vivid detail and intellectual insight that Steil so easily captures. I enjoyed the book and look forward to Steil's next outing.

Very nicely constructed hair dryer. Comfortable in hand and not too heavy for a full size dryer. Three choices of heating level and two choices of speed through switches that can easily be accessed and manipulated with one hand while drying. The noise level is not uncomfortably loud, but isn't as quiet as those models that promote their minimal noise output. There is an air filter on the back that can be pulled off (not turned and removed, as the instructions suggest) and cleaned. The unit comes with both a concentrator and diffuser attachment. I noticed no static or frizz, suggesting that the ionic technology in use here is effective. Overall a strong step up from my previous blow-dryer.

I tried this on my own thinning graying straight hair, and then on my 11 year old son's thick, curly, and easily tangled hair. Neither of us found the gel to be particularly useful. It provides a nice sheen, and certainly settled his locks down a bit, but neither of us liked either the scent, which was a strong musky odor, or the way our hair felt on our hands. Even ten minutes after application, if I ran my hand through my hair, my hand felt sticky afterward, so rather than my hair having a clean and lightweight feel, it had a sticky feel that didn't smell good anymore. I've liked the other Dove Men + Care products including their soap and body wash, but this one left me unimpressed.

First of all, I have a HEOS 3, a HEOS 5, and a HEOS Link on my network already, along with a wireless Polk Omni system. The Denon speakers work wonderfully. They connect to networks smoothly (unlike the Polk, which is occasionally a nightmare to reset), stay connected, and reconnect unceremoniously after a power failure or being moved within the household. They always appear available from the HEOS app, and are always present when I use Spotify from either computer or iPhone. So kudos to whomever put together the networking software within the HEOS systems. That team deserves a raise.The HEOS 1 is very impressive for its size, particularly given the fact that it is mixing down two channels of audio into a mono output. While I thought there would be less overall fidelity, there isn't, and honestly - in the bathroom - I'm pretty sure I don't need to listen to a clear stereo soundstage. The bathroom is precisely what the HEOS 1 is designed for, what with its high humidity tolerance and specific design to be in a moist/damp environment. No, you can't put it IN the shower stall, but it's fine for the bathroom counter. Adjusting the bass/treble response is easily accomplished with the iPhone app. Volume is more than adequate, even for a large bathroom. Up to 10x10' rooms should be easily filled with the HEOS 1.This is a very nice addition to the HEOS line, with a nice design, pleasant appearance, excellent software, and great sound.

I don't tend to use washcloths or body wash, generally using hands and soap instead, but since I have body wash handy, I thought I'd try this. You place body wash on the mesh side, lather up, and then use the pad to clean the area. The mesh and pad are both equally rough, though not too rough, with an exfoliating quality. I wouldn't want to use this every day as it might be somewhat irritating, but 2-3x/week would work out nicely. If rinsed and hung out to dry as instructed, the mesh/pad combo should last about 4-6 weeks. The packaging opens up easily, without sharp edges to the plastic. Construction of the mesh/pad with a small rope for hanging it up is very good. Overall, a nice product for those having body wash to use up and skin that needs cleaning.

Great yoga mat for kids. Rolls and unrolls easily and lies flat without difficulty. Just the right amount of stickiness for yoga maneuvering. At 60" in length, it's the right size for kids under 10 and not too heavy for them to carry around. Attractive largely purple color with some flower/butterfly images (well, you have to use your imagination - it's pretty abstract). Great mat overall.

Seven pens: Black, Dark Blue, Light Blue, Purple, Pink, Dark Green, Red. Each pen has a friction generating eraser at the top that looks like a clicker, but you actually press down the pocket holder to push the pen out and then release it again. The pens themselves all write smoothly and easily but generate a line which isn't quite as solid or as full as with a non-erasable pen. Under a magnifying glass, what you see in a straight line drawn with the pen is a pale area in the center of the line. As a result, the colors aren't quite as bold and the lines aren't quite as dark as you would typically get. Erasing is reasonably complete and you can easily re-write over the erased area. Green and purple are both fairly dark, so rather than shouting GREEN or PURPLE, they are such deep hues that they could be confused with black ink if looked at quickly and without a direct comparison to the other colors. So ultimately this set is something of a tradeoff with less boldness than I would generally expect from a Pilot pen, but with the advantage of erasability.

Dymo makes all kinds of new fancy printing devices, but one of the best features about the vintage Dymo printers is that they require neither ink nor power. I've had a Dymo 1700 printer for over 40 years and it hasn't failed me yet so long as I use actual Dymo brand tapes. They fit properly, the adhesive lasts forever, and they display a clear white embossed image on top of whatever color tape you choose. Here we get some nifty florescent colors to choose from instead of the bland office black/red/blue standards. Fits right into my old 1700 and looks great.

Assembly takes a minute to simply insert each handle extension into the next. You then have a lightweight brush on a long aluminum extension that can easily reach far under couches, the top of curtain rods, the edges where the ceiling meets the wall, and of course, along the floor. The kit includes three damp pads and seven dry pads, perfect for those who find vacuums a noisy bit of overkill for hardwood or tile flooring. The mop pads work easily and the pad base swivels to easily access whatever you might try to reach.

All kinds of uses. I like it in the car to keep cords out of the way. There's the bluetooth cord, the radar detector cord, the phone cord, all of which have a tendency to be near the shifter and which, with this handy wrap, are firmly routed out of the way. It's strong enough to hold thick electrical cord as well, so if you've got a long cord attached to a power tool but need only a short distance covered, this is a nice application as well. The strap has slits cut through it so that cords stay put rather than slipping out as they might if this were merely a thick rubber band. Nicely designed. Velcro holds well.

Soap-free, white creamy substance that easily lathers in the shower. Feels moisturizing, without the drying nature that soap has. Should be great in the winter, but a nice way to avoid dry skin in the summer as well. No itchiness or redness after use. Pleasant smell. Burns a bit if it gets in your eyes - try to avoid that - but otherwise nice as a facial cleanser as well.

A delicate chain meets a smoothly polished silver infinity sign emblazoned with seven small diamonds. Glistens nicely in the sun. Clasp works well. As noted, the chain is delicate and will not survive the pull of a toddler's hand. Also note that the symbol looks pretty in only one direction. It doesn't' appear to turn around easily as mounted, but this is more for an individual engaged in office work than for someone who is involved in more athletic pursuits during the day. Very pretty.

I actually don't use this on instruments but rather on cork gaskets that are used on older outdoor mechanisms. I have one device that has such a gasket between the fuel door and the body. Cork grease preserves the gasket and if applied regularly, the cork lasts years longer than it does otherwise. Whether all natural organic cork grease will work identically to the synthetic that I've used in the past, I don't know, but it applies easily and appears to have the same characteristics.This product is packaged like chapstick. The only problem is that, in a home where we have several chapsticks that often find their way to various locations, the cork grease could easily be confused for chapstick. The cork grease has no scent and has the look and feel of chapstick, even once the cap is pulled off. There are no toxic ingredients that I can see, so ultimately I suppose there's no concern if someone accidentally uses it as chapstick.

Energy saving with respect to home windows can work in two ways; here in the northeast, when I think of energy savings, I'm concerned primarily with keeping my home warm in the cold weather. I therefore want all the sun I can get and a minimal amount of air passage around the windows. In the summer, since we don't have air conditioning, we typically have the windows open. So film on the windows won't do much to save energy in my situation. That said, I do have colors that need to be protected in certain areas, so blocking the UV radiation from fading my colors is another story entirely.I therefore applied this film kit to two windows where materials were in color-fading jeopardy. The first window is a single 31"x31" pane. The second window had a single 15"x21" pane, and another 15x21" expanse divided into six smaller panes. Have you ever placed one of those small film screen protectors onto your iPhone? There's always a little air bubble or speck of dust or cat hair that immediately appears or creates havoc with your efforts. Eventually you get close but never achieve perfection. That was my experience here, though the smaller window panes were the easiest to work with. Ultimately, though, it didn't matter too much since once applied you can't really see the film in place. The air bubbles that remained weren't visible unless one looked quite closely. My windows are over 100 years old and have many imperfections in them, so your mileage may vary if you're applying the film to brand new glass.I won't know if this works to prevent fading for a year or so, but in the meantime, the film is sticking in place and cutting down on the sun's brightness a bit. So that's a start.

Nice lightweight paddle with excellent spin and control characteristics. Balances well in the hand and I find that the slightly lighter weight allows me a bit more control, if a bit less mass against the ball. I suspect the more advanced players will prefer the heavier paddle, but after going back and forth a few times, I found this paddle led to a better game than Stiga's next paddle up. The only thing I don't like is the little indentation in the handle used for the plastic logo. I'd rather have my handle pure without anything to deflect a perfect grip. How about putting the logo on the base of the handle?

It seems rediculous that I carry so many handy items everywhere I go, until the train stops running, the lights go out, or someone just needs something fixed on the spot and I'm the only one with a tool or light handy, or a comforting travel cup full of coffee and a snack.  Just sneezed all over yourself?  Here's a pack of wet tissues.  I've got ibuprophen, aspirin, allergy medicine. a camera, pen and paper, a mini flashlight or three, a battery charger with a USB outlet, a whistle, .... You get the idea.  Call me weird, and then when you need my help kindly say thank you.But when I'm not leaving the neighborhood, other than my camera, watch, and money I don't feel I have to carry all that stuff.  Still, even then, I wish I could at least have my Leatherman with me--scissors, a screwdriver, and pliers are amazingly handy to have on you at all times.That's why I'm thrilled with this multitool, because I can take it with me without having to carry a bag or wear some kind of holster.  It's pocket size, and flat, so it's about like carrying a Zippo lighter.  (Note to self: Add a Zippo lighter to my go bag.)  In fact, it has a smaller profile than that, and yet so many tools.  It's also lighter and more 'comfortable' but not too small to do the job.Do I prefer it over the Leatherman?  Of course not, but I can't go walking around an urban neighborhood wearing a holster.

This is a great diaper bag for men.  Great for outings with the kids.This sleek gender-neutral diaper bag is very light, waterproof and sturdy. The swift changing pad works great and is very convenient.I like the two pockets located on the back of the flap, where you can store diapers, cream, and travel-size wipes that you can easily access during a diaper change.  However, the pad is short.  I doubt it we can used on a one year old.I'm giving this four stars because the shoulder pad got ripped after using it for a couple of weeks.  But overall, it's a good product.

Overall, it's a good product as a handy body and face wipe. And because it's unscented it works for people who are sensitive to smells.It is more of a travel pack-about 2/3 of a Huggies's hard case. Unlike other brands, the wipes can be pulled out one at a time without tearing. No frustration of shaking to get only one whereas Huggies often come out a few at a time.  And the packaging reseals well, so they don't dry out.But they're a bit pricey, so I'm giving this item four stars.

I generally prefer dark chocolate.  Milk chocolate tends to be too 'milky' and sweet for me.Every chocolate maker likes to use words like 'luxurious' and 'gourmet' to describe their product, even when it's cheap, children's candy.  However, this Scharffen Berger chocolate deserves to use those words.

Easily as good as Pur and Braun, and the way they install and remove from the Aqua Optima pitcher is much easier than other filtration systems I've tried.  Especially good for people who are somewhat disabled.

Never thought I'd say this about a pitcher, but the design of this thing is absolutely brilliant.From the bottom up:â€¢ The filters are easy to install and remove.  They don't lock or screw in.  So they don't require much strength and there is no need for tools.* Nice handle.  Not overbuilt.  Not too small, not too big.* The well you put the water into for filtration is a nice size.  Fill it twice and you've got a good amount of filtered water.  Just stick it in the fridge and fill it again each time you use it.* The really brilliant part is the top.  You don't even have to open it to pour in water to filter, or pour out filtered water.  No clipping, snapping, or switching.  All the little openings fully open and close, water and air tight, with no effort at all.  The design reminds me of the kinds of things I find in Japan which are so useful and smartly made.* A handy counter dial on the top helps you keep track of when you need to change the filter, so no stickers or need for a pen.Generally there's no need to take it apart in any way, and because of how it's designed you can probably not bother even washing the pitcher until you change the filter.I am very pleasantly suprised at how smart this design is.  It puts all other filtration pitchers to shame.

I love coconut, and what I especially love about this coconut snack is that it's not over-sweetened.  Good stuff, nice snack.I would really love it if this company made something akin to a Bounty bar with the same, reasonable amount of sweetness.

I bought this to use as checked-in baggage for my all carbon Trek Madone 5.9, flying to Japan.SIZE: My old bag, which someone borrowed and never returned, was large enough that I could put my mountain bike in it upside down so it rested on the saddle and handlebar, without taking the bar off. This one is not that large, but it does provide plenty of room for your full size bike, accessories, and to throw in your cycling clothes, helmet, shoes and such as well.  I did have to take the handlebar off, but not remove the saddle.  I also wrapped the entire bike in bubble wrap and created a cardboard protector for the rear triangle and derailer.* Remember that you have to take all the air out of the tires before you fly your bike.  The airport requires it, and if you don't do this the tires will explode--and it sounds like gun shots, so that's a bad thing on a plane.It seems rediculous to me that these bags aren't made for you to put the bike in upside down, but that's the typical way they pack.Note that it does come with a plastic fork protector--which my wife put in the trash because she didn't know what it was.  You can get these at your local bike shop as bike manufacturers put them on all their bikes for shipping.  The bike shops then throw them away, so call ahead and ask if they have any and to save you one if for some reason you lost the one that comes with the bag.POCKETS: Besides the two very generously sized wheel pockets that run the entire length of the bag and come with two velcro straps each, there are two deep, velcro enclosed pockets on the outside as well.  These proved deep enough to put just about every small item and tool into, including my woven steel cable lock.  I placed sheets of cardboard between the wheels and the outside of the bag, which provided adaquate protection for handling by the luggage folks at the airport.CARRYING: There is not an additional strap, and none of the straps are removable or expandable.  Those handles are it.  On the other hand, I'm fairly big in the chest and shoulders, and I didn't have any trouble putting my head and arm through and carrying the bike like a shoulder bag.BOTTOM LINE: The pros use soft bags for their bikes as well without problems, but of course they have much pricier bags.  But I feel this bag provided adaquate protection for my precious and very expensive all carbon bike.  After I arrived, I took it out to inspect the bike and there wasn't a scratch on it.  Money well spent.Note that I've traveled on trains and such in both the United States and Japan with my bike in a bag like this and never had a problem or even had to pay extra.  Bikes are generally not allowed on Japanese trains for example--unless they're in a fully enclosed, bicycle bag like this one.

I started using KT Tape after I was hit by car and completely disabled in late 2010.  Both my knees had to be surgically reconstructed with cadaver parts and titanium, and I had minor spine and foot surgery as well.Because I'm a lifetime athlete and particularly wanted to get back on the bicycle as soon as possible, I understood that if I didn't give my physical therapy far more than the prescribed amount of effort, I would have to be satisfied with, at best, being able to ride at a novice level and probably never be able to walk normally again.There were a lot of things I did which contributed to my full recovery over the long term, but KT Tape was a big part of it.  I lost strength and aerobic capacity far faster and more completely than I could have possibly imagined, but with painful and extraordinary effort those things are can be recovered.  What isn't easy to get back is the strength and endurance of all the little muscles, particularly at the joints--feet, ankles, knees, wrists, hands, and shoulders.  That's where KT Tape came in.But it is important that you learn how to tape yourself properly, because if you don't it can be counterproductive.  People see their sports heroes with KT Tape on and suddenly it becomes a form of performance enhancement.  People who don't even need tape start using it because they think it makes them look like more hardcore.Every athlete, and even non-athletes can use this product instead of medication to relieve pain or repetitive stress disorder, but you have to learn how to use it properly.  There is plenty of information in the included material, as well as on the internet.  But the best resource is to study up, try it out, and ask a licensed physical therapist.

I live in New York City, which is synonymous with both airborne grime and--you may not know this latter part--pockets of green cityscapes.  Specifically, I live near Astoria Park, near the East River and the Triborough (aka 'RFK') Bridge.  So not only does my car get it all but so do my high end bicycles--most notably my prized Trek Madone 5.9 all carbon racing bike.  Both my car and my bikes get nothing but loving care and hard driving.You know when you've entered New York City because the roads are horrible: ruts, potholes, uneven pavement.  As soon as you cross the border into New York City you're in worse conditions than if the roads were unpaved.  And this shows on vehicles, which if I were to rely solely on car washes would require that I go once a week.  That's about $80 in car washes a month just so that I can look and feel decent.So naturally I use some instant detailer or car wipes once a week, between monthly car washes.  With the car, I usually do this when I have a moment in a parking garage or lot while commuting or running errands, and on the bikes I do it about every third weekend.COMPARED TO 'GLOSSER' (My previous favorite): Until this speed detailer I had been using Glosser pre-waxed car detailing wipes, a product I started using when I lived in Japan, and on occassion I would use the much pricier Finish Line Pro Detailer.  They worked better than anything else I tried, but by comparison the Glosser wipes left white streaks of wax that were obvious, and it took more effort to really make the finish shine.  Still, Glosser was better than any other detailer or spray on wax.  I might still use Glosser on the bikes on occassion because the towels can really get into the all the curves and corners of the bicycle, but then so will a shop towel.COMPARED TO WASHING AND WAXING: Sure, washing and waxing your car, or taking it to the car wash to have it done, is the best possible option, but it's expensive in terms of both time and money.  This speed detailer gives you those results with only five to ten minutes of effort.USING BLUE DISPOSABLE SHOP TOWELS: You know those shop towels you can buy by the roll in any Pep Boys or Target?  Until now, they've really only been good for the glass on my car.  They left streaks on my finish.With this detailer formula I go once over to get the dirt off, then go back with a clean, dry shop towel to finish it off for the perfect shine.  I don't have to apply pressure, or buff any film off--just wipe and it's done.BOTTOM LINE: I'm glad I tried this even though the other products I mentioned were ones I had been using for over ten years.  I've tried other formulas before, including Mother's, but never 'converted' to one as I did with this.  Try a bottle of 303 and I'm confident you will have a similar experience with it.

I know I should floss, I know how to floss, and when I'm done flossing I feel great, but the string method is uncomfortable and inconvenient.  If I flossed even once a week that would be meaningful to my dental health, and therefore my health overall.  Besides, I'm a television and film actor, so I really should do it because it makes me look good on camera--and to me that's money in the bank.Thanks to this new version of Waterpik's affordable model, I am flossing regularly.GREATLY IMPROVED--LARGER CAPACITY AND POWER: I had a different model of Waterpik before that I bought in my local drug store but ended up throwing it out.  The power ran down completely after only one use and it held slightly less fluid than was needed to make it through a single flossing--so it needed to be recharged after each use and filled twice for a single use.This model is much better.  With the upgrade in the battery, I can do three or four flosses before I need to recharge, and with the slightly larger tank it holds plenty of fluid so I can floss thoroughly and do a second pass.SEEMS LIGHTER AND EASIER TO HOLD: Even with the slightly larger tank completely full, and though the overall design is about the same size, it seems lighter than the previous model.  This design is also more ergonomic.TOOTHBRUSH: I had been using Oral B electronic toothbrushes with guilty conscience because when an Oral B's brush head wears out it's not replaceable so you have to throw the whole thing out.  But with the Waterpik Nano Sonic Toothbrush, not only is the head replaceable but it's also a much better electronic toothbrush.The Oral B model is too powerful.  I would say it's like sticking a Dremel tool in your mouth, but that would be an insult to the fine tools by Dremel with which you can do very detailed work.The Waterpik Nano Sonic seems like a much more expensive electric toothbrush but at an affordable price.  Again, this is a good item to buy if you're considering paying big money for a top of the line model, but not sure if you would use it yet.  The Waterpik will certainly sell you on the idea where the Oral B may not.BOTTOM LINE: There are much smaller, lighter, and better water flossing wands out there, but they cost at least four times as much.  This is the best bang for your buck, especially if you've never used a liquid flosser before.  While I'm sure that I will one day get a deluxe model now that I'm on my second flosser, I'm extremely pleased with this one particularly for the price and convenience.The Nano Sonic toothbrush as well is much better than the cheap Oral B models I had been using until now, and for a bonus, this one has a replaceable brush head, which means less plastic items in land fills and floating around in our oceans.

LAYOUT: I have the iPhone 5 and my wife has the 5S.  Both phones have the same layout of holes for the microphone, camera, and so forth.  So it's a mystery to us why this company would claim these screen protectors are made specifically for our phone models and yet have extra holes.The set does not include even one seal to protect the back of the phone.MATERIAL: When you buy a screen protector or 'skin' you expect the material to be pliable, sticker-like, and actually look good on your phone.  The material of these is rigid like clear, plastic packaging material.BOTTOM LINE: This design makes our pricey phones look like cheap knockoffs.  We didn't like them at all.

We already had a similar radio with all the same features, but in reality it hardly worked to the point that we thought all similar items might be equally useless, so we are extremely pleased that we gave it another try with this well-known name brand--Midland.RECHARGABLE BATTERY, CRANK, AND SOLAR PANEL, : The most important feature in any emergency radio is of course the battery.  The one we previously had couldn't hold a charge after being cranked up or charged via the solar panel.  We tried to run this one down to see how well the rechargeable battery lasted by turning on the radio and light, but unlike the other model it would not die.The last thing you want to be doing when the power goes out is sit there cranking up the battery on your emergency radio, or using precious and expensive disposable batteries you rather use in other devices just so you can hear the news or music to pass the time.  The battery in the Midland emergency radio is plenty reliable, to the point that you really don't need to worry about making sure it has disposable batteries in it.RADIO, LIGHT, ET CETERA: Like all emergency radios, this one has all the standard features, but unlike most emergency radios, due to the quality of the battery and general build, this one is not useless.They all have working radios, lights, and so forth, but most rely on you having quality disposable batteries on hand.BOTTOM LINE: There are a lot of junk devices out there which seem like exactly the same thing, but they're not.  If you want a reliable emergency radio, or one that you could also use daily without it failing when you really need it to work, get a Midland.

I like any dental care product that allows me to be lazy and still get great results.  In this case, I get the best results.  I've tried whitening strips for example, and they work, but not as well as Colgate Optic White Platinum toothpaste.I've also tried other 'whitening' toothpastes, but have seen as good results except for one I can't recall the name of.It's not whitening to the level you would get at the dentist, but most people really don't want that.  We just want our teeth to look clean, but natural, and Optic White gives you that kind of result.Bottom Line: If you want whiter teeth but without white strips or using some invention you saw on television late one night--in other words, if you're lazy about it like I am--Colgate Optic White is as good a method as you can expect, it's noticeably effective, and it's as easy as brushing your teeth.

ADDED:I must add this in because I'm very impressed with what my new TomTom did the other day.I live in Astoria, Queens, right near the Triborough Bridge.  Anyone who has driven in and out of New York City knows the tolls are criminal.  You can easily spend $20 or more a day just leaving and reentering New York City with the exception of the Bronx, whereas tolls outside of NYC are typically a couple of dollars at most.  If I miss an exit on my way home while driving on the Grand Central Parkway, just going over the bridge and coming back could cost me $11 currently--so I always have the GPS on for those drives just to remind me not to miss the exit because a few times I have spaced out or was talking to someone in the car and that happened.But there is a way to get out, and even back in to New York City without paying a toll if you are intimately familiar with driving directions around here.  It takes longer and could cost you a bit in gas, but typically if you have the time then it's worth the effort.  The only problem is, no GPS, none, not a TomTom, Garmin, Magellen, Google Maps, you name it will provide you toll free directions out or into New York City, to or from anywhere but Manhattan--until now.Here's what happened.  I had an acting gig for the show 'Flesh and Bone' being shot somewhere in Westchester.  It's only a forty minute drive, but because of the tolls I initially decided to schlep into Manhattan to take the shuttle bus the production company was providing.  I changed my mind when I thought of the prospect of a shoot lasting until late at night and having to go home, carrying wardrobe, possibly wearing makeup, on the subway for over an hour just to get less than five miles East.So I was sitting in my car, with my brand new TomTom, and asked for the impossible--for it to avoid tolls between my home in Queens all the way to the location in Westchester.  To my absolute, pure joy, it did it!  It even gave me an ETA which was earlier than my Call Time!It was a nice, easy drive that went the long way round, but didn't cost me a cent in tolls.At the end of the day--lunch was at 7pm, so when I say 'day' I mean we wrapped at 10pm--after having offered several other actors who live in my neighborhood rides home, I was more than happy to pay the single toll back in, but this TomTom did provide me the even more impossible option of a toll free drive, back into New York City and my Queens neighborhood of Astoria.I am thoroughly impressed.  This experience alone would make this GPS a five star item.---------------------------THE ORIGINAL REVIEWI like maps more than most people, and grew up with essential map skills which have carried through to my use of GPS units as an adult.  I have multiple GPS devices which I've been using for years by Garmin, Magellan, and TomTom.  There are some GPS devices I've forgotten I have for cycling, running, hiking, driving, and just plain finding my way around.For the last several years my best buddy in the car has been my TomTom VIA 1535T 5-Inch Bluetooth GPS Navigator with Lifetime Traffic and Voice Recognition but I was frustrated with not having Lifetime Maps, resulting in a yearly charge of about $50 for maps I could have received for free if I had just bought a different model.So I was in the market for a new GPS unit, wanting all the same features of my old friend, but with a bigger screen and improved functionality.  Even though that's exactly what I got in the GO 600, even though it's the same brand, it wasn't an automatic easy adjustment, due to the following good and bad points.I've written a heck of a lot here, but not everything I could have, so if you have any questions that I didn't cover, please feel free to ask.FINDING PLACES (huge improvement): I can't even make a comparison.  This unit works how you wish all GPS units worked in finding locations.  You can look up places however you want, from the same screen, by name of business, street address, or point of interest.  It's about the same, if not better than using Google Maps on an iPad.  And once you've found the place, you can immediately add it to your Favorite Places instead of having to go to another screen--which is extremely helpful if your job, like mine as a television and film actor, takes you to different locations at different times which only need to be on your favorites for a week or two.It's very intuitive in ways that no other GPS unit is yet.GRAPHICS (better maps, tiny text, bad lane guidance by comparison): The map views in 2D and 3D are better than it's predecessor, but not as good as on, for comparison, Google Maps.  Even here in New York City, the 3D view provides very sparse building models, but the roads are much more accurately portrayed than they were on my 1535T (and who really needs 3D buildings while driving anyway).Text on the screen is tiny to the point of being difficult to read at a glance.  This is a bizarre change given that the screen is bigger and a larger percentage of it is used to display the map than on previous models.  I want to be able to look at the screen once, just glance at it, and be able to read the name of the next street I'll be turning onto.Another thing I could do on the 1535T which is apparently missing on this model is touch a portion of the screen and have the voice tell me what my next turn would be, on demand, including the name of the street.  I'll have to do a diligent search, but it seems like they left it out on the GO 600.On Lane Guidance, I like the old model better which gave me a generously sized, screen wide graphic of the available lanes, highlighting which lanes are recommended.  It would also tell me to 'stay in the right lane' and so forth, and this one simply doesn't.  Instead, you get a graphic not even as large as a thumbprint next to the name of the next street or turn.  Still far better than Garmin, but not as good as TomTom's prior models.VOICES (better): The voices are better than before, but only the default voice reads street names and numbers.  Particularly given the tiny text on this version, that's a real problem.  It basically makes all other voices--a product TomTom tries to get customers to buy--useless.Still, even the default voice is more natural sounding than before.PLACEMENT (bad): I always placed my 1535T on a friction mount directly in front of me on the dash board, right in front of the steering wheel.  I realize most people put it in the center of the dashboard, but I don't understand why.  All your other readouts--speedometer and such--are directly in front of you in the driver's seat.  Only non-essentials like the stereo and climate control go in the middle of the dash.There are two reasons I can't do this with the GO 600.  One, it's bigger, but that wouldn't be a problem if it were not for, two, this unit does not have a way to flip the screen as my 1535T does.  With the 1535T I could simply turn it over so that it stands lower and doesn't block my view out the windshield, but the GO600 has no accelerometer or other ability to rotate or flip the screen which causes it to sit too high on the friction mount or dashboard.  It blocks your view significantly no matter where it's placed for simple lack of ability to flip the screen.  Why oh why would TomTom neglect to include this feature in their new design?  It's a mystery.So I've had to become accustomed to mounting my GPS on the windshield glass, in the middle, where I have to look away from the road to view it.  If this causes an accident, I'll make sure to mention TomTom to the insurance adjusters, but I'm getting used to it.SCREEN VIEWABILITY (not as good): I immediately noticed that it's hard to see the image on the screen well by comparison when wearing sunglasses.  My 1535T had the ability to turn the screen brightness up enough that I could see it just fine with sunglasses on, whether in bright or low light, and there was plenty of room in the settings to go much brighter.  And with polarized sunglasses--who wears non-polarized sunglasses?--it's worse.  You have to make sure you've got the unit at just the right angle so you can clearly see the image on the screen while wearing sunglasses or you have to take them off to view the GPS well.I'll add though that once I became familiar with the display items and angling the unit just right, it became less of a problem.  Regardless, they should have considered this and made the unit able to increase brightness beyond the current maximum.STARTUP SPEED (excellent): The 1535T was a pain in the butt to start up.  You might press the on button and nothing would happen or it would take a long time to start up and then far longer to find satellites.  If you didn't use the 1535T for a few days, for some odd reason you had to perform a completely restart, which requires you acknowledge the terms and conditions yet again.  Then it took a long time to find satellites even when you hadn't moved from the last position you were in when you turned it off.  The 1535T also would occasionally nag the user to update new maps.  It wasn't an unacceptably slow machine, but it was annoying just to get the thing turned on and ready to provide directions.None of these technical problems exist with the GO 600.  They really worked out all the bugs.  You touch the power button and it starts up immediately.  It finds satellites in the next instant, and is quick to plot directions.  It's frustration free.ACCURACY (excellent): If there is one thing Garmin has always beat out every other brand of GPS I've used on, it's accuracy--until I started using the GO 600.  The 1535T would often relocate me on an entirely different roadway, going in a different direction, mid-travel, or assume I was on the roadway it directed me to go on if I had intentionally or accidentally missed an exit I was instructed to take.  This GO 600, even in New York City, knows instantly when I'm on a different road, even if it's running parallel to the one I was directed to take.BOTTOM LINE: I love my new GO 600, BUT the tiny text, the lack of screen brightness making it hard to see with sunglasses on, the miniaturization of lane guidance should be addressed in software updates.  Still, putting aside all comparisons, this is an excellent GPS unit and the best I've ever had for driving.

I'll upload a photo at some point--wish I could add a photo just to my review, but currently can't--to show you that this apron looks rather good even on a manly-man like myself.  And not only does it look good, but it fits just fine.I'm an Actor on television and in films (Blue Bloods, Orange is the New Black, Boardwalk Empire to name a few shows I've been on) so I know my measurements.  According to the latest from Wardrobe, I'm 5'9", wear a 42 Regular jacket, and measure 36" at the belly button; so I'm not small, but not huge either.BELLY FIT: So as I wrote, currently I'm 36" around at the belly button and dropping because I've been losing weight.  This apron has waist ties which are long enough to go around the back and still have enough slack to shoe-knot tie them at the front.  I figure that altogether that makes the two ties with the width of the apron about 80 inches--plenty big enough to fit most men.I also get full coverage, so my clothes are protected whether I'm grilling steaks or working on my car.AROUND THE NECK: The strap at the top is fastened with a good old fashioned pair of D rings, placed on one side at the top of the front panel of the apron.  No clips, no buckles, no having to tie a knot behind your back.  And as with the waist, it's plenty long, so whether you're short or tall it should fit.FRONT POCKET: The first thing I thought of when I ordered this is how big the front pocket is.  It had to be bigger than a shirt pocket to be at all useful.  So I tried various common 'man-objects' in it for relative size, including a Thermos travel mug and a full-size hardcover book, but the best object for understanding size turned out to be my iPad (the model just before the iPad Air).  The pocket is plenty big enough for the iPad with it sticking out of the top, and not much else.  I could probably slip a notebook in there too, certainly a magazine would fit, but the iPad by itself fills the pocket.MATERIAL AND STITCHING: It seems durable, but it's not Carhartt durable.  The material is tougher than a dress shirt, but I wouldn't call it duck, canvas, or denim tough.BOTTOM LINE: I'm rather happy with it.  I plan on using it when I'm doing maintenance on my bicycles and/or using my fryer to make hot wings.  If it fails or disappoints in any way, I'll make sure to update this review to tell you about it.

In Japan we use a lot of this style of bin or basket, so my wife and I are somewhat of aficionados on this type of product.  While the quality and design are excellent, and we are giving it the full five stars, we do have some notes about why we would still recommend going to a Japanese store to buy this style of bin or basket even if it costs more.MATERIAL / QUALITY: The material is first rate, not too rigid or hard.  It seems durable enough to withstand years of regular use without breaking.  It is also strong enough to hold water or other liquids if you want to use it as a small bucket.  In fact, I'll go so far as to write that you could rely on this bin for heavy items such as nails or batteries as well.DESIGN: Overall, we love the design.  The cutouts are large enough for even exceptionally large hands to grab the bin, and that's especially important if you want to use it for hefty items.SMALL FINISHING PROBLEMS: Our only real complaints are about there being too many sharp edges at key points.  Again, the only reason we notice these things is because of our experience with similar products in Japan.The handles are plenty large but the designers should have rounded off the edges just for comfort.  They did so where it complimented the look of the basket, but didn't bother with the areas where this is functionally important--notably the handles and the bottom--to prevent discomfort or scratches.Also, the part on the bottom, in the center, where the plastic was injected into the mold should be smoothed off or at least neater.  Just because it's on the bottom doesn't mean it's 'out of sight, out of mind.'BOTTOM LINE: A good product, but for our money we still rather go with one from a Japanese market.  If you don't have access to a Japanese market, this is the best you can expect to find--and I mean that in the best possible sense.

We enjoyed not only the flavors of these gummy candies, but the shapes as well.SHAPES: The random variety of objects these gummy sweets come in are too numerous to mention.  Unlike Lucky Charms, there aren't just a few interesting shapes and the shapes also seem to be independent of flavor--so a clock shaped gummy wouldn't always be grape for example.My wife and I genuinely enjoy the shapes.FLAVORS: Having lived in Japan, I became accustomed to sweets which are not nearly as sugary as the ones in my native United States to the point that I developed a dislike for anything packed with sugar.  In Japan, sweets generally use fruit sugars which taste much better.  Sometimes even my favorite sugary snacks are just too sweet for me here because too much sugar masks the flavor of whatever it is you're eating.  In coffee for example, I used to use plenty of sugar, and now I can't stand plain white sugar because you need too much of it just for it to effect the taste, whether it's coffee, peanut butter, or chocolate--but a little Sugar in the Raw is wonderful, because it has flavor.  Refined sugar is also patently bad for your health of course.These gummies have a good, subtle sweet flavor, no bitterness at all, and the flavor does not taste thin or watered down.  They're comparable to Haribo but a bit less sweet.TEXTURE, CHEWINESS, and SOFTNESS: Each gummy has a nice, smooth texture and the shapes don't take away from that.  In terms of chewiness and softness as well, these are comparable to Haribo, but slightly less chewy without being too soft.  They're not tough like licorice or stick to your teeth, so they're probably a good choice for people who wear dentures, partials, braces, or who have trouble chewing but can't resist gummies.Even when we kept them chilled in the refrigerator, they didn't become hard to chew or swallow.  We prefer them cold.BOTTOM LINE:  These days even fruit chews tend to be far too sugary, and the best alternative is typically gummies and the like made for athletes, but they tend to be too pricey.  I hope the Wonka gummy candies represent a trend in the United States away from overly sugary snacks for the common consumer--particularly kids.If you're absolutely addicted to jelly beans, gummy bears, and the like and wish you could switch to something less 'intense' and sugar loaded, these are a good choice.

I'm an actor and filmmaker in addition to writing these reviews, so when I looked up reviews and videos about this style of fryer because I've wanted one for a long time, I was surprised at how bad they were.  Most of the videos were of people talking about the fryer, but not actually using it.  The only good ones I saw were a woman showing how to make hot wings, another where two drunken roommates used this style of fryer to cook frozen fish sticks which were already cooked, and a chef who talked about this particular fryer and had great tips and information but didn't actually demonstrate it.  So maybe one day I'll make a video but for now just know that there isn't a whole lot of helpful information out there about fryers and how to cook with them despite the vastness of the internet except here on Amazon.I have seen full size professional fryers used in restaurant kitchens and tiny boxy ones used in grocery stores to cook sample sizes of food products for customers to try.  I don't know how the tiny fryers manage to get oil all over the place, but that was the one lasting impression that prevented me from getting one until now.This one doesn't spatter or burn at all.  It's as clean and easy to use as a coffee maker.NO SPATTER: It's the way that it encloses properly for its size versus other designs of home fryers which are basically mini versions of full size, professional fryers.  A mini-version fryer will spread oil around like it was made to do it, whereas this one wont spatter at all.  And yet you can still watch the food frying with the top on, or even with the top open, safely.NO BURN: I didn't understand what they meant by a 'cool zone' in the product specs until I watched a video by a professional chef.  The cool zone is the area below the heating element, inside the fryer, where the oil is.  So you might be thinking they're calling something a design feature which actually isn't, until you know why it's designed that way.If you heat the oil by heating the container, then not only will the oil be hot, but the metal surface as well.  So imagine for example if you made fried chicken in a skillet or pan instead, where the pan itself is heated.  Of course bit of food would not only cook on the surface of the pan, but would bond, harden, and solidify on it--resulting in a long, hard cleaning process of scrubbing the pan afterwards.Because of the 'cool zone,' this doesn't happen, so you never have to scrub hard to remove bits off any of the surfaces of the fryer.EASY CLEAN-UP: I don't currently have a dishwasher, but this fryer is dishwasher safe.  All you have to do is drain the oil, and either rinse and wash the easy to clean parts with a sponge, or put it in the dishwasher.  It really couldn't be easier or cleaner than this design.  Again, about the same level as cleaning a coffee maker, except in this case you can clean the entire appliance.DIGITAL TEMPERATURE CONTROL: This is a great feature because it makes a big difference exactly what temperature you fry foods at.  A little hotter or a little cooler can make the difference between whether or not your fried foods are greasy, crispy, or tender.  Without a digital temperature control, I couldn't recommend any fryer.BOTTOM LINE: Not so long ago, in relationships in which gender roles were strong, women did all the cooking, and the worst of it was Thanksgiving, when the family had to have a turkey which took over seven hours to prepare, cook and serve.  Then along came cooking appliances for guys.  Particularly for guy (I'm using a cooking stereotype here which includes me) appliances like this make the difference between whether they cook or not, and particularly whether they enjoy it or not.  Guys and appliances are a natural combination.  If we can put it in some kind of machine and the result makes us look like cooking superheroes, then not only will we cook but we wont allow others to use our toys.This is one of those wonderful toys.

HANDWRITING RECOGNITION in MULTIPLE LANGUAGES, DRAWING, and PHOTOSHOP: Some time after writing this review, we discovered that, just like you would expect on a tablet, this laptop's touch screen recognizes your handwriting.  We tried it with a stylus, by finger, in English, and in Japanese.  We even tried sloppy handwriting, and it still worked perfectly.  So if you prefer to not use the keyboard, or you just don't want to switch because you have a stylus in your hand at the moment, it's very intuitively useful that the touch screen works so well.  And of course this means a lot for creative professionals like myself who draw and use programs such as Adobe PhotoShop on their computers.  Before, to get the usefulness of a brush or pen, I either had to use a tablet--which isn't as powerful or functional as a laptop--or some sort of accessory in place of a mouse which wouldn't allow me to interact with the image on the screen directly as I would do with drawn, painted, or printed material.It's a most useable laptop for creative professionals given these basic features that don't exist on Apple products.MOJO: The best comparison I can make is with cars.  You could have your choice of five different cars with similar specs, but you know it all comes down to two things--the look and how you feel driving it.  This computer has looks, power, and performance, which is why I say it's the first PC of many I've used which has 'mojo.'LONGEVITY: Sure, I could get technical about the specs, but the fact is that any computer, no matter how souped up it may be the day you buy it, is going to age very quickly.  This computer has enough horsepower and capacity that you wont feel the need to upgrade for a good five years at least, but when you are ready to upgrade you will probably want one with the same features.WINDOWS 8: I'll tuck this in the middle of the review because I feel it has to be written but it doesn't belong at the opening or conclusion of the review.  Windows, from the first version to this latest one, is a great system until you start adding things to your computer.  On Apple, you can keep adding and adding features and it wont effect the function and performance of the computer, but with Windows, the more features you use the more trouble you're asking for.  It's enough to make you want to go back to using DOS.Windows 8 not only completely ignores this historical problem, but adds to it with this new graphic based finder/desktop/proxy.  When you're a kid, and you have a lot of toys, you might have like to have all your favorite toys out at once and never put them away.  What Windows 8 does is put out all your toys, plus all your clothes, every color of crayon, and ever Pokemon character out all the time in a bizarre attempt to appeal to any and all possible whims you may have all at once.  Put simply, it's a messy collage of everything you can do with your computer, placed as a proxy for a system which has never been user friendly much less intuitive.Fortunately, you can bypass this mess, use Windows the old fashioned way, and learn to love it like an arranged marriage or the clothes your mother picked out for you.TOUCHSCREEN:  The number one thing I love about this computer is that it has all the power and convenience of a top of the line laptop, and it has a touch screen.  Much as I thought when I first laid hands on my Canon EOS Rebel T4i 18.0 MP Digital SLR with 18-135mm EF-S IS STM Lens and used the first ever touch screen installed on a DSLR, my thought was "Why haven't all the computer manufacturers done this by now?"BOTTOM LINE: The combination of a powerful laptop with a touchscreen is something we've all been waiting for even if we didn't know it yet.  Additionally, this computer is a pleasure to use despite Microsoft Windows.If a committed Apple user has to be chained to a PC laptop for work, this is the laptop (s)he will be happy with.

I'm a cycling freak, and therefore very diligent about sunblock use.  It's important that the sunblock I use actually work all day, from getting suited up as early as 4am to going home some time in the afternoon.This water resistant lotion held up rather well for a full day as a Marshal for the Five Borough Bike Tour in New York City, which had me out there from six in the morning until five in the afternoon.My only criticism is that in comparison to my old favorite, Brave Soldier brand sunscreen, it didn't hold up as well and did allow me to become slightly red.  I will add though, I've used other Banana Boat lotions before, in far harsher conditions, and they worked just fine.  My only problem with those was that they have a tendency to degrade over a few months, after which they can cause skin irritation.For most people, this is a good all-day sunblock, though I'll take one star away for not being as durable as Brave Soldier.It's a good walking around lotion, but if you're doing sports you may want to go with something that's going to provide all day protection without having take take a bottle of lotion with you.

Having used quite a lot of chalk in my time, I very much appreciate the quality of this chalk as well as the unique shades of color.The colors are neither too basic or too pastel.If you teach, and you're a bit artistic about using the blackboard, or you have some other reason to make your chalk board art really pop--such as to attract customers--then this is an excellent set to have.

I've had quite a few of these, particularly when I was starving my way through college and this type of vacuum was all I could afford.Until this one, none of them had the kind of power and durability you would need to use for more than a year.In a small apartment, this has more than adequate power to be part of a thorough cleaning.  It definitely has more power than is needed for quick little pickups.It's also great for cleaning up your desk area, vacuuming out your computer keyboard, and generally making your work space more comfortable.Note that this is not a wet-vac.  Having owned several Black & Decker hand vacs, my impression is that it wouldn't be as strong and durable as it is if it were a wet vac.This is the perfect item to give to your college bound student, whether they are moving into the dorms or their own apartment.  Particularly young people would be more likely to form good cleaning habits with a quality hand vacuum like this one.

Update to my original review: I liked these so much that I bought a small bag of them recently--except I bought Godiva Chocolatier Assorted Classic Truffles Milk Dark White 4.25oz instead.  And I was surprised to discover that I really didn't enjoy the Godiva truffles.  They just didn't have as much flavor.  So the next time I bought Lindt Lindor Four Flavors Assorted Chocolate Truffles 19 ounce instead and think I'll have a bag of these in the fridge from now on.-----------------------These are surprisingly refreshing white chocolates.  Typically white chocolate tastes about the same as butter--creamy, sweet, and not much else--but these have more flavor to them.Unlike other Lindt truffle chocolates I've tried, these also don't have that structure of a 'chocolatey' shell which once broken away reveals a slightly chalky core--at least that's how they seem when I buy them at a convenience store here in New York City.  The white chocolates have a consistent smoothness throughout.I kept them in the fridge and treated myself to one or two a day.Bottom Line: The perfect little sweet treat, just the right size, not overly creamy or sweet.  I'm definitely planning on buying more of these in the future.

This is a good device even if you're a lifetime athlete, because sometimes you may have a few years where it's impossible to keep up a high level of activity due to life experiences, injury, or just plain misfortune.  Besides which, a lot of athletic people like to track every step and calorie.But my wife road tested this item for me, and she's no athlete.  I'm Man vs. Wild, while she's Girl vs. Shopping.  On top of that, she has rheumatoid arthritis, so sometimes she finds it very difficult to do even basic activities.GREAT FOR PEOPLE WITH ARTHRITIS: That's why we were so glad, first off, to find that inserting the watch type battery in this device didn't require squeezing, pushing, or using a coin to open and close a cover.  There's a simple switch on the back which locks and unlocks the battery compartment which she found joyfully easy to use.The three buttons on the front are also very easy to operate and the display has nice, big numbers so you shouldn't have trouble reading the display.VARIOUS WAYS TO ATTACH: It comes with several ways to attach or carry the pedometer: a large clip, a lanyard wrist strap, and a clip on the wrist strap for clipping to a pocket so it doesn't just fall out and get lost.COLORS (the one CON): In Japan, where both my wife and OMRON are from, this pedometer comes in other colors including black, navy, red, pink, and white.  Why battleship grey is the only color available in the States is beyond me.  In grey, it looks like a medical device.  And as someone who was hit by a car and disabled for over two years I can tell you that the last thing I want my pedometer to look like is a medical device--like I'm crippled or elderly.  Americans like colors too people!But my wife likes it OK.

After three Dysons my standards for beauty are quite high, so at first glance at the Oreck I thought, "Wow, what an ugly, old looking machine."  First impression, it looks like an old vacuum, and it also looks industrial like something you would use to clean up a store at the end of the day.  But looking longer and more carefully I realized it actually has all the best features of classic vacuums my parents and grandparents owned, but in a lighter and sleeker design.SIZE AND WEIGHT: The motor alone is a fraction of the size of vacuums of yesteryear, and no part of the body or frame is made of heavy steel, mostly plastic and heavy duty but light aluminum.  It's not a smaller than 'classic' vacuum, but it's a hell of a lot lighter, and the over all weight seems about the same or less than a Dyson upright.NOTABLE FEATURES:* BAG: I'm glad to see a vacuum with a bag.  After many years of empting bagless Dysons, I'm very happy with the bag.  The novelty of seeing all the dirt and hair my Dyson picks up wore off within the first year, and now I think it would be a good idea of Dyson came out with a bag model as well if that would work with their technology.  It could even be a clear, plastic bag so you could tell when it's full, but the bagless Dyson with transparrent dust bin now just seems like I'm trying to sell myself the vacuum I already own.* BUMPER: If Oreck is known for one thing, it's taking abuse.
