These are industrial strength vacuums.  And part of that durability is the oversized bumper that runs along the outside edge of the body at floor level.  So when you're trying to get though the chore of vacuuming in a large space as quickly as possible, you don't have to worry about accidentally slamming it into something because neither the vacuum nor whatever it bumps into will likely be damaged.* LIGHT: It's got a headlight.  You don't know how valuable that is until you've tried it.* BIG, THICK, LONG CORD: The cord on this thing is big, thick, and durable but it's not as heavy as you would imagine.  This cord should be plenty tough to resist knicks, cuts, fraying, twisting, and everything else that can ruin your typical vacuum cord.  Dyson would never put a cord like this on one of their vacuums because it's not pretty, but like everything else on an Oreck it will likely outlive you.Only one CON: It's so loud that it seems like it's ready to take off.  It's literally about as loud as a lawnmower.BOTTOM LINE: Why not five stars?  It's a great vacuum for the elderly because the simple yet light design will be just like the vacuums that they're used to, only better.  By comparison, the Dyson has a lot of parts, switches, and requires a lot of maintenance on the part of the user.  The Oreck is simple and trouble free in that respect.  On the other hand, it doesn't actually pick up dirt as well as the Dyson, and that after all is the true purpose of a good vacuum cleaner.

You don't need to attend film school to learn to make movies.  Particularly these days, when you can carry everything you need to make a movie in a backpack or messenger bag, literally anyone with enough self-motivation and basic tools can learn to make quality films.  That's not just because the technology is now more accessible and easy to use than ever before.  Stanley Kubrik was entirely self-taught long before personal computers, and he was one of the greatest filmmakers of all time, just to name one of the innumerable examples.  It has far more to do with your ability to tell a story than with how pricey your equipment is.Most mobile devices and computers these days come with some kind of movie editing software.  For most people, who make maybe one short film a year, that's plenty.  But if you make films on any kind of regular basis, and edit them, then eventually you're going to find that you have outgrown what that software or app is capable of doing.  Even something so simple as a title screen and end credits are beyond the capabilities of basic editing software.If your computer is a PC, you might think your only option is to buy an iMac for $1500 with Final Cut Pro for another $300.  That's quite a commitment.  But the truth is, I can't think of any major function that Final Cut Pro has that Corel VideoStudio Pro doesn't for the very reasonable price of about $70.  You can actually do professional level work on this program--including color correction, subtitles, effects, voiceover, and background music.  And if you know how to use this program, the rest of them, including that industry standard, Final Cut Pro aren't very different at all.  If you can use this one, you can use any video editing software.THE DIFFERENCE BETWEEN VIDEO AND FILM IS EDITING:Please, I beg of you, edit your videos.  Even if they're home movies, nobody wants to watch unedited video footage of your kid's school play or dance recital, including you or your kid.  You will never watch that.  But if you learn to edit, not only will you watch it, but your friends, even strangers will want to watch it too.  A good book for learning video editing, which is available on Kindle, is called,How to Shoot Video That Doesn't Suck: Advice to Make Any Amateur Look Like a Pro by Steve Stockman--the filmmaker, not the politician--and a great website for learning and sharing filmmaking, no matter how humble your efforts may be, is Vimeo.If you learn to edit, not only will your videos and films be better, but you will enjoy movies you pay to see on cable, online, and in the theater a whole lot more.  It's like watching a football game when you enjoy not only the action, but how the game is played.When you edit you no longer have a video, it's a movie.  Movies are the difference between listening to an Astronomer like Carl Sagan or Neil DeGrasse Tyson bore you into a stupor as they drone on about physics, and the hit show Cosmos.  It's not because these people or their subjects are so interesting; it's because they work with people who know how to turn their boring lectures into entertaining content.WHY ISN'T THIS A VIDEO?:So why isn't this a video review?  The fact is, I intended to make a short film just for this review using this software, but the old PC laptop I tried this software on is simply not powerful enough to edit a film shot in 1080p without a lot of waiting for the processor to catch up.I could have shot the scenes in standard definition, but didn't want to change the settings in my camera.  I do all my filming on a Canon DSLR in 1080p and usually do all my editing on an iPad using several different pieces of software.This program is far more capable of accomplishing what I really want to do, all in one program, than every program I use on the iPad combined, but I don't have a PC fast enough with enough RAM to make it work.  In fact, my old PC is starting to show signs that it can't handle basic internet anymore either.That's my one warning about the program--your computer.  If you have an old computer, make sure it's fast enough and has enough memory before investing in graphics or video editing software.  On the other hand, if that's all you have, and you really want to learn to edit films, even put it on your resume, then you can make it work with compromises on video resolution and your end product really wont suffer for not being in 1080p.  You don' t need a supercomputer, but if your computer is more than five years old you should consider replacing it.BOTTOM LINE: This is a great, pro-level program at an impulse buy, hobbyist's price.  It includes two versions to accommodate slower, older computers as well as the latest, most powerful machines, but be aware that if your computer is really old you may have to compromise on image quality in favor of accomplishing your storytelling goals.With this program, you have everything you need to make great home movies that people actually want to watch, business presentations that are engaging and informative, or even shoot your own commercials for your business that are good enough for local television or posting on the internet.And you can have fun doing it.

I taught classes for over fifteen years, but only a few of those years had me using chalk boards on any regular basis.  Mostly I used projectors because I was teaching multimedia, or a white board because I was teaching in corporate conference rooms.  But I actually prefer chalk.Compared to white boards and markers: chalk doesn't go dull; there's always more chalk; and you're never stuck with several pieces of chalk, none of which work, as you do with markers.  And of course chalk doesn't need to be sharpened to work at all as is the case with pencils.  With chalk, you're never standing in front of a group of people, grab the only marker in a particular color, and find out it's useless.  Chalk on a blackboard works every time, and it's also a hell of a lot more versatile than any other way to write for an audience to see.  I wish writing on my iPad had the functionality of chalk on a blackboard.With computers and projectors, a lot of things can go wrong, to the point that you could be standing there, ready to teach a class or make a planned presentation and have absolutely nothing to show your clients or students because some part in the massive chain of technology between your computer and the big screen within arm's reach right behind you isn't working.This is a top quality blackboard and the frame is nice and solid--made of some kind of press or particle board with a wood grain graphic on it.  Of course, nothing beats a solid wood frame, but this frame is good enough to stand up to years of abuse.Small and light enough that you could carry it with you from place to place or pass it around.  You could use several of them for a group activity at a training seminar.  (To add my two cents, I really don't like it when I'm an attendee in some kind of training seminar at a company and they hand out one of these odd game sets with factory made pieces which you're not allowed to mark up or take home).  It fits in my Timbuk2 large size messenger bag, though it adds a bit of height.When ordering, please realize that this item does not come with any chalk or eraser.One negative on whomever designed the packaging--the product is five stars, just something bothers me about the packaging.  The picture on the front is of a chalkboard with two sentences written on it, "Plan dinner menu" and "Mail out cards" but it was done on a computer instead of using photography, and the text is typed out.  How hard is it to demonstrate the product, on the packaging, by taking an actual photograph of something written in chalk on this make and model of blackboard?  Many restaurants and most pubs have people who write on small blackboards like this beautifully to attract customers to their business with daily specials and special events.  As someone who does both computer graphics and photography, I can tell you a photo would have been easier, cheaper, and of course better.

I bought this set because it was cheap and included the basics.  I couldn't have imagined how useful four filters would be.HOW TO USE: Basically, choose the filter which is the color the object you're viewing is not.  So if you're looking at Mars, use a blue filter; if you're looking at the Moon, use the gray filter; et cetera.You can also stack filters, because they not only thread into the telescope but to each other as well.  I sometimes use two filters for exceptionally bright objects.Especially very bright objects such as Jupiter look so much better if you use a filter.  You can really see the details.  And for exceptionally bright objects like the Moon, it makes viewing not only more pleasant in terms of detail but because the Moon is so intensely bright it's very difficult to see it through a telescope without a filter.It can be very hard to tell which filter is which in the dark, so I suggest you mark the case somehow that can tell you the difference when seen under a red light.

My wife bakes breads and pies, making them from scratch.  First time she used this mixer she said to me, "I usually have to kneed the pie dough a hundred times by hand.  It take a long time and it's painful for me.  I just flipped the switch and it was done in about a minute!"  That was her way of saying 'thank you' for just spontaneously buying her this mixer.  And then she immediately wanted several accessories which I was glad to buy.Both because my wife has rheumatoid arthritis and because she loves to cook, any gadget or appliance which will make her life easier I don't hesitate to buy it--and buy the best one.This is the best one, the most powerful, the most solidly built.  All the internal parts are metal, whereas other models have plastic machine parts, so it's built to last a lifetime.It also has a big bling factor.  Even a professional will admire your prize possession of this mixer.  It's a beautiful, professional grade machine, that will make your life easier and make other cooks jealous.

This type of fuel wont expire.  You could store it indefinitely just for emergencies or only occasional need and it's as safe as new.  I imagine this is a good type of fuel for survivalists and doomsday preppers to stock up on for that reason, but certainly if you live in an earthquake zone where the gas to your house could be cut off unexpectedly it's a good idea to have some fuel stored.  And of course it's good for camping and cookouts as well.This is the largest canister they make.  To be specific, they all have the same circumference, but this is the tallest canister they make.  It easily fits in the pot of my JetBoil Sumo but not with any of the other parts or accessories.  Still, those other parts are small, so it's easier to stash them somewhere else in your pack than to store put the fuel canister somewhere else.If you want to get the fuel and other parts inside your JetBoil, then go with the 100gm--so long as that's all you need.  I prefer the larger canister because it keeps me prepared for the unexpected, and any little extra is a luxury while either camping or making due after a Superstorm Sandy situation.

If you're going to jump rope, whether it's for CrossFit, martial arts, or just plain exercise, you need a proper jump rope.  This type of rope is also sometimes called a 'speed rope.'  It's a great aerobic and endurance workout, especially for people who don't have the time or desire to jog.  In fighting or martial arts forms you don't do any running, but you do a heck of a lot of bouncing, dancing, and jumping, so jump rope is a great way to get in shape for that.Most exercise gyms these days will either provide or charge you about what this cost me for a cheap, plastic child's toy.  You don't want that.  Better to own and bring your own.There are other speed ropes with the same ball bearing design made of plastic, with foam padded handles, or even weights, and I've used those, but I much prefer this wood and leather model.  The wood handles are plenty comfortable, and frankly I think they're better than padded or plastic handles because they don't flex, wear, or give.  And as for the rope itself, leather doesn't whip you as badly as a plastic rope in my experience.Right out of the box, the rope will have kinks in it from sitting in the packaging, but it will soften up after the first day of using it.  I've heard suggestions such as soaking it first and such, but mine was fine after the first day.SIZING: Without debate--because some people will troll about anything--this is the time tested way of knowing what size jump rope is good for you.  Standing on the rope or measure with your feet together and hold the rope to your body, the two ends should come up to your armpits.  I'm not saying there isn't another way to size a jump rope, but unless you're doing some specific jump rope technique, that's a good general guide.  If you're going to be doing double and triple jumps constantly, ask someone who does it how to know what size you use.  I just know that when I was jumping rope every day, without any tricks, for at least ten minutes a day, the sizing above was fine.I'm exactly 175cm (I guess that's 5'8.5" or 5'9") and the 9.5 foot rope is the right size for me, if that helps.

In New York City the rule is that recyclables have to go in clear or blue bags.  If you put recyclables in regular white, black, or green trash bags then that means it's regular trash and you can be fined.But typically it's very hard to find clear or blue bags.  Sometimes the stores are stocked with them and other times they will be out of them for weeks or even months.  So this last time after we were out of them and I went to five different stores including three supermarkets and a Target only to find them nowhere, I finally just ordered them from Amazon.The price is right, and with my Amazon Prime membership I had them in two days with free shipping.  So from now on I'm not even going to bother looking for them in the store.

When I say 'all time' favorites I really mean it.  It's right up there with the Little Rascals, I Love Lucy, the X-Files, and the remake of the Battlestar Galactica series.  It's highly original, features both comedy and drama, special effects and just plain good sitcom sketches, and it's a show you can watch with anyone from a sophisticated book smart person to a small child.  Though I'm a sucker for any really well done science fiction genre show, I am oh so picky, and this certainly makes the grade with me.One small complaint though.  I've seen every episode when this was on television, and not every episode is available on Amazon.  I don't know if this is due to an error or they intentionally only include about twelve episodes out of what should be roughly eighteen.

When I was growing up and camping, I never had any kind of camp stove.  I would cook things on or in a campfire, either in foil or with my rather bulky cooking set--mostly the former.  The cook set only came with me when I was chaperoning for the Boy Scouts who only knew pancakes, franks, and beans.  Otherwise: take a chunk of meat, wrap it in foil, put it in the fire; wrap a potato, put it in the fire; an ear of corn, don't even shuck it, just stick it in the fire--best corn you ever ate.  I went camping with a five star chef once, and even he used foil in similar fashion to make--I am not making this up--poached salmon out in the middle of nowhere.Coffee was always a challenge, but I always managed to make it somehow--and many of those somehows you really don't want to know.  Stoves were for novices who needed an actual 'camp ground' within sight of their cars, or professionals who climbed famous mountains I would never see.Just about every person I learned from was an old man who was in the military in WWII or Vietnam, and knew how to make themselves really comfortable in the middle of the woods.My camping days ended when Man vs. Wild married Girl vs. Mall.DO YOU NEED IT IF YOU DON'T GO CAMPING ANYMORE?  UM, YEAH, SURE, ABSOLUTELY: Well now I have this thing, which I bought pre-Superstorm Sandy but haven't actually needed yet.  I knew of course that the gas for cooking at home would likely never be out short of a major earthquake, but hurricanes were my justification to my wife for buying the JetBoil.  I really could have (almost) used it after Hurricane Irene the year before because my parents live on a mountain in Vermont and three days after hearing they couldn't get off the mountain to go to the store because the road had washed away, I was just about to head up there with an SUV full of supplies, figuring I would sleep in my Honda Element, when they called and said the power was back on and the road was passable again.  So finally I thought I should at least try using it so that when I actually need it I won't be just figuring it out then.WHAT IS IT GOOD FOR?: Logically you would think you could dump a can of soup in the pot and cook it, but you would be wrong.  You can get away with cooking something that cooks in boiling water such as pasta or coffee, but you really don't want to try making mac & cheese or chili in this thing.  Just say no to putting any kind of sauce in this pot or anything that would require stirring.  As is, right out of the box, it boils water and that's it.There are a lot of accessories you can get for a more complete cook set.  There are frying pans and coffee presses for example which are made to mount onto the burner for windproof cooking, but just the ability to boil water is amazingly handy, particularly with this design.  With boiled water you can make coffee, tea, ramen, pasta, or boil some eggs.  And of course it's good for washing the dishes or cleaning yourself up at the end of the day.SIZE and HANDLING: The Sumo is especially handy because it boils a fairly large amount of water very quickly, so if you can keep boiling water so long as you have gas.Don't to carry so much gas?  Well it sure beats finding firewood and keeping a camp fire going.  Even if you used a grill and you were at home that grill isn't going to stay hot more than an hour without constant care and an endless supply of charcoal.  In terms of size and efficiency, the Jetboil SUMO is the best combination of the two.What I'm most impressed with is the ability to handle the pot without any accessories.  Those old cooksets I used as a kid all fit together into one unit, but they were big and you couldn't handle a pot or pan without a handle.  This thing you can pick right up with your bare hand and even drink straight from it.STORAGE, CARRYING, and FUEL: It comes as shown in the photo minus the gas canister.  You can fit one gas canister, any size inside, BUT if you want to put all the parts and a gas canister inside, then stick with the 100g canister because even though the 230g or 450g will also fit you can't fit the larger size canisters inside the pot along with the other parts.  Still, the other parts are rather small so I don't see that as a big deal.  I would rather carry one 450g canister if I think I'll need that much than a few smaller canisters.The fuel doesn't expire.  You can store it and forget it without worrying that it will go bad or become volatile within a year or two--though of course make sure you put it somewhere dry that it's not going to get damaged or heated up unexpectedly.  You can also use the fuel and store the unused portion until you need it.BOTTOM LINE: You don't need to be climbing mountains or have an excuse to buy one of these.  Like any handy thing, such as a Leatherman, it's something you will be glad you have when you need it, as well as a nice extra to have when you go on a picnic or other outing.  Put it in the car on road trips or when you're heading out into bad weather just in case.Also, before you really need it, make sure you have used it a few times.  Make a few lunches with it, just for practice.  That way you wont fumble with it when you're under pressure.

It's termed the iPad 4 but technically it's the iPad 6.I bought this particular model several months after its release at an AT&T store in a mall.  They had it in stock, so I was thrilled with the fact that I could walk out of the store on my lunch break with a fully functioning new iPad.  I'm a sucker for picking things up in person, unless it means waiting on a line with people who think they are 'making history' with their purchase, in which case I just have it shipped to me at home or work, most likely from Amazon.This is my first iPad.  I held off on buying one because I'm a film geek and wanted a full HD display.  When Apple came out with the Retina Display, I thought, "That's great, but with a maximum of 64GB it's still just a toy.  I need at least 120GB."  And then they came out with a 128GB model plus a better port and it was time to buy.  All my friends who rushed to buy the first iPad, the iPad 2, and 'The New iPad' as the 3rd generation model was called were definitely jealous; but more important for me was that I got exactly what I wanted.In fact I was so happy with getting exactly what I wanted that when the iPad Air came out, a little faster and lighter than the one I bought, it didn't make a difference to me.  Sure, I'm looking forward to when Apple comes out with what I predict will be a larger, more powerful, fully functioning computer in iPad form--and I'm predicting it will be called the iPad Pro--but even then I'll probably wait until at least the next generation of that model before buying it unless it features the ability to use Final Cut Pro (which no current iPad can do).Will you regret buying this one instead of the iPad Air or waiting for the next model?  I don't think so.  First thing, it's nearly as powerful as the iPad Air, and if you wait for the next model you're going to pay top dollar.  If you wait for the price to drop, then you're going to want the model after that.  And the cycle of suffering on this matter is endless.When you're ready to buy, then buy.  Buy the one you want.  This one versus the Air, personally I think the only significant difference is price, that you're not missing something.  Just make sure to buy it new from an authorized Apple dealer.

I want to make this device the subject of my first video review, but right now I just want to write something quick about it.Anyone who has been through physical therapy after surgery or an accident is familiar with this type of device.  I had always thought it was to strengthen the muscles around my knees, which were both surgically reconstructed with cadaver parts and titanium after I was hit by a car.  But it turns out it's to soften the tissues which have become stiff and painful.Even though I've had hours and hours of experience with this kind of therapy, I didn't really understand how good it is until I tried this unit.  For starters, it's just as strong and effective as the larger machine you will find at your orthopedic surgeon's physical therapy area, but--minus the belt clip holder which I personally don't use--it can easily fit in your hand.  The unit is pocket sized, and the pads on their holder are also pocket sized.  It comes with a nice little soft bag, so you can keep it with you when you travel.THE ROAD TEST: I had injured my left hand weeks earlier in a CrossFit class where we were doing power lifting, and aggravated the injury by playing video games and resting my head on that hand while laying on my side.  I was at the point where I stopped using the hand thinking that would solve the problem, but it didn't.  It had been stiff and painful for weeks.Two fifteen minute sessions with this--and this is why I want to make a video--and my hand was completely fine again.  I was blown away.  Ice and heat didn't work, massage didn't work, over-the-counter pain relievers didn't work, but the Omron Pain Relief Pro did.It also has worked well on back and shoulder aches, and as a result I'm taking a lot less ibuprophen.PRO?  REALLY?: Why "Pro"?  Because it's virtually as effective as the unit I was hooked up to in physical therapy.  The difference is, I can use this unit anywhere.  A Physical Therapist will use a bigger, more durable unit, but functionally their the same thing.IS IT SAFE?  WILL I ELECTROCUTE MYSELF?: This is another reason I want to make a vide review, to show how if I turn it up enough it will cause my muscles to move with each surge of power, but it is neither painful nor harmful.  Even on a strong setting, the only place I felt the effects of the electricity was on the area the pads were connected.

You expect Buddhists to be happy all the time, oozing with positive vibes.  In reality, we all have suffering and it is actually suffering--the crap of life--which is the best environment to change one's karma and pursue enlightenment.  Or to use the Buddha's illustration, the lotus flower grows in a muddy (crappy) swamp; it cannot grow anywhere else.  The lotus flower also is unique in that it blooms and seeds at the same time, so as the individual gains enlightenment they spread the seeds of enlightenment in their environment, the society, and people around them.The Life is Crap t-shirt is practically a Buddhist parable.On fit: My size large fit me well even after I gained forty pounds and my torso looked like a bag of potatoes because I was hit by a car while cycling and disabled for over two years.  And it has a nice semi-loose fit to it now that I've lost twenty-five of those pounds.Quality: I suppose you could call this a medium weight cotton, but it has the comfort of a heavy weight t-shirt.  Good softness, but not too soft.  It doesn't feel or fit like silk, so it's not 'revealing', but it doesn't feel like you're wearing a scratchy burlap bag either.  Good-to-excellent quality.Graphics: I haven't had any problems with the graphics cracking or peeling, and they're not thick and rigid so they don't mess with the feel and fit of the shirt.  The brown parts of the graphic on a dark blue t-shirt didn't stand out so well right out of the box--I bought it anyway because I really wanted it--but I got to liking it.  Now that I've been wearing it several months, I don't think about how well the graphic stands out against the color.  After all, it's for me, it's not advertising.There is a small Life Is Crap logo on the back of the shirt, center of the neck, which is green and stands out well.  I like it.Overall: Didn't shrink in the wash, hasn't faded, and after several trips through the laundry the color is still even.  It's a good clothing buy, not just a novelty shirt.

Easy to use, good soil, but the bag it comes in isn't resealable.  Since this is potting mix--eight quarts can fill quite a few pots--instead of garden soil, it should come in a resealable bag to keep the soil fresh.The soil itself is the level of quality you would expect from Miracle-Gro, so it's a natural choice.

Easy to use, good soil, but the bag it comes in isn't resealable.  Since this is potting mix--eight quarts can fill quite a few pots--instead garden soil, it should come in a resealable bag to keep the soil fresh.The soil itself is the level of quality you would expect from Miracle-Gro, so it's a natural choice.

Not too sweet, not hard, and not sticky, but a bit too soft for room temperature or warmer.We put them in a jar and kept them in the fridge, so that both in terms of how firm the caramel was, and the way it melted in our mouths was much more enjoyable than taking them out of the bag at room temperature.We only had one or two a day each and certainly didn't get tired of them.I also continued to lose weight as I had been before while trying out these caramels.  I'm not saying it's low calorie or diet food, but in terms of satisfying a craving for something sweet without digging into even a snack size amount of ice cream it really did the trick.  From the first of the year, I have lost twenty-five pounds so far.

I am an avid, amateur Astronomer, so of course I'm fascinated by this topic.It's a great topic because while it's science, it also requires imagination as we have not actually confirmed any life on another planet or elsewhere in the galaxy.

I've been taking fish oil for a while now of a different brand, where the capsules are absolutely huge, so I though I would try these fruit gummys for a bit.  In the end, I prefer the huge capsules for a few reasons.On the pro side, I'll say that they are very easy to consume, just like any very soft gummy candy.  They're not hard to chew or swallow.  If you have trouble swallow pills or capsules, this is the way to go.So fish oil gummys are not bad, but they're not delicious either, and the taste of the fish oil in these gummies isn't as good as the ones I take by Nature Made.  But again, these are easy to take versus the Nature Made ones which are bigger than horse pills.If I had to recommend one or the other, I would recommend these gummys purely on the ability to swallow them without any trouble.

UPDATE: Since I tried out this kit, I've been making chili about once a week.  I didn't realize it was so easy because cooking shows make it look like you need special equipment, rare ingredients, and years of practice to make decent chili.  But the truth is you can make chili very quickly and easily with just a few basic ingredients--and it's soooooo much better than anything you can find in a can.Literally, you can find everything you need to make chili at any grocery store.This is a wonderful starter kit, and I highly recommend it.------------------------------------------From a commercial kit, I was expecting so-so chili, but this chili is the best I've had outside of a restaurant.It makes exactly 1.5 Quarts.Doesn't it seem like every time you want to make something you saw on a cooking show it includes at least one rare, and expensive ingredient?  And surprisingly, chili has this mythology of being one of those things where you need a special mix of spices, or chili peppers which are impossible to find outside of their native lands.  Well, it turns out it is just a myth.  I'm telling you, yes YOU, that YOU CAN MAKE CHILI !!!Back when I was a bachelor, I used to think I knew how to cook, that there were at least six things which I knew how to make well.  But after I met my wife, I knew that even if we're talking purely pub food I really don't know how to make anything from whole ingredients--which is what real cooking is.  So over the past ten years, aside from making lunches for myself which strongly resemble British pub food, and my surprising aptitude for charcoal grilling (which is all about building the right kind of fire), I hardly could claim any kind of cooking ability.So one day I told my wife that I wish I could find a great chili in a take out restaurant or can, and she said I should learn to make my own.  I don't know why, but I found this project somewhat intimidating.  If it was some kind of complicated technology I could learn it quickly and teach it to others, but this chili thing had me hitting the wall.  I suppose it's because, being somewhat of a perfectionist, I didn't want to experience a failed attempt.  Besides which, food is money.  If you buy a computer program of device, eventually you will learn how to use it and it will cost you nothing to do so, but when you try to make food and you fail you waste money--and you have to clean up after yourself without the reward of delicious food.You've seen the typical chili kit.  It's nothing more than a bag of spices with instructions on soaking kidney beans, and doing some odd thing with ripe, fresh tomatoes both of which require cooking skills you don't have. How hard can it be to make chili?Not at all it turns out.Hunts made this painless.  You want to start from scratch instead?  You have to walk before you can run, so learn the basics first, then experiment.IN THE BOX: You get three cans of ingredients: Kidney Beans, Tomato Sauce, and Diced Tomatoes, plus a packet of spices.  You need these and, as it says on the box, a pound of ground beef or other ground meat.  You can find these ingredients in virtually any grocery store.DIRECTIONS: 1. Cook meat, and 2. Dump in everything else and simmer until it seems like you have chili.That's it.Now if I can only figure out which beer goes best with my chili.BOTTOM LINE: Love it.  It couldn't be easier.  A child could do it.  And once you've done it, from then on you can make your own signature chili or just stick with this one.  Your friends and family will be impressed.

I don't usually put a case on my phone at all, unless I'm doing something athletic or outdoor sports.  Generally, I just stick it in my pocket.  But I pay for insurance with my cell phone carrier for all the devices on my plan in case I break them and need them repaired or replaced.  Currently, that's a top of the line iPad, an iPhone 5 (mine), and my wife's iPhone 5S.  I have a good, shock resistant case for my iPad that also looks good, my wife has a decorative case for her iPhone which barely offers any protection, and as I wrote above I usually don't use any case at all for my phone.One person I asked about why they put a bulky case on their phone answered, "I'm protecting my investment."  If a cell phone is an investment, it's the worst kind.  It depreciates rapidly.  Just ask yourself how much you would pay for someone's used 4S or 5 at this point.  Not much of course.But these things cost a lot of money, even if you're getting a discount.  My wife's 32GB 5S on opening day cost me $300 on paper, but there were several additional charges, so let's say it was at least $400 out of pocket.  I would be stupid not to protect this expensive item in some way against damage; but I always purchase the insurance because not only does it protect 'my investments' in terms of damage, but for wear and tear, complete destruction, theft, and just plain losing it somewhere.  Over the last several years, I've had two phones repaired and three replaced, well worth the price of the insurance.OK, but insurance is expensive, right?  That's where you have to consider your options.  This particular case, for this model of phone, only cost about $35 currently, versus fully insuring the phone for $8 a month / $96 per year--you likely spend more on coffee at Starbucks.  So if I'm fairly confident that I will never ever lose my phone and it will never-ever-ever be stolen (I live in New York City, where stealing iPhones is common) then the case seems like a good deal.  But if the case cost $60 or more, then the insurance would be the better option.Aside from cost is the case itself.  Otterbox of course is the most famous for protecting your electronics better than any other brand in terms of impact, dust, and so forth, and some people just plain love the bulky, 'military grade' armor plating because ... because ... because they just do. but I'm a bit mystified by some of the design features--for which I took away one star.If you're going to go this far to protect a cell phone why not go all the way and make it water resistant as well?  There's a plastic window protecting the Apple logo on the back while letting you display it, but no window or gasket door for the camera and flash, so obviously water, dust, and sand can still get in.  There is also no cover for the ports, speaker, and mic on the bottom of the phone, or the home button on the front.  In other words, this case is ONLY impact resistant, where as the Life case for example is also water resistant.On the positive side though, there is no problem working all the buttons on the phone even under this thick armor.  This is a vast improvement over the Commuter case that I had for a previous phone which fit loosely and made using the buttons and accessing the ports difficult.And lastly there is this great holster clip.  While I would never wear something like this on my belt, I love it for my TimBuk2 messenger bag and outdoor sports gear.  I have absolutely no worries about this coming off if I choose to have it hanging out on a strap or even clipped to a pocket--only I would have to slip it inside a ziplock bag if it started to rain.BOTTOM LINE:Consider what it costs you to buy a pricey protective case versus just insuring the phone.  At the current price, this is a good deal and good option if you're reluctant to add another $8 to your wireless bill.The phone couldn't possibly be better protected from impacts and drops, and the holster is so secure that I doubt there any risk of it falling out while maintaining easy access.The only thing that is really inadaquate about the design is it's lack of water, splash, dust, sand, and rain resistance.  I would make sure to carry a ziplock bag with me if there was any chance I would get caught in the rain while using this case on my phone.

Once a year I clay bar my car to remove all the particles embedded in the paint, making it look brand new, same as professional detailers do.  Before applying this, however I thought it better to have professionals do the clay bar work.  They do a better job and applying this paint defender will decrease the frequency of clay barring while also keeping the paint looking new longer.

I'm a cyclist, so when I see an item made for cyclists I'm interested but usually disappointed because most of the time it seems they don't field test these things or ask the end users what they would change if they could.  Belkin obvously took their product to the field and listened to people who actually be using this thing instead of just putting team colors on it.Compared to the standard Belkin armband, there a lot of excellent changes.The fit is better on my iPhone 5.  On my other armband the home button is near the overbuilt reflective border so it's difficult to use, especially while moving.  This one the fit is very exact so my phone has no additional wiggle room I don't need.There is only one hole which is exactly where the headphone jack goes in.  No more poking around for it.  And the opening is tight enough that rain, dust, bicycle grease, suntan lotion, sports drink, goo, pieces of energy bar, or any of the other things we cyclists use while we ride don't have a chance of getting in there.  The original armband has many holes and they're always open.The key slot isn't difficult to access like the one on the original is.The feature I'm most thankful for is that the armband is a bit longer, so it fits my larger than most biceps comfortably.  To be frank, the original armband is very uncomfortable not only because it's too tight for a full grown adult male athlete, but the case is too bulky.This one is slim, comfortable, and when you're not using it on your arm it fits nicely in a jersey pocket or bento box without taking up more than its share of space.Bottom Line: Like the now ubiquitous bento box, and before that the water bottle, the design has now come to the point that I would choose this over mounting my iPhone on the handlebar--which I would never do.It's also great when you're riding a trainer--which is perhaps the world's most boring activity otherwise.This is a much improved, more usable product than its predecessors.

I wish I had bought this thing years earlier.  It's worth every penny.  If you have ever had neighbors or roommates complain about how your sound system is too loud and shakes the room, you absolutely must get an isolation riser.  Carpeting will not do the job like one of this will.I live in New York City.  I rent the top floor of a house, and the current house we live in is connected to other houses on either side--so we share walls with our next door neighbors, and our floor is our landlord's ceiling.While I love my home theater system, without this isolation riser I couldn't possibly turn up the volume loud enough to enjoy it because the subwoofer would shake the floor and the sound would travel to all the neighbors.  Besides causing problems, when the stereo shakes the room it sounds muddy because buildings are not speaker cabinets.I know what you're thinking--"But I like that!  I like to shake the room.  It sounds better."  No, it doesn't.  Trust me.  Try the isolation riser.  You'll like it.  It sounds a hell of a lot better than your buzzing, muddy sounding walls.Even with the volume turned up beyond the point that your neighbors would normally call the police, the sound hardly travels outside the room except through an open window or door, and it sounds soooooo much better.

You might think that you don't need this item because you don't see any obvious flare or glare in your photos, but you should absolutely have a lens hood for every lens you own.  You will notice the difference immediately.  It's shocking how much better your photos look when you use a lens hood.For the same reason you can see better when you're standing out in the sun if you wear a hat with a brim--such as a baseball cap--a lens hood will allow your camera to see better.  And it doesn't just shade the face of the lens from light from above, but from the sides and below as well.Besides that, there are the traditional reasons for adding a lens hood: It makes you look like you know what you're doing, and it protects the lens from getting scratched or broken if you bump into something hard or drop the camera.  The latter reason is an especially good one because this particular $20 piece of plastic protects my $500 lens--which otherwise should outlive me.As for the price, like I wrote above this item costs $20 or less here on Amazon.  On the Canon website they sell it for $40.  Enough said about that.There may be alternative lens hoods which are the right size for your lens, but if you're using a Canon lens I recommend getting the Canon lens hood.  It fits right, it looks right.And lastly I should note that with this lens hood facing out, attached to my Canon EF-S 18-135mm STM lens, mounted on my Canon T4i, it fits fine in my MegaGear holster bag.  I do not need to turn the hood around to put the camera in the bag, zippered up, at the ready.

My wife is from Japan.  She only weighs a hundred pounds; she's kid size, and she's always looking for those small size brushes like the ones available in Japan.  Until now, all the electric toothbrushes she has looked at were too large and powerful, but this one is perfect.The head is small enough to reach her back teeth without causing discomfort, and unlike my Oral B electric brush it's not over powered.  The motor is gentle and quiet.We also like--for adults as well as kids--how this toothbrush comes with several decals, with several designs and colors so you can personalize it.The only con to note is that the handle is rather large for kids--or my kid size wife--though it's not too heavy.  This is probably out of necessity to put the right motor in the brush without driving up the price by miniturizing it.  And it's not really a problem.From the day we received it, my wife has been using it every day.

Ethan Canin's new novel demonstrates that plain language and direct characterization can be as compelling as verbal pyrotechnics and indirection. The portrayal of the gifted mathematician Milo Andret is an unflinching yet sympathetic, and completely believable, examination of genius and its price. This is a theme that often leads novelists down the thorny path of caricature, but Canin is able to disentangle the realities that shape the caricature and present them as they are. This is a slow-burning novel of great scope from a writer whose carefully-hewn prose is unforgettable.

Robert Jackson Bennett's latest novel is a sequel to his acclaimed City of Stairs, which I read for the first time only a few days before beginning City of Blades. That may have been a poor choice, as the new book is quite similar in structure to its predecessor. Again the protagonist is a representative of the now-dominant Saypuri government visiting an occupied, resentful Continental city to investigate the mysterious fate of someone associated with that government. Again the protagonist discovers that an old acquaintance with whom she has a difficult history is a powerful figure in local circles, one who may end up helping or hindering her investigation. And again what she discovers suggests that the gods of the Continent, murdered by her people generations ago, may not be as dead as they seem.Of course I've structured this summary to emphasize the similarities (not all of which I've mentioned here) and downplay the differences. And of course playing with formula is part of the appeal of many ongoing series. But while Bennett's characters are as charmingly warped as ever, it takes a long time for City of Blades to feel truly distinctive, and there's a deeper level on which it can't help but lack the appeal of the first book. Part of the pleasure of City of Stairs was working out the history and metaphysics of the setting; the very nature of that universe was as much one of that novel's mysteries as what had happened to Efrem Pangyui. But this time, we already know all that. The only way City of Blades can innovate there is by giving its particular city and deity a unique and memorable identity. And while there are certainly some unforgettably unpleasant images and deliciously twisted concepts, they're thinner on the ground than they were in the first book. As a dark urban fantasy, this novel is undeniably weaker than City of Stairs. And yet in thematic terms, this may be the better book.City of Stairs set up powerful ambiguities concerning oppressors and oppressed with the complex history of Saypur and the Continent, and by focusing more directly on military realities City of Blades really digs into their ugly nature. Bulikov was seething with tension, but the occupation of Voortyashtan is an even grittier affair, and Turyin Mulaghesh's dark past, while easy to predict and rather long in being confirmed, personalizes the novel's meditations on warfare and justice. At times Bennett's characters can behave like caricatures of anti-heroic toughness, but when it counts he doesn't shy away from the psychological consequences of their actions. Its horror imagery may be less vivid, but in the long run this is a darker book than City of Stairs, its moral ambiguities harder to resolve, its tragedies more emotionally punishing. Together, they represent a substantial achievement in contemporary dark fantasy, and I'm eager to see where Bennett takes the series in the next book, City of Miracles. Readers who like their weird fiction to be thoughtful and meaningful without sacrificing entertainment value should not miss these novels.

A twisting plot and a sympathetically understated portrait of teen despair make More Than This both compelling and moving. A boy drowns and then, somehow, wakes up, and at first that's all the reader knows. As he explores his mysterious, seemingly-impossible new environment, flashback chapters begin to reveal who he is and how he ended up in the water. The first third of the novel, in which the mystery is at its strongest, is especially good, with revelations and weird discoveries ideally paced to keep the reader hooked. Once the major questions have been answered, the book becomes in some respects a more conventional teen adventure novel with a familiar premise. But the action remains crisply described, and the boy's emotional struggles capture the very real frustration of teenagers who want more out of life than it feels like they can ever have. More Than This is another sign that Patrick Ness is one of our finest writers of literate, entertaining YA.

This posthumous volume of odds and ends not included in David Rakoff's previous collections may feel a trifle insubstantial, but the quality is high enough that it doesn't really matter. The main stumbling block is that Rakoff didn't leave behind quite enough uncollected work for a full book, so in addition to 200 pages of essays we have two 30-page transcripts of Fresh Air interviews and the full text of Rakoff's short verse novel Love, Dishonor, Marry, Die, Cherish, Perish. I'm going to confess that I didn't read the latter, because it wasn't what interested me about the book and because the second couplet attempted to rhyme "help her" with a description of a midwife as a "whelper." While I'm sure the novel is lovely if you like that sort of thing, I have very little patience for straining after sing-songy rhymes. The interviews, on the other hand, and funny and insightful, and a welcome way to round out the volume. The essays themselves are generally short, and sometimes one feels that they're just getting warmed up when they suddenly end, but Rakoff is a smooth and witty stylist, and the catch-all nature of the collection allows for a range of topics and structures, from op-eds on smoking bans and Laura Bush's view of American literature to travel pieces, memoirs, and reviews. Overall, this is a nice sampler for those who haven't yet experienced Rakoff, and one more chance for his established fans to reflect on what we've lost.

These chocolates are packaged as a luxury experience, and I mean that both figuratively and literally: the packaging is gorgeous, if rather difficult to get into. But I can't say that the flavor and the texture quite live up to the branding (or the pricing). The flavors are subtler and the texture less smooth than in many chocolates, which may be preferable for some; while it did grow on me as I worked my way through the package, I can't say I came to prefer it to less expensive, less pretentious varieties. I did like that many of the flavors had light infusions of various nuts, giving a light flavoring without the gritty texture of larger pieces of nut. Note that these chocolates, while still high in fat, are less so than many brands: you can eat more than one piece a day without going over any recommended daily values. At these prices, though, it might still be better to savor.

I was a little suspicious of this range extender, because the emphasis in the product description on the bells and whistles had a faintly desperate "as seen on TV" vibe. But in my case at least, it delivered on what it promised. Although there's only one normal-sized wall between it and the router, my bedroom has always been an iffy spot for wireless connections. My laptop would lose the network and need to be manually disconnected and reconnected; my PS4 would have periods where it would download at a measly 0.07 MB per second; my Bose SoundTouch 20 would buffer several times in a single song; streaming video on my phone barely worked; and so on. An inexpensive nightlight sized range extender helped somewhat, but it was still a 50/50 shot whether you'd do better connecting to it or to the original network. Now, with the TITAN-EX positioned just on the other side of that wall, about halfway between the router and the PS4, everything runs smoothly. The laptop never loses its connection, the Bose never buffers. The PS4 is at about 5 MB per second, nearly what it gets when wired directly to the router, and Netflix buffers noticeably faster on it. And I can run a livestream from Twitch at source quality on my phone, while Netflix is streaming on the PS4, without any slowdown.Setup of the range extender is very easy if you have a basic understanding of how to connect to Wi-fi networks in the first place; 2.5 GHz and 5 GHz connections can be created simultaneously. You do have to attach the four antennas yourself, but it's a simple process. Once the initial setup is complete, you can unplug and move the range extender without having to redo the settings, allowing easy experimentation to find an optimal position. A signal strength LED helps with this process, though of course in some cases the actual difference between green (good signal) and yellow (adequate signal) may be so small as to make no difference. The antennas do stick up quite a bit, so you may have to get inventive if you're positioning the extender within a desk or an entertainment center or close to a screen. This is obviously a premium-priced product, and in many cases a less expensive extender may meet your needs. But if you're willing to pay more for something with a lot of power, the TITAN-EX is worth serious consideration.

David Mitchell's new novel is divided into several sections with diverse narrators, but where Cloud Atlas and The Bone Clocks told sprawling, interconnected stories whose settings ranged across great swathes of time and space, Slade House is a much more focused and straightforward (and much shorter) affair. Even its prose style shows less variety, though the voices of the characters are confidently differentiated. The problem is that the straightforwardness verges on the formulaic. The first section explains so much about what's going on that all the reader can do is watch the pattern repeat and wait for the inevitable climactic variation. The elaborate, eccentric world-building may make more sense to those better versed in Mitchell's work, but to the uninitiated it comes across as an ungainly hybrid of crackpot mysticism and bad horror movies. And yet there's a ridiculous charm there. The characters, though they're more types than people, are sympathetically drawn, and the prose is lively and involving. Although it technically has the word count of a novel, by Mitchell's standards Slade House is more a piece of long short fiction. But what it lacks in grandeur it makes up for in fast-paced, streamlined entertainment.

Hey, look, it's another King game. But it doesn't have Saga in the title, its not about matching, and it doesn't very quickly become super-difficult if you don't spend money. Instead, it's a crafting-based community-building game with a cutesy tropical/pirate theme and very minimal story elements built around jokey character dialogues. You plant and harvest crops and trees, which are used as the base materials to make nets (for catching fish), backpacks (for digging ore), boards (for making sandals-- don't think too hard about that one), food items, etc. Members of your community will request particular combinations of items at the trading post in exchange for coins (in-game currency), hearts (a relationship metric), and experience points.As your experience level improves, new items and locations will become available for use, increasing the number of things you can do. Improving relationships with characters will yield treasure chests that also give coins, XP, and random items, and will unlock yet more items at one of the game's locations. You can exchange items with passing traders, who make time-limited requests that sometimes have pretty nice rewards, or buy and sell items to other players online. You can even visit other players' islands if you know anyone else who is playing the game on Facebook, which I unfortunately do not. Random treasure chests sometimes appear, as do tappable elements (mussels, crabs, butterflies) that yield small amounts of XP. Overall, there's enough to do that for long stretches of time you can lose sight of the pointlessness of the entire enterprise, which is the best that can be said for a game like this.The premium currency here is gems, which can be used to buy resources you don't have, get exclusive decorations, unlock additional slots at crafting locations so you can queue up more items, or speed up crafting. You can get small amounts of premium currency from treasure chests and from completing achievements, or get a whole bunch via in-app purchases. As I said above, I'm not really feeling like I need more gems than the game gives for free, though that may change at higher levels (I'm currently level 17). The range of items residents can request that use the same base materials means that there's room for mild strategic planning in what to make when, which keeps crafting from feeling like a slog. Limits on stored materials also prevent you from building up large reserves, though gradual storage capacity upgrades do provide some flexibility.I'm playing on an old Kindle Fire HD 8.9 and an LG Ultimate 2 phone and haven't experienced any of the freezing or crashing issues other users report. The game definitely works better on a larger screen: some tappable objects are just too small to hit on a 4.5 inch display, and the planting/reaping mechanic can be tricky even on the Kindle. Overall, I'm not sure how long it'll be before I get sick of the game, but I'm pretty happy with the free diversion it's provided so far.

The gimmick of Patrick Ness's charming new novel is that it focuses on the kids who AREN'T part of the main story in a paranormal romance scenario. The "indie kids" are the ones who have to face down the invasion by demons or zombies or aliens; everyone else just has to live an ordinary life and hope the school doesn't get blown up this time. There's an element of parody here, but it's mostly confined to consciously overwrought chapter titles that summarize the supernatural action, of which the protagonists are largely ignorant. In practice, then, this is a realistic YA novel with a light tinge of genre, and on those terms it works quite well.Schoolwork doesn't matter much as senior year winds down, but Mike has a lot of other stuff on his mind: his crush on his longtime friend Henna, which is threatened by mysterious and handsome new kid Nathan; the possibility that college will separate him from his buddy Jared, who is gay, descended from a god, and the best friend Mike has ever had; and worries about his sister Melinda, who is struggling with an eating disorder exacerbated by their well-meaning but hopelessly alcoholic father and their ruthlessly ambitious politician mother. Navigating these relationships, and his own struggles with obsessive behavior and self-esteem issues, is no easy task even without the indie kids' latest drama getting in the way.For all the heavy thematic material alluded to above, this is a light, extremely readable novel (I sped through it in a few hours) with a sharp sense of humor and a gift for tackling issues in a quietly realistic way. The family dynamic is especially impressive, capturing imperfect but well-intentioned parenting without any corny reconciliations or cheap moments of mutual insight. There's nothing especially surprising in the course of the narrative-- various conflicts rise to confrontation, revelation, and resolution-- but Mike is a likable yet flawed narrator whose issues manifest in believable ways across his various relationships. There's one iffy moment late in the novel, where the fantasy plot mechanics require a decision a character wouldn't make that also undermines a major thematic point, but it's tangential enough to the larger purpose that I can overlook it. This is smart, warm-hearted YA, and leaves me very excited for Ness' forthcoming Doctor Who spin-off, and eager to read his other novels.

Umberto Eco's new novel is slim and, by his standards, slight, but it's still a playful yet thoughtful diversion from the ordinary world. The protagonist is employed creating dummy issues of a newspaper that will never exist, but that doesn't mean it won't have an impact, as he discovers when a colleague begins unfolding a conspiracy theory about Mussolini, the Vatican, and the CIA. There's not much narrative complexity here, but the dizzying charm of fringe notions takes the book a long way, and the sections about the fake newspaper offer a lot of cynical insight into how the press manipulates the public. One might wish that Ecco had taken all these thoughts on the relationship between reality and illusion, between brilliance and obsession, and woven them into a more elaborate and elegantly-structured plot, but the book is what it is, and I'm glad to have read it.

The new kids' tablet from LeapFrog does a fine job of balancing the company's educational goals with the less-than-educational nature of most tablet features. But the first thing caregivers considering a purchase should understand is that this is not just an ordinary tablet with a kid-friendly design. As a LeapFrog device, it's limited to running the company's apps, and while they have a wide range of games, books, videos, and music in their proprietary store, it's not a patch on the variety (or the pricing) of other app stores. The manufacturer recommends the tablet for ages 3-9, and I suspect that even some kids on the higher end of that range will want more from a tablet than this can provide. The LeapPad Platinum is probably best for kids old enough to want a tablet of their own, but not old enough to want specific games or features on that tablet.Which isn't to say that there aren't a fair number of bells and whistles on this Platinum model. A 1024x600 seven-inch screen, 8GB of memory, and front and back cameras with video capability make for decent specs, and the included games have a surprising amount of depth, with achievements and a reward system that mimic, and should prove as compelling, as those found in tablet games for grown-ups. The balance between fun and learning is just right: enough play that kids in the right age range won't become suspicious or bored, but enough teaching that the educational label can be taken seriously. A mini-game in the included virtual pet app, for example, requires the player to solve four simple math problems before a fast-paced touch-based section begins. That mini-game, like others in the app, offers more gameplay time as the player progresses in the main app, allowing increases in high score that will keep kids coming back... and doing math.Pet Pad Party is probably the most substantial of the included apps, but there's also a music player with 10 included songs, a photo app that allows  kids to add lots of wacky effects to the pictures they take, and a range of smaller, more functional apps, including a notepad, a voice recorder, and a calculator. A free download of one app from a list of options is also available. The tablet is compatible with, but does not include, LeapFrog's cartridge-based learning games. Overall there's a decent amount of free content, but if you really want your child to get a lot of use out of this tablet, you'll probably have to buy more, so it's worth keeping in mind that LeapFrog apps are more expensive than those in ordinary app stores; you'll want to choose carefully to make sure kids will keep playing and get your money's worth.Because it has a shatter-safe screen and built-in bumper case, the LeapPad Platinum is slightly bulkier and heavier than ordinary 7-inch tablets, but it should still be easy for most children to carry, and will probably stand up to any damage they could inflict on it. The stylus is attached on a string, so it can't be lost. A parent control system allows limits on playtime. Its password protection is only a four-digit number, which isn't terribly robust, but even a determined child would probably give up before trying all 10,000 variations.The real question for anyone considering a purchase of this product is not whether it's high-quality--- it very much is-- as whether it's right for the child they're buying for. Some kids just won't be interested in an educational tablet that, apart from some Disney-branded content, doesn't offer the recognizable franchises of the adult tablet world. But for the ones who aren't already familiar enough with that kind of thing to be hooked on it, the LeapPad Platinum is a great introduction to the world of mobile devices, with games that are both enjoyable and educational and lots of ways for kids to express their own creativity.

This is a comfortable if snug sleeping bag for someone of average height who doesn't care about having lots of wiggle room inside the bag. The zippered section to allow your feet to stick out is a nice touch. The material is strong and good quality, though not astonishingly so given the premium pricing. If you want a quality sleeping bag, this is definitely worth considering.

A highly readable and atmospheric prose style distinguishes this supernatural romantic thriller in which the under-explained fantasy elements are the main narrative attraction. The romantic thriller plot is standard-issue stuff; it's built around the old "which of the heroine's two love interests is the killer?" approach, which is very difficult to do well. It's A, or it's B, or it's neither, and it takes real skill to make any of those outcomes feel like a surprise. Here the answer is so obvious that I'm honestly surprised the book waits most of its length to directly confirm it. Once confirmation comes, a rapid and anti-climactic resolution makes this first in a trilogy feel like it might have worked better as the first 150 pages of a more focused single novel. And yet the lively style keeps things moving fast enough that the book's flaws are forgivable. Narration alternates between a second-person account of the killer and his target's first person. The latter is engaging, touched with comedy, likable in the crude way of beach reads; the former is  cold, piercing, creepy without being exploitative. The only drawback is occasional lapses into the florid, most notably in impressionistic sensory descriptions of emotion (a la the title, but much more elaborate) that sound nice, but don't mean much of anything. The supernatural elements are barely explained despite some intriguing last-minute hints, and it's not at all clear how the story will progress in future volumes. But I'm eager to find out. Love is Red doesn't break new ground in its increasingly popular niche, but it's compelling enough to be worth a look all the same.

China Mieville's second collection includes 28 stories, exactly twice as many as were in his first. And it's one of those cases where less is more: Looking for Jake was a masterpiece, while Three Moments of an Explosion is less than the sum of its parts. It's not that Mieville has declined as a writer: his distinctive blend of the weird, the political, and the urban is as eerily atmospheric as ever. He has a gift for devising concepts that are unusual, downright peculiar, yet enormously resonant. But in Three Moments of an Explosion the conce[ts aren't consistently matched by the execution. A few of these stories are structured as transcripts of movie trailers, and many of the other short pieces feel similarly like previews of what might be done with the ideas involved. Even the longer ones tend not to develop so much as to proceed, and then simply to stop. This is an occupational hazard in the writing of truly weird fiction, where explanations and a sense of conclusion are not the point, but as his best Mieville arranges the revelation of what little exists to be revealed in a way that maximizes its impact. Here you can see him reaching for similar effect, but instead what one feels is a sense of sameness, Mieville's distinctiveness working against itself. And yet the best stories are reminders of his genius. "The Dowager of Bees," about unexpected-- and impossible-- high stakes card-playing, with a thoroughly satisfying ending; "The Buzzard's Egg," a melancholy monologue about the implications of henotheism; "The Rabbet," a horror story that is perhaps the strangest homage yet to M. R. James'  "The Mezzotint." Even the lesser stories linger in the mind, more satisfying in retrospect than they were in the reading. Three Moments of an Explosion is not China Mieville at his best, but it's still a rare treat.

I own three Bluetooth-enabled devices: a last-gen Kindle Fire HD 8.9, an HP Stream 7 32GB Windows 8.1 tablet, and an Acer chromebook. Perhaps unsurprisingly, this Microsoft keyboard and mouse works best with the Windows tablet. It's not compatible with the Kindle at all, and while the mouse works with the Chromebook, the keyboard tries to pair, responds to the passcode prompt, and then doesn't actually work. If you're curious about compatibility with other devices, there's a partial compatibility chart by operating system on the Microsoft website, though it may not be much help.If they can connect to the device you want to use them with, these are a decent keyboard and mouse that do a good job of striking the balance between size and functionality. The keyboard is bigger than a lot of Bluetooth keyboards (and, for that matter, bigger than the keyboard on my Chromebook), and feels slim and lightweight but not flimsy. The battery compartment is under the top of the keyboard, adding a nice sense of weight and balance. The mouse is basic, thin and squarish, but it responds nicely even when run along a surface as uncongenial as the arm of a recliner.Overall this keyboard and mouse works perfectly well, but there's nothing to make it stand out in comparison to other, cheaper models, especially given the variable compatibility. If you're attached for whatever reason to the Microsoft name, this is a solid choice, but otherwise, use caution unless you can get it for well below the current MSRP.

This is an odd hybrid: half a conventional true crime account of the Aurora theater shooting, half a reflection on the causes of mass shootings more generally. The former is solid, unexceptionable work of its type, hampered only by the facts that the trial is ongoing and that the title document, written by James Holmes and possibly revealing his psychological state, remains unavailable to the general public. There's a tetchy quality to the authors' discussion of the delays and secrecy surrounding the trial. A cynic might attribute this to frustration that they've been following the case for years and have only gotten half a book out of it, but that would be unfair. The Singulars want a speedy resolution, I think, because they imagine that the completion of the trial and the revelation of the notebook's contents will explain the Aurora shooting, and provide answers to the larger question of why such things happen. But I'm not sure that's true, and that disagreement cuts to the heart of my issues with this well-intentioned, thoughtful book.Two members of the Singular family are credited as authors of The Spiral Notebook, but the writers' son Eric is also a major influence. In the aftermath of the Aurora shooting, the family engaged in a conversation about how contemporary society has shaped and warped people of Eric's generation. Let's be clear: it's great that they had this dialogue, and it's great that it gave the family a greater sense that they understood and appreciated each other. But the degree to which Eric's personal influences and opinions have shaped this book's treatment of an entire generation is a problem. The meaning of alternative media to "millenials" is a valuable subject, but why talk about Vice in particular, except that it's what Eric happens to know? I'm aware that a lot of guys think, like Eric, that Fight Club is a big deal, but then a lot of us don't. A breathless and initially baffling late chapter on the intriguing but tentative possible benefits of yoga and mindfulness because clearer when we learn that Eric Singular has taken up the practice. Scattered quotes from interviews with others in his age group give an impression of a wider focus, but one suspects they've been carefully chosen to reflect the things the authors have already decided are important.One of the many commendable aspects of The Spiral Notebook is that its social critique is wide-ranging. Gun control, mental health, bullying, foreign policy, economic stability: there's barely an aspect of modern American life that the Singulars don't take issue with. But trying to tackle all of that in half of a 318-page book means that there isn't much room for argumentation or nuance. Apart from scattered citation of statistics about the rise of mass violence and the increase in heavy use of psychoactive drugs, the authors tend to assert rather than argue, which will have many readers nodding at certain points, shaking their head at others, and rarely being persuaded to look at the subject in a new way. Personally, I found myself most frustrated by the authors' perception of my own generation as uniquely disillusioned and out of touch with the beliefs of the wider society. Young people must always confront and cope with the ways in which the values on which they were reared conflict with and complicate adult life, and I really don't think, despite a brief, hand-waving effort to explain how today's counter-culture kids are different from those of the 60s and the 70s, that the frustrations and protest movements of today are much distinct from those of the past.The real question, though, is to what extent a wide-ranging discontent can explain a disproportionately visible but small-scale phenomenon like mass violence. There may be a current "epidemic" by comparison to previous decades, but the absolute number of people committing acts of mass violence is still miniscule. To what extent can we assume that these deeply troubled individuals are different in degree rather than kind from their conflicted but not violent contemporaries, that they are products of a sort of perfect storm of common social failings rather than of distinctive biological or environmental circumstance? The issues under discussion in this book are important, but their importance doesn't stand or fall on their possible contribution to mass violence. Bullying is a social problem even if the idea (echoed here) that it was a significant factor in the Columbine shooting has been convincingly debunked. Part of the reason our society can't make any progress on major questions of our time is that we only talk about them after extreme, headline-generating cases. We talk about guns and mental health after mass shootings, about bullying after tragic suicides, about bigotry after a celebrity says something stupid or careless. But gun violence hurts many more people than mass shooting victims, and bullying scars even the vast majorities who don't commit suicide. In some ways the social commentary of this book might be more powerful if it were entirely divorced from the question of mass violence.To return, then, to the spiral notebook. The Singulars seem to believe, or to hope, that because Holmes was smarter than some mass shooters, and because he was studying the workings of the mind, his notebook will lay bare not only his only motivations but the logic (as it were) of mass shootings more generally. But every mass shooter is different. There can be no Rosetta Stone for their minds, any more than Eric Singular can speak for his generation. The best thing about The Spiral Notebook is its warm-hearted optimism, its emphasis on the importance of community, acknowledgement, and understanding for the general welfare. But part of understanding is acceptance of complexity, recognition that some dilemmas remain inexplicable or insoluble and that a hunger for simple and satisfying answers can exacerbate the problems it's meant to solve. This is a valuable book for those looking for an introduction to the social and political topics that surround mass violence, but its limitations make it a place to begin rather than a one-stop guide.

This collection, reissued with a new preface in the wake of Fowler's award-winning novel We Are All Completely Beside Ourselves, was originally published in 1998, but its stories feel as fresh and startling as if they were brand-new. Fowler is both a co-founder of and a multiple nominee for the Tiptree Award for science fiction and fantasy that explores gender, and some of the collection's most memorable stories work in that territory, including its first and last. The opening and title novella has a premise that would sound silly if stated flat-out, but it makes for a sharp exploration of the dearth of historical heroines, the fault lines that society builds into even those marriages committed to equality and fairness, and the appeal of uncompromising, audacious action in support of one's beliefs. It's also a marvelously entertaining story, with delightfully surreal overlapping plotlines and flashes of the humor that makes some readers underestimate the serious of Fowler's literary purpose. At the other end of the collection is "Game Night at the Fox and Goose," a bleaker look at similar themes, in which Fowler's eye for revealing historical moments leads to a very literal take on the battle of the sexes.I mention historical moments. Some of the stories here are so thoroughly derived from fact that they could almost be speculative essays. These include "Shimabara," an exploration of motherhood and religious zealotry based on a seventeenth-century Japanese rebellion; "Lieserl," an eerie imagining of the long-unknown, still-mysterious first child of Albert Einstein; and "The Elizabeth Complex," a dizzying look at the parallel lives of several famous and unconventional women of that name. Pop culture, literature and myth are also inspirations, whether fairy tales ("Lily Red" and "The Black Fairy's Curse"), Gulliver's Travels ("The Travails"), or the Lone Ranger ("The Faithful Companion at Forty"). Whatever her source, Fowler is both playful and thoughtful, pointing out the implications of tropes we often take for granted.Several stories draw on Fowler's childhood in Indiana and her time as a college student in 1970s California. "Go Back" meditates on memory, shifting from a kaleidoscope of pleasant recollections to something darker, while "The Brew" gives a supernatural twist to that familiar childhood figure, the mysterious and crotchety neighbor. It's one of the collection's less successful stories, only because its theme is the sort of tried-and-yet-possibly-not-true thing Fowler usually takes apart. "Letters from Home" seems to be a memoir of what the Vietnam War meant to a young man who fought in it and a young woman who protested it, but as with much of Fowler's work, a final turn reveals the emotional desperation at the heart of the recollection.
