This 1968 western is a good, solid, honest thing about a particularly difficult and controversial topic - white women captured and kept as slaves by American Indians. I watched it three times at different moments of life and I always liked it a lot. Below, more of my impressions, with some limited SPOILERS.PRECISION: this is the review of Region 1 NTSC version â€“ it will not play on standard Region 2 PAL equipment. For the Region 2 version, you will have to buy the Spanish released "La nocha de los gigantes", which contains an English version.Somewhere around 1880 in Arizona, during the last stage of Apache Wars, U.S. Army soldiers surprise and round up a group of Indians. They find among them a white woman, Sarah Carver (Eva Marie Saint) and her half-Indian child. Abducted as young teenager Sarah was taken as slave by a particularly fierce warrior known as Salvaje ("Ghost") - a man so dangerous that even his own tribe is scared of him.As most white slaves in such cases Sarah was treated harshly, even when she gave birth to Salvaje's son. She is in poor shape and after so many years of captivity finds it difficult to even speak English - and she has no family, as all her folks were murdered in the same raid in which she was taken. Army scout Sam Varner (Gregory Peck), who just finished his service, ends by proposing her to live for a time at his ranch in New Mexico, the time for her to recover and make some plans for the future. They leave for Sam's ranch - but somebody will follow their trail... And then the film really begins.This is a really good, solid film, mixing drama, action and tension and even a little bit of thriller/horror by moments, as Salvaje seems to be really more a supernatural creature than a man... However, the action scenes and other adventures are not the most important thing here. Much more intense, sometimes even heart-breaking, are the drama elements about Sarah and her son.Sarah is a victim who tries to recover after a long, long ordeal of being forced to have sex for years with a man who murdered her family, enslaved her and stole her childhood and young years. Eva Marie Saint was 44 when she played in this film and it actually helped to make this film look more realistic â€“ because slavery and abuse definitely make people age quickerâ€¦ Her son, whom we know only as Boy (he is about eight years old), is even more traumatised, as he was abruptly taken from the world he knew into an alien place he doesn't care for. Also, even if Salvaje treated his mother badly, he is still his father and Boy misses him â€“ in fact wants to escape to go to himâ€¦ Those elements make this film into something much deeper and sombre than most of westerns.This film also quite usefully deals with the politically correct bull**** about white captives living with Indian tribes, like the one served in "Dancing with wolves". All slavery is a horrible violation of human rights, but the one practiced by American Indians as late as 1880s and was a particularly cruel kind, as slaves mostly had no place in the society and no chance of recovering freedom, but to the contrary, were just exploited in the most extreme way until they died, before being replaced. With time Indian captives from other tribes could occasionally (not often) be accepted into the tribe as free people, but it was almost never the case of whites â€“ they were put to hard work, fed the least possible and were ultimately killed once useless. Indian men treated all women harshly, but the enslaved ones faired the worse â€“ even if they bore children the their owners.If you would like to read more about this topic, I recommend "A fate worse than death" by Gregory Michno. For years this author patiently collected as much TRUE memories of white captives freed from Indian captivity in the period between 1830 and 1885 as he could find and then published them in one volume. I must warn you that this is a nightmarish read but also a very useful one, as it immediately puts to grave most of politically correct nonsense about American Indians, by showing that those Palaeolithic hunters-gatherers were definitely not peace loving hippies, but as warlike and predatory as it is humanly possibleâ€¦I like this film, I am glad that I bought it and I will definitely keep my DVD. A recommended viewing. ENJOY!

Long time ago I watched and liked this 1968 western mixed with a whodunnit mystery and recently I was glad to see it didn't age much. It is still a very entertaining viewing. Below, more of my impressions, with some limited SPOILERS.In 1880, a gambler in the small town of Rincon, just outside of Denver, Colorado, is caught cheating at a five-card stud poker game. Usually this kind of incident would end with the cheater being disarmed, beaten senseless by every person in attendance and then chased out of town with a strong warning to never return again. But this time one of the players, a sadistic vicious little thug named Nick Evers (Roddy MacDowall), leads his drunken companions into lynching the cheater - of whom they don't even know the name. Only one player, Van Morgan (Dean Martin) and Little George, black barman who watched the game, realising that things are going too far, try to stop the murder - but in vain... Soon after that, one after another, two of the men who played that fateful night and participated in the lynching are found dead and the city of Ricon is grasped by fear... Local preacher, Reverend Rudd (Robert Mitchum), a very tough man who - according to the rumors - is himself a reformed gunfighter, tries to comfort local people and assist to the best of his abilities in finding the culprit (or culprits)... And then the film really begins.This is a very honest, very entertaining film, with a strong performance by all the main four actors. The solution of the mystery appears quickly evident - there are however some details which are revealed only late and they come as a surprise. Characters are very much alive, each of them with its own story to tell - formidable preacher, borderline insane Nick, surprisingly tough Little George and of course Van Morgan, played by Dean Martin in the "scoundrel, ma non troppo" register...))) Ladies are less important, but they add some charm and wit to the film, especially Inger Stevens who plays here Lily Langford, a surprisingly sophisticated owner and manager of a particularly charming house of perdition...)))Ultimately it is however Robert Mitchum who is the greatest treasure of this film, with his Colt, black religious garb and his Bible - which, as fits the Holy Book, contains many a treasure...))) I will say no more here.Made in 1968, this film was part of the 'last hurrah" of westerns, which were being pushed towards the exit this time - but still managed to make a splash on their way out... I like this film a lot and I will definitely keep the DVD for another viewing. ENJOY!

Even though it is only an action B movie, I always liked it and I was glad to see it one more time. Rating it four stars may be a little bit generous, but still, I had such a good time watching it, that I simply had no choice. Below, more of my impressions, with some limited SPOILERS.A precision here - I know absolutely NOTHING about climbing and the highest place where I ever have been is Klein Matterhorn (3883 metres), followed by Teide (3718 metres), both valiantly ascended by cable-car... This might explain why I liked this film so much...Peter Garrett (Chris O'Donnell) and his sister Annie (Robin Tunney) were climbing mountains since they were very young, but now have a difficult relationship, following a very bad accident three years earlier. Peter is now a photographer but Annie continues a very succesful climbing career - she was in fact selected to be part of an expedition ascending K2, together with an exuberant billionnaire Elliot Vaughn (Bill Paxton) and a renowned climber Tom McLaren (Nicholas Lea, of X-Files fame).The expedition meets with problems and a rescue party, encouraged by a financial reward, is formed to attempt a rescue. This group will be led by an eccentric but extremely competent hermit/climber Montgomery Wick (Scott Glenn, amazing!) - other members will be Peter Garrett, two somehow psychedelic Australians, a Pakistani soldier and last but not least Monique Aubertine (Isabella Scorupco), a woman climber so deep in debt, that she doesn't even dare to descend into the valleys...This is a surprisingly well done little film, mixing the climber/mountain drama with some additional elements. There is an old and terrible score to settle between two of the characters (I will say no more here). There is a dangerous cargo some people have to carry. There is war raging nearby - the merciless high-altitude confrontation between India and Pakistan, mostly in form of artillery duels, called the Siachen War, still not finished albeit a cease-fire is in effect since 2003. And then of course there is the mountain itself...Even if Mount Everest killed much more people, K2 is considered an even more difficult and dangerous mountain - and the only reason why it killed less climbers is that much, much less people try to ascend it, because of all the perils. The horrible weather, extremely deadly avalanches and even the name itself, all created a threatening aura around this mountain - and it adds to the climate of tension in this film.Even if the scenario may seem by moments a little bit extravagant and the main villain slightly too one-dimensional, this is still a darn good action/adventure movie. Lots of imagination and creativity went into creating some of the scenes - I almost would like to say more here, but I will not, to preserve the surprises. High mountain scenes are very good, characters are rather well done, the scenario is honest and the ending is quite strong, at least for my personal taste.I liked this film in 2000 when it was in the cinemas and I liked it again 15 years later, therefore I simply have no choice than rating it four stars. I will definitely keep the DVD for another viewing in the future. ENJOY!

I spend a nice moment watching this 1966 romantic comedy set in the Wild West. It is a light-hearted and mostly not serious thing, which can be watched in family, with some good humour, very limited violence and just one really sad (but very carefully showed) moment. Below, more of my impressions, with some LIMITED SPOILERS.Martha Price (Maureen O'Hara), an English lady, middle aged but still hot like hell and her daughter Hilary (Juliet Mills), a bright young damsel very easy on eyes, find themselves stranded in Saint Louis, with for all possessions the clothes on their back and a Hereford bull, a very precious reproductor. Selling the bull on auction they recolt enough money to be able to return to England, but first they want to be certain that the animal, which they both raised from calf, arrives safe to the Texan ranch of his new owner, Alexander Bowen (Brain Keith). A local wrangler, Sam Burnett (James Stewart), is hired to accompany them and then the whole company of two women, one man, four horses and one bull leaves for Texas... It will be one helluva journey and once in Texas, things will get even more interesting, but I will say no more here...This is not your typical western - in fact it is mostly a romantic comedy set in the Wild West. Violence and action are very limited and anyway toned down, even if there is one vile murder, one fight to death, one pretty realistic stampede scene, some (non letal) fistfights and one terrific face slap (delivered by Maureen O'Hara character)... On another hand there is a lot dialogs, romance, surprises, twists, emotions, gentlemen courting bonnie lassies - and one really sad scene. All of this makes for a very pleasant, relaxing, amusing and cheerful viewing.It is true that the low content of scum and villainy may be an issue as there is only one desperado in the film - but after adding three bottles of my own I stopped noticing...))) A somehow bigger problem was for me one rather assinine decision concerning practical details of cattle reproduction, - but on another hand without this decision there would be no second half of the film...Actors did very well in "The rare breed". James Stewart and Maureen O'hara are of course perfect as always, but in fact a large part of charm of this film resides in Juliet Mills and Brian Keith characters, of which I will say nothing more, to not spoil the surprise. Jack Elam also appears in this film and as you probably immediately guessed, yes, he plays the main villain.However the GREATEST star in this film is the bull reproductor. Unlike most of specimens of taurine tribe, this is a tame, gentle creature, astonishingly zen and greatly charismatic. Now, you take such an animal, with all the formidable appearance and fierce temper of a caramel coated marshmallow, you make it obey to the whistling of "God save the Queen" and you name it Vindicator and you have immediately material for a lot of comedy and cheerful laughter - and this film definitely used all this potential... This adorable creature presents an especially great challenge for the hard as rock wrangler, always ready to take the bull by the horns but somehow defenceless when facing a creature which don't have any of them...)))This is not any kind of masterpiece, but I liked this vaguely westernish feel-good romantic comedy and it cheered me no end (that and the three bottles of "Desperados"). I will absolutely keep the DVD for another viewing. ENJOY!

This is one of the greatest novels ever written, a book which you read a hundred times without ever tiring. Ever since I read it in my early teen years I was deeply in love with it - and I still am. There is not one page, not even one line, which would not be a pure perfection. Below, more of my impressions, with some very limited SPOILERS.This book describes a visit by Satan to Moscow in late 1920s. Satan was quite busy in previous years and he neglected a little bit his Russian domains, but now he comes for an inspection (in fact an audit) - he is especially curious about this whole communism thing, which is a kind of novelty for him. For the purpose of this visit he takes form of a distinguished albeit slightly eccentric gentleman named Woland. He also brings with him an entourage of four lesser devils: Azazello, a strangely likeable demon murderer, who serves as messenger and enforcer, Hella, a somehow vampiric succubus, who is a maid, Koroviev, a fallen choir angel with a particularly nasty sense of humour, who is a page and last but definitely not least, Behemoth, a huge demonic cat-from-hell, who is Woland's jester (and also a world class @hole! - but that is only to be expected from a cat...). Together they will wreck absolute havoc in Moscow in a thunderstorm of irresistibly hilarious but also sometimes pretty nasty episodes, which will culminate during the Satan's Midnight Ball - for which the Devil, an eternal bachelor, needs to find a suitable Lady to assist him in welcoming the guests...I will not go here in more details to not provide spoilers, but it must be said that this is one of those books which simply reached PERFECTION. There is nothing here that could be criticized. Every single page, every single line is simply PERFECT. This is an incredibly entertaining book - but which is also very touching, very profound and also contains lots of sadness. Which is understandable, considering that it was written in horrible times and in a horrible place - USSR in Stalin times...Extremely subversive, "The Master and Margarita" was never published during Bulgakov's life and in fact, in desperation of ever seeing it published, he even burned the first version of the book - but as Satan said: "Manuscripts don't burn". After his death in 1940 copies of final version of the book survived and it was finally published in a censored edition in the 60s, before being finally released in its integrality in 1989. Being openly sceptical towards communism and having relatives who emigrated in 1919, Bulgakov was considered a "hostile element" and was closely watched and also frequently fired from various jobs - but unlike so many others he was never send to Gulag concentration camps. He had indeed one great admirer and protector - Stalin himself, who actually kept from 1940 to his death in his personal safe a copy of full text of "The Master and Margarita" and read it many times (although he never allowed it to be published). Stalin's protection assured also that when Bulgakov gave the final text to the publisher in 1939, against the expectations of his friends and family he wasn't arrested or killed - the manuscript was only rejected (after one copy was delivered to Stalin in person), but the political police didn't show. That still probably hastened Bulgakov's death - he was already very ill at that time and heart-broken he stopped fighting...For me, "The Master and Margarita" is amongst the greatest, the most important, most profound and most touching things that were ever written. On my personal list of seven books which I would save from the destruction in case of the end of the world, it figures on fourth position - after the Bible, Sienkiewicz's "Trilogy" and "Lord of the Rings" and before "Pride and Prejudice, "Gone with the wind" and "From here to eternity".I don't have words strong enough to praise this book and to encourage you to discover this incredible, immortal masterpiece. Reading it is a unique experience - don't miss it!

In this book Gardner Dozois gathered what he considered as best SF works published in 2014. It was roughly on the same level as the one from 2013 â€“ with some more very good stories, but also much more stinkers.Having read all the thirty two Gardner Dozois yearly collections I couldn't help but notice a steady but regular decline in quality of SF writing, from the 80s to the modern times. OK, granted, this is just one of yearly anthologies amongst many, and yes, it reflects the very personal, subjective taste of the editor, but still, there is a clear trend towards a lesser quality. The main reasons of that, at least in my personal opinion and for my subjective taste, are the following:- a tendency to run after the developments in the world, rather than trying to anticipate them. Global warming hysteria, fear of nanotechnologies and GMOs and consequences of recent progress in informatics are the best examples of it. Few writers even try to think about something really new - and it seems that even fewer have intellectual capacity of doing it...- nihilism, pessimism and fear-mongering seem to be the leading motive in recent SF, as there is hardly any joy and exaltation linked usually with new discoveries and opening of new horizons. To the contrary, everything and anything seems to be a threat.- lack of humour. In this anthology there is at best one story which contains at least some humour and wit. Everything is mostly gloom and doom taken DEADLY seriously...- left winged politics. That is probably due to Gardner Dozois personal choice, but at least in his anthologies anything conservative, religious and especially military is mostly the source of all evil in the world. Christianity seems to be particularly hated.- poorly developed characters, with whom we cannot really connect.- poor endings - or no endings at all. It seems that nowadays there are few writers able to find a good closure or a punch line.For all that reasons, reading those huge collections was frequently much less fun than expected - and I distinctly remember that when I discovered SF with classic short stories from the 50s and 60s, well, this was a much more enjoyable experience...This collection includes also two very precious things. In the introduction we have an overview of what happened in SF (largely understood) in 2014 - in all Gardner Dozois yearly collections that thing is invariably always very precious. At the end there is also the very useful section of "honourable mentions" - stories which couldn't be selected for this collection because of lack of space (and this is already a HUGE book!), but which were also of good quality.There were six very good stories: "The rider", "The burial of Sir John Mawe at Cassini", "The regular", "Passage of Earth", "Thing and sick" (THE BEST IN THIS COLLECTION) and "Yesterday"s kin". There were also four good stories: "Amicae eternum", "In Babelsberg", "Grand jetÃ© (the great leap)", "Jubilee". All those definitely deserve to be discovered.The category readable (sometimes barely) includes fourteen stories â€“ if you skip them, you will not miss much.For my personal taste there were eleven stinkers: "The fifth dragon", "The days of the war, as red as blood, as dark as bile", "Shooting the Apocalypse", "The colonel", "Entanglement", "Slipping", "Covenant", "Los piratas del mar de plastic (Pirates of the plastic ocean)", "God decay", "Communion", "Someday". Those ones I advise to simply avoid.One story, "The man who sold the moon", I am unable to rate because it bore me so badly that I stopped reading it after 15 pages. You will have to make your own mind about it.Below, more of my impressions about the stories, with some limited SPOILERS.--------------------------------------------------------------------------------"The fifth dragon" by Ian McDonald â€“ near future, colonized Moon; a bisexual woman remembers how she emigrated from Earth, joined a kind of swinger sex-cluster and met the love of her life; under the pretence of SF it's mostly LGBT soft porn story. I didn't like it much."The rider" by Jerome Cigut â€“ in the near future rogue AI's wage a mysterious war, via human allies/carriers called "riders". In this story we follow a "rider" and his artificial master/partner/friend David. Cyberpunk is not my usual poison, but stories like that, I am always ready for more. A VERY GOOD, solid, honest thing."The days of the war, as red as blood, as dark as bile" by Aliette de Bodard â€“ and like every year, another story about a future dominated by rival Chinese and Aztec empires in which intelligent ships travel through stars. There is a war, some people wonder if they should run away from their homes or not, then blah blah blah all the way until a very stupid ending. AVOID!"The burial of Sir John Mawe at Cassini" by Chaz Brenchley â€“ now that is SF! In a parallel world Mars was colonized by British Empire - which still remains very Victorian. This is the tale of the funeral of a colonial dignitary, a burial like no one saw since ages, with almost all human Mars population attending â€“ and you will fully understand why only at the end. A BRILLIANT, VERY GOOD STORY! TO READ ABSOLUTELY!"The regular" by Ken Liu â€“ IMPRESSIVE! This story, occurring in near future, about an Eurasian woman who after a career in police works as a private eye and one day is asked to investigate the murder of a call girl, rather than her usual cases of insurance frauds, is one of the best written and most interesting things I read recently. A BRILLIANT, VERY GOOD STORY. TO READ ABSOLUTELY!"The woman from the ocean" by Karl Bunker â€“ a woman, sole survivor of an ill-fated expedition to another star system, comes back to Earth after many, many years of absence â€“ and finds that humanity was changed, in fact terribly mutilatedâ€¦ A READABLE story, with a rather clever conclusion (war can be totally eradicated only if humans stop being humans), but also horribly depressing and with an ending which is wrong - simply wrong."Shooting the Apocalypse" by Paolo Bacigalupi â€“ in United States devastated by â€“ what else? (sigh) â€“ global warming and Republicans, two paparazzi in need of money are chasing a scoop on the border between struggling Arizona and devastated Texasâ€¦ Story without a real conclusion and ultimately without much of plot, lazily mining once again global warming hysteria. I didn't like it."Weather" by Susan Palwick â€“ a man tries desperately to get to the hospital where his daughter is dying â€“ before she is "translated" (downloaded) â€“ all of this with global warming in the background. A very banal story â€“ READABLE, but barely."The hand is quicker" by Elizabeth Bear â€“ a lesbian woman is downgraded from first to second class citizen in a rather nightmarish future society. The story begins with a shock and seemed promising, but very quickly author got scared by her own courage and followed with one banality after another, until a supremely lame ending. READABLE â€“ but also disappointing."The man who sold the moon" by Cory Doctorow â€“ this 59 pages long novella I cannot rate, as I couldn't finish it; it seems to be about a group of highly educated people living in a kind of counter-culture in California who make an invention â€“ but as I found the characters unlikeable this story wore me down and I gave up. You will have to read it and make up your own mind."Vladimir Chong chooses to die" by Lavie Tidhar â€“ another story in the Central Station series, happening in a very, very weird future Israel; as the title indicates, it is about Vladimir Chong who just decided to die; I don't like the freakishly weird, even creepy world described in those stories, but the story is READABLE."Beside the damned river" by D.J. Cockburn â€“ in a near future northern Thailand, devastated by drought, an old man helps repair a broken truck, which carries a mysterious cargo; a quite READABLE, if banal story"The colonel" by Peter Watts â€“ in a near future there is a war between humans and a sort of enemies, but who are those enemies, I don't know, because this story is so confusing, so poorly written and so drowned in informatics lingo, that I couldn't understand one simple thing. I HATED IT!"Entanglement" by Vandana Singh â€“ scientists fight global warming; one of them is an Inuit â€“ and there are also so beluga whales in it and some kind of monks; this is more or less everything I could understand from this boring mess. I couldn't even finish it after going through two-thirds of the story. AVOID!"White Curtain" by Pavel Amnuel â€“ a guy who can affect reality finds that he cannot affect the reality when it really matters â€“ but is it really true? A quite banal story reminding a little bit of Russian fantastic tales of late XIX century (author is actually Russian), but still READABLE."Slipping" by Lauren Beukes â€“ a girl who was mutilated in a weird accident struggles to adapt to life again after some kind of weird therapy. Poorly written and boring â€“ I HATED IT!"Passage of Earth" by Michael Swanwick â€“ a man with a past is asked to perform an autopsy of an alien creature â€“ and I will say nothing more about the plot. It is a surprising, shocking, original, VERY GOOD STORY, very much unlike anything else I ever read â€“ and nowadays it is a hard thing to invent something new in SF. Kudos for the wicked title tooâ€¦))) Bravo Michael Swanwick!"Amicae aeternum" by Ellen Klages â€“ a short, but very powerful story about two eleven year old girls, BFFs, who spend a last moment together, before a separation which is as definite as humanly possible, as one of them is leaving on a generation starship which will travel to another solar system â€“ for two hundred yearsâ€¦ A GOOD, solid thing. Darn sad thoughâ€¦"In Babelsberg" by Alastair Reynolds â€“ a self-aware AI robot came back from an exploration travel through Solar System and appears on various talk shows to share his experiences â€“ but is he telling all the truth? An intelligent, solid, GOOD story, which reminded me a little of an even better old archi-classic, "The Inquest" by Stanislaw Lem (part of "Tales of Pirx the Pilot" collection). If you liked this story, try to find and read "The inquest" â€“ you will not regret it."Sadness" by Timons Esaias â€“ Earth was invaded and humans live in the most abject slavery â€“ and somehow they are now so sheepish, that don't even try to resist, no matter what indignity is inflicted to them! It is not half bad written, I admit, therefore I rate it as READABLE but I could only feel total contempt for the main character â€“ and all other humans who appearâ€¦"West to East" by Jay Lake â€“ two people crash-landed on a terminally hostile planet and it seems that they cannot be rescued. They accepted the idea that they will die â€“ and awaiting the seemingly unavoidable death, they try to find a way to do anything meaningful. The story is READABLE, but I found the whole idea morbidly depressing - and the whole thing about two highly trained space pilots giving up, rather than fighting for their lives to the last breath, simply WRONG."Grand jetÃ© (the great leap)" by Rachel Swirsky â€“ a young girl is dying from a horrible cancer â€“ her grandfather tries to build a cyborg into which he could download her conscience; all this mixed with Old Testament lore (the heroes are Jewish); objectively speaking this is a GOOD, solid, very poignant story â€“ but the description of a long agony of a child dying of cancer was really too much for me, so I "fast forwarded" most of it."Covenant" by Elizabeth Bear â€“ a serial killer who murdered thirteen little girls was sentenced to "right-minding" (in this future world it replaces imprisonment) and now tries to adjust to his new life. Reading the memories of a serial killer who preyed on children and who basically got away with it (nothing short of death penalty is adapted to such crimes in my perception of reality) was too much for me. I HATED THAT ONE!"Jubilee" by Karl Schroeder â€“ a Romeo and Juliette story; a boy and a girl fall in love â€“ trouble is, they belong to two mutually hostile communities of people who, albeit not different of the rest of mankind, live their lives in a cycle of one day of activity/years of suspended animation â€“ and as their cycles are different, both groups wake up on the same day only once in a thousand years or soâ€¦ It has interesting consequences, to say the least. I liked this story â€“ this is a GOOD, solid, honest thing."Los piratas del mar de plastic (Pirates of the plastic ocean)" by Paul Graham Raven â€“ in near future Spain an economist/journalist is hired to make some kind of market situation analysis; at least that is what is said at the beginning because immediately after this whole thing dissolves into completely incomprehensible mess. I have no idea what this story was about â€“ AVOID!"Red lights and rain" by Gareth L. Powell â€“ two former soldiers, veterans of a war which will be fought in a distant future, fight one last time â€“ in our times. One of them is a woman, the other a kind of cybernetic vampire. Interesting idea but the plot is very banal, flat and ultimately disappointing â€“ a READABLE thing at best."Coma kings" by Jessica Barber â€“ in a near future two girls are addicted to high tech video games â€“ one of them terminally soâ€¦ A READABLE thing."The prodigal son" by Allen M. Steele â€“ a private foundation tries to send the first starship to another solar system â€“ some Christian fundamentalists try to stop them; this story seemed very promising in the beginning, but for me it became clear very quickly that, for reasons which I will not reveal to avoid spoilers, this mission is really an abomination and the protesters are actually darn right! From that moment I really couldn't sympathize with the main protagonists. Also, in a world where Islamic terrorists kill people every day, when needing a suicide bomber author had to make him, of course, a Christianâ€¦ Because of hateful Christian bashing and abject character of the whole endeavour described here I hated this story â€“ but to be absolutely objective I must admit it is READABLE."God decay" by Rich Larson â€“ in a near future, an augmented athlete, a Polish guy named Ostap Kerensky (which is by the way as much a Polish name as Isoroku Yamamoto), worried by his health, comes to check with his doctor, an older woman who also used to be his squeezeâ€¦ I found this story banal, quite boring and didn't like it much."Blood wedding" by Robert Reed â€“ in the future the perfect woman (and also heiress to a financial empire) marries a rich, handsome suitor â€“ then somebody with access to ultra-high technology attacks the ceremony, all hell breaks loose and it is up to unexpected heroes to save the dayâ€¦ It could have been a good story, but it became more and more weird and finally crashed and burned at the last pages. This story had potential but because of the poor ending I rate it only as READABLE"The long haul, from the annals of transportation, the Pacfic Monthly, may 2009" by Ken Liu â€“ in a near future exists a society based on low-carbon emissions principle, where giant airships carry most of goods; this is the story of an airship captain and his Chinese mail-bride wife. Nothing special, but a READABLE story."Shadow flock" by Greg Egan â€“ a woman recognised as a top-level drone programmer is contacted for a very, very special job - which she cannot possibly likeâ€¦ It is actually a quite honest high-tech "film noir" scenario â€“ just with a very disappointing ending. A READABLE thing."Thing and sick" by Adam Roberts â€“ on an isolated SETI outpost in Antarctica an unpleasant and unstable nerd solves Fermi's Paradox â€“ the story is told much later by his less extravagant and more likeable companion. I will say nothing more, because this thing deserves to be discovered and appreciated on your own. For my personal taste this is THE BEST STORY IN THE COLLECTION and one of the most intelligent and especially original SF works I read in years. TO READ ABSOLUTELY!"Communion" by Mary Anne Mohanraj â€“ two lesbian women have a dispute about the future of their relationship â€“ an alien somehow unwillingly mediatesâ€¦ Contains some gross elements. Only for LGBT fans â€“ I didn't like it."Someday" by James Patrick Kelly â€“ a soft porn about a lesbian woman who wants to conceive and looks for ideal father(s) for the child. Mostly for LGBT fans â€“ I didn't like it."Yesterday's kin" by Nancy Kress â€“ Marianne, a geneticist who just published her first really outstanding discovery (and also mother of three fully grown up children â€“ who barely can stand one another), is summoned by alien ambassador on Earth â€“ together with the Secretary General of UN and couple of other people. They will not like what they will hearâ€¦ I will say nothing more about the plot, because this 70+ pages long novella contains many twists and surprises. After some hesitation I rate this story as VERY GOOD, even if I didn't like some elements in it, mostly the religion bashing, the hatred Nancy Kress seems to feel for her country, really old clichÃ©s and some really stupid ideas (like the possibility of extremely high tech civilization having underdeveloped biological science). Still, this was a good read, which kept me interested until the end. A RECOMMENDED READING.-------------------------------------------------------------------------CONCLUSION: an OK, more or less honest anthology, but only the top ten stories out of thirty six are really worth reading (and eleven are pure waste of time). Still, this collection indeed offers a nice overview of latest trends in SF â€“ it's not really Gardner Dozois fault that SF writers nowadays seem frequently to struggle with inspiration.

In this book Gardner Dozois gathered what he considered as best SF works published in 2014. It was roughly on the same level as the one from 2013 â€“ with some more very good stories, but also much more stinkers.Having read all the thirty two Gardner Dozois yearly collections I couldn't help but notice a steady but regular decline in quality of SF writing, from the 80s to the modern times. OK, granted, this is just one of yearly anthologies amongst many, and yes, it reflects the very personal, subjective taste of the editor, but still, there is a clear trend towards a lesser quality. The main reasons of that, at least in my personal opinion and for my subjective taste, are the following:- a tendency to run after the developments in the world, rather than trying to anticipate them. Global warming hysteria, fear of nanotechnologies and GMOs and consequences of recent progress in informatics are the best examples of it. Few writers even try to think about something really new - and it seems that even fewer have intellectual capacity of doing it...- nihilism, pessimism and fear-mongering seem to be the leading motive in recent SF, as there is hardly any joy and exaltation linked usually with new discoveries and opening of new horizons. To the contrary, everything and anything seems to be a threat.- lack of humour. In this anthology there is at best one story which contains at least some humour and wit. Everything is mostly gloom and doom taken DEADLY seriously...- left winged politics. That is probably due to Gardner Dozois personal choice, but at least in his anthologies anything conservative, religious and especially military is mostly the source of all evil in the world. Christianity seems to be particularly hated.- poorly developed characters, with whom we cannot really connect.- poor endings - or no endings at all. It seems that nowadays there are few writers able to find a good closure or a punch line.For all that reasons, reading those huge collections was frequently much less fun than expected - and I distinctly remember that when I discovered SF with classic short stories from the 50s and 60s, well, this was a much more enjoyable experience...This collection includes also two very precious things. In the introduction we have an overview of what happened in SF (largely understood) in 2014 - in all Gardner Dozois yearly collections that thing is invariably always very precious. At the end there is also the very useful section of "honourable mentions" - stories which couldn't be selected for this collection because of lack of space (and this is already a HUGE book!), but which were also of good quality.There were six very good stories: "The rider", "The burial of Sir John Mawe at Cassini", "The regular", "Passage of Earth", "Thing and sick" (THE BEST IN THIS COLLECTION) and "Yesterday"s kin". There were also four good stories: "Amicae eternum", "In Babelsberg", "Grand jetÃ© (the great leap)", "Jubilee". All those definitely deserve to be discovered.The category readable (sometimes barely) includes fourteen stories â€“ if you skip them, you will not miss much.For my personal taste there were eleven stinkers: "The fifth dragon", "The days of the war, as red as blood, as dark as bile", "Shooting the Apocalypse", "The colonel", "Entanglement", "Slipping", "Covenant", "Los piratas del mar de plastic (Pirates of the plastic ocean)", "God decay", "Communion", "Someday". Those ones I advise to simply avoid.One story, "The man who sold the moon", I am unable to rate because it bore me so badly that I stopped reading it after 15 pages. You will have to make your own mind about it.Below, more of my impressions about the stories, with some limited SPOILERS.--------------------------------------------------------------------------------"The fifth dragon" by Ian McDonald â€“ near future, colonized Moon; a bisexual woman remembers how she emigrated from Earth, joined a kind of swinger sex-cluster and met the love of her life; under the pretence of SF it's mostly LGBT soft porn story. You will never find anything better in hard SF than short stories about Pirx the Pilot, masterfully written by Stanislaw Lem. This book is the second and sadly also the last collection of those stories, following and completing the earlier anthology "Tales of Pirx the Pilot".Albeit much less known in the West than he should be, Stanislaw Lem (1921-2006) was a titan of SF. His classical works, written in the 50s and 60s, didn't age one bit and remain amongst the greatest SF writings ever. For my personal taste, the "Invincible", a short novel he wrote in 1964, is simply THE BEST SF thing ever published. The hilarious but also deeply philosophical compilations "Star Diaries" and "The Cyberiad" can be read and re-read infinitely and you will always find another layer of wisdom in them at every lecture!The stories about Pirx the Pilot are another of Lem's masterpieces. They are set somewhere in the 22nd century, in a reality in which Mankind started to colonize the Solar System. There are already settlements on the Moon and Mars, and manned expeditions begun the exploration of the other solar systems. In this world lives Pirx, a rather likeable but quite average, hard-working, no-nonsense guy. In this second collection Pirx is in fact no more a mere pilot, but already a respected captain of spaceships.Those stories are hard SF, or rather "nuts and bolts" and their tonality is rather low-key - but still they deliver an amazing punch. They are all very good and I always took a great pleasure in reading every single one of them. "The Inquest" is absolutely the best - it might be in fact one of the most profound and thought-provoking things you will ever read. "Accident" is a particularly beautiful thing, when "The hunt" is the most tense and the most poignant. "Pirx's tale" is the only one somehow lighter and actually pretty funny. Finally, "Ananke", as it's very name suggests, is the darkest - and the saddest.I read those stories many, many times and I never got bored - not even for one moment. I don't have words strong enough to praise this book. Buy it, read it, keep it and leave it to your children. ENJOY!

IMPRESSIVE! I loved every single scene of this film! It is even more impressive if we take in account that it was the first film Mel Gibson directed - and he immediately made a masterpiece. Below, more of my impressions, with some limited SPOILERS.1968, a little town somewhere near Boston. Chuck Nordstadt (Nick Stahl), a boy about 12-years old, lives with his dysfunctional mother and his two half-sisters, an older one, Gloria, a gorgeous redhead who hates him and a younger one, Meg, who is friendly, precociously intelligent but also a little pesky. Chuck misses his father, who died in somehow mysterious circumstances and totally hates his life - he dreams of entering the military boarding school to later become a pilot but also to get away from his family. He is however a slow learner and needs desperately a tutor - and then one day he learns that the reclusive, unfriendly disfigured man living nearby, a certain Justin McLeod (Mel Gibson) is actually a former university teacher. And then the film begins. This is one of the BEST FILMS I saw in many years. Mel Gibson did an amazing job as director and also as actor. He very carefully adapted the original novel, changing it in some crucial aspects and I believe that he did the right thing - I am quite certain that I would hate this film if it followed closely the book. Casting was simply perfect, with young Nick Stahl giving an incredible performance, Margaret Witton being perfect as the unstable mom, Fay Masterson portraying marvellously a spiteful viper and little Gaby Hoffmann doing great as brilliant pixish Meg. The life of a little town is described with care, amusement, criticism but also some tenderness. Views are marvellous and dialogs are frequently irresistible.I will keep this review deliberately short to avoid spoilers, because this is a film with surprises and it keeps us guessing and wondering how will it end until the very final scene. I have no words strong enough to praise it. This is a film to buy, watch, keep and re-watch. ENJOY!

I was only partially satisfied with this film, even if I rather enjoyed watching it. It could have been a much better thing, if the director made into an original thing, rather than trying hard to make another "Dirty Dozen" - which obviously was an impossible task. Below, more of my impressions, with some LIMITED SPOILERS.This film is based on the true story of First Special Service Force, indeed sometimes nicknamed "Devil's Brigade", a mixed American-Canadian commando created in 1942 and which, after participating in the Aleutian Islands campaign (landing on Kiska in 1943), fought with distinction in 1943 and 1944 in Italy and southern France. It was disbanded on 5 December 1944 near Menton (France). This unit is being considered as the direct ancestor of modern US and Canadian Special Forces, which both celebrate Menton Day every 5 December, by a combined parachute jump and a ball.This film describes only the first part of this history, beginning with the recruitement and ending at the Monte La Difensa fight on 2 December 1943, which was indeed the greatest exploit of "Devil's Brigade" (the unopposed Kiska landing during Aleutian Campaign was however completely skipped, to streamline the narration).The film has many merits, beginning with good actors (William Holden, Cliff Robertson, Richard Jaeckel and a cameo by Dana Andrews), a quite honest final battle sequence, some good humour and some not half bad dialogs. It has however also one HUGE weakness - it tries to be a remake of "Dirty Dozen", which not only is impossible (there will never be another "Dirty Dozen", not even in a thousand years) but it also falsifies real history. In this film the American component of the unit is made of the scum of the earth, the worse elements everybody was happy to get rid off once the commando starts recruiting - in fact they are even brought to the training camp under the guard of MPs, in cattle wagons! That is absolutely NOT how it was in reality - all American members of the commando without exception were volunteers and a great number of applicants were rejected, because they didn't fit the very demanding profile necessary to serve in the unit.Also, the film really follows the general line of events in "Dirty Dozen": difficult and forced recruitement, efforts to unify the initially very divided group by offering them a common enemy, hostility of some high ranking @holes, a first mission which is in fact a repetition of the already legendary maneuvres scenes from "Dirty Dozen" and finally the real battle. It is really like watching a remake of a much better film, which was incidentally made only one year earlier...Let's stress it again - I am not saying that this is a bad film, no, in fact I rather enjoyed watching it. But this is not really a faithful description of real "Devil's Brigade" and it could have been a much better thing, if Andrew V. McLaglen didn't try so hard to step in Robert Aldrich's much wider and deeper tracks. Still, a rather honest thing, for which the ideal rating would probably be 3,5 stars. ENJOY!

I was disappointed by this action "comedy", which had such a potential - and managed to waste almost al of it. Below, more of my impressions, with some limited SPOILERS.The film opens with John (Brad Pitt) and Jane Smith (Angelina Jolie) answering questions during marriage counselling. They talk about their troubles, how they met, how they fell in love and married, etc. However, very quickly we learn that their official jobs are a cover and that they are both professional hitmen (or rather a hitman and a hitwoman) - and neither of them have a clue about the real profession of another. Quite unavoidably, this will lead to a lot of complications...Mixing "True Lies" with "War of the Roses" and casting two such gifted and beautiful people in main roles was a great idea. It was however mostly wasted. Rather than insisting fully on the humour, either black one like in "War of the Roses" or more relaxed like in "True Lies", this film relies more on repetitive action scenes and wild stunts - which start to get boring quite soon. Dialogs are a huge disappointment - with the exception of a couple of good moments in the marriage counselor office and some occasional snappy one liners, they are for their majority humourless, banal and pale. The "war of sexes" waged mercilessly in a luxurious residence could have been a great comic moment, but the insistence on fire power and martial completely eliminated this possibility. If you think you will see another Michael Douglas vs. Kathleen Turner moment from "War of the Roses" you will be very, very disappointed.Sadly, this is a mostly failed film. It is not funny and therefore it doesn't work as a comedy, and it is not serious enough to be an interesting action movie. The only interest resides in the two main actors, who are indeed a vision of splendor - quite obviously, being a man, I liked Ms Jolie more, but I must admit that Brad Pitt is in this film at his most handsome. Small wonder that they started an affair when filming this... And then of course we have also Stephanie March, Kerry Washington, Michelle Monaghan and jennifer Morrison in second roles.I give to this film 2,5 stars only for the sheer accumulation of (mostly) feminine beauty. Otherwise, this is really a thing you can skip without losing much.

You will never find anything better in hard SF than those masterfully written short stories. Albeit much less known in the West than he should be, Stanislaw Lem (1921-2006) was a titan of SF. His classical works, written in the 50s and 60s, didn't age one bit and remain amongst the greatest SF writings ever. For my personal taste, the "Invincible", a short novel he wrote in 1964, is simply THE BEST SF thing ever published. The hilarious but also deeply philosophical compilations "Star Diaries" and "The Cyberiad" can be read and re-read infinitely and you will always find another layer of wisdom in them at every lecture!The "Tales of Pirx the Pilot" are another of Lem's masterpieces. Those are five stories set somewhere in the 22nd century, in a reality in which Mankind started to colonize the Solar System. There are already settlements on the Moon and Mars, and manned expeditions begun the exploration of the other solar systems. In this world lives Pirx, a rather likeable but quite average, hard-working, no-nonsense guy. We meet him first as a cadet, then he becomes a pilot and finally a captain of a merchant spaceship.Those stories are hard SF, or rather "nuts and bolts" and their tonality is rather low-key - but still they deliver an amazing punch. They are all very good and I always took a great pleasure in reading every single one of them. "Albatross" is the most tragic, but it is "Terminus" which is the best here. My advice is however to read them in order, with "Terminus" being the last, as Pirx character grows and develops from one story to another. "Terminus" is the crowning point of this collection and I guarantee that you will have tears in your eyes at the last word and you will be lost deeply in your thoughts when closing this book.If you like it, don't hesitate to get "More tales of Pirx the Pilot", with five more stories, which are EVEN BETTER, with especially "The Inquest" being one of the most profound and thought-provoking things you will ever read.I don't have words strong enough to praise this book. Buy it, read it, keep it and leave it to your children. ENJOY!

I liked this 1953 quasi-document about the siege of Malta during WWII. It is very well done and moving - the only thing which I found weaker was the romance. Below, more of my impressions, with some LIMITED SPOILERS.Malta, 1942. The hardest moments of the terrifying siege, which lasts now since more than two years. Bringing in the supplies by sea is now harder than ever and Italians and Germans bomb with unprecedented vigor airfields, ports and towns. Flight Lieutenant Peter Ross (Alec Guinness), an experienced photo reconnaissance pilot, stranded in Malta on his way to Egypt, ends by being assigned to one of RAF squadrons there. He soon meets Maria (Muriel Pavlow), a young Maltese woman working in the RAF operations room and they become close... And then the film really begins.As already said, this is a quasi document, with fictitious characters being more a pretext to show the reality of life (and death) during the siege, than real heroes of the film. The hardships endured valiantly by the defenders and the sacrifice of those who brought supplies through blocade lines are the real subject "Malta story". The most dramatic and tense moment of the fillm is of course the convoy battle which raged in the western Mediterranean from 3 to 15 August 1942, better known as operation "Pedestal" (Italians call it Battaglia di Mezzo Agosto and to the Maltese it is known as "The Convoy of Santa Mariya", as it arrived on Assumption Day). The scenes with the tanker "Ohio" (the most crucial element of the convoy), a ship which was really martyred (there is simply no other word) are purely incredible in their intensity. The fighting spirit of the defenders, shown in many, many ways, including some defiant graffitis, is also perfectly shown here. This is a very moving, tragic but finally very uplifting and optimistic film.The only thing which I liked less is the character played by Alec Guinness. The director ordered him to play a man who is more than calm and stoical - he is introverted and indifferent to the point of being completely cold and ultimately unlikeable. It hurst the romance aspect of the film because it is impossible to detect any kind of interest (let's not even talk about passion) in this guy. It probably makes him a good oficer and a great pilot (and before war a good scientist) but also a singularly uninteresting cinema character. Sir Alec Guinness was a great actor - it is a real pity, that here he was hardly allowed to act.This film has considerable value as a quasi document, as it allows us to really feel what it was to be one of Malta defenders in thyose terrible years 1940-43. As a fiction on another hand it doesn't work that well. still, I am glad that I bought and watched this film and I will keep the DVD for a future viewing. ENJOY!

I was disappointed by this 1968 adaptation of Alistair MacLean's spy novel. There were many changes made to the original material and most of them were, for my personal taste, completely useless and very, very stupid which resulted in serious damage caused to the cohesion and logics of the story. Below, more of my personal impressions, with some LIMITED SPOILERS.A satellite re-enters the atmosphere and ejects a capsule which parachutes to the Arctic. Very soon after Commander James Ferraday (Rock Hudson), captain of the U.S. nuclear attack submarine USS "Tigerfish" (SSN-509), stationed at Holy Loch, Scotland, is ordered to make sail to the Arctic (small precision here â€“ in real life there never was a US submarine named "Tigerfish"). His mission is to rescue the personnel of Drift Ice Station Zebra, a British civilian scientific weather station moving with the ice pack. However, as he welcomes on board a British intelligence agent "Mr. Jones" (Patrick McGoohan), a whole platoon of heavily armed US Marines under Captain Anders (Jim Brown) and Boris Vaslov (Ernest Borgnine), a Russian defector who is a colleague of "Mr. Jones", it becomes quickly obvious that the mission is actually a cover for a more dangerous, highly classified assignment. And then the film begins.This could have been a very good spy/action thriller. I mean, you take a good novel by Alistair MacLean ("Guns of Navarone", "Where eagles dare") with action taking place in Arctica, a place which always inspired this author ("Night without end" is a masterpiece), you take for directing no lesser a person than John Sturges ("The magnificent seven"), you get a huge budget (8 million USD â€“ 1968 dollars) and actors like Rock Hudson, Patrick McGoohan and Ernest Borgnine. How can you possibly mess it up? Well, this film clearly proves that nothing is impossibleâ€¦The poor, absurd scenario is the main problem. For the needs of the film the story was so much changed that ultimately there is not much left from the book and also many mistakes were made. One of the worse ideas was to change the identity of the main villain, who in the film is possibly the most obvious person possible and therefore most of the suspense is gone. Everything that happens once the submarine surfaces in the Arctic was changed and as result became un incomprehensible mess. But the worst thing is the last 15 minutes, which have nothing more to do with what happens in the book and in which Western soldiers and Soviet soldiers are shown as just two equally honourable and respectable sides in what turns out to be a kind of misunderstanding â€“ when in the book the mission is clearly for Western agents to recover crucial intelligence, which Soviets covet immensely too. The absurdity of the scenario makes the watching of this very long film (150 minutes) a quite difficult thing.The good things in this film are the character of "Mr. Jones" and the way Patrick McGoohan played him. Some scenes on board of USS "Tigerfish" are also very honest and Rock Hudson gives a good show as the captain. This is why I give to this film two stars â€“ but other than that there is only disappointment. I gave this film away as soon as I finished watching it and I just really want to forget it. AVOID!

This 2006 film is a good, powerful, shocking and extremely upsetting social drama. It certainly is something that you don't forget easily. Below, more of my impressions, with some limited SPOILERS.The film begins when a young woman named Sherry Swanson (Maggie Gyllenhaal) is released from prison, meets her parole officer and starts looking for a job - and also tries to repair her relationship with her little daughter Alexis, who in her absence was raised by her brother and his wife. It is going to be a very bumpy ride, as Sherry is a former heroine addict - and the hardships she faces make her crave a moment of articificial bliss... She will get however some help from another former convict/addict, Dean Walker (Danny Trejo).This is a very tough film, so tough that by moments I found it almost impossible to watch - especially in the most heartbreaking moments between Sherry and Alexis. I found this film more disturbing than most of the horrors I saw, even if finally not so much happens, other that day to day struggle of a broken, suffering human being.There are some hints about Sherry's past and they make this film even tougher to watch... but I will say no more here.The performance of Maggie Gyllenhaal is incredible and I am very surprised that she wasn't at least nominated for an Oscar. She very much carries this film on her shoulders - and other parts of her body, which she displays here a lot... After watching her in this film and in "Secretary" I am in awe of her talent and also of her courage, because she sure as hell doesn't pick easy roles... Danny Trejo gives also a great show in a rather atypical role. Giancarlo Esposito (of "Breaking Bad" fame) is also very good as a tough, no-nonsense parole officer.I would probably rate this film five stars if it was not for the very ending, which I found weak - almost as if the director didn't know how to wrap the film and decided to just rush it and get it over with.That being said, it is still a good, powerful drama and even if it shook me badly, I am glad that I discovered it. This is not a film which you will enjoy - but it is very much worth watching. A recommended viewing.

Well, I finally discovered this 1958 great classic and I LOVED it! After reading so many good feedback, I was wondering if it will be as good as expected - but I had no reasons to worry. IT IS THAT GOOD! Below, more of my impressions, with some limited SPOILERS.IMPORTANT PRECISION: this is a Region 2 Europe PAL DVD - it will NOT work on standard US/Canada Region 1 NTSC equipment.Battle of Gazala, 1942. A British ambulance leaves Tobruk just before Afrika Korps cuts the city off. Five people are on board: Captain Anson (John Mills), a seriously shaken in battle officer from transport pool, his tough as nails chief NCO, mechanist sergeant major Tom Pugh (Harry Andrews), nurses Diana Murdoch (Sylvia Syms) and Denise Norton (Diane Clare) and an Afrikaner South African officer, Captain van der Poel (Anthony Quayle), who got separated from his unit and catches the ride with them to go to Alexandria. As Axis troops progress quickly, they have soon to leave the main road and cut through the most hostile regions of desert. This is how the film begins and the rest is the struggle of those five ill assorted people against the deadly dangeorus wilderness - and their own demons...The film begins slowly and in fact during the first ten minutes I was actually wondering what everybody saw in this film, but then it started catching momentum and I finally understood that everybody was right. It is a great film and a great story, with tragedy included but ultimately very uplifting.The scenario is strong. The ending, always the most vulnerable point, is VERY good. There is a lot of tension and drama. Characters are well shown, with their strengths and vulnerabilities. The one point slightly less good was the romance element - I somehow found it a little bit artificial, but it ultimately is not all so important to the plot. Finally, it is worth mentioning, that as in case of quite a lot of very good war films, in this one there is virtually no fighting...Actors were perfectly used. John Mills plays very well a tired, damaged man. Harry Andrews is excellent as the undestructible NCO. Sylvia Syms is impossibly cute and sexy - so is Diane Clare, who added to it the element of vulnerability. As for Anthony Quayle, well, he gives here his usual perfect performance - and it is also in this film that I finally realised how physically powerful this actor was!I will keep this review short on purpose, to avoid giving away any clues about the twists and turns, which add a lot to this film and which I never saw coming. I like to watch war films and I saw many, many hundreds of them - and this one is amongst the best. I recommend it with all my heart. ENJOY!Once you watched "Ice cold in Alex", if you are up for another terrible, heartbreaking trek through the desert roughly at the same moment, you should try "A taxi for Tobruk", a French 1960 film, with Lino Ventura, Charles Aznavour and Hardy Kruger. This is also a little jewel - albeit more brutal... Enjoy that one too - if you dare...

I liked this surprisingly deep and serious psychological and social drama disguised as a western. It certainly deserves to be better known than it is. Below, more of my impressions, with some limited SPOILERS.Steve Sinclair (Robert Taylor) is nowadays a farmer in a mountainous valley, but once he was a valiant soldier and a dangerous gunslinger. During the War Between States he fought for the Confederation and not just in any unit - he was one of the Quantrill Raiders, brave but quite pitiless secessionist guerrillas. The fact that he once rode with Quantrill tells us, that the action of the film takes place probably either in Missouri or in Kentucky (Arkansas is also a possibility). He rents his ranch from the main landowner and real power figure in the area, a certain Dennis Deneen (Donald Crisp), a man already aged but who still wears that crown...His peaceful life is however frequently disrupted by various incidents caused by his emotionally unstable and gun loving younger brother Tony (John Cassavetes). Tony can do his job when he wants and the film begins when he comes back from the expedition to sell the cattle, bringing a lot of money, as he didn't lose many animals on the way and got for the herd a better price than expected. But he also brings an unexpected guest into the house - Joan Blake (Julie London), a stunningly beautiful saloon girl, who looks for a new start in life and is ready to try her chance even with an immature, (and by the way younger than her), unstable and ultimately not very bright guy like Tony. The same day arrive also to the valley a gunman from Steve's past and a group of farmers, former Union soldiers, who have a claim on part of Steve's land. And then the film really begins.This is a surprisingly serious and dark movie, in which an almost oppressive feeling of approaching tragedy appears immediately in the first seconds. More than a western this is actually a psychological drama about a community which has to cope with the presence of a dangerous, irresponsible, childish, sociopath â€“ who still is nevertheless precious to many of themâ€¦ Then there is also social drama, about a terrible conflict of interests between farmers and cattle herders, magnified by the fact that both groups fought earlier on opposite sides in War Between Statesâ€¦ And then thrown in the middle there is also a former saloon girl, who is ready to do almost anything to just feel clean again when she wakes up in the morningâ€¦Actors offered a great show here, beginning with Robert Taylor who is very convincing as a reformed killer, a very dangerous man who doesn't have anything to prove anymore and who was very much pacified by a life of hardships... John Cassavetes is AMAZING as immature, unpredictable, gun crazy Tony, who just was born too late to go to war and somehow is unable to live peacefully. Julie London has a smaller part, but she adds a lot to this film, especially in the wonderful scene when she sings to Tony the beautiful "Saddle the wind" songâ€¦The scenario is strong and the result of the unavoidable final confrontation is both immensely tragic and quite logical. All the tragedies shown in this film are somehow underlined by the incredible beauty of the mountains, with its fields of wild flowers covering the slopes and old trees keeping watch over deep valleys.I liked this film a lot and I am glad that I bought and watched it. I will definitely keep the DVD for another viewing in the future. ENJOY!

I LOVED this 1943 drama/romance/war film! It impressed and enchanted me. I don't have words strong enough to praise it. Below more of my impressions, with some LIMITED SPOILERS.The film begins somewhere around 1942 I think, with an old gentleman, Major-General Clive Wynne-Candy (Roger Livesey), a senior commander in Home Guard, taking some rest in Turkish bath before an important military exercise, which is supposed to start the next day. However, even if "War starts at midnight", a young hot shot lieutenant decides to break the rules and strike pre-emptively, capturing the old general when he wears nothing except his birthsuit. Terribly humiliated, general Wynne-Candy gets into a fight with the young officer - as they fall into water, we go back 40 years, to a time when a young hot shot lieutenant named Clive Candy, who distinguished himself in Boer War, just returned to England... And then the film really begins and takes us on a wonderful, albeit also frequently tragic, voyage through 40 years of life and service of an officer and gentleman, until it brings us finally back to the "Turkish Bath Pre-emptive Strike of 1942"...)))This film is such a wonderful masterpiece that it is even hard to decide where to begin the praise, however, after some reflexion I believe that the greatest treasure is the scenario. Michael Powell and Emeric Pressburger based their film on a cartoon, which mocked mercilessly conservative British old-timers, symbolised by a certain Colonel Blimp, an overweight fellow commenting and lecturing (with utmost stupidity) on political and social events, always wearing for all clothes a towel wrapped around his prominent belly, as all conversations invariably took place in a Turkish bathâ€¦ Their great idea was however to take such a character and go back in time, to show him in his youth and then follow him all the way until the time when he achieved full Blimp-ness. The result is one of the most wonderful and touching life stories everâ€¦Casting was perfect, simply perfect. Roger Livesey did an amazing job, as well as Anton Walbrook, who plays Theo Kretschmar-Schuldorff, German alter ego of Clive Candy, who for most of this film is simultaneously his enemy, rival, opponent â€“ and best friendâ€¦ But it is Deborah Kerr who completes this film and makes it into such a masterpiece. She plays here three different women, but I cannot say anything more, because it would be revealing too much. I made some calculations and I realised that this was the 9th film with her that I saw â€“ and she always was perfect in all of themâ€¦This is a long film (163 minutes), because Major-General Clive Wynne-Candy lived a long and well filled life. I guarantee however that you will not see the time passing, as there is not even one scene too much.Churchill hated this film for some reason and even tried to stop its distribution, but I honestly would be at a loss to explain why, because this is not only a tribute but in fact a LOVE SONG for Merry Old England, conservatives, soldiers, patriotism, aged gentlemen, fair-play, hunting, love and marriage, honour, good liquor, stiff upper lip, Empire and general Britishness - and also Turkish bathsâ€¦))) All of it bathing (sorry, I couldn't resist) in clever, intelligent, wonderful, kind and very gentle but nevertheless absolutely omnipresent humour. The main character himself is incredibly attaching, even more so if you pay attention to one detail which is never explicitly explained â€“ when he was a young lieutenant, his name was Clive Candy, but later at one moment he changes his name into Clive Wynne-Candy. When I noticed that and realised WHY EXACTLY he did it, well, I had tears in my eyesâ€¦There is one and only one thing in this film which I didn't like and it was the treatment of Boer War. In 1902 Lieutenant Clive Candy goes to Germany to defend the honour of England after German Press started a campaign of denunciation of alleged British war crimes. Well, the problem is that Germans, this one time, were right on money! British troops indeed committed horrible atrocities against Boer civilians and prisoners of war and those crimes included the creation of first concentration camps in history! Now, I understand that it wasn't something one could say on the screen when the nation was fighting a merciless, total war â€“ but still, it is a very dark spot on an otherwise PERFECT thing!Bottom line, this is a wonderful film, a real treasure of world cinema and an incredibly beautiful, touching, moving, amusing and occasionally heart-breaking thing. I am definitely not a young girl (and not even a girl â€“ and not exactly even young anymore for that matter) but still, there were moments during this film when I had tears in my eyes. This is a thing to BUY, SEE, LOVE and KEEP for your children. ENJOY!

I was quite favourably surprised by this 2013 Spanish-Canadian film, officially presented as horror. It is an original, clever and quite atmospheric thing. Below, more of my impressions, with some limited SPOILERS.The film begins in 2008, at the worst moment of financial crisis, with a distraught stockbroker Jeffrey D'Asange (Nikolaj Coster-Waldau) driving on a snowy road, with his children, three-year-old Victoria and one-year-old Lilly, in the backseat. They will ultimately arrive to an isolated, abandoned cabin in the woods - where very quickly it will become apparent, that SOMETHING already made this place it's den earlier... I will say nothing more about the story.This is a highly original film with some ideas which I never saw adapted to the screen. Guillermo del Toro produced with film and his influence is visible here, as you will probably recognise some elements from "Pan's Labyrinth" (which he directed) and "Orphanage" (which he produced). I would say that this film is more or less on the same level as "Orphanage" but somehow inferior to "Pan' Labyrinth". Also, as both those previous films, this is definitely a quite dark opus.Although officially a horror, this film quickly stops being scary (albeit it is definitely creepy until the end) and evolves into a psychological thriller with supernatural elements. As you will discover in the first minutes, there is without question a supernatural, dangerous entity in this film - but it is definitely NOT your standard issue monster from American straight to DVD Bminus movies. There is a deep conflict of interests here between human and not-really-human protagonists in "Mama" - and there is also the question of terrible, heart-breaking choices. This film didn't really scare me, but it kept me interested, tense and guessing how-the-heck-will-all-it-end until the very last seconds. The fact that fate of two little girls is the main object of the whole conflict makes the whole thing even more dramatic.Grown up actors (Jessica Chastain and Nikolaj Coster-Waldau) did a honest job, but the film reposes in great part on the amazing performance of child actresses, Megan Charpentier (Victoria), who was 12 at that time and Isabelle Nelisse, who I think was not older than 7. The director managed to guide those two kids in an absolutely incredible way! Those two kids really will blow your mind!Bottom line, this is very honest, very watchable film, more psychological thriller with supernatural elements, than a real horror, but most certainly a very original thing. A recommended viewing! ENJOY!

This is an impressive masterpiece of cinema and possibly the best vampire movie ever. Albeit very old, it is still not aged - and I think it never will. Below, more of my impressions, with some LIMITED SPOILERS."Nosferatu" is the first cinema adaptation of Bram Stoker's "Dracula", but as the producers were unable to acquire the rights to the title, it was decided to change the name of the main character to Graf (or Count) Orlok. Similarly the word "vampire" was replaced with "nosferatu", a term used in Romanian folk tales to design many kind of sinister forces of the night, which Bram Stoker considered in his book as a synonym of "vampire". Some other changes were also introduced, but the main story nevertheless follows the lines of Bram Stoker's book - with the exception of the ending...The film begins therefore with a certain Thomas Hutter, who lives in the fictitious German city of Wisborg and is a quite happy fellow, married to beautiful Ellen. Then one day his employer, a somehow shady real estate dealer named Knock, sends Hutter to Transylvania to visit a new client named Count Orlok, who desires to acquire a residence in Wisborg. And then the film REALLY begins...This being a black and white silent movie, it is of course very different from most of other vampire films - but this is precisely what gives it an unique flavour. F.W. Murnau used all the tricks available in his trade at this time to make this film really scary and especially incredibly atmospheric and he succeeded - BIG TIME! The vampire is in no way a dangerously charming aristocrat as in later films with Bela Lugosi and Christopher Lee - here he is a freakishly creepishly grotesque creature, which makes the viewer feel uncomfortable from the first moment we see him. Actor Max Schreck who plays the vampire (and who by the way was a handsome man) was completely transformed by make up and other characterisation but he especially did an incredible job by using the body language in such a way that we really have an impression that Count Orlok is NOT human! This is an incredible performance!The performance of actors, the atmospheric music, the tricks of lights and shadows and impressive cinematography, all this contributed to make this film into something exceptionnal. Released in 1922 "Nosferatu" is a very old, even ancient thing, but it didn't really age and probably never will anymore, but to the contrary, it will keep haunting generation after generation of humans - exactly like a vampire...)))I am very glad that I bought and watched it and I intend to keep this DVD as long as DVD players exist. I don't have words strong enough to recommend it so I will just say, BUY IT, SEE IT and KEEP IT!

I liked this 1941 film much more than I expected and I spend a really nice moment watching it. Below, more of my impressions, with some limited SPOILERS.In 1940 a cocky, arrogant and rather immature American pilot Tim Baker (Tyrone Power) accepts to ferry Lockheed Hudson bombers to Britain, for the very generous fee of $1,000 per flight. In London, he meets his former British girlfriend Carol Brown (Betty Grable), who works in the Women's Auxiliary Air Force by day and stars in a nightclub by night. He tries to rekindle the relation, but she rebukes him strongly, as he treated her badly in the past. Treating all this as a challenge and a game, Baker decides to reconquer Carol, no matter what... And then the film really begins.As stated in the title, this is more a war-time romantic comedy than a war film, even if there is some fighting. The real topic of the film is not really war time adventures of Tim Baker but his attempts to get his girl back. It is an uphill battle, because he is kind of an @hole and Carol, who knows this side of him perfectly well, already found a more suitable replacement. But on another hand Tim is a dashing, attractive, dangerously charming @hole - and Carol still has feelings for him. This dance of seduction, attraction and repulsion is very nicely shown and gives the occasion for many excellent dialogs. There is also a lot of polite but nevertheless frequently very corrosive humour.The only film with Betty Grable I saw before that one was "How to marry a millionnaire", in which she was of course very charming but also somehow outstaged by Marilyn Monroe and Lauren Bacall. It was therefore a very, VERY pleasant surprise for me to discover how great was this actress and with how much skill and charm she could deliver killer dialog lines. Skill, wit and charm, all inside a very pleasant frame, walking on never ending legs - well, small wonder that she was the number one pin-up girl during WWII, surpassing even Rita Hayworth... She is GREAT in this film - I will look for more of her movies.Albeit USA were not yet at war at the time of the release, the film contains also some strongly anti-German and pro-British propaganda, but also gives some insight in the early stages of WWII (1940-1941), showing how USA cheated in order to support Great Britain when preserving the appearances of neutrality, but also how ridiculous were the first RAF air raids against Germany. There is an almost unbelievable but nevertheless strictly true scene with British bombers crews throwing leaflets on Germany and taking great care to unpack them well, so nobody gets hurt on the ground... Well, it all changed quickly after the beginning of the Blitz...Bottom line, this is a very honest, surprisingly pleasant war-time romantic comedy - not any kind of masterpiece, but a good, solid, honest film and a nice watch. I will keep my DVD for another viewing in the future. ENJOY!

I had some hopes for this 2003 American-Australian horror, but I found it disappointing and even boring. Below, more of my impressions, with some limited SPOILERS.The story takes place in the town of Darkness Falls, in Massachusetts (I think). A local legend tells about a disfigured woman, a lonesome widow, who liked to give town's children gifts and gold coins when they lost a tooth, thus earning her the name "Tooth Fairy". One day however she was wrongly accused of murder and lynched - but not before swearing vengeance and putting a curse upon the town. Legend has it that her dark spirit visits children on the night they lose their last baby tooth. However, should any person see her when she visits, they put themselves in great danger - and one day Kyle Walsh (Chaney Clay), a local teenager, realizes VERY clearly that the legend is not just a fable... The film really begins when Kyle, after many years spend out of town, returns (very reluctantly) to Darkness Fallss, summoned by Caitlin Greene (Emma Caulfield), on whom he used to have a major crush as a teenager.
