In an alternate reality, on a Mars quite different from what it really is, human immigrants are slowly but surely colonizing the planet â€“ and the less advanced natives are not happy with itâ€¦ One day, a Mars-born human guide is hired by an Earth scientist for a risky questâ€¦ The story begins very well, but then turns into nonsense and crashes in an abysmally IDIOTIC and morally REPUGNANT ending (which includes a very cruel and totally useless murder)â€¦ I was DISGUSTED by it â€“ AVOID!"Zero For Conduct" by Greg Egan â€“ definitely NOT one of my favourite authors, but here he delivers â€“ BIG TIME. The story takes place in contemporary Iran and the main hero is a very, very gifted teenage girl, working very hard to get her high-school diploma. One day she makes a stunning discovery â€“ but as she belongs to a very vulnerable segment of society (she is an Afghan refugee, belonging to Tajik nation) she is concerned that it will be stolen from herâ€¦ A GOOD, well written, dramatic and profound story."The Waiting Stars" by Aliette de Bodard â€“ another story in the distant future/alternate reality cycle about a high tech future world dominated by rivalry between Chinese and Azteca empires. This time a Vietnamese woman goes to space to try to salvage a derelict sapient spaceshipâ€¦ READABLE but, as most of the stories in this cycle, freakishly WEIRDâ€¦"A Map of Mercury" by Alastair Reynolds â€“ a human messenger tries to contact an artistic community of cyborgs "living" on Mercury; he carries an important message and needs a simple "yes" or "no" answer. It is a READABLE story, but CREEPY and with some really unpleasant moments."One" by Nancy Kress â€“ a boxing story, in fact a kind of variation on "Rocky" by, who would ever believe that, Nancy Kress, of all peopleâ€¦ Well, she had also to throw in some LGBT stuff, probably to lessen the shockâ€¦))) A not so good boxer undergoes brain surgery â€“ and results are, well, surprising, to say the leastâ€¦ A GOOD, solid, well written novella â€“ it could have been a masterpiece, if the ending was just a little bit better."Murder on the Aldrin Express" by Martin L. Shoemaker â€“ obviously inspired by Agatha Christieâ€™s classic, this futuristic whodunit takes place onboard an Earth-bound space ship, bringing home the remains of a tragically ended Martian expedition. This is a GOOD, solid, honest story, with just the solution of the whole thing being a little bit disappointing."Biographical Fragments of the Life of Julian Prince" by Jake Kerr â€“ a collection of articles from various sources about Julian Prince, a Nobel-prize winning writer, who lived and wrote after the impact of an asteroid devastated North America. Even if it is a short thing, I found it boring â€“ and also stupid, depressing and unpleasant. AVOID."The Plague" by Ken Liu â€“ A short story about the meeting of two people after a catastrophic event linked to nanotechnologies â€“ one is a â€œregularâ€ human, the other descendant of victims of the nanotechnology linked plague. Unpleasant and shocking but original in its conclusion, this is a READABLE story."Fleet" by Sandra McDonald â€“ the story of a transsexual person living on a post-apocalyptic Guam â€“ and that is more or less everything I could understand from this thing. I donâ€™t usually care a lot for LGBT stories and this one I found particularly messy, weird and the obscene language certainly didnâ€™t help... AVOID!"The She-Wolf's Hidden Grin" by Michael Swanwick â€“ humans colonized an alien world and its indigenous inhabitants are now extinct. But are they REALLY extinct? A very strange story, with a lot of LGBT elements, but certainly creative â€“ it is a great pity that author had to add one last line which makes the whole story almost impossible to understand... A READABLE thing."Bad Day on Boscobel" by Alexander Jablokov â€“ somewhere in outer limits of Solar System, inside a very much transformed asteroid exists a human colony, subsisting thanks to gigantic genetically modified trees. A single mother, raising a rebellious teenage daughter, struggles to keep her job and try to control the more and more problematic brat... The story is very boring and characters not very interesting either â€“ but the description of this strange world makes it a READABLE story."The Irish Astronaut" by Val Nolan â€“ an American man comes to Ireland to bury the remains of an American-Irish astronaut. A good story lies buried somewhere in this very boring narrative, which ultimately goes absolutely nowhere... AVOID."The Other Gun" by Neal Asher â€“ this story is situated in Polity/prador universe; a very dangerous man and his faithful female troodon sidekick/pet/friend search for a lost weapon of enormous power for a mysterious entity known as the Client â€“ but their quest takes them in an unexpected direction. This is a GOOD, solid, honest space-opera, with just the ending maybe a little bit weaker."Only Human" by Lavie Tidhar â€“ another short story related to Central Station universe, but this time dominated by LGBT themes â€“ it happens on Titan and main characters are a lesbian couple... I found the intrigue freakishly weird and the story impossibly boring. AVOID!"Entangled" by Ian R. MacLeod â€“ This story about a radical youthful rebellion which went very, very bad and about the very Christian virtues of sacrifice, forgiveness, charity, love and mercy (even if there is no Christians in this story) is a really surprising, clever and interesting thing. It could be a masterpiece, if only author didn't decide to surf on the global warming hysteria and surrender to the "upcoming collapse of capitalism" fadâ€¦ Still, it is a GOOD, solid, shocking and moving story."Earth 1" by Stephen Baxter â€“ in a distant future our descendants start a quest to find the birth world of humanity â€“ it will be a long questâ€¦ There was potential for a masterpiece here, but the story was a little damaged by unlikeable characters and very stupid ending. Still, it is a GOOD, solid story."Technarion" by Sean McMullen â€“ this very original, in fact quite brilliant story happens somewhere around 1850 in England and I will say nothing more about the plot, because you deserve to discover it by yourself; let's just say that it will delight all people who hate computersâ€¦))) I don't fully agree with the ideology of it, but it is nevertheless a VERY GOOD, surprising and deeply shocking thing."Finders" by Melissa Scott â€“ in some kind of alternate reality universe three people go to an abandoned space station to salvage precious resources â€“ of course they will find more than they bargained forâ€¦ It is a quite banal and rather tedious treasure hunt, with pale characters and a very predictable ending. READABLE, but barely."The Queen of Night's Aria" by Ian McDonald â€“ this story occurs on Mars but in an alternate reality universe; here the Red Planet not only harbours life but even an alien civilization â€“ more than one in factâ€¦ Human soldiers are engaged in a merciless war against indigenous Uliri on Mars and an opera singer comes from Earth to entertain the troops â€“ it will be one helluva tourâ€¦))) This is a rather rare thing in modern SF: extremely well written, with interesting characters, fast pace of action, great originality, tons of wit and humour, twists on every page, very well chosen title and finally a terrific punch line! A VERY GOOD STORY â€“ the BEST IN THIS COLLECTION! TO READ ABSOLUTELY!"Hard Stars" by Brendan DuBois â€“ in a near future technologically outmatched USA face a massive drone attack by China, Iran and North Korea, which makes it almost impossible to use any advanced technological device; some federal agents try to carry a mission when avoiding drone attacksâ€¦ This is more a techno-thriller than SF, but it is a well written story, with a very powerful message â€“ democracies cannot afford losing technological and military edge, because authoritarian regimes will never miss a chance to destroy themâ€¦ A VERY GOOD, quite scary story."The Promise of Space" by James Patrick Kelly â€“ short but powerful story about the dangers and hardships of space exploration and Mars colonization; nothing more will be said, as you deserve to discover the details by yourselfâ€¦ It's actually pretty depressing, but, albeit a little reluctantly, I must admit that this is a VERY GOOD story."Quicken" by Damien Broderick â€“ a new technology makes it possible to "rekindle" (resurrect) the dead â€“ but those who come back are not very well received by the rest of the societyâ€¦ That was a great idea, but to my great regret this long-winded 59 pages novella is a total disaster. It becomes quickly boring, then turns into weird and on most pages delivers an incredibly insulting rant against Christianity and Christians, who are more or less compared to Nazisâ€¦ And all that only in the first part of the story â€“ in the second one we go in a kind of freaky absurdity which one usually associates with high-fever delusionsâ€¦ It is also occasionally obscene and in some other moments GROSS. Bottom line, this is a HORRIBLY BAD THING, the WORST STORY IN THE COLLECTION. AVOID!-------------------------------CONCLUSION: an average collection, slightly better than the one from 2012 â€“ but reading it was not always easy or pleasant.

This collection devoted to what Gardner Dozois considered as best SF published in 2013 is slightly better than the one from 2012, because even if there were more very bad stories (no less than seven), on another hand fifteen are really worth reading (four being very good).Having now read twenty nine Gardner Dozois yearly collections (from third to thirty first) I couldn't help but notice a steady but regular decline in quality of SF writing, from the 80s to the modern times. OK, granted, this is just one of yearly anthologies amongst many, and yes, it reflects the very personal, subjective taste of the editor, but still, there is a clear trend towards a lesser quality. The main reasons of that, at least in my personal opinion and for my subjective taste, are the following:- a tendency to run after the developments in the world, rather than trying to anticipate them. Global warming hysteria, fear of nanotechnologies and GMOs and consequences of recent progress in informatics are the best examples of it. Few writers even try to think about something really new â€“ even less seem to have any intellectual capacity of doing itâ€¦- nihilism, pessimism and fear-mongering seem to be the leading motive in recent SF, as there is hardly any joy and exaltation linked usually with new discoveries and opening of new horizons. To the contrary, everything and anything seems to be a threat.- lack of humour. In this anthology there are at the best two stories, out of thirty two, which contain some humour and wit. The rest is mostly gloom and doom taken DEADLY seriouslyâ€¦- left winged politics. That is probably due to Gardnez Dozois personal choice, but at least in his anthologies anything conservative, religious and especially military is mostly the source of all evil in the world. Christianity seems to be particularly hated â€“ but almost everybody panders to islam.- poorly developed characters, with whom we cannot really connect.- poor endings â€“ or no endings at all. It seems that nowadays there are few writers able to find a good closure or a punch line.For all that reasons, reading those huge collections was frequently much less fun than expected â€“ and I distinctly remember that when I discovered SF with classic short stories from the 50s and 60s, well this was a much more enjoyable experienceâ€¦Returning now to this collection, out of the 32 stories, this year, for my personal taste, only four could be considered as VERY GOOD: "Technarion", "The promise of space", "The Queen of the Night's Aria" and "Hard Stars".On another hand there were also seven stinkers: "The Discovered Country", "Martian blood", â€œBiographical Fragments of the Life of Julian Princeâ€, â€œFleetâ€, â€œThe Irish astronautâ€, "Only human" and "Quicken"Other stories ranged from GOOD (11) to READABLE (10).This collection includes also, as usual, an overview of what happened in SF (largely understood) in 2013 and that section is invariably always very precious. Moore). To the contrary, everything and anything seems to be a threat.- lack of humour. In this anthology there are at the best two stories, out of thirty two, which contain some humour and wit. The rest is mostly gloom and doom taken DEADLY seriouslyâ€¦- left winged politics. That is probably due to Gardnez Dozois personal choice, but at least in his anthologies anything conservative, religious and especially military is mostly the source of all evil in the world. Christianity seems to be particularly hated â€“ but almost everybody panders to islam.- poorly developed characters, with whom we cannot really connect.- poor endings â€“ or no endings at all. It seems that nowadays there are few writers able to find a good closure or a punch line.For all that reasons, reading those huge collections was frequently much less fun than expected â€“ and I distinctly remember that when I discovered SF with classic short stories from the 50s and 60s, well this was a much more enjoyable experienceâ€¦Returning now to this collection, out of the 32 stories, this year, for my personal taste, only four could be considered as VERY GOOD: "Technarion", "The promise of space", "The Queen of the Night's Aria" and "Hard Stars".On another hand there were also seven stinkers: "The Discovered Country", "Martian blood", â€œBiographical Fragments of the Life of Julian Princeâ€, â€œFleetâ€, â€œThe Irish astronautâ€, "Only human" and "Quicken"Other stories ranged from GOOD (11) to READABLE (10).This collection includes also, as usual, an overview of what happened in SF (largely understood) in 2013 and that section is invariably always very precious. At the end there is also the very useful section of "honourable mentions" - stories which couldn't be selected for this collection because of lack of space (and this is already a HUGE book!), but which were also of good quality.Below, more of my impressions, with some SPOILERS:---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------"The Discovered Country" by Ian R. MacLeod â€“ the world is dying and so is humanity; obscenely wealthy people download into virtual reality to become immortal â€“ invited by the owner, a musician arrives to one of their "residences"â€¦; this story was simply boring on the first ten pages and became a totally idiotic nonsense on the next twelve. AVOID!"The Book Seller" by Lavie Tidhar â€“ surprise, surprise! I usually don't like things written by this author and I certainly never cared much for the stories about "Central Station", situated in the very strange, in fact freakishly weird, futuristic Israel. This one however completely broke through my defences, by its heart-warming, passionate message of love for books â€“ and also by the tribute it pays to one of the most important pioneering SF stories ever ("Shambleau" by Catherine L. Moore). A GOOD, solid, honest "Central Station" story â€“ even if it still is very, very weirdâ€¦"Pathways" by Nancy Kress â€“ in a near future, in an area of United States particularly ravaged by extreme poverty, a young girl who suffers from a rare incurable disease undergoes an experimental treatment. This dark, depressing and pretty scary SF story mixed with some social criticism reminded me a little of "Winter's bone" movie (which I LOVED by the way). A GOOD, honest, solid thing."A Heap of Broken Images" by Sunny Moraine â€“ years ago, on a distant exoplanet, human colonists committed a genocide, or maybe rather a xenocide (thanks, Orson Scott Card) against indigenous intelligent alien population; now, a young alien female works as a guide for human tourists who come to visit the sites of this atrocity. The initial idea is interesting and the story is quite READABLE."Rock of Ages" by Jay Lake â€“ this is the story of a strange adventurer, half-punk anarchist, half-radical environmentalist, a kind of green Snake Plissken aged 130 (but well preserved), who tries to prevent a great disaster; this 50+ pages novella is a little bit too long for its own good â€“ also, it seems to be attached to earlier novels by the same writer (the "Green" cycle) and if you didn't read them (I didn't) you may have trouble to fully understand what the heck is going onâ€¦ I didn't like the radical environmentalist ideology of this story and I struggled through it a lot, but I managed to finish it, so I rate it READABLE â€“ but barelyâ€¦"Rosary and Goldenstar" by Geoff Ryman â€“ in XVI century, in a slightly alternate history, two Danes come to visit their England and meet people who, like them, are fascinated by astronomy; a young struggling actor, a certain Shakespeare, also participates in the meeting; this is a well written and quite amusing short story â€“ it's just a pity that the ending is weak. Also I wasâ€¦ wellâ€¦ surprised, that in a meeting of XVI century astronomers Copernicus is never mentioned, even once, unlike Galileo and Tycho Bracheâ€¦ Still, it is a GOOD, interesting thing."Gray Wings" by Karl Bunker â€“ in a distant future a very rich girl participates in a race of flyers (people who grew wings for this occasion) across Africa; in the opening lines circumstances force her to crash land in a very poor Nigerian villageâ€¦ A well written, GOOD, interesting story."The Best We Can" by Carrie Vaughn â€“ an extremely pessimistic, even depressing, atypical and for my personal taste incredibly STUPID description of First Contact; it is a READABLE story, but in my opinion also a totally ludicrous thingâ€¦"Transitional Forms" by Paul McAuley â€“ genetically modified organisms created to cleanse a heavily polluted industrial area mutated and escaped all control; the whole area became a "hot zone" and its borders are patrolled; this is the story of one of guards who keep the "hot zone" off limits. A rather banal, although READABLE story."Precious Mental" by Robert Reed â€“ and yet another Great Ship 50+ pages novellaâ€¦ This time an immortal man who used to be one of the captains of the Great Ship is recruited (well, in a way of speakingâ€¦) for a salvage mission far, far awayâ€¦ I noticed that every time Great Ship stories actually live the Great Ship they get better â€“ and the further the Great Ship stories go from the Great Ship, the better they getâ€¦))) This one is a GOOD, solid, honest thing â€“ if only the ending wasn't so lame, it could be a masterpieceâ€¦"Martian Blood" by Allen M. Steele â€“ first story ever by this usually very good author that I absolutely HATED! In an alternate reality, on a Mars quite different from what it really is, human immigrants are slowly but surely colonizing the planet â€“ and the less advanced natives are not happy with itâ€¦ One day, a Mars-born human guide is hired by an Earth scientist for a risky questâ€¦ The story begins very well, but then turns into nonsense and crashes in an abysmally IDIOTIC and morally REPUGNANT ending (which includes a very cruel and totally useless murder)â€¦ I was DISGUSTED by it â€“ AVOID!"Zero For Conduct" by Greg Egan â€“ definitely NOT one of my favourite authors, but here he delivers â€“ BIG TIME. The story takes place in contemporary Iran and the main hero is a very, very gifted teenage girl, working very hard to get her high-school diploma. One day she makes a stunning discovery â€“ but as she belongs to a very vulnerable segment of society (she is an Afghan refugee, belonging to Tajik nation) she is concerned that it will be stolen from herâ€¦ A GOOD, well written, dramatic and profound story."The Waiting Stars" by Aliette de Bodard â€“ another story in the distant future/alternate reality cycle about a high tech future world dominated by rivalry between Chinese and Azteca empires. This time a Vietnamese woman goes to space to try to salvage a derelict sapient spaceshipâ€¦ READABLE but, as most of the stories in this cycle, freakishly WEIRDâ€¦"A Map of Mercury" by Alastair Reynolds â€“ a human messenger tries to contact an artistic community of cyborgs "living" on Mercury; he carries an important message and needs a simple "yes" or "no" answer. It is a READABLE story, but CREEPY and with some really unpleasant moments."One" by Nancy Kress â€“ a boxing story, in fact a kind of variation on "Rocky" by, who would ever believe that, Nancy Kress, of all peopleâ€¦ Well, she had also to throw in some LGBT stuff, probably to lessen the shockâ€¦))) A not so good boxer undergoes brain surgery â€“ and results are, well, surprising, to say the leastâ€¦ A GOOD, solid, well written novella â€“ it could have been a masterpiece, if the ending was just a little bit better."Murder on the Aldrin Express" by Martin L. Shoemaker â€“ obviously inspired by Agatha Christieâ€™s classic, this futuristic whodunit takes place onboard an Earth-bound space ship, bringing home the remains of a tragically ended Martian expedition. This is a GOOD, solid, honest story, with just the solution of the whole thing being a little bit disappointing."Biographical Fragments of the Life of Julian Prince" by Jake Kerr â€“ a collection of articles from various sources about Julian Prince, a Nobel-prize winning writer, who lived and wrote after the impact of an asteroid devastated North America. Even if it is a short thing, I found it boring â€“ and also stupid, depressing and unpleasant. AVOID."The Plague" by Ken Liu â€“ A short story about the meeting of two people after a catastrophic event linked to nanotechnologies â€“ one is a â€œregularâ€ human, the other descendant of victims of the nanotechnology linked plague. Unpleasant and shocking but original in its conclusion, this is a READABLE story."Fleet" by Sandra McDonald â€“ the story of a transsexual person living on a post-apocalyptic Guam â€“ and that is more or less everything I could understand from this thing. I donâ€™t usually care a lot for LGBT stories and this one I found particularly messy, weird and the obscene language certainly didnâ€™t help... AVOID!"The She-Wolf's Hidden Grin" by Michael Swanwick â€“ humans colonized an alien world and its indigenous inhabitants are now extinct. But are they REALLY extinct? A very strange story, with a lot of LGBT elements, but certainly creative â€“ it is a great pity that author had to add one last line which makes the whole story almost impossible to understand... A READABLE thing."Bad Day on Boscobel" by Alexander Jablokov â€“ somewhere in outer limits of Solar System, inside a very much transformed asteroid exists a human colony, subsisting thanks to gigantic genetically modified trees. A single mother, raising a rebellious teenage daughter, struggles to keep her job and try to control the more and more problematic brat... The story is very boring and characters not very interesting either â€“ but the description of this strange world makes it a READABLE story."The Irish Astronaut" by Val Nolan â€“ an American man comes to Ireland to bury the remains of an American-Irish astronaut. A good story lies buried somewhere in this very boring narrative, which ultimately goes absolutely nowhere... AVOID."The Other Gun" by Neal Asher â€“ this story is situated in Polity/prador universe; a very dangerous man and his faithful female troodon sidekick/pet/friend search for a lost weapon of enormous power for a mysterious entity known as the Client â€“ but their quest takes them in an unexpected direction. This is a GOOD, solid, honest space-opera, with just the ending maybe a little bit weaker."Only Human" by Lavie Tidhar â€“ another short story related to Central Station universe, but this time dominated by LGBT themes â€“ it happens on Titan and main characters are a lesbian couple... I found the intrigue freakishly weird and the story impossibly boring. AVOID!"Entangled" by Ian R. MacLeod â€“ This story about a radical youthful rebellion which went very, very bad and about the very Christian virtues of sacrifice, forgiveness, charity, love and mercy (even if there is no Christians in this story) is a really surprising, clever and interesting thing. It could be a masterpiece, if only author didn't decide to surf on the global warming hysteria and surrender to the "upcoming collapse of capitalism" fadâ€¦ Still, it is a GOOD, solid, shocking and moving story."Earth 1" by Stephen Baxter â€“ in a distant future our descendants start a quest to find the birth world of humanity â€“ it will be a long questâ€¦ There was potential for a masterpiece here, but the story was a little damaged by unlikeable characters and very stupid ending. Still, it is a GOOD, solid story."Technarion" by Sean McMullen â€“ this very original, in fact quite brilliant story happens somewhere around 1850 in England and I will say nothing more about the plot, because you deserve to discover it by yourself; let's just say that it will delight all people who hate computersâ€¦))) I don't fully agree with the ideology of it, but it is nevertheless a VERY GOOD, surprising and deeply shocking thing."Finders" by Melissa Scott â€“ in some kind of alternate reality universe three people go to an abandoned space station to salvage precious resources â€“ of course they will find more than they bargained forâ€¦ It is a quite banal and rather tedious treasure hunt, with pale characters and a very predictable ending. READABLE, but barely."The Queen of Night's Aria" by Ian McDonald â€“ this story occurs on Mars but in an alternate reality universe; here the Red Planet not only harbours life but even an alien civilization â€“ more than one in factâ€¦ Human soldiers are engaged in a merciless war against indigenous Uliri on Mars and an opera singer comes from Earth to entertain the troops â€“ it will be one helluva tourâ€¦))) This is a rather rare thing in modern SF: extremely well written, with interesting characters, fast pace of action, great originality, tons of wit and humour, twists on every page, very well chosen title and finally a terrific punch line! A VERY GOOD STORY â€“ the BEST IN THIS COLLECTION! TO READ ABSOLUTELY!"Hard Stars" by Brendan DuBois â€“ in a near future technologically outmatched USA face a massive drone attack by China, Iran and North Korea, which makes it almost impossible to use any advanced technological device; some federal agents try to carry a mission when avoiding drone attacksâ€¦ This is more a techno-thriller than SF, but it is a well written story, with a very powerful message â€“ democracies cannot afford losing technological and military edge, because authoritarian regimes will never miss a chance to destroy themâ€¦ A VERY GOOD, quite scary story."The Promise of Space" by James Patrick Kelly â€“ short but powerful story about the dangers and hardships of space exploration and Mars colonization; nothing more will be said, as you deserve to discover the details by yourselfâ€¦ It's actually pretty depressing, but, albeit a little reluctantly, I must admit that this is a VERY GOOD story."Quicken" by Damien Broderick â€“ a new technology makes it possible to "rekindle" (resurrect) the dead â€“ but those who come back are not very well received by the rest of the societyâ€¦ That was a great idea, but to my great regret this long-winded 59 pages novella is a total disaster. It becomes quickly boring, then turns into weird and on most pages delivers an incredibly insulting rant against Christianity and Christians, who are more or less compared to Nazisâ€¦ And all that only in the first part of the story â€“ in the second one we go in a kind of freaky absurdity which one usually associates with high-fever delusionsâ€¦ It is also occasionally obscene and in some other moments GROSS. Bottom line, this is a HORRIBLY BAD THING, the WORST STORY IN THE COLLECTION. AVOID!-------------------------------CONCLUSION: an average collection, slightly better than the one from 2012 â€“ but reading it was not always easy or pleasant.

Great! My 8yo grandson loves this and figured out how to set it and the alarm right away. It is about 10" tall and substantial. It seems to work as expected so. I recommend it and would buy it again.

We bought this for our granddaughters 10th birthday, trip to Disneyland with brand new camera in hand. Lots of potential photos not taken due to this bad memory chip. Mr. Beams is well-made, I have several sets. I do not know what is in this that works, but it seems to help with getting to sleep and tastes very good. I recommend this, check that this goes with your meds, and I hope this helps you.

I am amazed at how easily this went on. It sucked down and there were only a few bubbles on the black areas, which were near the edge and were easily pushed out. These are great! Not bubble-free but pretty close. I only used one and it is on well.
Very nice and works well. It does smell very strong/bad so, minus a star. After a couple of days airing it out I will update if it does not go away. Otherwise it is very nice.

Very nice item, fits well and easily to the tank tube, centers well, and flushes completely. Recommended, will buy again, and I hope this helps. If there is any complaint it is difficult to connect to the handle, but all are.

Just too big and no replaceable band. I like that this counts floors. I wanted a tracker that I could wear all day and though I like Fitbits a lot, I really like my new Basis Peak. If I want floors I will wear my Fitbit Charge HR. I know a woman that will not wear this because of its size and weight.

These are very much appreciated by my dog (picky Havanese) and my son's (Australian Labradoodle), are easy to break apart to divvy-up or sprinkle over food, but they seem to be ground-up and reconstituted  (stated nowhere in the write-up).  They are NOT just cut-up 'heart Medallions', but evidently are processed, ground up, and squirted out as equally sized pieces that are much like the Turkey Giblet paddy's I can buy for my dog through Amazon.  I can recommend them, though, will likely NOT order more, and I hope this helps. But be aware these are not just beef heart's cut-up into filet type Medallion's. Perhaps there would be too many spaces (ventricles and atria's, but I would prefer that form. I feel it is misleading to call these beef heart medallions. I just received an email on hidden poisonous preservatives in most fish animal food and treats for dogs, and the fish food makers do not disclose it in the ingredients. I do not like the idea of selling these as beef heart medallions when they are likely fish food, a mixture of processed ingredients) and the beef gives it the coloring. It is much like calling hamburger ground beef paddy clumps 'medallion's'.

Almost exactly what I wanted. Easy to Use. My biggest desires were sleep, steps taken, floors climbed, and heart rate. The only con for me is no 'floors climbed'. but no big deal breaker. Sleep is much better, and the ease. I do recommend a screen protector, placed over the Gorilla Glass.
Excellent and all work as described. Great PRICE! I recommend.
I love the one that comes on the saw. I ordered an extra one but it was stolen. This cuts very fast and easy if you do not have a chainsaw handy or for liming. Very good customer care. Recommended.

This is a great product that seems to have finally caught up to the times. I returned the Surge and this with it. as it came with about 6 and my friend ha spares. I have several Fitbits and love them and The Surge but I have a Charge HR and it does most the Surge can but I cannot read it outside. My favorite for my needs is the Basis Peak and it costs about $50 less and I like it a lot better. For it, Amazon only sells 1 screen packs for about $16, from Germany (about a week to 2 wait). If you have extras that you like for a larger screen I recommend custom cutting it or spring for the one recommended. If you speak Deutsch well enough, fine, If you are not fluent they will communicate in English if asked. Highly recommended and I have only used one of each pack of 4-6 of these screen protectors; 1, or 2 max is all you need per unit. Recommended! To help protect your investment.

My picky 3yo Havanese does not like these, but my son's Australian Goldendoodle seems to eat anything: which can get him into trouble if it is chocolate, raisins/grapes, and many other foods we eat that get left laying around, or drop to the ground that are bad for dogs/pets. A little 2 yo girl told me their dog (a nice lab) was covered in body lotion, licked it off and died. No big deal, they just bought another pup and this little girl love to pick them up and give them a big squeeze! One almost died from eating 'Snarol Kills Snails'. Things like this happen often to very well loved pets. My son would rate this a 5, but me a 3. Contents look good

My first ten pack was mixed good and defective pads but  it was a manufacturing mistake, it happens. Great/fast/efficient/friendly customer service from Amazon AND Bear's Best Pet Products!! I was refunded right away and the company's follow-up was great and I was sent a free pack. It was all fine, my dog hit the Bull's-eye the first time but I think that was just luck as he has missed it completely all of the other times and seems to avoid the bull's-eye. A great idea but one cannot tell if the scent is on the bull...., but the pads absorbed well. I bought this to retrain my long Havanese (3yo) to hit the center and it is working well and is very absorbent. I recommend, will likely buy more, and hope this helps. It is a little small for my 23x23" holder. I think it is a great pad for puppy training and the replacement pads seem very absorbent.. This size pad is best for very small/short dogs. Mine is a small Havanese, but the breed is long. This is good otherwise for a Chihuahua, Maltese, minipoo, minpin, and pug breeds and the like
Great build and quality. Highly recommended. Stock up or get at least one as these are getting hard to find.

I returned this but have several as they are for all but the two oldest (no longer made) models (ultra and classic). This will work automatically with all current models (unlike the unit-specific charging cords for Zip, One, Flex, Charge, Charge HR, Surge). The charging cords are all different and the Zip requires a new battery occasionally as it is not rechargeable. I recommend having one of these on hand if you will be keeping your Fitbit as they do go bad.

Great stuff for stings and bites. It does not seem to treat or heal but at least it takes away the pain. I recommended and may buy more (maybe as gifts), and I hope this helps someone. Having it on hand is good.
Great gift idea. This is for my granddaughter's 10th birthday so, I stuck some money in there. I recommend, would buy again, and I hope this helps someone.
Very effective but heavy and has no door so it is a step-over. It did not work for us.
Very nice BUT you must step over the lower bar and it is a bit narrow, not practical for us. East to assemble and adjust.
No door, step-over type, and unstained. Unless you wear only pants or jeans this can be hard to step-over. It did not work for us.

Smooth on one side, a saw blade on the other, and one still needs a lot of strength, and the metal shards can be dangerous to consume or to try to reopen. I recommend the Hamilton-Beach electric (battery) or the Leitheit, not this one.
This works great and is a nice refill for their spray bottle. We recommend for mistakes and vomit.

I found this to be a very well made and functional scratching post. The large base makes the post extremely stable which is a good thing since our male cat is, to put it kindly, weight challenged. He's able to stand and fully stretched to scratch at the post and I don't have to worry about it falling over on him.It's a well made post, the jute is of good quality and I feel that it will last for quite some time. Do I think it's worth the $55 price tag?  Not really.  There are other equally well made sisal covered tall posts available for much less. I guess it's a matter of preference as to whether you want sisal or jute. All in all though it is a great scratching post which will have your cat ignoring the furniture and carpets which is the best feature of this post!

I LOVE this vacuum! My house is all hardwood with 12 area rugs of varying degrees of thickness throughout. There is no height setting on this vacuum...just Hi or Low, yet it picks up everything, whether it be bare floor, or the shaggiest carpet.The only thing missing from this vacuum is attachments, but I have another vac that has all the hose attachments, so this is not a problem for me. I take that one out once a month to get things like baseboards and ceiling fans.Overall, I absolutely recommend this vacuum, whether you have a cleaning business or you just want a powerful (yet still lightweight) vac for your own house. Definitely worth every penny!

We just moved into a house that has a pool, and I was just about to look for a waterproof case for my Kindle (Voyage) when this was offered to me...perfect timing!I LOVE this case. It's exactly what I needed. It keeps my Kindle 100% dry while floating in the pool. Plus it seems to be a pretty tough case, so I'm not worried about dropping it, or if it gets scratched up.It took me a few minutes to figure out how to open it, but once I did, it's no problem at all getting the Kindle in and out of the case.Overall, I absolutely recommend this case. It's perfect for pool or beach reading, and you don't need to worry at all about water splashes or sand getting into your device...this is definitely a secure case.

I get horrible motion sickness. As a passenger in a car, on a train, amusement rides...really in anything that I'm not driving myself. Between these and the motion sickness wrist bands, I'm doing awesome!Unlike regular Dramamine, this doesn't make me the least bit tired. I used it during a recent week long trip to Washington DC...I was on and off the Metro all day, and as long as I took this, I didn't get sick. One day I had forgotten to take it, and I nearly vomited on the train, so I made sure never to forget it again. Had to buy more while there since I used all I had on me.Overall, if you get any type of car/motion sickness, then I HIGHLY recommend this. You don't get sick, but you also don't get tired...it's a win/win!

We love this little skillet! We brought it camping with us in our RV, and it's perfect for breakfast. It is small, so you'll want to cook things one at a time (all your bacon first, the your eggs), but it heats up fast, and, most importantly, it heats evenly.It's non-stick, so it's super easy to clean (just wipe it down), and it stores easy. It's small, so it doesn't take up much space, especially if you're using it camping, where space is at a premium.Overall, we're very happy with this. Thanks Amazon!

Got these for my husband to keep in our camper and he's extremely pleased with them. They're extremely good quality, and reasonably priced. Good luck getting them out of the package as it took FOREVER, but overall, we are very happy with these. Great to have around the house/RV.

I LOVE this case! I saw it in Best Buy about a month ago, but was hesitant to spend that much on a case. I nearly fell off the couch when I saw it offered to me on the Vine!I have the Gold iPhone 6, and this case looks amazing on it. I get so many compliments. It a pretty heavy duty case with a clear bumper that goes around the edge of the phone, then the hard plastic gold portion that goes over it. If you're a fan of super slim type cases, then this is not for you. It does add a bit of bulk and weight to your phone, but I don't mind it at all.SO happy to have been offered this case. It's beautiful to look at and offers plenty of protection as well. Highly recommend!

These soaps are pretty good. Nothing amazing, but a few of them smell really good. A couple (mainly the Gourmet scents) were just to strong and overpowering for me.As for how it cleans, it's does what it's supposed to do! My hands smell nice and this doesn't dry them out like some soaps I've tried. Overall, I'd recommend most of these (the Cherry scent is just awful), and you do get a lot of soap for your money!

This has become a favorite spot of mine to curl up in and read a book!  It's big, but not too huge. My husband and I can fit on it and cozy up without getting uncomfortable!  Once I got it out of the packaging and "fluffed" it, it took a couple days for the foam to expand...it got bigger and bigger!  It's been really nice to have, and the kids absolutely love it. Highly recommend!

This is a great dutch oven. Lightweight, well made and it cooks evenly. I love the glass lid which allows me to see what I'm cooking...no chance of anything boiling over or being overcooked as long as you're keeping an eye on it. And it's nice that it easily goes from stovetop to oven.It heats up pretty quickly and maintains a consistent temperature. Clean up was easy, but it should be noted that it is hand wash only which isn't a problem for me because I normally hand wash larger items like this because they take up too much room in the dishwasher. You also have to be careful with the glass lid. Just make sure it doesn't come into contact with a cool or wet surface when it's hot or it could break.It's lightweight which is a bonus over a heavy cast iron dutch oven, so getting it in and out of the oven doesn't require a lot of effort. I would definitely recommend this dutch oven...it's attractive, functional and a great price.

I love this French Press. My friends husband makes and grounds his own coffee. I go through about a bag a week, and was using a small single-serving press. It was functional for me, but a pain when I wanted to make more than one cup.This press holds 34 oz and even if your brewing that much just for yourself, the coffee left in the press stays hot for quite awhile. It's easy to clean and is dishwasher safe, so you can always throw it in there (though I prefer to hand wash mine).I absolutely recommend this product. It's not only functional, but it's also beautiful to look at. I keep it on my kitchen counter so I can always see it!

This dress fit like it was MADE for me, and that NEVER happens! I'm 5'4" and weigh 117. I ordered the Small and it was perfect. The length was just right, it didn't drag on the floor, but lightly brushed it, so I never felt like I was going to trip over it or step on it.Of all the dresses I've worn to military balls over the years, this was by FAR the most comfortable. I could breath and move easily the whole night and got numerous compliments. You absolutely can NOT beat this price. People were shocked when I told them what I paid! So, so happy with this purchase!

The Philips Wake-up Light is a great productâ€¦. if you are the only one getting up or everyone gets up at the same time, but what a way to wake up.  I have been using this alarm clock for the last month now since I am on travel and I absolutely love it.  It starts to turn on dimly about 30 minutes prior to the alarm setting then at the alarm time it is fully on when the radio comes on.  I have not had the â€œscareâ€ of a regular alarm clock with this at all and I have no problem getting up in the morning no matter how little sleep I got.  I did not set it this morning on purpose, and I over slept by hitting the snooze button on my regular alarm clock.Like I said though, this is great if you donâ€™t mind waking everyone up.  The light is very bright.  My wife visited last week and although she said it is a great alarm clock, it will brighten the entire room.  The brightness is adjustable but I found I need it at full otherwise it doesn't work for me.

I am a Star Wars fanatic, and my 7 year old son is as well. As soon as I saw this I knew he needed it. We got it yesterday and absolutely love it. Its very well made and has a lightness to it that, while it will keep him warm, he won't sweat to death while he sleeps. I would absolutely recommend this to any little Star Wars fan! Oh, and it's reversible, so if your child gets tired of one side, he can flip it over to have a completely different look!
Great bag, works exactly as I need it to! I love the design and have gotten a bunch of compliments on it. No complaints!

Opal is my birthstone, so I jumped on this when it was offered. Is it a real Opal? Of course not...not at this price. Are the diamonds CZ? You betcha'...don't care. It's still a really pretty piece of jewelry. I was a little surprised at the size...it's much smaller than I expected (the listing photo makes it look much larger), however the smaller than expected size is ok...it's got a delicate look to it, and I'm very happy with it.If you're looking for real, then move on. If you want a pretty Opal and diamond 'look' that is affordable, then this is for you.

This was a very rare DNF for me. I got through about 70% and finally threw in the towel. I went to the Red Queen wiki page to see how it ended, and just as I thought, I saw the deception and the 'plot twist' from a mile away. The second you see what type of person Queen Elarais, and then find out that Cal is her stepson and Maven is her real son (this is not a spoiler, it's introduced as soon as you meet them), then you already know what's going to happen.I found the characters to be extremely wooden and stereotypical. The poor Red girl trying to fit into the Silver Elite that she suddenly find herself apart of...the rough boy/love interest from her village who always seems to be angry...the prince who's been trained his whole life to become the next king (another love interest)...the 'spare' who never seems to live up to his perfect big brother (yet ANOTHER love interest)...the Silver Elite bitch who can can control metal...and the Evil Queen with an agenda.***Snooze***I've read it all before, and done better. I gave it two stars because I think YA's may enjoy this, and I DID get through 70%, but still...I'm being generous. I really had high hopes for this book, but it was just a disappointment all around

I got this case to protect my new iPad and allow me to type a little easier.  It served both purposes.  The protection this case provides is very good and I had no problems while traveling through multiple airports and even dropped it a couple times.  The keyboard is very useful and works like a normal keyboard as long as the bluetooth is activated.  When I shifted to airplane mode, and lost the Bluetooth connection and it no longer served a purpose except to protect my iPad.  Overall, I would recommend this product to anyone looking for good protection from a case that also provides a keyboard.  There are better cases for protection but not with keyboards.  Also, there are better keyboards but not with the protection this case provides.  This is the best of both worlds I have found so far.

I love this vacuum! It has awesome suction and for how big and bulky it is, it's incredibly light! There are a couple minor annoyances (hence the 4 stars), but they're easy to live with.The cord holder is in an awkward place. The bottom of the hose is so close to the bottom rung of the cord holder that it can be a pain to wrap up the cord. I find that if I remove the canister and pull the hose away, it makes it much easier to wrap up, then just replace the canister when it's done. Also, the attachments (mainly the skinny attachment) never stays in place and always fall off. I just take it off and set it on the coffee table until I'm done vacuuming, then replace it when I store it.Overall though, this machine is awesome. I love how easy it is to remove the canister for cleaning hard to reach areas (behind the couch, ceiling fans), and the filter is washable and reusable...no need to purchase replacement anything for this vacuum. I live in a super-split level with three flight of stairs (about 6-7 stairs per flight) and this is very light to carry up and down to each floor...a major plus for me. Overall, I absolutely recommend this vacuum. I have both hardwood and carpet, and this vacuum does a great job at cleaning both. Very happy with this item.

If you're new to the iPhone (or even if you think you're a pro), this book has some great tips and is super easy to follow. There's a lot to read through in this book, and much of it is basic knowledge (helpful for the older generation who may not be able to 'jump right in' as quickly as the younger folks), but I'd bet almost anyone that's there's some useful information in here for all iPhone users...even those who think they know it all.As other reviewers have mentioned, the Index is off, and this is unfortunate as it's a very important part of any reference book, but I felt the usefulness of the book outweighed the this one oversight. Overall, a very handy book, and one I absolutely recommend for people looking to learn about everything their iPhone's can do.

Not a bad story. Was a bit basic in it's storytelling...almost like a friend was re-hashing a ghost story to you, but it wasn't terrible. I agree with everyone who says this book needs an editor, cause it absolutely does. I read a bunch of the reviews before starting this though, so I was expecting it...I'm not deducting any stars based on the editing.Overall, a decent little story. Loved the setting and the majority of the main characters (though Sweetie Pie was really starting to irritate me. Who lets their CAT outside for a walk numerous times a day and then puts her in the car to go visit friends?? It was weird. I don't get why the author didn't just make her a dog). Some were a bit underdeveloped...I would have loved to known more about Billy Jack, but it is what it is. I wouldn't pay money for this, but I got it free with Kindle Unlimited, so it wasn't all bad.

I have a few Fintie cases and I've always been very happy with their quality. I have a super slim Fintie case for my Kindle Voyage, but wanted something with a little more protection, so I ordered this. I am extremely happy with it. It has the auto-awake feature that I love, and it's protective without being bulky.I do want to mention though, the case I received is a little different than what I ordered. I purchased the black and white damask. The stock photo shows the inside of the case, the part that your kindle slides into, as having the same damask design as the outside...it does not. Mine is black on the inside. This actually works great for me as I was concerned the damask pattern on the inside would be distracting while reading. I've included some photos so you can see what I mean.Overall, I'm extremely happy with this purchase. This case offers great protection, is stylish and had an awesome price tag. Can't beat that!

Ehhh. These were ok, certainly nothing spectacular. In fact, most of these ended up in the trash. I opened the bag and tried the Strawberry Creme and the Mint. They were ok...a little dense for my liking. I prefer truffles to be soft on the inside. The Coconut was absolutely vile. It tasted like plastic. I actually spit it out into the garbage can.These sat in a dish on the kitchen counter for about 2 weeks before I finally tossed them. No one else in the house cared to eat them, so away they went. If you want to give these as a gift, I suppose they would do, but they're really no better than the chocolate gift bags you can get at your local drug store. I wouldn't go out of my way for these.

This is a fun game. We played it on Christmas Day and everyone really enjoyed it. The more cards you have out, the harder it gets. The only reason I'm giving the game 3 stars is because the size of the cards is absolutely ridiculous. There is no reason they needed to make  them so tiny. Reading them is tough, especially for older people who may have poor eyesight...my mother played one game then dropped out because it was difficult for her to read the cards, especially if you're sitting around a table and the cards are in the middle.Overall, really cool game, but what were they thinking making the cards so minuscule??

I love these cloths! I'm terrible about remembering to take my makeup off every night, and 9 times out of 10 I sleep with it on. These cloths are super easy and gentle on the face. One cloth takes off all my makeup...foundation and mascara. They've been 'Currently Unavailable' for awhile now, but I really hope Amazon gets more in because I'll absolutely start purchasing them on a regular basis. I use one every night before bed now!

This is an awesome toothbrush! My 6 years old son loves using it. The little ding lets him know when to move the brush to a new spot, and the timer ensures that he always brushes long enough. We still help him brush, just to make sure he's getting all his teeth, but this is one powerful little toothbrush. Absolutely recommend this if you're interested. It's pretty pricey for a kids toothbrush, but Sonicare is definitely a brand you can trust. My husband's been using a Sonicare brush for years and has never had an issue with it.

I tried, I really, really did. There was just so much STUFF going on that most of the time I had no idea what was happening or where Steptember even was. There was so much detail that the story itself started to get lost (as least for me).The book is really well written, and the author has an amazing imagination, but this is a tough book to get through. Not only do you have to pay super close attention to all the minute details, but her vocabulary is way beyond that of the recommended age group (ages 10-14). I can't remember the last time I used the dictionary feature on my Kindle so much. While a hearty vocabulary is always good, it just seemed unnecessary and a bit pretentious here.I wish I could have loved this book as much as most people seem to, but it just wasn't for me. Maybe my heart wasn't in it as I read, or I was distracted, but either way, I never looked forward to picking this up. By about 30% into it, it started feeling like a chore to read it.

I used this cream for just under three weeks and don't notice any difference in my skin. The smell is bad, but not so terrible that I couldn't use it. My skin feels soft, but I haven't noticed a disappearance of any fine lines...especially around my eyes. There are plenty of other facial creams out there that can give you soft skin, and are a fraction of the cost of this stuff. I definitely wouldn't pay this price for what this cream does.

Meh. This book was ok, but I certainly didn't love it. I spent the majority of it thinking how incredibly unbelievable it was. ALL these people (Myra, Heather, Fish, Robbie, Karen, etc.) didn't catch on to the fact that Jenny wasn't Jessie? The noticeably different shoe size, the completely different personality, the vague look that would cross her face whenever anyone mentioned anything about the past? Nope. Sorry...not buying it.Don't get me wrong, this is a cute, well written book, and if you're able to suspend all belief and read it as something to take up a lazy Sunday, then you'll enjoy it. I just couldn't get over the unrealistic (and often times creepy) scenarios. Jenny may have convinced herself that she meant well, but she was still a stranger staying in Myra's house...sleeping with a man who thought she was another woman. Sorry...that's not funny or charming...its sad and creepy.

I flew through this book. Such a good (and original) story. It made me take a good hard look at my own marriage and, while mine is in a very good place right now, you still tend to take things for granted...especially after 13 years. It's nice to remember the little things that made you fall in love with your significant other in the first place.I do think Grandma had a point though. Taking a whole year off from one another was a little overkill, but I suppose it got the job done. The ending is predictable, and I knew almost from the very beginning what was going to happen, but it was ok...I enjoyed it nonetheless. Next up ...'Forever Interrupted'!

My 6 year old son loves this toy! He's been using Air Hunterz bow and arrows for a while now. He lost all the arrows to his last set, so he was thrilled when this arrived. We hung the target up on a tree in the back yard and he'll spend a good hour or so just practicing shooting. The arrows always suction to the target (when he hits it) and pop off easily.My only issue was the way this was packaged...the target, bow and all the arrows were just thrown in an Amazon box...no packaging, no containment. It looked like someone just threw a used toy in a box and shipped it. Not sure what that's all about, but hopefully it was just a Vine thing and not that way for everyone.

This is a beautiful, sleek, modern faucet. It replaced an older 2 handle faucet and having the single handle is a great improvement. The pull out sprayer is convenient as is the flow to spray button which allows you to go from having a normal water flow coning directly from the faucet to a spray. The faucet is angled rather than pointing straight down which does give you more versatility as you move the faucet around. It was relatively easy to install, no need to call a plumber.One thing to take notice of is that it's an "all in one" design.  So if you have a sink with an older faucet you'll either have to replace the entire sink or buy a few plugs to cover the holes left by the handles of an older faucet.  What we did was cover one hole and added a built-in dish soap dispenser where the other hole was located...handy!Having said all that, do I like the faucet?  Yes, very much.  Do I love it?  Not for the price!

This was my first DNF of the year. I tried to get into this book...made it about 45% of the way through before I finally gave up. The author attempts to be witty and funny, and seems like he's trying to take after the likes of Christopher Moore and Carl Hiaasen, but he falls flat (at least he did for me).This isn't a terrible book, and I don't discourage anyone from reading it (everyone has a different sense of humor), but I found it to be tedious. I considered trudging through it just to be able to say I finished it, but life's to short to read books you don't like.

This is a great product for your little baseball player! I got this for my friends sons to use. Two of her three boys play baseball and they absolutely loved this. Set up was simple, her oldest boy (12 yrs old) out it together himself, and within 15 minutes they were practicing different ball heights.This is sturdy, well made, and simple for the kids to adjust the height cones on their own. Definitely recommend this as an extremely useful at-home practice tool for your Little Leaguer.

I LOVED this book! I read and loved 'The Husband's Secret' as well, but I think I liked this book just a little bit better!I won't go into detail re-hashing this story since so many other reviewers have already done so, but I absolutely recommend this. While there are just a few slow-ish sections, the majority of this book is very hard to put down. I did NOT see the little twist at the end, and was very pleased with the ending.I have since added all of Ms. Moriarty's other books to by to-be-read list, and can't WAIT to see the movie version of this book. I found out about half-way through it that it was going to be a movie starring Nicole Kidman (yuck) and Reese Witherspoon...awesome!

Well, aside from the ending (which was just odd and felt incredibly rushed), I really liked this book! I'm not a religious person (in fact, I usually avoid ALL religious crap), but I didn't feel like this book was jamming it down my throat.The story was told at a great pace and the writing was good! I found myself being disappointed whenever I had to put this down and really excited to pick it back up. Which virgin would bear the child of Satan, and which would bear the Savior?As I said, the ending was a bit out of place and rushed when compared to the rest of the novel, and there was a bizarre 'Prologue' at the end of the book that COMPLETELY confused me. I still have no idea what purpose it served as (at least to me) it had nothing to do with the book. In fact, I thought it was a preview of another James Patterson book (you know how authors will sometimes include a few chapters of another book at the end of one?) but it wasn't. Very strange.Anyway, overall it was a good story and it kept me coming back...maybe more of a 3 1/2 star book, but I'll round up.

Got this club for my husband and he really liked it. He said it has a nice feel and weight to it. I'm not a golfer myself, but he seems pretty happy with it. It's a good price and (according to him) a good brand. He recommends this for beginner golfers or for those who golf irregularly.

My cat did not take kindly to having his litter changed. I know he's a bit finicky, so I tried mixing this in with his current litter, and he pee'd in my foyer. I added more of his regular litter and, while he DID use it, I could tell he didn't like it.Another problem for me was scooping. The pellets are so big that when I would go to scoop his box, my scoop was filled with all the pellets, even if they weren't soiled! This seems like a huge waste of perfectly good litter. I don't want to play around in the litter box making sure I get ONLY the soiled litter on my scoop...I scoop, I shake, I discard. The end.My cat was happy though cause after a few days of cleaning his box, I had pretty much scooped out all the pellets and he was back to just his regular litter. While I would love to have less dust and littler on the floor, the high cost of this just isn't worth it to me. That and the cat seriously hated it. The unused portion of my box went into the trash

Great toy gun, but be careful cause it's definitely got some power behind it. The bullets come out FAST, and if you're aiming at someone (say a younger sibling), it could take them by surprise.The wall target is a little chintzy, but the bullets absolutely stick to them! The tips are this weird stretchy, rubbery material that can sometimes be difficult to pull off the target. My son had some trouble getting a few off, but aside from that, he really liked this.Aiming can take a little getting used to since there's no traditional trigger, there's a handle that you pull pack. My son kept shooting way too high at first cause when he would pull the lever, his other hand would aim the gun up toward the ceiling. After a little practice he got the hang of it.Overall, great toy. Not sure how long the target is going to last, it's already started bending and becoming more and more disfigured each time we pull the bullets off, but for now, he's happy with this.

Love its printer! Set up was simple (I was able to do it myself in about 20 minutes, and I'm am by no means a 'techie'). Wi-Fi works great and I get clean pages printed out easily from my laptop. Printing is fast and the black ink is sharp. It is a pretty hefty printer size-wise, but I have it in a location where it's hardly seen. Not sure how long the ink lasts, but I've been printing on it regularly for over a month now and it's still going!

I'm fairly new to the world of flat irons. Prior to receiving this I was using a $40 iron I purchased at Walmart. I don't use one often as I feel they're very damaging, but that one seemed to do what it needed to do just fine.This flat iron feels very sturdy and well made (in fact, it's pretty heavy). It heats up very quickly and will shut itself off should you forget to (I don't know after how much time though...never really paid attention). My issue with it is that it takes numerous passes over the same strands of hair to get them perfectly flat. It goes up to 395 degrees, and there's a lot of steam coming off my hair, but it's not flattening it as quickly as my other iron did. I don't know anything about 'Nanoe Technology', but I'm not really sure it does anything. This $140+ flat iron (for me at least) doesn't do anything any better or more efficiently than my $40 flat iron. If I had paid for this item, I would absolutely return it and stick with my cheaper model.

Not quite as good as the first 2, but still funny. I thought the chapter where the twins end up in Brooklyn and meet Adam the author was a bit confusing and unnecessary. I did NOT like the kids leaving the fairy tale world and bring brought into our world...it really cheapened the story for me.The whole point of fairy tales is to escape to another time and place. To read about far away characters in far away places having amazing and fantastical adventures. Having Jorinda and Joringle wander into 21st century New York City is just wrong. It took me a few chapters to shake my head of that and return to the Marchenwald. I kind of felt like I'd been awakened from a really great dream, then tried to go back to sleep and recapture some if it's magic. Unfortunately it just wasn't the same for me after that.Overall though, this was a highly entertaining series. I'm really glad I found this little trio of books. They're certainly dark, and not at all for children, but they're fun as well. A little misstep with this last book (in my opinion), but a great collection of stories as a whole.

I really liked this! I was afraid it was gonna be cheesy and childish, but it's actually really good! It's not something that should be read to children under 10 (as the author mentions numerous times throughout the book), but it's certainly a book that grown-ups who love their Grimm stories can get into! Glad I gave it a shot...getting ready to start book 2 in the series!

Just as good as the first one! Where 'A Tale Dark and Grimm' focused on the adventures of Hansel and Gretel, 'In a Glass Grimmly' follows the travels of cousins Jack and Jill. While Mr. Gidwitz sticks to the original fairy tales a little less in this book, his stories are still just as good! He draws inspiration from many different places, but the gist of each chapter is made up of his own warped ideas (seriously...the giant story? Bleck!).If you like re-imagined dark fairy tales, then this is definitely the series for you. As soon as I finished this book I purchased and downloaded the final book to this series, 'The Grimm Conclusion'. So glad I stumbled on these books...they've been a fun way to pass a few hours.

My hair dresser showed me this tool last time I went in for a cut. I have pretty straight hair, but the underneath part of my hair is EXTREMELY curly. Just in one spot though (happened after I got pregnant years ago and ever went back). It's very, very difficult to get this part of my hair perfectly straight since it's so curly.Using this comb along with my flat iron has been fantastic. It took a little getting used to, but I quickly got the hang of it. The wand end is great for picking up sections of hair and running the straightener over without having to use your hands, and the comb helps pull the hair straight for the flat iron to go over.Overall, this was an awesome purchase. I'm not a fan of hair 'gadgets', and have used the same products and styling tools for years and years, but this was one new 'gadget' that I absolutely needed. I use it every time I wash and straighten my hair...now that I have it, I couldn't live without it!

I looked everywhere for these out in town...no one carries them for children. My son (6) has seasonal allergies and gets very stuffy at night when he lays down. We have a humidifier in his room, but it only helps a little. These have been wonderful.At first I wasn't convinced that these would stay on. The first one I applied looked like it was coming up at the ends. I left it on for about 5 minutes but thought it was coming off. I went to pull it off and realized that no, it was in fact on there securely...it just LOOKED like it was popping up at each end. I applied a fresh one and we haven't had any issues with them in the week we've been using them. Each morning they're still firmly in place and my son says they help a LOT with allowing him to breath through his nose at night.So glad I was able to find these at Amazon, and for such a great price. I much prefer putting one of these on my son each nice than giving him allergy medicine. I'm not against medicine, but it's nice to have a drug-free solution to sleeping comfortably with seasonal allergies. I use the adult size myself in the spring and fall and they're amazing. Love these!

I got this bag in all black for a recent event. I was staying overnight at the hotel where the event was taking place and needed just a small bag to hold enough for an overnight stay. This bag was perfect. It will easily hold enough clothes for 2-3 days, along with toiletries. Now, if you need to pack a bunch of large items, like a hair dryer, curling iron or hair straighter, two pairs of shoes and a ton of products, then no, look for something bigger. I'm a pretty low-maintenance gal though, so this had more than enough room for everything I needed to bring. Plus it's well made, so I wasn't worried about it falling apart at all. Overall, great purchase...very happy with this!

I was SOOOOO excited to see these as I love Starbursts (especially the pink and red), but these were pretty bad. They taste like little chewy squares of plastic. Seriously, no matter what flavor, it tastes like your chewing flavored plastic. They don't come close to the juicy, super flavorful originals. I'll gladly deal with a little wrapper to get the Starbursts that I love. Very disappointed by these :(

My cat was sloshing all the water out of his water bowl every single night. I tried adding just a teeny bit of water to the bowl, but it didn't matter...out it went. I tried using deeper and bigger bowls, but nothing worked. This bowl has been awesome.The first couple mornings I found a little water on the table (his food is in our spare room on an end table so the dog doesn't eat it), which was clearly from him using his paw to get it out, but after a few days this stopped. He's never knocked it over (I doubt he even can) but he still gets water all night. This was exactly what I was looking for!

I used this case for 2 days before removing it and stuffing it in a drawer. Set-up was simple and it worked perfectly fine, but it made things more difficult.First, once you set this up, the iPhone keyboard will no longer come up...EVER. So for simple tasks, like entering something in to my calendar, I had to tilt the screen and open this up. I use symbols in front of all my calendar events so I can easily identify things at a glance (a bowling ball and pins in front of Sunday Bowling, a needle icon in front of the days I have to take my shots, a money bag on 'pay rent' days, etc), but since they symbols are part of the iPhone keyboard, I could no longer access them.Also, you lose things you didn't even realize you used all the time....double-tap the iPhone space bar to add a period, automatic capitalization of the first letter of a sentence, even auto-correct for spelling goes away! Overall, everything I was losing just wasn't worth keeping this case on. I had planned to return it, but for what it would cost to ship it back, it just wasn't worth it, so into the drawer it went.

I was sent this thermos to test and evaluate. The following is my unbiased review based on testing the product.The first thing that I noted is the thermos has a tiny cup on the lid. It is something fairly useless due to it being so very small. It only holds a few ounces. It is also plastic and the handle broke off after I dropped the thermos. Not a big deal, and the slim line of the thermos means that the cup has to be small in order to fit. Just be aware that the cup is tea cup sized.The box is covered in Asian writing, the only part in English is "Stainless Steel Thermos". Everything else is not readable. If that is going to bother you, skip this. (Not sure why it would as the thermos works as it should.)The thermos was tested with hot coffee. The coffee stayed hot for 4 hours and then the heat began to drop off after that. The lid has a flip top that I found a bit hard to drink from, it seems designed for pouring the liquid into a cup vs. drinking directly from it.The mouth is a narrow mouth, so do not expect to be able to use this for stews or to be able to fit a spoon inside to eat. This is better suited for use with liquids. It is hard to clean without a bottle brush, so be sure you have a bottle brush handy when the thermos arrives. This will help to keep it squeaky clean and remove coffee or tea stains from the inside easily.I am guessing this is not dishwasher safe, but the narrow mouth of the bottle would make it hard to get clean in a dishwasher, so that is probably for the best.The biggest flaw I found with it was the enamel like paint on the bottle is smudged in one spot and the stainless shows through. Quality control checks appear to have missed this one.

I received this set of blackhead remover tools for free. The following is my unbiased review based on product testing over the course of a few weeks.These tools are an inexpensive but useful set. The case is cute and well made. The zipper functions without sticking or jamming on fabric or the stitches.Inside, the tools are durable. They are not flimsy nor easily broken. I am finding them to be of good quality. I rinsed one and left it to dry to test if it would rust. It didn't. That is important as I need to be able to clean these after use. There are no sharp edge and the tips are fashioned just thick enough to where my skin is not being cut, bruised or otherwise damaged. Blackheads and pimples are gently removed with a small amount of pressure using these.The tools are very effective at removing blackheads. There is a slight learning curve if someone has never used these before, do a search for how to use them, and find some good tips.This is a nice set. I already had two of my Aunts try to talk me out of the set. I had to nearly pry it out of one Aunt's hands, she was insisting that she needed it. I suggested that she was welcome to buy her own set.I would recommend this product to others.

I received this item for free from the seller. The following is my unbiased review based on product testing.This cute sofa arrived and I blew it up. It takes a very long time to blow up using breath. It was far easier after I switched to the pump for the air mattress. (What possessed me to try blowing it up by mouth??? Duh.)This tiny chair is adorable. It is toddler sized. The face is cute, it looks exactly like the picture. I found no leaks, and the air holes are the type that have a blocker piece of plastic so that all the air you blew in does not escape while you are taking another breath.The chair does smell of plastic as expected, but airing it out for a few days has helped. (It arrived Friday. By Monday, much of the strong odor had disappeared. There are no flaws that I can find other than it takes a lot of air to blow this up. Don't attempt if you have recently been ill or are short of breath. This took around 20 minutes to blow up using breath. 3 minutes to blow up using the electric pump. If you have a pump, use it and save yourself some time.

I was offered this bottle for free to evaluate and test it out. This is my honest review.I am going to start by saying I try to review objectively. I don't care if I was given an item for free or if I paid full price. I base my review on if I feel the item works as promised, how easy it is to use, etc... I want to be sure that someone reads my review, they get an honest look at the pros (if there are any) and the cons so they can judge for themselves if they wish to spend their money. I do take into account if the item is a $5 dollar store type of product and mention that it will "do the job if you just need cheap", but I also take into account if it doesn't even do that.This bottle is interesting. I didn't look at the blender ball before I ordered it. I was expecting a little metal coil thingie that most shaker bottles have now. This has a plastic ball that has little plastic spikes. My "skeptical" side kicked into high gear upon seeing that. I washed the bottle carefully, allowed it to dry and put it into product testing.The first thing I did was make sure to add gooey stuff to my bottle. Chia seeds, honey, chopped blueberries and then in a snarky mode, as it shows oatmeal on the tag, I tossed in some for good measure. My plan was to prove that after one use that silly looking ball was going to be cemented with food that would need dynamite to blast it off.To my surprise... The ball mixed this concoction with my juice nicely. Washing it up was easy. The few bits of seeds and oatmeal that remained came off with a bottle brush. I was happy to have been proven wrong. This ball, unlike those flexi spring things actually mixes thicker drinks. It won't grind up fruit for smoothies, but it will mix those premade smoothies with other stuff added in! (Yes I tried it!)On to what is great about this bottle. There are two small snack containers included. One fits inside the bottle. I would not leave it there when it was full of a drink because the bottom of it would be coated with liquid. Either one snaps onto the bottom of the bottle for transport. I have never had a bottle that did this before, but it is a good idea. One option for the inner container is to fill the bottle with veggie pieces, then use the container for dip or cheese and nuts. Or even ice.The bottle washes up easily. It is dishwasher safe. It says it is microwave safe. It is freezer safe. BPA free too. All these are bonus points. I do not like the fact that is not at least opaque but we can't have everything!I would recommend this bottle to anyone who needs a multi-use bottle. If you are looking for just a basic bottle without the extra containers/freezer/microwave safe functions, there are other slightly less expensive bottles out there, but this bottle is a good one. It is very well made. It passes the drop test without breaking or the lid popping open. (Yes, I test that stuff because I have had bottle failures when dropped. I drop stuff, it's a fact of my life. I am that person going to die from choking on food after tripping over the cat.)

I was sent this set of headphones to test and review. The following is my review based on testing the product. I hope that the honest people will vote this as being helpful, the unscrupulous people are going to vote it unhelpful to hide it.I wanted to like this set of headphones. I really wanted to like them. If I grade them only on the look, the product packaging and the excellent directions, they would get a 5 star review. I was excited to try this great looking set of headphones.The reason they are getting two stars is the headphones stutter. Not once or twice for a few seconds per hour, the set sent to me stutters and cuts out more than it is smooth. I wore them on a 15 minute walk to the corner market and back, and couldn't wait to turn them off. I only caught half of the story because it  was tting in d o t lik this. (Oh, you can't read that? Well, that was how my audio book sounded! That should read it was cutting in and out like this.) There were a few smooth patches, but testing while sitting still, walking, having the phone sitting right against them, all of it, it stuttered and cut out.I didn't test the bass. I did test the controls which are great. The noise canceling is good. I really, really, REALLY love the controls buttons that are easy to find and use. The overall fit was good, there was a slight bit of slippage from my ears but I changed to the alternate set of ear pieces sent and they fit excellently after that.
